Title:  
Title:  AUTHOR'S PREFACE
Title:  
Title:  In which it is proved that, notwithstanding their names' ending
Title:  in OS and IS, the heroes of the story which we are about to have
Title:  the honor to relate to our readers have nothing mythological
Title:  about them.
Title:  
Title:  A short time ago, while making researches in the Royal Library
Title:  for my History of Louis XIV, I stumbled by chance upon the
Title:  Memoirs of M. d'Artagnan, printed--as were most of the works of
Title:  that period, in which authors could not tell the truth without
Title:  the risk of a residence, more or less long, in the Bastille--at
Title:  Amsterdam, by Pierre Rouge.  The title attracted me; I took them
Title:  home with me, with the permission of the guardian, and devoured
Title:  them.
Title:  
Title:  It is not my intention here to enter into an analysis of this
Title:  curious work; and I shall satisfy myself with referring such of
Title:  my readers as appreciate the pictures of the period to its pages.
Title:  They will therein find portraits penciled by the hand of a
Title:  master; and although these squibs may be, for the most part,
Title:  traced upon the doors of barracks and the walls of cabarets, they
Title:  will not find the likenesses of Louis XIII, Anne of Austria,
Title:  Richelieu, Mazarin, and the courtiers of the period, less
Title:  faithful than in the history of M. Anquetil.
Title:  
Title:  But, it is well known, what strikes the capricious mind of the
Title:  poet is not always what affects the mass of readers.  Now, while
Title:  admiring, as others doubtless will admire, the details we have to
Title:  relate, our main preoccupation concerned a matter to which no one
Title:  before ourselves had given a thought.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan relates that on his first visit to M. de Treville,
Title:  captain of the king's Musketeers, he met in the antechamber three
Title:  young men, serving in the illustrious corps into which he was
Title:  soliciting the honor of being received, bearing the names of
Title:  Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  We must confess these three strange names struck us; and it
Title:  immediately occurred to us that they were but pseudonyms, under
Title:  which d'Artagnan had disguised names perhaps illustrious, or else
Title:  that the bearers of these borrowed names had themselves chosen
Title:  them on the day in which, from caprice, discontent, or want of
Title:  fortune, they had donned the simple Musketeer's uniform.
Title:  
Title:  From the moment we had no rest till we could find some trace in
Title:  contemporary works of these extraordinary names which had so
Title:  strongly awakened our curiosity.
Title:  
Title:  The catalogue alone of the books we read with this object would
Title:  fill a whole chapter, which, although it might be very
Title:  instructive, would certainly afford our readers but little
Title:  amusement.  It will suffice, then, to tell them that at the
Title:  moment at which, discouraged by so many fruitless investigations,
Title:  we were about to abandon our search, we at length found, guided
Title:  by the counsels of our illustrious friend Paulin Paris, a
Title:  manuscript in folio, endorsed 4772 or 4773, we do not recollect
Title:  which, having for title, "Memoirs of the Comte de la Fere,
Title:  Touching Some Events Which Passed in France Toward the End of the
Title:  Reign of King Louis XIII and the Commencement of the Reign of
Title:  King Louis XIV."
Title:  
Title:  It may be easily imagined how great was our joy when, in turning
Title:  over this manuscript, our last hope, we found at the twentieth
Title:  page the name of Athos, at the twenty-seventh the name of
Title:  Porthos, and at the thirty-first the name of Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  The discovery of a completely unknown manuscript at a period in
Title:  which historical science is carried to such a high degree
Title:  appeared almost miraculous.  We hastened, therefore, to obtain
Title:  permission to print it, with the view of presenting ourselves
Title:  someday with the pack of others at the doors of the Academie des
Title:  Inscriptions et Belles Lettres, if we should not succeed--a very
Title:  probable thing, by the by--in gaining admission to the Academie
Title:  Francaise with our own proper pack.  This permission, we feel
Title:  bound to say, was graciously granted; which compels us here to
Title:  give a public contradiction to the slanderers who pretend that we
Title:  live under a government but moderately indulgent to men of
Title:  letters.
Title:  
Title:  Now, this is the first part of this precious manuscript which we
Title:  offer to our readers, restoring it to the title which belongs to
Title:  it, and entering into an engagement that if (of which we have no
Title:  doubt) this first part should obtain the success it merits, we
Title:  will publish the second immediately.
Title:  
Title:  In the meanwhile, as the godfather is a second father, we beg the
Title:  reader to lay to our account, and not to that of the Comte de la
Title:  Fere, the pleasure or the ENNUI he may experience.
Title:  
Title:  This being understood, let us proceed with our history.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  1  THE THREE PRESENTS OF D'ARTAGNAN THE ELDER
Title:  
Title:  On the first Monday of the month of April, 1625, the market town
Title:  of Meung, in which the author of ROMANCE OF THE ROSE was born,
Title:  appeared to be in as perfect a state of revolution as if the
Title:  Huguenots had just made a second La Rochelle of it.  Many
Title:  citizens, seeing the women flying toward the High Street, leaving
Title:  their children crying at the open doors, hastened to don the
Title:  cuirass, and supporting their somewhat uncertain courage with a
Title:  musket or a partisan, directed their steps toward the hostelry of
Title:  the Jolly Miller, before which was gathered, increasing every
Title:  minute, a compact group, vociferous and full of curiosity.
Title:  
Title:  In those times panics were common, and few days passed without
Title:  some city or other registering in its archives an event of this
Title:  kind.  There were nobles, who made war against each other; there
Title:  was the king, who made war against the cardinal; there was Spain,
Title:  which made war against the king.  Then, in addition to these
Title:  concealed or public, secret or open wars, there were robbers,
Title:  mendicants, Huguenots, wolves, and scoundrels, who made war upon
Title:  everybody.  The citizens always took up arms readily against
Title:  thieves, wolves or scoundrels, often against nobles or Huguenots,
Title:  sometimes against the king, but never against cardinal or Spain.
Title:  It resulted, then, from this habit that on the said first Monday
Title:  of April, 1625, the citizens, on hearing the clamor, and seeing
Title:  neither the red-and-yellow standard nor the livery of the Duc de
Title:  Richelieu, rushed toward the hostel of the Jolly Miller.  When
Title:  arrived there, the cause of the hubbub was apparent to all.
Title:  
Title:  A young man--we can sketch his portrait at a dash.  Imagine to
Title:  yourself a Don Quixote of eighteen; a Don Quixote without his
Title:  corselet, without his coat of mail, without his cuisses; a Don
Title:  Quixote clothed in a woolen doublet, the blue color of which had
Title:  faded into a nameless shade between lees of wine and a heavenly
Title:  azure; face long and brown; high cheek bones, a sign of sagacity;
Title:  the maxillary muscles enormously developed, an infallible sign by
Title:  which a Gascon may always be detected, even without his cap--and
Title:  our young man wore a cap set off with a sort of feather; the eye
Title:  open and intelligent; the nose hooked, but finely chiseled.  Too
Title:  big for a youth, too small for a grown man, an experienced eye
Title:  might have taken him for a farmer's son upon a journey had it not
Title:  been for the long sword which, dangling from a leather baldric,
Title:  hit against the calves of its owner as he walked, and against the
Title:  rough side of his steed when he was on horseback.
Title:  
Title:  For our young man had a steed which was the observed of all
Title:  observers.  It was a Bearn pony, from twelve to fourteen years
Title:  old, yellow in his hide, without a hair in his tail, but not
Title:  without windgalls on his legs, which, though going with his head
Title:  lower than his knees, rendering a martingale quite unnecessary,
Title:  contrived nevertheless to perform his eight leagues a day.
Title:  Unfortunately, the qualities of this horse were so well concealed
Title:  under his strange-colored hide and his unaccountable gait, that
Title:  at a time when everybody was a connoisseur in horseflesh, the
Title:  appearance of the aforesaid pony at Meung--which place he had
Title:  entered about a quarter of an hour before, by the gate of
Title:  Beaugency--produced an unfavorable feeling, which extended to his
Title:  rider.
Title:  
Title:  And this feeling had been more painfully perceived by young
Title:  d'Artagnan--for so was the Don Quixote of this second Rosinante
Title:  named--from his not being able to conceal from himself the
Title:  ridiculous appearance that such a steed gave him, good horseman
Title:  as he was.  He had sighed deeply, therefore, when accepting the
Title:  gift of the pony from M. d'Artagnan the elder.  He was not
Title:  ignorant that such a beast was worth at least twenty livres; and
Title:  the words which had accompanied the present were above all price.
Title:  
Title:  "My son," said the old Gascon gentleman, in that pure Bearn
Title:  PATOIS of which Henry IV could never rid himself, "this horse was
Title:  born in the house of your father about thirteen years ago, and
Title:  has remained in it ever since, which ought to make you love it.
Title:  Never sell it; allow it to die tranquilly and honorably of old
Title:  age, and if you make a campaign with it, take as much care of it
Title:  as you would of an old servant.  At court, provided you have ever
Title:  the honor to go there," continued M. d'Artagnan the elder, "--an
Title:  honor to which, remember, your ancient nobility gives you the
Title:  right--sustain worthily your name of gentleman, which has been
Title:  worthily borne by your ancestors for five hundred years, both for
Title:  your own sake and the sake of those who belong to you.  By the
Title:  latter I mean your relatives and friends.  Endure nothing from
Title:  anyone except Monsieur the Cardinal and the king.  It is by his
Title:  courage, please observe, by his courage alone, that a gentleman
Title:  can make his way nowadays.  Whoever hesitates for a second
Title:  perhaps allows the bait to escape which during that exact second
Title:  fortune held out to him.  You are young.  You ought to be brave
Title:  for two reasons:  the first is that you are a Gascon, and the
Title:  second is that you are my son.  Never fear quarrels, but seek
Title:  adventures.  I have taught you how to handle a sword; you have
Title:  thews of iron, a wrist of steel.  Fight on all occasions.  Fight
Title:  the more for duels being forbidden, since consequently there is
Title:  twice as much courage in fighting.  I have nothing to give you,
Title:  my son, but fifteen crowns, my horse, and the counsels you have
Title:  just heard.  Your mother will add to them a recipe for a certain
Title:  balsam, which she had from a Bohemian and which has the
Title:  miraculous virtue of curing all wounds that do not reach the
Title:  heart.  Take advantage of all, and live happily and long.  I have
Title:  but one word to add, and that is to propose an example to you--
Title:  not mine, for I myself have never appeared at court, and have
Title:  only taken part in religious wars as a volunteer; I speak of
Title:  Monsieur de Treville, who was formerly my neighbor, and who had
Title:  the honor to be, as a child, the play-fellow of our king, Louis
Title:  XIII, whom God preserve!  Sometimes their play degenerated into
Title:  battles, and in these battles the king was not always the
Title:  stronger.  The blows which he received increased greatly his
Title:  esteem and friendship for Monsieur de Treville.  Afterward,
Title:  Monsieur de Treville fought with others: in his first journey to
Title:  Paris, five times; from the death of the late king till the young
Title:  one came of age, without reckoning wars and sieges, seven times;
Title:  and from that date up to the present day, a hundred times,
Title:  perhaps!  So that in spite of edicts, ordinances, and decrees,
Title:  there he is, captain of the Musketeers; that is to say, chief of
Title:  a legion of Caesars, whom the king holds in great esteem and whom
Title:  the cardinal dreads--he who dreads nothing, as it is said.  Still
Title:  further, Monsieur de Treville gains ten thousand crowns a year;
Title:  he is therefore a great noble.  He began as you begin.  Go to him
Title:  with this letter, and make him your model in order that you may
Title:  do as he has done."
Title:  
Title:  Upon which M. d'Artagnan the elder girded his own sword round his
Title:  son, kissed him tenderly on both cheeks, and gave him his
Title:  benediction.
Title:  
Title:  On leaving the paternal chamber, the young man found his mother,
Title:  who was waiting for him with the famous recipe of which the
Title:  counsels we have just repeated would necessitate frequent
Title:  employment.  The adieux were on this side longer and more tender
Title:  than they had been on the other--not that M. d'Artagnan did not
Title:  love his son, who was his only offspring, but M. d'Artagnan was a
Title:  man, and he would have considered it unworthy of a man to give
Title:  way to his feelings; whereas Mme. d'Artagnan was a woman, and
Title:  still more, a mother.  She wept abundantly; and--let us speak it
Title:  to the praise of M. d'Artagnan the younger--notwithstanding the
Title:  efforts he made to remain firm, as a future Musketeer ought,
Title:  nature prevailed, and he shed many tears, of which he succeeded
Title:  with great difficulty in concealing the half.
Title:  
Title:  The same day the young man set forward on his journey, furnished
Title:  with the three paternal gifts, which consisted, as we have said,
Title:  of fifteen crowns, the horse, and the letter for M. de Treville--
Title:  the counsels being thrown into the bargain.
Title:  
Title:  With such a VADE MECUM d'Artagnan was morally and physically an
Title:  exact copy of the hero of Cervantes, to whom we so happily
Title:  compared him when our duty of an historian placed us under the
Title:  necessity of sketching his portrait.  Don Quixote took windmills
Title:  for giants, and sheep for armies; d'Artagnan took every smile for
Title:  an insult, and every look as a provocation--whence it resulted
Title:  that from Tarbes to Meung his fist was constantly doubled, or his
Title:  hand on the hilt of his sword; and yet the fist did not descend
Title:  upon any jaw, nor did the sword issue from its scabbard.  It was
Title:  not that the sight of the wretched pony did not excite numerous
Title:  smiles on the countenances of passers-by; but as against the side
Title:  of this pony rattled a sword of respectable length, and as over
Title:  this sword gleamed an eye rather ferocious than haughty, these
Title:  passers-by repressed their hilarity, or if hilarity prevailed
Title:  over prudence, they endeavored to laugh only on one side, like
Title:  the masks of the ancients.  D'Artagnan, then, remained majestic
Title:  and intact in his susceptibility, till he came to this unlucky
Title:  city of Meung.
Title:  
Title:  But there, as he was alighting from his horse at the gate of the
Title:  Jolly Miller, without anyone--host, waiter, or hostler--coming to
Title:  hold his stirrup or take his horse, d'Artagnan spied, though an
Title:  open window on the ground floor, a gentleman, well-made and of
Title:  good carriage, although of rather a stern countenance, talking
Title:  with two persons who appeared to listen to him with respect.
Title:  d'Artagnan fancied quite naturally, according to his custom, that
Title:  he must be the object of their conversation, and listened.  This
Title:  time d'Artagnan was only in part mistaken; he himself was not in
Title:  question, but his horse was. The gentleman appeared to be
Title:  enumerating all his qualities to his auditors; and, as I have
Title:  said, the auditors seeming to have great deference for the
Title:  narrator, they every moment burst into fits of laughter.  Now, as
Title:  a half-smile was sufficient to awaken the irascibility of the
Title:  young man, the effect produced upon him by this vociferous mirth
Title:  may be easily imagined.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, d'Artagnan was desirous of examining the appearance
Title:  of this impertinent personage who ridiculed him.  He fixed his
Title:  haughty eye upon the stranger, and perceived a man of from forty
Title:  to forty-five years of age, with black and piercing eyes, pale
Title:  complexion, a strongly marked nose, and a black and well-shaped
Title:  mustache.  He was dressed in a doublet and hose of a violet
Title:  color, with aiguillettes of the same color, without any other
Title:  ornaments than the customary slashes, through which the shirt
Title:  appeared.  This doublet and hose, though new, were creased, like
Title:  traveling clothes for a long time packed in a portmanteau.
Title:  d'Artagnan made all these remarks with the rapidity of a most
Title:  minute observer, and doubtless from an instinctive feeling that
Title:  this stranger was destined to have a great influence over his
Title:  future life.
Title:  
Title:  Now, as at the moment in which d'Artagnan fixed his eyes upon the
Title:  gentleman in the violet doublet, the gentleman made one of his
Title:  most knowing and profound remarks respecting the Bearnese pony,
Title:  his two auditors laughed even louder than before, and he himself,
Title:  though contrary to his custom, allowed a pale smile (if I may
Title:  allowed to use such an expression) to stray over his countenance.
Title:  This time there could be no doubt; d'Artagnan was really
Title:  insulted.  Full, then, of this conviction, he pulled his cap down
Title:  over his eyes, and endeavoring to copy some of the court airs he
Title:  had picked up in Gascony among young traveling nobles, he
Title:  advanced with one hand on the hilt of his sword and the other
Title:  resting on his hip.  Unfortunately, as he advanced, his anger
Title:  increased at every step; and instead of the proper and lofty
Title:  speech he had prepared as a prelude to his challenge, he found
Title:  nothing at the tip of his tongue but a gross personality, which
Title:  he accompanied with a furious gesture.
Title:  
Title:  "I say, sir, you sir, who are hiding yourself behind that
Title:  shutter--yes, you, sir, tell me what you are laughing at, and we
Title:  will laugh together!"
Title:  
Title:  The gentleman raised his eyes slowly from the nag to his
Title:  cavalier, as if he required some time to ascertain whether it
Title:  could be to him that such strange reproaches were addressed;
Title:  then, when he could not possibly entertain any doubt of the
Title:  matter, his eyebrows slightly bent, and with an accent of irony
Title:  and insolence impossible to be described, he replied to
Title:  d'Artagnan, "I was not speaking to you, sir."
Title:  
Title:  "But I am speaking to you!" replied the young man, additionally
Title:  exasperated with this mixture of insolence and good manners, of
Title:  politeness and scorn.
Title:  
Title:  The stranger looked at him again with a slight smile, and
Title:  retiring from the window, came out of the hostelry with a slow
Title:  step, and placed himself before the horse, within two paces of
Title:  d'Artagnan.  His quiet manner and the ironical expression of his
Title:  countenance redoubled the mirth of the persons with whom he had
Title:  been talking, and who still remained at the window.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, seeing him approach, drew his sword a foot out of the
Title:  scabbard.
Title:  
Title:  "This horse is decidedly, or rather has been in his youth, a
Title:  buttercup," resumed the stranger, continuing the remarks he had
Title:  begun, and addressing himself to his auditors at the window,
Title:  without paying the least attention to the exasperation of
Title:  d'Artagnan, who, however placed himself between him and them.
Title:  "It is a color very well known in botany, but till the present
Title:  time very rare among horses."
Title:  
Title:  "There are people who laugh at the horse that would not dare to
Title:  laugh at the master," cried the young emulator of the furious
Title:  Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "I do not often laugh, sir," replied the stranger, "as you may
Title:  perceive by the expression of my countenance; but nevertheless I
Title:  retain the privilege of laughing when I please."
Title:  
Title:  "And I," cried d'Artagnan, "will allow no man to laugh when it
Title:  displeases me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed, sir," continued the stranger, more calm than ever;
Title:  "well, that is perfectly right!" and turning on his heel, was
Title:  about to re-enter the hostelry by the front gate, beneath which
Title:  d'Artagnan on arriving had observed a saddled horse.
Title:  
Title:  But, d'Artagnan was not of a character to allow a man to escape
Title:  him thus who had the insolence to ridicule him.  He drew his
Title:  sword entirely from the scabbard, and followed him, crying,
Title:  "Turn, turn, Master Joker, lest I strike you behind!"
Title:  
Title:  "Strike me!" said the other, turning on his heels, and surveying
Title:  the young man with as much astonishment as contempt.  "Why, my
Title:  good fellow, you must be mad!"  Then, in a suppressed tone, as if
Title:  speaking to himself, "This is annoying," continued he.  "What a
Title:  godsend this would be for his Majesty, who is seeking everywhere
Title:  for brave fellows to recruit for his Musketeers!"
Title:  
Title:  He had scarcely finished, when d'Artagnan made such a furious
Title:  lunge at him that if he had not sprung nimbly backward, it is
Title:  probable he would have jested for the last time.  The stranger,
Title:  then perceiving that the matter went beyond raillery, drew his
Title:  sword, saluted his adversary, and seriously placed himself on
Title:  guard.  But at the same moment, his two auditors, accompanied by
Title:  the host, fell upon d'Artagnan with sticks, shovels and tongs.
Title:  This caused so rapid and complete a diversion from the attack
Title:  that d'Artagnan's adversary, while the latter turned round to
Title:  face this shower of blows, sheathed his sword with the same
Title:  precision, and instead of an actor, which he had nearly been,
Title:  became a spectator of the fight--a part in which he acquitted
Title:  himself with his usual impassiveness, muttering, nevertheless, "A
Title:  plague upon these Gascons!  Replace him on his orange horse, and
Title:  let him begone!"
Title:  
Title:  "Not before I have killed you, poltroon!" cried d'Artagnan,
Title:  making the best face possible, and never retreating one step
Title:  before his three assailants, who continued to shower blows upon
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  "Another gasconade!" murmured the gentleman.  "By my honor, these
Title:  Gascons are incorrigible!  Keep up the dance, then, since he will
Title:  have it so.  When he is tired, he will perhaps tell us that he
Title:  has had enough of it."
Title:  
Title:  But the stranger knew not the headstrong personage he had to do
Title:  with; d'Artagnan was not the man ever to cry for quarter.  The
Title:  fight was therefore prolonged for some seconds; but at length
Title:  d'Artagnan dropped his sword, which was broken in two pieces by
Title:  the blow of a stick.  Another blow full upon his forehead at the
Title:  same moment brought him to the ground, covered with blood and
Title:  almost fainting.
Title:  
Title:  It was at this moment that people came flocking to the scene of
Title:  action from all sides.  The host, fearful of consequences, with
Title:  the help of his servants carried the wounded man into the
Title:  kitchen, where some trifling attentions were bestowed upon him.
Title:  
Title:  As to the gentleman, he resumed his place at the window, and
Title:  surveyed the crowd with a certain impatience, evidently annoyed
Title:  by their remaining undispersed.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, how is it with this madman?" exclaimed he, turning round
Title:  as the noise of the door announced the entrance of the host, who
Title:  came in to inquire if he was unhurt.
Title:  
Title:  "Your excellency is safe and sound?" asked the host.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes!  Perfectly safe and sound, my good host; and I wish to
Title:  know what has become of our young man."
Title:  
Title:  "He is better," said the host, "he fainted quite away."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!" said the gentleman.
Title:  
Title:  "But before he fainted, he collected all his strength to
Title:  challenge you, and to defy you while challenging you."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, this fellow must be the devil in person!" cried the
Title:  stranger.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no, your Excellency, he is not the devil," replied the host,
Title:  with a grin of contempt; "for during his fainting we rummaged his
Title:  valise and found nothing but a clean shirt and eleven crowns--
Title:  which however, did not prevent his saying, as he was fainting,
Title:  that if such a thing had happened in Paris, you should have cause
Title:  to repent of it at a later period."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said the stranger coolly, "he must be some prince in
Title:  disguise."
Title:  
Title:  "I have told you this, good sir," resumed the host, "in order
Title:  that you may be on your guard."
Title:  
Title:  "Did he name no one in his passion?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; he struck his pocket and said, 'We shall see what Monsieur
Title:  de Treville will think of this insult offered to his protege.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Treville?" said the stranger, becoming attentive,
Title:  "he put his hand upon his pocket while pronouncing the name of
Title:  Monsieur de Treville?  Now, my dear host, while your young man
Title:  was insensible, you did not fail, I am quite sure, to ascertain
Title:  what that pocket contained.  What was there in it?"
Title:  
Title:  "A letter addressed to Monsieur de Treville, captain of the
Title:  Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly as I have the honor to tell your Excellency."
Title:  
Title:  The host, who was not endowed with great perspicacity, did not
Title:  observe the expression which his words had given to the
Title:  physiognomy of the stranger.  The latter rose from the front of
Title:  the window, upon the sill of which he had leaned with his elbow,
Title:  and knitted his brow like a man disquieted.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" murmured he, between his teeth.  "Can Treville have
Title:  set this Gascon upon me?  He is very young; but a sword thrust is
Title:  a sword thrust, whatever be the age of him who gives it, and a
Title:  youth is less to be suspected than an older man," and the
Title:  stranger fell into a reverie which lasted some minutes.  "A weak
Title:  obstacle is sometimes sufficient to overthrow a great design.
Title:  
Title:  "Host," said he, "could you not contrive to get rid of this
Title:  frantic boy for me?  In conscience, I cannot kill him; and yet,"
Title:  added he, with a coldly menacing expression, "he annoys me.
Title:  Where is he?"
Title:  
Title:  "In my wife's chamber, on the first flight, where they are
Title:  dressing his wounds."
Title:  
Title:  "His things and his bag are with him?  Has he taken off his
Title:  doublet?"
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary, everything is in the kitchen.  But if he annoys
Title:  you, this young fool--"
Title:  
Title:  "To be sure he does.  He causes a disturbance in your hostelry,
Title:  which respectable people cannot put up with.  Go; make out my
Title:  bill and notify my servant."
Title:  
Title:  "What, monsieur, will you leave us so soon?"
Title:  
Title:  "You know that very well, as I gave my order to saddle my horse.
Title:  Have they not obeyed me?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is done; as your Excellency may have observed, your horse is
Title:  in the great gateway, ready saddled for your departure."
Title:  
Title:  "That is well; do as I have directed you, then."
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil!" said the host to himself. "Can he be afraid of
Title:  this boy?"  But an imperious glance from the stranger stopped him
Title:  short; he bowed humbly and retired.
Title:  
Title:  "It is not necessary for Milady* to be seen by this fellow,"
Title:  continued the stranger.  "She will soon pass; she is already
Title:  late.  I had better get on horseback, and go and meet her.  I
Title:  should like, however, to know what this letter addressed to
Title:  Treville contains."
Title:  
Title:  *We are well aware that this term, milady, is only properly used
Title:  when followed by a family name.  But we find it thus in the manuscript,
Title:  and we do not choose to take upon ourselves to alter it.
Title:  
Title:  And the stranger, muttering to himself, directed his steps toward
Title:  the kitchen.
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime, the host, who entertained no doubt that it was
Title:  the presence of the young man that drove the stranger from his
Title:  hostelry, re-ascended to his wife's chamber, and found d'Artagnan
Title:  just recovering his senses.  Giving him to understand that the
Title:  police would deal with him pretty severely for having sought a
Title:  quarrel with a great lord--for the opinion of the host the
Title:  stranger could be nothing less than a great lord--he insisted
Title:  that notwithstanding his weakness d'Artagnan should get up and
Title:  depart as quickly as possible.  D'Artagnan, half stupefied,
Title:  without his doublet, and with his head bound up in a linen cloth,
Title:  arose then, and urged by the host, began to descend the stairs;
Title:  but on arriving at the kitchen, the first thing he saw was his
Title:  antagonist talking calmly at the step of a heavy carriage, drawn
Title:  by two large Norman horses.
Title:  
Title:  His interlocutor, whose head appeared through the carriage
Title:  window, was a woman of from twenty to two-and-twenty years.  We
Title:  have already observed with what rapidity d'Artagnan seized the
Title:  expression of a countenance.  He perceived then, at a glance,
Title:  that this woman was young and beautiful; and her style of beauty
Title:  struck him more forcibly from its being totally different from
Title:  that of the southern countries in which d'Artagnan had hitherto
Title:  resided.  She was pale and fair, with long curls falling in
Title:  profusion over her shoulders, had large, blue, languishing eyes,
Title:  rosy lips, and hands of alabaster.  She was talking with great
Title:  animation with the stranger.
Title:  
Title:  "His Eminence, then, orders me--" said the lady.
Title:  
Title:  "To return instantly to England, and to inform him as soon as the
Title:  duke leaves London."
Title:  
Title:  "And as to my other instructions?" asked the fair traveler.
Title:  
Title:  "They are contained in this box, which you will not open until
Title:  you are on the other side of the Channel."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well; and you--what will you do?"
Title:  
Title:  "I--I return to Paris."
Title:  
Title:  "What, without chastising this insolent boy?" asked the lady.
Title:  
Title:  The stranger was about to reply; but at the moment he opened his
Title:  mouth, d'Artagnan, who had heard all, precipitated himself over
Title:  the threshold of the door.
Title:  
Title:  "This insolent boy chastises others," cried he; "and I hope that
Title:  this time he whom he ought to chastise will not escape him as
Title:  before."
Title:  
Title:  "Will not escape him?" replied the stranger, knitting his brow.
Title:  
Title:  "No; before a woman you would dare not fly, I presume?"
Title:  
Title:  "Remember," said Milady, seeing the stranger lay his hand on his
Title:  sword, "the least delay may ruin everything."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right," cried the gentleman; "begone then, on your part,
Title:  and I will depart as quickly on mine."  And bowing to the lady,
Title:  sprang into his saddle, while her coachman applied his whip
Title:  vigorously to his horses.  The two interlocutors thus separated,
Title:  taking opposite directions, at full gallop.
Title:  
Title:  "Pay him, booby!" cried the stranger to his servant, without
Title:  checking the speed of his horse; and the man, after throwing two
Title:  or three silver pieces at the foot of mine host, galloped after
Title:  his master.
Title:  
Title:  "Base coward! false gentleman!" cried d'Artagnan, springing
Title:  forward, in his turn, after the servant.  But his wound had
Title:  rendered him too weak to support such an exertion.  Scarcely had
Title:  he gone ten steps when his ears began to tingle, a faintness
Title:  seized him, a cloud of blood passed over his eyes, and he fell in
Title:  the middle of the street, crying still, "Coward! coward! coward!"
Title:  
Title:  "He is a coward, indeed," grumbled the host, drawing near to
Title:  d'Artagnan, and endeavoring by this little flattery to make up
Title:  matters with the young man, as the heron of the fable did with
Title:  the snail he had despised the evening before.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, a base coward," murmured d'Artagnan; "but she--she was very
Title:  beautiful."
Title:  
Title:  "What she?" demanded the host.
Title:  
Title:  "Milady," faltered d'Artagnan, and fainted a second time.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, it's all one," said the host; "I have lost two customers,
Title:  but this one remains, of whom I am pretty certain for some days
Title:  to come.  There will be eleven crowns gained."
Title:  
Title:  It is to be remembered that eleven crowns was just the sum that
Title:  remained in d'Artagnan's purse.
Title:  
Title:  The host had reckoned upon eleven days of confinement at a crown
Title:  a day, but he had reckoned without his guest.  On the following
Title:  morning at five o'clock d'Artagnan arose, and descending to the
Title:  kitchen without help, asked, among other ingredients the list of
Title:  which has not come down to us, for some oil, some wine, and some
Title:  rosemary, and with his mother's recipe in his hand composed a
Title:  balsam, with which he anointed his numerous wounds, replacing his
Title:  bandages himself, and positively refusing the assistance of any
Title:  doctor, d'Artagnan walked about that same evening, and was almost
Title:  cured by the morrow.
Title:  
Title:  But when the time came to pay for his rosemary, this oil, and the
Title:  wine, the only expense the master had incurred, as he had
Title:  preserved a strict abstinence--while on the contrary, the yellow
Title:  horse, by the account of the hostler at least, had eaten three
Title:  times as much as a horse of his size could reasonably supposed to
Title:  have done--d'Artagnan found nothing in his pocket but his little
Title:  old velvet purse with the eleven crowns it contained; for as to
Title:  the letter addressed to M. de Treville, it had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  The young man commenced his search for the letter with the
Title:  greatest patience, turning out his pockets of all kinds over and
Title:  over again, rummaging and rerummaging in his valise, and opening
Title:  and reopening his purse; but when he found that he had come to
Title:  the conviction that the letter was not to be found, he flew, for
Title:  the third time, into such a rage as was near costing him a fresh
Title:  consumption of wine, oil, and rosemary--for upon seeing this hot-
Title:  headed youth become exasperated and threaten to destroy
Title:  everything in the establishment if his letter were not found, the
Title:  host seized a spit, his wife a broom handle, and the servants the
Title:  same sticks they had used the day before.
Title:  
Title:  "My letter of recommendation!" cried d'Artagnan, "my letter of
Title:  recommendation! or, the holy blood, I will spit you all like
Title:  ortolans!"
Title:  
Title:  Unfortunately, there was one circumstance which created a
Title:  powerful obstacle to the accomplishment of this threat; which
Title:  was, as we have related, that his sword had been in his first
Title:  conflict broken in two, and which he had entirely forgotten.
Title:  Hence, it resulted when d'Artagnan proceeded to draw his sword in
Title:  earnest, he found himself purely and simply armed with a stump of
Title:  a sword about eight or ten inches in length, which the host had
Title:  carefully placed in the scabbard.  As to the rest of the blade,
Title:  the master had slyly put that on one side to make himself a
Title:  larding pin.
Title:  
Title:  But this deception would probably not have stopped our fiery
Title:  young man if the host had not reflected that the reclamation
Title:  which his guest made was perfectly just.
Title:  
Title:  "But, after all," said he, lowering the point of his spit, "where
Title:  is this letter?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, where is this letter?" cried d'Artagnan.  "In the first
Title:  place, I warn you that that letter is for Monsieur de Treville,
Title:  and it must be found, he will know how to find it."
Title:  
Title:  His threat completed the intimidation of the host.  After the
Title:  king and the cardinal, M. de Treville was the man whose name was
Title:  perhaps most frequently repeated by the military, and even by
Title:  citizens.  There was, to be sure, Father Joseph, but his name was
Title:  never pronounced but with a subdued voice, such was the terror
Title:  inspired by his Gray Eminence, as the cardinal's familiar was
Title:  called.
Title:  
Title:  Throwing down his spit, and ordering his wife to do the same with
Title:  her broom handle, and the servants with their sticks, he set the
Title:  first example of commencing an earnest search for the lost
Title:  letter.
Title:  
Title:  "Does the letter contain anything valuable?" demanded the host,
Title:  after a few minutes of useless investigation.
Title:  
Title:  "Zounds! I think it does indeed!" cried the Gascon, who reckoned
Title:  upon this letter for making his way at court.  "It contained my
Title:  fortune!"
Title:  
Title:  "Bills upon Spain?" asked the disturbed host.
Title:  
Title:  "Bills upon his Majesty's private treasury," answered d'Artagnan,
Title:  who, reckoning upon entering into the king's service in
Title:  consequence of this recommendation, believed he could make this
Title:  somewhat hazardous reply without telling of a falsehood.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" cried the host, at his wit's end.
Title:  
Title:  "But it's of no importance," continued d'Artagnan, with natural
Title:  assurance; "it's of no importance.  The money is nothing; that
Title:  letter was everything.  I would rather have lost a thousand
Title:  pistoles than have lost it."  He would not have risked more if he
Title:  had said twenty thousand; but a certain juvenile modesty
Title:  restrained him.
Title:  
Title:  A ray of light all at once broke upon the mind of the host as he
Title:  was giving himself to the devil upon finding nothing.
Title:  
Title:  "That letter is not lost!" cried he.
Title:  
Title:  "What!" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "No, it has been stolen from you."
Title:  
Title:  "Stolen? By whom?"
Title:  
Title:  "By the gentleman who was here yesterday.  He came down into the
Title:  kitchen, where your doublet was.  He remained there some time
Title:  alone.  I would lay a wager he has stolen it."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you think so?" answered d'Artagnan, but little convinced, as
Title:  he knew better than anyone else how entirely personal the value
Title:  of this letter was, and was nothing in it likely to tempt
Title:  cupidity.  The fact was that none of his servants, none of the
Title:  travelers present, could have gained anything by being possessed
Title:  of this paper.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you say," resumed d'Artagnan, "that you suspect that
Title:  impertinent gentleman?"
Title:  
Title:  "I tell you I am sure of it," continued the host.  "When I
Title:  informed him that your lordship was the protege of Monsieur de
Title:  Treville, and that you even had a letter for that illustrious
Title:  gentleman, he appeared to be very much disturbed, and asked me
Title:  where that letter was, and immediately came down into the
Title:  kitchen, where he knew your doublet was."
Title:  
Title:  "Then that's my thief," replied d'Artagnan.  "I will complain to
Title:  Monsieur de Treville, and Monsieur de Treville will complain to
Title:  the king."  He then drew two crowns majestically from his purse
Title:  and gave them to the host, who accompanied him, cap in hand, to
Title:  the gate, and remounted his yellow horse, which bore him without
Title:  any further accident to the gate of St. Antoine at Paris, where
Title:  his owner sold him for three crowns, which was a very good price,
Title:  considering that d'Artagnan had ridden him hard during the last
Title:  stage.  Thus the dealer to whom d'Artagnan sold him for the nine
Title:  livres did not conceal from the young man that he only gave that
Title:  enormous sum for him on the account of the originality of his
Title:  color.
Title:  
Title:  Thus d'Artagnan entered Paris on foot, carrying his little packet
Title:  under his arm, and walked about till he found an apartment to be
Title:  let on terms suited to the scantiness of his means.  This chamber
Title:  was a sort of garret, situated in the Rue des Fossoyeurs, near
Title:  the Luxembourg.
Title:  
Title:  As soon as the earnest money was paid, d'Artagnan took possession
Title:  of his lodging, and passed the remainder of the day in sewing
Title:  onto his doublet and hose some ornamental braiding which his
Title:  mother had taken off an almost-new doublet of the elder M.
Title:  d'Artagnan, and which she had given her son secretly.  Next he
Title:  went to the Quai de Feraille to have a new blade put to his
Title:  sword, and then returned toward the Louvre, inquiring of the
Title:  first Musketeer he met for the situation of the hotel of M. de
Title:  Treville, which proved to be in the Rue du Vieux-Colombier; that
Title:  is to say, in the immediate vicinity of the chamber hired by
Title:  d'Artagnan--a circumstance which appeared to furnish a happy
Title:  augury for the success of his journey.
Title:  
Title:  After this, satisfied with the way in which he had conducted
Title:  himself at Meung, without remorse for the past, confident in the
Title:  present, and full of hope for the future, he retired to bed and
Title:  slept the sleep of the brave.
Title:  
Title:  This sleep, provincial as it was, brought him to nine o'clock in
Title:  the morning; at which hour he rose, in order to repair to the
Title:  residence of M. de Treville, the third personage in the kingdom, in the
Title:  paternal estimation.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  2  THE ANTECHAMBER OF M. DE TREVILLE
Title:  
Title:  M. de Troisville, as his family was still called in Gascony, or
Title:  M. de Treville, as he has ended by styling himself in Paris, had
Title:  really commenced life as d'Artagnan now did; that is to say,
Title:  without a sou in his pocket, but with a fund of audacity,
Title:  shrewdness, and intelligence which makes the poorest Gascon
Title:  gentleman often derive more in his hope from the paternal
Title:  inheritance than the richest Perigordian or Berrichan gentleman
Title:  derives in reality from his.  His insolent bravery, his still
Title:  more insolent success at a time when blows poured down like hail,
Title:  had borne him to the top of that difficult ladder called Court
Title:  Favor, which he had climbed four steps at a time.
Title:  
Title:  He was the friend of the king, who honored highly, as everyone
Title:  knows, the memory of his father, Henry IV.  The father of M. de
Title:  Treville had served him so faithfully in his wars against the
Title:  league that in default of money--a thing to which the Bearnais
Title:  was accustomed all his life, and who constantly paid his debts
Title:  with that of which he never stood in need of borrowing, that is
Title:  to say, with ready wit--in default of money, we repeat, he
Title:  authorized him, after the reduction of Paris, to assume for his
Title:  arms a golden lion passant upon gules, with the motto FIDELIS ET
Title:  FORTIS.  This was a great matter in the way of honor, but very
Title:  little in the way of wealth; so that when the illustrious
Title:  companion of the great Henry died, the only inheritance he was
Title:  able to leave his son was his sword and his motto.  Thanks to
Title:  this double gift and the spotless name that accompanied it, M. de
Title:  Treville was admitted into the household of the young prince
Title:  where he made such good use of his sword, and was so faithful to
Title:  his motto, that Louis XIII, one of the good blades of his
Title:  kingdom, was accustomed to say that if he had a friend who was
Title:  about to fight, he would advise him to choose as a second,
Title:  himself first, and Treville next--or even, perhaps, before
Title:  himself.
Title:  
Title:  Thus Louis XIII had a real liking for Treville--a royal liking, a
Title:  self-interested liking, it is true, but still a liking.  At that
Title:  unhappy period it was an important consideration to be surrounded
Title:  by such men as Treville.  Many might take for their device the
Title:  epithet STRONG, which formed the second part of his motto, but
Title:  very few gentlemen could lay claim to the FAITHFUL, which
Title:  constituted the first.  Treville was one of these latter.  His
Title:  was one of those rare organizations, endowed with an obedient
Title:  intelligence like that of the dog; with a blind valor, a quick
Title:  eye, and a prompt hand; to whom sight appeared only to be given
Title:  to see if the king were dissatisfied with anyone, and the hand to
Title:  strike this displeasing personage, whether a Besme, a Maurevers,
Title:  a Poltiot de Mere, or a Vitry.  In short, up to this period
Title:  nothing had been wanting to Treville but opportunity; but he was
Title:  ever on the watch for it, and he faithfully promised himself that
Title:  he would not fail to seize it by its three hairs whenever it came
Title:  within reach of his hand.  At last Louis XIII made Treville the
Title:  captain of his Musketeers, who were to Louis XIII in devotedness,
Title:  or rather in fanaticism, what his Ordinaries had been to Henry
Title:  III, and his Scotch Guard to Louis XI.
Title:  
Title:  On his part, the cardinal was not behind the king in this
Title:  respect.  When he saw the formidable and chosen body with which
Title:  Louis XIII had surrounded himself, this second, or rather this
Title:  first king of France, became desirous that he, too, should have
Title:  his guard.  He had his Musketeers therefore, as Louis XIII had
Title:  his, and these two powerful rivals vied with each other in
Title:  procuring, not only from all the provinces of France, but even
Title:  from all foreign states, the most celebrated swordsmen.  It was
Title:  not uncommon for Richelieu and Louis XIII to dispute over their
Title:  evening game of chess upon the merits of their servants.  Each
Title:  boasted the bearing and the courage of his own people.  While
Title:  exclaiming loudly against duels and brawls, they excited them
Title:  secretly to quarrel, deriving an immoderate satisfaction or
Title:  genuine regret from the success or defeat of their own
Title:  combatants.  We learn this from the memoirs of a man who was
Title:  concerned in some few of these defeats and in many of these
Title:  victories.
Title:  
Title:  Treville had grasped the weak side of his master; and it was to
Title:  this address that he owed the long and constant favor of a king
Title:  who has not left the reputation behind him of being very faithful
Title:  in his friendships.  He paraded his Musketeers before the
Title:  Cardinal Armand Duplessis with an insolent air which made the
Title:  gray moustache of his Eminence curl with ire.  Treville
Title:  understood admirably the war method of that period, in which he
Title:  who could not live at the expense of the enemy must live at the
Title:  expense of his compatriots.  His soldiers formed a legion of
Title:  devil-may-care fellows, perfectly undisciplined toward all but
Title:  himself.
Title:  
Title:  Loose, half-drunk, imposing, the king's Musketeers, or rather M.
Title:  de Treville's, spread themselves about in the cabarets, in the
Title:  public walks, and the public sports, shouting, twisting their
Title:  mustaches, clanking their swords, and taking great pleasure in
Title:  annoying the Guards of the cardinal whenever they could fall in
Title:  with them; then drawing in the open streets, as if it were the
Title:  best of all possible sports; sometimes killed, but sure in that
Title:  case to be both wept and avenged; often killing others, but then
Title:  certain of not rotting in prison, M. de Treville being there to
Title:  claim them.  Thus M. de Treville was praised to the highest note
Title:  by these men, who adored him, and who, ruffians as they were,
Title:  trembled before him like scholars before their master, obedient
Title:  to his least word, and ready to sacrifice themselves to wash out
Title:  the smallest insult.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville employed this powerful weapon for the king, in the
Title:  first place, and the friends of the king--and then for himself
Title:  and his own friends.  For the rest, in the memoirs of this
Title:  period, which has left so many memoirs, one does not find this
Title:  worthy gentleman blamed even by his enemies; and he had many such
Title:  among men of the pen as well as among men of the sword.  In no
Title:  instance, let us say, was this worthy gentleman accused of
Title:  deriving personal advantage from the cooperation of his minions.
Title:  Endowed with a rare genius for intrigue which rendered him the
Title:  equal of the ablest intriguers, he remained an honest man.  Still
Title:  further, in spite of sword thrusts which weaken, and painful
Title:  exercises which fatigue, he had become one of the most gallant
Title:  frequenters of revels, one of the most insinuating lady's men,
Title:  one of the softest whisperers of interesting nothings of his
Title:  day; the BONNES FORTUNES of de Treville were talked of as those
Title:  of M. de Bassompierre had been talked of twenty years before, and
Title:  that was not saying a little.  The captain of the Musketeers was
Title:  therefore admired, feared, and loved; and this constitutes the
Title:  zenith of human fortune.
Title:  
Title:  Louis XIV absorbed all the smaller stars of his court in his own
Title:  vast radiance; but his father, a sun PLURIBUS IMPAR, left his
Title:  personal splendor to each of his favorites, his individual value
Title:  to each of his courtiers.  In addition to the leeves of the king
Title:  and the cardinal, there might be reckoned in Paris at that time
Title:  more than two hundred smaller but still noteworthy leeves.  Among
Title:  these two hundred leeves, that of Treville was one of the most
Title:  sought.
Title:  
Title:  The court of his hotel, situated in the Rue du Vieux-Colombier,
Title:  resembled a camp from by six o'clock in the morning in summer and
Title:  eight o'clock in winter.  From fifty to sixty Musketeers, who
Title:  appeared to replace one another in order always to present an
Title:  imposing number, paraded constantly, armed to the teeth and ready
Title:  for anything.  On one of those immense staircases, upon whose
Title:  space modern civilization would build a whole house, ascended and
Title:  descended the office seekers of Paris, who ran after any sort of
Title:  favor--gentlemen from the provinces anxious to be enrolled, and
Title:  servants in all sorts of liveries, bringing and carrying messages
Title:  between their masters and M. de Treville.  In the antechamber,
Title:  upon long circular benches, reposed the elect; that is to say,
Title:  those who were called.  In this apartment a continued buzzing
Title:  prevailed from morning till night, while M. de Treville, in his
Title:  office contiguous to this antechamber, received visits, listened
Title:  to complaints, gave his orders, and like the king in his balcony
Title:  at the Louvre, had only to place himself at the window to review
Title:  both his men and arms.
Title:  
Title:  The day on which d'Artagnan presented himself the assemblage was
Title:  imposing, particularly for a provincial just arriving from his
Title:  province.  It is true that this provincial was a Gascon; and
Title:  that, particularly at this period, the compatriots of d'Artagnan
Title:  had the reputation of not being easily intimidated.  When he had
Title:  once passed the massive door covered with long square-headed
Title:  nails, he fell into the midst of a troop of swordsmen, who
Title:  crossed one another in their passage, calling out, quarreling,
Title:  and playing tricks one with another.  In order to make one's way
Title:  amid these turbulent and conflicting waves, it was necessary to
Title:  be an officer, a great noble, or a pretty woman.
Title:  
Title:  It was, then, into the midst of this tumult and disorder that our
Title:  young man advanced with a beating heat, ranging his long rapier
Title:  up his lanky leg, and keeping one hand on the edge of his cap,
Title:  with that half-smile of the embarrassed a provincial who wishes
Title:  to put on a good face.  When he had passed one group he began to
Title:  breathe more freely; but he could not help observing that they
Title:  turned round to look at him, and for the first time in his life
Title:  d'Artagnan, who had till that day entertained a very good opinion
Title:  of himself, felt ridiculous.
Title:  
Title:  Arrived at the staircase, it was still worse.  There were four
Title:  Musketeers on the bottom steps, amusing themselves with the
Title:  following exercise, while ten or twelve of their comrades waited
Title:  upon the landing place to take their turn in the sport.
Title:  
Title:  One of them, stationed upon the top stair, naked sword in hand,
Title:  prevented, or at least endeavored to prevent, the three others
Title:  from ascending.
Title:  
Title:  These three others fenced against him with their agile swords.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan at first took these weapons for foils, and believed
Title:  them to be buttoned; but he soon perceived by certain scratches
Title:  that every weapon was pointed and sharpened, and that at each of
Title:  these scratches not only the spectators, but even the actors
Title:  themselves, laughed like so many madmen.
Title:  
Title:  He who at the moment occupied the upper step kept his adversaries
Title:  marvelously in check.  A circle was formed around them.  The
Title:  conditions required that at every hit the man touched should quit
Title:  the game, yielding his turn for the benefit of the adversary who
Title:  had hit him.  In five minutes three were slightly wounded, one on
Title:  the hand, another on the ear, by the defender of the stair, who
Title:  himself remained intact--a piece of skill which was worth to him,
Title:  according to the rules agreed upon, three turns of favor.
Title:  
Title:  However difficult it might be, or rather as he pretended it was,
Title:  to astonish our young traveler, this pastime really astonished
Title:  him.  He had seen in his province--that land in which heads
Title:  become so easily heated--a few of the preliminaries of duels; but
Title:  the daring of these four fencers appeared to him the strongest he
Title:  had ever heard of even in Gascony.  He believed himself
Title:  transported into that famous country of giants into which
Title:  Gulliver afterward went and was so frightened; and yet he had not
Title:  gained the goal, for there were still the landing place and the
Title:  antechamber.
Title:  
Title:  On the landing they were no longer fighting, but amused
Title:  themselves with stories about women, and in the antechamber, with
Title:  stories about the court.  On the landing d'Artagnan blushed; in
Title:  the antechamber he trembled.  His warm and fickle imagination,
Title:  which in Gascony had rendered formidable to young chambermaids,
Title:  and even sometimes their mistresses, had never dreamed, even in
Title:  moments of delirium, of half the amorous wonders or a quarter of
Title:  the feats of gallantry which were here set forth in connection
Title:  with names the best known and with details the least concealed.
Title:  But if his morals were shocked on the landing, his respect for
Title:  the cardinal was scandalized in the antechamber.  There, to his
Title:  great astonishment, d'Artagnan heard the policy which made all
Title:  Europe tremble criticized aloud and openly, as well as the
Title:  private life of the cardinal, which so many great nobles had been
Title:  punished for trying to pry into.  That great man who was so
Title:  revered by d'Artagnan the elder served as an object of ridicule
Title:  to the Musketeers of Treville, who cracked their jokes upon his
Title:  bandy legs and his crooked back.  Some sang ballads about Mme.
Title:  d'Aguillon, his mistress, and Mme. Cambalet, his niece; while
Title:  others formed parties and plans to annoy the pages and guards of
Title:  the cardinal duke--all things which appeared to d'Artagnan
Title:  monstrous impossibilities.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, when the name of the king was now and then uttered
Title:  unthinkingly amid all these cardinal jests, a sort of gag seemed
Title:  to close for a moment on all these jeering mouths.  They looked
Title:  hesitatingly around them, and appeared to doubt the thickness of
Title:  the partition between them and the office of M. de Treville; but
Title:  a fresh allusion soon brought back the conversation to his
Title:  Eminence, and then the laughter recovered its loudness and the
Title:  light was not withheld from any of his actions.
Title:  
Title:  "Certes, these fellows will all either be imprisoned or hanged,"
Title:  thought the terrified d'Artagnan, "and I, no doubt, with them;
Title:  for from the moment I have either listened to or heard them, I
Title:  shall be held as an accomplice.  What would my good father say,
Title:  who so strongly pointed out to me the respect due to the
Title:  cardinal, if he knew I was in the society of such pagans?"
Title:  
Title:  We have no need, therefore, to say that d'Artagnan dared not join
Title:  in the conversation, only he looked with all his eyes and
Title:  listened with all his ears, stretching his five senses so as to
Title:  lose nothing; and despite his confidence on the paternal
Title:  admonitions, he felt himself carried by his tastes and led by his
Title:  instincts to praise rather than to blame the unheard-of things
Title:  which were taking place.
Title:  
Title:  Although he was a perfect stranger in the court of M. de
Title:  Treville's courtiers, and this his first appearance in that
Title:  place, he was at length noticed, and somebody came and asked him
Title:  what he wanted.  At this demand d'Artagnan gave his name very
Title:  modestly, emphasized the title of compatriot, and begged the
Title:  servant who had put the question to him to request a moment's
Title:  audience of M. de Treville--a request which the other, with an
Title:  air of protection, promised to transmit in due season.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, a little recovered from his first surprise, had now
Title:  leisure to study costumes and physiognomy.
Title:  
Title:  The center of the most animated group was a Musketeer of great
Title:  height and haughty countenance, dressed in a costume so peculiar
Title:  as to attract general attention.  He did not wear the uniform
Title:  cloak--which was not obligatory at that epoch of less liberty but
Title:  more independence--but a cerulean-blue doublet, a little faded and
Title:  worn, and over this a magnificent baldric, worked in gold, which
Title:  shone like water ripples in the sun.  A long cloak of crimson
Title:  velvet fell in graceful folds from his shoulders, disclosing in
Title:  front the splendid baldric, from which was suspended a gigantic
Title:  rapier. This Musketeer had just come off guard, complained of
Title:  having a cold, and coughed from time to time affectedly.  It was
Title:  for this reason, as he said to those around him, that he had put
Title:  on his cloak; and while he spoke with a lofty air and twisted his
Title:  mustache disdainfully, all admired his embroidered baldric, and
Title:  d'Artagnan more than anyone.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "What would you have?" said the Musketeer.  "This fashion is
Title:  coming in.  It is a folly, I admit, but still it is the fashion.
Title:  Besides, one must lay out one's inheritance somehow."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, Porthos!" cried one of his companions, "don't try to make us
Title:  believe you obtained that baldric by paternal generosity.  It was
Title:  given to you by that veiled lady I met you with the other Sunday,
Title:  near the gate St. Honor."
Title:  
Title:  "No, upon honor and by the faith of a gentleman, I bought it with
Title:  the contents of my own purse," answered he whom they designated
Title:  by the name Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; about in the same manner," said another Musketeer, "that I
Title:  bought this new purse with what my mistress put into the old
Title:  one."
Title:  
Title:  "It's true, though," said Porthos; "and the proof is that I paid
Title:  twelve pistoles for it."
Title:  
Title:  The wonder was increased, though the doubt continued to exist.
Title:  
Title:  "Is it not true, Aramis?" said Porthos, turning toward another
Title:  Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  This other Musketeer formed a perfect contrast to his
Title:  interrogator, who had just designated him by the name of Aramis.
Title:  He was a stout man, of about two- or three-and-twenty, with an
Title:  open, ingenuous countenance, a black, mild eye, and cheeks rosy
Title:  and downy as an autumn peach.  His delicate mustache marked a
Title:  perfectly straight line upon his upper lip; he appeared to dread
Title:  to lower his hands lest their veins should swell, and he pinched
Title:  the tips of his ears from time to time to preserve their delicate
Title:  pink transparency.  Habitually he spoke little and slowly, bowed
Title:  frequently, laughed without noise, showing his teeth, which were
Title:  fine and of which, as the rest of his person, he appeared to take
Title:  great care.  He answered the appeal of his friend by an
Title:  affirmative nod of the head.
Title:  
Title:  This affirmation appeared to dispel all doubts with regard to the
Title:  baldric.  They continued to admire it, but said no more about it;
Title:  and with a rapid change of thought, the conversation passed
Title:  suddenly to another subject.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you think of the story Chalais's esquire relates?" asked
Title:  another Musketeer, without addressing anyone in particular, but
Title:  on the contrary speaking to everybody.
Title:  
Title:  "And what does he say?" asked Porthos, in a self-sufficient tone.
Title:  
Title:  "He relates that he met at Brussels Rochefort, the AME DAMNEE of
Title:  the cardinal disguised as a Capuchin, and that this cursed
Title:  Rochefort, thanks to his disguise, had tricked Monsieur de
Title:  Laigues, like a ninny as he is."
Title:  
Title:  "A ninny, indeed!" said Porthos; "but is the matter certain?"
Title:  
Title:  "I had it from Aramis," replied the Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, you knew it, Porthos," said Aramis.  "I told you of it
Title:  yesterday.  Let us say no more about it."
Title:  
Title:  "Say no more about it?  That's YOUR opinion!" replied Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Say no more about it!  PESTE!  You come to your conclusions
Title:  quickly.  What!  The cardinal sets a spy upon a gentleman, has
Title:  his letters stolen from him by means of a traitor, a brigand, a
Title:  rascal-has, with the help of this spy and thanks to this
Title:  correspondence, Chalais's throat cut, under the stupid pretext
Title:  that he wanted to kill the king and marry Monsieur to the queen!
Title:  Nobody knew a word of this enigma.  You unraveled it yesterday to
Title:  the great satisfaction of all; and while we are still gaping with
Title:  wonder at the news, you come and tell us today, 'Let us say no
Title:  more about it.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, let us talk about it, since you desire it," replied
Title:  Aramis, patiently.
Title:  
Title:  "This Rochefort," cried Porthos, "if I were the esquire of poor
Title:  Chalais, should pass a minute or two very uncomfortably with me."
Title:  
Title:  "And you--you would pass rather a sad quarter-hour with the Red
Title:  Duke," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, the Red Duke!  Bravo!  Bravo!  The Red Duke!" cried Porthos,
Title:  clapping his hands and nodding his head.  "The Red Duke is
Title:  capital.  I'll circulate that saying, be assured, my dear fellow.
Title:  Who says this Aramis is not a wit?  What a misfortune it is you
Title:  did not follow your first vocation; what a delicious abbe you
Title:  would have made!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, it's only a temporary postponement," replied Aramis; "I
Title:  shall be one someday.  You very well know, Porthos, that I
Title:  continue to study theology for that purpose."
Title:  
Title:  "He will be one, as he says," cried Porthos; "he will be one,
Title:  sooner or later."
Title:  
Title:  "Sooner." said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "He only waits for one thing to determine him to resume his
Title:  cassock, which hangs behind his uniform," said another Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "What is he waiting for?" asked another.
Title:  
Title:  "Only till the queen has given an heir to the crown of France."
Title:  
Title:  "No jesting upon that subject, gentlemen," said Porthos; "thank
Title:  God the queen is still of an age to give one!"
Title:  
Title:  "They say that Monsieur de Buckingham is in France," replied
Title:  Aramis, with a significant smile which gave to this sentence,
Title:  apparently so simple, a tolerably scandalous meaning.
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis, my good friend, this time you are wrong," interrupted
Title:  Porthos.  "Your wit is always leading you beyond bounds; if
Title:  Monsieur de Treville heard you, you would repent of speaking
Title:  thus."
Title:  
Title:  "Are you going to give me a lesson, Porthos?" cried Aramis, from
Title:  whose usually mild eye a flash passed like lightning.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear fellow, be a Musketeer or an abbe.  Be one or the other,
Title:  but not both,"  replied Porthos.  "You know what Athos told you
Title:  the other day; you eat at everybody's mess.  Ah, don't be angry,
Title:  I beg of you, that would be useless; you know what is agreed upon
Title:  between you, Athos and me.  You go to Madame d'Aguillon's, and
Title:  you pay your court to her; you go to Madame de Bois-Tracy's, the
Title:  cousin of Madame de Chevreuse, and you pass for being far
Title:  advanced in the good graces of that lady.  Oh, good Lord!  Don't
Title:  trouble yourself to reveal your good luck; no one asks for your
Title:  secret-all the world knows your discretion.  But since you possess
Title:  that virtue, why the devil don't you make use of it with respect
Title:  to her Majesty?  Let whoever likes talk of the king and the
Title:  cardinal, and how he likes; but the queen is sacred, and if
Title:  anyone speaks of her, let it be respectfully."
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos, you are as vain as Narcissus; I plainly tell you so,"
Title:  replied Aramis.  "You know I hate moralizing, except when it is
Title:  done by Athos.  As to you, good sir, you wear too magnificent a
Title:  baldric to be strong on that head.  I will be an abbe if it suits
Title:  me.  In the meanwhile I am a Musketeer; in that quality I say
Title:  what I please, and at this moment it pleases me to say that you
Title:  weary me."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis!"
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos!"
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen! Gentlemen!" cried the surrounding group.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Treville awaits Monsieur d'Artagnan," cried a
Title:  servant, throwing open the door of the cabinet.
Title:  
Title:  At this announcement, during which the door remained open,
Title:  everyone became mute, and amid the general silence the young man
Title:  crossed part of the length of the antechamber, and entered the
Title:  apartment of the captain of the Musketeers, congratulating
Title:  himself with all his heart at having so narrowly escaped the end
Title:  of this strange quarrel.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  3  THE AUDIENCE
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville was at the moment in rather ill-humor,
Title:  nevertheless he saluted the young man politely, who bowed to the
Title:  very ground; and he smiled on receiving d'Artagnan's response,
Title:  the Bearnese accent of which recalled to him at the same time
Title:  his youth and his country--a double remembrance which makes a man
Title:  smile at all ages; but stepping toward the antechamber and making
Title:  a sign to d'Artagnan with his hand, as if to ask his permission
Title:  to finish with others before he began with him, he called three
Title:  times, with a louder voice at each time, so that he ran through
Title:  the intervening tones between the imperative accent and the angry
Title:  accent.
Title:  
Title:  "Athos!  Porthos!  Aramis!"
Title:  
Title:  The two Musketeers with whom we have already made acquaintance,
Title:  and who answered to the last of these three names, immediately
Title:  quitted the group of which they had formed a part, and advanced
Title:  toward the cabinet, the door of which closed after them as soon
Title:  as they had entered.  Their appearance, although it was not quite
Title:  at ease, excited by its carelessness, at once full of dignity and
Title:  submission, the admiration of d'Artagnan, who beheld in these two
Title:  men demigods, and in their leader an Olympian Jupiter, armed with
Title:  all his thunders.
Title:  
Title:  When the two Musketeers had entered; when the door was closed
Title:  behind them; when the buzzing murmur of the antechamber, to which
Title:  the summons which had been made had doubtless furnished fresh
Title:  food, had recommenced; when M. de Treville had three or four
Title:  times paced in silence, and with a frowning brow, the whole
Title:  length of his cabinet, passing each time before Porthos and
Title:  Aramis, who were as upright and silent as if on parade--he
Title:  stopped all at once full in front of them, and covering them from
Title:  head to foot with an angry look, "Do you know what the king said
Title:  to me," cried he, "and that no longer ago than yesterday
Title:  evening--do you know, gentlemen?"
Title:  
Title:  "No," replied the two Musketeers, after a moment's silence, "no,
Title:  sir, we do not."
Title:  
Title:  "But I hope that you will do us the honor to tell us," added
Title:  Aramis, in his politest tone and with his most graceful bow.
Title:  
Title:  "He told me that he should henceforth recruit his Musketeers from
Title:  among the Guards of Monsieur the Cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "The Guards of the cardinal! And why so?" asked Porthos, warmly.
Title:  
Title:  "Because he plainly perceives that his piquette* stands in need
Title:  of being enlivened by a mixture of good wine."
Title:  
Title:  *A watered liquor, made from the second pressing of the grape.
Title:  
Title:  The two Musketeers reddened to the whites of their eyes.
Title:  d'Artagnan did not know where he was, and wished himself a
Title:  hundred feet underground.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," continued M. de Treville, growing warmer as he spoke,
Title:  "and his majesty was right; for, upon my honor, it is true that
Title:  the Musketeers make but a miserable figure at court.  The
Title:  cardinal related yesterday while playing with the king, with an
Title:  air of condolence very displeasing to me, that the day before
Title:  yesterday those DAMNED MUSKETEERS, those DAREDEVILS--he dwelt
Title:  upon those words with an ironical tone still more displeasing to
Title:  me--those BRAGGARTS, added he, glancing at me with his tiger-
Title:  cat's eye, had made a riot in the Rue Ferou in a cabaret, and
Title:  that a party of his Guards (I thought he was going to laugh in my
Title:  face) had been forced to arrest the rioters!  MORBLEU!  You must
Title:  know something about it.  Arrest Musketeers!  You were among
Title:  them--you were!  Don't deny it; you were recognized, and the
Title:  cardinal named you.  But it's all my fault; yes, it's all my
Title:  fault, because it is myself who selects my men.  You, Aramis, why
Title:  the devil did you ask me for a uniform when you would have been
Title:  so much better in a cassock?  And you, Porthos, do you only wear
Title:  such a fine golden baldric to suspend a sword of straw from it?
Title:  And Athos--I don't see Athos.  Where is he?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ill--" 
Title:  
Title:  "Very ill, say you? And of what malady?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is feared that it may be the smallpox, sir," replied Porthos,
Title:  desirous of taking his turn in the conversation; "and what is
Title:  serious is that it will certainly spoil his face."
Title:  
Title:  "The smallpox!  That's a great story to tell me, Porthos!  Sick
Title:  of the smallpox at his age!  No, no; but wounded without doubt,
Title:  killed, perhaps.  Ah, if I knew! S'blood!  Messieurs Musketeers,
Title:  I will not have this haunting of bad places, this quarreling in
Title:  the streets, this swordplay at the crossways; and above all, I
Title:  will not have occasion given for the cardinal's Guards, who are
Title:  brave, quiet, skillful men who never put themselves in a
Title:  position to be arrested, and who, besides, never allow themselves
Title:  to be arrested, to laugh at you!  I am sure of it--they would
Title:  prefer dying on the spot to being arrested or taking back a step.
Title:  To save yourselves, to scamper away, to flee--that is good for
Title:  the king's Musketeers!"
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis trembled with rage.  They could willingly have
Title:  strangled M. de Treville, if, at the bottom of all this, they had
Title:  not felt it was the great love he bore them which made him speak
Title:  thus.  They stamped upon the carpet with their feet; they bit
Title:  their lips till the blood came, and grasped the hilts of their
Title:  swords with all their might.  All without had heard, as we have
Title:  said, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis called, and had guessed, from M.
Title:  de Treville's tone of voice, that he was very angry about
Title:  something.  Ten curious heads were glued to the tapestry and
Title:  became pale with fury; for their ears, closely applied to the
Title:  door, did not lose a syllable of what he said, while their mouths
Title:  repeated as he went on, the insulting expressions of the captain
Title:  to all the people in the antechamber.  In an instant, from the
Title:  door of the cabinet to the street gate, the whole hotel was
Title:  boiling.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah! The king's Musketeers are arrested by the Guards of the
Title:  cardinal, are they?" continued M. de Treville, as furious at
Title:  heart as his soldiers, but emphasizing his words and plunging
Title:  them, one by one, so to say, like so many blows of a stiletto,
Title:  into the bosoms of his auditors.  "What! Six of his Eminence's
Title:  Guards arrest six of his Majesty's Musketeers! MORBLEU!  My part
Title:  is taken!  I will go straight to the louvre; I will give in my
Title:  resignation as captain of the king's Musketeers to take a
Title:  lieutenancy in the cardinal's Guards, and if he refuses me,
Title:  MORBLEU!  I will turn abbe."
Title:  
Title:  At these words, the murmur without became an explosion; nothing
Title:  was to be heard but oaths and blasphemies.  The MORBLEUS, the
Title:  SANG DIEUS, the MORTS TOUTS LES DIABLES, crossed one another in
Title:  the air.  D'Artagnan looked for some tapestry behind which he
Title:  might hide himself, and felt an immense inclination to crawl
Title:  under the table.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, my Captain," said Porthos, quite beside himself, "the
Title:  truth is that we were six against six.  But we were not captured
Title:  by fair means; and before we had time to draw our swords, two of
Title:  our party were dead, and Athos, grievously wounded, was very
Title:  little better.  For you know Athos.  Well, Captain, he endeavored
Title:  twice to get up, and fell again twice.  And we did not
Title:  surrender--no!  They dragged us away by force.  On the way we
Title:  escaped.  As for Athos, they believed him to be dead, and left him
Title:  very quiet on the field of battle, not thinking it worth the trouble
Title:  to carry him away.  That's the whole story.  What the devil,
Title:  Captain, one cannot win all one's battles!  The great Pompey lost
Title:  that of Pharsalia; and Francis the First, who was, as I have
Title:  heard say, as good as other folks, nevertheless lost the Battle
Title:  of Pavia."
Title:  
Title:  "And I have the honor of assuring you that I killed one of them
Title:  with his own sword," said Aramis; "for mine was broken at the
Title:  first parry.  Killed him, or poniarded him, sir, as is most
Title:  agreeable to you."
Title:  
Title:  "I did not know that," replied M. de Treville, in a somewhat
Title:  softened tone.  "The cardinal exaggerated, as I perceive."
Title:  
Title:  "But pray, sir," continued Aramis, who, seeing his captain become
Title:  appeased, ventured to risk a prayer, "do not say that Athos is
Title:  wounded.  He would be in despair if that should come to the ears
Title:  of the king; and as the wound is very serious, seeing that after
Title:  crossing the shoulder it penetrates into the chest, it is to be feared--"
Title:  
Title:  At this instant the tapestry was raised and a noble and handsome
Title:  head, but frightfully pale, appeared under the fringe.
Title:  
Title:  "Athos!" cried the two Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  "Athos!" repeated M. de Treville himself.
Title:  
Title:  "You have sent for me, sir," said Athos to M. de Treville, in a
Title:  feeble yet perfectly calm voice, "you have sent for me, as my
Title:  comrades inform me, and I have hastened to receive your orders.
Title:  I am here; what do you want with me?"
Title:  
Title:  And at these words, the Musketeer, in irreproachable costume,
Title:  belted as usual, with a tolerably firm step, entered the cabinet.
Title:  M. de Treville, moved to the bottom of his heart by this proof of
Title:  courage, sprang toward him.
Title:  
Title:  "I was about to say to these gentlemen," added he, "that I forbid
Title:  my Musketeers to expose their lives needlessly; for brave men are
Title:  very dear to the king, and the king knows that his Musketeers are
Title:  the bravest on the earth.  Your hand, Athos!"
Title:
