Title:  And without waiting for the answer of the newcomer to this proof
Title:  of affection, M. de Treville seized his right hand and pressed it
Title:  with all his might, without perceiving that Athos, whatever might
Title:  be his self-command, allowed a slight murmur of pain to escape
Title:  him, and if possible, grew paler than he was before.
Title:  
Title:  The door had remained open, so strong was the excitement produced
Title:  by the arrival of Athos, whose wound, though kept as a secret,
Title:  was known to all.  A burst of satisfaction hailed the last words
Title:  of the captain; and two or three heads, carried away by the
Title:  enthusiasm of the moment, appeared through the openings of the
Title:  tapestry.  M. de Treville was about to reprehend this breach of
Title:  the rules of etiquette, when he felt the hand of Athos, who had
Title:  rallied all his energies to contend against pain, at length
Title:  overcome by it, fell upon the floor as if he were dead.
Title:  
Title:  "A surgeon!" cried M. de Treville, "mine! The king's! The best! A
Title:  surgeon! Or, s'blood, my brave Athos will die!"
Title:  
Title:  At the cries of M. de Treville, the whole assemblage rushed into
Title:  the cabinet, he not thinking to shut the door against anyone, and
Title:  all crowded round the wounded man.  But all this eager attention
Title:  might have been useless if the doctor so loudly called for
Title:  had not chanced to be in the hotel.  He pushed through the crowd,
Title:  approached Athos, still insensible, and as all this noise and
Title:  commotion inconvenienced him greatly, he required, as the first
Title:  and most urgent thing, that the Musketeer should be carried into
Title:  an adjoining chamber.  Immediately M. de Treville opened and
Title:  pointed the way to Porthos and Aramis, who bore their comrade in
Title:  their arms.  Behind this group walked the surgeon; and behind the
Title:  surgeon the door closed.
Title:  
Title:  The cabinet of M. de Treville, generally held so sacred, became
Title:  in an instant the annex of the antechamber.  Everyone spoke,
Title:  harangued, and vociferated, swearing, cursing, and consigning the
Title:  cardinal and his Guards to all the devils.
Title:  
Title:  An instant after, Porthos and Aramis re-entered, the surgeon and
Title:  M. de Treville alone remaining with the wounded.
Title:  
Title:  At length, M. de Treville himself returned.  The injured man had
Title:  recovered his senses.  The surgeon declared that the situation of
Title:  the Musketeer had nothing in it to render his friends uneasy, his
Title:  weakness having been purely and simply caused by loss of blood.
Title:  
Title:  Then M. de Treville made a sign with his hand, and all retired
Title:  except d'Artagnan, who did not forget that he had an audience,
Title:  and with the tenacity of a Gascon remained in his place.
Title:  
Title:  When all had gone out and the door was closed, M. de Treville, on
Title:  turning round, found himself alone with the young man.  The event
Title:  which had occurred had in some degree broken the thread of his
Title:  ideas.  He inquired what was the will of his persevering visitor.
Title:  d'Artagnan then repeated his name, and in an instant recovering
Title:  all his remembrances of the present and the past, M. de Treville
Title:  grasped the situation.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon me," said he, smiling, "pardon me my dear compatriot, but
Title:  I had wholly forgotten you.  But what help is there for it!  A
Title:  captain is nothing but a father of a family, charged with even a
Title:  greater responsibility than the father of an ordinary family.
Title:  Soldiers are big children; but as I maintain that the orders of
Title:  the king, and more particularly the orders of the cardinal,
Title:  should be executed--"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan could not restrain a smile.  By this smile M. de
Title:  Treville judged that he had not to deal with a fool, and changing
Title:  the conversation, came straight to the point.
Title:  
Title:  "I respected your father very much," said he.  "What can I do for
Title:  the son?  Tell me quickly; my time is not my own."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said d'Artagnan, "on quitting Tarbes and coming
Title:  hither, it was my intention to request of you, in remembrance of
Title:  the friendship which you have not forgotten, the uniform of a
Title:  Musketeer; but after all that I have seen during the last two
Title:  hours, I comprehend that such a favor is enormous, and tremble
Title:  lest I should not merit it."
Title:  
Title:  "It is indeed a favor, young man," replied M. de Treville, "but
Title:  it may not be so far beyond your hopes as you believe, or rather
Title:  as you appear to believe.  But his majesty's decision is always
Title:  necessary; and I inform you with regret that no one becomes a
Title:  Musketeer without the preliminary ordeal of several campaigns,
Title:  certain brilliant actions, or a service of two years in some
Title:  other regiment less favored than ours."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan bowed without replying, feeling his desire to don the
Title:  Musketeer's uniform vastly increased by the great difficulties
Title:  which preceded the attainment of it.
Title:  
Title:  "But," continued M. de Treville, fixing upon his compatriot a
Title:  look so piercing that it might be said he wished to read the
Title:  thoughts of his heart, "on account of my old companion, your
Title:  father, as I have said, I will do something for you, young man.
Title:  Our recruits from Bearn are not generally very rich, and I have
Title:  no reason to think matters have much changed in this respect
Title:  since I left the province.  I dare say you have not brought too
Title:  large a stock of money with you?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan drew himself up with a proud air which plainly said,
Title:  "I ask alms of no man."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, that's very well, young man," continued M. de Treville,
Title:  "that's all very well.  I know these airs; I myself came to Paris
Title:  with four crowns in my purse, and would have fought with anyone
Title:  who dared to tell me I was not in a condition to purchase the
Title:  Louvre."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan's bearing became still more imposing.  Thanks to the
Title:  sale of his horse, he commenced his career with four more crowns
Title:  than M. de Treville possessed at the commencement of his.
Title:  
Title:  "You ought, I say, then, to husband the means you have, however
Title:  large the sum may be; but you ought also to endeavor to perfect
Title:  yourself in the exercises becoming a gentleman.  I will write a
Title:  letter today to the Director of the Royal Academy, and tomorrow
Title:  he will admit you without any expense to yourself.  Do not refuse
Title:  this little service.  Our best-born and richest gentlemen
Title:  sometimes solicit it without being able to obtain it.  You will
Title:  learn horsemanship, swordsmanship in all its branches, and
Title:  dancing.  You will make some desirable acquaintances; and from
Title:  time to time you can call upon me, just to tell me how you are getting
Title:  on, and to say whether I can be of further service to you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, stranger as he was to all the manners of a court,
Title:  could not but perceive a little coldness in this reception.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, sir," said he, "I cannot but perceive how sadly I miss the
Title:  letter of introduction which my father gave me to present to
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "I certainly am surprised," replied M. de Treville, "that you
Title:  should undertake so long a journey without that necessary
Title:  passport, the sole resource of us poor Bearnese."
Title:  
Title:  "I had one, sir, and, thank God, such as I could wish," cried
Title:  d'Artagnan; "but it was perfidiously stolen from me."
Title:  
Title:  He then related the adventure of Meung, described the unknown
Title:  gentleman with the greatest minuteness, and all with a warmth and
Title:  truthfulness that delighted M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "This is all very strange," said M. de Treville, after meditating
Title:  a minute; "you mentioned my name, then, aloud?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sir, I certainly committed that imprudence; but why should
Title:  I have done otherwise?  A name like yours must be as a buckler to
Title:  me on my way.  Judge if I should not put myself under its
Title:  protection."
Title:  
Title:  Flattery was at that period very current, and M. de Treville
Title:  loved incense as well as a king, or even a cardinal.  He could
Title:  not refrain from a smile of visible satisfaction; but this smile
Title:  soon disappeared, and returning to the adventure of Meung, "Tell
Title:  me," continued he, "had not this gentlemen a slight scar on his
Title:  cheek?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, such a one as would be made by the grazing of a ball."
Title:  
Title:  "Was he not a fine-looking man?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Of lofty stature."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Of complexion and brown hair?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, that is he; how is it, sir, that you are acquainted
Title:  with this man?  If I ever find him again--and I will find him, I
Title:  swear, were it in hell!"
Title:  
Title:  "He was waiting for a woman," continued Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "He departed immediately after having conversed for a minute with
Title:  her whom he awaited."
Title:  
Title:  "You know not the subject of their conversation?"
Title:  
Title:  "He gave her a box, told her not to open it except in London."
Title:  
Title:  "Was this woman English?"
Title:  
Title:  "He called her Milady."
Title:  
Title:  "It is he; it must be he!"  murmured Treville.  "I believed him
Title:  still at Brussels."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, sir, if you know who this man is," cried d'Artagnan, "tell
Title:  me who he is, and whence he is.  I will then release you from all
Title:  your promises--even that of procuring my admission into the
Title:  Musketeers; for before everything, I wish to avenge myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Beware, young man!"  cried Treville.  "If you see him coming on
Title:  one side of the street, pass by on the other.  Do not cast
Title:  yourself against such a rock; he would break you like glass."
Title:  
Title:  "That will not prevent me," replied d'Artagnan, "if ever I find
Title:  him."
Title:  
Title:  "In the meantime," said Treville, "seek him not--if I have a
Title:  right to advise you."
Title:  
Title:  All at once the captain stopped, as if struck by a sudden
Title:  suspicion.  This great hatred which the young traveler manifested
Title:  so loudly for this man, who--a rather improbable thing--had
Title:  stolen his father's letter from him--was there not some perfidy
Title:  concealed under this hatred?  Might not this young man be sent by
Title:  his Eminence?  Might he not have come for the purpose of laying a
Title:  snare for him?  This pretended d'Artagnan--was he not an emissary
Title:  of the cardinal, whom the cardinal sought to introduce into
Title:  Treville's house, to place near him, to win his confidence, and
Title:  afterward to ruin him as had been done in a thousand other
Title:  instances?  He fixed his eyes upon d'Artagnan even more earnestly
Title:  than before.  He was moderately reassured however, by the aspect
Title:  of that countenance, full of astute intelligence and affected
Title:  humility.  "I know he is a Gascon," reflected he, "but he may be
Title:  one for the cardinal as well as for me.  Let us try him."
Title:  
Title:  "My friend," said he, slowly, "I wish, as the son of an ancient
Title:  friend--for I consider this story of the lost letter perfectly
Title:  true--I wish, I say, in order to repair the coldness you may have
Title:  remarked in my reception of you, to discover to you the secrets
Title:  of our policy.  The king and the cardinal are the best of
Title:  friends; their apparent bickerings are only feints to deceive
Title:  fools.  I am not willing that a compatriot, a handsome cavalier,
Title:  a brave youth, quite fit to make his way, should become the dupe
Title:  of all these artifices and fall into the snare after the example
Title:  of so many others who have been ruined by it.  Be assured that I
Title:  am devoted to both these all-powerful masters, and that my
Title:  earnest endeavors have no other aim than the service of the king,
Title:  and also the cardinal--one of the most illustrious geniuses that
Title:  France has ever produced.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, young man, regulate your conduct accordingly; and if you
Title:  entertain, whether from your family, your relations, or even from
Title:  your instincts, any of these enmities which we see constantly
Title:  breaking out against the cardinal, bid me adieu and let us
Title:  separate.  I will aid you in many ways, but without attaching you
Title:  to my person.  I hope that my frankness at least will make you my
Title:  friend; for you are the only young man to whom I have hitherto
Title:  spoken as I have done to you."
Title:  
Title:  Treville said to himself:  "If the cardinal has set this young
Title:  fox upon me, he will certainly not have failed--he, who knows how
Title:  bitterly I execrate him--to tell his spy that the best means of
Title:  making his court to me is to rail at him.  Therefore, in spite of
Title:  all my protestations, if it be as I suspect, my cunning gossip
Title:  will assure me that he holds his Eminence in horror."
Title:  
Title:  It, however, proved otherwise.  D'Artagnan answered, with the
Title:  greatest simplicity:  "I came to Paris with exactly such
Title:  intentions.  My father advised me to stoop to nobody but the
Title:  king, the cardinal, and yourself--whom he considered the first
Title:  three personages in France."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan added M. de Treville to the others, as may be
Title:  perceived; but he thought this addition would do no harm.
Title:  
Title:  "I have the greatest veneration for the cardinal," continued he,
Title:  "and the most profound respect for his actions.  So much the
Title:  better for me, sir, if you speak to me, as you say, with
Title:  frankness--for then you will do me the honor to esteem the
Title:  resemblance of our opinions; but if you have entertained any
Title:  doubt, as naturally you may, I feel that I am ruining myself by
Title:  speaking the truth.  But I still trust you will not esteem me the
Title:  less for it, and that is my object beyond all others."
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville was surprised to the greatest degree.  So much
Title:  penetration, so much frankness, created admiration, but did not
Title:  entirely remove his suspicions.  The more this young man was
Title:  superior to others, the more he was to be dreaded if he meant to
Title:  deceive him; "You are an honest youth; but at the present moment
Title:  I can only do for you that which I just now offered.  My hotel
Title:  will be always open to you.  Hereafter, being able to ask for me
Title:  at all hours, and consequently to take advantage of all
Title:  opportunities, you will probably obtain that which you desire."
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say," replied d'Artagnan, "that you will wait until I
Title:  have proved myself worthy of it.  Well, be assured," added he,
Title:  with the familiarity of a Gascon, "you shall not wait long."  And
Title:  he bowed in order to retire, and as if he considered the future
Title:  in his own hands.
Title:  
Title:  "But wait a minute," said M. de Treville, stopping him.  "I
Title:  promised you a letter for the director of the Academy.  Are you
Title:  too proud to accept it, young gentleman?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, sir," said d'Artagnan; "and I will guard it so carefully
Title:  that I will be sworn it shall arrive at its address, and woe be
Title:  to him who shall attempt to take it from me!"
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville smiled at this flourish; and leaving his young man
Title:  compatriot in the embrasure of the window, where they had talked
Title:  together, he seated himself at a table in order to write the
Title:  promised letter of recommendation.  While he was doing this,
Title:  d'Artagnan, having no better employment, amused himself with
Title:  beating a march upon the window and with looking at the
Title:  Musketeers, who went away, one after another, following them with
Title:  his eyes until they disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville, after having written the letter, sealed it, and
Title:  rising, approached the young man in order to give it to him.  But
Title:  at the very moment when d'Artagnan stretched out his hand to
Title:  receive it, M. de Treville was highly astonished to see his
Title:  protege make a sudden spring, become crimson with passion, and
Title:  rush from the cabinet crying, "S'blood, he shall not escape me
Title:  this time!"
Title:  
Title:  "And who?" asked M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "He, my thief!" replied d'Artagnan.  "Ah, the traitor!" and he
Title:  disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil take the madman!" murmured M. de Treville, "unless,"
Title:  added he, "this is a cunning mode of escaping, seeing that he had
Title:  failed in his purpose!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  4  THE SHOULDER OF ATHOS, THE BALDRIC OF PORTHOS AND THE
Title:  HANDKERCHIEF OF ARAMIS
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, in a state of fury, crossed the antechamber at three
Title:  bounds, and was darting toward the stairs, which he reckoned upon
Title:  descending four at a time, when, in his heedless course, he ran
Title:  head foremost against a Musketeer who was coming out of one of M.
Title:  de Treville's private rooms, and striking his shoulder violently,
Title:  made him utter a cry, or rather a howl.
Title:  
Title:  "Excuse me," said d'Artagnan, endeavoring to resume his course,
Title:  "excuse me, but I am in a hurry."
Title:  
Title:  Scarcely had he descended the first stair, when a hand of iron
Title:  seized him by the belt and stopped him.
Title:  
Title:  "You are in a hurry?" said the Musketeer, as pale as a sheet.
Title:  "Under that pretense you run against me!  You say. 'Excuse me,'
Title:  and you believe that is sufficient?  Not at all my young man.  Do
Title:  you fancy because you have heard Monsieur de Treville speak to us
Title:  a little cavalierly today that other people are to treat us as he
Title:  speaks to us?  Undeceive yourself, comrade, you are not Monsieur
Title:  de Treville."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!" replied d'Artagnan, recognizing Athos, who, after the
Title:  dressing performed by the doctor, was returning to his own
Title:  apartment.  "I did not do it intentionally, and not doing it
Title:  intentionally, I said 'Excuse me.'  It appears to me that this is
Title:  quite enough.  I repeat to you, however, and this time on my word
Title:  of honor--I think perhaps too often--that I am in haste, great
Title:  haste.  Leave your hold, then, I beg of you, and let me go where
Title:  my business calls me."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said Athos, letting him go, "you are not polite; it
Title:  is easy to perceive that you come from a distance."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had already strode down three or four stairs, but at
Title:  Athos's last remark he stopped short.
Title:  
Title:  "MORBLEU, monsieur!" said he, "however far I may come, it is not
Title:  you who can give me a lesson in good manners, I warn you."
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  If I were not in such haste, and if I were not running
Title:  after someone," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Man-in-a-hurry, you can find me without running--ME,
Title:  you understand?"
Title:  
Title:  "And where, I pray you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Near the Carmes-Deschaux."
Title:  
Title:  "At what hour?"
Title:  
Title:  "About noon."
Title:  
Title:  "About noon?  That will do; I will be there."
Title:  
Title:  "Endeavor not to make me wait; for at quarter past twelve I will
Title:  cut off your ears as you run."
Title:  
Title:  "Good!" cried d'Artagnan, "I will be there ten minutes before
Title:  twelve."  And he set off running as if the devil possessed him,
Title:  hoping that he might yet find the stranger, whose slow pace could
Title:  not have carried him far.
Title:  
Title:  But at the street gate, Porthos was talking with the soldier on
Title:  guard.  Between the two talkers there was just enough room for a
Title:  man to pass.  D'Artagnan thought it would suffice for him, and he
Title:  sprang forward like a dart between them.  But d'Artagnan had
Title:  reckoned without the wind.  As he was about to pass, the wind
Title:  blew out Porthos's long cloak, and d'Artagnan rushed straight
Title:  into the middle of it.  Without doubt, Porthos had reasons for
Title:  not abandoning this part of his vestments, for instead of
Title:  quitting his hold on the flap in his hand, he pulled it toward
Title:  him, so that d'Artagnan rolled himself up in the velvet by a
Title:  movement of rotation explained by the persistency of Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, hearing the Musketeer swear, wished to escape from
Title:  the cloak, which blinded him, and sought to find his way from
Title:  under the folds of it.  He was particularly anxious to avoid
Title:  marring the freshness of the magnificent baldric we are
Title:  acquainted with; but on timidly opening his eyes, he found
Title:  himself with his nose fixed between the two shoulders of
Title:  Porthos--that is to say, exactly upon the baldric.
Title:  
Title:  Alas, like most things in this world which have nothing in their
Title:  favor but appearances, the baldric was glittering with gold in
Title:  the front, but was nothing but simple buff behind.  Vainglorious
Title:  as he was, Porthos could not afford to have a baldric wholly of
Title:  gold, but had at least half.  One could comprehend the necessity
Title:  of the cold and the urgency of the cloak.
Title:  
Title:  "Bless me!" cried Porthos, making strong efforts to disembarrass
Title:  himself of d'Artagnan, who was wriggling about his back; "you
Title:  must be mad to run against people in this manner."
Title:  
Title:  "Excuse me," said d'Artagnan, reappearing under the shoulder of
Title:  the giant, "but I am in such haste--I was running after someone
Title:  and--"
Title:  
Title:  "And do you always forget your eyes when you run?" asked Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "No," replied d'Artagnan, piqued, "and thanks to my eyes, I can
Title:  see what other people cannot see."
Title:  
Title:  Whether Porthos understood him or did not understand him, giving
Title:  way to his anger, "Monsieur," said he, "you stand a chance of
Title:  getting chastised if you rub Musketeers in this fashion."
Title:  
Title:  "Chastised, Monsieur!" said d'Artagnan, "the expression is
Title:  strong."
Title:  
Title:  "It is one that becomes a man accustomed to look his enemies in
Title:  the face."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, PARDIEU!  I know full well that you don't turn your back to
Title:  yours."
Title:  
Title:  And the young man, delighted with his joke, went away laughing
Title:  loudly.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos foamed with rage, and made a movement to rush after
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Presently, presently," cried the latter, "when you haven't your
Title:  cloak on."
Title:  
Title:  "At one o'clock, then, behind the Luxembourg."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well, at one o'clock, then," replied d'Artagnan, turning
Title:  the angle of the street.
Title:  
Title:  But neither in the street he had passed through, nor in the one
Title:  which his eager glance pervaded, could he see anyone; however
Title:  slowly the stranger had walked, he was gone on his way, or
Title:  perhaps had entered some house.  D'Artagnan inquired of everyone
Title:  he met with, went down to the ferry, came up again by the Rue de
Title:  Seine, and the Red Cross; but nothing, absolutely nothing!  This
Title:  chase was, however, advantageous to him in one sense, for in
Title:  proportion as the perspiration broke from his forehead, his heart
Title:  began to cool.
Title:  
Title:  He began to reflect upon the events that had passed; they were
Title:  numerous and inauspicious.  It was scarcely eleven o'clock in the
Title:  morning, and yet this morning had already brought him into
Title:  disgrace with M. de Treville, who could not fail to think the
Title:  manner in which d'Artagnan had left him a little cavalier.
Title:  
Title:  Besides this, he had drawn upon himself two good duels with two
Title:  men, each capable of killing three d'Artagnans--with two
Title:  Musketeers, in short, with two of those beings whom he esteemed
Title:  so greatly that he placed them in his mind and heart above all
Title:  other men.
Title:  
Title:  The outlook was sad.  Sure of being killed by Athos, it may
Title:  easily be understood that the young man was not very uneasy about
Title:  Porthos.  As hope, however, is the last thing extinguished in the
Title:  heart of man, he finished by hoping that he might survive, even
Title:  though with terrible wounds, in both these duels; and in case of
Title:  surviving, he made the following reprehensions upon his own
Title:  conduct:
Title:  
Title:  "What a madcap I was, and what a stupid fellow I am!  That brave
Title:  and unfortunate Athos was wounded on that very shoulder against
Title:  which I must run head foremost, like a ram.  The only thing that
Title:  astonishes me is that he did not strike me dead at once.  He had
Title:  good cause to do so; the pain I gave him must have been
Title:  atrocious.  As to Porthos--oh, as to Porthos, faith, that's a
Title:  droll affair!"
Title:  
Title:  And in spite of himself, the young man began to laugh aloud,
Title:  looking round carefully, however, to see that his solitary laugh,
Title:  without a cause in the eyes of passers-by, offended no one.
Title:  
Title:  "As to Porthos, that is certainly droll; but I am not the less a
Title:  giddy fool.  Are people to be run against without warning?  No!
Title:  And have I any right to go and peep under their cloaks to see
Title:  what is not there?  He would have pardoned me, he would certainly
Title:  have pardoned me, if I had not said anything to him about that
Title:  cursed baldric--in ambiguous words, it is true, but rather drolly
Title:  ambiguous.  Ah, cursed Gascon that I am, I get from one hobble
Title:  into another.  Friend d'Artagnan," continued he, speaking to
Title:  himself with all the amenity that he thought due himself, "if you
Title:  escape, of which there is not much chance, I would advise you to
Title:  practice perfect politeness for the future.  You must henceforth
Title:  be admired and quoted as a model of it.  To be obliging and
Title:  polite does not necessarily make a man a coward.  Look at Aramis,
Title:  now; Aramis is mildness and grace personified.  Well, did anybody
Title:  ever dream of calling Aramis a coward?  No, certainly not, and
Title:  from this moment I will endeavor to model myself after him.  Ah!
Title:  That's strange!  Here he is!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, walking and soliloquizing, had arrived within a few
Title:  steps of the hotel d'Arguillon and in front of that hotel
Title:  perceived Aramis, chatting gaily with three gentlemen; but as he
Title:  had not forgotten that it was in presence of this young man that
Title:  M. de Treville had been so angry in the morning, and as a witness
Title:  of the rebuke the Musketeers had received was not likely to be at
Title:  all agreeable, he pretended not to see him.  D'Artagnan, on the
Title:  contrary, quite full of his plans of conciliation and courtesy,
Title:  approached the young men with a profound bow, accompanied by a
Title:  most gracious smile.  All four, besides, immediately broke off
Title:  their conversation.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was not so dull as not to perceive that he was one too
Title:  many; but he was not sufficiently broken into the fashions of the
Title:  gay world to know how to extricate himself gallantly from a false
Title:  position, like that of a man who begins to mingle with people he
Title:  is scarcely acquainted with and in a conversation that does not
Title:  concern him.  He was seeking in his mind, then, for the least
Title:  awkward means of retreat, when he remarked that Aramis had let
Title:  his handkerchief fall, and by mistake, no doubt, had placed his
Title:  foot upon it.  This appeared to be a favorable opportunity to
Title:  repair his intrusion.  He stooped, and with the most gracious air
Title:  he could assume, drew the handkerchief from under the foot of the
Title:  Musketeer in spite of the efforts the latter made to detain it,
Title:  and holding it out to him, said, "I believe, monsieur, that this
Title:  is a handkerchief you would be sorry to lose?"
Title:  
Title:  The handkerchief was indeed richly embroidered, and had a coronet
Title:  and arms at one of its corners.  Aramis blushed excessively, and
Title:  snatched rather than took the handkerchief from the hand of the
Title:  Gascon.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" cried one of the Guards, "will you persist in saying,
Title:  most discreet Aramis, that you are not on good terms with Madame
Title:  de Bois-Tracy, when that gracious lady has the kindness to lend
Title:  you one of her handkerchiefs?"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis darted at d'Artagnan one of those looks which inform a man
Title:  that he has acquired a mortal enemy.  Then, resuming his mild
Title:  air, "You are deceived, gentlemen," said he, "this handkerchief
Title:  is not mine, and I cannot fancy why Monsieur has taken it into
Title:  his head to offer it to me rather than to one of you; and as a
Title:  proof of what I say, here is mine in my pocket."
Title:  
Title:  So saying, he pulled out his own handkerchief, likewise a very
Title:  elegant handkerchief, and of fine cambric--though cambric was
Title:  dear at the period--but a handkerchief without embroidery and
Title:  without arms, only ornamented with a single cipher, that of its
Title:  proprietor.
Title:  
Title:  This time d'Artagnan was not hasty.  He perceived his mistake;
Title:  but the friends of Aramis were not at all convinced by his
Title:  denial, and one of them addressed the young Musketeer with
Title:  affected seriousness.  "If it were as you pretend it is," said
Title:  he, "I should be forced, my dear Aramis, to reclaim it myself;
Title:  for, as you very well know, Bois-Tracy is an intimate friend of
Title:  mine, and I cannot allow the property of his wife to be sported
Title:  as a trophy."
Title:  
Title:  "You make the demand badly," replied Aramis; "and while
Title:  acknowledging the justice of your reclamation, I refuse it on
Title:  account of the form."
Title:  
Title:  "The fact is," hazarded d'Artagnan, timidly, "I did not see the
Title:  handkerchief fall from the pocket of Monsieur Aramis.  He had his
Title:  foot upon it, that is all; and I thought from having his foot
Title:  upon it the handkerchief was his."
Title:  
Title:  "And you were deceived, my dear sir," replied Aramis, coldly,
Title:  very little sensible to the reparation.  Then turning toward that
Title:  one of the guards who had declared himself the friend of Bois-
Title:  Tracy, "Besides," continued he, "I have reflected, my dear
Title:  intimate of Bois-Tracy, that I am not less tenderly his friend
Title:  than you can possibly be; so that decidedly this handkerchief is
Title:  as likely to have fallen from your pocket as mine."
Title:  
Title:  "No, upon my honor!" cried his Majesty's Guardsman.
Title:  
Title:  "You are about to swear upon your honor and I upon my word, and
Title:  then it will be pretty evident that one of us will have lied.
Title:  Now, here, Montaran, we will do better than that--let each take a
Title:  half."
Title:  
Title:  "Of the handkerchief?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Perfectly just," cried the other two Guardsmen, "the judgment of
Title:  King Solomon!  Aramis, you certainly are full of wisdom!"
Title:  
Title:  The young men burst into a laugh, and as may be supposed, the
Title:  affair had no other sequel.  In a moment or two the conversation
Title:  ceased, and the three Guardsmen and the Musketeer, after having
Title:  cordially shaken hands, separated, the Guardsmen going one way
Title:  and Aramis another.
Title:  
Title:  "Now is my time to make peace with this gallant man," said
Title:  d'Artagnan to himself, having stood on one side during the whole
Title:  of the latter part of the conversation; and with this good
Title:  feeling drawing near to Aramis, who was departing without paying
Title:  any attention to him, "Monsieur," said he, "you will excuse me, I
Title:  hope."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur," interrupted Aramis, "permit me to observe to you
Title:  that you have not acted in this affair as a gallant man ought."
Title:  
Title:  "What, monsieur!" cried d'Artagnan, "and do you suppose--"
Title:  
Title:  "I suppose, monsieur that you are not a fool, and that you knew
Title:  very well, although coming from Gascony, that people do not tread
Title:  upon handkerchiefs without a reason.  What the devil!  Paris is
Title:  not paved with cambric!"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, you act wrongly in endeavoring to mortify me," said
Title:  d'Artagnan, in whom the natural quarrelsome spirit began to speak
Title:  more loudly than his pacific resolutions.  "I am from Gascony, it
Title:  is true; and since you know it, there is no occasion to tell you
Title:  that Gascons are not very patient, so that when they have begged
Title:  to be excused once, were it even for a folly, they are convinced
Title:  that they have done already at least as much again as they ought
Title:  to have done."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, what I say to you about the matter," said Aramis, "is
Title:  not for the sake of seeking a quarrel.  Thank God, I am not a
Title:  bravo!  And being a Musketeer but for a time, I only fight when I
Title:  am forced to do so, and always with great repugnance; but this
Title:  time the affair is serious, for here is a lady compromised by
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "By US, you mean!" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Why did you so maladroitly restore me the handkerchief?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why did you so awkwardly let it fall?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have said, monsieur, and I repeat, that the handkerchief did
Title:  not fall from my pocket."
Title:  
Title:  "And thereby you have lied twice, monsieur, for I saw it fall."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you take it with that tone, do you, Master Gascon?  Well, I
Title:  will teach you how to behave yourself."
Title:  
Title:  "And I will send you back to your Mass book, Master Abbe.  Draw,
Title:  if you please, and instantly--"
Title:  
Title:  "Not so, if you please, my good friend--not here, at least.  Do
Title:  you not perceive that we are opposite the Hotel d'Arguillon,
Title:  which is full of the cardinal's creatures?  How do I know that
Title:  this is not his Eminence who has honored you with the commission
Title:  to procure my head?  Now, I entertain a ridiculous partiality for
Title:  my head, it seems to suit my shoulders so correctly.  I wish to
Title:  kill you, be at rest as to that, but to kill you quietly in a
Title:  snug, remote place, where you will not be able to boast of your
Title:  death to anybody."
Title:  
Title:  "I agree, monsieur; but do not be too confident.  Take your
Title:  handkerchief; whether it belongs to you or another, you may
Title:  perhaps stand in need of it."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur is a Gascon?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes.  Monsieur does not postpone an interview through prudence?"
Title:  
Title:  "Prudence, monsieur, is a virtue sufficiently useless to
Title:  Musketeers, I know, but indispensable to churchmen; and as I am
Title:  only a Musketeer provisionally, I hold it good to be prudent.  At
Title:  two o'clock I shall have the honor of expecting you at the hotel
Title:  of Monsieur de Treville.  There I will indicate to you the best
Title:  place and time."
Title:  
Title:  The two young men bowed and separated, Aramis ascending the
Title:  street which led to the Luxembourg, while d'Artagnan, perceiving
Title:  the appointed hour was approaching, took the road to the
Title:  Carmes-Deschaux, saying to himself, "Decidedly I can't draw back;
Title:  but at least, if I am killed, I shall be killed by a Musketeer."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  5  THE KING'S MUSKETEERS AND THE CARDINAL'S GUARDS
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was acquainted with nobody in Paris.  He went
Title:  therefore to his appointment with Athos without a second,
Title:  determined to be satisfied with those his adversary should
Title:  choose.  Besides, his intention was formed to make the brave
Title:  Musketeer all suitable apologies, but without meanness or
Title:  weakness, fearing that might result from this duel which
Title:  generally results from an affair of this kind, when a young and
Title:  vigorous man fights with an adversary who is wounded and
Title:  weakened--if conquered, he doubles the triumph of his antagonist;
Title:  if a conqueror, he is accused of foul play and want of courage.
Title:  
Title:  Now, we must have badly painted the character of our adventure
Title:  seeker, or our readers must have already perceived that
Title:  d'Artagnan was not an ordinary man; therefore, while repeating to
Title:  himself that his death was inevitable, he did not make up his
Title:  mind to die quietly, as one less courageous and less restrained
Title:  might have done in his place.  He reflected upon the different
Title:  characters of men he had to fight with, and began to view his
Title:  situation more clearly.  He hoped, by means of loyal excuses, to
Title:  make a friend of Athos, whose lordly air and austere bearing
Title:  pleased him much.  He flattered himself he should be able to
Title:  frighten Porthos with the adventure of the baldric, which he
Title:  might, if not killed upon the spot, relate to everybody a recital
Title:  which, well managed, would cover Porthos with ridicule.  As to
Title:  the astute Aramis, he did not entertain much dread of him; and
Title:  supposing he should be able to get so far, he determined to
Title:  dispatch him in good style or at least, by hitting him in the
Title:  face, as Caesar recommended his soldiers do to those of Pompey,
Title:  to damage forever the beauty of which he was so proud.
Title:  
Title:  In addition to this, d'Artagnan possessed that invincible stock
Title:  of resolution which the counsels of his father had implanted in
Title:  his heart: "Endure nothing from anyone but the king, the
Title:  cardinal, and Monsieur de Treville."  He flew, then, rather than
Title:  walked, toward the convent of the Carmes Dechausses, or rather
Title:  Deschaux, as it was called at that period, a sort of building
Title:  without a window, surrounded by barren fields--an accessory to
Title:  the Preaux-Clercs, and which was generally employed as the place
Title:  for the duels of men who had no time to lose.
Title:  
Title:  When d'Artagnan arrived in sight of the bare spot of ground which
Title:  extended along the foot of the monastery, Athos had been waiting
Title:  about five minutes, and twelve o'clock was striking.  He was,
Title:  then, as punctual as the Samaritan woman, and the most rigorous
Title:  casuist with regard to duels could have nothing to say.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, who still suffered grievously from his wound, though it
Title:  had been dressed anew by M. de Treville's surgeon, was seated on
Title:  a post and waiting for his adversary with hat in hand, his
Title:  feather even touching the ground.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said Athos, "I have engaged two of my friends as
Title:  seconds; but these two friends are not yet come, at which I am
Title:  astonished, as it is not at all their custom."
Title:  
Title:  "I have no seconds on my part, monsieur," said d'Artagnan; "for
Title:  having only arrived yesterday in Paris, I as yet know no one but
Title:  Monsieur de Treville, to whom I was recommended by my father, who
Title:  has the honor to be, in some degree, one of his friends."
Title:  
Title:  Athos reflected for an instant.  "You know no one but Monsieur de
Title:  Treville?" he asked.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, I know only him."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but then," continued Athos, speaking half to himself, "if
Title:  I kill you, I shall have the air of a boy-slayer."
Title:  
Title:  "Not too much so," replied d'Artagnan, with a bow that was not
Title:  deficient in dignity, "since you do me the honor to draw a sword
Title:  with me while suffering from a wound which is very inconvenient."
Title:  
Title:  "Very inconvenient, upon my word; and you hurt me devilishly, I
Title:  can tell you.  But I will take the left hand--it is my custom in
Title:  such circumstances.  Do not fancy that I do you a favor; I use
Title:  either hand easily.  And it will be even a disadvantage to you; a
Title:  left-handed man is very troublesome to people who are not
Title:  prepared for it.  I regret I did not inform you sooner of this
Title:  circumstance."
Title:  
Title:  "You have truly, monsieur," said d'Artagnan, bowing again, "a
Title:  courtesy, for which, I assure you, I am very grateful."
Title:  
Title:  "You confuse me," replied Athos, with his gentlemanly air; "let
Title:  us talk of something else, if you please.  Ah, s'blood, how you
Title:  have hurt me!  My shoulder quite burns."
Title:  
Title:  "If you would permit me--" said d'Artagnan, with timidity.
Title:  
Title:  "What, monsieur?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have a miraculous balsam for wounds--a balsam given to me by
Title:  my mother and of which I have made a trial upon myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I am sure that in less than three days this balsam would
Title:  cure you; and at the end of three days, when you would be cured--
Title:  well, sir, it would still do me a great honor to be your man."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan spoke these words with a simplicity that did honor to
Title:  his courtesy, without throwing the least doubt upon his courage.
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU, monsieur!" said Athos, "that's a proposition that
Title:  pleases me; not that I can accept it, but a league off it savors
Title:  of the gentleman.  Thus spoke and acted the gallant knights of
Title:  the time of Charlemagne, in whom every cavalier ought to seek his
Title:  model.  Unfortunately, we do not live in the times of the great
Title:  emperor, we live in the times of the cardinal; and three days
Title:  hence, however well the secret might be guarded, it would be
Title:  known, I say, that we were to fight, and our combat would be
Title:  prevented.  I think these fellows will never come."
Title:  
Title:  "If you are in haste, monsieur," said d'Artagnan, with the same
Title:  simplicity with which a moment before he had proposed to him to
Title:  put off the duel for three days, "and if it be your will to
Title:  dispatch me at once, do not inconvenience yourself, I pray you."
Title:  
Title:  "There is another word which pleases me," cried Athos, with a
Title:  gracious nod to d'Artagnan.  "That did not come from a man
Title:  without a heart.  Monsieur, I love men of your kidney; and I
Title:  foresee plainly that if we don't kill each other, I shall
Title:  hereafter have much pleasure in your conversation.  We will wait
Title:  for these gentlemen, so please you; I have plenty of time, and it
Title:  will be more correct.  Ah, here is one of them, I believe."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, at the end of the Rue Vaugirard the gigantic Porthos
Title:  appeared.
Title:  
Title:  "What!" cried d'Artagnan, "is your first witness Monsieur
Title:  Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that disturbs you?"
Title:  
Title:  "By no means."
Title:  
Title:  "And here is the second."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan turned in the direction pointed to by Athos, and
Title:  perceived Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "What!" cried he, in an accent of greater astonishment than
Title:  before, "your second witness is Monsieur Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "Doubtless!  Are you not aware that we are never seen one without
Title:  the others, and that we are called among the Musketeers and the
Title:  Guards, at court and in the city, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, or
Title:  the Three Inseparables?  And yet, as you come from Dax or Pau--"
Title:  
Title:  "From Tarbes," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "It is probable you are ignorant of this little fact," said
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!" replied d'Artagnan, "you are well named, gentlemen;
Title:  and my adventure, if it should make any noise, will prove at
Title:  least that your union is not founded upon contrasts."
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime, Porthos had come up, waved his hand to Athos,
Title:  and then turning toward d'Artagnan, stood quite astonished.
Title:  
Title:  Let us say in passing that he had changed his baldric and
Title:  relinquished his cloak.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said he, "what does this mean?"
Title:  
Title:  "This is the gentleman I am going to fight with," said Athos,
Title:  pointing to d'Artagnan with his hand and saluting him with the
Title:  same gesture.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, it is with him I am also going to fight," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "But not before one o'clock," replied d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And I also am to fight with this gentleman," said Aramis, coming
Title:  in his turn onto the place.
Title:  
Title:  "But not until two o'clock," said d'Artagnan, with the same
Title:  calmness.
Title:  
Title:  "But what are you going to fight about, Athos?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Faith! I don't very well know.  He hurt my shoulder.  And you,
Title:  Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Faith!  I am going to fight--because I am going to fight,"
Title:  answered Porthos, reddening.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, whose keen eye lost nothing, perceived a faintly sly smile
Title:  pass over the lips of the young Gascon as he replied, "We had a
Title:  short discussion upon dress."
Title:  
Title:  "And you, Aramis?" asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, ours is a theological quarrel," replied Aramis, making a
Title:  sign to d'Artagnan to keep secret the cause of their duel.
Title:  
Title:  Athos indeed saw a second smile on the lips of d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; a passage of St. Augustine, upon which we could not agree,"
Title:  said the Gascon.
Title:  
Title:  "Decidedly, this is a clever fellow," murmured Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "And now you are assembled, gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, "permit
Title:  me to offer you my apologies."
Title:  
Title:  At this word APOLOGIES, a cloud passed over the brow of Athos, a
Title:  haughty smile curled the lip of Porthos, and a negative sign was
Title:  the reply of Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "You do not understand me, gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, throwing
Title:  up his head, the sharp and bold lines of which were at the moment
Title:  gilded by a bright ray of the sun.  "I asked to be excused in
Title:  case I should not be able to discharge my debt to all three; for
Title:  Monsieur Athos has the right to kill me first, which must much diminish
Title:  the face-value of your bill, Monsieur Porthos, and render
Title:  yours almost null, Monsieur Aramis.  And now, gentlemen, I
Title:  repeat, excuse me, but on that account only, and--on guard!"
Title:  
Title:  At these words, with the most gallant air possible, d'Artagnan
Title:  drew his sword.
Title:  
Title:  The blood had mounted to the head of d'Artagnan, and at that
Title:  moment he would have drawn his sword against all the Musketeers
Title:  in the kingdom as willingly as he now did against Athos, Porthos,
Title:  and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  It was a quarter past midday.  The sun was in its zenith, and the
Title:  spot chosen for the scene of the duel was exposed to its full
Title:  ardor.
Title:  
Title:  "It is very hot," said Athos, drawing his sword in its turn, "and
Title:  yet I cannot take off my doublet; for I just now felt my wound
Title:  begin to bleed again, and I should not like to annoy Monsieur
Title:  with the sight of blood which he has not drawn from me himself."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true, Monsieur," replied d'Artagnan, "and whether drawn
Title:  by myself or another, I assure you I shall always view with
Title:  regret the blood of so brave a gentleman.  I will therefore fight
Title:  in my doublet, like yourself."
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come, enough of such compliments!" cried Porthos.
Title:  "Remember, we are waiting for our turns."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak for yourself when you are inclined to utter such
Title:  incongruities," interrupted Aramis.  "For my part, I think what
Title:  they say is very well said, and quite worthy of two gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  "When you please, monsieur," said Athos, putting himself on
Title:  guard.
Title:  
Title:  "I waited your orders," said d'Artagnan, crossing swords.
Title:  
Title:  But scarcely had the two rapiers clashed, when a company of the
Title:  Guards of his Eminence, commanded by M. de Jussac, turned the
Title:  corner of the convent.
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal's Guards!" cried Aramis and Porthos at the same
Title:  time.  "Sheathe your swords, gentlemen, sheathe your swords!"
Title:  
Title:  But it was too late.  The two combatants had been seen in a
Title:  position which left no doubt of their intentions.
Title:  
Title:  "Halloo!" cried Jussac, advancing toward them and making a sign
Title:  to his men to do so likewise, "halloo, Musketeers?  Fighting
Title:  here, are you?  And the edicts?  What is become of them?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are very generous, gentlemen of the Guards," said Athos,
Title:  full of rancor, for Jussac was one of the aggressors of the
Title:  preceding day.  "If we were to see you fighting, I can assure you
Title:  that we would make no effort to prevent you.  Leave us alone,
Title:  then, and you will enjoy a little amusement without cost to
Title:  yourselves."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Jussac, "it is with great regret that I
Title:  pronounce the thing impossible.  Duty before everything.
Title:  Sheathe, then, if you please, and follow us."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said Aramis, parodying Jussac, "it would afford us
Title:  great pleasure to obey your polite invitation if it depended upon
Title:  ourselves; but unfortunately the thing is impossible--Monsieur de
Title:  Treville has forbidden it.  Pass on your way, then; it is the
Title:  best thing to do."
Title:  
Title:  This raillery exasperated Jussac.  "We will charge upon you,
Title:  then," said he, "if you disobey."
Title:  
Title:  "There are five of them," said Athos, half aloud, "and we are but
Title:  three; we shall be beaten again, and must die on the spot, for,
Title:  on my part, I declare I will never appear again before the
Title:  captain as a conquered man."
Title:  
Title:  Athos, Porthos, and Aramis instantly drew near one another, while
Title:  Jussac drew up his soldiers.
Title:  
Title:  This short interval was sufficient to determine d'Artagnan on the
Title:  part he was to take.  It was one of those events which decide the
Title:  life of a man; it was a choice between the king and the
Title:  cardinal--the choice made, it must be persisted in.  To fight,
Title:  that was to disobey the law, that was to risk his head, that was
Title:  to make at one blow an enemy of a minister more powerful than the
Title:  king himself.  All this young man perceived, and yet, to his
Title:  praise we speak it, he did not hesitate a second.  Turning
Title:  towards Athos and his friends, "Gentlemen," said he, "allow me to
Title:  correct your words, if you please.  You said you were but three,
Title:  but it appears to me we are four."
Title:  
Title:  "But you are not one of us," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," replied d'Artagnan; "I have not the uniform, but I
Title:  have the spirit.  My heart is that of a Musketeer; I feel it,
Title:  monsieur, and that impels me on."
Title:  
Title:  "Withdraw, young man," cried Jussac, who doubtless, by his
Title:  gestures and the expression of his countenance, had guessed
Title:  d'Artagnan's design.  "You may retire; we consent to that.  Save
Title:  your skin; begone quickly."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan did not budge.
Title:  
Title:  "Decidedly, you are a brave fellow," said Athos, pressing the
Title:  young man's hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come, choose your part," replied Jussac.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos to Aramis, "we must do something."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur is full of generosity," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  But all three reflected upon the youth of d'Artagnan, and dreaded
Title:  his inexperience.
Title:  
Title:  "We should only be three, one of whom is wounded, with the
Title:  addition of a boy," resumed Athos; "and yet it will not be the
Title:  less said we were four men."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but to yield!" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "That IS difficult," replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan comprehended their irresolution.
Title:  
Title:  "Try me, gentlemen," said he, "and I swear to you by my honor
Title:  that I will not go hence if we are conquered."
Title:  
Title:  "What is your name, my brave fellow?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, Athos, Porthos, Aramis, and d'Artagnan, forward!"
Title:  cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, gentlemen, have you decided?" cried Jussac for the third
Title:  time.
Title:  
Title:  "It is done, gentlemen," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "And what is your choice?" asked Jussac.
Title:  
Title:  "We are about to have the honor of charging you," replied Aramis,
Title:  lifting his hat with one hand and drawing his sword with the
Title:  other.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah! You resist, do you?" cried Jussac.
Title:  
Title:  "S'blood; does that astonish you?"
Title:  
Title:  And the nine combatants rushed upon each other with a fury which
Title:  however did not exclude a certain degree of method.
Title:  
Title:  Athos fixed upon a certain Cahusac, a favorite of the cardinal's.
Title:  Porthos had Bicarat, and Aramis found himself opposed to two
Title:  adversaries.  As to d'Artagnan, he sprang toward Jussac himself.
Title:  
Title:  The heart of the young Gascon beat as if it would burst through
Title:  his side--not from fear, God he thanked, he had not the shade of
Title:  it, but with emulation; he fought like a furious tiger, turning
Title:  ten times round his adversary, and changing his ground and his
Title:  guard twenty times.  Jussac was, as was then said, a fine blade,
Title:  and had had much practice; nevertheless it required all his skill
Title:  to defend himself against an adversary who, active and energetic,
Title:  departed every instant from received rules, attacking him on all
Title:  sides at once, and yet parrying like a man who had the greatest
Title:  respect for his own epidermis.
Title:  
Title:  This contest at length exhausted Jussac's patience.  Furious at
Title:  being held in check by one whom he had considered a boy, he
Title:  became warm and began to make mistakes.  D'Artagnan, who though
Title:  wanting in practice had a sound theory, redoubled his agility.
Title:  Jussac, anxious to put an end to this, springing forward, aimed a
Title:  terrible thrust at his adversary, but the latter parried it; and
Title:  while Jussac was recovering himself, glided like a serpent
Title:  beneath his blade, and passed his sword through his body.  Jussac
Title:  fell like a dead mass.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan then cast an anxious and rapid glance over the field
Title:  of battle.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis had killed one of his adversaries, but the other pressed
Title:  him warmly.  Nevertheless, Aramis was in a good situation, and
Title:  able to defend himself.
Title:  
Title:  Bicarat and Porthos had just made counterhits.  Porthos had
Title:  received a thrust through his arm, and Bicarat one through his
Title:  thigh.  But neither of these two wounds was serious, and they
Title:  only fought more earnestly.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, wounded anew by Cahusac, became evidently paler, but did
Title:  not give way a foot.  He only changed his sword hand, and fought
Title:  with his left hand.
Title:  
Title:  According to the laws of dueling at that period, d'Artagnan was
Title:  at liberty to assist whom he pleased.  While he was endeavoring
Title:  to find out which of his companions stood in greatest need, he
Title:  caught a glance from Athos.  The glance was of sublime eloquence.
Title:  Athos would have died rather than appeal for help; but he could
Title:  look, and with that look ask assistance.  D'Artagnan interpreted
Title:  it; with a terrible bound he sprang to the side of Cahusac,
Title:  crying, "To me, Monsieur Guardsman; I will slay you!"
Title:  
Title:  Cahusac turned.  It was time; for Athos, whose great courage
Title:  alone supported him, sank upon his knee.
Title:  
Title:  "S'blood!" cried he to d'Artagnan, "do not kill him, young man, I
Title:  beg of you.  I have an old affair to settle with him when I am
Title:  cured and sound again.  Disarm him only--make sure of his sword.
Title:  That's it!  Very well done!"
Title:  
Title:  The exclamation was drawn from Athos by seeing the sword of
Title:  Cahusac fly twenty paces from him.  D'Artagnan and Cahusac sprang
Title:  forward at the same instant, the one to recover, the other to
Title:  obtain, the sword; but d'Artagnan, being the more active, reached
Title:  it first and placed his foot upon it.
Title:  
Title:  Cahusac immediately ran to the Guardsman whom Aramis had killed,
Title:  seized his rapier, and returned toward d'Artagnan; but on his way
Title:  he met Athos, who during his relief which d'Artagnan had procured
Title:  him had recovered his breath, and who, for fear that d'Artagnan
Title:  would kill his enemy, wished to resume the fight.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan perceived that it would be disobliging Athos not to
Title:  leave him alone; and in a few minutes Cahusac fell, with a sword
Title:  thrust through his throat.
Title:  
Title:  At the same instant Aramis placed his sword point on the breast
Title:  of his fallen enemy, and forced him to ask for mercy.
Title:  
Title:  There only then remained Porthos and Bicarat.  Porthos made a
Title:  thousand flourishes, asking Bicarat what o'clock it could be, and
Title:  offering him his compliments upon his brother's having just
Title:  obtained a company in the regiment of Navarre; but, jest as he
Title:  might, he gained nothing.  Bicarat was one of those iron men who
Title:  never fell dead.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, it was necessary to finish.  The watch might come
Title:  up and take all the combatants, wounded or not, royalists or
Title:  cardinalists.  Athos, Aramis, and d'Artagnan surrounded Bicarat,
Title:  and required him to surrender.  Though alone against all and with
Title:  a wound in his thigh, Bicarat wished to hold out; but Jussac, who
Title:  had risen upon his elbow, cried out to him to yield.  Bicarat was
Title:  a Gascon, as d'Artagnan was; he turned a deaf ear, and contented
Title:  himself with laughing, and between two parries finding time to
Title:  point to a spot of earth with his sword, "Here," cried he,
Title:  parodying a verse of the Bible, "here will Bicarat die; for I
Title:  only am left, and they seek my life."
Title:  
Title:  "But there are four against you; leave off, I command you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, if you command me, that's another thing," said Bicarat.  "As
Title:  you are my commander, it is my duty to obey."  And springing
Title:  backward, he broke his sword across his knee to avoid the
Title:  necessity of surrendering it, threw the pieces over the convent
Title:  wall, and crossed him arms, whistling a cardinalist air.
Title:  
Title:  Bravery is always respected, even in an enemy.  The Musketeers
Title:  saluted Bicarat with their swords, and returned them to their
Title:  sheaths.  D'Artagnan did the same.  Then, assisted by Bicarat,
Title:  the only one left standing, he bore Jussac, Cahusac, and one of
Title:  Aramis's adversaries who was only wounded, under the porch of the
Title:  convent.  The fourth, as we have said, was dead.  They then rang
Title:  the bell, and carrying away four swords out of five, they took
Title:  their road, intoxicated with joy, toward the hotel of M. de
Title:  Treville.
Title:  
Title:  They walked arm in arm, occupying the whole width of the street
Title:  and taking in every Musketeer they met, so that in the end it
Title:  became a triumphal march.  The heart of d'Artagnan swam in
Title:  delirium; he marched between Athos and Porthos, pressing them
Title:  tenderly.
Title:  
Title:  "If I am not yet a Musketeer," said he to his new friends, as he
Title:  passed through the gateway of M. de Treville's hotel, "at least I
Title:  have entered upon my apprenticeship, haven't I?"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  6  HIS MAJESTY KING LOUIS XIII
Title:  
Title:  This affair made a great noise.  M. de Treville scolded his
Title:  Musketeers in public, and congratulated them in private; but as
Title:  no time was to be lost in gaining the king, M. de Treville
Title:  hastened to report himself at the Louvre.  It was already too
Title:  late.  The king was closeted with the cardinal, and M. de
Title:  Treville was informed that the king was busy and could not
Title:  receive him at that moment.  In the evening M. de Treville
Title:  attended the king's gaming table.  The king was winning; and as
Title:  he was very avaricious, he was in an excellent humor.  Perceiving
Title:  M. de Treville at a distance--
Title:  
Title:  "Come here, Monsieur Captain," said he, "come here, that I may
Title:  growl at you.  Do you know that his Eminence has been making
Title:  fresh complaints against your Musketeers, and that with so much
Title:  emotion, that this evening his Eminence is indisposed?  Ah, these
Title:  Musketeers of yours are very devils--fellows to be hanged."
Title:  
Title:  "No, sire," replied Treville, who saw at the first glance how
Title:  things would go, "on the contrary, they are good creatures, as
Title:  meek as lambs, and have but one desire, I'll be their warranty.
Title:  And that is that their swords may never leave their scabbards but
Title:  in your majesty's service.  But what are they to do?  The Guards
Title:  of Monsieur the Cardinal are forever seeking quarrels with them,
Title:  and for the honor of the corps even, the poor young men are
Title:  obliged to defend themselves."
Title:  
Title:  "Listen to Monsieur de Treville," said the king; "listen to him!
Title:  Would not one say he was speaking of a religious community?  In
Title:  truth, my dear Captain, I have a great mind to take away your
Title:  commission and give it to Mademoiselle de Chemerault, to whom I
Title:  promised an abbey.  But don't fancy that I am going to take you
Title:  on your bare word.  I am called Louis the Just, Monsieur de
Title:  Treville, and by and by, by and by we will see."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, sire; it is because I confide in that justice that I shall
Title:  wait patiently and quietly the good pleasure of your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Wait, then, monsieur, wait," said the king; "I will not detain
Title:  you long."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, fortune changed; and as the king began to lose what he
Title:  had won, he was not sorry to find an excuse for playing
Title:  Charlemagne--if we may use a gaming phrase of whose origin we
Title:  confess our ignorance.  The king therefore arose a minute after,
Title:  and putting the money which lay before him into his pocket, the
Title:  major part of which arose from his winnings, "La Vieuville," said
Title:  he, "take my place; I must speak to Monsieur de Treville on an
Title:  affair of importance.  Ah, I had eighty louis before me; put down
Title:  the same sum, so that they who have lost may have nothing to
Title:  complain of.  Justice before everything."
Title:  
Title:  Then turning toward M. de Treville and walking with him toward
Title:  the embrasure of a window, "Well, monsieur," continued he, "you
Title:  say it is his Eminence's Guards who have sought a quarrel with
Title:  your Musketeers?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire, as they always do."
Title:  
Title:  "And how did the thing happen?  Let us see, for you know, my dear
Title:  Captain, a judge must hear both sides."
Title:  
Title:  "Good Lord!  In the most simple and natural manner possible.
Title:  Three of my best soldiers, whom your Majesty knows by name, and
Title:  whose devotedness you have more than once appreciated, and who
Title:  have, I dare affirm to the king, his service much at heart--three
Title:  of my best soldiers, I say, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, had made
Title:  a party of pleasure with a young fellow from Gascony, whom I had
Title:  introduced to them the same morning.  The party was to take place
Title:  at St. Germain, I believe, and they had appointed to meet at the
Title:  Carmes-Deschaux, when they were disturbed by de Jussac, Cahusac,
Title:  Bicarat, and two other Guardsmen, who certainly did not go there
Title:  in such a numerous company without some ill intention against the
Title:  edicts."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!  You incline me to think so," said the king.  "There is
Title:  no doubt they went thither to fight themselves."
Title:  
Title:  "I do not accuse them, sire; but I leave your Majesty to judge
Title:  what five armed men could possibly be going to do in such a
Title:  deserted place as the neighborhood of the Convent des Carmes."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, you are right, Treville, you are right!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then, upon seeing my Musketeers they changed their minds, and
Title:  forgot their private hatred for partisan hatred; for your Majesty
Title:  cannot be ignorant that the Musketeers, who belong to the king
Title:  and nobody but the king, are the natural enemies of the
Title:  Guardsmen, who belong to the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, Treville, yes," said the king, in a melancholy tone; "and
Title:  it is very sad, believe me, to see thus two parties in France,
Title:  two heads to royalty. But all this will come to an end, Treville,
Title:  will come to an end.  You say, then, that the Guardsmen sought a
Title:  quarrel with the Musketeers?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say that it is probable that things have fallen out so, but I
Title:  will not swear to it, sire.  You know how difficult it is to
Title:  discover the truth; and unless a man be endowed with that
Title:  admirable instinct which causes Louis XIII to be named the
Title:  Just--"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, Treville; but they were not alone, your
Title:  Musketeers.  They had a youth with them?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire, and one wounded man; so that three of the king's
Title:  Musketeers--one of whom was wounded--and a youth not only
Title:  maintained their ground against five of the most terrible of the
Title:  cardinal's Guardsmen, but absolutely brought four of them to
Title:  earth."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, this is a victory!" cried the king, all radiant, "a
Title:  complete victory!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire; as complete as that of the Bridge of Ce."
Title:  
Title:  "Four men, one of them wounded, and a youth, say you?"
Title:  
Title:  "One hardly a young man; but who, however, behaved himself so
Title:  admirably on this occasion that I will take the liberty of
Title:  recommending him to your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "How does he call himself?"
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan, sire; he is the son of one of my oldest friends--the
Title:  son of a man who served under the king your father, of glorious
Title:  memory, in the civil war."
Title:  
Title:  "And you say this young man behaved himself well?  Tell me how,
Title:  Treville--you know how I delight in accounts of war and
Title:  fighting."
Title:  
Title:  And Louis XIII twisted his mustache proudly, placing his hand
Title:  upon his hip.
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," resumed Treville, "as I told you, Monsieur d'Artagnan is
Title:  little more than a boy; and as he has not the honor of being a
Title:  Musketeer, he was dressed as a citizen.  The Guards of the
Title:  cardinal, perceiving his youth and that he did not belong to the
Title:  corps, invited him to retire before they attacked."
Title:  
Title:  "So you may plainly see, Treville," interrupted the king, "it was
Title:  they who attacked?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is true, sire; there can be no more doubt on that head.
Title:  They called upon him then to retire; but he answered that he was
Title:  a Musketeer at heart, entirely devoted to your Majesty, and that
Title:  therefore he would remain with Messieurs the Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "Brave young man!" murmured the king.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, he did remain with them; and your Majesty has in him so
Title:  firm a champion that it was he who gave Jussac the terrible sword
Title:  thrust which has made the cardinal so angry."
Title:  
Title:  "He who wounded Jussac!" cried the king, "he, a boy!  Treville,
Title:  that's impossible!"
Title:  
Title:  "It is as I have the honor to relate it to your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "Jussac, one of the first swordsmen in the kingdom?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, sire, for once he found his master."
Title:  
Title:  "I will see this young man, Treville--I will see him; and if anything
Title:  can be done--well, we will make it our business."
Title:  
Title:  "When will your Majesty deign to receive him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow, at midday, Treville."
Title:  
Title:  "Shall I bring him alone?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, bring me all four together.  I wish to thank them all at
Title:  once.  Devoted men are so rare, Treville, by the back staircase.
Title:  It is useless to let the cardinal know."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "You understand, Treville--an edict is still an edict, it is
Title:  forbidden to fight, after all."
Title:  
Title:  "But this encounter, sire, is quite out of the ordinary
Title:  conditions of a duel.  It is a brawl; and the proof is that there
Title:  were five of the cardinal's Guardsmen against my three Musketeers
Title:  and Monsieur d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true," said the king; "but never mind, Treville, come
Title:  still by the back staircase."
Title:  
Title:  Treville smiled; but as it was indeed something to have prevailed
Title:  upon this child to rebel against his master, he saluted the king
Title:  respectfully, and with this agreement, took leave of him.
Title:  
Title:  That evening the three Musketeers were informed of the honor
Title:  accorded them.  As they had long been acquainted with the king,
Title:  they were not much excited; but d'Artagnan, with his Gascon
Title:  imagination, saw in it his future fortune, and passed the night
Title:  in golden dreams.  By eight o'clock in the morning he was at the
Title:  apartment of Athos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan found the Musketeer dressed and ready to go out.  As
Title:  the hour to wait upon the king was not till twelve, he had made a
Title:  party with Porthos and Aramis to play a game at tennis in a
Title:  tennis court situated near the stables of the Luxembourg.  Athos
Title:  invited d'Artagnan to follow them; and although ignorant of the
Title:  game, which he had never played, he accepted, not knowing what to
Title:  do with his time from nine o'clock in the morning, as it then
Title:  scarcely was, till twelve.
Title:  
Title:  The two Musketeers were already there, and were playing together.
Title:  Athos, who was very expert in all bodily exercises, passed with
Title:  d'Artagnan to the opposite side and challenged them; but at the
Title:  first effort he made, although he played with his left hand, he
Title:  found that his wound was yet too recent to allow of such
Title:  exertion.  D'Artagnan remained, therefore, alone; and as he
Title:  declared he was too ignorant of the game to play it regularly
Title:  they only continued giving balls to one another without counting.
Title:  But one of these balls, launched by Porthos' herculean hand,
Title:  passed so close to d'Artagnan's face that he thought that if,
Title:  instead of passing near, it had hit him, his audience would have
Title:  been probably lost, as it would have been impossible for him to
Title:  present himself before the king.  Now, as upon this audience, in
Title:  his Gascon imagination, depended his future life, he saluted
Title:  Aramis and Porthos politely, declaring that he would not resume
Title:  the game until he should be prepared to play with them on more
Title:  equal terms, and went and took his place near the cord and in the
Title:  gallery.
Title:  
Title:  Unfortunately for d'Artagnan, among the spectators was one of his
Title:  Eminence's Guardsmen, who, still irritated by the defeat of his
Title:  companions, which had happened only the day before, had promised
Title:  himself to seize the first opportunity of avenging it.  He
Title:  believed this opportunity was now come and addressed his
Title:  neighbor:  "It is not astonishing that that young man should be
Title:  afraid of a ball, for he is doubtless a Musketeer apprentice."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan turned round as if a serpent had stung him, and fixed
Title:  his eyes intensely upon the Guardsman who had just made this
Title:  insolent speech.
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU," resumed the latter, twisting his mustache, "look at me
Title:  as long as you like, my little gentleman!  I have said what I
Title:  have said."
Title:  
Title:  "And as since that which you have said is too clear to require
Title:  any explanation," replied d'Artagnan, in a low voice, "I beg you
Title:  to follow me."
Title:  
Title:  "And when?" asked the Guardsman, with the same jeering air.
Title:  
Title:  "At once, if you please."
Title:  
Title:  "And you know who I am, without doubt?"
Title:  
Title:  "I?  I am completely ignorant; nor does it much disquiet me."
Title:  
Title:  "You're in the wrong there; for if you knew my name, perhaps you
Title:  would not be so pressing."
Title:  
Title:  "What is your name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Bernajoux, at your service."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, Monsieur Bernajoux," said d'Artagnan, tranquilly, "I
Title:  will wait for you at the door."
Title:  
Title:  "Go, monsieur, I will follow you."
Title:  
Title:  "Do not hurry yourself, monsieur, lest it be observed that we go
Title:  out together.  You must be aware that for our undertaking,
Title:  company would be in the way."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said the Guardsman, astonished that his name had
Title:  not produced more effect upon the young man.
Title:  
Title:  Indeed, the name of Bernajoux was known to all the world,
Title:  d'Artagnan alone excepted, perhaps; for it was one of those which
Title:  figured most frequently in the daily brawls which all the edicts
Title:  of the cardinal could not repress.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis were so engaged with their game, and Athos was
Title:  watching them with so much attention, that they did not even
Title:  perceive their young companion go out, who, as he had told the
Title:  Guardsman of his Eminence, stopped outside the door.  An instant
Title:  after, the Guardsman descended in his turn.  As d'Artagnan had no
Title:  time to lose, on account of the audience of the king, which was
Title:  fixed for midday, he cast his eyes around, and seeing that the
Title:  street was empty, said to his adversary, "My faith!  It is
Title:  fortunate for you, although your name is Bernajoux, to have only
Title:  to deal with an apprentice Musketeer.  Never mind; be content, I
Title:  will do my best.  On guard!"
Title:  
Title:  "But," said he whom d'Artagnan thus provoked, "it appears to me
Title:  that this place is badly chosen, and that we should be better
Title:  behind the Abbey St. Germain or in the Pre-aux-Clercs."
Title:  
Title:  "What you say is full of sense," replied d'Artagnan; "but
Title:  unfortunately I have very little time to spare, having an
Title:  appointment at twelve precisely.  On guard, then, monsieur, on
Title:  guard!"
Title:  
Title:  Bernajoux was not a man to have such a compliment paid to him
Title:  twice.  In an instant his sword glittered in his hand, and he
Title:  sprang upon his adversary, whom, thanks to his great
Title:  youthfulness, he hoped to intimidate.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan had on the preceding day served his
Title:  apprenticeship.  Fresh sharpened by his victory, full of hopes of
Title:  future favor, he was resolved not to recoil a step.  So the two
Title:  swords were crossed close to the hilts, and as d'Artagnan stood
Title:  firm, it was his adversary who made the retreating step; but
Title:  d'Artagnan seized the moment at which, in this movement, the
Title:  sword of Bernajoux deviated from the line.  He freed his weapon,
Title:  made a lunge, and touched his adversary on the shoulder.
Title:  d'Artagnan immediately made a step backward and raised his sword;
Title:  but Bernajoux cried out that it was nothing, and rushing blindly
Title:  upon him, absolutely spitted himself upon d'Artagnan's sword.
Title:  As, however, he did not fall, as he did not declare himself
Title:  conquered, but only broke away toward the hotel of M. de la
Title:  Tremouille, in whose service he had a relative, d'Artagnan was
Title:  ignorant of the seriousness of the last wound his adversary had
Title:  received, and pressing him warmly, without doubt would soon have
Title:  completed his work with a third blow, when the noise which arose
Title:  from the street being heard in the tennis court, two of the
Title:  friends of the Guardsman, who had seen him go out after
Title:  exchanging some words with d'Artagnan, rushed, sword in hand,
Title:  from the court, and fell upon the conqueror.  But Athos, Porthos,
Title:  and Aramis quickly appeared in their turn, and the moment the two
Title:  Guardsmen attacked their young companion, drove them back.
Title:  Bernajoux now fell, and as the Guardsmen were only two against
Title:  four, they began to cry, "To the rescue!  The Hotel de la
Title:  Tremouille!"  At these cries, all who were in the hotel rushed
Title:  out and fell upon the four companions, who on their side cried
Title:  aloud, "To the rescue, Musketeers!"
Title:  
Title:  This cry was generally heeded; for the Musketeers were known to
Title:  be enemies of the cardinal, and were beloved on account of the
Title:  hatred they bore to his Eminence.  Thus the soldiers of other
Title:  companies than those which belonged to the Red Duke, as Aramis
Title:  had called him, often took part with the king's Musketeers in
Title:  these quarrels.  Of three Guardsmen of the company of M.
Title:  Dessessart who were passing, two came to the assistance of the
Title:  four companions, while the other ran toward the hotel of M. de
Title:  Treville, crying, "To the rescue, Musketeers!  To the rescue!"
Title:  As usual, this hotel was full of soldiers of this company, who
Title:  hastened to the succor of their comrades.  The MELEE became
Title:  general, but strength was on the side of the Musketeers.  The
Title:  cardinal's Guards and M. de la Tremouille's people retreated into
