Title:  the hotel, the doors of which they closed just in time to prevent
Title:  their enemies from entering with them.  As to the wounded man, he
Title:  had been taken in at once, and, as we have said, in a very bad
Title:  state.
Title:  
Title:  Excitement was at its height among the Musketeers and their
Title:  allies, and they even began to deliberate whether they should not
Title:  set fire to the hotel to punish the insolence of M. de la
Title:  Tremouille's domestics in daring to make a SORTIE upon the king's
Title:  Musketeers.  The proposition had been made, and received with
Title:  enthusiasm, when fortunately eleven o'clock struck.  D'Artagnan
Title:  and his companions remembered their audience, and as they would
Title:  very much have regretted that such an opportunity should be lost,
Title:  they succeeded in calming their friends, who contented themselves
Title:  with hurling some paving stones against the gates; but the gates
Title:  were too strong.  They soon tired of the sport.  Besides, those
Title:  who must be considered the leaders of the enterprise had quit the
Title:  group and were making their way toward the hotel of M. de
Title:  Treville, who was waiting for them, already informed of this
Title:  fresh disturbance.
Title:  
Title:  "Quick to the Louvre," said he, "to the Louvre without losing an
Title:  instant, and let us endeavor to see the king before he is
Title:  prejudiced by the cardinal.  We will describe the thing to him as
Title:  a consequence of the affair of yesterday, and the two will pass
Title:  off together."
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville, accompanied by the four young fellows, directed
Title:  his course toward the Louvre; but to the great astonishment of
Title:  the captain of the Musketeers, he was informed that the king had
Title:  gone stag hunting in the forest of St. Germain.  M. de Treville
Title:  required this intelligence to be repeated to him twice, and each
Title:  time his companions saw his brow become darker.
Title:  
Title:  "Had his Majesty," asked he, "any intention of holding this
Title:  hunting party yesterday?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, your Excellency," replied the valet de chambre, "the Master
Title:  of the Hounds came this morning to inform him that he had marked
Title:  down a stag.  At first the king answered that he would not go;
Title:  but he could not resist his love of sport, and set out after
Title:  dinner."
Title:  
Title:  "And the king has seen the cardinal?" asked M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "In all probability he has," replied the valet, "for I saw the
Title:  horses harnessed to his Eminence's carriage this morning, and
Title:  when I asked where he was going, they told me, 'To St. Germain.'"
Title:  
Title:  "He is beforehand with us," said M. de Treville.  "Gentlemen, I
Title:  will see the king this evening; but as to you, I do not advise
Title:  you to risk doing so."
Title:  
Title:  This advice was too reasonable, and moreover came from a man who
Title:  knew the king too well, to allow the four young men to dispute
Title:  it.  M. de Treville recommended everyone to return home and wait
Title:  for news.
Title:  
Title:  On entering his hotel, M. de Treville thought it best to be first
Title:  in making the complaint.  He sent one of his servants to M. de la
Title:  Tremouille with a letter in which he begged of him to eject the
Title:  cardinal's Guardsmen from his house, and to reprimand his people
Title:  for their audacity in making SORTIE against the king's
Title:  Musketeers.  But M. de la Tremouille--already prejudiced by his
Title:  esquire, whose relative, as we already know, Bernajoux was--
Title:  replied that it was neither for M. de Treville nor the Musketeers
Title:  to complain, but, on the contrary, for him, whose people the
Title:  Musketeers had assaulted and whose hotel they had endeavored to
Title:  burn.  Now, as the debate between these two nobles might last a
Title:  long time, each becoming, naturally, more firm in his own
Title:  opinion, M. de Treville thought of an expedient which might
Title:  terminate it quietly.  This was to go himself to M. de la
Title:  Tremouille.
Title:  
Title:  He repaired, therefore, immediately to his hotel, and caused
Title:  himself to be announced.
Title:  
Title:  The two nobles saluted each other politely, for if no friendship
Title:  existed between them, there was at least esteem.  Both were men
Title:  of courage and honor; and as M. de la Tremouille--a Protestant,
Title:  and seeing the king seldom--was of no party, he did not, in
Title:  general, carry any bias into his social relations.  This time,
Title:  however, his address, although polite, was cooler than usual.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said M. de Treville, "we fancy that we have each
Title:  cause to complain of the other, and I am come to endeavor to
Title:  clear up this affair."
Title:  
Title:  "I have no objection," replied M. de la Tremouille, "but I warn
Title:  you that I am well informed, and all the fault is with your
Title:  Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "You are too just and reasonable a man, monsieur!" said Treville,
Title:  "not to accept the proposal I am about to make to you."
Title:  
Title:  "Make it, monsieur, I listen."
Title:  
Title:  "How is Monsieur Bernajoux, your esquire's relative?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, monsieur, very ill indeed!  In addition to the sword thrust
Title:  in his arm, which is not dangerous, he has received another right
Title:  through his lungs, of which the doctor says bad things."
Title:  
Title:  "But has the wounded man retained his senses?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perfectly."
Title:  
Title:  "Does he talk?"
Title:  
Title:  "With difficulty, but he can speak."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur, let us go to him.  Let us adjure him, in the
Title:  name of the God before whom he must perhaps appear, to speak the
Title:  truth.  I will take him for judge in his own cause, monsieur, and
Title:  will believe what he will say."
Title:  
Title:  M. de la Tremouille reflected for an instant; then as it was
Title:  difficult to suggest a more reasonable proposal, he agreed to it.
Title:  
Title:  Both descended to the chamber in which the wounded man lay.  The
Title:  latter, on seeing these two noble lords who came to visit him,
Title:  endeavored to raise himself up in his bed; but he was too weak,
Title:  and exhausted by the effort, he fell back again almost senseless.
Title:  
Title:  M. de la Tremouille approached him, and made him inhale some
Title:  salts, which recalled him to life.  Then M. de Treville,
Title:  unwilling that it should be thought that he had influenced the
Title:  wounded man, requested M. de la Tremouille to interrogate him
Title:  himself.
Title:  
Title:  That happened which M. de Treville had foreseen.  Placed between
Title:  life and death, as Bernajoux was, he had no idea for a moment of
Title:  concealing the truth; and he described to the two nobles the
Title:  affair exactly as it had passed.
Title:  
Title:  This was all that M. de Treville wanted.  He wished Bernajoux a
Title:  speedy convalescence, took leave of M. de la Tremouille, returned
Title:  to his hotel, and immediately sent word to the four friends that
Title:  he awaited their company at dinner.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville entertained good company, wholly anticardinalist,
Title:  though.  It may easily be understood, therefore, that the
Title:  conversation during the whole of dinner turned upon the two
Title:  checks that his Eminence's Guardsmen had received.  Now, as
Title:  d'Artagnan had been the hero of these two fights, it was upon him
Title:  that all the felicitations fell, which Athos, Porthos, and Aramis
Title:  abandoned to him, not only as good comrades, but as men who had
Title:  so often had their turn that could very well afford him his.
Title:  
Title:  Toward six o'clock M. de Treville announced that it was time to
Title:  go to the Louvre; but as the hour of audience granted by his
Title:  Majesty was past, instead of claiming the ENTREE by the back
Title:  stairs, he placed himself with the four young men in the
Title:  antechamber.  The king had not yet returned from hunting.  Our
Title:  young men had been waiting about half an hour, amid a crowd of
Title:  courtiers, when all the doors were thrown open, and his Majesty
Title:  was announced.
Title:  
Title:  At his announcement d'Artagnan felt himself tremble to the very
Title:  marrow of his bones.  The coming instant would in all probability
Title:  decide the rest of his life.  His eyes therefore were fixed in a
Title:  sort of agony upon the door through which the king must enter.
Title:  
Title:  Louis XIII appeared, walking fast.  He was in hunting costume
Title:  covered with dust, wearing large boots, and holding a whip in his
Title:  hand.  At the first glance, d'Artagnan judged that the mind of
Title:  the king was stormy.
Title:  
Title:  This disposition, visible as it was in his Majesty, did not
Title:  prevent the courtiers from ranging themselves along his pathway.
Title:  In royal antechambers it is worth more to be viewed with an angry
Title:  eye than not to be seen at all.  The three Musketeers therefore
Title:  did not hesitate to make a step forward.  D'Artagnan on the
Title:  contrary remained concealed behind them; but although the king
Title:  knew Athos, Porthos, and Aramis personally, he passed before them
Title:  without speaking or looking--indeed, as if he had never seen them
Title:  before.  As for M. de Treville, when the eyes of the king fell
Title:  upon him, he sustained the look with so much firmness that it was
Title:  the king who dropped his eyes; after which his Majesty,
Title:  grumbling, entered his apartment.
Title:  
Title:  "Matters go but badly," said Athos, smiling; "and we shall not be
Title:  made Chevaliers of the Order this time."
Title:  
Title:  "Wait here ten minutes," said M. de Treville; "and if at the
Title:  expiration of ten minutes you do not see me come out, return to
Title:  my hotel, for it will be useless for you to wait for me longer."
Title:  
Title:  The four young men waited ten minutes, a quarter of an hour,
Title:  twenty minutes; and seeing that M. de Treville did not return,
Title:  went away very uneasy as to what was going to happen.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville entered the king's cabinet boldly, and found his
Title:  Majesty in a very ill humor, seated on an armchair, beating his
Title:  boot with the handle of his whip.  This, however, did not prevent
Title:  his asking, with the greatest coolness, after his Majesty's
Title:  health.
Title:  
Title:  "Bad, monsieur, bad!" replied the king; "I am bored."
Title:  
Title:  This was, in fact, the worst complaint of Louis XIII, who would
Title:  sometimes take one of his courtiers to a window and say,
Title:  "Monsieur So-and-so, let us weary ourselves together."
Title:  
Title:  "How!  Your Majesty is bored?  Have you not enjoyed the pleasures
Title:  of the chase today?"
Title:  
Title:  "A fine pleasure, indeed, monsieur!  Upon my soul, everything
Title:  degenerates; and I don't know whether it is the game which leaves
Title:  no scent, or the dogs that have no noses.  We started a stag of
Title:  ten branches.  We chased him for six hours, and when he was near
Title:  being taken--when St.-Simon was already putting his horn to his
Title:  mouth to sound the mort--crack, all the pack takes the wrong
Title:  scent and sets off after a two-year-older.  I shall be obliged to
Title:  give up hunting, as I have given up hawking.  Ah, I am an
Title:  unfortunate king, Monsieur de Treville!  I had but one gerfalcon,
Title:  and he died day before yesterday."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed, sire, I wholly comprehend your disappointment.  The
Title:  misfortune is great; but I think you have still a good number of
Title:  falcons, sparrow hawks, and tiercets."
Title:  
Title:  "And not a man to instruct them.  Falconers are declining.  I
Title:  know no one but myself who is acquainted with the noble art of
Title:  venery.  After me it will all be over, and people will hunt with
Title:  gins, snares, and traps.  If I had but the time to train pupils!
Title:  But there is the cardinal always at hand, who does not leave me a
Title:  moment's repose; who talks to me about Spain, who talks to me
Title:  about Austria, who talks to me about England!  Ah!  A PROPOS of
Title:  the cardinal, Monsieur de Treville, I am vexed with you!"
Title:  
Title:  This was the chance at which M. de Treville waited for the king.
Title:  He knew the king of old, and he knew that all these complaints
Title:  were but a preface--a sort of excitation to encourage himself--
Title:  and that he had now come to his point at last.
Title:  
Title:  "And in what have I been so unfortunate as to displease your
Title:  Majesty?" asked M. de Treville, feigning the most profound
Title:  astonishment.
Title:  
Title:  "Is it thus you perform your charge, monsieur?" continued the
Title:  king, without directly replying to de Treville's question.  "Is
Title:  it for this I name you captain of my Musketeers, that they should
Title:  assassinate a man, disturb a whole quarter, and endeavor to set
Title:  fire to Paris, without your saying a word?  But yet," continued
Title:  the king, "undoubtedly my haste accuses you wrongfully; without
Title:  doubt the rioters are in prison, and you come to tell me justice
Title:  is done."
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," replied M. de Treville, calmly, "on the contrary, I come
Title:  to demand it of you."
Title:  
Title:  "And against whom?" cried the king.
Title:  
Title:  "Against calumniators," said M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  This is something new," replied the king.  "Will you tell
Title:  me that your three damned Musketeers, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis,
Title:  and your youngster from Bearn, have not fallen, like so many
Title:  furies, upon poor Bernajoux, and have not maltreated him in such
Title:  a fashion that probably by this time he is dead?  Will you tell
Title:  me that they did not lay siege to the hotel of the Duc de la
Title:  Tremouille, and that they did not endeavor to burn it?--which
Title:  would not, perhaps, have been a great misfortune in time of war,
Title:  seeing that it is nothing but a nest of Huguenots, but which is,
Title:  in time of peace, a frightful example.  Tell me, now, can you
Title:  deny all this?"
Title:  
Title:  "And who told you this fine story, sire?" asked Treville,
Title:  quietly.
Title:  
Title:  "Who has told me this fine story, monsieur?  Who should it be but
Title:  he who watches while I sleep, who labors while I amuse myself,
Title:  who conducts everything at home and abroad--in France as in
Title:  Europe?"
Title:  
Title:  "Your Majesty probably refers to God," said M. de Treville; "for
Title:  I know no one except God who can be so far above your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur; I speak of the prop of the state, of my only
Title:  servant, of my only friend--of the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "His Eminence is not his holiness, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean by that, monsieur?"
Title:  
Title:  "That it is only the Pope who is infallible, and that this
Title:  infallibility does not extend to cardinals."
Title:  
Title:  "You mean to say that he deceives me; you mean to say that he
Title:  betrays me?  You accuse him, then?  Come, speak; avow freely that
Title:  you accuse him!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, sire, but I say that he deceives himself.  I say that he is
Title:  ill-informed.  I say that he has hastily accused your Majesty's
Title:  Musketeers, toward whom he is unjust, and that he has not
Title:  obtained his information from good sources."
Title:  
Title:  "The accusation comes from Monsieur de la Tremouille, from the
Title:  duke himself.  What do you say to that?"
Title:  
Title:  "I might answer, sire, that he is too deeply interested in the
Title:  question to be a very impartial witness; but so far from that,
Title:  sire, I know the duke to be a royal gentleman, and I refer the
Title:  matter to him--but upon one condition, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is that your Majesty will make him come here, will
Title:  interrogate him yourself, TETE-A-TETE, without witnesses, and
Title:  that I shall see your Majesty as soon as you have seen the duke."
Title:  
Title:  "What, then!  You will bind yourself," cried the king, "by what
Title:  Monsieur de la Tremouille shall say?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "You will accept his judgment?"
Title:  
Title:  "Undoubtedly."
Title:  
Title:  "Any you will submit to the reparation he may require?"
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly."
Title:  
Title:  "La Chesnaye," said the king.  "La Chesnaye!"
Title:  
Title:  Louis XIII's confidential valet, who never left the door, entered
Title:  in reply to the call.
Title:  
Title:  "La Chesnaye," said the king, "let someone go instantly and find
Title:  Monsieur de la Tremouille; I wish to speak with him this
Title:  evening."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Majesty gives me your word that you will not see anyone
Title:  between Monsieur de la Tremouille and myself?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nobody, by the faith of a gentleman."
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow, then, sire?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "At what o'clock, please your Majesty?"
Title:  
Title:  "At any hour you will."
Title:  
Title:  "But in coming too early I should be afraid of awakening your
Title:  Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "Awaken me!  Do you think I ever sleep, then?  I sleep no longer,
Title:  monsieur.  I sometimes dream, that's all.  Come, then, as early
Title:  as you like--at seven o'clock; but beware, if you and your
Title:  Musketeers are guilty."
Title:  
Title:  "If my Musketeers are guilty, sire, the guilty shall be placed in
Title:  your Majesty's hands, who will dispose of them at your good
Title:  pleasure.  Does your Majesty require anything further?  Speak, I
Title:  am ready to obey."
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, no; I am not called Louis the Just without reason.
Title:  Tomorrow, then, monsieur--tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  "Till then, God preserve your Majesty!"
Title:  
Title:  However ill the king might sleep, M. de Treville slept still
Title:  worse.  He had ordered his three Musketeers and their companion
Title:  to be with him at half past six in the morning.  He took them
Title:  with him, without encouraging them or promising them anything,
Title:  and without concealing from them that their luck, and even his
Title:  own, depended upon the cast of the dice.
Title:  
Title:  Arrived at the foot of the back stairs, he desired them to wait.
Title:  If the king was still irritated against them, they would depart
Title:  without being seen; if the king consented to see them, they would
Title:  only have to be called.
Title:  
Title:  On arriving at the king's private antechamber, M. de Treville
Title:  found La Chesnaye, who informed him that they had not been able
Title:  to find M. de la Tremouille on the preceding evening at his
Title:  hotel, that he returned too late to present himself at the
Title:  Louvre, that he had only that moment arrived and that he was at
Title:  that very hour with the king.
Title:  
Title:  This circumstance pleased M. de Treville much, as he thus became
Title:  certain that no foreign suggestion could insinuate itself between
Title:  M. de la Tremouille's testimony and himself.
Title:  
Title:  In fact, ten minutes had scarcely passed away when the door of
Title:  the king's closet opened, and M. de Treville saw M. de la
Title:  Tremouille come out.  The duke came straight up to him, and said:
Title:  "Monsieur de Treville, his Majesty has just sent for me in order
Title:  to inquire respecting the circumstances which took place
Title:  yesterday at my hotel.  I have told him the truth; that is to
Title:  say, that the fault lay with my people, and that I was ready to
Title:  offer you my excuses.  Since I have the good fortune to meet you,
Title:  I beg you to receive them, and to hold me always as one of your
Title:  friends."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur the Duke," said M. de Treville, "I was so confident of
Title:  your loyalty that I required no other defender before his Majesty
Title:  than yourself.  I find that I have not been mistaken, and I thank
Title:  you that there is still one man in France of whom may be said,
Title:  without disappointment, what I have said of you."
Title:  
Title:  "That's well said," cried the king, who had heard all these
Title:  compliments through the open door; "only tell him, Treville,
Title:  since he wishes to be considered your friend, that I also wish to
Title:  be one of his, but he neglects me; that it is nearly three years
Title:  since I have seen him, and that I never do see him unless I send
Title:  for him.  Tell him all this for me, for these are things which a
Title:  king cannot say for himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, sire, thanks," said the duke; "but your Majesty may be
Title:  assured that it is not those--I do not speak of Monsieur de
Title:  Treville--whom your Majesty sees at all hours of the day that are
Title:  most devoted to you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  You have heard what I said?  So much the better, Duke, so
Title:  much the better," said the king, advancing toward the door.  "Ah!
Title:  It is you, Treville.  Where are your Musketeers?  I told you the
Title:  day before yesterday to bring them with you; why have you not
Title:  done so?"
Title:  
Title:  "They are below, sire, and with your permission La Chesnaye will
Title:  bid them come up."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, let them come up immediately.  It is nearly eight
Title:  o'clock, and at nine I expect a visit.  Go, Monsieur Duke, and
Title:  return often.  Come in, Treville."
Title:  
Title:  The Duke saluted and retired.  At the moment he opened the door,
Title:  the three Musketeers and d'Artagnan, conducted by La Chesnaye,
Title:  appeared at the top of the staircase.
Title:  
Title:  "Come in, my braves," said the king, "come in; I am going to
Title:  scold you."
Title:  
Title:  The Musketeers advanced, bowing, d'Artagnan following closely
Title:  behind them.
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil!" continued the king.  "Seven of his Eminence's
Title:  Guards placed HORS DE COMBAT by you four in two days!  That's too
Title:  many, gentlemen, too many!  If you go on so, his Eminence will be
Title:  forced to renew his company in three weeks, and I to put the
Title:  edicts in force in all their rigor.  One now and then I don't say
Title:  much about; but seven in two days, I repeat, it is too many, it
Title:  is far too many!"
Title:  
Title:  "Therefore, sire, your Majesty sees that they are come, quite
Title:  contrite and repentant, to offer you their excuses."
Title:  
Title:  "Quite contrite and repentant!  Hem!" said the king.  "I place no
Title:  confidence in their hypocritical faces.  In particular, there is
Title:  one yonder of a Gascon look.  Come hither, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who understood that it was to him this compliment was
Title:  addressed, approached, assuming a most deprecating air.
Title:  
Title:  "Why you told me he was a young man?  This is a boy, Treville, a
Title:  mere boy!  Do you mean to say that it was he who bestowed that
Title:  severe thrust at Jussac?"
Title:  
Title:  "And those two equally fine thrusts at Bernajoux."
Title:  
Title:  "Truly!"
Title:  
Title:  "Without reckoning," said Athos, "that if he had not rescued me
Title:  from the hands of Cahusac, I should not now have the honor of
Title:  making my very humble reverence to your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "Why he is a very devil, this Bearnais!  VENTRE-SAINT-GRIS,
Title:  Monsieur de Treville, as the king my father would have said.  But
Title:  at this sort of work, many doublets must be slashed and many
Title:  swords broken.  Now, Gascons are always poor, are they not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sire, I can assert that they have hitherto discovered no gold
Title:  mines in their mountains; though the Lord owes them this miracle
Title:  in recompense for the manner in which they supported the
Title:  pretensions of the king your father."
Title:  
Title:  "Which is to say that the Gascons made a king of me, myself,
Title:  seeing that I am my father's son, is it not, Treville?  Well,
Title:  happily, I don't say nay to it.  La Chesnaye, go and see if by
Title:  rummaging all my pockets you can find forty pistoles; and if you
Title:  can find them, bring them to me.  And now let us see, young man,
Title:  with your hand upon your conscience, how did all this come to
Title:  pass?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related the adventure of the preceding day in all its
Title:  details; how, not having been able to sleep for the joy he felt
Title:  in the expectation of seeing his Majesty, he had gone to his
Title:  three friends three hours before the hour of audience; how they
Title:  had gone together to the tennis court, and how, upon the fear he
Title:  had manifested lest he receive a ball in the face, he had been
Title:  jeered at by Bernajoux who had nearly paid for his jeer with his
Title:  life and M. de la Tremouille, who had nothing to do with the
Title:  matter, with the loss of his hotel.
Title:  
Title:  "This is all very well," murmured the king, "yes, this is just
Title:  the account the duke gave me of the affair.  Poor cardinal!
Title:  Seven men in two days, and those of his very best!  But that's
Title:  quite enough, gentlemen; please to understand, that's enough.
Title:  You have taken your revenge for the Rue Ferou, and even exceeded
Title:  it; you ought to be satisfied."
Title:  
Title:  "If your Majesty is so," said Treville, "we are."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes; I am," added the king, taking a handful of gold from La
Title:  Chesnaye, and putting it into the hand of d'Artagnan.  "Here,"
Title:  said he, "is a proof of my satisfaction."
Title:  
Title:  At this epoch, the ideas of pride which are in fashion in our
Title:  days did not prevail.  A gentleman received, from hand to hand,
Title:  money from the king, and was not the least in the world
Title:  humiliated.  D'Artagnan put his forty pistoles into his pocket
Title:  without any scruple--on the contrary, thanking his Majesty
Title:  greatly.
Title:  
Title:  "There," said the king, looking at a clock, "there, now, as it is
Title:  half past eight, you may retire; for as I told you, I expect
Title:  someone at nine.  Thanks for your devotedness, gentlemen.  I may
Title:  continue to rely upon it, may I not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, sire!" cried the four companions, with one voice, "we would
Title:  allow ourselves to be cut to pieces in your Majesty's service."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, well, but keep whole; that will be better, and you will be
Title:  more useful to me.  Treville," added the king, in a low voice, as
Title:  the others were retiring, "as you have no room in the Musketeers,
Title:  and as we have besides decided that a novitiate is necessary
Title:  before entering that corps, place this young man in the company
Title:  of the Guards of Monsieur Dessessart, your brother-in-law.  Ah,
Title:  PARDIEU, Treville!  I enjoy beforehand the face the cardinal will
Title:  make.  He will be furious; but I don't care.  I am doing what is
Title:  right."
Title:  
Title:  The king waved his hand to Treville, who left him and rejoined
Title:  the Musketeers, whom he found sharing the forty pistoles with
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal, as his Majesty had said, was really furious, so
Title:  furious that during eight days he absented himself from the
Title:  king's gaming table.  This did not prevent the king from being as
Title:  complacent to him as possible whenever he met him, or from asking
Title:  in the kindest tone, "Well, Monsieur Cardinal, how fares it with
Title:  that poor Jussac and that poor Bernajoux of yours?"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  7  THE INTERIOR OF "THE MUSKETEERS"
Title:  
Title:  When d'Artagnan was out of the Louvre, and consulted his friends
Title:  upon the use he had best make of his share of the forty pistoles,
Title:  Athos advised him to order a good repast at the Pomme-de-Pin,
Title:  Porthos to engage a lackey, and Aramis to provide himself with a
Title:  suitable mistress.
Title:  
Title:  The repast was carried into effect that very day, and the lackey
Title:  waited at table.  The repast had been ordered by Athos, and the
Title:  lackey furnished by Porthos.  He was a Picard, whom the glorious
Title:  Musketeer had picked up on the Bridge Tournelle, making rings and
Title:  plashing in the water.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos pretended that this occupation was proof of a reflective
Title:  and contemplative organization, and he had brought him away
Title:  without any other recommendation.  The noble carriage of this
Title:  gentleman, for whom he believed himself to be engaged, had won
Title:  Planchet--that was the name of the Picard.  He felt a slight
Title:  disappointment, however, when he saw that this place was already
Title:  taken by a compeer named Mousqueton, and when Porthos signified
Title:  to him that the state of his household, though great, would not
Title:  support two servants, and that he must enter into the service of
Title:  d'Artagnan.  Nevertheless, when he waited at the dinner given by
Title:  his master, and saw him take out a handful of gold to pay for it,
Title:  he believed his fortune made, and returned thanks to heaven for
Title:  having thrown him into the service of such a Croesus.  He
Title:  preserved this opinion even after the feast, with the remnants of
Title:  which he repaired his own long abstinence; but when in the
Title:  evening he made his master's bed, the chimeras of Planchet faded
Title:  away.  The bed was the only one in the apartment, which consisted
Title:  of an antechamber and a bedroom.  Planchet slept in the
Title:  antechamber upon a coverlet taken from the bed of d'Artagnan, and
Title:  which d'Artagnan from that time made shift to do without.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, on his part, had a valet whom he had trained in his
Title:  service in a thoroughly peculiar fashion, and who was named
Title:  Grimaud.  He was very taciturn, this worthy signor.  Be it
Title:  understood we are speaking of Athos.  During the five or six
Title:  years that he had lived in the strictest intimacy with his
Title:  companions, Porthos and Aramis, they could remember having often
Title:  seen him smile, but had never heard him laugh.  His words were
Title:  brief and expressive, conveying all that was meant, and no more;
Title:  no embellishments, no embroidery, no arabesques.  His
Title:  conversation a matter of fact, without a single romance.
Title:  
Title:  Although Athos was scarcely thirty years old, and was of great
Title:  personal beauty and intelligence of mind, no one knew whether he
Title:  had ever had a mistress.  He never spoke of women.  He certainly
Title:  did not prevent others from speaking of them before him, although
Title:  it was easy to perceive that this kind of conversation, in which
Title:  he only mingled by bitter words and misanthropic remarks, was
Title:  very disagreeable to him.  His reserve, his roughness, and his
Title:  silence made almost an old man of him.  He had, then, in order
Title:  not to disturb his habits, accustomed Grimaud to obey him upon a
Title:  simple gesture or upon a simple movement of his lips.  He never
Title:  spoke to him, except under the most extraordinary occasions.
Title:  
Title:  Sometimes, Grimaud, who feared his master as he did fire, while
Title:  entertaining a strong attachment to his person and a great
Title:  veneration for his talents, believed he perfectly understood what
Title:  he wanted, flew to execute the order received, and did precisely
Title:  the contrary.  Athos then shrugged his shoulders, and, without
Title:  putting himself in a passion, thrashed Grimaud.  On these days he
Title:  spoke a little.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, as we have seen, had a character exactly opposite to
Title:  that of Athos.  He not only talked much, but he talked loudly,
Title:  little caring, we must render him that justice, whether anybody
Title:  listened to him or not.  He talked for the pleasure of talking
Title:  and for the pleasure of hearing himself talk.  He spoke upon all
Title:  subjects except the sciences, alleging in this respect the
Title:  inveterate hatred he had borne to scholars from his childhood.
Title:  He had not so noble an air as Athos, and the commencement of
Title:  their intimacy often rendered him unjust toward that gentleman,
Title:  whom he endeavored to eclipse by his splendid dress.  But with
Title:  his simple Musketeer's uniform and nothing but the manner in
Title:  which he threw back his head and advanced his foot, Athos
Title:  instantly took the place which was his due and consigned the
Title:  ostentatious Porthos to the second rank.  Porthos consoled
Title:  himself by filling the antechamber of M. de Treville and the
Title:  guardroom of the Louvre with the accounts of his love scrapes,
Title:  after having passed from professional ladies to military ladies,
Title:  from the lawyer's dame to the baroness, there was question of
Title:  nothing less with Porthos than a foreign princess, who was
Title:  enormously fond of him.
Title:  
Title:  An old proverb says, "Like master, like man."  Let us pass, then,
Title:  from the valet of Athos to the valet of Porthos, from Grimaud to
Title:  Mousqueton.
Title:  
Title:  Mousqueton was a Norman, whose pacific name of Boniface his
Title:  master had changed into the infinitely more sonorous name of
Title:  Mousqueton.  He had entered the service of Porthos upon condition
Title:  that he should only be clothed and lodged, though in a handsome
Title:  manner; but he claimed two hours a day to himself, consecrated to
Title:  an employment which would provide for his other wants.  Porthos
Title:  agreed to the bargain; the thing suited him wonderfully well.  He
Title:  had doublets cut out of his old clothes and cast-off cloaks for
Title:  Mousqueton, and thanks to a very intelligent tailor, who made his
Title:  clothes look as good as new by turning them, and whose wife was
Title:  suspected of wishing to make Porthos descend from his
Title:  aristocratic habits, Mousqueton made a very good figure when
Title:  attending on his master.
Title:  
Title:  As for Aramis, of whom we believe we have sufficiently explained
Title:  the character--a character which, like that of his lackey was
Title:  called Bazin.  Thanks to the hopes which his master entertained
Title:  of someday entering into orders, he was always clothed in black,
Title:  as became the servant of a churchman.  He was a Berrichon,
Title:  thirty-five or forty years old, mild, peaceable, sleek, employing
Title:  the leisure his master left him in the perusal of pious works,
Title:  providing rigorously for two a dinner of few dishes, but
Title:  excellent.  For the rest, he was dumb, blind, and deaf, and of
Title:  unimpeachable fidelity.
Title:  
Title:  And now that we are acquainted, superficially at least, with the
Title:  masters and the valets, let us pass on to the dwellings occupied
Title:  by each of them.
Title:  
Title:  Athos dwelt in the Rue Ferou, within two steps of the Luxembourg.
Title:  His apartment consisted of two small chambers, very nicely fitted
Title:  up, in a furnished house, the hostess of which, still young and
Title:  still really handsome, cast tender glances uselessly at him.
Title:  Some fragments of past splendor appeared here and there upon the
Title:  walls of this modest lodging; a sword, for example, richly
Title:  embossed, which belonged by its make to the times of Francis I,
Title:  the hilt of which alone, encrusted with precious stones, might be
Title:  worth two hundred pistoles, and which, nevertheless, in his
Title:  moments of greatest distress Athos had never pledged or offered
Title:  for sale.  It had long been an object of ambition for Porthos.
Title:  Porthos would have given ten years of his life to possess this
Title:  sword.
Title:  
Title:  One day, when he had an appointment with a duchess, he endeavored
Title:  even to borrow it of Athos.  Athos, without saying anything,
Title:  emptied his pockets, got together all his jewels, purses,
Title:  aiguillettes, and gold chains, and offered them all to Porthos;
Title:  but as to the sword, he said it was sealed to its place and
Title:  should never quit it until its master should himself quit his
Title:  lodgings.  In addition to the sword, there was a portrait
Title:  representing a nobleman of the time of Henry III, dressed with
Title:  the greatest elegance, and who wore the Order of the Holy Ghost;
Title:  and this portrait had certain resemblances of lines with Athos,
Title:  certain family likenesses which indicated that this great noble,
Title:  a knight of the Order of the King, was his ancestor.
Title:  
Title:  Besides these, a casket of magnificent goldwork, with the same
Title:  arms as the sword and the portrait, formed a middle ornament to
Title:  the mantelpiece, and assorted badly with the rest of the
Title:  furniture.  Athos always carried the key of this coffer about
Title:  him; but he one day opened it before Porthos, and Porthos was
Title:  convinced that this coffer contained nothing but letters and
Title:  papers--love letters and family papers, no doubt.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos lived in an apartment, large in size and of very
Title:  sumptuous appearance, in the Rue du Vieux-Colombier.  Every time
Title:  he passed with a friend before his windows, at one of which
Title:  Mousqueton was sure to be placed in full livery, Porthos raised
Title:  his head and his hand, and said, "That is my abode!"  But he was
Title:  never to be found at home; he never invited anybody to go up with
Title:  him, and no one could form an idea of what his sumptuous
Title:  apartment contained in the shape of real riches.
Title:  
Title:  As to Aramis, he dwelt in a little lodging composed of a boudoir,
Title:  an eating room, and a bedroom, which room, situated, as the
Title:  others were, on the ground floor, looked out upon a little fresh
Title:  green garden, shady and impenetrable to the eyes of his
Title:  neighbors.
Title:  
Title:  With regard to d'Artagnan, we know how he was lodged, and we have
Title:  already made acquaintance with his lackey, Master Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who was by nature very curious--as people generally
Title:  are who possess the genius of intrigue--did all he could to make
Title:  out who Athos, Porthos, and Aramis really were (for under these
Title:  pseudonyms each of these young men concealed his family name)--
Title:  Athos in particular, who, a league away, savored of nobility.  He
Title:  addressed himself then to Porthos to gain information respecting
Title:  Athos and Aramis, and to Aramis in order to learn something of
Title:  Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  Unfortunately Porthos knew nothing of the life of his silent
Title:  companion but what revealed itself.  It was said Athos had met
Title:  with great crosses in love, and that a frightful treachery had
Title:  forever poisoned the life of this gallant man.  What could this
Title:  treachery be?  All the world was ignorant of it.
Title:  
Title:  As to Porthos, except his real name (as was the case with those
Title:  of his two comrades), his life was very easily known.  Vain and
Title:  indiscreet, it was as easy to see through him as through a
Title:  crystal.  The only thing to mislead the investigator would have
Title:  been belief in all the good things he said of himself.
Title:  
Title:  With respect to Aramis, though having the air of having nothing
Title:  secret about him, he was a young fellow made up of mysteries,
Title:  answering little to questions put to him about others, and having
Title:  learned from him the report which prevailed concerning the
Title:  success of the Musketeer with a princess, wished to gain a little
Title:  insight into the amorous adventures of his interlocutor.  "And
Title:  you, my dear companion," said he, "you speak of the baronesses,
Title:  countesses, and princesses of others?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU!  I spoke of them because Porthos talked of them
Title:  himself, because he had paraded all these fine things before me.
Title:  But be assured, my dear Monsieur d'Artagnan, that if I had
Title:  obtained them from any other source, or if they had been confided
Title:  to me, there exists no confessor more discreet than myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I don't doubt that," replied d'Artagnan; "but it seems to me
Title:  that you are tolerably familiar with coats of arms--a certain
Title:  embroidered handkerchief, for instance, to which I owe the honor
Title:  of your acquaintance?"
Title:  
Title:  This time Aramis was not angry, but assumed the most modest air
Title:  and replied in a friendly tone, "My dear friend, do not forget
Title:  that I wish to belong to the Church, and that I avoid all mundane
Title:  opportunities.  The handkerchief you saw had not been given to
Title:  me, but it had been forgotten and left at my house by one of my
Title:  friends.  I was obliged to pick it up in order not to compromise
Title:  him and the lady he loves.  As for myself, I neither have, nor
Title:  desire to have, a mistress, following in that respect the very
Title:  judicious example of Athos, who has none any more than I have."
Title:  
Title:  "But what the devil!  You are not a priest, you are a Musketeer!"
Title:  
Title:  "A Musketeer for a time, my friend, as the cardinal says, a
Title:  Musketeer against my will, but a churchman at heart, believe me.
Title:  Athos and Porthos dragged me into this to occupy me.  I had, at
Title:  the moment of being ordained, a little difficulty with--But that
Title:  would not interest you, and I am taking up your valuable time."
Title:  
Title:  "Not at all; it interests me very much," cried d'Artagnan; "and
Title:  at this moment I have absolutely nothing to do."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but I have my breviary to repeat," answered Aramis; "then
Title:  some verses to compose, which Madame d'Aiguillon begged of me.
Title:  Then I must go to the Rue St. Honore in order to purchase some
Title:  rouge for Madame de Chevreuse.  So you see, my dear friend, that
Title:  if you are not in a hurry, I am very much in a hurry."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis held out his hand in a cordial manner to his young
Title:  companion, and took leave of him.
Title:  
Title:  Notwithstanding all the pains he took, d'Artagnan was unable to
Title:  learn any more concerning his three new-made friends.  He formed,
Title:  therefore, the resolution of believing for the present all that
Title:  was said of their past, hoping for more certain and extended
Title:  revelations in the future.  In the meanwhile, he looked upon
Title:  Athos as an Achilles, Porthos as an Ajax, and Aramis as a Joseph.
Title:  
Title:  As to the rest, the life of the four young friends was joyous
Title:  enough.  Athos played, and that as a rule unfortunately.
Title:  Nevertheless, he never borrowed a sou of his companions, although
Title:  his purse was ever at their service; and when he had played upon
Title:  honor, he always awakened his creditor by six o'clock the next
Title:  morning to pay the debt of the preceding evening.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos had his fits.  On the days when he won he was insolent
Title:  and ostentatious; if he lost, he disappeared completely for
Title:  several days, after which he reappeared with a pale face and
Title:  thinner person, but with money in his purse.
Title:  
Title:  As to Aramis, he never played.  He was the worst Musketeer and
Title:  the most unconvivial companion imaginable.  He had always
Title:  something or other to do.  Sometimes in the midst of dinner, when
Title:  everyone, under the attraction of wine and in the warmth of
Title:  conversation, believed they had two or three hours longer to
Title:  enjoy themselves at table, Aramis looked at his watch, arose with
Title:  a bland smile, and took leave of the company, to go, as he said,
Title:  to consult a casuist with whom he had an appointment.  At other
Title:  times he would return home to write a treatise, and requested his
Title:  friends not to disturb him.
Title:  
Title:  At this Athos would smile, with his charming, melancholy smile,
Title:  which so became his noble countenance, and Porthos would drink,
Title:  swearing that Aramis would never be anything but a village CURE.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet, d'Artagnan's valet, supported his good fortune nobly.
Title:  He received thirty sous per day, and for a month he returned to
Title:  his lodgings gay as a chaffinch, and affable toward his master.
Title:  When the wind of adversity began to blow upon the housekeeping of
Title:  the Rue des Fossoyeurs--that is to say, when the forty pistoles
Title:  of King Louis XIII were consumed or nearly so--he commenced
Title:  complaints which Athos thought nauseous, Porthos indecent, and
Title:  Aramis ridiculous.  Athos counseled d'Artagnan to dismiss the
Title:  fellow; Porthos was of opinion that he should give him a good
Title:  thrashing first; and Aramis contended that a master should never
Title:  attend to anything but the civilities paid to him.
Title:  
Title:  "This is all very easy for you to say," replied d'Artagnan, "for
Title:  you, Athos, who live like a dumb man with Grimaud, who forbid him
Title:  to speak, and consequently never exchange ill words with him; for
Title:  you, Porthos, who carry matters in such a magnificent style, and
Title:  are a god to your valet, Mousqueton; and for you, Aramis, who,
Title:  always abstracted by your theological studies, inspire your
Title:  servant, Bazin, a mild, religious man, with a profound respect;
Title:  but for me, who am without any settled means and without
Title:  resources--for me, who am neither a Musketeer nor even a
Title:  Guardsman, what I am to do to inspire either the affection, the
Title:  terror, or the respect in Planchet?"
Title:  
Title:  "This is serious," answered the three friends; "it is a family
Title:  affair.  It is with valets as with wives, they must be placed at
Title:  once upon the footing in which you wish them to remain.  Reflect
Title:  upon it."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan did reflect, and resolved to thrash Planchet
Title:  provisionally; which he did with the conscientiousness that
Title:  d'Artagnan carried into everything.  After having well beaten
Title:  him, he forbade him to leave his service without his permission.
Title:  "For," added he, "the future cannot fail to mend; I inevitably
Title:  look for better times.  Your fortune is therefore made if you
Title:  remain with me, and I am too good a master to allow you to miss
Title:  such a chance by granting you the dismissal you require."
Title:  
Title:  This manner of acting roused much respect for d'Artagnan's policy
Title:  among the Musketeers.  Planchet was equally seized with
Title:  admiration, and said no more about going away.
Title:  
Title:  The life of the four young men had become fraternal.  D'Artagnan,
Title:  who had no settled habits of his own, as he came from his
Title:  province into the midst of his world quite new to him, fell
Title:  easily into the habits of his friends.
Title:  
Title:  They rose about eight o'clock in the winter, about six in summer,
Title:  and went to take the countersign and see how things went on at M.
Title:  de Treville's.  D'Artagnan, although he was not a Musketeer,
Title:  performed the duty of one with remarkable punctuality.  He went
Title:  on guard because he always kept company with whoever of his
Title:  friends was on duty.  He was well known at the Hotel of the
Title:  Musketeers, where everyone considered him a good comrade.  M. de
Title:  Treville, who had appreciated him at the first glance and who
Title:  bore him a real affection, never ceased recommending him to the
Title:  king.
Title:  
Title:  On their side, the three Musketeers were much attached to their
Title:  young comrade.  The friendship which united these four men, and
Title:  the need they felt of seeing another three or four times a day,
Title:  whether for dueling, business, or pleasure, caused them to be
Title:  continually running after one another like shadows; and the
Title:  Inseparables were constantly to be met with seeking one another,
Title:  from the Luxembourg to the Place St. Sulpice, or from the Rue du
Title:  Vieux-Colombier to the Luxembourg.
Title:  
Title:  In the meanwhile the promises of M. de Treville went on
Title:  prosperously.  One fine morning the king commanded M. de
Title:  Chevalier Dessessart to admit d'Artagnan as a cadet in his
Title:  company of Guards.  D'Artagnan, with a sigh, donned his uniform,
Title:  which he would have exchanged for that of a Musketeer at the
Title:  expense of ten years of his existence.  But M. de Treville
Title:  promised this favor after a novitiate of two years--a novitiate
Title:  which might besides be abridged if an opportunity should present
Title:  itself for d'Artagnan to render the king any signal service, or
Title:  to distinguish himself by some brilliant action.  Upon this
Title:  promise d'Artagnan withdrew, and the next day he began service.
Title:  
Title:  Then it became the turn of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis to mount
Title:  guard with d'Artagnan when he was on duty.  The company of M. le
Title:  Chevalier Dessessart thus received four instead of one when it
Title:  admitted d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  8  CONCERNING A COURT INTRIGUE
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime, the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII, like all
Title:  other things of this world, after having had a beginning had an
Title:  end, and after this end our four companions began to be somewhat
Title:  embarrassed.  At first, Athos supported the association for a
Title:  time with his own means.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos succeeded him; and thanks to one of those disappearances
Title:  to which he was accustomed, he was able to provide for the wants
Title:  of all for a fortnight.  At last it became Aramis's turn, who
Title:  performed it with a good grace and who succeeded--as he said, by
Title:  selling some theological books--in procuring a few pistoles.
Title:  
Title:  Then, as they had been accustomed to do, they had recourse to M.
Title:  de Treville, who made some advances on their pay; but these
Title:  advances could not go far with three Musketeers who were already
Title:  much in arrears and a Guardsman who as yet had no pay at all.
Title:  
Title:  At length when they found they were likely to be really in want,
Title:  they got together, as a last effort, eight or ten pistoles, with
Title:  which Porthos went to the gaming table.  Unfortunately he was in
Title:  a bad vein; he lost all, together with twenty-five pistoles for
Title:  which he had given his word.
Title:  
Title:  Then the inconvenience became distress.  The hungry friends,
Title:  followed by their lackeys, were seen haunting the quays and Guard
Title:  rooms, picking up among their friends abroad all the dinners they
Title:  could meet with; for according to the advice of Aramis, it was
Title:  prudent to sow repasts right and left in prosperity, in order to
Title:  reap a few in time of need.
Title:  
Title:  Athos was invited four times, and each time took his friends and
Title:  their lackeys with him.  Porthos had six occasions, and contrived
Title:  in the same manner that his friends should partake of them;
Title:  Aramis had eight of them.  He was a man, as must have been
Title:  already perceived, who made but little noise, and yet was much
Title:  sought after.
Title:  
Title:  As to d'Artagnan, who as yet knew nobody in the capital, he only
Title:  found one chocolate breakfast at the house of a priest of his own
Title:  province, and one dinner at the house of a cornet of the Guards.
Title:  He took his army to the priest's, where they devoured as much
Title:  provision as would have lasted him for two months, and to the
Title:  cornet's, who performed wonders; but as Planchet said, "People do
Title:  not eat at once for all time, even when they eat a good deal."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan thus felt himself humiliated in having only procured
Title:  one meal and a half for his companions--as the breakfast at the
Title:  priest's could only be counted as half a repast--in return for
Title:  the feasts which Athos, Porthos, and Aramis had procured him.  He
Title:  fancied himself a burden to the society, forgetting in his
Title:  perfectly juvenile good faith that he had fed this society for a
Title:  month; and he set his mind actively to work.  He reflected that
Title:  this coalition of four young, brave, enterprising, and active men
Title:  ought to have some other object than swaggering walks, fencing
Title:  lessons, and practical jokes, more or less witty.
Title:  
Title:  In fact, four men such as they were--four men devoted to one
Title:  another, from their purses to their lives; four men always
Title:  supporting one another, never yielding, executing singly or
Title:  together the resolutions formed in common; four arms threatening
Title:  the four cardinal points, or turning toward a single point--must
Title:  inevitably, either subterraneously, in open day, by mining, in
Title:  the trench, by cunning, or by force, open themselves a way toward
Title:  the object they wished to attain, however well it might be
Title:  defended, or however distant it may seem.  The only thing that
Title:  astonished d'Artagnan was that his friends had never thought of
Title:  this.
Title:  
Title:  He was thinking by himself, and even seriously racking his brain
Title:  to find a direction for this single force four times multiplied,
Title:  with which he did not doubt, as with the lever for which
Title:  Archimedes sought, they should succeed in moving the world, when
Title:  someone tapped gently at his door.  D'Artagnan awakened Planchet
Title:  and ordered him to open it.
Title:  
Title:  From this phrase, "d'Artagnan awakened Planchet," the reader must
Title:  not suppose it was night, or that day was hardly come.  No, it
Title:  had just struck four.  Planchet, two hours before, had asked his
Title:  master for some dinner, and he had answered him with the proverb,
Title:  "He who sleeps, dines."  And Planchet dined by sleeping.
Title:  
Title:  A man was introduced of simple mien, who had the appearance of a
Title:  tradesman.  Planchet, by way of dessert, would have liked to hear
Title:  the conversation; but the citizen declared to d'Artagnan that
Title:  what he had to say being important and confidential, he desired
Title:  to be left alone with him.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan dismissed Planchet, and requested his visitor to be
Title:  seated.  There was a moment of silence, during which the two men
Title:  looked at each other, as if to make a preliminary acquaintance,
Title:  after which d'Artagnan bowed, as a sign that he listened.
Title:  
Title:  "I have heard Monsieur d'Artagnan spoken of as a very brave young
Title:  man," said the citizen; "and this reputation which he justly
Title:  enjoys had decided me to confide a secret to him."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak, monsieur, speak," said d'Artagnan, who instinctively
Title:  scented something advantageous.
Title:  
Title:  The citizen made a fresh pause and continued, "I have a wife who
Title:  is seamstress to the queen, monsieur, and who is not deficient in
Title:  either virtue or beauty.  I was induced to marry her about three
Title:  years ago, although she had but very little dowry, because
Title:  Monsieur Laporte, the queen's cloak bearer, is her godfather, and
Title:  befriends her."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Well!" resumed the citizen, "well, monsieur, my wife was
Title:  abducted yesterday morning, as she was coming out of her
Title:  workroom."
Title:  
Title:  "And by whom was your wife abducted?"
Title:  
Title:  "I know nothing surely, monsieur, but I suspect someone."
Title:  
Title:  "And who is the person whom you suspect?"
Title:  
Title:  "A man who has pursued her a long time."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!"
Title:  
Title:  "But allow me to tell you, monsieur," continued the citizen,
Title:  "that I am convinced that there is less love than politics in all
Title:  this."
Title:  
Title:  "Less love than politics," replied d'Artagnan, with a reflective
Title:  air; "and what do you suspect?"
Title:  
Title:  "I do not know whether I ought to tell you what I suspect."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, I beg you to observe that I ask you absolutely
Title:  nothing.  It is you who have come to me.  It is you who have told
Title:  me that you had a secret to confide in me.  Act, then, as you
Title:  think proper; there is still time to withdraw."
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, no; you appear to be an honest young man, and I
Title:  will have confidence in you.  I believe, then, that it is not on
Title:  account of any intrigues of her own that my wife has been
Title:  arrested, but because of those of a lady much greater than
Title:  herself."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!  Can it be on account of the amours of Madame de
Title:  Bois-Tracy?" said d'Artagnan, wishing to have the air, in the
Title:  eyes of the citizen, of being posted as to court affairs.
Title:  
Title:  "Higher, monsieur, higher."
Title:  
Title:  "Of Madame d'Aiguillon?"
Title:  
Title:  "Still higher."
Title:  
Title:  "Of Madame de Chevreuse?"
Title:  
Title:  "Of the--" d'Artagnan checked himself.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," replied the terrified citizen, in a tone so low
Title:  that he was scarcely audible.
Title:  
Title:  "And with whom?"
Title:  
Title:  "With whom can it be, if not the Duke of--"
Title:  
Title:  "The Duke of--"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," replied the citizen, giving a still fainter
Title:  intonation to his voice.
Title:  
Title:  "But how do you know all this?"
Title:  
Title:  "How do I know it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, how do you know it?  No half-confidence, or--you understand!"
Title:  
Title:  "I know it from my wife, monsieur--from my wife herself."
Title:  
Title:  "Who learns it from whom?"
Title:  
Title:  "From Monsieur Laporte.  Did I not tell you that she was the
Title:  goddaughter of Monsieur Laporte, the confidential man of the
Title:  queen?  Well, Monsieur Laporte placed her near her Majesty in
Title:  order that our poor queen might at least have someone in whom she
Title:  could place confidence, abandoned as she is by the king, watched
Title:  as she is by the cardinal, betrayed as she is by everybody."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!  It begins to develop itself," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, my wife came home four days ago, monsieur.  One of her
Title:  conditions was that she should come and see me twice a week; for,
Title:  as I had the honor to tell you, my wife loves me dearly--my wife,
Title:  then, came and confided to me that the queen at that very moment
Title:  entertained great fears."
Title:  
Title:  "Truly!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes.  The cardinal, as it appears, pursues he and persecutes her
Title:  more than ever.  He cannot pardon her the history of the
Title:  Saraband.  You know the history of the Saraband?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU!  Know it!" replied d'Artagnan, who knew nothing about
Title:  it, but who wished to appear to know everything that was going
Title:  on.
Title:  
Title:  "So that now it is no longer hatred, but vengeance."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  "And the queen believes--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what does the queen believe?"
Title:  
Title:  "She believes that someone has written to the Duke of Buckingham
Title:  in her name."
Title:  
Title:  "In the queen's name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, to make him come to Paris; and when once come to Paris, to
Title:  draw him into some snare."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  But your wife, monsieur, what has she to do with all
Title:  this?"
Title:  
Title:  "Her devotion to the queen is known; and they wish either to
Title:  remove her from her mistress, or to intimidate her, in order to
Title:  obtain her Majesty's secrets, or to seduce her and make use of
Title:  her as a spy."
Title:  
Title:  "That is likely," said d'Artagnan; "but the man who has abducted
Title:  her--do you know him?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have told you that I believe I know him."
Title:  
Title:  "His name?"
Title:  
Title:  "I do not know that; what I do know is that he is a creature of
Title:  the cardinal, his evil genius."
Title:  
Title:  "But you have seen him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, my wife pointed him out to me one day."
Title:  
Title:  'Has he anything remarkable about him by which one may recognize
Title:  him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, certainly; he is a noble of very lofty carriage, black hair,
Title:  swarthy complexion, piercing eye, white teeth, and has a scar on
Title:  his temple."
Title:  
Title:  "A scar on his temple!" cried d'Artagnan; "and with that, white
Title:  teeth, a piercing eye, dark complexion, black hair, and haughty
Title:  carriage--why, that's my man of Meung."
Title:  
Title:  "He is your man, do you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes; but that has nothing to do with it.  No, I am wrong.
Title:  On the contrary, that simplifies the matter greatly.  If your man
Title:  is mine, with one blow I shall obtain two revenges, that's all;
Title:  but where to find this man?"
Title:  
Title:  "I know not."
Title:  
Title:  "Have you no information as to his abiding place?"
Title:  
Title:  "None.  One day, as I was conveying my wife back to the Louvre,
Title:  he was coming out as she was going in, and she showed him to me."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  The devil!" murmured d'Artagnan; "all this is vague
Title:  enough.  From whom have you learned of the abduction of your
Title:  wife?"
Title:  
Title:  "From Monsieur Laporte."
Title:  
Title:  "Did he give you any details?"
Title:  
Title:  "He knew none himself."
Title:  
Title:  "And you have learned nothing from any other quarter?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I have received--"
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "I fear I am committing a great imprudence."
Title:  
Title:  "You always come back to that; but I must make you see this time
Title:  that it is too late to retreat."
Title:  
Title:  "I do not retreat, MORDIEU!" cried the citizen, swearing in order
Title:  to rouse his courage.  "Besides, by the faith of Bonacieux--"
Title:  
Title:  "You call yourself Bonacieux?" interrupted d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that is my name."
Title:  
Title:  "You said, then, by the word of Bonacieux.  Pardon me for
Title:  interrupting you, but it appears to me that that name is familiar
Title:  to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Possibly, monsieur. I am your landlord."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said d'Artagnan, half rising and bowing; "you are my
Title:  landlord?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, yes.  And as it is three months since you have
Title:  been here, and though, distracted as you must be in your
Title:  important occupations, you have forgotten to pay me my rent--as,
Title:  I say, I have not tormented you a single instant, I thought you
Title:  would appreciate my delicacy."
Title:  
Title:  "How can it be otherwise, my dear Bonacieux?" replied d'Artagnan;
Title:  "trust me, I am fully grateful for such unparalleled conduct, and
Title:  if, as I told you, I can be of any service to you--"
Title:  
Title:  "I believe you, monsieur, I believe you; and as I was about to
Title:  say, by the word of Bonacieux, I have confidence in you."
Title:  
Title:  "Finish, then, what you were about to say."
Title:  
Title:  The citizen took a paper from his pocket, and presented it to
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "A letter?" said the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Which I received this morning."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan opened it, and as the day was beginning to decline, he
Title:  approached the window to read it.  The citizen followed him.
Title:  
Title:  "'Do not seek your wife,'" read d'Artagnan; "'she will be
Title:  restored to you when there is no longer occasion for her. If you
Title:  make a single step to find her you are lost.'
Title:  
Title:  "That's pretty positive," continued d'Artagnan; "but after all,
Title:  it is but a menace."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but that menace terrifies me.  I am not a fighting man at
Title:  all, monsieur, and I am afraid of the Bastille."
Title:  
Title:  "Hum!" said d'Artagnan.  "I have no greater regard for the
Title:  Bastille than you.  If it were nothing but a sword thrust, why
Title:  then--"
Title:  
Title:  "I have counted upon you on this occasion, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes?"
Title:  
Title:  "Seeing you constantly surrounded by Musketeers of a very superb
Title:  appearance, and knowing that these Musketeers belong to Monsieur
Title:  de Treville, and were consequently enemies of the cardinal, I
Title:  thought that you and your friends, while rendering justice to
Title:  your poor queen, would be pleased to play his Eminence an ill
Title:  turn."
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt."
Title:  
Title:  "And then I have thought that considering three months' lodging,
Title:  about which I have said nothing--"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes; you have already given me that reason, and I find it
Title:  excellent."
Title:  
Title:  "Reckoning still further, that as long as you do me the honor to
Title:  remain in my house I shall never speak to you about rent--"
Title:  
Title:  "Very kind!"
Title:  
Title:  "And adding to this, if there be need of it, meaning to offer you
Title:  fifty pistoles, if, against all probability, you should be short
Title:  at the present moment."
Title:  
Title:  "Admirable!  You are rich then, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am comfortably off, monsieur, that's all; I have scraped
Title:  together some such thing as an income of two or three thousand
Title:  crown in the haberdashery business, but more particularly in
Title:  venturing some funds in the last voyage of the celebrated
Title:  navigator Jean Moquet; so that you understand, monsieur--But"
Title:  cried the citizen.
Title:  
Title:  "What!" demanded d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Whom do I see yonder?"
Title:  
Title:  "Where?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the street, facing your window, in the embrasure of that
Title:  door--a man wrapped in a cloak."
Title:  
Title:  "It is he!" cried d'Artagnan and the citizen at the same time,
Title:  each having recognized his man.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, this time," cried d'Artagnan, springing to his sword, "this
Title:  time he will not escape me!"
Title:  
Title:  Drawing his sword from its scabbard, he rushed out of the
Title:  apartment.  On the staircase he met Athos and Porthos, who were
Title:  coming to see him.  They separated, and d'Artagnan rushed between
Title:  them like a dart.
Title:  
Title:  "Pah!  Where are you going?" cried the two Musketeers in a breath.
Title:  
Title:  "The man of Meung!" replied d'Artagnan, and disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had more than once related to his friends his
Title:  adventure with the stranger, as well as the apparition of the
Title:  beautiful foreigner, to whom this man had confided some important
Title:  missive.
Title:  
Title:  The opinion of Athos was that d'Artagnan had lost his letter in
Title:  the skirmish.  A gentleman, in his opinion--and according to
Title:  d'Artagnan's portrait of him, the stranger must be a gentleman--
Title:  would be incapable of the baseness of stealing a letter.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos saw nothing in all this but a love meeting, given by a
Title:  lady to a cavalier, or by a cavalier to a lady, which had been
Title:  disturbed by the presence of d'Artagnan and his yellow horse.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis said that as these sorts of affairs were mysterious, it
Title:  was better not to fathom them.
Title:  
Title:  They understood, then, from the few words which escaped from
Title:  d'Artagnan, what affair was in hand, and as they thought that
Title:  overtaking his man, or losing sight of him, d'Artagnan would
Title:  return to his rooms, they kept on their way.
Title:  
Title:  When they entered d'Artagnan's chamber, it was empty; the
Title:  landlord, dreading the consequences of the encounter which was
Title:  doubtless about to take place between the young man and the
Title:  stranger, had, consistent with the character he had given
Title:  himself, judged it prudent to decamp.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  9  D'ARTAGNAN SHOWS HIMSELF
Title:  
Title:  As Athos and Porthos had foreseen, at the expiration of a half
Title:  hour, d'Artagnan returned.  He had again missed his man, who had
Title:  disappeared as if by enchantment.  D'Artagnan had run, sword in
Title:  hand, through all the neighboring streets, but had found nobody
Title:  resembling the man he sought for.  Then he came back to the point
Title:  where, perhaps, he ought to have begun, and that was to knock at
Title:  the door against which the stranger had leaned; but this proved
Title:  useless--for though he knocked ten or twelve times in succession,
Title:  no one answered, and some of the neighbors, who put their noses
Title:  out of their windows or were brought to their doors by the noise,
Title:  had assured him that that house, all the openings of which were
Title:  tightly closed, had not been inhabited for six months.
Title:  
Title:  While d'Artagnan was running through the streets and knocking at
Title:  doors, Aramis had joined his companions; so that on returning home
Title:  d'Artagnan found the reunion complete.
Title:  
Title:  "Well!" cried the three Musketeers all together, on seeing
Title:  d'Artagnan enter with his brow covered with perspiration and his
Title:  countenance upset with anger.
Title:  
Title:  "Well!" cried he, throwing his sword upon the bed, "this man must
Title:  be the devil in person; he has disappeared like a phantom,
Title:  like a shade, like a specter."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you believe in apparitions?" asked Athos of Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "I never believe in anything I have not seen, and as I never have
Title:  seen apparitions, I don't believe in them."
Title:  
Title:  "The Bible," said Aramis, "make our belief in them a law; the
Title:  ghost of Samuel appeared to Saul, and it is an article of faith
Title:  that I should be very sorry to see any doubt thrown upon,
Title:  Porthos."
Title:  
Title:  "At all events, man or devil, body or shadow, illusion or
Title:  reality, this man is born for my damnation; for his flight has
Title:  caused us to miss a glorious affair, gentlemen--an affair by
Title:  which there were a hundred pistoles, and perhaps more, to be
Title:  gained."
Title:  
Title:  "How is that?" cried Porthos and Aramis in a breath.
Title:  
Title:  As to Athos, faithful to his system of reticence, he contented
Title:  himself with interrogating d'Artagnan by a look.
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet," said d'Artagnan to his domestic, who just then
Title:  insinuated his head through the half-open door in order to catch
Title:  some fragments of the conversation, "go down to my landlord,
Title:  Monsieur Bonacieux, and ask him to send me half a dozen bottles
Title:  of Beaugency wine; I prefer that."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!  You have credit with your landlord, then?" asked
Title:  Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," replied d'Artagnan, "from this very day; and mind, if the
Title:  wine is bad, we will send him to find better."
Title:  
Title:  "We must use, and not abuse," said Aramis, sententiously.
Title:  
Title:  "I always said that d'Artagnan had the longest head of the four,"
Title:  said Athos, who, having uttered his opinion, to which d'Artagnan
Title:  replied with a bow, immediately resumed his accustomed silence.
Title:  
Title:  "But come, what is this about?" asked Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Aramis, "impart it to us, my dear friend, unless the
Title:  honor of any lady be hazarded by this confidence; in that case
Title:  you would do better to keep it to yourself."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied," replied d'Artagnan; "the honor of no one will
Title:  have cause to complain of what I have to tell."
Title:  
Title:  He then related to his friends, word for word, all that had
Title:  passed between him and his host, and how the man who had abducted
Title:  the wife of his worthy landlord was the same with whom he had had
Title:  the difference at the hostelry of the Jolly Miller.
Title:  
Title:  "Your affair is not bad," said Athos, after having tasted like a
Title:  connoisseur and indicated by a nod of his head that he thought
Title:  the wine good; "and one may draw fifty or sixty pistoles from
Title:  this good man.  Then there only remains to ascertain whether
Title:  these fifty or sixty pistoles are worth the risk of four heads."
Title:  
Title:  "But observe," cried d'Artagnan, "that there is a woman in the
Title:  affair--a woman carried off, a woman who is doubtless threatened,
Title:  tortured perhaps, and all because she is faithful to her
Title:  mistress."
Title:  
Title:  "Beware, d'Artagnan, beware," said Aramis.  "You grow a little
Title:  too warm, in my opinion, about the fate of Madame Bonacieux.
Title:  Woman was created for our destruction, and it is from her we
Title:  inherit all our miseries."
Title:  
Title:  At this speech of Aramis, the brow of Athos became clouded and he
Title:  bit his lips.
Title:  
Title:  "It is not Madame Bonacieux about whom I am anxious," cried
Title:  d'Artagnan, "but the queen, whom the king abandons, whom the
Title:  cardinal persecutes, and who sees the heads of all her friends
Title:  fall, one after the other."
Title:  
Title:  "Why does she love what we hate most in the world, the Spaniards
Title:  and the English?"
Title:  
Title:  "Spain is her country," replied d'Artagnan; "and it is very
Title:  natural that she should love the Spanish, who are the children of
Title:  the same soil as herself.  As to the second reproach, I have
Title:  heard it said that she does not love the English, but an
Title:  Englishman."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, and by my faith," said Athos, "it must be acknowledged
Title:  that this Englishman is worthy of being loved.  I never saw a man
Title:  with a nobler air than his."
Title:  
Title:  "Without reckoning that he dresses as nobody else can," said
Title:  Porthos.  "I was at the Louvre on the day when he scattered his
Title:  pearls; and, PARDIEU, I picked up two that I sold for ten
Title:  pistoles each.  Do you know him, Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "As well as you do, gentlemen; for I was among those who seized
Title:  him in the garden at Amiens, into which Monsieur Putange, the
Title:  queen's equerry, introduced me.  I was at school at the time, and
Title:  the adventure appeared to me to be cruel for the king."
Title:  
Title:  "Which would not prevent me," said d'Artagnan, "if I knew where
Title:  the Duke of Buckingham was, from taking him by the hand and
Title:  conducting him to the queen, were it only to enrage the cardinal,
Title:  and if we could find means to play him a sharp turn, I vow that I
Title:  would voluntarily risk my head in doing it."
Title:  
Title:  "And did the mercer*," rejoined Athos, "tell you, d'Artagnan,
Title:  that the queen thought that Buckingham had been brought over by a
Title:  forged letter?"
Title:  
Title:  *Haberdasher
Title:  
Title:  "She is afraid so."
Title:  
Title:  "Wait a minute, then," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "What for?" demanded Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Go on, while I endeavor to recall circumstances."
Title:  
Title:  "And now I am convinced," said d'Artagnan, "that this abduction
Title:  of the queen's woman is connected with the events of which we are
Title:  speaking, and perhaps with the presence of Buckingham in Paris."
Title:  
Title:  "The Gascon is full of ideas," said Porthos, with admiration.
Title:  
Title:  "I like to hear him talk," said Athos; "his dialect amuses me."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," cried Aramis, "listen to this."
Title:  
Title:  "Listen to Aramis," said his three friends.
Title:  
Title:  "Yesterday I was at the house of a doctor of theology, whom I
Title:  sometimes consult about my studies."
Title:  
Title:  Athos smiled.
Title:  
Title:  "He resides in a quiet quarter," continued Aramis; "his tastes
Title:  and his profession require it.  Now, at the moment when I left
Title:  his house--"
Title:  
Title:  Here Aramis paused.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," cried his auditors; "at the moment you left his house?"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis appeared to make a strong inward effort, like a man who,
Title:  in the full relation of a falsehood, finds himself stopped by
Title:  some unforeseen obstacle; but the eyes of his three companions
Title:  were fixed upon him, their ears were wide open, and there were no
Title:  means of retreat.
Title:  
Title:  "This doctor has a niece," continued Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, he has a niece!" interrupted Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "A very respectable lady," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  The three friends burst into laughter.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, if you laugh, if you doubt me," replied Aramis, "you shall
Title:  know nothing."
Title:  
Title:  "We believe like Mohammedans, and are as mute as tombstones,"
Title:  said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I will continue, then," resumed Aramis.  "This niece comes
Title:  sometimes to see her uncle; and by chance was there yesterday at
Title:  the same time that I was, and it was my duty to offer to conduct
Title:  her to her carriage."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  She has a carriage, then, this niece of the doctor?"
Title:  interrupted Porthos, one of whose faults was a great looseness of
Title:  tongue.  "A nice acquaintance, my friend!"
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos," replied Aramis, "I have had the occasion to observe to
Title:  you more than once that you are very indiscreet; and that is
Title:  injurious to you among the women."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen, gentlemen," cried d'Artagnan, who began to get a
Title:  glimpse of the result of the adventure, "the thing is serious.
Title:  Let us try not to jest, if we can.  Go on Aramis, go on."
Title:  
Title:  "All at once, a tall, dark gentleman--just like yours,
Title:  d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "The same, perhaps," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Possibly," continued Aramis, "came toward me, accompanied by
Title:  five or six men who followed about ten paces behind him; and in
Title:  the politest tone, 'Monsieur Duke,' said he to me, 'and you
Title:  madame,' continued he, addressing the lady on my arm--"
Title:  
Title:  "The doctor's niece?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue, Porthos," said Athos; "you are insupportable."
Title:  
Title:  "'--will you enter this carriage, and that without offering the
Title:  least resistance, without making the least noise?'"
Title:  
Title:  "He took you for Buckingham!" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I believe so," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "But the lady?" asked Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "He took her for the queen!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Just so," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "The Gascon is the devil!" cried Athos; "nothing escapes him."
Title:  
Title:  "The fact is," said Porthos, "Aramis is of the same height, and
Title:  something of the shape of the duke; but it nevertheless appears
Title:  to me that the dress of a Musketeer--"
Title:
