Title:  "I wore an enormous cloak," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "In the month of July?  The devil!" said Porthos.  "Is the doctor
Title:  afraid that you may be recognized?"
Title:  
Title:  "I can comprehend that the spy may have been deceived by the
Title:  person; but the face--"
Title:  
Title:  "I had a large hat," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, good lord," cried Porthos, "what precautions for the study
Title:  of theology!"
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen, gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, "do not let us lose our
Title:  time in jesting.  Let us separate, and let us seek the mercer's
Title:  wife--that is the key of the intrigue."
Title:  
Title:  "A woman of such inferior condition!  Can you believe so?" said
Title:  Porthos, protruding his lips with contempt.
Title:  
Title:  "She is goddaughter to Laporte, the confidential valet of the
Title:  queen.  Have I not told you so, gentlemen?  Besides, it has
Title:  perhaps been her Majesty's calculation to seek on this occasion
Title:  for support so lowly.  High heads expose themselves from afar,
Title:  and the cardinal is longsighted."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos, "in the first place make a bargain with the
Title:  mercer, and a good bargain."
Title:  
Title:  "That's useless," said d'Artagnan; "for I believe if he does not
Title:  pay us, we shall be well enough paid by another party."
Title:  
Title:  At this moment a sudden noise of footsteps was heard upon the
Title:  stairs; the door was thrown violently open, and the unfortunate
Title:  mercer rushed into the chamber in which the council was held.
Title:  
Title:  "Save me, gentlemen, for the love of heaven, save me!" cried he.
Title:  "There are four men come to arrest me.  Save me!  Save me!"
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis arose.
Title:  
Title:  "A moment," cried d'Artagnan, making them a sign to replace in
Title:  the scabbard their half-drawn swords.  "It is not courage that is
Title:  needed; it is prudence."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," cried Porthos, "we will not leave--"
Title:  
Title:  "You will leave d'Artagnan to act as he thinks proper," said
Title:  Athos.  "He has, I repeat, the longest head of the four, and for
Title:  my part I declare that I will obey him.  Do as you think best,
Title:  d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  At this moment the four Guards appeared at the door of the
Title:  antechamber, but seeing four Musketeers standing, and their
Title:  swords by their sides, they hesitated about going farther.
Title:  
Title:  "Come in, gentlemen, come in," called d'Artagnan; "you are here
Title:  in my apartment, and we are all faithful servants of the king and
Title:  cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Then, gentlemen, you will not oppose our executing the orders we
Title:  have received?" asked one who appeared to be the leader of the
Title:  party.
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary, gentlemen, we would assist you if it were
Title:  necessary."
Title:  
Title:  "What does he say?" grumbled Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "You are a simpleton," said Athos.  "Silence!"
Title:  
Title:  "But you promised me--" whispered the poor mercer.
Title:  
Title:  "We can only save you by being free ourselves," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan, in a rapid, low tone; "and if we appear inclined to
Title:  defend you, they will arrest us with you."
Title:  
Title:  "It seems, nevertheless--"
Title:  
Title:  "Come, gentlemen, come!" said d'Artagnan, aloud; "I have no
Title:  motive for defending Monsieur.  I saw him today for the first
Title:  time, and he can tell you on what occasion; he came to demand the
Title:  rent of my lodging.  Is that not true, Monsieur Bonacieux?
Title:  Answer!"
Title:  
Title:  "That is the very truth," cried the mercer; "but Monsieur does
Title:  not tell you--"
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, with respect to me, silence, with respect to my
Title:  friends; silence about the queen, above all, or you will ruin
Title:  everybody without saving yourself!  Come, come, gentlemen, remove
Title:  the fellow."  And d'Artagnan pushed the half-stupefied mercer
Title:  among the Guards, saying to him, "You are a shabby old fellow, my
Title:  dear.  You come to demand money of me--of a Musketeer!  To prison
Title:  with him!  Gentlemen, once more, take him to prison, and keep him
Title:  under key as long as possible; that will give me time to pay
Title:  him."
Title:  
Title:  The officers were full of thanks, and took away their prey.  As
Title:  they were going down d'Artagnan laid his hand on the shoulder of
Title:  their leader.
Title:  
Title:  "May I not drink to your health, and you to mine?" said
Title:  d'Artagnan, filling two glasses with the Beaugency wine which he
Title:  had obtained from the liberality of M. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "That will do me great honor," said the leader of the posse, "and
Title:  I accept thankfully."
Title:  
Title:  "Then to yours, monsieur--what is your name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Boisrenard."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Boisrenard."
Title:  
Title:  "To yours, my gentlemen!  What is your name, in your turn, if you
Title:  please?"
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "To yours, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "And above all others," cried d'Artagnan, as if carried away by
Title:  his enthusiasm, "to that of the king and the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  The leader of the posse would perhaps have doubted the sincerity
Title:  of d'Artagnan if the wine had been bad; but the wine was good,
Title:  and he was convinced.
Title:  
Title:  "What diabolical villainy you have performed here," said Porthos,
Title:  when the officer had rejoined his companions and the four friends
Title:  found themselves alone.  "Shame, shame, for four Musketeers to
Title:  allow an unfortunate fellow who cried for help to be arrested in
Title:  their midst!  And a gentleman to hobnob with a bailiff!"
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos," said Aramis, "Athos has already told you that you are
Title:  a simpleton, and I am quite of his opinion.  D'Artagnan, you are
Title:  a great man; and when you occupy Monsieur de Treville's place, I
Title:  will come and ask your influence to secure me an abbey."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I am in a maze," said Porthos; "do YOU approve of what
Title:  d'Artagnan has done?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARBLEU!  Indeed I do," said Athos; "I not only approve of what
Title:  he has done, but I congratulate him upon it."
Title:  
Title:  "And now, gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, without stopping to
Title:  explain his conduct to Porthos, "All for one, one for all--that
Title:  is our motto, is it not?"
Title:  
Title:  "And yet--" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold out your hand and swear!" cried Athos and Aramis at once.
Title:  
Title:  Overcome by example, grumbling to himself, nevertheless, Porthos
Title:  stretched out his hand, and the four friends repeated with one
Title:  voice the formula dictated by d'Artagnan:
Title:  
Title:  "All for one, one for all."
Title:  
Title:  "That's well!  Now let us everyone retire to his own home," said
Title:  d'Artagnan, as if he had done nothing but command all his life;
Title:  "and attention!  For from this moment we are at feud with the
Title:  cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  10  A MOUSETRAP IN THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY
Title:  
Title:  The invention of the mousetrap does not date from our days; as
Title:  soon as societies, in forming, had invented any kind of police,
Title:  that police invented mousetraps.
Title:  
Title:  As perhaps our readers are not familiar with the slang of the Rue
Title:  de Jerusalem, and as it is fifteen years since we applied this
Title:  word for the first time to this thing, allow us to explain to
Title:  them what is a mousetrap.
Title:  
Title:  When in a house, of whatever kind it may be, an individual
Title:  suspected of any crime is arrested, the arrest is held secret.
Title:  Four or five men are placed in ambuscade in the first room.  The
Title:  door is opened to all who knock.  It is closed after them, and
Title:  they are arrested; so that at the end of two or three days they
Title:  have in their power almost all the HABITUES of the establishment.
Title:  And that is a mousetrap.
Title:  
Title:  The apartment of M. Bonacieux, then, became a mousetrap; and
Title:  whoever appeared there was taken and interrogated by the
Title:  cardinal's people.  It must be observed that as a separate
Title:  passage led to the first floor, in which d'Artagnan lodged, those
Title:  who called on him were exempted from this detention.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, nobody came thither but the three Musketeers; they had
Title:  all been engaged in earnest search and inquiries, but had
Title:  discovered nothing.  Athos had even gone so far as to question M.
Title:  de Treville--a thing which, considering the habitual reticence of
Title:  the worthy Musketeer, had very much astonished his captain.  But
Title:  M. de Treville knew nothing, except that the last time he had
Title:  seen the cardinal, the king, and the queen, the cardinal looked
Title:  very thoughtful, the king uneasy, and the redness of the queen's
Title:  eyes donated that she had been sleepless or tearful.  But this
Title:  last circumstance was not striking, as the queen since her
Title:  marriage had slept badly and wept much.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville requested Athos, whatever might happen, to be
Title:  observant of his duty to the king, but particularly to the queen,
Title:  begging him to convey his desires to his comrades.
Title:  
Title:  As to d'Artagnan, he did not budge from his apartment.  He
Title:  converted his chamber into an observatory.  From his windows he
Title:  saw all the visitors who were caught.  Then, having removed a
Title:  plank from his floor, and nothing remaining but a simple ceiling
Title:  between him and the room beneath, in which the interrogatories
Title:  were made, he heard all that passed between the inquisitors and
Title:  the accused.
Title:  
Title:  The interrogatories, preceded by a minute search operated upon
Title:  the persons arrested, were almost always framed thus: "Has Madame
Title:  Bonacieux sent anything to you for her husband, or any other
Title:  person?  Has Monsieur Bonacieux sent anything to you for his
Title:  wife, or for any other person?  Has either of them confided
Title:  anything to you by word of mouth?"
Title:  
Title:  "If they knew anything, they would not question people in this
Title:  manner," said d'Artagnan to himself.  "Now, what is it they want
Title:  to know?  Why, they want to know if the Duke of Buckingham is in
Title:  Paris, and if he has had, or is likely to have, an interview with
Title:  the queen."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan held onto this idea, which, from what he had heard,
Title:  was not wanting in probability.
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime, the mousetrap continued in operation, and
Title:  likewise d'Artagnan's vigilance.
Title:  
Title:  On the evening of the day after the arrest of poor Bonacieux, as
Title:  Athos had just left d'Artagnan to report at M. de Treville's, as
Title:  nine o'clock had just struck, and as Planchet, who had not yet
Title:  made the bed, was beginning his task, a knocking was heard at the
Title:  street door.  The door was instantly opened and shut; someone was
Title:  taken in the mousetrap.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan flew to his hole, laid himself down on the floor at
Title:  full length, and listened.
Title:  
Title:  Cries were soon heard, and then moans, which someone appeared to
Title:  be endeavoring to stifle.  There were no questions.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said d'Artagnan to himself.  "It seems like a woman!
Title:  They search her; she resists; they use force--the scoundrels!"
Title:  
Title:  In spite of his prudence, d'Artagnan restrained himself with
Title:  great difficulty from taking a part in the scene that was going
Title:  on below.
Title:  
Title:  "But I tell you that I am the mistress of the house, gentlemen!
Title:  I tell you I am Madame Bonacieux; I tell you I belong to the
Title:  queen!" cried the unfortunate woman.
Title:  
Title:  "Madame Bonacieux!" murmured d'Artagnan.  "Can I be so lucky as
Title:  to find what everybody is seeking for?"
Title:  
Title:  The voice became more and more indistinct; a tumultuous movement
Title:  shook the partition.  The victim resisted as much as a woman
Title:  could resist four men.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon, gentlemen--par--" murmured the voice, which could now
Title:  only be heard in inarticulate sounds.
Title:  
Title:  "They are binding her; they are going to drag her away," cried
Title:  d'Artagnan to himself, springing up from the floor.  "My sword!
Title:  Good, it is by my side!  Planchet!"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Run and seek Athos, Porthos and Aramis.  One of the three will
Title:  certainly be at home, perhaps all three.  Tell them to take arms,
Title:  to come here, and to run!  Ah, I remember, Athos is at Monsieur
Title:  de Treville's."
Title:  
Title:  "But where are you going, monsieur, where are you going?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am going down by the window, in order to be there the sooner,"
Title:  cried d'Artagnan.  "You put back the boards, sweep the floor, go
Title:  out at the door, and run as I told you."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, monsieur!  Monsieur!  You will kill yourself," cried
Title:  Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue, stupid fellow," said d'Artagnan; and laying
Title:  hold of the casement, he let himself gently down from the first
Title:  story, which fortunately was not very elevated, without doing
Title:  himself the slightest injury.
Title:  
Title:  He then went straight to the door and knocked, murmuring, "I will
Title:  go myself and be caught in the mousetrap, but woe be to the cats
Title:  that shall pounce upon such a mouse!"
Title:  
Title:  The knocker had scarcely sounded under the hand of the young man
Title:  before the tumult ceased, steps approached, the door was opened,
Title:  and d'Artagnan, sword in hand, rushed into the rooms of M.
Title:  Bonacieux, the door of which doubtless acted upon by a spring,
Title:  closed after him.
Title:  
Title:  Then those who dwelt in Bonacieux's unfortunate house, together
Title:  with the nearest neighbors, heard loud cries, stamping of feet,
Title:  clashing of swords, and breaking of furniture.  A moment after,
Title:  those who, surprised by this tumult, had gone to their windows to
Title:  learn the cause of it, saw the door open, and four men, clothed
Title:  in black, not COME out of it, but FLY, like so many frightened
Title:  crows, leaving on the ground and on the corners of the furniture,
Title:  feathers from their wings; that is to say, patches of their
Title:  clothes and fragments of their cloaks.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was conqueror--without much effort, it must be
Title:   confessed, for only one of the officers was armed, and even he
Title:  defended himself for form's sake.  It is true that the three
Title:  others had endeavored to knock the young man down with chairs,
Title:  stools, and crockery; but two or three scratches made by the
Title:  Gascon's blade terrified them.  Ten minutes sufficed for their
Title:  defeat, and d'Artagnan remained master of the field of battle.
Title:  
Title:  The neighbors who had opened their windows, with the coolness
Title:  peculiar to the inhabitants of Paris in these times of perpetual
Title:  riots and disturbances, closed them again as soon as they saw the
Title:  four men in black flee--their instinct telling them that for the
Title:  time all was over.  Besides, it began to grow late, and then, as
Title:  today, people went to bed early in the quarter of the Luxembourg.
Title:  
Title:  On being left alone with Mme. Bonacieux, d'Artagnan turned toward
Title:  her; the poor woman reclined where she had been left,
Title:  half-fainting upon an armchair.  D'Artagnan examined her with a
Title:  rapid glance.
Title:  
Title:  She was a charming woman of twenty-five or twenty-six years, with
Title:  dark hair, blue eyes, and a nose slightly turned up, admirable
Title:  teeth, and a complexion marbled with rose and opal.  There,
Title:  however, ended the signs which might have confounded her with a
Title:  lady of rank.  The hands were white, but without delicacy; the
Title:  feet did not bespeak the woman of quality.  Happily, d'Artagnan
Title:  was not yet acquainted with such niceties.
Title:  
Title:  While d'Artagnan was examining Mme. Bonacieux, and was, as we
Title:  have said, close to her, he saw on the ground a fine cambric
Title:  handkerchief, which he picked up, as was his habit, and at the
Title:  corner of which he recognized the same cipher he had seen on the
Title:  handkerchief which had nearly caused him and Aramis to cut each
Title:  other's throat.
Title:  
Title:  From that time, d'Artagnan had been cautious with respect to
Title:  handkerchiefs with arms on them, and he therefore placed in the
Title:  pocket of Mme. Bonacieux the one he had just picked up.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment Mme. Bonacieux recovered her senses.  She opened
Title:  her eyes, looked around her with terror, saw that the apartment
Title:  was empty and that she was alone with her liberator.  She
Title:  extended her hands to him with a smile.  Mme. Bonacieux had the
Title:  sweetest smile in the world.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!" said she, "you have saved me; permit me to thank
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame," said d'Artagnan, "I have only done what every gentleman
Title:  would have done in my place; you owe me no thanks."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, monsieur, oh, yes; and I hope to prove to you that you
Title:  have not served an ingrate.  But what could these men, whom I at
Title:  first took for robbers, want with me, and why is Monsieur
Title:  Bonacieux not here?"
Title:  
Title:  "Madame, those men were more dangerous than any robbers could
Title:  have been, for they are the agents of the cardinal; and as to
Title:  your husband, Monsieur Bonacieux, he is not here because he was
Title:  yesterday evening conducted to the Bastille."
Title:  
Title:  "My husband in the Bastille!" cried Mme. Bonacieux.  "Oh, my God!
Title:  What has he done?  Poor dear man, he is innocence itself!"
Title:  
Title:  And something like a faint smile lighted the still-terrified
Title:  features of the young woman.
Title:  
Title:  "What has he done, madame?" said d'Artagnan.  "I believe that his
Title:  only crime is to have at the same time the good fortune and the
Title:  misfortune to be your husband."
Title:  
Title:  "But, monsieur, you know then--"
Title:  
Title:  "I know that you have been abducted, madame."
Title:  
Title:  "And by whom?  Do you know him?  Oh, if you know him, tell me!"
Title:  
Title:  "By a man of from forty to forty-five years, with black hair, a
Title:  dark complexion, and a scar on his left temple."
Title:  
Title:  "That is he, that is he; but his name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, his name?  I do not know that."
Title:  
Title:  "And did my husband know I had been carried off?"
Title:  
Title:  "He was informed of it by a letter, written to him by the
Title:  abductor himself."
Title:  
Title:  "And does he suspect," said Mme. Bonacieux, with some
Title:  embarrassment, "the cause of this event?"
Title:  
Title:  "He attributed it, I believe, to a political cause."
Title:  
Title:  "I doubted from the first; and now I think entirely as he does.
Title:  Then my dear Monsieur Bonacieux has not suspected me a single
Title:  instant?"
Title:  
Title:  "So far from it, madame, he was too proud of your prudence, and
Title:  above all, of your love."
Title:  
Title:  A second smile, almost imperceptible, stole over the rosy lips of
Title:  the pretty young woman.
Title:  
Title:  "But," continued d'Artagnan, "how did you escape?"
Title:  
Title:  "I took advantage of a moment when they left me alone; and as I
Title:  had known since morning the reason of my abduction, with the help
Title:  of the sheets I let myself down from the window.  Then, as I
Title:  believed my husband would be at home, I hastened hither."
Title:  
Title:  "To place yourself under his protection?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no, poor dear man!  I knew very well that he was incapable
Title:  of defending me; but as he could serve us in other ways, I wished
Title:  to inform him."
Title:  
Title:  "Of what?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, that is not my secret; I must not, therefore, tell you."
Title:  
Title:  "Besides," said d'Artagnan, "pardon me, madame, if, guardsman as
Title:  I am, I remind you of prudence--besides, I believe we are not
Title:  here in a very proper place for imparting confidences.  The men I
Title:  have put to flight will return reinforced; if they find us here,
Title:  we are lost.  I have sent for three of my friends, but who knows
Title:  whether they were at home?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes!  You are right," cried the affrighted Mme. Bonacieux;
Title:  "let us fly!  Let us save ourselves."
Title:  
Title:  At these words she passed her arm under that of d'Artagnan, and
Title:  urged him forward eagerly.
Title:  
Title:  "But whither shall we fly--whither escape?"
Title:  
Title:  "Let us first withdraw from this house; afterward we shall see."
Title:  
Title:  The young woman and the young man, without taking the trouble to
Title:  shut the door after them, descended the Rue des Fossoyeurs
Title:  rapidly, turned into the Rue des Fosses-Monsieur-le-Prince, and
Title:  did not stop till they came to the Place St. Sulpice.
Title:  
Title:  "And now what are we to do, and where do you wish me to conduct
Title:  you?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I am at quite a loss how to answer you, I admit," said Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux.  "My intention was to inform Monsieur Laporte, through
Title:  my husband, in order that Monsieur Laporte might tell us
Title:  precisely what had taken place at the Louvre in the last three
Title:  days, and whether there is any danger in presenting myself
Title:  there."
Title:  
Title:  "But I," said d'Artagnan, "can go and inform Monsieur Laporte."
Title:  
Title:  "No doubt you could, only there is one misfortune, and that is
Title:  that Monsieur Bonacieux is known at the Louvre, and would be
Title:  allowed to pass; whereas you are not known there, and the gate
Title:  would be closed against you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, bah!" said d'Artagnan; "you have at some wicket of the
Title:  Louvre a CONCIERGE who is devoted to you, and who, thanks to a
Title:  password, would--"
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux looked earnestly at the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "And if I give you this password," said she, "would you forget it
Title:  as soon as you used it?"
Title:  
Title:  "By my honor, by the faith of a gentleman!" said d'Artagnan, with
Title:  an accent so truthful that no one could mistake it.
Title:  
Title:  "Then I believe you.  You appear to be a brave young man;
Title:  besides, your fortune may perhaps be the result of your
Title:  devotedness."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "I will do, without a promise and voluntarily, all that I can do
Title:  to serve the king and be agreeable to the queen.  Dispose of me,
Title:  then, as a friend."
Title:  
Title:  "But I--where shall I go meanwhile?"
Title:  
Title:  "Is there nobody from whose house Monsieur Laporte can come and
Title:  fetch you?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, I can trust nobody."
Title:  
Title:  "Stop," said d'Artagnan; "we are near Athos's door.  Yes, here it
Title:  is."
Title:  
Title:  "Who is this Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "One of my friends."
Title:  
Title:  "But if he should be at home and see me?"
Title:  
Title:  "He is not at home, and I will carry away the key, after having
Title:  placed you in his apartment."
Title:  
Title:  "But if he should return?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, he won't return; and if he should, he will be told that I
Title:  have brought a woman with me, and that woman is in his
Title:  apartment."
Title:  
Title:  "But that will compromise me sadly, you know."
Title:  
Title:  "Of what consequence?  Nobody knows you.  Besides, we are in a
Title:  situation to overlook ceremony."
Title:  
Title:  "Come, then, let us go to your friend's house.  Where does he
Title:  live?"
Title:  
Title:  "Rue Ferou, two steps from here."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us go!"
Title:  
Title:  Both resumed their way.  As d'Artagnan had foreseen, Athos was
Title:  not within.  He took the key, which was customarily given him as
Title:  one of the family, ascended the stairs, and introduced Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux into the little apartment of which we have given a
Title:  description.
Title:  
Title:  "You are at home," said he.  "Remain here, fasten the door
Title:  inside, and open it to nobody unless you hear three taps like
Title:  this;" and he tapped thrice--two taps close together and pretty
Title:  hard, the other after an interval, and lighter.
Title:  
Title:  "That is well," said Mme. Bonacieux.  "Now, in my turn, let me
Title:  give you my instructions."
Title:  
Title:  "I am all attention."
Title:  
Title:  "Present yourself at the wicket of the Louvre, on the side of the
Title:  Rue de l'Echelle, and ask for Germain."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, and then?"
Title:  
Title:  "He will ask you what you want, and you will answer by these two
Title:  words, 'Tours' and 'Bruxelles.'  He will at once put himself at
Title:  your orders."
Title:  
Title:  "And what shall I command him?"
Title:  
Title:  "To go and fetch Monsieur Laporte, the queen's VALET DE CHAMBRE."
Title:  
Title:  "And when he shall have informed him, and Monsieur Laporte is
Title:  come?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will send him to me."
Title:  
Title:  "That is well; but where and how shall I see you again?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you wish to see me again?"
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, let that care be mine, and be at ease."
Title:  
Title:  "I depend upon your word."
Title:  
Title:  "You may."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan bowed to Mme. Bonacieux, darting at her the most
Title:  loving glance that he could possibly concentrate upon her
Title:  charming little person; and while he descended the stairs, he
Title:  heard the door closed and double-locked.  In two bounds he was at
Title:  the Louvre; as he entered the wicket of L'Echelle, ten o'clock
Title:  struck.  All the events we have described had taken place within
Title:  a half hour.
Title:  
Title:  Everything fell out as Mme. Bonacieux prophesied.  On hearing the
Title:  password, Germain bowed.  In a few minutes, Laporte was at the
Title:  lodge; in two words d'Artagnan informed him where Mme. Bonacieux
Title:  was.  Laporte assured himself, by having it twice repeated, of
Title:  the accurate address, and set off at a run.  Hardly, however, had
Title:  he taken ten steps before he returned.
Title:  
Title:  "Young man," said he to d'Artagnan, "a suggestion."
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "You may get into trouble by what has taken place."
Title:  
Title:  "You believe so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes.  Have you any friend whose clock is too slow?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Go and call upon him, in order that he may give evidence of your
Title:  having been with him at half past nine.  In a court of justice
Title:  that is called an alibi."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan found his advice prudent.  He took to his heels, and
Title:  was soon at M. de Treville's; but instead of going into the
Title:  saloon with the rest of the crowd, he asked to be introduced to
Title:  M. de Treville's office.  As d'Artagnan so constantly frequented
Title:  the hotel, no difficulty was made in complying with his request,
Title:  and a servant went to inform M. de Treville that his young
Title:  compatriot, having something important to communicate, solicited a
Title:  private audience.  Five minutes after, M. de Treville was asking
Title:  d'Artagnan what he could do to serve him, and what caused his
Title:  visit at so late an hour.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon me, monsieur," said d'Artagnan, who had profited by the
Title:  moment he had been left alone to put back M. de Treville's clock
Title:  three-quarters of an hour, "but I thought, as it was yet only
Title:  twenty-five minutes past nine, it was not too late to wait upon
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "Twenty-five minutes past nine!" cried M. de Treville, looking at
Title:  the clock; "why, that's impossible!"
Title:  
Title:  "Look, rather, monsieur," said d'Artagnan, "the clock shows it."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said M. de Treville; "I believed it later.  But
Title:  what can I do for you?"
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan told M. de Treville a long history about the
Title:  queen.  He expressed to him the fears he entertained with respect
Title:  to her Majesty; he related to him what he had heard of the
Title:  projects of the cardinal with regard to Buckingham, and all with
Title:  a tranquillity and candor of which M. de Treville was the more
Title:  the dupe, from having himself, as we have said, observed
Title:  something fresh between the cardinal, the king, and the queen.
Title:  
Title:  As ten o'clock was striking, d'Artagnan left M. de Treville, who
Title:  thanked him for his information, recommended him to have the
Title:  service of the king and queen always at heart, and returned to
Title:  the saloon; but at the foot of the stairs, d'Artagnan remembered
Title:  he had forgotten his cane.  He consequently sprang up again,
Title:  re-entered the office, with a turn of his finger set the clock
Title:  right again, that it might not be perceived the next day that it
Title:  had been put wrong, and certain from that time that he had a
Title:  witness to prove his alibi, he ran downstairs and soon found
Title:  himself in the street.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  11  IN WHICH THE PLOT THICKENS
Title:  
Title:  His visit to M. de Treville being paid, the pensive d'Artagnan
Title:  took the longest way homeward.
Title:  
Title:  On what was d'Artagnan thinking, that he strayed thus from his
Title:  path, gazing at the stars of heaven, and sometimes sighing,
Title:  sometimes smiling?
Title:  
Title:  He was thinking of Mme. Bonacieux.  For an apprentice Musketeer
Title:  the young woman was almost an ideal of love.  Pretty, mysterious,
Title:  initiated in almost all the secrets of the court, which reflected
Title:  such a charming gravity over her pleasing features, it might be
Title:  surmised that she was not wholly unmoved; and this is an
Title:  irresistible charm to novices in love.  Moreover, d'Artagnan had
Title:  delivered her from the hands of the demons who wished to search
Title:  and ill treat her; and this important service had established
Title:  between them one of those sentiments of gratitude which so easily
Title:  assume a more tender character.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan already fancied himself, so rapid is the flight of our
Title:  dreams upon the wings of imagination, accosted by a messenger
Title:  from the young woman, who brought him some billet appointing a
Title:  meeting, a gold chain, or a diamond.  We have observed that young
Title:  cavaliers received presents from their king without shame.  Let
Title:  us add that in these times of lax morality they had no more
Title:  delicacy with respect to the mistresses; and that the latter
Title:  almost always left them valuable and durable remembrances, as if
Title:  they essayed to conquer the fragility of their sentiments by the
Title:  solidity of their gifts.
Title:  
Title:  Without a blush, men made their way in the world by the means of
Title:  women blushing.  Such as were only beautiful gave their beauty,
Title:  whence, without doubt, comes the proverb, "The most beautiful
Title:  girl in the world can only give what she has."  Such as were rich
Title:  gave in addition a part of their money; and a vast number of
Title:  heroes of that gallant period may be cited who would neither have
Title:  won their spurs in the first place, nor their battles afterward,
Title:  without the purse, more or less furnished, which their mistress
Title:  fastened to the saddle bow.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan owned nothing.  Provincial diffidence, that slight
Title:  varnish, the ephemeral flower, that down of the peach, had
Title:  evaporated to the winds through the little orthodox counsels
Title:  which the three Musketeers gave their friend.  D'Artagnan,
Title:  following the strange custom of the times, considered himself at
Title:  Paris as on a campaign, neither more nor less than if he had been
Title:  in Flanders--Spain yonder, woman here.  In each there was an
Title:  enemy to contend with, and contributions to be levied.
Title:  
Title:  But, we must say, at the present moment d'Artagnan was ruled by
Title:  a feeling much more noble and disinterested.  The mercer had
Title:  said that he was rich; the young man might easily guess that
Title:  with so weak a man as M. Bonacieux; and interest was almost
Title:  foreign to this commencement of love, which had been the
Title:  consequence of it.  We say ALMOST, for the idea that a young,
Title:  handsome, kind, and witty woman is at the same time rich takes
Title:  nothing from the beginning of love, but on the contrary
Title:  strengthens it.
Title:  
Title:  There are in affluence a crowd of aristocratic cares and caprices
Title:  which are highly becoming to beauty.  A fine and white stocking,
Title:  a silken robe, a lace kerchief, a pretty slipper on the foot, a
Title:  tasty ribbon on the head do not make an ugly woman pretty, but
Title:  they make a pretty woman beautiful, without reckoning the hands,
Title:  which gain by all this; the hands, among women particularly, to
Title:  be beautiful must be idle.
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan, as the reader, from whom we have not concealed
Title:  the state of his fortune, very well knows--d'Artagnan was not a
Title:  millionaire; he hoped to become one someday, but the time which
Title:  in his own mind he fixed upon for this happy change was still far
Title:  distant.  In the meanwhile, how disheartening to see the woman
Title:  one loves long for those thousands of nothings which constitute a
Title:  woman's happiness, and be unable to give her those thousands of
Title:  nothings.  At least, when the woman is rich and the lover is not,
Title:  that which he cannot offer she offers to herself; and although it
Title:  is generally with her husband's money that she procures herself
Title:  this indulgence, the gratitude for it seldom reverts to him.
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan, disposed to become the most tender of lovers,
Title:  was at the same time a very devoted friend, In the midst of his
Title:  amorous projects for the mercer's wife, he did not forget his
Title:  friends.  The pretty Mme. Bonacieux was just the woman to walk
Title:  with in the Plain St. Denis or in the fair of St. Germain, in
Title:  company with Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, to whom d'Artagnan had
Title:  often remarked this.  Then one could enjoy charming little
Title:  dinners, where one touches on one side the hand of a friend, and
Title:  on the other the foot of a mistress.  Besides, on pressing
Title:  occasions, in extreme difficulties, d'Artagnan would become the
Title:  preserver of his friends.
Title:  
Title:  And M. Bonacieux? whom d'Artagnan had pushed into the hands of
Title:  the officers, denying him aloud although he had promised in a
Title:  whisper to save him.  We are compelled to admit to our readers
Title:  that d'Artagnan thought nothing about him in any way; or that if
Title:  he did think of him, it was only to say to himself that he was
Title:  very well where he was, wherever it might be.  Love is the most
Title:  selfish of all the passions.
Title:  
Title:  Let our readers reassure themselves.  IF d'Artagnan forgets his
Title:  host, or appears to forget him, under the pretense of not knowing
Title:  where he has been carried, we will not forget him, and we know
Title:  where he is.  But for the moment, let us do as did the amorous
Title:  Gascon; we will see after the worthy mercer later.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, reflecting on his future amours, addressing himself
Title:  to the beautiful night, and smiling at the stars, ascended the
Title:  Rue Cherish-Midi, or Chase-Midi, as it was then called.  As he
Title:  found himself in the quarter in which Aramis lived, he took it
Title:  into his head to pay his friend a visit in order to explain the
Title:  motives which had led him to send Planchet with a request that he
Title:  would come instantly to the mousetrap.  Now, if Aramis had been
Title:  at home when Planchet came to his abode, he had doubtless
Title:  hastened to the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and finding nobody there but
Title:  his other two companions perhaps, they would not be able to
Title:  conceive what all this meant.  This mystery required an
Title:  explanation; at least, so d'Artagnan declared to himself.
Title:  
Title:  He likewise thought this was an opportunity for talking about
Title:  pretty little Mme. Bonacieux, of whom his head, if not his heart,
Title:  was already full.  We must never look for discretion in first
Title:  love.  First love is accompanied by such excessive joy that
Title:  unless the joy be allowed to overflow, it will stifle you.
Title:  
Title:  Paris for two hours past had been dark, and seemed a desert.
Title:  Eleven o'clock sounded from all the clocks of the Faubourg St.
Title:  Germain.  It was delightful weather.  D'Artagnan was passing
Title:  along a lane on the spot where the Rue d'Assas is now situated,
Title:  breathing the balmy emanations which were borne upon the wind
Title:  from the Rue de Vaugirard, and which arose from the gardens
Title:  refreshed by the dews of evening and the breeze of night.  From a
Title:  distance resounded, deadened, however, by good shutters, the
Title:  songs of the tipplers, enjoying themselves in the cabarets
Title:  scattered along the plain.  Arrived at the end of the lane,
Title:  d'Artagnan turned to the left.  The house in which Aramis dwelt
Title:  was situated between the Rue Cassette and the Rue Servandoni.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had just passed the Rue Cassette, and already
Title:  perceived the door of his friend's house, shaded by a mass of
Title:  sycamores and clematis which formed a vast arch opposite the
Title:  front of it, when he perceived something like a shadow issuing
Title:  from the Rue Servandoni.  This something was enveloped in a
Title:  cloak, and d'Artagnan at first believed it was a man; but by the
Title:  smallness of the form, the hesitation of the walk, and the
Title:  indecision of the step, he soon discovered that it was a woman.
Title:  Further, this woman, as if not certain of the house she was
Title:  seeking, lifted up her eyes to look around her, stopped, went
Title:  backward, and then returned again.  D'Artagnan was perplexed.
Title:  
Title:  "Shall I go and offer her my services?" thought he.  "By her step
Title:  she must be young; perhaps she is pretty.  Oh, yes!  But a woman
Title:  who wanders in the streets at this hour only ventures out to meet
Title:  her lover.  If I should disturb a rendezvous, that would not be
Title:  the best means of commencing an acquaintance."
Title:  
Title:  Meantime the young woman continued to advance, counting the
Title:  houses and windows.  This was neither long nor difficult.  There
Title:  were but three hotels in this part of the street; and only two
Title:  windows looking toward the road, one of which was in a pavilion
Title:  parallel to that which Aramis occupied, the other belonging to
Title:  Aramis himself.
Title:  
Title:  "PARIDIEU!" said d'Artagnan to himself, to whose mind the niece
Title:  of the theologian reverted, "PARDIEU, it would be droll if this
Title:  belated dove should be in search of our friend's house.  But on
Title:  my soul, it looks so.  Ah, my dear Aramis, this time I shall find
Title:  you out."  And d'Artagnan, making himself as small as he could,
Title:  concealed himself in the darkest side of the street near a stone
Title:  bench placed at the back of a niche.
Title:  
Title:  The young woman continued to advance; and in addition to the
Title:  lightness of her step, which had betrayed her, she emitted a
Title:  little cough which denoted a sweet voice.  D'Artagnan believed
Title:  this cough to be a signal.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, whether the cough had been answered by a similar
Title:  signal which had fixed the irresolution of the nocturnal seeker,
Title:  or whether without this aid she saw that she had arrived at the
Title:  end of her journey, she resolutely drew near to Aramis's shutter,
Title:  and tapped, at three equal intervals, with her bent finger.
Title:  
Title:  "This is all very fine, dear Aramis," murmured d'Artagnan.
Title:  "Ah, Monsieur Hypocrite, I understand how you study theology."
Title:  
Title:  The three blows were scarcely struck, when the inside blind was
Title:  opened and a light appeared through the panes of the outside
Title:  shutter.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said the listener, "not through doors, but through
Title:  windows!  Ah, this visit was expected.  We shall see the windows
Title:  open, and the lady enter by escalade.  Very pretty!"
Title:  
Title:  But to the great astonishment of d'Artagnan, the shutter remained
Title:  closed.  Still more, the light which had shone for an instant
Title:  disappeared, and all was again in obscurity.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan thought this could not last long, and continued to
Title:  look with all his eyes and listen with all his ears.
Title:  
Title:  He was right; at the end of some seconds two sharp taps were
Title:  heard inside.  The young woman in the street replied by a single
Title:  tap, and the shutter was opened a little way.
Title:  
Title:  It may be judged whether d'Artagnan looked or listened with
Title:  avidity.  Unfortunately the light had been removed into another
Title:  chamber; but the eyes of the young man were accustomed to the
Title:  night.  Besides, the eyes of the Gascons have, as it is asserted,
Title:  like those of cats, the faculty of seeing in the dark.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan then saw that the young woman took from her pocket a
Title:  white object, which she unfolded quickly, and which took the form
Title:  of a handkerchief.  She made her interlocutor observe the corner
Title:  of this unfolded object.
Title:  
Title:  This immediately recalled to d'Artagnan's mind the handkerchief
Title:  which he had found at the feet of Mme. Bonacieux, which had
Title:  reminded him of that which he had dragged from under the feet of
Title:  Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil could that handkerchief signify?"
Title:  
Title:  Placed where he was, d'Artagnan could not perceive the face of
Title:  Aramis.  We say Aramis, because the young man entertained no
Title:  doubt that it was his friend who held this dialogue from the
Title:  interior with the lady of the exterior.  Curiosity prevailed over
Title:  prudence; and profiting by the preoccupation into which the sight
Title:  of the handkerchief appeared to have plunged the two personages
Title:  now on the scene, he stole from his hiding place, and quick as
Title:  lightning, but stepping with utmost caution, he ran and placed
Title:  himself close to the angle of the wall, from which his eye could
Title:  pierce the interior of Aramis's room.
Title:  
Title:  Upon gaining this advantage d'Artagnan was near uttering a cry of
Title:  surprise; it was not Aramis who was conversing with the nocturnal
Title:  visitor, it was a woman!  D'Artagnan, however, could only see
Title:  enough to recognize the form of her vestments, not enough to
Title:  distinguish her features.
Title:  
Title:  At the same instant the woman inside drew a second handkerchief
Title:  from her pocket, and exchanged it for that which had just been
Title:  shown to her.  Then some words were spoken by the two women.  At
Title:  length the shutter closed.  The woman who was outside the window
Title:  turned round, and passed within four steps of d'Artagnan, pulling
Title:  down the hood of her mantle; but the precaution was too late,
Title:  d'Artagnan had already recognized Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux!  The suspicion that it was she had crossed the
Title:  mind of d'Artagnan when she drew the handkerchief from her
Title:  pocket; but what probability was there that Mme. Bonacieux, who
Title:  had sent for M. Laporte in order to be reconducted to the Louvre,
Title:  should be running about the streets of Paris at half past eleven
Title:  at night, at the risk of being abducted a second time?
Title:  
Title:  This must be, then, an affair of importance; and what is the most
Title:  important affair to a woman of twenty-five!  Love.
Title:  
Title:  But was it on her own account, or on account of another, that she
Title:  exposed herself to such hazards?  This was a question the young
Title:  man asked himself, whom the demon of jealousy already gnawed,
Title:  being in heart neither more nor less than an accepted lover.
Title:  
Title:  There was a very simple means of satisfying himself whither Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux was going; that was to follow her.  This method was so
Title:  simple that d'Artagnan employed it quite naturally and
Title:  instinctively.
Title:  
Title:  But at the sight of the young man, who detached himself from the
Title:  wall like a statue walking from its niche, and at the noise of
Title:  the steps which she heard resound behind her, Mme. Bonacieux
Title:  uttered a little cry and fled.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan ran after her.  It was not difficult for him to
Title:  overtake a woman embarrassed with her cloak.  He came up with her
Title:  before she had traversed a third of the street.  The unfortunate
Title:  woman was exhausted, not by fatigue, but by terror, and when
Title:  d'Artagnan placed his hand upon her shoulder, she sank upon one
Title:  knee, crying in a choking voice, "Kill me, if you please, you
Title:  shall know nothing!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan raised her by passing his arm round her waist; but as
Title:  he felt by her weight she was on the point of fainting, he made
Title:  haste to reassure her by protestations of devotedness.  These
Title:  protestations were nothing for Mme. Bonacieux, for such
Title:  protestations may be made with the worst intentions in the world;
Title:  but the voice was all.  Mme. Bonacieux thought she recognized the
Title:  sound of that voice; she reopened her eyes, cast a quick glance
Title:  upon the man who had terrified her so, and at once perceiving it
Title:  was d'Artagnan, she uttered a cry of joy, "Oh, it is you, it is
Title:  you!  Thank God, thank God!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, it is I," said d'Artagnan, "it is I, whom God has sent to
Title:  watch over you."
Title:  
Title:  "Was it with that intention you followed me?" asked the young
Title:  woman, with a coquettish smile, whose somewhat bantering
Title:  character resumed its influence, and with whom all fear had
Title:  disappeared from the moment in which she recognized a friend in
Title:  one she had taken for an enemy.
Title:  
Title:  "No," said d'Artagnan; "no, I confess it.  It was chance that
Title:  threw me in your way; I saw a woman knocking at the window of one
Title:  of my friends."
Title:  
Title:  "One of your friends?" interrupted Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt; Aramis is one of my best friends."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis!  Who is he?"
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come, you won't tell me you don't know Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "This is the first time I ever heard his name pronounced."
Title:  
Title:  "It is the first time, then, that you ever went to that house?"
Title:  
Title:  "Undoubtedly."
Title:  
Title:  "And you did not know that it was inhabited by a young man?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "By a Musketeer?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  "It was not he, then, you came to seek?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not the least in the world.  Besides, you must have seen that
Title:  the person to whom I spoke was a woman."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true; but this woman is a friend of Aramis--"
Title:  
Title:  "I know nothing of that."
Title:  
Title:  "--since she lodges with him."
Title:  
Title:  "That does not concern me."
Title:  
Title:  "But who is she?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, that is not my secret."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Madame Bonacieux, you are charming; but at the same time
Title:  you are one of the most mysterious women."
Title:  
Title:  "Do I lose by that?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; you are, on the contrary, adorable."
Title:  
Title:  "Give me your arm, then."
Title:  
Title:  "Most willingly.  And now?"
Title:  
Title:  "Now escort me."
Title:  
Title:  "Where?"
Title:  
Title:  "Where I am going."
Title:  
Title:  "But where are you going?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will see, because you will leave me at the door."
Title:  
Title:  "Shall I wait for you?"
Title:  
Title:  "That will be useless."
Title:  
Title:  "You will return alone, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps yes, perhaps no."
Title:  
Title:  "But will the person who shall accompany you afterward be a man
Title:  or a woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know yet."
Title:  
Title:  "But I will know it!"
Title:  
Title:  "How so?"
Title:  
Title:  "I will wait until you come out."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case, adieu."
Title:  
Title:  "Why so?"
Title:  
Title:  "I do not want you."
Title:  
Title:  "But you have claimed--"
Title:  
Title:  "The aid of a gentleman, not the watchfulness of a spy."
Title:  
Title:  "The word is rather hard."
Title:  
Title:  "How are they called who follow others in spite of them?"
Title:  
Title:  "They are indiscreet."
Title:  
Title:  "The word is too mild."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, madame, I perceive I must do as you wish."
Title:  
Title:  "Why did you deprive yourself of the merit of doing so at once?"
Title:  
Title:  "Is there no merit in repentance?"
Title:  
Title:  "And do you really repent?"
Title:  
Title:  "I know nothing about it myself.  But what I know is that I
Title:  promise to do all you wish if you allow me to accompany you where
Title:  you are going."
Title:  
Title:  "And you will leave me then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Without waiting for my coming out again?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Word of honor?"
Title:  
Title:  "By the faith of a gentleman.  Take my arm, and let us go."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan offered his arm to Mme. Bonacieux, who willingly took
Title:  it, half laughing, half trembling, and both gained the top of Rue
Title:  de la Harpe.  Arriving there, the young woman seemed to hesitate,
Title:  as she had before done in the Rue Vaugirard.  She seemed,
Title:  however, by certain signs, to recognize a door, and approaching
Title:  that door, "And now, monsieur," said she, "it is here I have
Title:  business; a thousand thanks for your honorable company, which has
Title:  saved me from all the dangers to which, alone I was exposed.  But
Title:  the moment is come to keep your word; I have reached my
Title:  destination."
Title:  
Title:  "And you will have nothing to fear on your return?"
Title:  
Title:  "I shall have nothing to fear but robbers."
Title:  
Title:  "And that is nothing?"
Title:  
Title:  "What could they take from me?  I have not a penny about me."
Title:  
Title:  "You forget that beautiful handkerchief with the coat of arms."
Title:  
Title:  "Which?"
Title:  
Title:  "That which I found at your feet, and replaced in your pocket."
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue, imprudent man!  Do you wish to destroy me?"
Title:  
Title:  "You see very plainly that there is still danger for you, since a
Title:  single word makes you tremble; and you confess that if that word
Title:  were heard you would be ruined.  Come, come, madame!" cried
Title:  d'Artagnan, seizing her hands, and surveying her with an ardent
Title:  glance, "come, be more generous.  Confide in me.  Have you not
Title:  read in my eyes that there is nothing but devotion and sympathy
Title:  in my heart?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," replied Mme. Bonacieux; "therefore, ask my own secrets,
Title:  and I will reveal them to you; but those of others--that is quite
Title:  another thing."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well," said d'Artagnan, "I shall discover them; as these
Title:  secrets may have an influence over your life, these secrets must
Title:  become mine."
Title:  
Title:  "Beware of what you do!" cried the young woman, in a manner so
Title:  serious as to make d'Artagnan start in spite of himself.  "Oh,
Title:  meddle in nothing which concerns me.  Do not seek to assist me in
Title:  that which I am accomplishing.  This I ask of you in the name of
Title:  the interest with which I inspire you, in the name of the service
Title:  you have rendered me and which I never shall forget while I have
Title:  life.  Rather, place faith in what I tell you.  Have no more
Title:  concern about me; I exist no longer for you, any more than if you
Title:  had never seen me."
Title:  
Title:  "Must Aramis do as much as I, madame?" said d'Artagnan, deeply
Title:  piqued.
Title:  
Title:  "This is the second or third time, monsieur, that you have
Title:  repeated that name, and yet I have told you that I do not know
Title:  him."
Title:  
Title:  "You do not know the man at whose shutter you have just knocked?
Title:  Indeed, madame, you believe me too credulous!"
Title:  
Title:  "Confess that it is for the sake of making me talk that you
Title:  invent this story and create this personage."
Title:  
Title:  "I invent nothing, madame; I create nothing.  I only speak that
Title:  exact truth."
Title:  
Title:  "And you say that one of your friends lives in that house?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say so, and I repeat it for the third time; that house is one
Title:  inhabited by my friend, and that friend is Aramis."
Title:  
Title:  "All this will be cleared up at a later period," murmured the
Title:  young woman; "no, monsieur, be silent."
Title:  
Title:  "If you could see my heart," said d'Artagnan, "you would there
Title:  read so much curiosity that you would pity me and so much love
Title:  that you would instantly satisfy my curiosity.  We have nothing
Title:  to fear from those who love us."
Title:  
Title:  "You speak very suddenly of love, monsieur," said the young
Title:  woman, shaking her head.
Title:  
Title:  "That is because love has come suddenly upon me, and for the
Title:  first time; and because I am only twenty."
Title:  
Title:  The young woman looked at him furtively.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen; I am already upon the scent," resumed d'Artagnan.
Title:  "About three months ago I was near having a duel with Aramis
Title:  concerning a handkerchief resembling the one you showed to the
Title:  woman in his house--for a handkerchief marked in the same manner,
Title:  I am sure."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said the young woman, "you weary me very much, I
Title:  assure you, with your questions."
Title:  
Title:  "But you, madame, prudent as you are, think, if you were to be
Title:  arrested with that handkerchief, and that handkerchief were to be
Title:  seized, would you not be compromised?"
Title:  
Title:  "In what way?  The initials are only mine--C. B., Constance
Title:  Bonacieux."
Title:  
Title:  "Or Camille de Bois-Tracy."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, monsieur!  Once again, silence!  Ah, since the dangers
Title:  I incur on my own account cannot stop you, think of those you may
Title:  yourself run!"
Title:  
Title:  "Me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; there is peril of imprisonment, risk of life in knowing
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "Then I will not leave you."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur!" said the young woman, supplicating him and clasping
Title:  her hands together, "monsieur, in the name of heaven, by the
Title:  honor of a soldier, by the courtesy of a gentleman, depart!
Title:  There, there midnight sounds!  That is the hour when I am
Title:  expected."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame," said the young man, bowing; "I can refuse nothing asked
Title:  of me thus.  Be content; I will depart."
Title:  
Title:  "But you will not follow me; you will not watch me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I will return home instantly."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, I was quite sure you were a good and brave young man," said
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux, holding out her hand to him, and placing the
Title:  other upon the knocker of a little door almost hidden in the
Title:  wall.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan seized the hand held out to him, and kissed it
Title:  ardently.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  I wish I had never seen you!" cried d'Artagnan, with that
Title:  ingenuous roughness which women often prefer to the affectations
Title:  of politeness, because it betrays the depths of the thought and
Title:  proves that feeling prevails over reason.
Title:  
Title:  "Well!" resumed Mme. Bonacieux, in a voice almost caressing, and
Title:  pressing the hand of d'Artagnan, who had not relinquished hers,
Title:  "well:  I will not say as much as you do; what is lost for today
Title:  may not be lost forever.  Who knows, when I shall be at liberty,
Title:  that I may not satisfy your curiosity?"
Title:  
Title:  "And will you make the same promise to my love?" cried
Title:  d'Artagnan, beside himself with joy.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, as to that, I do not engage myself.  That depends upon the
Title:  sentiments with which you may inspire me."
Title:  
Title:  "Then today, madame--"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, today, I am no further than gratitude."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  You are too charming," said d'Artagnan, sorrowfully; "and
Title:  you abuse my love."
Title:  
Title:  "No, I use your generosity, that's all.  But be of good cheer;
Title:  with certain people, everything comes round."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you render me the happiest of men!  Do not forget this
Title:  evening--do not forget that promise."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied.  In the proper time and place I will remember
Title:  everything.  Now then, go, go, in the name of heaven!  I was
Title:  expected at sharp midnight, and I am late."
Title:  
Title:  "By five minutes."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but in certain circumstances five minutes are five ages."
Title:  
Title:  "When one loves."
Title:  
Title:  "Well!  And who told you I had no affair with a lover?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is a man, then, who expects you?" cried d'Artagnan.  "A man!"
Title:  
Title:  "The discussion is going to begin again!" said Mme. Bonacieux,
Title:  with a half-smile which was not exempt from a tinge of
Title:  impatience.
Title:  
Title:  "No, no; I go, I depart!  I believe in you, and I would have all
Title:  the merit of my devotion, even if that devotion were stupidity.
Title:  Adieu, madame, adieu!"
Title:  
Title:  And as if he only felt strength to detach himself by a violent
Title:  effort from the hand he held, he sprang away, running, while Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux knocked, as at the shutter, three light and regular
Title:  taps.  When he had gained the angle of the street, he turned.
Title:  The door had been opened, and shut again; the mercer's pretty
Title:  wife had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan pursued his way.  He had given his word not to watch
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux, and if his life had depended upon the spot to
Title:  which she was going or upon the person who should accompany her,
Title:  d'Artagnan would have returned home, since he had so promised.
Title:  Five minutes later he was in the Rue des Fossoyeurs.
Title:  
Title:  "Poor Athos!" said he; "he will never guess what all this means.
Title:  He will have fallen asleep waiting for me, or else he will have
Title:  returned home, where he will have learned that a woman had been
Title:  there.  A woman with Athos!  After all," continued d'Artagnan,
Title:  "there was certainly one with Aramis.  All this is very strange;
Title:  and I am curious to know how it will end."
Title:  
Title:  "Badly, monsieur, badly!" replied a voice which the young man
Title:  recognized as that of Planchet; for, soliloquizing aloud, as very
Title:  preoccupied people do, he had entered the alley, at the end of
Title:  which were the stairs which led to his chamber.
Title:  
Title:  "How badly?  What do you mean by that, you idiot?" asked
Title:  d'Artagnan.  "What has happened?"
Title:  
Title:  "All sorts of misfortunes."
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the first place, Monsieur Athos is arrested."
Title:  
Title:  "Arrested!  Athos arrested!  What for?"
Title:  
Title:  "He was found in your lodging; they took him for you."
Title:  
Title:  "And by whom was he arrested?"
Title:  
Title:  "By Guards brought by the men in black whom you put to flight."
Title:  
Title:  "Why did he not tell them his name?  Why did he not tell them he
Title:  knew nothing about this affair?"
Title:  
Title:  "He took care not to do so, monsieur; on the contrary, he came up
Title:  to me and said, 'It is your master that needs his liberty at this
Title:  moment and not I, since he knows everything and I know nothing.
Title:  They will believe he is arrested, and that will give him time; in
Title:  three days I will tell them who I am, and they cannot fail to let
Title:  me go.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Bravo, Athos!  Noble heart!" murmured d'Artagnan.  "I know him
Title:  well there!  And what did the officers do?"
Title:  
Title:  "Four conveyed him away, I don't know where--to the Bastille or
Title:  Fort l'Eveque.  Two remained with the men in black, who rummaged
Title:  every place and took all the papers.  The last two mounted guard
Title:  at the door during this examination; then, when all was over,
Title:  they went away, leaving the house empty and exposed."
Title:  
Title:  "And Porthos and Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "I could not find them; they did not come."
Title:  
Title:  "But they may come any moment, for you left word that I awaited
Title:  them?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, don't budge, then; if they come, tell them what has
Title:  happened.  Let them wait for me at the Pomme-de-Pin.  Here it
Title:  would be dangerous; the house may be watched.  I will run to
Title:  Monsieur de Treville to tell them all this, and will meet them
Title:  there."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well, monsieur," said Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  "But you will remain; you are not afraid?" said d'Artagnan,
Title:  coming back to recommend courage to his lackey.
Title:  
Title:  "Be easy, monsieur," said Planchet; "you do not know me yet.  I
Title:  am brave when I set about it.  It is all in beginning.  Besides,
Title:  I am a Picard."
Title:  
Title:  "Then it is understood," said d'Artagnan; "you would rather be
Title:  killed than desert your post?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur; and there is nothing I would not do to prove to
Title:  Monsieur that I am attached to him."
Title:  
Title:  "Good!" said d'Artagnan to himself.  "It appears that the method
Title:  I have adopted with this boy is decidedly the best.  I shall use
Title:  it again upon occasion."
Title:  
Title:  And with all the swiftness of his legs, already a little fatigued
Title:  however, with the perambulations of the day, d'Artagnan directed
Title:  his course toward M. de Treville's.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville was not at his hotel.  His company was on guard at
Title:  the Louvre; he was at the Louvre with his company.
Title:  
Title:  It was necessary to reach M. de Treville; it was important that
Title:  he should be informed of what was passing.  D'Artagnan resolved
Title:  to try and enter the Louvre.  His costume of Guardsman in the
Title:  company of M. Dessessart ought to be his passport.
Title:  
Title:  He therefore went down the Rue des Petits Augustins, and came up
Title:  to the quay, in order to take the New Bridge.  He had at first an
Title:  idea of crossing by the ferry; but on gaining the riverside, he
Title:  had mechanically put his hand into his pocket, and perceived that
Title:  he had not wherewithal to pay his passage.
Title:  
Title:  As he gained the top of the Rue Guenegaud, he saw two persons
Title:  coming out of the Rue Dauphine whose appearance very much struck
Title:  him.  Of the two persons who composed this group, one was a man
Title:  and the other a woman.  The woman had the outline of Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux; the man resembled Aramis so much as to be mistaken for
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, the woman wore that black mantle which d'Artagnan could
Title:  still see outlined on the shutter of the Rue de Vaugirard and on
Title:  the door of the Rue de la Harpe; still further, the man wore the
Title:  uniform of a Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  The woman's hood was pulled down, and the man held a handkerchief
Title:  to his face.  Both, as this double precaution indicated, had an
Title:  interest in not being recognized.
Title:  
Title:  They took the bridge.  That was d'Artagnan's road, as he was
Title:  going to the Louvre.  D'Artagnan followed them.
Title:  
Title:  He had not gone twenty steps before he became convinced that the
Title:  woman was really Mme. Bonacieux and that the man was Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  He felt at that instant all the suspicions of jealousy agitating
Title:  his heart.  He felt himself doubly betrayed, by his friend and by
Title:  her whom he already loved like a mistress.  Mme. Bonacieux had
Title:  declared to him, by all the gods, that she did not know Aramis;
Title:  and a quarter of an hour after having made this assertion, he
Title:  found her hanging on the arm of Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan did not reflect that he had only known the mercer's
Title:  pretty wife for three hours; that she owed him nothing but a
Title:  little gratitude for having delivered her from the men in black,
Title:  who wished to carry her off, and that she had promised him
Title:  nothing.  He considered himself an outraged, betrayed, and
Title:  ridiculed lover.  Blood and anger mounted to his face; he was
Title:  resolved to unravel the mystery.
Title:  
Title:  The young man and young woman perceived they were watched, and
Title:  redoubled their speed.  D'Artagnan determined upon his course.
Title:  He passed them, then returned so as to meet them exactly before
Title:  the Samaritaine. Which was illuminated by a lamp which threw its
Title:  light over all that part of the bridge.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan stopped before them, and they stopped before him.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you want, monsieur?" demanded the Musketeer, recoiling a
Title:  step, and with a foreign accent, which proved to d'Artagnan that
Title:  he was deceived in one of his conjectures.
Title:  
Title:  "It is not Aramis!" cried he.
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, it is not Aramis; and by your exclamation I
Title:  perceive you have mistaken me for another, and pardon you."
Title:  
Title:  "You pardon me?" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," replied the stranger.  "Allow me, then, to pass on, since
Title:  it is not with me you have anything to do."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, monsieur, it is not with you that I have anything
Title:  to do; it is with Madame."
Title:  
Title:  "With Madame!  You do not know her," replied the stranger.
Title:  
Title:  "You are deceived, monsieur; I know her very well."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said Mme. Bonacieux; in a tone of reproach, "ah, monsieur,
Title:  I had your promise as a soldier and your word as a gentleman.  I
Title:  hoped to be able to rely upon that."
Title:  
Title:  "And I, madame!" said d'Artagnan, embarrassed; "you promised me--"
Title:  
Title:  "Take my arm, madame," said the stranger, "and let us continue
Title:  our way."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, however, stupefied, cast down, annihilated by all
Title:  that happened, stood, with crossed arms, before the Musketeer and
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  The Musketeer advanced two steps, and pushed d'Artagnan aside
Title:  with his hand.  D'Artagnan made a spring backward and drew his
Title:  sword.  At the same time, and with the rapidity of lightning, the
Title:  stranger drew his.
Title:  
Title:  "In the name of heaven, my Lord!" cried Mme. Bonacieux, throwing
Title:  herself between the combatants and seizing the swords with her
Title:  hands.
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord!" cried d'Artagnan, enlightened by a sudden idea, "my
Title:  Lord!  Pardon me, monsieur, but you are not--"
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord the Duke of Buckingham," said Mme. Bonacieux, in an
Title:  undertone; "and now you may ruin us all."
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, Madame, I ask a hundred pardons!  But I love her, my
Title:  Lord, and was jealous.  You know what it is to love, my Lord.
Title:  Pardon me, and then tell me how I can risk my life to serve your
Title:  Grace?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are a brave young man," said Buckingham, holding out his
Title:  hand to d'Artagnan, who pressed it respectfully.  "You offer me
Title:  your services; with the same frankness I accept them.  Follow us
Title:  at a distance of twenty paces, as far as the Louvre, and if
Title:  anyone watches us, slay him!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan placed his naked sword under his arm, allowed the duke
Title:  and Mme. Bonacieux to take twenty steps ahead, and then followed
Title:  them, ready to execute the instructions of the noble and elegant
Title:  minister of Charles I.
Title:  
Title:  Fortunately, he had no opportunity to give the duke this proof of
Title:  his devotion, and the young woman and the handsome Musketeer
Title:  entered the Louvre by the wicket of the Echelle without any
Title:  interference.
Title:  
Title:  As for d'Artagnan, he immediately repaired to the cabaret of the
Title:  Pomme-de-Pin, where he found Porthos and Aramis awaiting him.
Title:  Without giving them any explanation of the alarm and
Title:  inconvenience he had caused them, he told them that he had
Title:  terminated the affair alone in which he had for a moment believed
Title:  he should need their assistance.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, carried away as we are by our narrative, we must leave
Title:  our three friends to themselves, and follow the Duke of
Title:  Buckingham and his guide through the labyrinths of the Louvre.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  12  GEORGE VILLIERS, DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux and the duke entered the Louvre without
Title:  difficulty.  Mme. Bonacieux was known to belong to the queen; the
Title:  duke wore the uniform of the Musketeers of M. de Treville, who,
Title:  as we have said, were that evening on guard.  Besides, Germain
Title:  was in the interests of the queen; and if anything should happen,
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux would be accused of having introduced her lover
Title:  into the Louvre, that was all.  She took the risk upon herself.
Title:  Her reputation would be lost, it is true; but of what value in
Title:  the world was the reputation of the little wife of a mercer?
Title:  
Title:  Once within the interior of the court, the duke and the young
Title:  woman followed the wall for the space of about twenty-five steps.
Title:  This space passed, Mme. Bonacieux pushed a little servants' door,
Title:  open by day but generally closed at night.  The door yielded.
Title:  Both entered, and found themselves in darkness; but Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux was acquainted with all the turnings and windings of
Title:  this part of the Louvre, appropriated for the people of the
Title:  household.  She closed the door after her, took the duke by the
Title:  hand, and after a few experimental steps, grasped a balustrade,
Title:  put her foot upon the bottom step, and began to ascend the
Title:  staircase.  The duke counted two stories.  She then turned to the
Title:  right, followed the course of a long corridor, descended a
Title:  flight, went a few steps farther, introduced a key into a lock,
Title:  opened a door, and pushed the duke into an apartment lighted only
Title:  by a lamp, saying, "Remain here, my Lord Duke; someone will
Title:  come."  She then went out by the same door, which she locked, so
Title:  that the duke found himself literally a prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, isolated as he was, we must say that the Duke of
Title:  Buckingham did not experience an instant of fear.  One of the
Title:  salient points of his character was the search for adventures and
Title:  a love of romance.  Brave, rash, and enterprising, this was not
Title:  the first time he had risked his life in such attempts.  He had
Title:  learned that the pretended message from Anne of Austria, upon the
Title:  faith of which he had come to Paris, was a snare; but instead of
Title:  regaining England, he had, abusing the position in which he had
Title:  been placed, declared to the queen that he would not depart
Title:  without seeing her.  The queen had at first positively refused;
Title:  but at length became afraid that the duke, if exasperated, would
Title:  commit some folly.  She had already decided upon seeing him and
Title:  urging his immediate departure, when, on the very evening of
Title:  coming to this decision, Mme. Bonacieux, who was charged with
Title:  going to fetch the duke and conducting him to the Louvre, was
Title:  abducted.  For two days no one knew what had become of her, and
Title:  everything remained in suspense; but once free, and placed in
Title:  communication with Laporte, matters resumed their course, and she
Title:  accomplished the perilous enterprise which, but for her arrest,
Title:  would have been executed three days earlier.
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham, left alone, walked toward a mirror.  His Musketeer's
Title:  uniform became him marvelously.
Title:  
Title:  At thirty-five, which was then his age, he passed, with just
Title:  title, for the handsomest gentleman and the most elegant cavalier
Title:  of France or England.
Title:  
Title:  The favorite of two kings, immensely rich, all-powerful in a
Title:  kingdom which he disordered at his fancy and calmed again at his
Title:  caprice, George Villiers, Duke of Buckingham, had lived one of
Title:  those fabulous existences which survive, in the course of
Title:  centuries, to astonish posterity.
Title:  
Title:  Sure of himself, convinced of his own power, certain that the
Title:  laws which rule other men could not reach him, he went straight
Title:  to the object he aimed at, even were this object were so elevated
Title:  and so dazzling that it would have been madness for any other
Title:  even to have contemplated it.  It was thus he had succeeded in
Title:  approaching several times the beautiful and proud Anne of
Title:  Austria, and in making himself loved by dazzling her.
Title:  
Title:  George Villiers placed himself before the glass, as we have said,
Title:  restored the undulations to his beautiful hair, which the weight
Title:  of his hat had disordered, twisted his mustache, and, his heart
Title:  swelling with joy, happy and proud at being near the moment he
Title:  had so long sighed for, he smiled upon himself with pride and
Title:  hope.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment a door concealed in the tapestry opened, and a
Title:  woman appeared.  Buckingham saw this apparition in the glass; he
Title:  uttered a cry.  It was the queen!
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria was then twenty-six or twenty-seven years of age;
Title:  that is to say, she was in the full splendor of her beauty.
Title:  
Title:  Her carriage was that of a queen or a goddess; her eyes, which
Title:  cast the brilliancy of emeralds, were perfectly beautiful, and
Title:  yet were at the same time full of sweetness and majesty.
Title:  
Title:  Her mouth was small and rosy; and although her underlip, like
Title:  that of all princes of the House of Austria, protruded slightly
Title:  beyond the other, it was eminently lovely in its smile, but as
Title:  profoundly disdainful in its contempt.
Title:  
Title:  Her skin was admired for its velvety softness; her hands and arms
Title:  were of surpassing beauty, all the poets of the time singing them
Title:  as incomparable.
Title:  
Title:  Lastly, her hair, which, from being light in her youth, had
Title:  become chestnut, and which she wore curled very plainly, and with
Title:  much powder, admirably set off her face, in which the most rigid
Title:  critic could only have desired a little less rouge, and the most
Title:  fastidious sculptor a little more fineness in the nose.
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham remained for a moment dazzled.  Never had Anne of
Title:  Austria appeared to him so beautiful, amid balls, fetes, or
Title:  carousals, as she appeared to him at this moment, dressed in a
Title:  simple robe of white satin, and accompanied by Donna Estafania--
Title:  the only one of her Spanish women who had not been driven from
Title:  her by the jealousy of the king or by the persecutions of
Title:  Richelieu.
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria took two steps forward.  Buckingham threw himself
Title:  at her feet, and before the queen could prevent him, kissed the
Title:  hem of her robe.
Title:  
Title:  "Duke, you already know that it is not I who caused you to be
Title:  written to."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, madame!  Yes, your Majesty!" cried the duke. "I know
Title:  that I must have been mad, senseless, to believe that snow would
Title:  become animated or marble warm; but what then!  They who love
Title:  believe easily in love.  Besides, I have lost nothing by this
Title:  journey because I see you."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," replied Anne, "but you know why and how I see you;
Title:  because, insensible to all my sufferings, you persist in
Title:  remaining in a city where, by remaining, you run the risk of your
Title:  life, and make me run the risk of my honor.  I see you to tell
Title:  you that everything separates us--the depths of the sea, the
Title:  enmity of kingdoms, the sanctity of vows.  It is sacrilege to
Title:  struggle against so many things, my Lord.  In short, I see you to
Title:  tell you that we must never see each other again."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak on, madame, speak on, Queen," said Buckingham; "the
Title:  sweetness of your voice covers the harshness of your words.  You
Title:  talk of sacrilege!  Why, the sacrilege is the separation of two
Title:  hearts formed by God for each other."
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord," cried the queen, "you forget that I have never said
Title:  that I love you."
Title:  
Title:  "But you have never told me that you did not love me; and truly,
Title:  to speak such words to me would be, on the part of your Majesty,
Title:  too great an ingratitude.  For tell me, where can you find a love
Title:  like mine--a love which neither time, nor absence, nor despair
Title:  can extinguish, a love which contents itself with a lost ribbon,
Title:  a stray look, or a chance word?  It is now three years, madame,
Title:  since I saw you for the first time, and during those three years
Title:  I have loved you thus.  Shall I tell you each ornament of your
Title:  toilet?  Mark!  I see you now.  You were seated upon cushions in
Title:  the Spanish fashion; you wore a robe of green satin embroidered
Title:  with gold and silver, hanging sleeves knotted upon your beautiful
Title:  arms--those lovely arms--with large diamonds.  You wore a close
Title:  ruff, a small cap upon your head of the same color as your robe,
Title:  and in that cap a heron's feather.  Hold!  Hold!  I shut my eyes,
Title:  and I can see you as you then were; I open them again, and I see
Title:  what you are now--a hundred time more beautiful!"
Title:
