Title:  "What folly," murmured Anne of Austria, who had not the courage
Title:  to find fault with the duke for having so well preserved her
Title:  portrait in his heart, "what folly to feed a useless passion with
Title:  such remembrances!"
Title:  
Title:  "And upon what then must I live?  I have nothing but memory.  It
Title:  is my happiness, my treasure, my hope.  Every time I see you is a
Title:  fresh diamond which I enclose in the casket of my heart.  This
Title:  is the fourth which you have let fall and I have picked up; for
Title:  in three years, madame, I have only seen you four times--the
Title:  first, which I have described to you; the second, at the mansion
Title:  of Madame de Chevreuse; the third, in the gardens of Amiens."
Title:  
Title:  "Duke," said the queen, blushing, "never speak of that evening."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, let us speak of it; on the contrary, let us speak of it!
Title:  That is the most happy and brilliant evening of my life!  You
Title:  remember what a beautiful night it was?  How soft and perfumed
Title:  was the air; how lovely the blue heavens and star-enameled sky!
Title:  Ah, then, madame, I was able for one instant to be alone with
Title:  you.  Then you were about to tell me all--the isolation of your
Title:  life, the griefs of your heart.  You leaned upon my arm--upon
Title:  this, madame!  I felt, in bending my head toward you, your
Title:  beautiful hair touch my cheek; and every time that it touched me
Title:  I trembled from head to foot.  Oh, Queen!  Queen!  You do not
Title:  know what felicity from heaven, what joys from paradise, are
Title:  comprised in a moment like that.  Take my wealth, my fortune, my
Title:  glory, all the days I have to live, for such an instant, for a
Title:  night like that.  For that night, madame, that night you loved
Title:  me, I will swear it."
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, yes; it is possible that the influence of the place,
Title:  the charm of the beautiful evening, the fascination of your
Title:  look--the thousand circumstances, in short, which sometimes unite
Title:  to destroy a woman--were grouped around me on that fatal evening;
Title:  but, my Lord, you saw the queen come to the aid of the woman who
Title:  faltered.  At the first word you dared to utter, at the first
Title:  freedom to which I had to reply, I called for help."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, that is true.  And any other love but mine would have
Title:  sunk beneath this ordeal; but my love came out from it more
Title:  ardent and more eternal.  You believed that you would fly from me
Title:  by returning to Paris; you believed that I would not dare to quit
Title:  the treasure over which my master had charged me to watch.  What
Title:  to me were all the treasures in the world, or all the kings of
Title:  the earth!  Eight days after, I was back again, madame.  That
Title:  time you had nothing to say to me; I had risked my life and favor
Title:  to see you but for a second.  I did not even touch your hand, and
Title:  you pardoned me on seeing me so submissive and so repentant."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but calumny seized upon all those follies in which I took
Title:  no part, as you well know, my Lord.  The king, excited by the
Title:  cardinal, made a terrible clamor.  Madame de Vernet was driven
Title:  from me, Putange was exiled, Madame de Chevreuse fell into
Title:  disgrace, and when you wished to come back as ambassador to
Title:  France, the king himself--remember, my lord--the king himself
Title:  opposed to it."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, and France is about to pay for her king's refusal with a
Title:  war.  I am not allowed to see you, madame, but you shall every
Title:  day hear of me.  What object, think you, have this expedition to
Title:  Re and this league with the Protestants of La Rochelle which I am
Title:  projecting?  The pleasure of seeing you.  I have no hope of
Title:  penetrating, sword in hand, to Paris, I know that well.  But this
Title:  war may bring round a peace; this peace will require a
Title:  negotiator; that negotiator will be me.  They will not dare to
Title:  refuse me then; and I will return to Paris, and will see you
Title:  again, and will be happy for an instant.  Thousands of men, it is
Title:  true, will have to pay for my happiness with their lives; but
Title:  what is that to me, provided I see you again!  All this is
Title:  perhaps folly--perhaps insanity; but tell me what woman has a
Title:  lover more truly in love; what queen a servant more ardent?"
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, my Lord, you invoke in your defense things which accuse
Title:  you more strongly.  All these proofs of love which you would give
Title:  me are almost crimes."
Title:  
Title:  "Because you do not love me, madame!  If you loved me, you would
Title:  view all this otherwise.  If you loved me, oh, if you loved me,
Title:  that would be too great happiness, and I should run mad.  Ah,
Title:  Madame de Chevreuse was less cruel than you.  Holland loved her,
Title:  and she responded to his love."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame de Chevreuse was not queen," murmured Anne of Austria,
Title:  overcome, in spite of herself, by the expression of so profound a
Title:  passion.
Title:  
Title:  "You would love me, then, if you were not queen!  Madame, say
Title:  that you would love me then!  I can believe that it is the
Title:  dignity of your rank alone which makes you cruel to me; I can
Title:  believe that you had been Madame de Chevreuse, poor Buckingham
Title:  might have hoped.  Thanks for those sweet words!  Oh, my
Title:  beautiful sovereign, a hundred times, thanks!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my Lord!  You have ill understood, wrongly interpreted; I
Title:  did not mean to say--"
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, silence!" cried the duke.  "If I am happy in an error,
Title:  do not have the cruelty to lift me from it.  You have told me
Title:  yourself, madame, that I have been drawn into a snare; I,
Title:  perhaps, may leave my life in it--for, although it may be
Title:  strange, I have for some time had a presentiment that I should
Title:  shortly die."  And the duke smiled, with a smile at once sad and
Title:  charming.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!" cried Anne of Austria, with an accent of terror
Title:  which proved how much greater an interest she took in the duke
Title:  than she ventured to tell.
Title:  
Title:  "I do not tell you this, madame, to terrify you; no, it is even
Title:  ridiculous for me to name it to you, and, believe me, I take no
Title:  heed of such dreams.  But the words you have just spoken, the
Title:  hope you have almost given me, will have richly paid all--were it
Title:  my life."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, but I," said Anne, "I also, duke, have had presentiments; I
Title:  also have had dreams.  I dreamed that I saw you lying bleeding,
Title:  wounded."
Title:  
Title:  "In the left side, was it not, and with a knife?" interrupted
Title:  Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, it was so, my Lord, it was so--in the left side, and with a
Title:  knife.  Who can possibly have told you I had had that dream?  I
Title:  have imparted it to no one but my God, and that in my prayers."
Title:  
Title:  "I ask for no more.  You love me, madame; it is enough."
Title:  
Title:  "I love you, I?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes.  Would God send the same dreams to you as to me if you
Title:  did not love me?  Should we have the same presentiments if our
Title:  existences did not touch at the heart?  You love me, my beautiful
Title:  queen, and you will weep for me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God!" cried Anne of Austria, "this is more than I
Title:  can bear.  In the name of heaven, Duke, leave me, go!  I do not
Title:  know whether I love you or love you not; but what I know is that
Title:  I will not be perjured.  Take pity on me, then, and go!  Oh, if
Title:  you are struck in France, if you die in France, if I could imagine
Title:  that your love for me was the cause of your death, I could not
Title:  console myself; I should run mad.  Depart then, depart, I implore
Title:  you!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, how beautiful you are thus!  Oh, how I love you!" said
Title:  Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  "Go, go, I implore you, and return hereafter!  Come back as
Title:  ambassador, come back as minister, come back surrounded with
Title:  guards who will defend you, with servants who will watch over
Title:  you, and then I shall no longer fear for your days, and I shall
Title:  be happy in seeing you."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, is this true what you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, then, some pledge of your indulgence, some object which came
Title:  from you, and may remind me that I have not been dreaming;
Title:  something you have worn, and that I may wear in my turn--a ring,
Title:  a necklace, a chain."
Title:  
Title:  "Will you depart--will you depart, if I give you that you
Title:  demand?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "This very instant?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "You will leave France, you will return to England?"
Title:  
Title:  "I will, I swear to you."
Title:  
Title:  "Wait, then, wait."
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria re-entered her apartment, and came out again
Title:  almost immediately, holding a rosewood casket in her hand, with
Title:  her cipher encrusted with gold.
Title:  
Title:  "Here, my Lord, here," said she, "keep this in memory of me."
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham took the casket, and fell a second time on his knees.
Title:  
Title:  "You have promised me to go," said the queen.
Title:  
Title:  "And I keep my word.  Your hand, madame, your hand, and I
Title:  depart!"
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria stretched forth her hand, closing her eyes, and
Title:  leaning with the other upon Estafania, for she felt that her
Title:  strength was about to fail her.
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham pressed his lips passionately to that beautiful hand,
Title:  and then rising, said, "Within six months, if I am not dead, I
Title:  shall have seen you again, madame--even if I have to overturn the
Title:  world."  And faithful to the promise he had made, he rushed out
Title:  of the apartment.
Title:  
Title:  In the corridor he met Mme. Bonacieux, who waited for him, and
Title:  who, with the same precautions and the same good luck, conducted
Title:  him out of the Louvre.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  13  MONSIEUR BONACIEUX
Title:  
Title:  There was in all this, as may have been observed, one personage
Title:  concerned, of whom, notwithstanding his precarious position, we
Title:  have appeared to take but very little notice.  This personage was
Title:  M. Bonacieux, the respectable martyr of the political and amorous
Title:  intrigues which entangled themselves so nicely together at this
Title:  gallant and chivalric period.
Title:  
Title:  Fortunately, the reader may remember, or may not remember--
Title:  fortunately we have promised not to lose sight of him.
Title:  
Title:  The officers who arrested him conducted him straight to the
Title:  Bastille, where he passed trembling before a party of soldiers
Title:  who were loading their muskets.  Thence, introduced into a half-
Title:  subterranean gallery, he became, on the part of those who had
Title:  brought him, the object of the grossest insults and the harshest
Title:  treatment.  The officers perceived that they had not to deal with
Title:  a gentleman, and they treated him like a very peasant.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of half an hour or thereabouts, a clerk came to put an
Title:  end to his tortures, but not to his anxiety, by giving the order
Title:  to conduct M. Bonacieux to the Chamber of Examination.
Title:  Ordinarily, prisoners were interrogated in their cells; but they
Title:  did not do so with M. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  Two guards attended the mercer who made him traverse a court and
Title:  enter a corridor in which were three sentinels, opened a door and
Title:  pushed him unceremoniously into a low room, where the only
Title:  furniture was a table, a chair, and a commissary.  The commissary
Title:  was seated in the chair, and was writing at the table.
Title:  
Title:  The two guards led the prisoner toward the table, and upon a sign
Title:  from the commissary drew back so far as to be unable to hear
Title:  anything.
Title:  
Title:  The commissary, who had till this time held his head down over
Title:  his papers, looked up to see what sort of person he had to do
Title:  with.  This commissary was a man of very repulsive mien, with a
Title:  pointed nose, with yellow and salient cheek bones, with eyes
Title:  small but keen and penetrating, and an expression of countenance
Title:  resembling at once the polecat and the fox.  His head, supported
Title:  by a long and flexible neck, issued from his large black robe,
Title:  balancing itself with a motion very much like that of the
Title:  tortoise thrusting his head out of his shell.  He began by asking
Title:  M. Bonacieux his name, age, condition, and abode.
Title:  
Title:  The accused replied that his name was Jacques Michel Bonacieux,
Title:  that he was fifty-one years old, a retired mercer, and lived Rue
Title:  des Fossoyeurs, No. 14.
Title:  
Title:  The commissary then, instead of continuing to interrogate him,
Title:  made him a long speech upon the danger there is for an obscure
Title:  citizen to meddle with public matters.  He complicated this
Title:  exordium by an exposition in which he painted the power and the
Title:  deeds of the cardinal, that incomparable minister, that conqueror
Title:  of past ministers, that example for ministers to come--deeds and
Title:  power which none could thwart with impunity.
Title:  
Title:  After this second part of his discourse, fixing his hawk's eye
Title:  upon poor Bonacieux, he bade him reflect upon the gravity of his
Title:  situation.
Title:  
Title:  The reflections of the mercer were already made; he cursed the
Title:  instant when M. Laporte formed the idea of marrying him to his
Title:  goddaughter, and particularly the moment when that goddaughter
Title:   had been received as Lady of the Linen to her Majesty.
Title:  
Title:  At bottom the character of M. Bonacieux was one of profound
Title:  selfishness mixed with sordid avarice, the whole seasoned with
Title:  extreme cowardice.  The love with which his young wife had
Title:  inspired him was a secondary sentiment, and was not strong enough
Title:  to contend with the primitive feelings we have just enumerated.
Title:  Bonacieux indeed reflected on what had just been said to him.
Title:  
Title:  "But, Monsieur Commissary," said he, calmly, "believe that I know
Title:  and appreciate, more than anybody, the merit of the incomparable
Title:  eminence by whom we have the honor to be governed."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed?" asked the commissary, with an air of doubt.  "If that
Title:  is really so, how came you in the Bastille?"
Title:  
Title:  "How I came there, or rather why I am there," replied Bonacieux,
Title:  "that is entirely impossible for me to tell you, because I don't
Title:  know myself; but to a certainty it is not for having, knowingly
Title:  at least, disobliged Monsieur the Cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "You must, nevertheless, have committed a crime, since you are
Title:  here and are accused of high treason."
Title:  
Title:  "Of high treason!" cried Bonacieux, terrified; "of high treason!
Title:  How is it possible for a poor mercer, who detests Huguenots and
Title:  who abhors Spaniards, to be accused of high treason?  Consider,
Title:  monsieur, the thing is absolutely impossible."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Bonacieux," said the commissary, looking at the accused
Title:  as if his little eyes had the faculty of reading to the very
Title:  depths of hearts, "you have a wife?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," replied the mercer, in a tremble, feeling that
Title:  it was at this point affairs were likely to become perplexing;
Title:  "that is to say, I HAD one."
Title:  
Title:  "What, you 'had one'?  What have you done with her, then, if you
Title:  have her no longer?"
Title:  
Title:  "They have abducted her, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "They have abducted her?  Ah!"
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux inferred from this "Ah" that the affair grew more and
Title:  more intricate.
Title:  
Title:  "They have abducted her," added the commissary; "and do you know
Title:  the man who has committed this deed?"
Title:  
Title:  "I think I know him."
Title:  
Title:  "Who is he?"
Title:  
Title:  "Remember that I affirm nothing, Monsieur the Commissary, and
Title:  that I only suspect."
Title:  
Title:  "Whom do you suspect?  Come, answer freely."
Title:  
Title:  M. Bonacieux was in the greatest perplexity possible.  Had he
Title:  better deny everything or tell everything?  By denying all, it
Title:  might be suspected that he must know too much to avow; by
Title:  confessing all he might prove his good will.  He decided, then,
Title:  to tell all.
Title:  
Title:  "I suspect," said he, "a tall, dark man, of lofty carriage, who
Title:  has the air of a great lord.  He has followed us several times,
Title:  as I think, when I have waited for my wife at the wicket of the
Title:  Louvre to escort her home."
Title:  
Title:  The commissary now appeared to experience a little uneasiness.
Title:  
Title:  "And his name?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, as to his name, I know nothing about it; but if I were ever
Title:  to meet him, I should recognize him in an instant, I will answer
Title:  for it, were he among a thousand persons."
Title:  
Title:  The face of the commissary grew still darker.
Title:  
Title:  "You should recognize him among a thousand, say you?" continued
Title:  he.
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say," cried Bonacieux, who saw he had taken a false
Title:  step, "that is to say--"
Title:  
Title:  "You have answered that you should recognize him," said the
Title:  commissary.  "That is all very well, and enough for today; before
Title:  we proceed further, someone must be informed that you know the
Title:  ravisher of your wife."
Title:  
Title:  "But I have not told you that I know him!" cried Bonacieux, in
Title:  despair.  "I told you, on the contrary--"
Title:  
Title:  "Take away the prisoner," said the commissary to the two guards.
Title:  
Title:  "Where must we place him?" demanded the chief.
Title:  
Title:  "In a dungeon."
Title:  
Title:  "Which?"
Title:  
Title:  "Good Lord!  In the first one handy, provided it is safe," said
Title:  the commissary, with an indifference which penetrated poor
Title:  Bonacieux with horror.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, alas!" said he to himself, "misfortune is over my head; my
Title:  wife must have committed some frightful crime.  They believe me
Title:  her accomplice, and will punish me with her.  She must have
Title:  spoken; she must have confessed everything--a woman is so weak!
Title:  A dungeon!  The first he comes to!  That's it!  A night is soon
Title:  passed; and tomorrow to the wheel, to the gallows!  Oh, my God,
Title:  my God, have pity on me!"
Title:  
Title:  Without listening the least in the world to the lamentations of
Title:  M. Bonacieux--lamentations to which, besides, they must have been
Title:  pretty well accustomed--the two guards took the prisoner each by
Title:  an arm, and led him away, while the commissary wrote a letter in
Title:  haste and dispatched it by an officer in waiting.
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux could not close his eyes; not because his dungeon was
Title:  so very disagreeable, but because his uneasiness was so great.
Title:  He sat all night on his stool, starting at the least noise; and
Title:  when the first rays of the sun penetrated into his chamber, the
Title:  dawn itself appeared to him to have taken funereal tints.
Title:  
Title:  All at once he heard his bolts drawn, and made a terrified bound.
Title:  He believed they were come to conduct him to the scaffold; so
Title:  that when he saw merely and simply, instead of the executioner he
Title:  expected, only his commissary of the preceding evening, attended
Title:  by his clerk, he was ready to embrace them both.
Title:  
Title:  "Your affair has become more complicated since yesterday evening,
Title:  my good man, and I advise you to tell the whole truth; for your
Title:  repentance alone can remove the anger of the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, I am ready to tell everything," cried Bonacieux, "at least,
Title:  all that I know.  Interrogate me, I entreat you!"
Title:  
Title:  "Where is your wife, in the first place?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, did not I tell you she had been stolen from me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but yesterday at five o'clock in the afternoon, thanks to
Title:  you, she escaped."
Title:  
Title:  "My wife escaped!" cried Bonacieux.  "Oh, unfortunate creature!
Title:  Monsieur, if she has escaped, it is not my fault, I swear."
Title:  
Title:  "What business had you, then, to go into the chamber of Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan, your neighbor, with whom you had a long conference
Title:  during the day?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, yes, Monsieur Commissary; yes, that is true, and I confess
Title:  that I was in the wrong.  I did go to Monsieur d'Artagnan's."
Title:  
Title:  "What was the aim of that visit?"
Title:  
Title:  "To beg him to assist me in finding my wife.  I believed I had a
Title:  right to endeavor to find her.  I was deceived, as it appears,
Title:  and I ask your pardon."
Title:  
Title:  "And what did Monsieur d'Artagnan reply?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur d'Artagnan promised me his assistance; but I soon found
Title:  out that he was betraying me."
Title:  
Title:  "You impose upon justice.  Monsieur d'Artagnan made a compact
Title:  with you; and in virtue of that compact put to flight the police
Title:  who had arrested your wife, and has placed her beyond reach."
Title:  
Title:  "Fortunately, Monsieur d'Artagnan is in our hands, and you shall
Title:  be confronted with him."
Title:  
Title:  "By my faith, I ask no better," cried Bonacieux; "I shall not be
Title:  sorry to see the face of an acquaintance."
Title:  
Title:  "Bring in the Monsieur d'Artagnan," said the commissary to the
Title:  guards.  The two guards led in Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur d'Artagnan," said the commissary, addressing Athos,
Title:  "declare all that passed yesterday between you and Monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "But," cried Bonacieux, "this is not Monsieur d'Artagnan whom you
Title:  show me."
Title:  
Title:  "What!  Not Monsieur d'Artagnan?" exclaimed the commissary.
Title:  
Title:  "Not the least in the world," replied Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "What is this gentleman's name?" asked the commissary.
Title:  
Title:  "I cannot tell you; I don't know him."
Title:  
Title:  "How!  You don't know him?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "Did you never see him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I have seen him, but I don't know what he calls himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Your name?" replied the commissary.
Title:  
Title:  "Athos," replied the Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "But that is not a man's name; that is the name of a mountain,"
Title:  cried the poor questioner, who began to lose his head.
Title:  
Title:  "That is my name," said Athos, quietly.
Title:  
Title:  "But you said that your name was d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "Who, I?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, you."
Title:  
Title:  "Somebody said to me, 'You are Monsieur d'Artagnan?' I answered,
Title:  'You think so?'  My guards exclaimed that they were sure of it.
Title:  I did not wish to contradict them; besides, I might be deceived."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, you insult the majesty of justice."
Title:  
Title:  "Not at all," said Athos, calmly.
Title:  
Title:  "You are Monsieur d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "You see, monsieur, that you say it again."
Title:  
Title:  "But I tell you, Monsieur Commissary," cried Bonacieux, in his
Title:  turn, "there is not the least doubt about the matter.  Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan is my tenant, although he does not pay me my rent--and
Title:  even better on that account ought I to know him.  Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan is a young man, scarcely nineteen or twenty, and this
Title:  gentleman must be thirty at least.  Monsieur d'Artagnan is in
Title:  Monsieur Dessessart's Guards, and this gentleman is in the company of
Title:  Monsieur de Treville's Musketeers.  Look at his uniform, Monsieur
Title:  Commissary, look at his uniform!"
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," murmured the commissary; "PARDIEU, that's true."
Title:  
Title:  At this moment the door was opened quickly, and a messenger,
Title:  introduced by one of the gatekeepers of the Bastille, gave a
Title:  letter to the commissary.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, unhappy woman!" cried the commissary.
Title:  
Title:  "How?  What do you say?  Of whom do you speak?  It is not of my
Title:  wife, I hope!"
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary, it is of her.  Yours is a pretty business."
Title:  
Title:  "But," said the agitated mercer, "do me the pleasure, monsieur,
Title:  to tell me how my own proper affair can become worse by anything
Title:  my wife does while I am in prison?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because that which she does is part of a plan concerted between
Title:  you--of an infernal plan."
Title:  
Title:  "I swear to you, Monsieur Commissary, that you are in the
Title:  profoundest error, that I know nothing in the world about what my
Title:  wife had to do, that I am entirely a stranger to what she has
Title:  done; and that if she has committed any follies, I renounce her,
Title:  I abjure her, I curse her!"
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!" said Athos to the commissary, "if you have no more need of
Title:  me, send me somewhere.  Your Monsieur Bonacieux is very
Title:  tiresome."
Title:  
Title:  The commissary designated by the same gesture Athos and
Title:  Bonacieux, "Let them be guarded more closely than ever."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," said Athos, with his habitual calmness, "if it be
Title:  Monsieur d'Artagnan who is concerned in this matter, I do not
Title:  perceive how I can take his place."
Title:  
Title:  "Do as I bade you," cried the commissary, "and preserve absolute
Title:  secrecy.  You understand!"
Title:  
Title:  Athos shrugged his shoulders, and followed his guards silently,
Title:  while M. Bonacieux uttered lamentations enough to break the heart
Title:  of a tiger.
Title:  
Title:  They locked the mercer in the same dungeon where he had passed
Title:  the night, and left him to himself during the day.  Bonacieux
Title:  wept all day, like a true mercer, not being at all a military
Title:  man, as he himself informed us.  In the evening, about nine
Title:  o'clock, at the moment he had made up his mind to go to bed, he
Title:  heard steps in his corridor.  These steps drew near to his
Title:  dungeon, the door was thrown open, and the guards appeared.
Title:  
Title:  "Follow me," said an officer, who came up behind the guards.
Title:  
Title:  "Follow you!" cried Bonacieux, "follow you at this hour!  Where,
Title:  my God?"
Title:  
Title:  "Where we have orders to lead you."
Title:  
Title:  "But that is not an answer."
Title:  
Title:  "It is, nevertheless, the only one we can give."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my God, my God!" murmured the poor mercer, "now, indeed, I
Title:  am lost!"  And he followed the guards who came for him,
Title:  mechanically and without resistance.
Title:  
Title:  He passed along the same corridor as before, crossed one court,
Title:  then a second side of a building; at length, at the gate of the
Title:  entrance court he found a carriage surrounded by four guards on
Title:  horseback.  They made him enter this carriage, the officer placed
Title:  himself by his side, the door was locked, and they were left in a
Title:  rolling prison.  The carriage was put in motion as slowly as a
Title:  funeral car.  Through the closely fastened windows the prisoner
Title:  could perceive the houses and the pavement, that was all; but,
Title:  true Parisian as he was, Bonacieux could recognize every street
Title:  by the milestones, the signs, and the lamps.  At the moment of
Title:  arriving at St. Paul--the spot where such as were condemned at
Title:  the Bastille were executed--he was near fainting and crossed
Title:  himself twice.  He thought the carriage was about to stop there.
Title:  The carriage, however, passed on.
Title:  
Title:  Farther on, a still greater terror seized him on passing by the
Title:  cemetery of St. Jean, where state criminals were buried.  One
Title:  thing, however, reassured him; he remembered that before they
Title:  were buried their heads were generally cut off, and he felt that
Title:  his head was still on his shoulders.  But when he saw the
Title:  carriage take the way to La Greve, when he perceived the pointed
Title:  roof of the Hotel de Ville, and the carriage passed under the
Title:  arcade, he believed it was over with him.  He wished to confess
Title:  to the officer, and upon his refusal, uttered such pitiable cries
Title:  that the officer told him that if he continued to deafen him
Title:  thus, he should put a gag in his mouth.
Title:  
Title:  This measure somewhat reassured Bonacieux.  If they meant to
Title:  execute him at La Greve, it could scarcely be worth while to gag
Title:  him, as they had nearly reached the place of execution.  Indeed,
Title:  the carriage crossed the fatal spot without stopping.  There
Title:  remained, then, no other place to fear but the Traitor's Cross;
Title:  the carriage was taking the direct road to it.
Title:  
Title:  This time there was no longer any doubt; it was at the Traitor's
Title:  Cross that lesser criminals were executed.  Bonacieux had
Title:  flattered himself in believing himself worthy of St. Paul or of
Title:  the Place de Greve; it was at the Traitor's Cross that his
Title:  journey and his destiny were about to end!  He could not yet see
Title:  that dreadful cross, but he felt somehow as if it were coming to
Title:  meet him.  When he was within twenty paces of it, he heard a
Title:  noise of people and the carriage stopped.  This was more than
Title:  poor Bonacieux could endure, depressed as he was by the
Title:  successive emotions which he had experienced; he uttered a feeble
Title:  groan which night have been taken for the last sigh of a dying
Title:  man, and fainted.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  14  THE MAN OF MEUNG
Title:  
Title:  The crowd was caused, not by the expectation of a man to be
Title:  hanged, but by the contemplation of a man who was hanged.
Title:  
Title:  The carriage, which had been stopped for a minute, resumed its
Title:  way, passed through the crowd, threaded the Rue St. Honore,
Title:  turned into the Rue des Bons Enfants, and stopped before a low
Title:  door.
Title:  
Title:  The door opened; two guards received Bonacieux in their arms from
Title:  the officer who supported him.  They carried him through an
Title:  alley, up a flight of stairs, and deposited him in an
Title:  antechamber.
Title:  
Title:  All these movements had been effected mechanically, as far as he
Title:  was concerned.  He had walked as one walks in a dream; he had a
Title:  glimpse of objects as through a fog.  His ears had perceived
Title:  sounds without comprehending them; he might have been executed at
Title:  that moment without his making a single gesture in his own
Title:  defense or uttering a cry to implore mercy.
Title:  
Title:  He remained on the bench, with his back leaning against the wall
Title:  and his hands hanging down, exactly on the spot where the guards
Title:  placed him.
Title:  
Title:  On looking around him, however, as he could perceive no
Title:  threatening object, as nothing indicated that he ran any real
Title:  danger, as the bench was comfortably covered with a well-stuffed
Title:  cushion, as the wall was ornamented with a beautiful Cordova
Title:  leather, and as large red damask curtains, fastened back by gold
Title:  clasps, floated before the window, he perceived by degrees that
Title:  his fear was exaggerated, and he began to turn his head to the
Title:  right and the left, upward and downward.
Title:  
Title:  At this movement, which nobody opposed, he resumed a little
Title:  courage, and ventured to draw up one leg and then the other.  At
Title:  length, with the help of his two hands he lifted himself from the
Title:  bench, and found himself on his feet.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment an officer with a pleasant face opened a door,
Title:  continued to exchange some words with a person in the next
Title:  chamber and then came up to the prisoner.  "Is your name
Title:  Bonacieux?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, Monsieur Officer," stammered the mercer, more dead than
Title:  alive, "at your service."
Title:  
Title:  "Come in," said the officer.
Title:  
Title:  And he moved out of the way to let the mercer pass.  The latter
Title:  obeyed without reply, and entered the chamber, where he appeared
Title:  to be expected.
Title:  
Title:  It was a large cabinet, close and stifling, with the walls
Title:  furnished with arms offensive and defensive, and in which there
Title:  was already a fire, although it was scarcely the end of the month
Title:  of September.  A square table, covered with books and papers,
Title:  upon which was unrolled an immense plan of the city of La
Title:  Rochelle, occupied the center of the room.
Title:  
Title:  Standing before the chimney was a man of middle height, of a
Title:  haughty, proud mien; with piercing eyes, a large brow, and a thin
Title:  face, which was made still longer by a ROYAL (or IMPERIAL, as it
Title:  is now called), surmounted by a pair of mustaches.  Although this
Title:  man was scarcely thirty-six or thirty-seven years of age, hair,
Title:  mustaches, and royal, all began to be gray.  This man, except a
Title:  sword, had all the appearance of a soldier; and his buff boots
Title:  still slightly covered with dust, indicated that he had been on
Title:  horseback in the course of the day.
Title:  
Title:  This man was Armand Jean Duplessis, Cardinal de Richelieu; not
Title:  such as he is now represented--broken down like an old man,
Title:  suffering like a martyr, his body bent, his voice failing, buried
Title:  in a large armchair as in an anticipated tomb; no longer living
Title:  but by the strength of his genius, and no longer maintaining the
Title:  struggle with Europe but by the eternal application of his
Title:  thoughts--but such as he really was at this period; that is to
Title:  say, an active and gallant cavalier, already weak of body, but
Title:  sustained by that moral power which made of him one of the most
Title:  extraordinary men that ever lived, preparing, after having
Title:  supported the Duc de Nevers in his duchy of Mantua, after having
Title:  taken Nimes, Castres, and Uzes, to drive the English from the
Title:  Isle of Re and lay siege to La Rochelle.
Title:  
Title:  At first sight, nothing denoted the cardinal; and it was
Title:  impossible for those who did not know his face to guess in whose
Title:  presence they were.
Title:  
Title:  The poor mercer remained standing at the door, while the eyes of
Title:  the personage we have just described were fixed upon him, and
Title:  appeared to wish to penetrate even into the depths of the past.
Title:  
Title:  "Is this that Bonacieux?" asked he, after a moment of silence.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur," replied the officer.
Title:  
Title:  "That's well.  Give me those papers, and leave us."
Title:  
Title:  The officer took from the table the papers pointed out, gave them
Title:  to him who asked for them, bowed to the ground, and retired.
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux recognized in these papers his interrogatories of the
Title:  Bastille.  From time to time the man by the chimney raised his
Title:  eyes from the writings, and plunged them like poniards into the
Title:  heart of the poor mercer.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of ten minutes of reading and ten seconds of
Title:  examination, the cardinal was satisfied.
Title:  
Title:  "That head has never conspired," murmured he, "but it matters
Title:  not; we will see."
Title:  
Title:  "You are accused of high treason," said the cardinal, slowly.
Title:  
Title:  "So I have been told already, monseigneur," cried Bonacieux,
Title:  giving his interrogator the title he had heard the officer give
Title:  him, "but I swear to you that I know nothing about it."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal repressed a smile.
Title:  
Title:  "You have conspired with your wife, with Madame de Chevreuse, and
Title:  with my Lord Duke of Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed, monseigneur," responded the mercer, "I have heard her
Title:  pronounce all those names."
Title:  
Title:  "And on what occasion?"
Title:  
Title:  "She said that the Cardinal de Richelieu had drawn the Duke of
Title:  Buckingham to Paris to ruin him and to ruin the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "She said that?" cried the cardinal, with violence.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur, but I told her she was wrong to talk about
Title:  such things; and that his Eminence was incapable--"
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue!  You are stupid," replied the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "That's exactly what my wife said, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know who carried off your wife?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "You have suspicions, nevertheless?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur; but these suspicions appeared to be
Title:  disagreeable to Monsieur the Commissary, and I no longer have
Title:  them."
Title:  
Title:  "Your wife has escaped.  Did you know that?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monseigneur.  I learned it since I have been in prison, and
Title:  that from the conversation of Monsieur the Commissary--an amiable
Title:  man."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal repressed another smile.
Title:  
Title:  "Then you are ignorant of what has become of your wife since her
Title:  flight."
Title:  
Title:  "Absolutely, monseigneur; but she has most likely returned to the
Title:  Louvre."
Title:  
Title:  "At one o'clock this morning she had not returned."
Title:  
Title:  "My God!  What can have become of her, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "We shall know, be assured.  Nothing is concealed from the
Title:  cardinal; the cardinal knows everything."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case, monseigneur, do you believe the cardinal will be
Title:  so kind as to tell me what has become of my wife?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps he may; but you must, in the first place, reveal to the
Title:  cardinal all you know of your wife's relations with Madame de
Title:  Chevreuse."
Title:  
Title:  "But, monseigneur, I know nothing about them; I have never seen
Title:  her."
Title:  
Title:  "When you went to fetch your wife from the Louvre, did you always
Title:  return directly home?"
Title:  
Title:  "Scarcely ever; she had business to transact with linen drapers,
Title:  to whose houses I conducted her."
Title:  
Title:  "And how many were there of these linen drapers?"
Title:  
Title:  "Two, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "And where did they live?"
Title:  
Title:  "One in Rue de Vaugirard, the other Rue de la Harpe."
Title:  
Title:  "Did you go into these houses with her?"
Title:  
Title:  "Never, monseigneur; I waited at the door."
Title:  
Title:  "And what excuse did she give you for entering all alone?"
Title:  
Title:  "She gave me none; she told me to wait, and I waited."
Title:  
Title:  "You are a very complacent husband, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux,"
Title:  said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "He calls me his dear Monsieur," said the mercer to himself.
Title:  "PESTE!  Matters are going all right."
Title:  
Title:  "Should you know those doors again?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know the numbers?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "What are they?"
Title:  
Title:  "No. 25 in the Rue de Vaugirard; 75 in the Rue de la Harpe."
Title:  
Title:  "That's well," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  At these words he took up a silver bell, and rang it; the officer
Title:  entered.
Title:  
Title:  "Go," said he, in a subdued voice, "and find Rochefort.  Tell him
Title:  to come to me immediately, if he has returned."
Title:  
Title:  "The count is here," said the officer, "and requests to speak
Title:  with your Eminence instantly."
Title:  
Title:  "Let him come in, then!" said the cardinal, quickly.
Title:  
Title:  The officer sprang out of the apartment with that alacrity which
Title:  all the servants of the cardinal displayed in obeying him.
Title:  
Title:  "To your Eminence!" murmured Bonacieux, rolling his eyes round in
Title:  astonishment.
Title:  
Title:  Five seconds has scarcely elapsed after the disappearance of the
Title:  officer, when the door opened, and a new personage entered.
Title:  
Title:  "It is he!" cried Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "He!  What he?" asked the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "The man who abducted my wife."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal rang a second time.  The officer reappeared.
Title:  
Title:  "Place this man in the care of his guards again, and let him wait
Title:  till I send for him."
Title:  
Title:  "No, monseigneur, no, it is not he!" cried Bonacieux; "no, I was
Title:  deceived.  This is quite another man, and does not resemble him
Title:  at all.  Monsieur is, I am sure, an honest man."
Title:  
Title:  "Take away that fool!" said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  The officer took Bonacieux by the arm, and led him into the
Title:  antechamber, where he found his two guards.
Title:  
Title:  The newly introduced personage followed Bonacieux impatiently
Title:  with his eyes till he had gone out; and the moment the door
Title:  closed, "They have seen each other;" said he, approaching the
Title:  cardinal eagerly.
Title:  
Title:  "Who?" asked his Eminence.
Title:  
Title:  "He and she."
Title:  
Title:  "The queen and the duke?" cried Richelieu.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Where?"
Title:  
Title:  "At the Louvre."
Title:  
Title:  "Are you sure of it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perfectly sure."
Title:  
Title:  "Who told you of it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Madame de Lannoy, who is devoted to your Eminence, as you know."
Title:  
Title:  "Why did she not let me know sooner?"
Title:  
Title:  "Whether by chance or mistrust, the queen made Madame de Surgis
Title:  sleep in her chamber, and detained her all day."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, we are beaten!  Now let us try to take our revenge."
Title:  
Title:  "I will assist you with all my heart, monseigneur; be assured of
Title:  that."
Title:  
Title:  "How did it come about?"
Title:  
Title:  "At half past twelve the queen was with her women--"
Title:  
Title:  "Where?"
Title:  
Title:  "In her bedchamber--"
Title:  
Title:  "Go on."
Title:  
Title:  "When someone came and brought her a handkerchief from her
Title:  laundress."
Title:  
Title:  "And then?"
Title:  
Title:  "The queen immediately exhibited strong emotion; and despite the
Title:  rouge with which her face was covered evidently turned pale--"
Title:  
Title:  "And then, and then?"
Title:  
Title:  "She then arose, and with altered voice, 'Ladies,' said she,
Title:  'wait for me ten minutes, I shall soon return.' She then opened
Title:  the door of her alcove, and went out."
Title:  
Title:  "Why did not Madame de Lannoy come and inform you instantly?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing was certain; besides, her Majesty had said, 'Ladies,
Title:  wait for me,' and she did not dare to disobey the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "How long did the queen remain out of the chamber?"
Title:  
Title:  "Three-quarters of an hour."
Title:  
Title:  "None of her women accompanied her?"
Title:  
Title:  "Only Donna Estafania."
Title:  
Title:  "Did she afterward return?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but only to take a little rosewood casket, with her cipher
Title:  upon it, and went out again immediately."
Title:  
Title:  "And when she finally returned, did she bring that casket with
Title:  her?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "Does Madame de Lannoy know what was in that casket?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; the diamond studs which his Majesty gave the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "And she came back without this casket?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame de Lannoy, then, is of opinion that she gave them to
Title:  Buckingham?"
Title:  
Title:  "She is sure of it."
Title:  
Title:  "How can she be so?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the course of the day Madame de Lannoy, in her quality of
Title:  tire-woman of the queen, looked for this casket, appeared uneasy
Title:  at not finding it, and at length asked information of the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "And then the queen?"
Title:  
Title:  "The queen became exceedingly red, and replied that having in the
Title:  evening broken one of those studs, she had sent it to her
Title:  goldsmith to be repaired."
Title:  
Title:  "He must be called upon, and so ascertain if the thing be true or
Title:  not."
Title:  
Title:  "I have just been with him."
Title:  
Title:  "And the goldsmith?"
Title:  
Title:  "The goldsmith has heard nothing of it."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, well!  Rochefort, all is not lost; and perhaps--perhaps
Title:  everything is for the best."
Title:  
Title:  "The fact is that I do not doubt your Eminence's genius--"
Title:  
Title:  "Will repair the blunders of his agent--is that it?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is exactly what I was going to say, if your Eminence had
Title:  let me finish my sentence."
Title:  
Title:  "Meanwhile, do you know where the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the
Title:  Duke of Buckingham are now concealed?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monseigneur; my people could tell me nothing on that head."
Title:  
Title:  "But I know."
Title:  
Title:  "You, monseigneur?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; or at least I guess.  They were, one in the Rue de
Title:  Vaugirard, No. 25; the other in the Rue de la Harpe, No. 75."
Title:  
Title:  "Does your Eminence command that they both be instantly
Title:  arrested?"
Title:  
Title:  "It will be too late; they will be gone."
Title:  
Title:  "But still, we can make sure that they are so."
Title:  
Title:  "Take ten men of my Guardsmen, and search the two houses
Title:  thoroughly."
Title:  
Title:  "Instantly, monseigneur."  And Rochefort went hastily out of the
Title:  apartment.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal being left alone, reflected for an instant and then
Title:  rang the bell a third time.  The same officer appeared.
Title:  
Title:  "Bring the prisoner in again," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  M. Bonacieux was introduced afresh, and upon a sign from the
Title:  cardinal, the officer retired.
Title:  
Title:  "You have deceived me!" said the cardinal, sternly.
Title:  
Title:  "I," cried Bonacieux, "I deceive your Eminence!"
Title:  
Title:  "Your wife, in going to Rue de Vaugirard and Rue de la Harpe, did
Title:  not go to find linen drapers."
Title:  
Title:  "Then why did she go, just God?"
Title:  
Title:  "She went to meet the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," cried Bonacieux, recalling all his remembrances of the
Title:  circumstances, "yes, that's it.  Your Eminence is right.  I told
Title:  my wife several times that it was surprising that linen drapers
Title:  should live in such houses as those, in houses that had no signs;
Title:  but she always laughed at me.  Ah, monseigneur!" continued
Title:  Bonacieux, throwing himself at his Eminence's feet, "ah, how
Title:  truly you are the cardinal, the great cardinal, the man of genius
Title:  whom all the world reveres!"
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal, however contemptible might be the triumph gained
Title:  over so vulgar a being as Bonacieux, did not the less enjoy it
Title:  for an instant; then, almost immediately, as if a fresh thought
Title:  has occurred, a smile played upon his lips, and he said, offering
Title:  his hand to the mercer, "Rise, my friend, you are a worthy man."
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal has touched me with his hand!  I have touched the
Title:  hand of the great man!" cried Bonacieux.  "The great man has
Title:  called me his friend!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, my friend, yes," said the cardinal, with that paternal tone
Title:  which he sometimes knew how to assume, but which deceived none
Title:  who knew him; "and as you have been unjustly suspected, well, you
Title:  must be indemnified.  Here, take this purse of a hundred
Title:  pistoles, and pardon me."
Title:  
Title:  "I pardon you, monseigneur!" said Bonacieux, hesitating to take
Title:  the purse, fearing, doubtless, that this pretended gift was but a
Title:  pleasantry.  "But you are able to have me arrested, you are able
Title:  to have me tortured, you are able to have me hanged; you are the
Title:  master, and I could not have the least word to say.  Pardon you,
Title:  monseigneur!  You cannot mean that!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, you are generous in this matter.
Title:  I see it and I thank you for it.  Thus, then, you will take this
Title:  bag, and you will go away without being too malcontent."
Title:  
Title:  "I go away enchanted."
Title:  
Title:  "Farewell, then, or rather, AU REVOIR!"
Title:  
Title:  And the cardinal made him a sign with his hand, to which
Title:  Bonacieux replied by bowing to the ground.  He then went out
Title:  backward, and when he was in the antechamber the cardinal heard
Title:  him, in his enthusiasm, crying aloud, "Long life to the
Title:  Monseigneur!  Long life to his Eminence!  Long life to the great
Title:  cardinal!"  The cardinal listened with a smile to this vociferous
Title:  manifestation of the feelings of M. Bonacieux; and then, when
Title:  Bonacieux's cries were no longer audible, "Good!" said he, "that
Title:  man would henceforward lay down his life for me."  And the
Title:  cardinal began to examine with the greatest attention the map of
Title:  La Rochelle, which, as we have said, lay open on the desk,
Title:  tracing with a pencil the line in which the famous dyke was to
Title:  pass which, eighteen months later, shut up the port of the
Title:  besieged city.  As he was in the deepest of his strategic
Title:  meditations, the door opened, and Rochefort returned.
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" said the cardinal, eagerly, rising with a promptitude
Title:  which proved the degree of importance he attached to the
Title:  commission with which he had charged the count.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said the latter, "a young woman of about twenty-six or
Title:  twenty-eight years of age, and a man of from thirty-five to
Title:  forty, have indeed lodged at the two houses pointed out by your
Title:  Eminence; but the woman left last night, and the man this
Title:  morning."
Title:  
Title:  "It was they!" cried the cardinal, looking at the clock; "and now
Title:  it is too late to have them pursued.  The duchess is at Tours,
Title:  and the duke at Boulogne.  It is in London they must be found."
Title:  
Title:  "What are your Eminence's orders?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not a word of what has passed.  Let the queen remain in perfect
Title:  security; let her be ignorant that we know her secret.  Let her
Title:  believe that we are in search of some conspiracy or other.  Send
Title:  me the keeper of the seals, Seguier."
Title:  
Title:  "And that man, what has your Eminence done with him?"
Title:  
Title:  "What man?" asked the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "That Bonacieux."
Title:  
Title:  "I have done with him all that could be done.  I have made him a
Title:  spy upon his wife."
Title:  
Title:  The Comte de Rochefort bowed like a man who acknowledges the
Title:  superiority of the master as great, and retired.
Title:  
Title:  Left alone, the cardinal seated himself again and wrote a letter,
Title:  which he secured with his special seal.  Then he rang.  The
Title:  officer entered for the fourth time.
Title:  
Title:  "Tell Vitray to come to me," said he, "and tell him to get ready
Title:  for a journey."
Title:  
Title:  An instant after, the man he asked for was before him, booted and
Title:  spurred.
Title:  
Title:  "Vitray," said he, "you will go with all speed to London.  You
Title:  must not stop an instant on the way.  You will deliver this
Title:  letter to Milady.  Here is an order for two hundred pistoles;
Title:  call upon my treasurer and get the money.  You shall have as much
Title:  again if you are back within six days, and have executed your
Title:  commission well."
Title:  
Title:  The messenger, without replying a single word, bowed, took the
Title:  letter, with the order for the two hundred pistoles, and retired.
Title:  
Title:  Here is what the letter contained:
Title:  
Title:  MILADY, Be at the first ball at which the Duke of Buckingham
Title:  shall be present.  He will wear on his doublet twelve diamond
Title:  studs; get as near to him as you can, and cut off two.
Title:  
Title:  As soon as these studs shall be in your possession, inform me.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  15 MEN OF THE ROBE AND MEN OF THE SWORD
Title:  
Title:  On the day after these events had taken place, Athos not having
Title:  reappeared, M. de Treville was informed by d'Artagnan and Porthos
Title:  of the circumstance.  As to Aramis, he had asked for leave of
Title:  absence for five days, and was gone, it was said, to Rouen on
Title:  family business.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville was the father of his soldiers.  The lowest or the
Title:  least known of them, as soon as he assumed the uniform of the
Title:  company, was as sure of his aid and support as if he had been his
Title:  own brother.
Title:  
Title:  He repaired, then, instantly to the office of the LIEUTENANT-
Title:  CRIMINEL.  The officer who commanded the post of the
Title:  Red Cross was sent for, and by successive inquiries they learned
Title:  that Athos was then lodged in the Fort l'Eveque.
Title:  
Title:  Athos had passed through all the examinations we have seen
Title:  Bonacieux undergo.
Title:  
Title:  We were present at the scene in which the two captives were
Title:  confronted with each other.  Athos, who had till that time said
Title:  nothing for fear that d'Artagnan, interrupted in his turn, should
Title:  not have the time necessary, from this moment declared that his
Title:  name was Athos, and not d'Artagnan.  He added that he did not
Title:  know either M. or Mme. Bonacieux; that he had never spoken to the
Title:  one or the other; that he had come, at about ten o'clock in the
Title:  evening, to pay a visit to his friend M. d'Artagnan, but that
Title:  till that hour he had been at M. de Treville's, where he had
Title:  dined.  "Twenty witnesses," added he, "could attest the fact";
Title:  and he named several distinguished gentlemen, and among them was
Title:  M. le Duc de la Tremouille.
Title:  
Title:  The second commissary was as much bewildered as the first had
Title:  been by the simple and firm declaration of the Musketeer, upon
Title:  whom he was anxious to take the revenge which men of the robe
Title:  like at all times to gain over men of the sword; but the name of
Title:  M. de Treville, and that of M. de la Tremouille, commanded a
Title:  little reflection.
Title:  
Title:  Athos was then sent to the cardinal; but unfortunately the
Title:  cardinal was at the Louvre with the king.
Title:  
Title:  It was precisely at this moment that M. de Treville, on leaving
Title:  the residence of the LIEUTENANT-CRIMINEL and the governor of the
Title:  Fort l'Eveque without being able to find Athos, arrived at the
Title:  palace.
Title:  
Title:  As captain of the Musketeers, M. de Treville had the right of
Title:  entry at all times.
Title:  
Title:  It is well known how violent the king's prejudices were against
Title:  the queen, and how carefully these prejudices were kept up by the
Title:  cardinal, who in affairs of intrigue mistrusted women infinitely
Title:  more than men.  One of the grand causes of this prejudice was the
Title:  friendship of Anne of Austria for Mme. de Chevreuse.  These two
Title:  women gave him more uneasiness than the war with Spain, the
Title:  quarrel with England, or the embarrassment of the finances.  In
Title:  his eyes and to his conviction, Mme. de Chevreuse not only served
Title:  the queen in her political intrigues, but, what tormented him
Title:  still more, in her amorous intrigues.
Title:  
Title:  At the first word the cardinal spoke of Mme. de Chevreuse--who,
Title:  though exiled to Tours and believed to be in that city, had come
Title:  to Paris, remained there five days, and outwitted the police--the
Title:  king flew into a furious passion.  Capricious and unfaithful, the
Title:  king wished to be called Louis the Just and Louis the Chaste.
Title:  Posterity will find a difficulty in understanding this character,
Title:  which history explains only by facts and never by reason.
Title:  
Title:  But when the cardinal added that not only Mme. de Chevreuse had
Title:  been in Paris, but still further, that the queen had renewed with
Title:  her one of those mysterious correspondences which at that time
Title:  was named a CABAL; when he affirmed that he, the cardinal, was
Title:  about to unravel the most closely twisted thread of this
Title:  intrigue; that at the moment of arresting in the very act, with
Title:  all the proofs about her, the queen's emissary to the exiled
Title:  duchess, a Musketeer had dared to interrupt the course of justice
Title:  violently, by falling sword in hand upon the honest men of the
Title:  law, charged with investigating impartially the whole affair in
Title:  order to place it before the eyes of the king--Louis XIII could
Title:  not contain himself, and he made a step toward the queen's
Title:  apartment with that pale and mute indignation which, when in
Title:  broke out, led this prince to the commission of the most pitiless
Title:  cruelty.  And yet, in all this, the cardinal had not yet said a
Title:  word about the Duke of Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  At this instant M. de Treville entered, cool, polite, and in
Title:  irreproachable costume.
Title:  
Title:  Informed of what had passed by the presence of the cardinal and
Title:  the alteration in the king's countenance, M. de Treville felt
Title:  himself something like Samson before the Philistines.
Title:  
Title:  Louis XIII had already placed his hand on the knob of the door;
Title:  at the noise of M. de Treville's entrance he turned round.  "You
Title:  arrive in good time, monsieur," said the king, who, when his
Title:  passions were raised to a certain point, could not dissemble; "I
Title:  have learned some fine things concerning your Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said Treville, coldly, "I have some pretty things
Title:  to tell your Majesty concerning these gownsmen."
Title:  
Title:  "What?" said the king, with hauteur.
Title:  
Title:  "I have the honor to inform your Majesty," continued M. de
Title:  Treville, in the same tone, "that a party of PROCUREURS,
Title:  commissaries, and men of the police--very estimable people, but
Title:  very inveterate, as it appears, against the uniform--have taken
Title:  upon themselves to arrest in a house, to lead away through the
Title:  open street, and throw into the Fort l'Eveque, all upon an order
Title:  which they have refused to show me, one of my, or rather your
Title:  Musketeers, sire, of irreproachable conduct, of an almost
Title:  illustrious reputation, and whom your Majesty knows favorably,
Title:  Monsieur Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "Athos," said the king, mechanically; "yes, certainly I know that
Title:  name."
Title:  
Title:  "Let your Majesty remember," said Treville, "that Monsieur Athos
Title:  is the Musketeer who, in the annoying duel which you are
Title:  acquainted with, had the misfortune to wound Monsieur de Cahusac
Title:  so seriously.  A PROPOS, monseigneur," continued Treville.
Title:  Addressing the cardinal, "Monsieur de Cahusac is quite recovered,
Title:  is he not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Thank you," said the cardinal, biting his lips with anger.
Title:  
Title:  "Athos, then, went to pay a visit to one of his friends absent at
Title:  the time," continued Treville, "to a young Bearnais, a cadet in
Title:  his Majesty's Guards, the company of Monsieur Dessessart, but
Title:  scarcely had he arrived at his friend's and taken up a book,
Title:  while waiting his return, when a mixed crowd of bailiffs and
Title:  soldiers came and laid siege to the house, broke open several
Title:  doors--"
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal made the king a sign, which signified, "That was on
Title:  account of the affair about which I spoke to you."
Title:  
Title:  "We all know that," interrupted the king; "for all that was done
Title:  for our service."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said Treville, "it was also for your Majesty's service
Title:  that one of my Musketeers, who was innocent, has been seized,
Title:  that he has been placed between two guards like a malefactor, and
Title:  that this gallant man, who has ten times shed his blood in your
Title:  Majesty's service and is ready to shed it again, has been paraded
Title:  through the midst of an insolent populace?"
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!" said the king, who began to be shaken, "was it so
Title:  managed?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Treville," said the cardinal, with the greatest
Title:  phlegm, "does not tell your Majesty that this innocent Musketeer,
Title:  this gallant man, had only an hour before attacked, sword in
Title:  hand, four commissaries of inquiry, who were delegated by myself
Title:  to examine into an affair of the highest importance."
Title:  
Title:  "I defy your Eminence to prove it," cried Treville, with his
Title:  Gascon freedom and military frankness; "for one hour before,
Title:  Monsieur Athos, who, I will confide it to your Majesty, is really
Title:  a man of the highest quality, did me the honor after having dined
Title:  with me to be conversing in the saloon of my hotel, with the Duc
Title:  de la Tremouille and the Comte de Chalus, who happened to be
Title:  there."
Title:  
Title:  The king looked at the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "A written examination attests it," said the cardinal, replying
Title:  aloud to the mute interrogation of his Majesty; "and the ill-
Title:  treated people have drawn up the following, which I have the
Title:  honor to present to your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "And is the written report of the gownsmen to be placed in
Title:  comparison with the word of honor of a swordsman?" replied
Title:  Treville haughtily.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come, Treville, hold your tongue," said the king.
Title:  
Title:  "If his Eminence entertains any suspicion against one of my
Title:  Musketeers," said Treville, "the justice of Monsieur the Cardinal
Title:  is so well known that I demand an inquiry."
Title:  
Title:  "In the house in which the judicial inquiry was made," continued
Title:  the impassive cardinal, "there lodges, I believe, a young
Title:  Bearnais, a friend of the Musketeer."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Eminence means Monsieur d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "I mean a young man whom you patronize, Monsieur de Treville."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, your Eminence, it is the same."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you not suspect this young man of having given bad counsel?"
Title:  
Title:  "To Athos, to a man double his age?" interrupted Treville.  "No,
Title:  monseigneur.  Besides, d'Artagnan passed the evening with me."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said the cardinal, "everybody seems to have passed the
Title:  evening with you."
Title:  
Title:  "Does your Eminence doubt my word?" said Treville, with a brow
Title:  flushed with anger.
Title:  
Title:  "No, God forbid," said the cardinal; "only, at what hour was he with you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, as to that I can speak positively, your Eminence; for as he
Title:  came in I remarked that it was but half past nine by the clock,
Title:  although I had believed it to be later."
Title:  
Title:  "At what hour did he leave your hotel?"
Title:  
Title:  "At half past ten--an hour after the event."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," replied the cardinal, who could not for an instant
Title:  suspect the loyalty of Treville, and who felt that the victory
Title:  was escaping him, "well, but Athos WAS taken in the house in the
Title:  Rue des Fossoyeurs."
Title:  
Title:  "Is one friend forbidden to visit another, or a Musketeer of my
Title:  company to fraternize with a Guard of Dessessart's company?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, when the house where he fraternizes is suspected."
Title:  
Title:  "That house is suspected, Treville," said the king; "perhaps you
Title:  did not know it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed, sire, I did not.  The house may be suspected; but I deny
Title:  that it is so in the part of it inhabited my Monsieur d'Artagnan,
Title:  for I can affirm, sire, if I can believe what he says, that there
Title:  does not exist a more devoted servant of your Majesty, or a more
Title:  profound admirer of Monsieur the Cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Was it not this d'Artagnan who wounded Jussac one day, in that
Title:  unfortunate encounter which took place near the Convent of the
Title:  Carmes-Dechausses?" asked the king, looking at the cardinal, who
Title:  colored with vexation.
Title:  
Title:  "And the next day, Bernajoux. Yes, sire, yes, it is the same; and
Title:  your Majesty has a good memory."
Title:  
Title:  "Come, how shall we decide?" said the king.
Title:  
Title:  "That concerns your Majesty more than me," said the cardinal.  "I
Title:  should affirm the culpability."
Title:  
Title:  "And I deny it," said Treville.  "But his Majesty has judges, and
Title:  these judges will decide."
Title:  
Title:  "That is best," said the king.  "Send the case before the judges;
Title:  it is their business to judge, and they shall judge."
Title:  
Title:  "Only," replied Treville, "it is a sad thing that in the
Title:  unfortunate times in which we live, the purest life, the most
Title:  incontestable virtue, cannot exempt a man from infamy and
Title:  persecution.  The army, I will answer for it, will be but little
Title:  pleased at being exposed to rigorous treatment on account of
Title:  police affairs."
Title:  
Title:  The expression was imprudent; but M. de Treville launched it with
Title:  knowledge of his cause.  He was desirous of an explosion, because
Title:  in that case the mine throws forth fire, and fire enlightens.
Title:  
Title:  "Police affairs!" cried the king, taking up Treville's words,
Title:  "police affairs!  And what do you know about them, Monsieur?
Title:  Meddle with your Musketeers, and do not annoy me in this way.  It
Title:  appears, according to your account, that if by mischance a
Title:  Musketeer is arrested, France is in danger.  What a noise about a
Title:  Musketeer!  I would arrest ten of them, VENTREBLEU, a hundred,
Title:  even, all the company, and I would not allow a whisper."
Title:  
Title:  "From the moment they are suspected by your Majesty," said
Title:  Treville, "the Musketeers are guilty; therefore, you see me
Title:  prepared to surrender my sword--for after having accused my
Title:  soldiers, there can be no doubt that Monsieur the Cardinal will
Title:  end by accusing me.  It is best to constitute myself at once a
Title:  prisoner with Athos, who is already arrested, and with
Title:  d'Artagnan, who most probably will be."
Title:  
Title:  "Gascon-headed man, will you have done?" said the king.
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," replied Treville, without lowering his voice in the
Title:  least, "either order my Musketeer to be restored to me, or let
Title:  him be tried."
Title:  
Title:  "He shall be tried," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, so much the better; for in that case I shall demand of his
Title:  Majesty permission to plead for him."
Title:  
Title:  The king feared an outbreak.
Title:  
Title:  "If his Eminence," said he, "did not have personal motives--"
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal saw what the king was about to say and interrupted
Title:  him:
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon me," said he; "but the instant your Majesty considers me
Title:  a prejudiced judge, I withdraw."
Title:  
Title:  "Come," said the king, "will you swear, by my father, that Athos
Title:  was at your residence during the event and that he took no part
Title:  in it?"
Title:  
Title:  "By your glorious father, and by yourself, whom I love and
Title:  venerate above all the world, I swear it."
Title:  
Title:  "Be so kind as to reflect, sire," said the cardinal.  "If we
Title:  release the prisoner thus, we shall never know the truth."
Title:  
Title:  "Athos may always be found," replied Treville, "ready to answer,
Title:  when it shall please the gownsmen to interrogate him.  He will
Title:  not desert, Monsieur the Cardinal, be assured of that; I will
Title:  answer for him."
Title:  
Title:  "No, he will not desert," said the king; "he can always be found,
Title:  as Treville says.  Besides," added he, lowering his voice and
Title:  looking with a suppliant air at the cardinal, "let us give them
Title:  apparent security; that is policy."
Title:  
Title:  This policy of Louis XIII made Richelieu smile.
Title:  
Title:  "Order it as you please, sire; you possess the right of pardon."
Title:  
Title:  "The right of pardoning only applies to the guilty," said
Title:  Treville, who was determined to have the last word, "and my
Title:  Musketeer is innocent.  It is not mercy, then, that you are about
Title:  to accord, sire, it is justice."
Title:  
Title:  "And he is in the Fort l'Eveque?" said the king.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire, in solitary confinement, in a dungeon, like the
Title:  lowest criminal."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" murmured the king; "what must be done?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sign an order for his release, and all will be said," replied
Title:  the cardinal.  "I believe with your Majesty that Monsieur de
Title:  Treville's guarantee is more than sufficient."
Title:  
Title:  Treville bowed very respectfully, with a joy that was not unmixed
Title:  with fear; he would have preferred an obstinate resistance on the
Title:  part of the cardinal to this sudden yielding.
Title:  
Title:  The king signed the order for release, and Treville carried it
Title:  away without delay.  As he was about to leave the presence, the
Title:  cardinal gave him a friendly smile, and said, "A perfect harmony
Title:  reigns, sire, between the leaders and the soldiers of your
Title:  Musketeers, which must be profitable for the service and
Title:  honorable to all."
Title:  
Title:  "He will play me some dog's trick or other, and that
Title:  immediately," said Treville.  "One has never the last word with
Title:  such a man.  But let us be quick--the king may change his mind in
Title:  an hour; and at all events it is more difficult to replace a man
Title:  in the Fort l'Eveque or the Bastille who has got out, than to
Title:  keep a prisoner there who is in."
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville made his entrance triumphantly into the Fort
Title:  l'Eveque, whence he delivered the Musketeer, whose peaceful
Title:  indifference had not for a moment abandoned him.
Title:  
Title:  The first time he saw d'Artagnan, "You have come off well," said
Title:  he to him; "there is your Jussac thrust paid for.  There still
Title:  remains that of Bernajoux, but you must not be too confident."
Title:  
Title:  As to the rest, M. de Treville had good reason to mistrust the
Title:  cardinal and to think that all was not over, for scarcely had the
Title:  captain of the Musketeers closed the door after him, than his
Title:  Eminence said to the king, "Now that we are at length by
Title:  ourselves, we will, if your Majesty pleases, converse seriously.
Title:  Sire, Buckingham has been in Paris five days, and only left this
Title:  morning."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  16  IN WHICH M. SEGUIER, KEEPER OF THE SEALS, LOOKS MORE THAN
Title:  ONCE FOR THE BELL, IN ORDER TO RING IT, AS HE DID BEFORE
Title:  
Title:  It is impossible to form an idea of the impression these few
Title:  words made upon Louis XIII.  He grew pale and red alternately;
Title:  and the cardinal saw at once that he had recovered by a single
Title:  blow all the ground he had lost.
Title:  
Title:  "Buckingham in Paris!" cried he, "and why does he come?"
Title:  
Title:  "To conspire, no doubt, with your enemies, the Huguenots and the
Title:  Spaniards."
Title:  
Title:  "No, PARDIEU, no!  To conspire against my honor with Madame de
Title:  Chevreuse, Madame de Longueville, and the Condes."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, sire, what an idea!  The queen is too virtuous; and besides,
Title:  loves your Majesty too well."
Title:  
Title:  "Woman is weak, Monsieur Cardinal," said the king; "and as to
Title:  loving me much, I have my own opinion as to that love."
Title:  
Title:  "I not the less maintain," said the cardinal, "that the Duke of
Title:  Buckingham came to Paris for a project wholly political."
Title:  
Title:  "And I am sure that he came for quite another purpose, Monsieur
Title:  Cardinal; but if the queen be guilty, let her tremble!"
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed," said the cardinal, "whatever repugnance I may have to
Title:  directing my mind to such a treason, your Majesty compels me to
Title:  think of it.  Madame de Lannoy, whom, according to your Majesty's
Title:  command, I have frequently interrogated, told me this morning
Title:  that the night before last her Majesty sat up very late, that
Title:  this morning she wept much, and that she was writing all day."
Title:  
Title:  "That's it!" cried the king; "to him, no doubt.  Cardinal, I must
Title:  have the queen's papers."
Title:  
Title:  "But how to take them, sire?  It seems to me that it is neither
Title:  your Majesty nor myself who can charge himself with such a
Title:  mission."
Title:  
Title:  "How did they act with regard to the Marechale d'Ancre?" cried
Title:  the king, in the highest state of choler; "first her closets were
Title:  thoroughly searched, and then she herself."
Title:  
Title:  "The Marechale d'Ancre was no more than the Marechale d'Ancre. A
Title:  Florentine adventurer, sire, and that was all; while the august
Title:  spouse of your Majesty is Anne of Austria, Queen of France--that
Title:  is to say, one of the greatest princesses in the world."
Title:  
Title:  "She is not the less guilty, Monsieur Duke!  The more she has
Title:  forgotten the high position in which she was placed, the more
Title:  degrading is her fall.  Besides, I long ago determined to put an
Title:  end to all these petty intrigues of policy and love.  She has
Title:  near her a certain Laporte."
Title:  
Title:  "Who, I believe, is the mainspring of all this, I confess," said
Title:  the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "You think then, as I do, that she deceives me?" said the king.
Title:  
Title:  "I believe, and I repeat it to your Majesty, that the queen
Title:  conspires against the power of the king, but I have not said
Title:  against his honor."
Title:  
Title:  "And I--I tell you against both.  I tell you the queen does not
Title:  love me; I tell you she loves another; I tell you she loves that
Title:  infamous Buckingham!  Why did you not have him arrested while in
Title:  Paris?"
Title:  
Title:  "Arrest the Duke!  Arrest the prime minister of King Charles I!
Title:  Think of it, sire!  What a scandal!  And if the suspicions of
Title:  your Majesty, which I still continue to doubt, should prove to
Title:  have any foundation, what a terrible disclosure, what a fearful
Title:  scandal!"
Title:  
Title:  "But as he exposed himself like a vagabond or a thief, he should
Title:  have been--"
Title:  
Title:  Louis XIII stopped, terrified at what he was about to say, while
Title:  Richelieu, stretching out his neck, waited uselessly for the word
Title:  which had died on the lips of the king.
Title:  
Title:  "He should have been--?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing," said the king, "nothing.  But all the time he was in
Title:  Paris, you, of course, did not lose sight of him?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "Where did he lodge?"
Title:  
Title:  "Rue de la Harpe. No. 75."
Title:  
Title:  "Where is that?"
Title:  
Title:  "By the side of the Luxembourg."
Title:  
Title:  "And you are certain that the queen and he did not see each
Title:  other?"
Title:  
Title:  "I believe the queen to have too high a sense of her duty, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "But they have corresponded; it is to him that the queen has been
Title:  writing all the day.  Monsieur Duke, I must have those letters!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sire, notwithstanding--"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Duke, at whatever price it may be, I will have them."
Title:  
Title:  "I would, however, beg your Majesty to observe--"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you, then, also join in betraying me, Monsieur Cardinal, by
Title:  thus always opposing my will?  Are you also in accord with Spain
Title:  and England, with Madame de Chevreuse and the queen?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," replied the cardinal, sighing, "I believed myself secure
Title:  from such a suspicion."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Cardinal, you have heard me; I will have those
Title:  letters."
Title:  
Title:  "There is but one way."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that?"
Title:  
Title:  "That would be to charge Monsieur de Seguier, the keeper of the
Title:  seals, with this mission.  The matter enters completely into the
Title:  duties of the post."
Title:  
Title:  "Let him be sent for instantly."
Title:  
Title:  "He is most likely at my hotel.  I requested him to call, and
Title:  when I came to the Louvre I left orders if he came, to desire him
Title:  to wait."
Title:  
Title:  "Let him be sent for instantly."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Majesty's orders shall be executed; but--"
Title:  
Title:  "But what?"
Title:  
Title:  "But the queen will perhaps refuse to obey."
Title:  
Title:  "My orders?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, if she is ignorant that these orders come from the king."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, that she may have no doubt on that head, I will go and
Title:  inform her myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Majesty will not forget that I have done everything in my
Title:  power to prevent a rupture."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, Duke, yes, I know you are very indulgent toward the queen,
Title:  too indulgent, perhaps; we shall have occasion, I warn you, at
Title:  some future period to speak of that."
Title:  
Title:  "Whenever it shall please your Majesty; but I shall be always
Title:  happy and proud, sire, to sacrifice myself to the harmony which I
Title:  desire to see reign between you and the Queen of France."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well, Cardinal, very well; but, meantime, send for Monsieur
Title:  the Keeper of the Seals.  I will go to the queen."
Title:  
Title:  And Louis XIII, opening the door of communication, passed into
Title:  the corridor which led from his apartments to those of Anne of
Title:  Austria.
Title:  
Title:  The queen was in the midst of her women--Mme. de Guitaut, Mme. de
Title:  Sable, Mme. de Montbazon, and Mme. de Guemene.  In a corner was
Title:  the Spanish companion, Donna Estafania, who had followed her from
Title:  Madrid.  Mme. Guemene was reading aloud, and everybody was
Title:  listening to her with attention with the exception of the queen,
Title:  who had, on the contrary, desired this reading in order that she
Title:  might be able, while feigning to listen, to pursue the thread of
Title:  her own thoughts.
Title:  
Title:  These thoughts, gilded as they were by a last reflection of love,
Title:  were not the less sad.  Anne of Austria, deprived of the
