Title:  confidence of her husband, pursued by the hatred of the cardinal,
Title:  who could not pardon her for having repulsed a more tender
Title:  feeling, having before her eyes the example of the queen-mother
Title:  whom that hatred had tormented all her life--though Marie de
Title:  Medicis, if the memoirs of the time are to be believed, had begun
Title:  by according to the cardinal that sentiment which Anne of Austria
Title:  always refused him--Anne of Austria had seen her most devoted
Title:  servants fall around her, her most intimate confidants, her
Title:  dearest favorites.  Like those unfortunate persons endowed with a
Title:  fatal gift, she brought misfortune upon everything she touched.
Title:  Her friendship was a fatal sign which called down persecution.
Title:  Mme. de Chevreuse and Mme. de Bernet were exiled, and Laporte did
Title:  not conceal from his mistress that he expected to be arrested
Title:  every instant.
Title:  
Title:  It was at the moment when she was plunged in the deepest and
Title:  darkest of these reflections that the door of the chamber opened,
Title:  and the king entered.
Title:  
Title:  The reader hushed herself instantly.  All the ladies rose, and
Title:  there was a profound silence.  As to the king, he made no
Title:  demonstration of politeness, only stopping before the queen.
Title:  "Madame," said he, "you are about to receive a visit from the
Title:  chancellor, who will communicate certain matters to you with
Title:  which I have charged him."
Title:  
Title:  The unfortunate queen, who was constantly threatened with
Title:  divorce, exile, and trial even, turned pale under her rouge, and
Title:  could not refrain from saying, "But why this visit, sire?  What
Title:  can the chancellor have to say to me that your Majesty could not
Title:  say yourself?"
Title:  
Title:  The king turned upon his heel without reply, and almost at the
Title:  same instant the captain of the Guards, M. de Guitant, announced
Title:  the visit of the chancellor.
Title:  
Title:  When the chancellor appeared, the king had already gone out by
Title:  another door.
Title:  
Title:  The chancellor entered, half smiling, half blushing.  As we shall
Title:  probably meet with him again in the course of our history, it may
Title:  be well for our readers to be made at once acquainted with him.
Title:  
Title:  This chancellor was a pleasant man.  He was Des Roches le Masle,
Title:  canon of Notre Dame, who had formerly been valet of a bishop, who
Title:  introduced him to his Eminence as a perfectly devout man.  The
Title:  cardinal trusted him, and therein found his advantage.
Title:  
Title:  There are many stories related of him, and among them this.
Title:  After a wild youth, he had retired into a convent, there to
Title:  expiate, at least for some time, the follies of adolescence.  On
Title:  entering this holy place, the poor penitent was unable to shut
Title:  the door so close as to prevent the passions he fled from
Title:  entering with him.  He was incessantly attacked by them, and the
Title:  superior, to whom he had confided this misfortune, wishing as
Title:  much as in him lay to free him from them, had advised him, in
Title:  order to conjure away the tempting demon, to have recourse to the
Title:  bell rope, and ring with all his might.  At the denunciating
Title:  sound, the monks would be rendered aware that temptation was
Title:  besieging a brother, and all the community would go to prayers.
Title:  
Title:  This advice appeared good to the future chancellor.  He conjured
Title:  the evil spirit with abundance of prayers offered up by the
Title:  monks.  But the devil does not suffer himself to be easily
Title:  dispossessed from a place in which he has fixed his garrison.  In
Title:  proportion as they redoubled the exorcisms he redoubled the
Title:  temptations; so that day and night the bell was ringing full
Title:  swing, announcing the extreme desire for mortification which the
Title:  penitent experienced.
Title:  
Title:  The monks had no longer an instant of repose.  By day they did
Title:  nothing but ascend and descend the steps which led to the chapel;
Title:  at night, in addition to complines and matins, they were further
Title:  obliged to leap twenty times out of their beds and prostrate
Title:  themselves on the floor of their cells.
Title:  
Title:  It is not known whether it was the devil who gave way, or the
Title:  monks who grew tired; but within three months the penitent
Title:  reappeared in the world with the reputation of being the most
Title:  terrible POSSESSED that ever existed.
Title:  
Title:  On leaving the convent he entered into the magistracy, became
Title:  president on the place of his uncle, embraced the cardinal's
Title:  party, which did not prove want of sagacity, became chancellor,
Title:  served his Eminence with zeal in his hatred against the queen-
Title:  mother and his vengeance against Anne of Austria, stimulated the
Title:  judges in the affair of Calais, encouraged the attempts of M. de
Title:  Laffemas, chief gamekeeper of France; then, at length, invested
Title:  with the entire confidence of the cardinal--a confidence which he
Title:  had so well earned--he received the singular commission for the
Title:  execution of which he presented himself in the queen's
Title:  apartments.
Title:  
Title:  The queen was still standing when he entered; but scarcely had
Title:  she perceived him then she reseated herself in her armchair, and
Title:  made a sign to her women to resume their cushions and stools, and
Title:  with an air of supreme hauteur, said, "What do you desire,
Title:  monsieur, and with what object do you present yourself here?"
Title:  
Title:  "To make, madame, in the name of the king, and without prejudice
Title:  to the respect which I have the honor to owe to your Majesty a
Title:  close examination into all your papers."
Title:  
Title:  "How, monsieur, an investigation of my papers--mine!  Truly, this
Title:  is an indignity!"
Title:  
Title:  "Be kind enough to pardon me, madame; but in this circumstance I
Title:  am but the instrument which the king employs.  Has not his
Title:  Majesty just left you, and has he not himself asked you to
Title:  prepare for this visit?"
Title:  
Title:  "Search, then, monsieur!  I am a criminal, as it appears.
Title:  Estafania, give up the keys of my drawers and my desks."
Title:  
Title:  For form's sake the chancellor paid a visit to the pieces of
Title:  furniture named; but he well knew that it was not in a piece of
Title:  furniture that the queen would place the important letter she had
Title:  written that day.
Title:  
Title:  When the chancellor had opened and shut twenty times the drawers
Title:  of the secretaries, it became necessary, whatever hesitation he
Title:  might experience--it became necessary, I say, to come to the
Title:  conclusion of the affair; that is to say, to search the queen
Title:  herself.  The chancellor advanced, therefore, toward Anne of
Title:  Austria, and said with a very perplexed and embarrassed air, "And
Title:  now it remains for me to make the principal examination."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that?" asked the queen, who did not understand, or
Title:  rather was not willing to understand.
Title:  
Title:  "His majesty is certain that a letter has been written by you
Title:  during the day; he knows that it has not yet been sent to its
Title:  address.  This letter is not in your table nor in your secretary;
Title:  and yet this letter must be somewhere."
Title:  
Title:  "Would you dare to lift your hand to your queen?" said Anne of
Title:  Austria, drawing herself up to her full height, and fixing her
Title:  eyes upon the chancellor with an expression almost threatening.
Title:  
Title:  "I am a faithful subject of the king, madame, and all that his
Title:  Majesty commands I shall do."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, it is true!" said Anne of Austria; "and the spies of the
Title:  cardinal have served him faithfully.  I have written a letter
Title:  today; that letter is not yet gone.  The letter is here."  And
Title:  the queen laid her beautiful hand on her bosom.
Title:  
Title:  "Then give me that letter, madame," said the chancellor.
Title:  
Title:  "I will give it to none but the king monsieur," said Anne.
Title:  
Title:  "If the king had desired that the letter should be given to him,
Title:  madame, he would have demanded it of you himself.  But I repeat
Title:  to you, I am charged with reclaiming it; and if you do not give
Title:  it up--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "He has, then, charged me to take it from you."
Title:  
Title:  "How!  What do you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "That my orders go far, madame; and that I am authorized to seek
Title:  for the suspected paper, even on the person of your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "What horror!" cried the queen.
Title:  
Title:  "Be kind enough, then, madame, to act more compliantly."
Title:  
Title:  "The conduct is infamously violent!  Do you know that, monsieur?"
Title:  
Title:  "The king commands it, madame; excuse me."
Title:  
Title:  "I will not suffer it!  No, no, I would rather die!" cried the
Title:  queen, in whom the imperious blood of Spain and Austria began to
Title:  rise.
Title:  
Title:  The chancellor made a profound reverence.  Then, with the
Title:  intention quite patent of not drawing back a foot from the
Title:  accomplishment of the commission with which he was charged, and
Title:  as the attendant of an executioner might have done in the chamber
Title:  of torture, he approached Anne of Austria, for whose eyes at the
Title:  same instant sprang tears of rage.
Title:  
Title:  The queen was, as we have said, of great beauty.  The commission
Title:  might well be called delicate; and the king had reached, in his
Title:  jealousy of Buckingham, the point of not being jealous of anyone
Title:  else.
Title:  
Title:  Without doubt the chancellor, Seguier looked about at that moment
Title:  for the rope of the famous bell; but not finding it he summoned
Title:  his resolution, and stretched forth his hands toward the place
Title:  where the queen had acknowledged the paper was to be found.
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria took one step backward, became so pale that it
Title:  might be said she was dying, and leaning with her left hand upon
Title:  a table behind her to keep herself from falling, she with her
Title:  right hand drew the paper from her bosom and held it out to the
Title:  keeper of the seals.
Title:  
Title:  "There, monsieur, there is that letter!" cried the queen, with a
Title:  broken and trembling voice; "take it, and deliver me from your
Title:  odious presence."
Title:  
Title:  The chancellor, who, on his part, trembled with an emotion easily
Title:  to be conceived, took the letter, bowed to the ground, and
Title:  retired.  The door was scarcely closed upon him, when the queen
Title:  sank, half fainting, into the arms of her women.
Title:  
Title:  The chancellor carried the letter to the king without having read
Title:  a single word of it.  The king took it with a trembling hand,
Title:  looked for the address, which was wanting, became very pale,
Title:  opened it slowly, then seeing by the first words that it was
Title:  addressed to the King of Spain, he read it rapidly.
Title:  
Title:  It was nothing but a plan of attack against the cardinal.  The
Title:  queen pressed her brother and the Emperor of Austria to appear to
Title:  be wounded, as they really were, by the policy of Richelieu--the
Title:  eternal object of which was the abasement of the house of
Title:  Austria--to declare war against France, and as a condition of
Title:  peace, to insist upon the dismissal of the cardinal; but as to
Title:  love, there was not a single word about it in all the letter.
Title:  
Title:  The king, quite delighted, inquired if the cardinal was still at
Title:  the Louvre; he was told that his Eminence awaited the orders of
Title:  his Majesty in the business cabinet.
Title:  
Title:  The king went straight to him.
Title:  
Title:  "There, Duke," said he, "you were right and I was wrong.  The
Title:  whole intrigue is political, and there is not the least question
Title:  of love in this letter; but, on the other hand, there is abundant
Title:  question of you."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal took the letter, and read it with the greatest
Title:  attention; then, when he had arrived at the end of it, he read it
Title:  a second time.  "Well, your Majesty," said he, "you see how far
Title:  my enemies go; they menace you with two wars if you do not
Title:  dismiss me.  In your place, in truth, sire, I should yield to
Title:  such powerful instance; and on my part, it would be a real
Title:  happiness to withdraw from public affairs."
Title:  
Title:  "What say you, Duke?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say, sire, that my health is sinking under these excessive
Title:  struggles and these never-ending labors.  I say that according to
Title:  all probability I shall not be able to undergo the fatigues of
Title:  the siege of La Rochelle, and that it would be far better that
Title:  you should appoint there either Monsieur de Conde, Monsieur de
Title:  Bassopierre, or some valiant gentleman whose business is war, and
Title:  not me, who am a churchman, and who am constantly turned aside
Title:  for my real vocation to look after matters for which I have no
Title:  aptitude.  You would be the happier for it at home, sire, and I
Title:  do not doubt you would be the greater for it abroad."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Duke," said the king, "I understand you.  Be satisfied,
Title:  all who are named in that letter shall be punished as they
Title:  deserve, even the queen herself."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you say, sire?  God forbid that the queen should suffer
Title:  the least inconvenience or uneasiness on my account!  She has
Title:  always believed me, sire, to be her enemy; although your Majesty
Title:  can bear witness that I have always taken her part warmly, even
Title:  against you.  Oh, if she betrayed your Majesty on the side of
Title:  your honor, it would be quite another thing, and I should be the
Title:  first to say, 'No grace, sire--no grace for the guilty!'
Title:  Happily, there is nothing of the kind, and your Majesty has just
Title:  acquired a new proof of it."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true, Monsieur Cardinal," said the king, "and you were
Title:  right, as you always are; but the queen, not the less, deserves
Title:  all my anger."
Title:  
Title:  "It is you, sire, who have now incurred hers.  And even if she
Title:  were to be seriously offended, I could well understand it; your
Title:  Majesty has treated her with a severity--"
Title:  
Title:  "It is thus I will always treat my enemies and yours, Duke,
Title:  however high they may be placed, and whatever peril I may incur
Title:  in acting severely toward them."
Title:  
Title:  "The queen is my enemy, but is not yours, sire; on the contrary,
Title:  she is a devoted, submissive, and irreproachable wife.  Allow me,
Title:  then, sire, to intercede for her with your Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "Let her humble herself, then, and come to me first."
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary, sire, set the example.  You have committed the
Title:  first wrong, since it was you who suspected the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "What!  I make the first advances?" said the king.  "Never!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sire, I entreat you to do so."
Title:  
Title:  "Besides, in what manner can I make advances first?"
Title:  
Title:  "By doing a thing which you know will be agreeable to her."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Give a ball; you know how much the queen loves dancing.  I will
Title:  answer for it, her resentment will not hold out against such an
Title:  attention."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Cardinal, you know that I do not like worldly
Title:  pleasures."
Title:  
Title:  "The queen will only be the more grateful to you, as she knows
Title:  your antipathy for that amusement; besides, it will be an
Title:  opportunity for her to wear those beautiful diamonds which you
Title:  gave her recently on her birthday and with which she has since
Title:  had no occasion to adorn herself."
Title:  
Title:  "We shall see, Monsieur Cardinal, we shall see," said the king,
Title:  who, in his joy at finding the queen guilty of a crime which he
Title:  cared little about, and innocent of a fault of which he had great
Title:  dread, was ready to make up all differences with her, "we shall
Title:  see, but upon my honor, you are too indulgent toward her."
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," said the cardinal, "leave severity to your ministers.
Title:  Clemency is a royal virtue; employ it, and you will find that you
Title:  derive advantage therein."
Title:  
Title:  Thereupon the cardinal, hearing the clock strike eleven, bowed
Title:  low, asking permission of the king to retire, and supplicating
Title:  him to come to a good understanding with the queen.
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria, who, in consequence of the seizure of her
Title:  letter, expected reproaches, was much astonished the next day to
Title:  see the king make some attempts at reconciliation with her.  Her
Title:  first movement was repellent.  Her womanly pride and her queenly
Title:  dignity had both been so cruelly offended that she could not come
Title:  round at the first advance; but, overpersuaded by the advice of
Title:  her women, she at last had the appearance of beginning to forget.
Title:  The king took advantage of this favorable moment to tell her that
Title:  her had the intention of shortly giving a fete.
Title:  
Title:  A fete was so rare a thing for poor Anne of Austria that at this
Title:  announcement, as the cardinal had predicted, the last trace of
Title:  her resentment disappeared, if not from her heart at least from
Title:  her countenance.  She asked upon what day this fete would take
Title:  place, but the king replied that he must consult the cardinal
Title:  upon that head.
Title:  
Title:  Indeed, every day the king asked the cardinal when this fete
Title:  should take place; and every day the cardinal, under some
Title:  pretext, deferred fixing it.  Ten days passed away thus.
Title:  
Title:  On the eighth day after the scene we have described, the cardinal
Title:  received a letter with the London stamp which only contained
Title:  these lines:  "I have them; but I am unable to leave London for
Title:  want of money.  Send me five hundred pistoles, and four or five
Title:  days after I have received them I shall be in Paris."
Title:  
Title:  On the same day the cardinal received this letter the king put
Title:  his customary question to him.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu counted on his fingers, and said to himself, "She will
Title:  arrive, she says, four or five days after having received the
Title:  money.  It will require four or five days for the transmission of
Title:  the money, four or five days for her to return; that makes ten
Title:  days.  Now, allowing for contrary winds, accidents, and a woman's
Title:  weakness, there are twelve days."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, Monsieur Duke," said the king, "have you made your
Title:  calculations?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire.  Today is the twentieth of September.  The aldermen
Title:  of the city give a fete on the third of October.  That will fall
Title:  in wonderfully well; you will not appear to have gone out of your
Title:  way to please the queen."
Title:  
Title:  Then the cardinal added, "A PROPOS, sire, do not forget to tell
Title:  her Majesty the evening before the fete that you should like to
Title:  see how her diamond studs become her."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  17  BONACIEUX AT HOME
Title:  
Title:  It was the second time the cardinal had mentioned these diamond
Title:  studs to the king.  Louis XIII was struck with this insistence,
Title:  and began to fancy that this recommendation concealed some
Title:  mystery.
Title:  
Title:  More than once the king had been humiliated by the cardinal,
Title:  whose police, without having yet attained the perfection of the
Title:  modern police, were excellent, being better informed than
Title:  himself, even upon what was going on in his own household.  He
Title:  hoped, then, in a conversation with Anne of Austria, to obtain
Title:  some information from that conversation, and afterward to come
Title:  upon his Eminence with some secret which the cardinal either knew
Title:  or did not know, but which, in either case, would raise him
Title:  infinitely in the eyes of his minister.
Title:  
Title:  He went then to the queen, and according to custom accosted her
Title:  with fresh menaces against those who surrounded her.  Anne of
Title:  Austria lowered her head, allowed the torrent to flow on without
Title:  replying, hoping that it would cease of itself; but this was not
Title:  what Louis XIII meant.  Louis XIII wanted a discussion from which
Title:  some light or other might break, convinced as he was that the
Title:  cardinal had some afterthought and was preparing for him one of
Title:  those terrible surprises which his Eminence was so skillful in
Title:  getting up.  He arrived at this end by his persistence in
Title:  accusation.
Title:  
Title:  "But," cried Anne of Austria, tired of these vague attacks, "but,
Title:  sire, you do not tell me all that you have in your heart.  What
Title:  have I done, then?  Let me know what crime I have committed.  It
Title:  is impossible that your Majesty can make all this ado about a
Title:  letter written to my brother."
Title:  
Title:  The king, attacked in a manner so direct, did not know what to
Title:  answer; and he thought that this was the moment for expressing
Title:  the desire which he was not going to have made until the evening
Title:  before the fete.
Title:  
Title:  "Madame," said he, with dignity, "there will shortly be a ball at
Title:  the Hotel de Ville.  I wish, in order to honor our worthy
Title:  aldermen, you should appear in ceremonial costume, and above all,
Title:  ornamented with the diamond studs which I gave you on your
Title:  birthday.  That is my answer."
Title:  
Title:  The answer was terrible.  Anne of Austria believed that Louis
Title:  XIII knew all, and that the cardinal had persuaded him to employ
Title:  this long dissimulation of seven or eight days, which, likewise,
Title:  was characteristic.  She became excessively pale, leaned her
Title:  beautiful hand upon a CONSOLE, which hand appeared then like one
Title:  of wax, and looking at the king with terror in her eyes, she was
Title:  unable to reply by a single syllable.
Title:  
Title:  "You hear, madame," said the king, who enjoyed the embarrassment
Title:  to its full extent, but without guessing the cause.  "You hear,
Title:  madame?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire, I hear," stammered the queen.
Title:  
Title:  "You will appear at this ball?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "With those studs?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  The queen's paleness, if possible, increased; the king perceived
Title:  it, and enjoyed it with that cold cruelty which was one of the
Title:  worst sides of his character.
Title:  
Title:  "Then that is agreed," said the king, "and that is all I had to
Title:  say to you."
Title:  
Title:  "But on what day will this ball take place?" asked Anne of
Title:  Austria.
Title:  
Title:  Louis XIII felt instinctively that he ought not to reply to this
Title:  question, the queen having put it in an almost dying voice.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, very shortly, madame," said he; "but I do not precisely
Title:  recollect the date of the day.  I will ask the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "It was the cardinal, then, who informed you of this fete?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, madame," replied the astonished king; "but why do you ask
Title:  that?"
Title:  
Title:  "It was he who told you to invite me to appear with these studs?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, madame--"
Title:  
Title:  "It was he, sire, it was he!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, and what does it signify whether it was he or I?  Is there
Title:  any crime in this request?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you will appear?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sire."
Title:  
Title:  "That is well," said the king, retiring, "that is well; I count
Title:  upon it."
Title:  
Title:  The queen made a curtsy, less from etiquette than because her
Title:  knees were sinking under her.  The king went away enchanted.
Title:  
Title:  "I am lost," murmured the queen, "lost!--for the cardinal knows
Title:  all, and it is he who urges on the king, who as yet knows nothing
Title:  but will soon know everything.  I am lost!  My God, my God, my
Title:  God!"
Title:  
Title:  She knelt upon a cushion and prayed, with her head buried between
Title:  her palpitating arms.
Title:  
Title:  In fact, her position was terrible.  Buckingham had returned to
Title:  London; Mme. Chevreuse was at Tours.  More closely watched than
Title:  ever, the queen felt certain, without knowing how to tell which,
Title:  that one of her women had betrayed her.  Laporte could not leave
Title:  the Louvre; she had not a soul in the world in whom she could
Title:  confide.  Thus, while contemplating the misfortune which
Title:  threatened her and the abandonment in which she was left, she
Title:  broke out into sobs and tears.
Title:  
Title:  "Can I be of service to your Majesty?" said all at once a voice
Title:  full of sweetness and pity.
Title:  
Title:  The queen turned sharply round, for there could be no deception
Title:  in the expression of that voice; it was a friend who spoke thus.
Title:  
Title:  In fact, at one of the doors which opened into the queen's
Title:  apartment appeared the pretty Mme. Bonacieux.  She had been
Title:  engaged in arranging the dresses and linen in a closet when the
Title:  king entered; she could not get out and had heard all.
Title:  
Title:  The queen uttered a piercing cry at finding herself surprised--
Title:  for in her trouble she did not at first recognize the young woman
Title:  who had been given to her by Laporte.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, fear nothing, madame!" said the young woman, clasping her
Title:  hands and weeping herself at the queen's sorrows; "I am your
Title:  Majesty's, body and soul, and however far I may be from you,
Title:  however inferior may be my position, I believe I have discovered
Title:  a means of extricating your Majesty from your trouble."
Title:  
Title:  "You, oh, heaven, you!" cried the queen; "but look me in the
Title:  face.  I am betrayed on all sides.  Can I trust in you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, madame!" cried the young woman, falling on her knees; "upon
Title:  my soul, I am ready to die for your Majesty!"
Title:  
Title:  This expression sprang from the very bottom of the heart, and,
Title:  like the first, there was no mistaking it.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," continued Mme. Bonacieux, "yes, there are traitors here;
Title:  but by the holy name of the Virgin, I swear that no one is more
Title:  devoted to your Majesty than I am.  Those studs which the king
Title:  speaks of, you gave them to the Duke of Buckingham, did you not?
Title:  Those studs were enclosed in a little rosewood box which he held
Title:  under his arm?  Am I deceived?  Is it not so, madame?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God!" murmured the queen, whose teeth chattered
Title:  with fright.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, those studs," continued Mme. Bonacieux, "we must have them
Title:  back again."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, without doubt, it is necessary," cried the queen; "but how
Title:  am I to act?  How can it be effected?"
Title:  
Title:  "Someone must be sent to the duke."
Title:  
Title:  "But who, who?  In whom can I trust?"
Title:  
Title:  "Place confidence in me, madame; do me that honor, my queen, and
Title:  I will find a messenger."
Title:  
Title:  "But I must write."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes; that is indispensable.  Two words from the hand of your
Title:  Majesty and your private seal."
Title:  
Title:  "But these two words would bring about my condemnation, divorce,
Title:  exile!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, if they fell into infamous hands.  But I will answer for
Title:  these two words being delivered to their address."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!  I must then place my life, my honor, my reputation,
Title:  in your hands?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, madame, you must; and I will save them all."
Title:  
Title:  "But how?  Tell me at least the means."
Title:  
Title:  "My husband had been at liberty these two or three days.  I have
Title:  not yet had time to see him again.  He is a worthy, honest man
Title:  who entertains neither love nor hatred for anybody.  He will do
Title:  anything I wish.  He will set out upon receiving an order from
Title:  me, without knowing what he carries, and he will carry your
Title:  Majesty's letter, without even knowing it is from your Majesty,
Title:  to the address which is on it."
Title:  
Title:  The queen took the two hands of the young woman with a burst of
Title:  emotion, gazed at her as if to read her very heart, and seeing
Title:  nothing but sincerity in her beautiful eyes, embraced her
Title:  tenderly.
Title:  
Title:  "Do that," cried she, "and you will have saved my life, you will
Title:  have saved my honor!"
Title:  
Title:  "Do not exaggerate the service I have the happiness to render
Title:  your Majesty.  I have nothing to save for your Majesty; you are
Title:  only the victim of perfidious plots."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true, that is true, my child," said the queen, "you are
Title:  right."
Title:  
Title:  "Give me then, that letter, madame; time presses."
Title:  
Title:  The queen ran to a little table, on which were ink, paper, and
Title:  pens.  She wrote two lines, sealed the letter with her private
Title:  seal, and gave it to Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "And now," said the queen, "we are forgetting one very necessary
Title:  thing."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that, madame?"
Title:  
Title:  "Money."
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux blushed.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that is true," said she, "and I will confess to your
Title:  Majesty that my husband--"
Title:  
Title:  "Your husband has none.  Is that what you would say?"
Title:  
Title:  "He has some, but he is very avaricious; that is his fault.
Title:  Nevertheless, let not your Majesty be uneasy, we will find
Title:  means."
Title:  
Title:  "And I have none, either," said the queen.  Those who have read
Title:  the MEMOIRS of Mme. de Motteville will not be astonished at this
Title:  reply.  "But wait a minute."
Title:  
Title:  Anne of Austria ran to her jewel case.
Title:  
Title:  "Here," said she, "here is a ring of great value, as I have been
Title:  assured.  It came from my brother, the King of Spain.  It is
Title:  mine, and I am at liberty to dispose of it.  Take this ring;
Title:  raise money with it, and let your husband set out."
Title:  
Title:  "In an hour you shall be obeyed."
Title:  
Title:  "You see the address," said the queen, speaking so low that Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux could hardly hear what she said, "To my Lord Duke of
Title:  Buckingham, London."
Title:  
Title:  "The letter shall be given to himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Generous girl!" cried Anne of Austria.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux kissed the hands of the queen, concealed the paper
Title:  in the bosom of her dress, and disappeared with the lightness of
Title:  a bird.
Title:  
Title:  Ten minutes afterward she was at home.  As she told the queen,
Title:  she had not seen her husband since his liberation; she was
Title:  ignorant of the change that had taken place in him with respect
Title:  to the cardinal--a change which had since been strengthened by
Title:  two or three visits from the Comte de Rochefort, who had become
Title:  the best friend of Bonacieux, and had persuaded him, without much
Title:  trouble, was putting his house in order, the furniture of which he
Title:  had found mostly broken and his closets nearly empty--justice not
Title:  being one of the three things which King Solomon names as leaving
Title:  no traces of their passage.  As to the servant, she had run away at
Title:  the moment of her master's arrest.  Terror had had such an effect
Title:  upon the poor girl that she had never ceased walking from Paris
Title:  till she reached Burgundy, her native place.
Title:  
Title:  The worthy mercer had, immediately upon re-entering his house,
Title:  informed his wife of his happy return, and his wife had replied
Title:  by congratulating him, and telling him that the first moment she
Title:  could steal from her duties should be devoted to paying him a
Title:  visit.
Title:  
Title:  This first moment had been delayed five days, which, under any
Title:  other circumstances, might have appeared rather long to M.
Title:  Bonacieux; but he had, in the visit he had made to the cardinal
Title:  and in the visits Rochefort had made him, ample subjects for
Title:  reflection, and as everybody knows, nothing makes time pass more
Title:  quickly than reflection.
Title:  
Title:  This was the more so because Bonacieux's reflections were all
Title:  rose-colored.  Rochefort called him his friend, his dear
Title:  Bonacieux, and never ceased telling him that the cardinal had a
Title:  great respect for him.  The mercer fancied himself already on the
Title:  high road to honors and fortune.
Title:  
Title:  On her side Mme. Bonacieux had also reflected; but, it must be
Title:  admitted, upon something widely different from ambition.  In
Title:  spite of herself her thoughts constantly reverted to that
Title:  handsome young man who was so brave and appeared to be so much in
Title:  love.  Married at eighteen to M. Bonacieux, having always lived
Title:  among her husband's friends--people little capable of inspiring
Title:  any sentiment whatever in a young woman whose heart was above her
Title:  position--Mme. Bonacieux had remained insensible to vulgar
Title:  seductions; but at this period the title of gentleman had great
Title:  influence with the citizen class, and d'Artagnan was a gentleman.
Title:  Besides, he wore the uniform of the Guards, which next to that of
Title:  the Musketeers was most admired by the ladies.  He was, we
Title:  repeat, handsome, young, and bold; he spoke of love like a man
Title:  who did love and was anxious to be loved in return.  There was
Title:  certainly enough in all this to turn a head only twenty-three
Title:  years old, and Mme. Bonacieux had just attained that happy period
Title:  of life.
Title:  
Title:  The couple, then, although they had not seen each other for eight
Title:  days, and during that time serious events had taken place in
Title:  which both were concerned, accosted each other with a degree of
Title:  preoccupation.  Nevertheless, Bonacieux manifested real joy, and
Title:  advanced toward his wife with open arms.  Madame Bonacieux
Title:  presented her cheek to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Let us talk a little," said she.
Title:  
Title:  "How!" said Bonacieux, astonished.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I have something of the highest importance to tell you."
Title:  
Title:  "True," said he, "and I have some questions sufficiently serious
Title:  to put to you.  Describe to me your abduction, I pray you."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, that's of no consequence just now," said Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "And what does it concern, then--my captivity?"
Title:  
Title:  "I heard of it the day it happened; but as you were not guilty of
Title:  any crime, as you were not guilty of any intrigue, as you, in
Title:  short, knew nothing that could compromise yourself or anybody
Title:  else, I attached no more importance to that event than it
Title:  merited."
Title:  
Title:  "You speak very much at your ease, madame," said Bonacieux, hurt
Title:  at the little interest his wife showed in him.  "Do you know that
Title:  I was plunged during a day and night in a dungeon of the
Title:  Bastille?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, a day and night soon pass away.  Let us return to the object
Title:  that brings me here."
Title:  
Title:  "What, that which brings you home to me?  Is it not the desire of
Title:  seeing a husband again from whom you have been separated for a
Title:  week?" asked the mercer, piqued to the quick.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that first, and other things afterward."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak."
Title:  
Title:  "It is a thing of the highest interest, and upon which our future
Title:  fortune perhaps depends."
Title:  
Title:  "The complexion of our fortune has changed very much since I saw
Title:  you, Madam Bonacieux, and I should not be astonished if in the
Title:  course of a few months it were to excite the envy of many folks."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, particularly if you follow the instructions I am about to
Title:  give you."
Title:  
Title:  "Me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, you.  There is good and holy action to be performed,
Title:  monsieur, and much money to be gained at the same time."
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux knew that in talking of money to her husband, she
Title:  took him on his weak side.  But a man, were he even a mercer,
Title:  when he had talked for ten minutes with Cardinal Richelieu, is no
Title:  longer the same man.
Title:  
Title:  "Much money to be gained?" said Bonacieux, protruding his lip.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, much."
Title:  
Title:  "About how much?"
Title:  
Title:  "A thousand pistoles, perhaps."
Title:  
Title:  "What you demand of me is serious, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is indeed."
Title:  
Title:  "What must be done?"
Title:  
Title:  "You must go away immediately.  I will give you a paper which you
Title:  must not part with on any account, and which you will deliver
Title:  into the proper hands."
Title:  
Title:  "And whither am I to go?"
Title:  
Title:  "To London."
Title:  
Title:  "I go to London?  Go to!  You jest!  I have no business in
Title:  London."
Title:  
Title:  "But others wish that you should go there."
Title:  
Title:  "But who are those others?  I warn you that I will never again
Title:  work in the dark, and that I will know not only to what I expose
Title:  myself, but for whom I expose myself."
Title:  
Title:  "An illustrious person sends you; an illustrious person awaits
Title:  you.  The recompense will exceed your expectations; that is all I
Title:  promise you."
Title:  
Title:  "More intrigues!  Nothing but intrigues!  Thank you, madame, I am
Title:  aware of them now; Monsieur Cardinal has enlightened me on that
Title:  head."
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal?" cried Mme. Bonacieux.  "Have you seen the
Title:  cardinal?"
Title:  
Title:  "He sent for me," answered the mercer, proudly.
Title:  
Title:  "And you responded to his bidding, you imprudent man?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I can't say I had much choice of going or not going, for I
Title:  was taken to him between two guards.  It is true also, that as I
Title:  did not then know his Eminence, if I had been able to dispense
Title:  with the visit, I should have been enchanted."
Title:  
Title:  "He ill-treated you, then; he threatened you?"
Title:  
Title:  "He gave me his hand, and called me his friend.  His friend!  Do
Title:  you hear that, madame?  I am the friend of the great cardinal!"
Title:  
Title:  "Of the great cardinal!"
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps you would contest his right to that title, madame?"
Title:  
Title:  "I would contest nothing; but I tell you that the favor of a
Title:  minister is ephemeral, and that a man must be mad to attach
Title:  himself to a minister.  There are powers above his which do not
Title:  depend upon a man or the issue of an event; it is to these powers
Title:  we should rally."
Title:  
Title:  "I am sorry for it, madame, but I acknowledge not her power but
Title:  that of the great man whom I have the honor to serve."
Title:  
Title:  "You serve the cardinal?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, madame; and as his servant, I will not allow you to be
Title:  concerned in plots against the safety of the state, or to serve
Title:  the intrigues of a woman who is not French and who has a Spanish
Title:  heart.  Fortunately we have the great cardinal; his vigilant eye
Title:  watches over and penetrates to the bottom of the heart."
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux was repeating, word for word, a sentence which he had
Title:  heard from the Comte de Rochefort; but the poor wife, who had
Title:  reckoned on her husband, and who, in that hope, had answered for
Title:  him to the queen, did not tremble the less, both at the danger
Title:  into which she had nearly cast herself and at the helpless state
Title:  to which she was reduced.  Nevertheless, knowing the weakness of
Title:  her husband, and more particularly his cupidity, she did not
Title:  despair of bringing him round to her purpose.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you are a cardinalist, then, monsieur, are you?" cried she;
Title:  "and you serve the party of those who maltreat your wife and
Title:  insult your queen?"
Title:  
Title:  "Private interests are as nothing before the interests of all.  I
Title:  am for those who save the state," said Bonacieux, emphatically.
Title:  
Title:  "And what do you know about the state you talk of?" said Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux, shrugging her shoulders.  "Be satisfied with being a
Title:  plain, straightforward citizen, and turn to that side which
Title:  offers the most advantages."
Title:  
Title:  "Eh, eh!" said Bonacieux, slapping a plump, round bag, which
Title:  returned a sound a money; "what do you think of this, Madame
Title:  Preacher?"
Title:  
Title:  "Whence comes that money?"
Title:  
Title:  "You do not guess?"
Title:  
Title:  "From the cardinal?"
Title:  
Title:  "From him, and from my friend the Comte de Rochefort."
Title:  
Title:  "The Comte de Rochefort!  Why it was he who carried me off!"
Title:  
Title:  "That may be, madame!"
Title:  
Title:  "And you receive silver from that man?"
Title:  
Title:  "Have you not said that that abduction was entirely political?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but that abduction had for its object the betrayal of my
Title:  mistress, to draw from me by torture confessions that might
Title:  compromise the honor, and perhaps the life, of my august
Title:  mistress."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame," replied Bonacieux, "your august mistress is a
Title:  perfidious Spaniard, and what the cardinal does is well done."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said the young woman, "I know you to be cowardly,
Title:  avaricious, and foolish, but I never till now believed you
Title:  infamous!"
Title:  
Title:  "Madame," said Bonacieux, who had never seen his wife in a
Title:  passion, and who recoiled before this conjugal anger, "madame,
Title:  what do you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say you are a miserable creature!" continued Mme. Bonacieux,
Title:  who saw she was regaining some little influence over her husband.
Title:  "You meddle with politics, do you--and still more, with
Title:  cardinalist politics?  Why, you sell yourself, body and soul, to
Title:  the demon, the devil, for money!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, to the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "It's the same thing," cried the young woman.  "Who calls
Title:  Richelieu calls Satan."
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue, hold your tongue, madame!  You may be
Title:  overheard."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, you are right; I should be ashamed for anyone to know your
Title:  baseness."
Title:  
Title:  "But what do you require of me, then?  Let us see."
Title:  
Title:  "I have told you.  You must depart instantly, monsieur.  You must
Title:  accomplish loyally the commission with which I deign to charge
Title:  you, and on that condition I pardon everything, I forget
Title:  everything; and what is more," and she held out her hand to him,
Title:  "I restore my love."
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux was cowardly and avaricious, but he loved his wife.  He
Title:  was softened.  A man of fifty cannot long bear malice with a wife
Title:  of twenty-three.  Mme. Bonacieux saw that he hesitated.
Title:  
Title:  "Come!  Have you decided?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "But, my dear love, reflect a little upon what you require of me.
Title:  London is far from Paris, very far, and perhaps the commission
Title:  with which you charge me is not without dangers?"
Title:  
Title:  "What matters it, if you avoid them?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hold, Madame Bonacieux," said the mercer, "hold!  I positively
Title:  refuse; intrigues terrify me.  I have seen the Bastille.  My!
Title:  Whew!  That's a frightful place, that Bastille!  Only to think of
Title:  it makes my flesh crawl.  They threatened me with torture.  Do
Title:  you know what torture is?  Wooden points that they stick in
Title:  between your legs till your bones stick out!  No, positively I
Title:  will not go.  And, MORBLEU, why do you not go yourself?  For in
Title:  truth, I think I have hitherto been deceived in you.  I really
Title:  believe you are a man, and a violent one, too."
Title:  
Title:  "And you, you are a woman--a miserable woman, stupid and brutal.
Title:  You are afraid, are you?  Well, if you do not go this very
Title:  instant, I will have you arrested by the queen's orders, and I
Title:  will have you placed in the Bastille which you dread so much."
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux fell into a profound reflection.  He weighed the two
Title:  angers in his brain--that of the cardinal and that of the queen;
Title:  that of the cardinal predominated enormously.
Title:  
Title:  "Have me arrested on the part of the queen," said he, "and I--I
Title:  will appeal to his Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  At once Mme. Bonacieux saw that she had gone too far, and she was
Title:  terrified at having communicated so much.  She for a moment
Title:  contemplated with fright that stupid countenance, impressed with
Title:  the invincible resolution of a fool that is overcome by fear.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, be it so!" said she.  "Perhaps, when all is considered,
Title:  you are right.  In the long run, a man knows more about politics
Title:  than a woman, particularly such as, like you, Monsieur Bonacieux,
Title:  have conversed with the cardinal.  And yet it is very hard,"
Title:  added she, "that a man upon whose affection I thought I might
Title:  depend, treats me thus unkindly and will not comply with any of
Title:  my fancies."
Title:  
Title:  "That is because your fancies go too far," replied the triumphant
Title:  Bonacieux, "and I mistrust them."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I will give it up, then," said the young woman, sighing.
Title:  "It is well as it is; say no more about it."
Title:  
Title:  "At least you should tell me what I should have to do in London,"
Title:  replied Bonacieux, who remembered a little too late that
Title:  Rochefort had desired him to endeavor to obtain his wife's
Title:  secrets.
Title:  
Title:  "It is of no use for you to know anything about it," said the
Title:  young woman, whom an instinctive mistrust now impelled to draw
Title:  back.  "It was about one of those purchases that interest women--
Title:  a purchase by which much might have been gained."
Title:  
Title:  But the more the young woman excused herself, the more important
Title:  Bonacieux thought the secret which she declined to confide to
Title:  him.  He resolved then to hasten immediately to the residence of
Title:  the Comte de Rochefort, and tell him that the queen was seeking
Title:  for a messenger to send to London.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon me for quitting you, my dear Madame Bonacieux," said he;
Title:  "but, not knowing you would come to see me, I had made an
Title:  engagement with a friend.  I shall soon return; and if you will
Title:  wait only a few minutes for me, as soon as I have concluded my
Title:  business with that friend, as it is growing late, I will come
Title:  back and reconduct you to the Louvre."
Title:  
Title:  "Thank you, monsieur, you are not brave enough to be of any use
Title:  to me whatever," replied Mme. Bonacieux.  "I shall return very
Title:  safely to the Louvre all alone."
Title:  
Title:  "As you please, Madame Bonacieux," said the ex-mercer.  "Shall I
Title:  see you again soon?"
Title:  
Title:  "Next week I hope my duties will afford me a little liberty, and
Title:  I will take advantage of it to come and put things in order here,
Title:  as they must necessarily be much deranged."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well; I shall expect you.  You are not angry with me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not the least in the world."
Title:  
Title:  "Till then, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Till then."
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux kissed his wife's hand, and set off at a quick pace.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Mme. Bonacieux, when her husband had shut the street
Title:  door and she found herself alone; "that imbecile lacked but one
Title:  thing to become a cardinalist.  And I, who have answered for him
Title:  to the queen--I, who have promised my poor mistress--ah, my God,
Title:  my God!  She will take me for one of those wretches with whom the
Title:  palace swarms and who are placed about her as spies!  Ah,
Title:  Monsieur Bonacieux, I never did love you much, but now it is
Title:  worse than ever.  I hate you, and on my word you shall pay for
Title:  this!"
Title:  
Title:  At the moment she spoke these words a rap on the ceiling made her
Title:  raise her head, and a voice which reached her through the ceiling
Title:  cried, "Dear Madame Bonacieux, open for me the little door on the
Title:  alley, and I will come down to you."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  18  LOVER AND HUSBAND
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, Madame," said d'Artagnan, entering by the door which the
Title:  young woman opened for him, "allow me to tell you that you have a
Title:  bad sort of a husband."
Title:  
Title:  "You have, then, overheard our conversation?" asked Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux, eagerly, and looking at d'Artagnan with disquiet.
Title:  
Title:  "The whole."
Title:  
Title:  "But how, my God?"
Title:  
Title:  "By a mode of proceeding known to myself, and by which I likewise
Title:  overheard the more animated conversation which he had with the
Title:  cardinal's police."
Title:  
Title:  "And what did you understand by what we said?"
Title:  
Title:  "A thousand things.  In the first place, that, unfortunately,
Title:  your husband is a simpleton and a fool; in the next place, you
Title:  are in trouble, of which I am very glad, as it gives me a
Title:  opportunity of placing myself at your service, and God knows I am
Title:  ready to throw myself into the fire for you; finally, that the
Title:  queen wants a brave, intelligent, devoted man to make a journey
Title:  to London for her.  I have at least two of the three qualities
Title:  you stand in need of, and here I am."
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux made no reply; but her heart beat with joy and
Title:  secret hope shone in her eyes.
Title:  
Title:  "And what guarantee will you give me," asked she, "if I consent
Title:  to confide this message to you?"
Title:  
Title:  "My love for you.  Speak!  Command!  What is to be done?"
Title:  
Title:  "My God, my God!" murmured the young woman, "ought I to confide
Title:  such a secret to you, monsieur?  You are almost a boy."
Title:  
Title:  "I see that you require someone to answer for me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I admit that would reassure me greatly."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "No.  Who are these gentleman?"
Title:  
Title:  "Three of the king's Musketeers.  Do you know Monsieur de
Title:  Treville, their captain?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, him!  I know him; not personally, but from having heard
Title:  the queen speak of him more than once as a brave and loyal
Title:  gentleman."
Title:  
Title:  "You do not fear lest he should betray you to the cardinal?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no, certainly not!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, reveal your secret to him, and ask him whether, however
Title:  important, however valuable, however terrible it may be, you may
Title:  not confide it to me."
Title:  
Title:  "But this secret is not mine, and I cannot reveal it in this
Title:  manner."
Title:  
Title:  "You were about to confide it to Monsieur Bonacieux," said
Title:  d'Artagnan, with chagrin.
Title:  
Title:  "As one confides a letter to the hollow of a tree, to the wing of
Title:  a pigeon, to the collar of a dog."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet, me--you see plainly that I love you."
Title:  
Title:  "You say so."
Title:  
Title:  "I am an honorable man."
Title:  
Title:  "You say so."
Title:  
Title:  "I am a gallant fellow."
Title:  
Title:  "I believe it."
Title:  
Title:  "I am brave."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I am sure of that!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then, put me to the proof."
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux looked at the young man, restrained for a minute
Title:  by a last hesitation; but there was such an ardor in his eyes,
Title:  such persuasion in his voice, that she felt herself constrained
Title:  to confide in him.  Besides, she found herself in circumstances
Title:  where everything must be risked for the sake of everything.  The
Title:  queen might be as much injured by too much reticence as by too
Title:  much confidence; and--let us admit it--the involuntary sentiment
Title:  which she felt for her young protector decided her to speak.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen," said she; "I yield to your protestations, I yield to
Title:  your assurances.  But I swear to you, before God who hears us,
Title:  that if you betray me, and my enemies pardon me, I will kill
Title:  myself, while accusing you of my death."
Title:  
Title:  "And I--I swear to you before God, madame," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  "that if I am taken while accomplishing the orders you give me, I
Title:  will die sooner than do anything that may compromise anyone."
Title:  
Title:  Then the young woman confided in him the terrible secret of which
Title:  chance had already communicated to him a part in front of the
Title:  Samaritaine.  This was their mutual declaration of love.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was radiant with joy and pride.  This secret which he
Title:  possessed, this woman whom he loved!  Confidence and love made him
Title:  a giant.
Title:  
Title:  "I go," said he; "I go at once."
Title:  
Title:  "How, you will go!" said Mme. Bonacieux; "and your regiment, your
Title:  captain?"
Title:  
Title:  "By my soul, you had made me forget all that, dear Constance!
Title:  Yes, you are right; a furlough is needful."
Title:  
Title:  "Still another obstacle," murmured Mme. Bonacieux, sorrowfully.
Title:  
Title:  "As to that," cried d'Artagnan, after a moment of reflection, "I
Title:  shall surmount it, be assured."
Title:  
Title:  "How so?"
Title:  
Title:  "I will go this very evening to Treville, whom I will request to
Title:  ask this favor for me of his brother-in-law, Monsieur
Title:  Dessessart."
Title:  
Title:  "But another thing."
Title:  
Title:  "What?" asked d'Artagnan, seeing that Mme. Bonacieux hesitated to
Title:  continue.
Title:  
Title:  "You have, perhaps, no money?"
Title:  
Title:  "PERHAPS is too much," said d'Artagnan, smiling.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," replied Mme. Bonacieux, opening a cupboard and taking
Title:  from it the very bag which a half hour before her husband had
Title:  caressed so affectionately, "take this bag."
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal's?" cried d'Artagnan, breaking into a loud laugh,
Title:  he having heard, as may be remembered, thanks to the broken
Title:  boards, every syllable of the conversation between the mercer and
Title:  his wife.
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal's," replied Mme. Bonacieux.  "You see it makes a
Title:  very respectable appearance."
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU," cried d'Artagnan, "it will be a double amusing affair
Title:  to save the queen with the cardinal's money!"
Title:  
Title:  "You are an amiable and charming young man," said Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  "Be assured you will not find her Majesty ungrateful."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I am already grandly recompensed!" cried d'Artagnan.  "I
Title:  love you; you permit me to tell you that I do--that is already
Title:  more happiness than I dared to hope."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" said Mme. Bonacieux, starting.
Title:  
Title:  "What!"
Title:  
Title:  "Someone is talking in the street."
Title:  
Title:  "It is the voice of--"
Title:  
Title:  "Of my husband!  Yes, I recognize it!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan ran to the door and pushed the bolt.
Title:  
Title:  "He shall not come in before I am gone," said he; "and when I am
Title:  gone, you can open to him."
Title:  
Title:  "But I ought to be gone, too.  And the disappearance of his
Title:  money; how am I to justify it if I am here?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are right; we must go out."
Title:  
Title:  "Go out?  How?  He will see us if we go out."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you must come up into my room."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said Mme. Bonacieux, "you speak that in a tone that
Title:  frightens me!"
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux pronounced these words with tears in her eyes.
Title:  d'Artagnan saw those tears, and much disturbed, softened, he
Title:  threw himself at her feet.
Title:  
Title:  "With me you will be as safe as in a temple; I give you my word
Title:  of a gentleman."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us go," said she, "I place full confidence in you, my
Title:  friend!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan drew back the bolt with precaution, and both, light as
Title:  shadows, glided through the interior door into the passage,
Title:  ascended the stairs as quietly as possible, and entered
Title:  d'Artagnan's chambers.
Title:  
Title:  Once there, for greater security, the young man barricaded the
Title:  door.  They both approached the window, and through a slit in the
Title:  shutter they saw Bonacieux talking with a man in a cloak.
Title:  
Title:  At sight of this man, d'Artagnan started, and half drawing his
Title:  sword, sprang toward the door.
Title:  
Title:  It was the man of Meung.
Title:  
Title:  "What are you going to do?" cried Mme. Bonacieux; "you will ruin
Title:  us all!"
Title:  
Title:  "But I have sworn to kill that man!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Your life is devoted from this moment, and does not belong to
Title:  you.  In the name of the queen I forbid you to throw yourself
Title:  into any peril which is foreign to that of your journey."
Title:  
Title:  "And do you command nothing in your own name?"
Title:  
Title:  "In my name," said Mme. Bonacieux, with great emotion, "in my
Title:  name I beg you!  But listen; they appear to be speaking of me."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan drew near the window, and lent his ear.
Title:  
Title:  M. Bonacieux had opened his door, and seeing the apartment, had
Title:  returned to the man in the cloak, whom he had left alone for an
Title:  instant.
Title:  
Title:  "She is gone," said he; "she must have returned to the Louvre."
Title:  
Title:  "You are sure," replied the stranger, "that she did not suspect
Title:  the intentions with which you went out?"
Title:  
Title:  "No," replied Bonacieux, with a self-sufficient air, "she is too
Title:  superficial a woman."
Title:  
Title:  "Is the young Guardsman at home?"
Title:  
Title:  "I do not think he is; as you see, his shutter is closed, and you
Title:  can see no light shine through the chinks of the shutters."
Title:  
Title:  "All the same, it is well to be certain."
Title:  
Title:  "How so?"
Title:  
Title:  "By knocking at his door.  Go."
Title:  
Title:  "I will ask his servant."
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux re-entered the house, passed through the same door that
Title:  had afforded a passage for the two fugitives, went up to
Title:  d'Artagnan's door, and knocked.
Title:  
Title:  No one answered.  Porthos, in order to make a greater display,
Title:  had that evening borrowed Planchet.  As to d'Artagnan, he took
Title:  care not to give the least sign of existence.
Title:  
Title:  The moment the hand of Bonacieux sounded on the door, the two
Title:  young people felt their hearts bound within them.
Title:  
Title:  "There is nobody within," said Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "Never mind.  Let us return to your apartment.  We shall be safer
Title:  there than in the doorway."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my God!" whispered Mme. Bonacieux, "we shall hear no more."
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary," said d'Artagnan, "we shall hear better."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan raised the three or four boards which made his chamber
Title:  another ear of Dionysius, spread a carpet on the floor, went upon
Title:  his knees, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to stoop as he did
Title:  toward the opening.
Title:  
Title:  "You are sure there is nobody there?" said the stranger.
Title:  
Title:  "I will answer for it," said Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "And you think that your wife--"
Title:  
Title:  "Has returned to the Louvre."
Title:  
Title:  "Without speaking to anyone but yourself?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am sure of it."
Title:  
Title:  "That is an important point, do you understand?"
Title:  
Title:  "Then the news I brought you is of value?"
Title:  
Title:  "The greatest, my dear Bonacieux; I don't conceal this from you."
Title:  
Title:  "Then the cardinal will be pleased with me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have no doubt of it."
Title:  
Title:  "The great cardinal!"
Title:  
Title:  "Are you sure, in her conversation with you, that your wife
Title:  mentioned no names?"
Title:  
Title:  "I think not."
Title:  
Title:  "She did not name Madame de Chevreuse, the Duke of Buckingham, or
Title:  Madame de Vernet?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; she only told me she wished to send me to London to serve
Title:  the interests of an illustrious personage."
Title:  
Title:  "The traitor!" murmured Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" said d'Artagnan, taking her hand, which, without
Title:  thinking of it, she abandoned to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Never mind," continued the man in the cloak; "you were a fool
Title:  not to have pretended to accept the mission.  You would then be
Title:  in present possession of the letter.  The state, which is now
Title:  threatened, would be safe, and you--"
Title:  
Title:  "And I?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well you--the cardinal would have given you letters of
Title:  nobility."
Title:  
Title:  "Did he tell you so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I know that he meant to afford you that agreeable
Title:  surprise."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied," replied Bonacieux; "my wife adores me, and there
Title:  is yet time."
Title:  
Title:  "The ninny!" murmured Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" said d'Artagnan, pressing her hand more closely.
Title:  
Title:  "How is there still time?" asked the man in the cloak.
Title:  
Title:  "I go to the Louvre; I ask for Mme. Bonacieux; I say that I have
Title:  reflected; I renew the affair; I obtain the letter, and I run
Title:  directly to the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, go quickly!  I will return soon to learn the result of
Title:  your trip."
Title:  
Title:  The stranger went out.
Title:  
Title:  "Infamous!" said Mme. Bonacieux, addressing this epithet to her
Title:  husband.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" said d'Artagnan, pressing her hand still more warmly.
Title:  
Title:  A terrible howling interrupted these reflections of d'Artagnan
Title:  and Mme. Bonacieux.  It was her husband, who had discovered the
Title:  disappearance of the moneybag, and was crying "Thieves!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!" cried Mme. Bonacieux, "he will rouse the whole
Title:  quarter."
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux called a long time; but as such cries, on account of
Title:  their frequency, brought nobody in the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and as
Title:  lately the mercer's house had a bad name, finding that nobody
Title:  came, he went out continuing to call, his voice being heard
Title:  fainter and fainter as he went in the direction of the Rue du
Title:  Bac.
Title:  
Title:  "Now he is gone, it is your turn to get out," said Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux.  "Courage, my friend, but above all, prudence, and
Title:  think what you owe to the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "To her and to you!" cried d'Artagnan.  "Be satisfied, beautiful
Title:  Constance.  I shall become worthy of her gratitude; but shall I
Title:  likewise return worthy of your love?"
Title:  
Title:  The young woman only replied by the beautiful glow which mounted
Title:  to her cheeks.  A few seconds afterward d'Artagnan also went out
Title:  enveloped in a large cloak, which ill-concealed the sheath of a
Title:  long sword.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux followed him with her eyes, with that long, fond
Title:  look with which he had turned the angle of the street, she fell
Title:  on her knees, and clasping her hands, "Oh, my God," cried she,
Title:  "protect the queen, protect me!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  19  PLAN OF CAMPAIGN
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan went straight to M. de Treville's.  He had reflected
Title:  that in a few minutes the cardinal would be warned by this cursed
Title:  stranger, who appeared to be his agent, and he judged, with
Title:  reason, he had not a moment to lose.
Title:  
Title:  The heart of the young man overflowed with joy.  An opportunity
Title:  presented itself to him in which there would be at the same time
Title:  glory to be acquired, and money to be gained; and as a far higher
Title:  encouragement, it brought him into close intimacy with a woman he
Title:  adored.  This chance did, then, for him at once more than he
Title:  would have dared to ask of Providence.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville was in his saloon with his habitual court of
Title:  gentlemen.  D'Artagnan, who was known as a familiar of the house,
Title:  went straight to his office, and sent word that he wished to see
Title:  him on something of importance.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had been there scarcely five minutes when M. de
Title:  Treville entered.  At the first glance, and by the joy which was
Title:  painted on his countenance, the worthy captain plainly perceived
Title:  that something new was on foot.
Title:  
Title:  All the way along d'Artagnan had been consulting with himself
Title:  whether he should place confidence in M. de Treville, or whether
Title:  he should only ask him to give him CARTE BLANCHE for some secret
Title:  affair.  But M. de Treville had always been so thoroughly his
Title:  friend, had always been so devoted to the king and queen, and
Title:  hated the cardinal so cordially, that the young man resolved to
Title:  tell him everything.
Title:  
Title:  "Did you ask for me, my good friend?" said M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," said d'Artagnan, lowering his voice, "and you
Title:  will pardon me, I hope, for having disturbed you when you know
Title:  the importance of my business."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak, then, I am all attention."
Title:  
Title:  "It concerns nothing less," said d'Artagnan, "than the honor,
Title:  perhaps the life of the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "What did you say?" asked M. de Treville, glancing round to see
Title:  if they were surely alone, and then fixing his questioning look
Title:  upon d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I say, monsieur, that chance has rendered me master of a
Title:  secret--"
Title:  
Title:  "Which you will guard, I hope, young man, as your life."
Title:  
Title:  "But which I must impart to you, monsieur, for you alone can
Title:  assist me in the mission I have just received from her Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "Is this secret your own?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur; it is her Majesty's."
Title:  
Title:  "Are you authorized by her Majesty to communicate it to me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, for, on the contrary, I am desired to preserve the
Title:  profoundest mystery."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, then, are you about to betray it to me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because, as I said, without you I can do nothing; and I am
Title:  afraid you will refuse me the favor I come to ask if you do not
Title:  know to what end I ask it."
Title:  
Title:  "Keep your secret, young man, and tell me what you wish."
Title:  
Title:  "I wish you to obtain for me, from Monsieur Dessessart, leave of
Title:  absence for fifteen days."
Title:  
Title:  "When?"
Title:  
Title:  "This very night."
Title:  
Title:  "You leave Paris?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am going on a mission."
Title:  
Title:  "May you tell me whither?"
Title:  
Title:  "To London."
Title:  
Title:  "Has anyone an interest in preventing your arrival there?"
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal, I believe, would give the world to prevent my
Title:  success."
Title:  
Title:  "And you are going alone?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am going alone."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case you will not get beyond Bondy.  I tell you so, by
Title:  the faith of de Treville."
Title:  
Title:  "How so?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will be assassinated."
Title:  
Title:  "And I shall die in the performance of my duty."
Title:  
Title:  "But your mission will not be accomplished."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true," replied d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Believe me," continued Treville, "in enterprises of this kind,
Title:  in order that one may arrive, four must set out."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you are right, monsieur," said d'Artagnan; "but you know
Title:  Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, and you know if I can dispose of
Title:  them."
Title:  
Title:  "Without confiding to them the secret which I am not willing to
Title:  know?"
Title:  
Title:  "We are sworn, once for all, to implicit confidence and
Title:  devotedness against all proof.  Besides, you can tell them that
Title:  you have full confidence in me, and they will not be more
Title:  incredulous than you."
Title:  
Title:  "I can send to each of them leave of absence for fifteen days,
Title:  that is all--to Athos, whose wound still makes him suffer, to go
Title:  to the waters of Forges; to Porthos and Aramis to accompany their
Title:  friend, whom they are not willing to abandon in such a painful
Title:  condition.  Sending their leave of absence will be proof enough
Title:  that I authorize their journey."
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, monsieur.  You are a hundred times too good."
Title:  
Title:  "Begone, then, find them instantly, and let all be done tonight!
Title:  Ha!  But first write your request to Dessessart.  Perhaps you had
Title:  a spy at your heels; and your visit, if it should ever be known
Title:  to the cardinal, will thus seem legitimate."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan drew up his request, and M. de Treville, on receiving
Title:  it, assured him that by two o'clock in the morning the four
Title:  leaves of absence should be at the respective domiciles of the
Title:  travelers.
Title:  
Title:  "Have the goodness to send mine to Athos's residence.  I should
Title:  dread some disagreeable encounter if I were to go home."
Title:  
Title:  "Be easy.  Adieu, and a prosperous voyage.  A PROPOS," said M. de
Title:  Treville, calling him back.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan returned.
Title:  
Title:  "Have you any money?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan tapped the bag he had in his pocket.
Title:  
Title:  "Enough?" asked M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "Three hundred pistoles."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, plenty!  That would carry you to the end of the world.
Title:  Begone, then!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan saluted M. de Treville, who held out his hand to him;
Title:  d'Artagnan pressed it with a respect mixed with gratitude.  Since
Title:  his first arrival at Paris, he had had constant occasion to honor
Title:  this excellent man, whom he had always found worthy, loyal, and
Title:  great.
Title:  
Title:  His first visit was to Aramis, at whose residence he had not been
Title:  since the famous evening on which he had followed Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  Still further, he had seldom seen the young Musketeer; but every
Title:  time he had seen him, he had remarked a deep sadness imprinted on
Title:  his countenance.
Title:  
Title:  This evening, especially, Aramis was melancholy and thoughtful.
Title:  d'Artagnan asked some questions about this prolonged melancholy.
Title:  Aramis pleaded as his excuse a commentary upon the eighteenth
Title:  chapter of St. Augustine, which he was forced to write in Latin
Title:  for the following week, and which preoccupied him a good deal.
Title:  
Title:  After the two friends had been chatting a few moments, a servant
Title:  from M. de Treville entered, bringing a sealed packet.
Title:  
Title:  "What is that?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "The leave of absence Monsieur has asked for," replied the
Title:  lackey.
Title:  
Title:  "For me!  I have asked for no leave of absence."
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue and take it!" said d'Artagnan.  "And you, my
Title:  friend, there is a demipistole for your trouble; you will tell
Title:  Monsieur de Treville that Monsieur Aramis is very much obliged to
Title:  him.  Go."
Title:  
Title:  The lackey bowed to the ground and departed.
Title:  
Title:  "What does all this mean?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Pack up all you want for a journey of a fortnight, and follow
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "But I cannot leave Paris just now without knowing--"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis stopped.
Title:  
Title:  "What is become of her?  I suppose you mean--" continued
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Become of whom?" replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "The woman who was here--the woman with the embroidered
Title:  handkerchief."
Title:  
Title:  "Who told you there was a woman here?" replied Aramis, becoming
Title:  as pale as death.
Title:  
Title:  "I saw her."
Title:  
Title:  "And you know who she is?"
Title:  
Title:  "I believe I can guess, at least."
Title:  
Title:  "Listen!" said Aramis.  "Since you appear to know so many things,
Title:  can you tell me what is become of that woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "I presume that she has returned to Tours."
Title:  
Title:  "To Tours?  Yes, that may be.  You evidently know her.  But why
Title:  did she return to Tours without telling me anything?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because she was in fear of being arrested."
Title:  
Title:  "Why has she not written to me, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because she was afraid of compromising you."
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan, you restore me to life!" cried Aramis.  "I fancied
Title:  myself despised, betrayed.  I was so delighted to see her again!
Title:  I could not have believed she would risk her liberty for me, and
Title:  yet for what other cause could she have returned to Paris?"
Title:  
Title:  "For the cause which today takes us to England."
Title:  
Title:  "And what is this cause?" demanded Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you'll know it someday, Aramis; but at present I must
Title:  imitate the discretion of 'the doctor's niece.'"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis smiled, as he remembered the tale he had told his friends
Title:  on a certain evening.  "Well, then, since she has left Paris, and
Title:  you are sure of it, d'Artagnan, nothing prevents me, and I am
Title:  ready to follow you.  You say we are going--"
Title:  
Title:  "To see Athos now, and if you will come thither, I beg you to
Title:  make haste, for we have lost much time already.  A PROPOS, inform
Title:  Bazin."
Title:  
Title:  "Will Bazin go with us?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps so.  At all events, it is best that he should follow us
Title:  to Athos's."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis called Bazin, and, after having ordered him to join them
Title:  at Athos's residence, said "Let us go then," at the same time
Title:  taking his cloak, sword, and three pistols, opening uselessly two
Title:  or three drawers to see if he could not find stray coin.  When
Title:  well assured this search was superfluous, he followed d'Artagnan,
Title:  wondering to himself how this young Guardsman should know so well
Title:  who the lady was to whom he had given hospitality, and that he
Title:  should know better than himself what had become of her.
Title:  
Title:  Only as they went out Aramis placed his hand upon the arm of
Title:  d'Artagnan, and looking at him earnestly, "You have not spoken of
Title:  this lady?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "To nobody in the world."
Title:  
Title:  "Not even to Athos or Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have not breathed a syllable to them."
Title:  
Title:  "Good enough!"
Title:  
Title:  Tranquil on this important point, Aramis continued his way with
Title:  d'Artagnan, and both soon arrived at Athos's dwelling.  They
Title:  found him holding his leave of absence in one hand, and M. de
Title:  Treville's note in the other.
Title:  
Title:  "Can you explain to me what signify this leave of absence and
Title:  this letter, which I have just received?" said the astonished
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  My dear Athos,
Title:  
Title:  I wish, as your health absolutely requires it,
Title:  that you should rest for a fortnight.  Go, then, and take the
Title:  waters of Forges, or any that may be more agreeable to you, and
Title:  recuperate yourself as quickly as possible.
Title:  
Title:  Yours affectionate
Title:  
Title:  de Treville
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Well, this leave of absence and that letter mean that you must
Title:  follow me, Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "To the waters of Forges?"
Title:  
Title:  "There or elsewhere."
Title:  
Title:  "In the king's service?"
Title:  
Title:  "Either the king's or the queen's.  Are we not their Majesties'
Title:  servants?"
Title:  
Title:  At that moment Porthos entered.  "PARDIEU!" said he, "here is a
Title:  strange thing!  Since when, I wonder, in the Musketeers, did they
Title:  grant men leave of absence without their asking for it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Since," said d'Artagnan, "they have friends who ask it for
Title:  them."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Porthos, "it appears there's something fresh
Title:  here."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, we are going--" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "To what country?" demanded Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!  I don't know much about it," said Athos.  "Ask
Title:  d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "To London, gentlemen," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "To London!" cried Porthos; "and what the devil are we going to
Title:  do in London?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is what I am not at liberty to tell you, gentlemen; you
Title:  must trust to me."
Title:  
Title:  "But in order to go to London," added Porthos, "money is needed,
Title:  and I have none."
Title:  
Title:  "Nor I," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Nor I," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I have," replied d'Artagnan, pulling out his treasure from his
Title:  pocket, and placing it on the table.  "There are in this bag
Title:  three hundred pistoles.  Let each take seventy-five; that is
Title:  enough to take us to London and back.  Besides, make yourselves
Title:  easy; we shall not all arrive at London."
Title:  
Title:  "Why so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because, in all probability, some one of us will be left on the
Title:  road."
Title:  
Title:  "Is this, then, a campaign upon which we are now entering?"
Title:  
Title:  "One of a most dangerous kind, I give you notice."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  But if we do risk being killed," said Porthos, "at least I
Title:  should like to know what for."
Title:  
Title:  "You would be all the wiser," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," said Aramis, "I am somewhat of Porthos's opinion."
Title:  
Title:  "Is the king accustomed to give you such reasons?  No.  He says
Title:  to you jauntily, 'Gentlemen, there is fighting going on in
Title:  Gascony or in Flanders; go and fight,' and you go there.  Why?
Title:  You need give yourselves no more uneasiness about this."
Title:
