Title:  "d'Artagnan is right," said Athos; "here are our three leaves of
Title:  absence which came from Monsieur de Treville, and here are three
Title:  hundred pistoles which came from I don't know where.  So let us
Title:  go and get killed where we are told to go.  Is life worth the
Title:  trouble of so many questions?  D'Artagnan, I am ready to follow
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "And I also," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "And I also," said Aramis.  "And, indeed, I am not sorry to quit
Title:  Paris; I had need of distraction."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, you will have distractions enough, gentlemen, be assured,"
Title:  said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And, now, when are we to go?" asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Immediately," replied d'Artagnan; "we have not a minute to
Title:  lose."
Title:  
Title:  "Hello, Grimaud!  Planchet!  Mousqueton!  Bazin!" cried the four
Title:  young men, calling their lackeys, "clean my boots, and fetch the
Title:  horses from the hotel."
Title:  
Title:  Each Musketeer was accustomed to leave at the general hotel, as
Title:  at a barrack, his own horse and that of his lackey.  Planchet,
Title:  Grimaud, Mousqueton, and Bazin set off at full speed.
Title:  
Title:  "Now let us lay down the plan of campaign," said Porthos.  "Where
Title:  do we go first?"
Title:  
Title:  "To Calais," said d'Artagnan; "that is the most direct line to
Title:  London."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos, "this is my advice--"
Title:  
Title:  "Speak!"
Title:  
Title:  "Four men traveling together would be suspected.  D'Artagnan will
Title:  give each of us his instructions.  I will go by the way of
Title:  Boulogne to clear the way; Athos will set out two hours after, by
Title:  that of Amiens; Aramis will follow us by that of Noyon; as to
Title:  d'Artagnan, he will go by what route he thinks is best, in
Title:  Planchet's clothes, while Planchet will follow us like
Title:  d'Artagnan, in the uniform of the Guards."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Athos, "my opinion is that it is not proper to
Title:  allow lackeys to have anything to do in such an affair.  A secret
Title:  may, by chance, be betrayed by gentlemen; but it is almost
Title:  always sold by lackeys."
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos's plan appears to me to be impracticable," said
Title:  d'Artagnan, "inasmuch as I am myself ignorant of what
Title:  instructions I can give you.  I am the bearer of a letter, that
Title:  is all.  I have not, and I cannot make three copies of that
Title:  letter, because it is sealed.  We must, then, as it appears to
Title:  me, travel in company.  This letter is here, in this pocket," and
Title:  he pointed to the pocket which contained the letter.  "If I
Title:  should be killed, one of you must take it, and continue the
Title:  route; if he be killed, it will be another's turn, and so on--
Title:  provided a single one arrives, that is all that is required."
Title:  
Title:  "Bravo, d'Artagnan, your opinion is mine," cried Athos, "Besides,
Title:  we must be consistent; I am going to take the waters, you will
Title:  accompany me.  Instead of taking the waters of Forges, I go and
Title:  take sea waters; I am free to do so.  If anyone wishes to stop
Title:  us, I will show Monsieur de Treville's letter, and you will show
Title:  your leaves of absence.  If we are attacked, we will defend
Title:  ourselves; if we are tried, we will stoutly maintain that we were
Title:  only anxious to dip ourselves a certain number of times in the
Title:  sea.  They would have an easy bargain of four isolated men;
Title:  whereas four men together make a troop.  We will arm our four
Title:  lackeys with pistols and musketoons; if they send an army out
Title:  against us, we will give battle, and the survivor, as d'Artagnan
Title:  says, will carry the letter."
Title:  
Title:  "Well said," cried Aramis; "you don't often speak, Athos, but
Title:  when you do speak, it is like St. John of the Golden Mouth.  I
Title:  agree to Athos's plan.  And you, Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "I agree to it, too," said Porthos, "if d'Artagnan approves of
Title:  it.  D'Artagnan, being the bearer of the letter, is naturally the
Title:  head of the enterprise; let him decide, and we will execute."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said d'Artagnan, "I decide that we should adopt Athos's
Title:  plan, and that we set off in half an hour."
Title:  
Title:  "Agreed!" shouted the three Musketeers in chorus.
Title:  
Title:  Each one, stretching out his hand to the bag, took his seventy-
Title:  five pistoles, and made his preparations to set out at the time
Title:  appointed.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  20  THE JOURNEY
Title:  
Title:  At two o'clock in the morning, our four adventurers left Paris by
Title:  the Barriere St. Denis.  As long as it was dark they remained
Title:  silent; in spite of themselves they submitted to the influence of
Title:  the obscurity, and apprehended ambushes on every side.
Title:  
Title:  With the first rays of day their tongues were loosened; with the
Title:  sun gaiety revived.  It was like the eve of a battle; the heart
Title:  beat, the eyes laughed, and they felt that the life they were
Title:  perhaps going to lose, was, after all, a good thing.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, the appearance of the caravan was formidable.  The black
Title:  horses of the Musketeers, their martial carriage, with the
Title:  regimental step of these noble companions of the soldier, would
Title:  have betrayed the most strict incognito.  The lackeys followed,
Title:  armed to the teeth.
Title:  
Title:  All went well till they arrived at Chantilly, which they reached
Title:  about eight o'clock in the morning.  They needed breakfast, and
Title:  alighted at the door of an AUBERGE, recommended by a sign
Title:  representing St. Martin giving half his cloak to a poor man.
Title:  They ordered the lackeys not to unsaddle the horses, and to hold
Title:  themselves in readiness to set off again immediately.
Title:  
Title:  They entered the common hall, and placed themselves at table.  A
Title:  gentleman, who had just arrived by the route of Dammartin, was
Title:  seated at the same table, and was breakfasting.  He opened the
Title:  conversation about rain and fine weather; the travelers replied.
Title:  He drank to their good health, and the travelers returned his
Title:  politeness.
Title:  
Title:  But at the moment Mousqueton came to announce that the horses
Title:  were ready, and they were arising from table, the stranger
Title:  proposed to Porthos to drink the health of the cardinal.  Porthos
Title:  replied that he asked no better if the stranger, in his turn,
Title:  would drink the health of the king.  The stranger cried that he
Title:  acknowledged no other king but his Eminence.  Porthos called him
Title:  drunk, and the stranger drew his sword.
Title:  
Title:  "You have committed a piece of folly," said Athos, "but it can't
Title:  be helped; there is no drawing back.  Kill the fellow, and rejoin
Title:  us as soon as you can."
Title:  
Title:  All three remounted their horses, and set out at a good pace,
Title:  while Porthos was promising his adversary to perforate him with
Title:  all the thrusts known in the fencing schools.
Title:  
Title:  "There goes one!" cried Athos, at the end of five hundred paces.
Title:  
Title:  "But why did that man attack Porthos rather than any other one of
Title:  us?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Because, as Porthos was talking louder than the rest of us, he
Title:  took him for the chief," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I always said that this cadet from Gascony was a well of
Title:  wisdom," murmured Athos; and the travelers continued their route.
Title:  
Title:  At Beauvais they stopped two hours, as well to breathe their
Title:  horses a little as to wait for Porthos.  At the end of two hours,
Title:  as Porthos did not come, not any news of him, they resumed their
Title:  journey.
Title:  
Title:  At a league from Beauvais, where the road was confined between
Title:  two high banks, they fell in with eight or ten men who, taking
Title:  advantage of the road being unpaved in this spot, appeared to be
Title:  employed in digging holes and filling up the ruts with mud.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, not liking to soil his boots with this artificial mortar,
Title:  apostrophized them rather sharply.  Athos wished to restrain him,
Title:  but it was too late.  The laborers began to jeer the travelers
Title:  and by their insolence disturbed the equanimity even of the cool
Title:  Athos, who urged on his horse against one of them.
Title:  
Title:  Then each of these men retreated as far as the ditch, from which
Title:  each took a concealed musket; the result was that our seven
Title:  travelers were outnumbered in weapons.  Aramis received a ball
Title:  which passed through his shoulder, and Mousqueton another ball
Title:  which lodged in the fleshy part which prolongs the lower portion
Title:  of the loins.  Therefore Mousqueton alone fell from his horse,
Title:  not because he was severely wounded, but not being able to see
Title:  the wound, he judged it to be more serious than it really was.
Title:  
Title:  "It was an ambuscade!" shouted d'Artagnan.  "Don't waste a
Title:  charge!  Forward!"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, wounded as he was, seized the mane of his horse, which
Title:  carried him on with the others.  Mousqueton's horse rejoined
Title:  them, and galloped by the side of his companions.
Title:  
Title:  "That will serve us for a relay," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I would rather have had a hat," said d'Artagnan.  "Mine was
Title:  carried away by a ball.  By my faith, it is very fortunate that
Title:  the letter was not in it."
Title:  
Title:  "They'll kill poor Porthos when he comes up," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "If Porthos were on his legs, he would have rejoined us by this
Title:  time," said Athos.  "My opinion is that on the ground the drunken
Title:  man was not intoxicated."
Title:  
Title:  They continued at their best speed for two hours, although the
Title:  horses were so fatigued that it was to be feared they would soon
Title:  refuse service.
Title:  
Title:  The travelers had chosen crossroads in the hope that they might
Title:  meet with less interruption; but at Crevecoeur, Aramis declared
Title:  he could proceed no farther.  In fact, it required all the
Title:  courage which he concealed beneath his elegant form and polished
Title:  manners to bear him so far.  He grew more pale every minute, and
Title:  they were obliged to support him on his horse.  They lifted him
Title:  off at the door of a cabaret, left Bazin with him, who, besides,
Title:  in a skirmish was more embarrassing than useful, and set forward
Title:  again in the hope of sleeping at Amiens.
Title:  
Title:  "MORBLEU," said Athos, as soon as they were again in motion,
Title:  "reduced to two masters and Grimaud and Planchet!  MORBLEU!  I
Title:  won't be their dupe, I will answer for it.  I will neither open
Title:  my mouth nor draw my sword between this and Calais.  I swear
Title:  by--"
Title:  
Title:  "Don't waste time in swearing," said d'Artagnan; "let us gallop,
Title:  if our horses will consent."
Title:  
Title:  And the travelers buried their rowels in their horses' flanks,
Title:  who thus vigorously stimulated recovered their energies.  They
Title:  arrived at Amiens at midnight, and alighted at the AUBERGE of the
Title:  Golden Lily.
Title:  
Title:  The host had the appearance of as honest a man as any on earth.
Title:  He received the travelers with his candlestick in one hand and
Title:  his cotton nightcap in the other.  He wished to lodge the two
Title:  travelers each in a charming chamber; but unfortunately these
Title:  charming chambers were at the opposite extremities of the hotel.
Title:  d'Artagnan and Athos refused them.  The host replied that he had
Title:  no other worthy of their Excellencies; but the travelers declared
Title:  they would sleep in the common chamber, each on a mattress which
Title:  might be thrown upon the ground.  The host insisted; but the
Title:  travelers were firm, and he was obliged to do as they wished.
Title:  
Title:  They had just prepared their beds and barricaded their door
Title:  within, when someone knocked at the yard shutter; they demanded
Title:  who was there, and recognizing the voices of their lackeys,
Title:  opened the shutter.  It was indeed Planchet and Grimaud.
Title:  
Title:  "Grimaud can take care of the horses," said Planchet.  "If you
Title:  are willing, gentlemen, I will sleep across your doorway, and you
Title:  will then be certain that nobody can reach you."
Title:  
Title:  "And on what will you sleep?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Here is my bed," replied Planchet, producing a bundle of straw.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, then," said d'Artagnan, "you are right.  Mine host's face
Title:  does not please me at all; it is too gracious."
Title:  
Title:  "Nor me either," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet mounted by the window and installed himself across the
Title:  doorway, while Grimaud went and shut himself up in the stable,
Title:  undertaking that by five o'clock in the morning he and the four
Title:  horses should be ready.
Title:  
Title:  The night was quiet enough.  Toward two o'clock in the morning
Title:  somebody endeavored to open the door; but as Planchet awoke in an
Title:  instant and cried, "Who goes there?" somebody replied that he was
Title:  mistaken, and went away.
Title:  
Title:  At four o'clock in the morning they heard a terrible riot in the
Title:  stables.  Grimaud had tried to waken the stable boys, and the
Title:  stable boys had beaten him.  When they opened the window, they
Title:  saw the poor lad lying senseless, with his head split by a blow
Title:  with a pitchfork.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet went down into the yard, and wished to saddle the
Title:  horses; but the horses were all used up.  Mousqueton's horse
Title:  which had traveled for five or six hours without a rider the day
Title:  before, might have been able to pursue the journey; but by an
Title:  inconceivable error the veterinary surgeon, who had been sent
Title:  for, as it appeared, to bleed one of the host's horses, had bled
Title:  Mousqueton's.
Title:  
Title:  This began to be annoying.  All these successive accidents were
Title:  perhaps the result of chance; but they might be the fruits of a
Title:  plot.  Athos and d'Artagnan went out, while Planchet was sent to
Title:  inquire if there were not three horses for sale in the
Title:  neighborhood.  At the door stood two horses, fresh, strong, and
Title:  fully equipped.  These would just have suited them.  He asked
Title:  where their masters were, and was informed that they had passed
Title:  the night in the inn, and were then settling their bill with the
Title:  host.
Title:  
Title:  Athos went down to pay the reckoning, while d'Artagnan and
Title:  Planchet stood at the street door.  The host was in a lower and
Title:  back room, to which Athos was requested to go.
Title:  
Title:  Athos entered without the least mistrust, and took out two
Title:  pistoles to pay the bill.  The host was alone, seated before his
Title:  desk, one of the drawers of which was partly open.  He took the
Title:  money which Athos offered to him, and after turning and turning
Title:  it over and over in his hands, suddenly cried out that it was
Title:  bad, and that he would have him and his companions arrested as
Title:  forgers.
Title:  
Title:  "You blackguard!" cried Athos, going toward him, "I'll cut your
Title:  ears off!"
Title:  
Title:  At the same instant, four men, armed to the teeth, entered by
Title:  side doors, and rushed upon Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I am taken!" shouted Athos, with all the power of his lungs.
Title:  "Go on, d'Artagnan!  Spur, spur!" and he fired two pistols.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan and Planchet did not require twice bidding; they
Title:  unfastened the two horses that were waiting at the door, leaped
Title:  upon them, buried their spurs in their sides, and set off at full
Title:  gallop.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know what has become of Athos?" asked d'Artagnan of
Title:  Planchet, as they galloped on.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur," said Planchet, "I saw one fall at each of his two
Title:  shots, and he appeared to me, through the glass door, to be
Title:  fighting with his sword with the others."
Title:  
Title:  "Brave Athos!" murmured d'Artagnan, "and to think that we are
Title:  compelled to leave him; maybe the same fate awaits us two paces
Title:  hence.  Forward, Planchet, forward!  You are a brave fellow."
Title:  
Title:  "As I told you, monsieur," replied Planchet, "Picards are found
Title:  out by being used.  Besides, I am here in my own country, and
Title:  that excites me."
Title:  
Title:  And both, with free use of the spur, arrived at St. Omer without
Title:  drawing bit.  At St. Omer they breathed their horses with the
Title:  bridles passed under their arms for fear of accident, and ate a
Title:  morsel from their hands on the stones of the street, after they
Title:  departed again.
Title:  
Title:  At a hundred paces from the gates of Calais, d'Artagnan's horse
Title:  gave out, and could not by any means be made to get up again, the
Title:  blood flowing from his eyes and his nose.  There still remained
Title:  Planchet's horse; but he stopped short, and could not be made to
Title:  move a step.
Title:  
Title:  Fortunately, as we have said, they were within a hundred paces of
Title:  the city; they left their two nags upon the high road, and ran
Title:  toward the quay.  Planchet called his master's attention to a
Title:  gentleman who had just arrived with his lackey, and only preceded
Title:  them by about fifty paces.  They made all speed to come up to
Title:  this gentleman, who appeared to be in great haste.  His boots
Title:  were covered with dust, and he inquired if he could not instantly
Title:  cross over to England.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing would be more easy," said the captain of a vessel ready
Title:  to set sail, "but this morning came an order to let no one leave
Title:  without express permission from the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "I have that permission," said the gentleman, drawing the paper
Title:  from his pocket; "here it is."
Title:  
Title:  "Have it examined by the governor of the port," said the
Title:  shipmaster, "and give me the preference."
Title:  
Title:  "Where shall I find the governor?"
Title:  
Title:  "At his country house."
Title:  
Title:  "And that is situated?"
Title:  
Title:  "At a quarter of a league from the city.  Look, you may see it

Title:  
Title:  "Very well," said the gentleman. And, with his lackey, he took

Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan and Planchet followed the gentleman at a distance of

Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, you appear to be in great haste?"
Title:  
Title:  "No one can be more so, monsieur."

Title:  "I am sorry for that," said d'Artagnan; "for as I am in great

Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "To let me sail first."
Title:  
Title:  "That's impossible," said the gentleman; "I have traveled sixty
Title:  leagues in forty hours, and by tomorrow at midday I must be in
Title:  London."
Title:  
Title:  "I have performed that same distance in forty hours, and by ten
Title:  o'clock in the morning I must be in London."
Title:  
Title:  "Very sorry, monsieur; but I was here first, and will not sail

Title:  
Title:  "I am sorry, too, monsieur; but I arrived second, and must sail

Title:

Title:  
Title:  "PARBLEU!  What do you desire it to be?"
Title:  
Title:  "What do you want?"

Title:  "Would you like to know?"

Title:  "Certainly."

Title:  "Well, then, I wish that order of which you are bearer, seeing

Title:  "Let me pass!"
Title:  
Title:  "You shall not pass."
Title:  
Title:  "My brave young man, I will blow out your brains.  HOLA, Lubin,

Title:  
Title:  "Planchet," called out d'Artagnan, "take care of the lackey; I

Title:  
Title:  Planchet, emboldened by the first exploit, sprang upon Lubin; and
Title:  being strong and vigorous, he soon got him on the broad of his
Title:  back, and placed his knee upon his breast.
Title:  
Title:  "Go on with your affair, monsieur," cried Planchet; "I have
Title:  finished mine."
Title:  
Title:  Seeing this, the gentleman drew his sword, and sprang upon
Title:  d'Artagnan; but he had too strong an adversary.  In three seconds

Title:  thrust, "One for Athos, one for Porthos; and one for Aramis!"
Title:  
Title:  At the third hit the gentleman fell like a log.  D'Artagnan
Title:  believed him to be dead, or at least insensible, and went toward

Title:  crying, "One for you!"
Title:  
Title:  "And one for me--the best for last!" cried d'Artagnan, furious,
Title:  nailing him to the earth with a fourth thrust through his body.
Title:  
Title:  This time the gentleman closed his eyes and fainted.  D'Artagnan
Title:  searched his pockets, and took from one of them the order for the
Title:  passage.  It was in the name of Comte de Wardes.
Title:  
Title:  Then, casting a glance on the handsome young man, who was
Title:  scarcely twenty-five years of age, and whom he was leaving in his
Title:  gore, deprived of sense and perhaps dead, he gave a sigh for that
Title:  unaccountable destiny which leads men to destroy each other for
Title:  the interests of people who are strangers to them and who often
Title:  do not even know that they exist.  But he was soon aroused from

Title:  
Title:  Planchet grasped him by the throat, and pressed as hard as he

Title:  manner, he can't cry, I'll be bound; but as soon as I let go he
Title:  will howl again.  I know him for a Norman, and Normans are
Title:  obstinate."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, tightly held as he was, Lubin endeavored still to cry
Title:  out.
Title:  
Title:  "Stay!" said d'Artagnan; and taking out his handkerchief, he
Title:  gagged him.

Title:  "Now," said Planchet, "let us bind him to a tree."
Title:  
Title:  This being properly done, they drew the Comte de Wardes close to
Title:  his servant; and as night was approaching, and as the wounded man
Title:  and the bound man were at some little distance within the wood,

Title:  And they both set forward as fast as they could toward the

Title:  
Title:  The Comte de Wardes was announced, and d'Artagnan was introduced.
Title:  
Title:  "You have an order signed by the cardinal?" said the governor.

Title:  "Yes, monsieur," replied d'Artagnan; "here it is."

Title:  "Without a doubt."

Title:  "Tell him, I beg you, that I am his humble servant."

Title:  "I will not fail."

Title:  Delighted with this assurance the governor countersigned the

Title:  
Title:  The vessel was quite ready to sail, and the captain was waiting
Title:  on the wharf.  "Well?" said he, on perceiving d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Here is my pass countersigned," said the latter.
Title:  
Title:  "And that other gentleman?
Title:  
Title:  "He will not go today," said d'Artagnan; "but here, I'll pay you
Title:  for us two."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case let us go," said the shipmaster.
Title:  
Title:  "Let us go," repeated d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  He leaped with Planchet into the boat, and five minutes after
Title:  they were on board.  It was time; for they had scarcely sailed
Title:  half a league, when d'Artagnan saw a flash and heard a
Title:  detonation.  It was the cannon which announced the closing of the
Title:  port.
Title:  
Title:  He had now leisure to look to his wound.  Fortunately, as
Title:  d'Artagnan had thought, it was not dangerous.  The point of the
Title:  sword had touched a rib, and glanced along the bone.  Still
Title:  further, his shirt had stuck to the wound, and he had lost only
Title:  a few drops of blood.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was worn out with fatigue.  A mattress was laid upon
Title:  the deck for him.  He threw himself upon it, and fell asleep.
Title:  
Title:  On the morrow, at break of day, they were still three or four
Title:  leagues from the coast of England.  The breeze had been so light
Title:  all night, they had made but little progress.  At ten o'clock the
Title:  vessel cast anchor in the harbor of Dover, and at half past ten
Title:  d'Artagnan placed his foot on English land, crying, "Here I am at
Title:  last!"
Title:  
Title:  But that was not all; they must get to London.  In England the
Title:  post was well served.  D'Artagnan and Planchet took each a post
Title:  horse, and a postillion rode before them.  In a few hours they
Title:  were in the capital.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan did not know London; he did not know a word of
Title:  English; but he wrote the name of Buckingham on a piece of paper,
Title:  and everyone pointed out to him the way to the duke's hotel.
Title:  
Title:  The duke was at Windsor hunting with the king.  D'Artagnan
Title:  inquired for the confidential valet of the duke, who, having
Title:  accompanied him in all his voyages, spoke French perfectly well;
Title:  he told him that he came from Paris on an affair of life and
Title:  death, and that he must speak with his master instantly.
Title:  
Title:  The confidence with which d'Artagnan spoke convinced Patrick,
Title:  which was the name of this minister of the minister.  He ordered
Title:  two horses to be saddled, and himself went as guide to the young
Title:  Guardsman.  As for Planchet, he had been lifted from his horse as
Title:  stiff as a rush; the poor lad's strength was almost exhausted.
Title:  d'Artagnan seemed iron.
Title:  
Title:  On their arrival at the castle they learned that Buckingham and
Title:  the king were hawking in the marshes two or three leagues away.
Title:  In twenty minutes they were on the spot named.  Patrick soon
Title:  caught the sound of his master's voice calling his falcon.
Title:  
Title:  "Whom must I announce to my Lord Duke?" asked Patrick.
Title:  
Title:  "The young man who one evening sought a quarrel with him on the
Title:  Pont Neuf, opposite the Samaritaine."
Title:  
Title:  "A singular introduction!"
Title:  
Title:  "You will find that it is as good as another."
Title:  
Title:  Patrick galloped off, reached the duke, and announced to him in
Title:  the terms directed that a messenger awaited him.
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham at once remembered the circumstance, and suspecting
Title:  that something was going on in France of which it was necessary
Title:  he should be informed, he only took the time to inquire where the
Title:  messenger was, and recognizing from afar the uniform of the
Title:  Guards, he put his horse into a gallop, and rode straight up to
Title:  d'Artagnan.  Patrick discreetly kept in the background.
Title:  
Title:  "No misfortune has happened to the queen?" cried Buckingham, the
Title:  instant he came up, throwing all his fear and love into the
Title:  question.
Title:  
Title:  "I believe not; nevertheless I believe she runs some great peril
Title:  from which your Grace alone can extricate her."
Title:  
Title:  "I!" cried Buckingham.  "What is it?  I should be too happy to be
Title:  of any service to her.  Speak, speak!"
Title:  
Title:  "Take this letter," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "This letter!  From whom comes this letter?"
Title:  
Title:  "From her Majesty, as I think."
Title:  
Title:  "From her Majesty!" said Buckingham, becoming so pale that
Title:  d'Artagnan feared he would faint as he broke the seal.
Title:  
Title:  "What is this rent?" said he, showing d'Artagnan a place where it
Title:  had been pierced through.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said d'Artagnan, "I did not see that; it was the sword of
Title:  the Comte de Wardes which made that hole, when he gave me a good
Title:  thrust in the breast."
Title:  
Title:  "You are wounded?" asked Buckingham, as he opened the letter.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, nothing but a scratch," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Just heaven, what have I read?" cried the duke.  "Patrick,
Title:  remain here, or rather join the king, wherever he may be, and
Title:  tell his Majesty that I humbly beg him to excuse me, but an
Title:  affair of the greatest importance recalls me to London.  Come,
Title:  monsieur, come!" and both set off towards the capital at full

Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  21  THE COUNTESS DE WINTER
Title:  
Title:  As they rode along, the duke endeavored to draw from d'Artagnan,
Title:  not all that had happened, but what d'Artagnan himself knew.  By
Title:  adding all that he heard from the mouth of the young man to his
Title:  own remembrances, he was enabled to form a pretty exact idea of a
Title:  position of the seriousness of which, for the rest, the queen's
Title:  letter, short but explicit, gave him the clue.  But that which
Title:  astonished him most was that the cardinal, so deeply interested
Title:  in preventing this young man from setting his foot in England,
Title:  had not succeeded in arresting him on the road.  It was then,
Title:  upon the manifestation of this astonishment, that d'Artagnan
Title:  related to him the precaution taken, and how, thanks to the
Title:  devotion of his three friends, whom he had left scattered and
Title:  bleeding on the road, he had succeeded in coming off with a
Title:  single sword thrust, which had pierced the queen's letter and for
Title:  which he had repaid M. de Wardes with such terrible coin.  While
Title:  he was listening to this recital, delivered with the greatest
Title:  simplicity, the duke looked from time to time at the young man
Title:  with astonishment, as if he could not comprehend how so much
Title:  prudence, courage, and devotedness could be allied with a
Title:  countenance which indicated not more than twenty years.
Title:  
Title:  The horses went like the wind, and in a few minutes they were at
Title:  the gates of London.  D'Artagnan imagined that on arriving in
Title:  town the duke would slacken his pace, but it was not so.  He kept
Title:  on his way at the same rate, heedless about upsetting those whom
Title:  he met on the road.  In fact, in crossing the city two or three
Title:  accidents of this kind happened; but Buckingham did not even turn
Title:  his head to see what became of those he had knocked down.
Title:  d'Artagnan followed him amid cries which strongly resembled
Title:  curses.
Title:  
Title:  On entering the court of his hotel, Buckingham sprang from his
Title:  horse, and without thinking what became of the animal, threw the
Title:  bridle on his neck, and sprang toward the vestibule.  D'Artagnan
Title:  did the same, with a little more concern, however, for the noble
Title:  creatures, whose merits he fully appreciated; but he had the
Title:  satisfaction of seeing three or four grooms run from the kitchens
Title:  and the stables, and busy themselves with the steeds.
Title:  
Title:  The duke walked so fast that d'Artagnan had some trouble in
Title:  keeping up with him.  He passed through several apartments, of an
Title:  elegance of which even the greatest nobles of France had not even
Title:  an idea, and arrived at length in a bedchamber which was at once
Title:  a miracle of taste and of richness.  In the alcove of this
Title:  chamber was a door concealed in the tapestry which the duke
Title:  opened with a little gold key which he wore suspended from his
Title:  neck by a chain of the same metal.  With discretion d'Artagnan
Title:  remained behind; but at the moment when Buckingham crossed the
Title:  threshold, he turned round, and seeing the hesitation of the
Title:  young man, "Come in!" cried he, "and if you have the good fortune
Title:  to be admitted to her Majesty's presence, tell her what you have
Title:  seen."
Title:  
Title:  Encouraged by this invitation, d'Artagnan followed the duke, who
Title:  closed the door after them.  The two found themselves in a small
Title:  chapel covered with a tapestry of Persian silk worked with gold,
Title:  and brilliantly lighted with a vast number of candles.  Over a
Title:  species of altar, and beneath a canopy of blue velvet, surmounted
Title:  by white and red plumes, was a full-length portrait of Anne of
Title:  Austria, so perfect in its resemblance that d'Artagnan uttered a
Title:  cry of surprise on beholding it.  One might believe the queen was
Title:  about to speak.  On the altar, and beneath the portrait, was the
Title:  casket containing the diamond studs.
Title:  
Title:  The duke approached the altar, knelt as a priest might have done
Title:  before a crucifix, and opened the casket.  "There," said he,
Title:  drawing from the casket a large bow of blue ribbon all sparkling
Title:  with diamonds, "there are the precious studs which I have taken
Title:  an oath should be buried with me.  The queen gave them to me, the
Title:  queen requires them again.  Her will be done, like that of God,
Title:  in all things."
Title:  
Title:  Then, he began to kiss, one after the other, those dear studs
Title:  with which he was about to part.  All at once he uttered a
Title:  terrible cry.
Title:  
Title:  "What is the matter?" exclaimed d'Artagnan, anxiously; "what has
Title:  happened to you, my Lord?"
Title:  
Title:  "All is lost!" cried Buckingham, becoming as pale as a corpse;
Title:  "two of the studs are wanting, there are only ten."
Title:  
Title:  "Can you have lost them, my Lord, or do you think they have been
Title:  stolen?"
Title:  
Title:  "They have been stolen," replied the duke, "and it is the
Title:  cardinal who has dealt this blow.  Hold; see!  The ribbons which
Title:  held them have been cut with scissors."
Title:  
Title:  "If my Lord suspects they have been stolen, perhaps the person
Title:  who stole them still has them in his hands."
Title:  
Title:  "Wait, wait!" said the duke.  "The only time I have worn these
Title:  studs was at a ball given by the king eight days ago at Windsor.
Title:  The Comtesse de Winter, with whom I had quarreled, became
Title:  reconciled to me at that ball.  That reconciliation was nothing
Title:  but the vengeance of a jealous woman.  I have never seen her from
Title:  that day.  The woman is an agent of the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "He has agents, then, throughout the world?" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes," said Buckingham, grating his teeth with rage.  "Yes,
Title:  he is a terrible antagonist.  But when is this ball to take
Title:  place?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monday next."
Title:  
Title:  "Monday next!  Still five days before us.  That's more time than
Title:  we want.  Patrick!" cried the duke, opening the door of the
Title:  chapel, "Patrick!"  His confidential valet appeared.
Title:  
Title:  "My jeweler and my secretary."
Title:  
Title:  The valet went out with a mute promptitude which showed him
Title:  accustomed to obey blindly and without reply.
Title:  
Title:  But although the jeweler had been mentioned first, it was the
Title:  secretary who first made his appearance.  This was simply because
Title:  he lived in the hotel.  He found Buckingham seated at a table in
Title:  his bedchamber, writing orders with his own hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Mr. Jackson," said he, "go instantly to the Lord Chancellor, and
Title:  tell him that I charge him with the execution of these orders.  I
Title:  wish them to be promulgated immediately."
Title:  
Title:  "But, my Lord, if the Lord Chancellor interrogates me upon the
Title:  motives which may have led your Grace to adopt such an
Title:  extraordinary measure, what shall I reply?"
Title:  
Title:  "That such is my pleasure, and that I answer for my will to no
Title:  man."
Title:  
Title:  "Will that be the answer," replied the secretary, smiling, "which
Title:  he must transmit to his Majesty if, by chance, his Majesty should
Title:  have the curiosity to know why no vessel is to leave any of the
Title:  ports of Great Britain?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, Mr. Jackson," replied Buckingham.  "He will say,
Title:  in that case, to the king that I am determined on war, and that
Title:  this measure is my first act of hostility against France."
Title:  
Title:  The secretary bowed and retired.
Title:  
Title:  "We are safe on that side," said Buckingham, turning toward
Title:  d'Artagnan.  "If the studs are not yet gone to Paris, they will
Title:  not arrive till after you."
Title:  
Title:  "How so?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have just placed an embargo on all vessels at present in his
Title:  Majesty's ports, and without particular permission, not one dare
Title:  lift an anchor."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan looked with stupefaction at a man who thus employed
Title:  the unlimited power with which he was clothed by the confidence
Title:  of a king in the prosecution of his intrigues.  Buckingham saw by
Title:  the expression of the young man's face what was passing in his
Title:  mind, and he smiled.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said he, "yes, Anne of Austria is my true queen.  Upon a
Title:  word from her, I would betray my country, I would betray my king,
Title:  I would betray my God.  She asked me not to send the Protestants
Title:  of La Rochelle the assistance I promised them; I have not done
Title:  so.  I broke my word, it is true; but what signifies that?  I
Title:  obeyed my love; and have I not been richly paid for that
Title:  obedience?  It was to that obedience I owe her portrait."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was amazed to note by what fragile and unknown threads
Title:  the destinies of nations and the lives of men are suspended.  He
Title:  was lost in these reflections when the goldsmith entered.  He was
Title:  an Irishman--one of the most skillful of his craft, and who
Title:  himself confessed that he gained a hundred thousand livres a year
Title:  by the Duke of Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  "Mr. O'Reilly," said the duke, leading him into the chapel, "look
Title:  at these diamond studs, and tell me what they are worth apiece."
Title:  
Title:  The goldsmith cast a glance at the elegant manner in which they
Title:  were set, calculated, one with another, what the diamonds were
Title:  worth, and without hesitation said, "Fifteen hundred pistoles
Title:  each, my Lord."
Title:  
Title:  "How many days would it require to make two studs exactly like
Title:  them?  You see there are two wanting."
Title:  
Title:  "Eight days, my Lord."
Title:  
Title:  "I will give you three thousand pistoles apiece if I can have
Title:  them by the day after tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, they shall be yours."
Title:  
Title:  "You are a jewel of a man, Mr. O'Reilly; but that is not all.
Title:  These studs cannot be trusted to anybody; it must be done in the
Title:  palace."
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible, my Lord!  There is no one but myself can so execute
Title:  them that one cannot tell the new from the old."
Title:  
Title:  "Therefore, my dear Mr. O'Reilly, you are my prisoner.  And if
Title:  you wish ever to leave my palace, you cannot; so make the best of
Title:  it.  Name to me such of your workmen as you need, and point out
Title:  the tools they must bring."
Title:  
Title:  The goldsmith knew the duke.  He knew all objection would be
Title:  useless, and instantly determined how to act.
Title:  
Title:  "May I be permitted to inform my wife?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you may even see her if you like, my dear Mr. O'Reilly.
Title:  Your captivity shall be mild, be assured; and as every
Title:  inconvenience deserves its indemnification, here is, in addition
Title:  to the price of the studs, an order for a thousand pistoles, to
Title:  make you forget the annoyance I cause you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan could not get over the surprise created in him by this
Title:  minister, who thus open-handed, sported with men and millions.
Title:  
Title:  As to the goldsmith, he wrote to his wife, sending her the order
Title:  for the thousand pistoles, and charging her to send him, in
Title:  exchange, his most skillful apprentice, an assortment of
Title:  diamonds, of which he gave the names and the weight, and the
Title:  necessary tools.
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham conducted the goldsmith to the chamber destined for
Title:  him, and which, at the end of half an hour, was transformed into
Title:  a workshop.  Then he placed a sentinel at each door, with an
Title:  order to admit nobody upon any pretense but his VALET DE CHAMBRE,
Title:  Patrick.  We need not add that the goldsmith, O'Reilly, and his
Title:  assistant, were prohibited from going out under any pretext.
Title:  This point, settled, the duke turned to d'Artagnan.  "Now, my
Title:  young friend," said he, "England is all our own.  What do you
Title:  wish for?  What do you desire?"
Title:  
Title:  "A bed, my Lord," replied d'Artagnan.  "At present, I confess,
Title:  that is the thing I stand most in need of."
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham gave d'Artagnan a chamber adjoining his own.  He
Title:  wished to have the young man at hand--not that he at all
Title:  mistrusted him, but for the sake of having someone to whom he
Title:  could constantly talk of the queen.
Title:  
Title:  In one hour after, the ordinance was published in London that no
Title:  vessel bound for France should leave port, not even the packet
Title:  boat with letters.  In the eyes of everybody this was a
Title:  declaration of war between the two kingdoms.
Title:  
Title:  On the day after the morrow, by eleven o'clock, the two diamond
Title:  studs were finished, and they were so completely imitated, so
Title:  perfectly alike, that Buckingham could not tell the new ones from
Title:  the old ones, and experts in such matters would have been
Title:  deceived as he was.  He immediately called d'Artagnan.  "Here,"
Title:  said he to him, "are the diamond studs that you came to bring;
Title:  and be my witness that I have done all that human power could
Title:  do."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied, my Lord, I will tell all that I have seen.  But
Title:  does your Grace mean to give me the studs without the casket?"
Title:  
Title:  "The casket would encumber you.  Besides, the casket is the more
Title:  precious from being all that is left to me.  You will say that I
Title:  keep it."
Title:  
Title:  "I will perform your commission, word for word, my Lord."
Title:  
Title:  "And now," resumed Buckingham, looking earnestly at the young
Title:  man, "how shall I ever acquit myself of the debt I owe you?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan blushed up to the whites of his eyes.  He saw that the
Title:  duke was searching for a means of making him accept something and
Title:  the idea that the blood of his friends and himself was about to
Title:  be paid for with English gold was strangely repugnant to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Let us understand each other, my Lord," replied d'Artagnan, "and
Title:  let us make things clear beforehand in order that there may be no
Title:  mistake.  I am in the service of the King and Queen of France,
Title:  and form part of the company of Monsieur Dessessart, who, as well
Title:  as his brother-in-law, Monsieur de Treville, is particularly
Title:  attached to their Majesties.  What I have done, then, has been
Title:  for the queen, and not at all for your Grace.  And still further,
Title:  it is very probable I should not have done anything of this, if
Title:  it had not been to make myself agreeable to someone who is my
Title:  lady, as the queen is yours."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said the duke, smiling, "and I even believe that I know
Title:  that other person; it is--"
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, I have not named her!" interrupted the young man,
Title:  warmly.
Title:  
Title:  "That is true," said the duke; "and it is to this person I am
Title:  bound to discharge my debt of gratitude."
Title:  
Title:  "You have said, my Lord; for truly, at this moment when there is
Title:  question of war, I confess to you that I see nothing in your
Title:  Grace but an Englishman, and consequently an enemy whom I should
Title:  have much greater pleasure in meeting on the field of battle than
Title:  in the park at Windsor or the corridors of the Louvre--all which,
Title:  however, will not prevent me from executing to the very point my
Title:  commission or from laying down my life, if there be need of it,
Title:  to accomplish it; but I repeat it to your Grace, without your
Title:  having personally on that account more to thank me for in this
Title:  second interview than for what I did for you in the first."
Title:  
Title:  "We say, 'Proud as a Scotsman,'" murmured the Duke of Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  "And we say, 'Proud as a Gascon,'" replied d'Artagnan.  "The
Title:  Gascons are the Scots of France."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan bowed to the duke, and was retiring.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, are you going away in that manner?  Where, and how?"
Title:  
Title:  "That's true!"
Title:  
Title:  "Fore Gad, these Frenchmen have no consideration!"
Title:  
Title:  "I had forgotten that England was an island, and that you were
Title:  the king of it."
Title:  
Title:  "Go to the riverside, ask for the brig SUND, and give this letter
Title:  to the captain; he will convey you to a little port, where
Title:  certainly you are not expected, and which is ordinarily only
Title:  frequented by fishermen."
Title:  
Title:  "The name of that port?"
Title:  
Title:  "St. Valery; but listen.  When you have arrived there you will go
Title:  to a mean tavern, without a name and without a sign--a mere
Title:  fisherman's hut.  You cannot be mistaken; there is but one."
Title:  
Title:  "Afterward?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will ask for the host, and will repeat to him the word
Title:  'Forward!'"
Title:  
Title:  "Which means?"
Title:  
Title:  "In French, EN AVANT.  It is the password.  He will give you a
Title:  horse all saddled, and will point out to you the road you ought
Title:  to take.  You will find, in the same way, four relays on your
Title:  route.  If you will give at each of these relays your address in
Title:  Paris, the four horses will follow you thither.  You already know
Title:  two of them, and you appeared to appreciate them like a judge.
Title:  They were those we rode on; and you may rely upon me for the
Title:  others not being inferior to them.  These horses are equipped for
Title:  the field.  However proud you may be, you will not refuse to
Title:  accept one of them, and to request your three companions to
Title:  accept the others--that is, in order to make war against us.
Title:  Besides, the end justified the means, as you Frenchmen say, does
Title:  it not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, my Lord, I accept them," said d'Artagnan; "and if it please
Title:  God, we will make a good use of your presents."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, now, your hand, young man.  Perhaps we shall soon meet on
Title:  the field of battle; but in the meantime we shall part good
Title:  friends, I hope."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, my Lord; but with the hope of soon becoming enemies."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied; I promise you that."
Title:  
Title:  "I depend upon your word, my Lord."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan bowed to the duke, and made his way as quickly as
Title:  possible to the riverside.  Opposite the Tower of London he found
Title:  the vessel that had been named to him, delivered his letter to
Title:  the captain, who after having it examined by the governor of the
Title:  port made immediate preparations to sail.
Title:  
Title:  Fifty vessels were waiting to set out.  Passing alongside one of
Title:  them, d'Artagnan fancied he perceived on board it the woman of
Title:  Meung--the same whom the unknown gentleman had called Milady, and
Title:  whom d'Artagnan had thought so handsome; but thanks to the
Title:  current of the stream and a fair wind, his vessel passed so
Title:  quickly that he had little more than a glimpse of her.
Title:  
Title:  The next day about nine o'clock in the morning, he landed at St.
Title:  Valery.  D'Artagnan went instantly in search of the inn, and
Title:  easily discovered it by the riotous noise which resounded from
Title:  it.  War between England and France was talked of as near and
Title:  certain, and the jolly sailors were having a carousal.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan made his way through the crowd, advanced toward the
Title:  host, and pronounced the word "Forward!"  The host instantly made
Title:  him a sign to follow, went out with him by a door which opened
Title:  into a yard, led him to the stable, where a saddled horse awaited
Title:  him, and asked him if he stood in need of anything else.
Title:  
Title:  "I want to know the route I am to follow," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Go from hence to Blangy, and from Blangy to Neufchatel.  At
Title:  Neufchatel, go to the tavern of the Golden Harrow, give the
Title:  password to the landlord, and you will find, as you have here, a
Title:  horse ready saddled."
Title:  
Title:  "Have I anything to pay?" demanded d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Everything is paid," replied the host, "and liberally.  Begone,
Title:  and may God guide you!"
Title:  
Title:  "Amen!" cried the young man, and set off at full gallop.
Title:  
Title:  Four hours later he was in Neufchatel.  He strictly followed the
Title:  instructions he had received.  At Neufchatel, as at St. Valery,
Title:  he found a horse quite ready and awaiting him.  He was about to
Title:  remove the pistols from the saddle he had quit to the one he was
Title:  about to fill, but he found the holsters furnished with similar
Title:  pistols.
Title:  
Title:  "Your address at Paris?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hotel of the Guards, company of Dessessart."
Title:  
Title:  "Enough," replied the questioner.
Title:  
Title:  "Which route must I take?" demanded d'Artagnan, in his turn.
Title:  
Title:  "That of Rouen; but you will leave the city on your right.  You
Title:  must stop at the little village of Eccuis, in which there is but
Title:  one tavern--the Shield of France.  Don't condemn it from
Title:  appearances; you will find a horse in the stables quite as good
Title:  as this."
Title:  
Title:  "The same password?"
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly."
Title:  
Title:  "Adieu, master!"
Title:  
Title:  "A good journey, gentlemen!  Do you want anything?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan shook his head, and set off at full speed.  At Eccuis,
Title:  the same scene was repeated.  He found as provident a host and a
Title:  fresh horse.  He left his address as he had done before, and set
Title:  off again at the same pace for Pontoise.  At Pontoise he changed
Title:  his horse for the last time, and at nine o'clock galloped into
Title:  the yard of Treville's hotel.  He had made nearly sixty leagues
Title:  in little more than twelve hours.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville received him as if he had seen him that same
Title:  morning; only, when pressing his hand a little more warmly than
Title:  usual, he informed him that the company of Dessessart was on duty
Title:  at the Louvre, and that he might repair at once to his post.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  22  THE BALLET OF LA MERLAISON
Title:  
Title:  On the morrow, nothing was talked of in Paris but the ball which
Title:  the aldermen of the city were to give to the king and queen, and
Title:  in which their Majesties were to dance the famous La Merlaison--
Title:  the favorite ballet of the king.
Title:  
Title:  Eight days had been occupied in preparations at the Hotel de
Title:  Ville for this important evening.  The city carpenters had
Title:  erected scaffolds upon which the invited ladies were to be
Title:  placed; the city grocer had ornamented the chambers with two
Title:  hundred FLAMBEAUX of white wax, a piece of luxury unheard of at
Title:  that period; and twenty violins were ordered, and the price for
Title:  them fixed at double the usual rate, upon condition, said the
Title:  report, that they should be played all night.
Title:  
Title:  At ten o'clock in the morning the Sieur de la Coste, ensign in
Title:  the king's Guards, followed by two officers and several archers
Title:  of that body, came to the city registrar, named Clement, and
Title:  demanded of him all the keys of the rooms and offices of the
Title:  hotel.  These keys were given up to him instantly.  Each of them
Title:  had ticket attached to it, by which it might be recognized; and
Title:  from that moment the Sieur de la Coste was charged with the care
Title:  of all the doors and all the avenues.
Title:  
Title:  At eleven o'clock came in his turn Duhallier, captain of the
Title:  Guards, bringing with him fifty archers, who were distributed
Title:  immediately through the Hotel de Ville, at the doors assigned
Title:  them.
Title:  
Title:  At three o'clock came two companies of the Guards, one French,
Title:  the other Swiss.  The company of French guards was composed of
Title:  half of M. Duhallier's men and half of M. Dessessart's men.
Title:  
Title:  At six in the evening the guests began to come.  As fast as they
Title:  entered, they were placed in the grand saloon, on the platforms
Title:  prepared for them.
Title:  
Title:  At nine o'clock Madame la Premiere Presidente arrived.  As next
Title:  to the queen, she was the most considerable personage of the
Title:  fete, she was received by the city officials, and placed in a box
Title:  opposite to that which the queen was to occupy.
Title:  
Title:  At ten o'clock, the king's collation, consisting of preserves and
Title:  other delicacies, was prepared in the little room on the side of
Title:  the church of St. Jean, in front of the silver buffet of the
Title:  city, which was guarded by four archers.
Title:  
Title:  At midnight great cries and loud acclamations were heard.  It was
Title:  the king, who was passing through the streets which led from the
Title:  Louvre to the Hotel de Ville, and which were all illuminated with
Title:  colored lanterns.
Title:  
Title:  Immediately the aldermen, clothed in their cloth robes and
Title:  preceded by six sergeants, each holding a FLAMBEAU in his hand,
Title:  went to attend upon the king, whom they met on the steps, where
Title:  the provost of the merchants made him the speech of welcome--a
Title:  compliment to which his Majesty replied with an apology for
Title:  coming so late, laying the blame upon the cardinal, who had
Title:  detained him till eleven o'clock, talking of affairs of state.
Title:  
Title:  His Majesty, in full dress, was accompanied by his royal
Title:  Highness, M. le Comte de Soissons, by the Grand Prior, by the Duc
Title:  de Longueville, by the Duc d'Euboeuf, by the Comte d'Harcourt, by
Title:  the Comte de la Roche-Guyon, by M. de Liancourt, by M. de
Title:  Baradas, by the Comte de Cramail, and by the Chevalier de
Title:  Souveray.  Everybody noticed that the king looked dull and
Title:  preoccupied.
Title:  
Title:  A private room had been prepared for the king and another for
Title:  Monsieur.  In each of these closets were placed masquerade
Title:  dresses.  The same had been done for the queen and Madame the
Title:  President.  The nobles and ladies of their Majesties' suites were
Title:  to dress, two by two, in chambers prepared for the purpose.
Title:  Before entering his closet the king desired to be informed the
Title:  moment the cardinal arrived.
Title:  
Title:  Half an hour after the entrance of the king, fresh acclamations
Title:  were heard; these announced the arrival of the queen.  The
Title:  aldermen did as they had done before, and preceded by their
Title:  sergeants, advanced to receive their illustrious guest.  The
Title:  queen entered the great hall; and it was remarked that, like the
Title:  king, she looked dull and even weary.
Title:  
Title:  At the moment she entered, the curtain of a small gallery which
Title:  to that time had been closed, was drawn, and the pale face of the
Title:  cardinal appeared, he being dressed as a Spanish cavalier.  His
Title:  eyes were fixed upon those of the queen, and a smile of terrible
Title:  joy passed over his lips; the queen did not wear her diamond
Title:  studs.
Title:  
Title:  The queen remained for a short time to receive the compliments of
Title:  the city dignitaries and to reply to the salutations of the
Title:  ladies.  All at once the king appeared with the cardinal at one
Title:  of the doors of the hall.  The cardinal was speaking to him in a
Title:  low voice, and the king was very pale.
Title:  
Title:  The king made his way through the crowd without a mask, and the
Title:  ribbons of his doublet scarcely tied.  He went straight to the
Title:  queen, and in an altered voice said, "Why, madame, have you not
Title:  thought proper to wear your diamond studs, when you know it would
Title:  give me so much gratification?"
Title:  
Title:  The queen cast a glance around her, and saw the cardinal behind,
Title:  with a diabolical smile on his countenance.
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," replied the queen, with a faltering voice, "because, in
Title:  the midst of such a crowd as this, I feared some accident might
Title:  happen to them."
Title:  
Title:  "And you were wrong, madame.  If I made you that present it was
Title:  that you might adorn yourself therewith.  I tell you that you
Title:  were wrong."
Title:  
Title:  The voice of the king was tremulous with anger.  Everybody looked
Title:  and listened with astonishment, comprehending nothing of what
Title:  passed.
Title:  
Title:  "Sire," said the queen, "I can send for them to the Louvre, where
Title:  they are, and thus your Majesty's wishes will be complied with."
Title:  
Title:  "Do so, madame, do so, and that at once; for within an hour the
Title:  ballet will commence."
Title:  
Title:  The queen bent in token of submission, and followed the ladies
Title:  who were to conduct her to her room.  On his part the king
Title:  returned to his apartment.
Title:  
Title:  There was a moment of trouble and confusion in the assembly.
Title:  Everybody had remarked that something had passed between the king
Title:  and queen; but both of them had spoken so low that everybody, out
Title:  of respect, withdrew several steps, so that nobody had heard
Title:  anything.  The violins began to sound with all their might, but
Title:  nobody listened to them.
Title:  
Title:  The king came out first from his room.  He was in a most elegant
Title:  hunting costume; and Monsieur and the other nobles were dressed
Title:  like him.  This was the costume that best became the king.  So
Title:  dressed, he really appeared the first gentleman of his kingdom.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal drew near to the king, and placed in his hand a
Title:  small casket.  The king opened it, and found in it two diamond
Title:  studs.
Title:  
Title:  "What does this mean?" demanded he of the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing," replied the latter; "only, if the queen has the studs,
Title:  which I very much doubt, count them, sire, and if you only find
Title:  ten, ask her Majesty who can have stolen from her the two studs
Title:  that are here."
Title:  
Title:  The king looked at the cardinal as if to interrogate him; but he
Title:  had not time to address any question to him--a cry of admiration
Title:  burst from every mouth.  If the king appeared to be the first
Title:  gentleman of his kingdom, the queen was without doubt the most
Title:  beautiful woman in France.
Title:  
Title:  It is true that the habit of a huntress became her admirably.
Title:  She wore a beaver hat with blue feathers, a surtout of gray-pearl
Title:  velvet, fastened with diamond clasps, and a petticoat of blue
Title:  satin, embroidered with silver.  On her left shoulder sparkled
Title:  the diamond studs, on a bow of the same color as the plumes and
Title:  the petticoat.
Title:  
Title:  The king trembled with joy and the cardinal with vexation;
Title:  although, distant as they were from the queen, they could not
Title:  count the studs.  The queen had them.  The only question was, had
Title:  she ten or twelve?
Title:  
Title:  At that moment the violins sounded the signal for the ballet.
Title:  The king advanced toward Madame the President, with whom he was
Title:  to dance, and his Highness Monsieur with the queen.  They took
Title:  their places, and the ballet began.
Title:  
Title:  The king danced facing the queen, and every time he passed by
Title:  her, he devoured with his eyes those studs of which he could not
Title:  ascertain the number.  A cold sweat covered the brow of the
Title:  cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  The ballet lasted an hour, and had sixteen ENTREES.  The ballet
Title:  ended amid the applause of the whole assemblage, and everyone
Title:  reconducted his lady to her place; but the king took advantage of
Title:  the privilege he had of leaving his lady, to advance eagerly
Title:  toward the queen.
Title:  
Title:  "I thank you, madame," said he, "for the deference you have shown
Title:  to my wishes, but I think you want two of the studs, and I bring
Title:  them back to you."
Title:  
Title:  With these words he held out to the queen the two studs the
Title:  cardinal had given him.
Title:  
Title:  "How, sire?" cried the young queen, affecting surprise, "you are
Title:  giving me, then, two more:  I shall have fourteen."
Title:  
Title:  In fact the king counted them, and the twelve studs were all on
Title:  her Majesty's shoulder.
Title:  
Title:  The king called the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "What does this mean, Monsieur Cardinal?" asked the king in a
Title:  severe tone.
Title:  
Title:  "This means, sire," replied the cardinal, "that I was desirous of
Title:  presenting her Majesty with these two studs, and that not daring
Title:  to offer them myself, I adopted this means of inducing her to
Title:  accept them."
Title:  
Title:  "And I am the more grateful to your Eminence," replied Anne of
Title:  Austria, with a smile that proved she was not the dupe of this
Title:  ingenious gallantry, "from being certain that these two studs
Title:  alone have cost you as much as all the others cost his Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  Then saluting the king and the cardinal, the queen resumed her
Title:  way to the chamber in which she had dressed, and where she was to
Title:  take off her costume.
Title:  
Title:  The attention which we have been obliged to give, during the
Title:  commencement of the chapter, to the illustrious personages we
Title:  have introduced into it, has diverted us for an instant from him
Title:  to whom Anne of Austria owed the extraordinary triumph she had
Title:  obtained over the cardinal; and who, confounded, unknown, lost in
Title:  the crowd gathered at one of the doors, looked on at this scene,
Title:  comprehensible only to four persons--the king, the queen, his
Title:  Eminence, and himself.
Title:  
Title:  The queen had just regained her chamber, and d'Artagnan was about
Title:  to retire, when he felt his shoulder lightly touched.  He turned
Title:  and saw a young woman, who made him a sign to follow her.  The
Title:  face of this young woman was covered with a black velvet mask;
Title:  but notwithstanding this precaution, which was in fact taken
Title:  rather against others than against him, he at once recognized his
Title:  usual guide, the light and intelligent Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  On the evening before, they had scarcely seen each other for a
Title:  moment at the apartment of the Swiss guard, Germain, whither
Title:  d'Artagnan had sent for her.  The haste which the young woman was
Title:  in to convey to the queen the excellent news of the happy return
Title:  of her messenger prevented the two lovers from exchanging more
Title:  than a few words.  D'Artagnan therefore followed Mme. Bonacieux
Title:  moved by a double sentiment--love and curiosity.  All the way,
Title:  and in proportion as the corridors became more deserted,
Title:  d'Artagnan wished to stop the young woman, seize her and gaze
Title:  upon her, were it only for a minute; but quick as a bird she
Title:  glided between his hands, and when he wished to speak to her, her
Title:  finger placed upon her mouth, with a little imperative gesture
Title:  full of grace, reminded him that he was under the command of a
Title:  power which he must blindly obey, and which forbade him even to
Title:  make the slightest complaint.  At length, after winding about for
Title:  a minute or two, Mme. Bonacieux opened the door of a closet,
Title:  which was entirely dark, and led d'Artagnan into it.  There she
Title:  made a fresh sign of silence, and opened a second door concealed
Title:  by tapestry.  The opening of this door disclosed a brilliant
Title:  light, and she disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan remained for a moment motionless, asking himself where
Title:  he could be; but soon a ray of light which penetrated through the
Title:  chamber, together with the warm and perfumed air which reached
Title:  him from the same aperture, the conversation of two of three
Title:  ladies in language at once respectful and refined, and the word
Title:  "Majesty" several times repeated, indicated clearly that he was
Title:  in a closet attached to the queen's apartment.  The young man
Title:  waited in comparative darkness and listened.
Title:  
Title:  The queen appeared cheerful and happy, which seemed to astonish
Title:  the persons who surrounded her and who were accustomed to see her
Title:  almost always sad and full of care.  The queen attributed this
Title:  joyous feeling to the beauty of the fete, to the pleasure she had
Title:  experienced in the ballet; and as it is not permissible to
Title:  contradict a queen, whether she smile or weep, everybody
Title:  expatiated on the gallantry of the aldermen of the city of Paris.
Title:  
Title:  Although d'Artagnan did not at all know the queen, he soon
Title:  distinguished her voice from the others, at first by a slightly
Title:  foreign accent, and next by that tone of domination naturally
Title:  impressed upon all royal words.  He heard her approach and
Title:  withdraw from the partially open door; and twice or three times
Title:  he even saw the shadow of a person intercept the light.
Title:  
Title:  At length a hand and an arm, surpassingly beautiful in their form
Title:  and whiteness, glided through the tapestry.  D'Artagnan at once
Title:  comprehended that this was his recompense.  He cast himself on
Title:  his knees, seized the hand, and touched it respectfully with his
Title:  lips.  Then the hand was withdrawn, leaving in his an object
Title:  which he perceived to be a ring.  The door immediately closed,
Title:  and d'Artagnan found himself again in complete obscurity.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan placed the ring on his finger, and again waited; it
Title:  was evident that all was not yet over.  After the reward of his
Title:  devotion, that of his love was to come.  Besides, although the
Title:  ballet was danced, the evening had scarcely begun.  Supper was to
Title:  be served at three, and the clock of St. Jean had struck three
Title:  quarters past two.
Title:  
Title:  The sound of voices diminished by degrees in the adjoining
Title:  chamber.  The company was then heard departing; then the door of
Title:  the closet in which d'Artagnan was, was opened, and Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux entered.
Title:  
Title:  "You at last?" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" said the young woman, placing her hand upon his lips;
Title:  "silence, and go the same way you came!"
Title:  
Title:  "But where and when shall I see you again?" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "A note which you will find at home will tell you.  Begone,
Title:  begone!"
Title:  
Title:  At these words she opened the door of the corridor, and pushed
Title:  d'Artagnan out of the room.  D'Artagnan obeyed like a child,
Title:  without the least resistance or objection, which proved that he
Title:  was really in love.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  23  THE RENDEZVOUS
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan ran home immediately, and although it was three
Title:  o'clock in the morning and he had some of the worst quarters of
Title:  Paris to traverse, he met with no misadventure.  Everyone knows
Title:  that drunkards and lovers have a protecting deity.
Title:  
Title:  He found the door of his passage open, sprang up the stairs and
Title:  knocked softly in a manner agreed upon between him and his
Title:  lackey.  Planchet*, whom he had sent home two hours before from
Title:  the Hotel de Ville, telling him to sit up for him, opened the
Title:  door for him.
Title:  
Title:  *The reader may ask, "How came Planchet here?" when he was left
Title:  "stiff as a rush" in London.  In the intervening time Buckingham
Title:  perhaps sent him to Paris, as he did the horses.
Title:  
Title:  "Has anyone brought a letter for me?" asked d'Artagnan, eagerly.
Title:  
Title:  "No one has BROUGHT a letter, monsieur," replied Planchet; "but
Title:  one has come of itself."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean, blockhead?"
Title:  
Title:  "I mean to say that when I came in, although I had the key of
Title:  your apartment in my pocket, and that key had never quit me, I
Title:  found a letter on the green table cover in your bedroom."
Title:  
Title:  "And where is that letter?"
Title:  
Title:  "I left it where I found it, monsieur.  It is not natural for
Title:  letters to enter people's houses in this manner.  If the window
Title:  had been open or even ajar, I should think nothing of it; but,
Title:  no--all was hermetically sealed.  Beware, monsieur; there is
Title:  certainly some magic underneath."
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, the young man had darted in to his chamber, and opened
Title:  the letter.  It was from Mme. Bonacieux, and was expressed in
Title:  these terms:
Title:  
Title:  "There are many thanks to be offered to you, and to be
Title:  transmitted to you.  Be this evening about ten o'clock at St.
Title:  Cloud, in front of the pavilion which stands at the corner of the
Title:  house of M. d'Estrees.--C.B."
Title:  
Title:  While reading this letter, d'Artagnan felt his heart dilated and
Title:  compressed by that delicious spasm which tortures and caresses
Title:  the hearts of lovers.
Title:  
Title:  It was the first billet he had received; it was the first
Title:  rendezvous that had been granted him.  His heart, swelled by the
Title:  intoxication of joy, felt ready to dissolve away at the very gate
Title:  of that terrestrial paradise called Love!
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur," said Planchet, who had observed his master grow
Title:  red and pale successively, "did I not guess truly?  Is it not
Title:  some bad affair?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are mistaken, Planchet," replied d'Artagnan; "and as a
Title:  proof, there is a crown to drink my health."
Title:  
Title:  "I am much obliged to Monsieur for the crown he had given me, and
Title:  I promise him to follow his instructions exactly; but it is not
Title:  the less true that letters which come in this way into shut-up
Title:  houses--"
Title:  
Title:  "Fall from heaven, my friend, fall from heaven."
Title:  
Title:  "Then Monsieur is satisfied?" asked Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Planchet, I am the happiest of men!"
Title:  
Title:  "And I may profit by Monsieur's happiness, and go to bed?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, go."
Title:  
Title:  "May the blessings of heaven fall upon Monsieur!  But it is not
Title:  the less true that that letter--"
Title:  
Title:  And Planchet retired, shaking his head with an air of doubt,
Title:  which the liberality of d'Artagnan had not entirely effaced.
Title:  
Title:  Left alone, d'Artagnan read and reread his billet.  Then he
Title:  kissed and rekissed twenty times the lines traced by the hand of
Title:  his beautiful mistress.  At length he went to bed, fell asleep,
Title:  and had golden dreams.
Title:  
Title:  At seven o'clock in the morning he arose and called Planchet, who
Title:  at the second summons opened the door, his countenance not yet
Title:  quite freed from the anxiety of the preceding night.
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet," said d'Artagnan, "I am going out for all day,
Title:  perhaps.  You are, therefore, your own master till seven o'clock
Title:  in the evening; but at seven o'clock you must hold yourself in
Title:  readiness with two horses."
Title:  
Title:  "There!" said Planchet.  "We are going again, it appears, to have
Title:  our hides pierced in all sorts of ways."
Title:  
Title:  "You will take your musketoon and your pistols."
Title:  
Title:  "There, now!  Didn't I say so?" cried Planchet.  "I was sure of
Title:  it--the cursed letter!"
Title:  
Title:  "Don't be afraid, you idiot; there is nothing in hand but a party
Title:  of pleasure."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, like the charming journey the other day, when it rained
Title:  bullets and produced a crop of steel traps!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, if you are really afraid, Monsieur Planchet," resumed
Title:  d'Artagnan, "I will go without you.  I prefer traveling alone to
Title:  having a companion who entertains the least fear."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur does me wrong," said Planchet; "I thought he had seen
Title:  me at work."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but I thought perhaps you had worn out all your courage the
Title:  first time."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur shall see that upon occasion I have some left; only I
Title:  beg Monsieur not to be too prodigal of it if he wishes it to last
Title:  long."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you believe you have still a certain amount of it to expend
Title:  this evening?"
Title:  
Title:  "I hope so, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, I count on you."
Title:  
Title:  "At the appointed hour I shall be ready; only I believed that
Title:  Monsieur had but one horse in the Guard stables."
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps there is but one at this moment; but by this evening
Title:  there will be four."
Title:  
Title:  "It appears that our journey was a remounting journey, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly so," said d'Artagnan; and nodding to Planchet, he went
Title:  out.
Title:  
Title:  M. Bonacieux was at his door.  D'Artagnan's intention was to go
Title:  out without speaking to the worthy mercer; but the latter made so
Title:  polite and friendly a salutation that his tenant felt obliged,
Title:  not only to stop, but to enter into conversation with him.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, how is it possible to avoid a little condescension
Title:  toward a husband whose pretty wife has appointed a meeting with
Title:  you that same evening at St. Cloud, opposite D'Estrees's
Title:  pavilion?  D'Artagnan approached him with the most amiable air he
Title:  could assume.
Title:  
Title:  The conversation naturally fell upon the incarceration of the
Title:  poor man.  M. Bonacieux, who was ignorant that d'Artagnan had
Title:  overheard his conversation with the stranger of Meung, related to
Title:  his young tenant the persecutions of that monster, M. de
Title:  Laffemas, whom he never ceased to designate, during his account,
Title:  by the title of the "cardinal's executioner," and expatiated at
Title:  great length upon the Bastille, the bolts, the wickets, the
Title:  dungeons, the gratings, the instruments of torture.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan listened to him with exemplary complaisance, and when
Title:  he had finished said, "And Madame Bonacieux, do you know who
Title:  carried her off?--For I do not forget that I owe to that
Title:  unpleasant circumstance the good fortune of having made your
Title:  acquaintance."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!" said Bonacieux, "they took good care not to tell me that;
Title:  and my wife, on her part, has sworn to me by all that's sacred
Title:  that she does not know.  But you," continued M. Bonacieux, in a
Title:  tine of perfect good fellowship, "what has become of you all
Title:  these days?  I have not seen you nor your friends, and I don't
Title:  think you could gather all that dust that I saw Planchet brush
Title:  off your boots yesterday from the pavement of Paris."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, my friends and I have
Title:  been on a little journey."
Title:  
Title:  "Far from here?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, Lord, no!  About forty leagues only.  We went to take
Title:  Monsieur Athos to the waters of Forges, where my friends still
Title:  remain."
Title:  
Title:  "And you have returned, have you not?" replied M. Bonacieux,
Title:  giving to his countenance a most sly air.  "A handsome young
Title:  fellow like you does not obtain long leaves of absence from his
Title:  mistress; and we were impatiently waited for at Paris, were we
Title:  not?"
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!" said the young man, laughing, "I confess it, and so
Title:  much more the readily, my dear Bonacieux, as I see there is no
Title:  concealing anything from you.  Yes, I was expected, and very
Title:  impatiently, I acknowledge."
Title:  
Title:  A slight shade passed over the brow of Bonacieux, but so slight
Title:  that d'Artagnan did not perceive it.
Title:  
Title:  "And we are going to be recompensed for our diligence?" continued
Title:  the mercer, with a trifling alteration in his voice--so trifling,
Title:  indeed, that d'Artagnan did not perceive it any more than he had
Title:  the momentary shade which, an instant before, had darkened the
Title:  countenance of the worthy man.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, may you be a true prophet!" said d'Artagnan, laughing.
Title:  
Title:  "No; what I say," replied Bonacieux, "is only that I may know
Title:  whether I am delaying you."
Title:  
Title:  "Why that question, my dear host?" asked d'Artagnan.  "Do you
Title:  intend to sit up for me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; but since my arrest and the robbery that was committed in my
Title:  house, I am alarmed every time I hear a door open, particularly
Title:  in the night.  What the deuce can you expect?  I am no
Title:  swordsman."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, don't be alarmed if I return at one, two or three o'clock
Title:  in the morning; indeed, do not be alarmed if I do not come at
Title:  all."
Title:  
Title:  This time Bonacieux became so pale that d'Artagnan could not help
Title:  perceiving it, and asked him what was the matter.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing," replied Bonacieux, "nothing.  Since my misfortunes I
Title:  have been subject to faintnesses, which seize me all at once, and
Title:  I have just felt a cold shiver.  Pay no attention to it; you have
Title:  nothing to occupy yourself with but being happy."
Title:  
Title:  "Then I have full occupation, for I am so."
Title:  
Title:  "Not yet; wait a little!  This evening, you said."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, this evening will come, thank God!  And perhaps you look
Title:  for it with as much impatience as I do; perhaps this evening
Title:  Madame Bonacieux will visit the conjugal domicile."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame Bonacieux is not at liberty this evening," replied the
Title:  husband, seriously; "she is detained at the Louvre this evening
Title:  by her duties."
Title:  
Title:  "So much the worse for you, my dear host, so much the worse!
Title:  When I am happy, I wish all the world to be so; but it appears
Title:  that is not possible."
Title:  
Title:  The young man departed, laughing at the joke, which he thought he
Title:  alone could comprehend.
Title:  
Title:  "Amuse yourself well!" replied Bonacieux, in a sepulchral tone.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan was too far off to hear him; and if he had heard
Title:  him in the disposition of mind he then enjoyed, he certainly
Title:  would not have remarked it.
Title:  
Title:  He took his way toward the hotel of M. de Treville; his visit of
Title:  the day before, it is to be remembered, had been very short and
Title:  very little explicative.
Title:  
Title:  He found Treville in a joyful mood.  He had thought the king and
