Title:  queen charming at the ball.  It is true the cardinal had been
Title:  particularly ill-tempered.  He had retired at one o'clock under
Title:  the pretense of being indisposed.  As to their Majesties, they
Title:  did not return to the Louvre till six o'clock in the morning.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said Treville, lowering his voice, and looking into every
Title:  corner of the apartment to see if they were alone, "now let us
Title:  talk about yourself, my young friend; for it is evident that your
Title:  happy return has something to do with the joy of the king, the
Title:  triumph of the queen, and the humiliation of his Eminence.  You
Title:  must look out for yourself."
Title:  
Title:  "What have I to fear," replied d'Artagnan, "as long as I shall
Title:  have the luck to enjoy the favor of their Majesties?"
Title:  
Title:  "Everything, believe me.  The cardinal is not the man to forget a
Title:  mystification until he has settled account with the mystifier;
Title:  and the mystifier appears to me to have the air of being a
Title:  certain young Gascon of my acquaintance."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you believe that the cardinal is as well posted as yourself,
Title:  and knows that I have been to London?"
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  You have been to London!  Was it from London you
Title:  brought that beautiful diamond that glitters on your finger?
Title:  Beware, my dear d'Artagnan!  A present from an enemy is not a
Title:  good thing.  Are there not some Latin verses upon that subject?
Title:  Stop!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, doubtless," replied d'Artagnan, who had never been able to
Title:  cram the first rudiments of that language into his head, and who
Title:  had by his ignorance driven his master to despair, "yes,
Title:  doubtless there is one."
Title:  
Title:  "There certainly is one," said M. de Treville, who had a tincture
Title:  of literature, "and Monsieur de Benserade was quoting it to me
Title:  the other day.  Stop a minute--ah, this is it:  'Timeo Danaos et
Title:  dona ferentes,' which means, 'Beware of the enemy who makes you
Title:  presents."
Title:  
Title:  "This diamond does not come from an enemy, monsieur," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan, "it comes from the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "From the queen! Oh, oh!" said M. de Treville.  "Why, it is
Title:  indeed a true royal jewel, which is worth a thousand pistoles if
Title:  it is worth a denier.  By whom did the queen send you this
Title:  jewel?"
Title:  
Title:  "She gave it to me herself."
Title:  
Title:  "Where?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the room adjoining the chamber in which she changed her
Title:  toilet."
Title:  
Title:  "How?"
Title:  
Title:  "Giving me her hand to kiss."
Title:  
Title:  "You have kissed the queen's hand?" said M. de Treville, looking
Title:  earnestly at d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Her Majesty did me the honor to grant me that favor."
Title:  
Title:  "And that in the presence of witnesses!  Imprudent, thrice
Title:  imprudent!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, be satisfied; nobody saw her," replied d'Artagnan,
Title:  and he related to M. de Treville how the affair came to pass.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, the women, the women!" cried the old soldier.  "I know them
Title:  by their romantic imagination.  Everything that savors of mystery
Title:  charms them.  So you have seen the arm, that was all.  You would
Title:  meet the queen, and she would not know who you are?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; but thanks to this diamond," replied the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen," said M. de Treville; "shall I give you counsel, good
Title:  counsel, the counsel of a friend?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will do me honor, monsieur," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, off to the nearest goldsmith's, and sell that
Title:  diamond for the highest price you can get from him.  However much
Title:  of a Jew he may be, he will give you at least eight hundred
Title:  pistoles.  Pistoles have no name, young man, and that ring has a
Title:  terrible one, which may betray him who wears it."
Title:  
Title:  "Sell this ring, a ring which comes from my sovereign?  Never!"
Title:  said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Then, at least turn the gem inside, you silly fellow; for
Title:  everybody must be aware that a cadet from Gascony does not find
Title:  such stones in his mother's jewel case."
Title:  
Title:  "You think, then, I have something to dread?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I mean to say, young man, that he who sleeps over a mine the
Title:  match of which is already lighted, may consider himself in safety
Title:  in comparison with you."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said d'Artagnan, whom the positive tone of M. de
Title:  Treville began to disquiet, "the devil!  What must I do?"
Title:  
Title:  "Above all things be always on your guard.  The cardinal has a
Title:  tenacious memory and a long arm; you may depend upon it, he will
Title:  repay you by some ill turn."
Title:  
Title:  "But of what sort?"
Title:  
Title:  "Eh!  How can I tell?  Has he not all the tricks of a demon at
Title:  his command?  The least that can be expected is that you will be
Title:  arrested."
Title:  
Title:  "What!  Will they dare to arrest a man in his Majesty's service?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU!  They did not scruple much in the case of Athos.  At
Title:  all events, young man, rely upon one who has been thirty years at
Title:  court.  Do not lull yourself in security, or you will be lost;
Title:  but, on the contrary--and it is I who say it--see enemies in all
Title:  directions.  If anyone seeks a quarrel with you, shun it, were it
Title:  with a child of ten years old.  If you are attacked by day or by
Title:  night, fight, but retreat, without shame; if you cross a bridge,
Title:  feel every plank of it with your foot, lest one should give way
Title:  beneath you; if you pass before a house which is being built,
Title:  look up, for fear a stone should fall upon your head; if you stay
Title:  out late, be always followed by your lackey, and let your lackey
Title:  be armed--if, by the by, you can be sure of your lackey.
Title:  Mistrust everybody, your friend, your brother, your mistress--
Title:  your mistress above all."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan blushed.
Title:  
Title:  "My mistress above all," repeated he, mechanically; "and why her
Title:  rather than another?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because a mistress is one of the cardinal's favorite means; he
Title:  has not one that is more expeditious.  A woman will sell you for
Title:  ten pistoles, witness Delilah.  You are acquainted with the
Title:  Scriptures?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan thought of the appointment Mme. Bonacieux had made
Title:  with him for that very evening; but we are bound to say, to the
Title:  credit of our hero, that the bad opinion entertained by M. de
Title:  Treville of women in general, did not inspire him with the least
Title:  suspicion of his pretty hostess.
Title:  
Title:  "But, A PROPOS," resumed M. de Treville, "what has become of your
Title:  three companions?"
Title:  
Title:  "I was about to ask you if you had heard any news of them?"
Title:  
Title:  "None, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I left them on my road--Porthos at Chantilly, with a duel
Title:  on his hands; Aramis at Crevecoeur, with a ball in his shoulder;
Title:  and Athos at Amiens, detained by an accusation of coining."
Title:  
Title:  "See there, now!" said M. de Treville; "and how the devil did you
Title:  escape?"
Title:  
Title:  "By a miracle, monsieur, I must acknowledge, with a sword thrust
Title:  in my breast, and by nailing the Comte de Wardes on the byroad to
Title:  Calais, like a butterfly on a tapestry."
Title:  
Title:  "There again!  De Wardes, one of the cardinal's men, a cousin of
Title:  Rochefort!  Stop, my friend, I have an idea."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "In your place, I would do one thing."
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "While his Eminence was seeking for me in Paris, I would take,
Title:  without sound of drum or trumpet, the road to Picardy, and would
Title:  go and make some inquiries concerning my three companions.  What
Title:  the devil!  They merit richly that piece of attention on your
Title:  part."
Title:  
Title:  "The advice is good, monsieur, and tomorrow I will set out."
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow!  Any why not this evening?"
Title:  
Title:  "This evening, monsieur, I am detained in Paris by indispensable
Title:  business."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, young man, young man, some flirtation or other.  Take care,
Title:  I repeat to you, take care.  It is woman who has ruined us, still
Title:  ruins us, and will ruin us, as long as the world stands.  Take my
Title:  advice and set out this evening."
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "You have given your word, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, that's quite another thing; but promise me, if you should
Title:  not be killed tonight, that you will go tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  "I promise it."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you need money?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have still fifty pistoles.  That, I think, is as much as I
Title:  shall want."
Title:  
Title:  "But your companions?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't think they can be in need of any.  We left Paris, each
Title:  with seventy-five pistoles in his pocket."
Title:  
Title:  "Shall I see you again before your departure?"
Title:  
Title:  "I think not, monsieur, unless something new should happen."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, a pleasant journey."
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan left M. de Treville, touched more than ever by his
Title:  paternal solicitude for his Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  He called successively at the abodes of Athos, Porthos, and
Title:  Aramis.  Neither of them had returned.  Their lackeys likewise
Title:  were absent, and nothing had been heard of either the one or the
Title:  other.  He would have inquired after them of their mistresses,
Title:  but he was neither acquainted with Porthos's nor Aramis's, and as
Title:  to Athos, he had none.
Title:  
Title:  As he passed the Hotel des Gardes, he took a glance in to the
Title:  stables.  Three of the four horses had already arrived.
Title:  Planchet, all astonishment, was busy grooming them, and had
Title:  already finished two.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur," said Planchet, on perceiving d'Artagnan, "how
Title:  glad I am to see you."
Title:  
Title:  "Why so, Planchet?" asked the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you place confidence in our landlord--Monsieur Bonacieux?"
Title:  
Title:  "I?  Not the least in the world."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you do quite right, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "But why this question?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because, while you were talking with him, I watched you without
Title:  listening to you; and, monsieur, his countenance changed color
Title:  two or three times!"
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!"
Title:  
Title:  "Preoccupied as Monsieur was with the letter he had received, he
Title:  did not observe that; but I, whom the strange fashion in which
Title:  that letter came into the house had placed on my guard--I did not
Title:  lose a movement of his features."
Title:  
Title:  "And you found it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Traitorous, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  "Still more; as soon as Monsieur had left and disappeared round
Title:  the corner of the street, Monsieur Bonacieux took his hat, shut
Title:  his door, and set off at a quick pace in an opposite direction."
Title:  
Title:  "It seems you are right, Planchet; all this appears to be a
Title:  little mysterious; and be assured that we will not pay him our
Title:  rent until the matter shall be categorically explained to us."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur jests, but Monsieur will see."
Title:  
Title:  "What would you have, Planchet?  What must come is written."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur does not then renounce his excursion for this evening?"
Title:  
Title:  "Quite the contrary, Planchet; the more ill will I have toward
Title:  Monsieur Bonacieux, the more punctual I shall be in keeping the
Title:  appointment made by that letter which makes you so uneasy."
Title:  
Title:  "Then that is Monsieur's determination?"
Title:  
Title:  "Undeniably, my friend.  At nine o'clock, then, be ready here at
Title:  the hotel, I will come and take you."
Title:  
Title:  Planchet seeing there was no longer any hope of making his master
Title:  renounce his project, heaved a profound sigh and set to work to
Title:  groom the third horse.
Title:  
Title:  As to d'Artagnan, being at bottom a prudent youth, instead of
Title:  returning home, went and dined with the Gascon priest, who, at
Title:  the time of the distress of the four friends, had given them a
Title:  breakfast of chocolate.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  24 THE PAVILION
Title:  
Title:  At nine o'clock d'Artagnan was at the Hotel des Gardes; he found
Title:  Planchet all ready.  The fourth horse had arrived.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet was armed with his musketoon and a pistol.  D'Artagnan
Title:  had his sword and placed two pistols in his belt; then both
Title:  mounted and departed quietly.  It was quite dark, and no one saw
Title:  them go out.  Planchet took place behind his master, and kept at
Title:  a distance of ten paces from him.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan crossed the quays, went out by the gate of La
Title:  Conference and followed the road, much more beautiful then than
Title:  it is now, which leads to St. Cloud.
Title:  
Title:  As long as he was in the city, Planchet kept at the respectful
Title:  distance he had imposed upon himself; but as soon as the road
Title:  began to be more lonely and dark, he drew softly nearer, so that
Title:  when they entered the Bois de Boulogne he found himself riding
Title:  quite naturally side by side with his master.  In fact, we must
Title:  not dissemble that the oscillation of the tall trees and the
Title:  reflection of the moon in the dark underwood gave him serious
Title:  uneasiness.  D'Artagnan could not help perceiving that something
Title:  more than usual was passing in the mind of his lackey and said,
Title:  "Well, Monsieur Planchet, what is the matter with us now?"
Title:  
Title:  "Don't you think, monsieur, that woods are like churches?"
Title:  
Title:  "How so, Planchet?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because we dare not speak aloud in one or the other."
Title:  
Title:  "But why did you not dare to speak aloud, Planchet--because you
Title:  are afraid?"
Title:  
Title:  "Afraid of being heard?  Yes, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Afraid of being heard!  Why, there is nothing improper in our
Title:  conversation, my dear Planchet, and no one could find fault with
Title:  it."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!" replied Planchet, recurring to his besetting
Title:  idea, "that Monsieur Bonacieux has something vicious in his
Title:  eyebrows, and something very unpleasant in the play of his lips."
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil makes you think of Bonacieux?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, we think of what we can, and not of what we will."
Title:  
Title:  "Because you are a coward, Planchet."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, we must not confound prudence with cowardice; prudence
Title:  is a virtue."
Title:  
Title:  "And you are very virtuous, are you not, Planchet?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, is not that the barrel of a musket which glitters
Title:  yonder?  Had we not better lower our heads?"
Title:  
Title:  "In truth," murmured d'Artagnan, to whom M. de Treville's
Title:  recommendation recurred, "this animal will end by making me
Title:  afraid."  And he put his horse into a trot.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet followed the movements of his master as if he had been
Title:  his shadow, and was soon trotting by his side.
Title:  
Title:  "Are we going to continue this pace all night?" asked Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  "No; you are at your journey's end."
Title:  
Title:  "How, monsieur!  And you?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am going a few steps farther."
Title:  
Title:  "And Monsieur leaves me here alone?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are afraid, Planchet?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; I only beg leave to observe to Monsieur that the night will
Title:  be very cold, that chills bring on rheumatism, and that a lackey
Title:  who has the rheumatism makes but a poor servant, particularly to
Title:  a master as active as Monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, if you are cold, Planchet, you can go into one of those
Title:  cabarets that you see yonder, and be in waiting for me at the
Title:  door by six o'clock in the morning."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, I have eaten and drunk respectfully the crown you gave
Title:  me this morning, so that I have not a sou left in case I should
Title:  be cold."
Title:  
Title:  "Here's half a pistole.  Tomorrow morning."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan sprang from his horse, threw the bridle to Planchet,
Title:  and departed at a quick pace, folding his cloak around him.
Title:  
Title:  "Good Lord, how cold I am!" cried Planchet, as soon as he had
Title:  lost sight of his master; and in such haste was he to warm
Title:  himself that he went straight to a house set out with all the
Title:  attributes of a suburban tavern, and knocked at the door.
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime d'Artagnan, who had plunged into a bypath,
Title:  continued his route and reached St. Cloud; but instead of
Title:  following the main street he turned behind the chateau, reached a
Title:  sort of retired lane, and found himself soon in front of the
Title:  pavilion named.  It was situated in a very private spot.  A high
Title:  wall, at the angle of which was the pavilion, ran along one side
Title:  of this lane, and on the other was a little garden connected with
Title:  a poor cottage which was protected by a hedge from passers-by.
Title:  
Title:  He gained the place appointed, and as no signal had been given
Title:  him by which to announce his presence, he waited.
Title:  
Title:  Not the least noise was to be heard; it might be imagined that he
Title:  was a hundred miles from the capital.  D'Artagnan leaned against
Title:  the hedge, after having cast a glance behind it.  Beyond that
Title:  hedge, that garden, and that cottage, a dark mist enveloped with
Title:  its folds that immensity where Paris slept--a vast void from
Title:  which glittered a few luminous points, the funeral stars of that
Title:  hell!
Title:  
Title:  But for d'Artagnan all aspects were clothed happily, all ideas
Title:  wore a smile, all shades were diaphanous.  The appointed hour was
Title:  about to strike.  In fact, at the end of a few minutes the belfry
Title:  of St. Cloud let fall slowly ten strokes from its sonorous jaws.
Title:  There was something melancholy in this brazen voice pouring out
Title:  its lamentations in the middle of the night; but each of those
Title:  strokes, which made up the expected hour, vibrated harmoniously
Title:  to the heart of the young man.
Title:  
Title:  His eyes were fixed upon the little pavilion situated at the
Title:  angle of the wall, of which all the windows were closed with
Title:  shutters, except one on the first story.  Through this window
Title:  shone a mild light which silvered the foliage of two or three
Title:  linden trees which formed a group outside the park.  There could
Title:  be no doubt that behind this little window, which threw forth
Title:  such friendly beams, the pretty Mme. Bonacieux expected him.
Title:  
Title:  Wrapped in this sweet idea, d'Artagnan waited half an hour
Title:  without the least impatience, his eyes fixed upon that charming
Title:  little abode of which he could perceive a part of the ceiling
Title:  with its gilded moldings, attesting the elegance of the rest of
Title:  the apartment.
Title:  
Title:  The belfry of St. Cloud sounded half past ten.
Title:  
Title:  This time, without knowing why, d'Artagnan felt a cold shiver run
Title:  through his veins.  Perhaps the cold began to affect him, and he
Title:  took a perfectly physical sensation for a moral impression.
Title:  
Title:  Then the idea seized him that he had read incorrectly, and that
Title:  the appointment was for eleven o'clock.  He drew near to the
Title:  window, and placing himself so that a ray of light should fall
Title:  upon the letter as he held it, he drew it from his pocket and
Title:  read it again; but he had not been mistaken, the appointment was
Title:  for ten o'clock.  He went and resumed his post, beginning to be
Title:  rather uneasy at this silence and this solitude.
Title:  
Title:  Eleven o'clock sounded.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan began now really to fear that something had happened
Title:  to Mme. Bonacieux.  He clapped his hands three times--the
Title:  ordinary signal of lovers; but nobody replied to him, not even an
Title:  echo.
Title:  
Title:  He then thought, with a touch of vexation, that perhaps the young
Title:  woman had fallen asleep while waiting for him.  He approached the
Title:  wall, and tried to climb it; but the wall had been recently
Title:  pointed, and d'Artagnan could get no hold.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment he thought of the trees, upon whose leaves the
Title:  light still shone; and as one of them drooped over the road, he
Title:  thought that from its branches he might get a glimpse of the
Title:  interior of the pavilion.
Title:  
Title:  The tree was easy to climb.  Besides, d'Artagnan was but twenty
Title:  years old, and consequently had not yet forgotten his schoolboy
Title:  habits.  In an instant he was among the branches, and his keen
Title:  eyes plunged through the transparent panes into the interior of
Title:  the pavilion.
Title:  
Title:  It was a strange thing, and one which made d'Artagnan tremble
Title:  from the sole of his foot to the roots of his hair, to find that
Title:  this soft light, this calm lamp, enlightened a scene of fearful
Title:  disorder.  One of the windows was broken, the door of the chamber
Title:  had been beaten in and hung, split in two, on its hinges.  A
Title:  table, which had been covered with an elegant supper, was
Title:  overturned.  The decanters broken in pieces, and the fruits
Title:  crushed, strewed the floor.  Everything in the apartment gave
Title:  evidence of a violent and desperate struggle.  D'Artagnan even
Title:  fancied he could recognize amid this strange disorder, fragments
Title:  of garments, and some bloody spots staining the cloth and the
Title:  curtains.  He hastened to descend into the street, with a
Title:  frightful beating at his heart; he wished to see if he could find
Title:  other traces of violence.
Title:  
Title:  The little soft light shone on in the calmness of the night.
Title:  d'Artagnan then perceived a thing that he had not before
Title:  remarked--for nothing had led him to the examination--that the
Title:  ground, trampled here and hoofmarked there, presented confused
Title:  traces of men and horses.  Besides, the wheels of a carriage,
Title:  which appeared to have come from Paris, had made a deep
Title:  impression in the soft earth, which did not extend beyond the
Title:  pavilion, but turned again toward Paris.
Title:  
Title:  At length d'Artagnan, in pursuing his researches, found near the
Title:  wall a woman's torn glove.  This glove, wherever it had not
Title:  touched the muddy ground, was of irreproachable odor.  It was one
Title:  of those perfumed gloves that lovers like to snatch from a pretty
Title:  hand.
Title:  
Title:  As d'Artagnan pursued his investigations, a more abundant and
Title:  more icy sweat rolled in large drops from his forehead; his heart
Title:  was oppressed by a horrible anguish; his respiration was broken
Title:  and short.  And yet he said, to reassure himself, that this
Title:  pavilion perhaps had nothing in common with Mme. Bonacieux; that
Title:  the young woman had made an appointment with him before the
Title:  pavilion, and not in the pavilion; that she might have been
Title:  detained in Paris by her duties, or perhaps by the jealousy of
Title:  her husband.
Title:  
Title:  But all these reasons were combated, destroyed, overthrown, by
Title:  that feeling of intimate pain which, on certain occasions, takes
Title:  possession of our being, and cries to us so as to be understood
Title:  unmistakably that some great misfortune is hanging over us.
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan became almost wild.  He ran along the high road,
Title:  took the path he had before taken, and reaching the ferry,
Title:  interrogated the boatman.
Title:  
Title:  About seven o'clock in the evening, the boatman had taken over a
Title:  young woman, wrapped in a black mantle, who appeared to be very
Title:  anxious not to be recognized; but entirely on account of her
Title:  precautions, the boatman had paid more attention to her and
Title:  discovered that she was young and pretty.
Title:  
Title:  There were then, as now, a crowd of young and pretty women who
Title:  came to St. Cloud, and who had reasons for not being seen, and
Title:  yet d'Artagnan did not for an instant doubt that it was Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux whom the boatman had noticed.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took advantage of the lamp which burned in the cabin
Title:  of the ferryman to read the billet of Mme. Bonacieux once again,
Title:  and satisfy himself that he had not been mistaken, that the
Title:  appointment was at St. Cloud and not elsewhere, before the
Title:  D'Estrees's pavilion and not in another street.  Everything
Title:  conspired to prove to d'Artagnan that his presentiments had not
Title:  deceived him, and that a great misfortune had happened.
Title:  
Title:  He again ran back to the chateau.  It appeared to him that
Title:  something might have happened at the pavilion in his absence, and
Title:  that fresh information awaited him.  The lane was still deserted,
Title:  and the same calm soft light shone through the window.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan then thought of that cottage, silent and obscure,
Title:  which had no doubt seen all, and could tell its tale.  The gate
Title:  of the enclosure was shut; but he leaped over the hedge, and in
Title:  spite of the barking of a chained-up dog, went up to the cabin.
Title:  
Title:  No one answered to his first knocking.  A silence of death
Title:  reigned in the cabin as in the pavilion; but as the cabin was his
Title:  last resource, he knocked again.
Title:  
Title:  It soon appeared to him that he heard a slight noise within--a
Title:  timid noise which seemed to tremble lest it should be heard.
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan ceased knocking, and prayed with an accent so
Title:  full of anxiety and promises, terror and cajolery, that his voice
Title:  was of a nature to reassure the most fearful.  At length an old,
Title:  worm-eaten shutter was opened, or rather pushed ajar, but closed
Title:  again as soon as the light from a miserable lamp which burned in
Title:  the corner had shone upon the baldric, sword belt, and pistol
Title:  pommels of d'Artagnan.  Nevertheless, rapid as the movement had
Title:  been, d'Artagnan had had time to get a glimpse of the head of an
Title:  old man.
Title:  
Title:  "In the name of heaven!" cried he, "listen to me; I have been
Title:  waiting for someone who has not come.  I am dying with anxiety.
Title:  Has anything particular happened in the neighborhood?  Speak!"
Title:  
Title:  The window was again opened slowly, and the same face appeared,
Title:  only it was now still more pale than before.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related his story simply, with the omission of names.
Title:  He told how he had a rendezvous with a young woman before that
Title:  pavilion, and how, not seeing her come, he had climbed the linden
Title:  tree, and by the light of the lamp had seen the disorder of the
Title:  chamber.
Title:  
Title:  The old man listened attentively, making a sign only that it was
Title:  all so; and then, when d'Artagnan had ended, he shook his head
Title:  with an air that announced nothing good.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean?" cried d'Artagnan.  "In the name of heaven,
Title:  explain yourself!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh!  Monsieur," said the old man, "ask me nothing; for if I
Title:  dared tell you what I have seen, certainly no good would befall
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "You have, then, seen something?" replied d'Artagnan.  "In that
Title:  case, in the name of heaven," continued he, throwing him a
Title:  pistole, "tell me what you have seen, and I will pledge you the
Title:  word of a gentleman that not one of your words shall escape from
Title:  my heart."
Title:  
Title:  The old man read so much truth and so much grief in the face of
Title:  the young man that he made him a sign to listen, and repeated in
Title:  a low voice: "It was scarcely nine o'clock when I heard a noise
Title:  in the street, and was wondering what it could be, when on coming
Title:  to my door, I found that somebody was endeavoring to open it.  As
Title:  I am very poor and am not afraid of being robbed, I went and
Title:  opened the gate and saw three men at a few paces from it.  In the
Title:  shadow was a carriage with two horses, and some saddlehorses.
Title:  These horses evidently belonged to the three men, who were dressed
Title:  as cavaliers.  'Ah, my worthy gentlemen,' cried I, 'what do you
Title:  want?'  'You must have a ladder?' said he who appeared to be the
Title:  leader of the party.  'Yes, monsieur, the one with which I gather
Title:  my fruit.'  'Lend it to us, and go into your house again; there
Title:  is a crown for the annoyance we have caused you.  Only remember
Title:  this--if you speak a word of what you may see or what you may
Title:  hear (for you will look and you will listen, I am quite sure,
Title:  however we may threaten you), you are lost.'  At these words he
Title:  threw me a crown, which I picked up, and he took the ladder.
Title:  After shutting the gate behind them, I pretended to return to the
Title:  house, but I immediately went out a back door, and stealing along
Title:  in the shade of the hedge, I gained yonder clump of elder, from
Title:  which I could hear and see everything.  The three men brought the
Title:  carriage up quietly, and took out of it a little man, stout,
Title:  short, elderly, and commonly dressed in clothes of a dark color,
Title:  who ascended the ladder very carefully, looked suspiciously in at
Title:  the window of the pavilion, came down as quietly as he had gone
Title:  up, and whispered, 'It is she!'  Immediately, he who had spoken
Title:  to me approached the door of the pavilion, opened it with a key
Title:  he had in his hand, closed the door and disappeared, while at the
Title:  same time the other two men ascended the ladder.  The little old
Title:  man remained at the coach door; the coachman took care of his
Title:  horses, the lackey held the saddlehorses.  All at once great
Title:  cries resounded in the pavilion, and a woman came to the window,
Title:  and opened it, as if to throw herself out of it; but as soon as
Title:  she perceived the other two men, she fell back and they went into
Title:  the chamber.  Then I saw no more; but I heard the noise of
Title:  breaking furniture.  The woman screamed, and cried for help; but
Title:  her cries were soon stifled.  Two of the men appeared, bearing
Title:  the woman in their arms, and carried her to the carriage, into
Title:  which the little old man got after her.  The leader closed the
Title:  window, came out an instant after by the door, and satisfied
Title:  himself that the woman was in the carriage.  His two companions
Title:  were already on horseback.  He sprang into his saddle; the lackey
Title:  took his place by the coachman; the carriage went off at a quick
Title:  pace, escorted by the three horsemen, and all was over.  From
Title:  that moment I have neither seen nor heard anything."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, entirely overcome by this terrible story, remained
Title:  motionless and mute, while all the demons of anger and jealousy
Title:  were howling in his heart.
Title:  
Title:  "But, my good gentleman," resumed the old man, upon whom this
Title:  mute despair certainly produced a greater effect than cries and
Title:  tears would have done, "do not take on so; they did not kill her,
Title:  and that's a comfort."
Title:  
Title:  "Can you guess," said d'Artagnan, "who was the man who headed
Title:  this infernal expedition?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know him."
Title:  
Title:  "But as you spoke to him you must have seen him."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, it's a description you want?"
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly so."
Title:  
Title:  "A tall, dark man, with black mustaches, dark eyes, and the air
Title:  of a gentleman."
Title:  
Title:  "That's the man!" cried d'Artagnan, "again he, forever he!  He is
Title:  my demon, apparently.  And the other?"
Title:  
Title:  "Which?"
Title:  
Title:  "The short one."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, he was not a gentleman, I'll answer for it; besides, he did
Title:  not wear a sword, and the others treated him with small
Title:  consideration."
Title:  
Title:  "Some lackey," murmured d'Artagnan.  "Poor woman, poor woman,
Title:  what have they done with you?"
Title:  
Title:  "You have promised to be secret, my good monsieur?" said the old
Title:  man.
Title:  
Title:  "And I renew my promise.  Be easy, I am a gentleman.  A gentleman
Title:  has but his word, and I have given you mine."
Title:  
Title:  With a heavy heart, d'Artagnan again bent his way toward the
Title:  ferry.  Sometimes he hoped it could not be Mme. Bonacieux, and
Title:  that he should find her next day at the Louvre; sometimes he
Title:  feared she had had an intrigue with another, who, in a jealous
Title:  fit, had surprised her and carried her off.  His mind was torn by
Title:  doubt, grief, and despair.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, if I had my three friends here," cried he, "I should have,
Title:  at least, some hopes of finding her; but who knows what has
Title:  become of them?"
Title:  
Title:  It was past midnight; the next thing was to find Planchet.
Title:  d'Artagnan went successively into all the cabarets in which there
Title:  was a light, but could not find Planchet in any of them.
Title:  
Title:  At the sixth he began to reflect that the search was rather
Title:  dubious.  D'Artagnan had appointed six o'clock in the morning for
Title:  his lackey, and wherever he might be, he was right.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, it came into the young man's mind that by remaining in
Title:  the environs of the spot on which this sad event had passed, he
Title:  would, perhaps, have some light thrown upon the mysterious
Title:  affair.  At the sixth cabaret, then, as we said, d'Artagnan
Title:  stopped, asked for a bottle of wine of the best quality, and
Title:  placing himself in the darkest corner of the room, determined
Title:  thus to wait till daylight; but this time again his hopes were
Title:  disappointed, and although he listened with all his ears, he
Title:  heard nothing, amid the oaths, coarse jokes, and abuse which
Title:  passed between the laborers, servants, and carters who comprised
Title:  the honorable society of which he formed a part, which could put
Title:  him upon the least track of her who had been stolen from him.  He
Title:  was compelled, then, after having swallowed the contents of his
Title:  bottle, to pass the time as well as to evade suspicion, to fall
Title:  into the easiest position in his corner and to sleep, whether
Title:  well or ill.  D'Artagnan, be it remembered, was only twenty years
Title:  old, and at that age sleep has its imprescriptible rights which
Title:  it imperiously insists upon, even with the saddest hearts.
Title:  
Title:  Toward six o'clock d'Artagnan awoke with that uncomfortable
Title:  feeling which generally accompanies the break of day after a bad
Title:  night.  He was not long in making his toilet.  He examined
Title:  himself to see if advantage had been taken of his sleep, and
Title:  having found his diamond ring on his finger, his purse in his
Title:  pocket, and his pistols in his belt, he rose, paid for his
Title:  bottle, and went out to try if he could have any better luck in
Title:  his search after his lackey than he had had the night before.
Title:  The first thing he perceived through the damp gray mist was
Title:  honest Planchet, who, with the two horses in hand, awaited him at
Title:  the door of a little blind cabaret, before which d'Artagnan had
Title:  passed without even a suspicion of its existence.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  25  PORTHOS
Title:  
Title:  Instead of returning directly home, d'Artagnan alighted at the
Title:  door of M. de Treville, and ran quickly up the stairs.  This time
Title:  he had decided to relate all that had passed.  M. de Treville
Title:  would doubtless give him good advice as to the whole affair.
Title:  Besides, as M. de Treville saw the queen almost daily, he might
Title:  be able to draw from her Majesty some intelligence of the poor
Title:  young woman, whom they were doubtless making pay very dearly for
Title:  her devotedness to her mistress.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville listened to the young man's account with a
Title:  seriousness which proved that he saw something else in this
Title:  adventure besides a love affair.  When d'Artagnan had finished,
Title:  he said, "Hum!  All this savors of his Eminence, a league off."
Title:  
Title:  "But what is to be done?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, absolutely nothing, at present, but quitting Paris,
Title:  as I told you, as soon as possible.  I will see the queen; I will
Title:  relate to her the details of the disappearance of this poor
Title:  woman, of which she is no doubt ignorant.  These details will
Title:  guide her on her part, and on your return, I shall perhaps have
Title:  some good news to tell you.  Rely on me."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan knew that, although a Gascon, M. de Treville was not
Title:  in the habit of making promises, and that when by chance he did
Title:  promise, he more than kept his word.  He bowed to him, then, full
Title:  of gratitude for the past and for the future; and the worthy
Title:  captain, who on his side felt a lively interest in this young
Title:  man, so brave and so resolute, pressed his hand kindly, wishing
Title:  him a pleasant journey.
Title:  
Title:  Determined to put the advice of M. de Treville in practice
Title:  instantly, d'Artagnan directed his course toward the Rue des
Title:  Fossoyeurs, in order to superintend the packing of his valise.
Title:  On approaching the house, he perceived M. Bonacieux in morning
Title:  costume, standing at his threshold.  All that the prudent
Title:  Planchet had said to him the preceding evening about the sinister
Title:  character of the old man recurred to the mind of d'Artagnan, who
Title:  looked at him with more attention than he had done before.  In
Title:  fact, in addition to that yellow, sickly paleness which indicates
Title:  the insinuation of the bile in the blood, and which might,
Title:  besides, be accidental, d'Artagnan remarked something
Title:  perfidiously significant in the play of the wrinkled features of
Title:  his countenance.  A rogue does not laugh in the same way that an
Title:  honest man does; a hypocrite does not shed the tears of a man of
Title:  good faith.  All falsehood is a mask; and however well made the
Title:  mask may be, with a little attention we may always succeed in
Title:  distinguishing it from the true face.
Title:  
Title:  It appeared, then, to d'Artagnan that M. Bonacieux wore a mask,
Title:  and likewise that that mask was most disagreeable to look upon.
Title:  In consequence of this feeling of repugnance, he was about to
Title:  pass without speaking to him, but, as he had done the day before,
Title:  M. Bonacieux accosted him.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, young man," said he, "we appear to pass rather gay nights!
Title:  Seven o'clock in the morning!  PESTE!  You seem to reverse
Title:  ordinary customs, and come home at the hour when other people are
Title:  going out."
Title:  
Title:  "No one can reproach you for anything of the kind, Monsieur
Title:  Bonacieux," said the young man; "you are a model for regular
Title:  people.  It is true that when a man possesses a young and pretty
Title:  wife, he has no need to seek happiness elsewhere.  Happiness
Title:  comes to meet him, does it not, Monsieur Bonacieux?"
Title:  
Title:  Bonacieux became as pale as death, and grinned a ghastly smile.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Bonacieux, "you are a jocular companion!  But
Title:  where the devil were you gladding last night, my young master?
Title:  It does not appear to be very clean in the crossroads."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan glanced down at his boots, all covered with mud; but
Title:  that same glance fell upon the shoes and stockings of the mercer,
Title:  and it might have been said they had been dipped in the same mud
Title:  heap.  Both were stained with splashes of mud of the same
Title:  appearance.
Title:  
Title:  Then a sudden idea crossed the mind of d'Artagnan.  That little
Title:  stout man, short and elderly, that sort of lackey, dressed in
Title:  dark clothes, treated without ceremony by the men wearing swords
Title:  who composed the escort, was Bonacieux himself.  The husband had
Title:  presided at the abduction of his wife.
Title:  
Title:  A terrible inclination seized d'Artagnan to grasp the mercer by
Title:  the throat and strangle him; but, as we have said, he was a very
Title:  prudent youth, and he restrained himself.  However, the
Title:  revolution which appeared upon his countenance was so visible
Title:  that Bonacieux was terrified at it, and he endeavored to draw
Title:  back a step or two; but as he was standing before the half of the
Title:  door which was shut, the obstacle compelled him to keep his
Title:  place.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, but you are joking, my worthy man!" said d'Artagnan.  It
Title:  appears to me that if my boots need a sponge, your stockings and
Title:  shoes stand in equal need of a brush.  May you not have been
Title:  philandering a little also, Monsieur Bonacieux?  Oh, the devil!
Title:  That's unpardonable in a man of your age, and who besides, has
Title:  such a pretty wife as yours."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, Lord! no," said Bonacieux, "but yesterday I went to St.
Title:  Mande to make some inquiries after a servant, as I cannot
Title:  possibly do without one; and the roads were so bad that I brought
Title:  back all this mud, which I have not yet had time to remove."
Title:  
Title:  The place named by Bonacieux as that which had been the object of
Title:  his journey was a fresh proof in support of the suspicions
Title:  d'Artagnan had conceived.  Bonacieux had named Mande because
Title:  Mande was in an exactly opposite direction from St. Cloud.  This
Title:  probability afforded him his first consolation.  If Bonacieux
Title:  knew where his wife was, one might, by extreme means, force the
Title:  mercer to open his teeth and let his secret escape.  The
Title:  question, then, was how to change this probability into a
Title:  certainty.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, if I don't stand upon
Title:  ceremony," said d'Artagnan, "but nothing makes one so thirsty as
Title:  want of sleep.  I am parched with thirst.  Allow me to take a
Title:  glass of water in your apartment; you know that is never refused
Title:  among neighbors."
Title:  
Title:  Without waiting for the permission of his host, d'Artagnan went
Title:  quickly into the house, and cast a rapid glance at the bed.  It
Title:  had not been used.  Bonacieux had not been abed.  He had only
Title:  been back an hour or two; he had accompanied his wife to the
Title:  place of her confinement, or else at least to the first relay.
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, Monsieur Bonacieux," said d'Artagnan, emptying his
Title:  glass, "that is all I wanted of you.  I will now go up into my
Title:  apartment.  I will make Planchet brush my boots; and when he has
Title:  done, I will, if you like, send him to you to brush your shoes."
Title:  
Title:  He left the mercer quite astonished at his singular farewell, and
Title:  asking himself if he had not been a little inconsiderate.
Title:  
Title:  At the top of the stairs he found Planchet in a great fright.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!" cried Planchet, as soon as he perceived his
Title:  master, "here is more trouble.  I thought you would never come
Title:  in."
Title:  
Title:  "What's the matter now, Planchet?" demanded d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh!  I give you a hundred, I give you a thousand times to guess,
Title:  monsieur, the visit I received in your absence."
Title:  
Title:  "When?"
Title:  
Title:  "About half an hour ago, while you were at Monsieur de
Title:  Treville's."
Title:  
Title:  "Who has been here?  Come, speak."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Cavois."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Cavois?"
Title:  
Title:  "In person."
Title:  
Title:  "The captain of the cardinal's Guards?"
Title:  
Title:  "Himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Did he come to arrest me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have no doubt that he did, monsieur, for all his wheedling
Title:  manner."
Title:  
Title:  "Was he so sweet, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed, he was all honey, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  "He came, he said, on the part of his Eminence, who wished you
Title:  well, and to beg you to follow him to the Palais-Royal."*
Title:  
Title:  *It was called the Palais-Cardinal before Richelieu gave it to
Title:  the King.
Title:  
Title:  "What did you answer him?"
Title:  
Title:  "That the thing was impossible, seeing that you were not at home,
Title:  as he could see."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what did he say then?"
Title:  
Title:  "That you must not fail to call upon him in the course of the
Title:  day; and then he added in a low voice, 'Tell your master that his
Title:  Eminence is very well disposed toward him, and that his fortune
Title:  perhaps depends upon this interview.'"
Title:  
Title:  "The snare is rather MALADROIT for the cardinal," replied the
Title:  young man, smiling.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I saw the snare, and I answered you would be quite in
Title:  despair on your return.
Title:  
Title:  "'Where has he gone?' asked Monsieur de Cavois.
Title:  
Title:  "'To Troyes, in Champagne,' I answered.
Title:  
Title:  "'And when did he set out?'
Title:  
Title:  "'Yesterday evening.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet, my friend," interrupted d'Artagnan, "you are really a
Title:  precious fellow."
Title:  
Title:  "You will understand, monsieur, I thought there would be still
Title:  time, if you wish, to see Monsieur de Cavois to contradict me by
Title:  saying you were not yet gone.  The falsehood would then lie at my
Title:  door, and as I am not a gentleman, I may be allowed to lie."
Title:  
Title:  "Be of good heart, Planchet, you shall preserve your reputation
Title:  as a veracious man.  In a quarter of an hour we set off."
Title:  
Title:  "That's the advice I was about to give Monsieur; and where are we
Title:  going, may I ask, without being too curious?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU!  In the opposite direction to that which you said I was
Title:  gone.  Besides, are you not as anxious to learn news of Grimaud,
Title:  Mousqueton, and Bazin as I am to know what has become of Athos,
Title:  Porthos, and Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," said Planchet, "and I will go as soon as you
Title:  please.  Indeed, I think provincial air will suit us much better
Title:  just now than the air of Paris.  So then--"
Title:  
Title:  "So then, pack up our luggage, Planchet, and let us be off.  On
Title:  my part, I will go out with my hands in my pockets, that nothing
Title:  may be suspected.  You may join me at the Hotel des Gardes.  By
Title:  the way, Planchet, I think you are right with respect to our
Title:  host, and that he is decidedly a frightfully low wretch."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur, you may take my word when I tell you anything.  I
Title:  am a physiognomist, I assure you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan went out first, as had been agreed upon.  Then, in
Title:  order that he might have nothing to reproach himself with, he
Title:  directed his steps, for the last time, toward the residences of
Title:  his three friends.  No news had been received of them; only a
Title:  letter, all perfumed and of an elegant writing in small
Title:  characters, had come for Aramis.  D'Artagnan took charge of it.
Title:  Ten minutes afterward Planchet joined him at the stables of the
Title:  Hotel des Gardes.  D'Artagnan, in order that there might be no
Title:  time lost, had saddled his horse himself.
Title:  
Title:  "That's well," said he to Planchet, when the latter added the
Title:  portmanteau to the equipment.  "Now saddle the other three
Title:  horses."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you think, then, monsieur, that we shall travel faster with
Title:  two horses apiece?" said Planchet, with his shrewd air.
Title:  
Title:  "No, Monsieur Jester," replied d'Artagnan; "but with our four
Title:  horses we may bring back our three friends, if we should have the
Title:  good fortune to find them living."
Title:  
Title:  "Which is a great chance," replied Planchet, "but we must not
Title:  despair of the mercy of God."
Title:  
Title:  "Amen!" said d'Artagnan, getting into his saddle.
Title:  
Title:  As they went from the Hotel des Gardes, they separated, leaving
Title:  the street at opposite ends, one having to quit Paris by the
Title:  Barriere de la Villette and the other by the Barriere Montmartre,
Title:  to meet again beyond St. Denis--a strategic maneuver which,
Title:  having been executed with equal punctuality, was crowned with the
Title:  most fortunate results.  D'Artagnan and Planchet entered
Title:  Pierrefitte together.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet was more courageous, it must be admitted, by day than by
Title:  night.  His natural prudence, however, never forsook him for a
Title:  single instant.  He had forgotten not one of the incidents of the
Title:  first journey, and he looked upon everybody he met on the road as
Title:  an enemy.  It followed that his hat was forever in his hand,
Title:  which procured him some severe reprimands from d'Artagnan, who
Title:  feared that his excess of politeness would lead people to think
Title:  he was the lackey of a man of no consequence.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, whether the passengers were really touched by the
Title:  urbanity of Planchet or whether this time nobody was posted on
Title:  the young man's road, our two travelers arrived at Chantilly
Title:  without any accident, and alighted at the tavern of Great St.
Title:  Martin, the same at which they had stopped on their first
Title:  journey.
Title:  
Title:  The host, on seeing a young man followed by a lackey with two
Title:  extra horses, advanced respectfully to the door.  Now, as they
Title:  had already traveled eleven leagues, d'Artagnan thought it time
Title:  to stop, whether Porthos were or were not in the inn.  Perhaps it
Title:  would not be prudent to ask at once what had become of the
Title:  Musketeer.  The result of these reflections was that d'Artagnan,
Title:  without asking information of any kind, alighted, commended the
Title:  horses to the care of his lackey, entered a small room destined
Title:  to receive those who wished to be alone, and desired the host to
Title:  bring him a bottle of his best wine and as good a breakfast as
Title:  possible--a desire which further corroborated the high opinion
Title:  the innkeeper had formed of the traveler at first sight.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was therefore served with miraculous celerity.  The
Title:  regiment of the Guards was recruited among the first gentlemen of
Title:  the kingdom; and d'Artagnan, followed by a lackey, and traveling
Title:  with four magnificent horses, despite the simplicity of his
Title:  uniform, could not fail to make a sensation.  The host desired
Title:  himself to serve him; which d'Artagnan perceiving, ordered two
Title:  glasses to be brought, and commenced the following conversation.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, my good host," said d'Artagnan, filling the two
Title:  glasses, "I asked for a bottle of your best wine, and if you have
Title:  deceived me, you will be punished in what you have sinned; for
Title:  seeing that I hate drinking my myself, you shall drink with me.
Title:  Take your glass, then, and let us drink.  But what shall we drink
Title:  to, so as to avoid wounding any susceptibility?  Let us drink to
Title:  the prosperity of your establishment."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Lordship does me much honor," said the host, "and I thank
Title:  you sincerely for your kind wish."
Title:  
Title:  "But don't mistake," said d'Artagnan, "there is more selfishness
Title:  in my toast than perhaps you may think--for it is only in
Title:  prosperous establishments that one is well received.  In hotels
Title:  that do not flourish, everything is in confusion, and the
Title:  traveler is a victim to the embarrassments of his host.  Now, I
Title:  travel a great deal, particularly on this road, and I wish to see
Title:  all innkeepers making a fortune."
Title:  
Title:  "It seems to me," said the host, "that this is not the first time
Title:  I have had the honor of seeing Monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah, I have passed perhaps ten times through Chantilly, and out
Title:  of the ten times I have stopped three or four times at your house
Title:  at least.  Why I was here only ten or twelve days ago.  I was
Title:  conducting some friends, Musketeers, one of whom, by the by, had
Title:  a dispute with a stranger--a man who sought a quarrel with him,
Title:  for I don't know what."
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly so," said the host; "I remember it perfectly.  It is not
Title:  Monsieur Porthos that your Lordship means?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that is my companion's name.  My God, my dear host, tell me
Title:  if anything has happened to him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Your Lordship must have observed that he could not continue his
Title:  journey."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, to be sure, he promised to rejoin us, and we have seen
Title:  nothing of him."
Title:  
Title:  "He has done us the honor to remain here."
Title:  
Title:  "What, he had done you the honor to remain here?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, in this house; and we are even a little uneasy--"
Title:  
Title:  "On what account?"
Title:  
Title:  "Of certain expenses he has contracted."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but whatever expenses he may have incurred, I am sure he
Title:  is in a condition to pay them."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur, you infuse genuine balm into my blood.  We have
Title:  made considerable advances; and this very morning the surgeon
Title:  declared that if Monsieur Porthos did not pay him, he should look
Title:  to me, as it was I who had sent for him."
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos is wounded, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "I cannot tell you, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "What!  You cannot tell me?  Surely you ought to be able to tell
Title:  me better than any other person."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but in our situation we must not say all we know--
Title:  particularly as we have been warned that our ears should answer
Title:  for our tongues."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, can I see Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly, monsieur.  Take the stairs on your right; go up the
Title:  first flight and knock at Number One.  Only warn him that it is
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "Why should I do that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because, monsieur, some mischief might happen to you."
Title:  
Title:  "Of what kind, in the name of wonder?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Porthos may imagine you belong to the house, and in a
Title:  fit of passion might run his sword through you or blow out your
Title:  brains."
Title:  
Title:  "What have you done to him, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "We have asked him for money."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  Ah, I can understand that.  It is a demand that
Title:  Porthos takes very ill when he is not in funds; but I know he
Title:  must be so at present."
Title:  
Title:  "We thought so, too, monsieur.  As our house is carried on very
Title:  regularly, and we make out our bills every week, at the end of
Title:  eight days we presented our account; but it appeared we had
Title:  chosen an unlucky moment, for at the first word on the subject,
Title:  he sent us to all the devils.  It is true he had been playing the
Title:  day before."
Title:  
Title:  "Playing the day before!  And with whom?"
Title:  
Title:  "Lord, who can say, monsieur?  With some gentleman who was
Title:  traveling this way, to whom he proposed a game of LANSQUENET."
Title:  
Title:  "That's it, then, and the foolish fellow lost all he had?"
Title:  
Title:  "Even to his horse, monsieur; for when the gentleman was about to
Title:  set out, we perceived that his lackey was saddling Monsieur
Title:  Porthos's horse, as well as his master's.  When we observed this
Title:  to him, he told us all to trouble ourselves about our own
Title:  business, as this horse belonged to him.  We also informed
Title:  Monsieur Porthos of what was going on; but he told us we were
Title:  scoundrels to doubt a gentleman's word, and that as he had said
Title:  the horse was his, it must be so."
Title:  
Title:  "That's Porthos all over," murmured d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," continued the host, "I replied that as from the moment we
Title:  seemed not likely to come to a good understanding with respect to
Title:  payment, I hoped that he would have at least the kindness to
Title:  grant the favor of his custom to my brother host of the Golden
Title:  Eagle; but Monsieur Porthos replied that, my house being the
Title:  best, he should remain where he was.  This reply was too
Title:  flattering to allow me to insist on his departure.  I confined
Title:  myself then to begging him to give up his chamber, which is the
Title:  handsomest in the hotel, and to be satisfied with a pretty little
Title:  room on the third floor; but to this Monsieur Porthos replied
Title:  that as he every moment expected his mistress, who was one of the
Title:  greatest ladies in the court, I might easily comprehend that the
Title:  chamber he did me the honor to occupy in my house was itself very
Title:  mean for the visit of such a personage.  Nevertheless, while
Title:  acknowledging the truth of what he said, I thought proper to
Title:  insist; but without even giving himself the trouble to enter into
Title:  any discussion with me, he took one of his pistols, laid it on
Title:  his table, day and night, and said that at the first word that
Title:  should be spoken to him about removing, either within the house
Title:  or out of it, he would blow out the brains of the person who
Title:  should be so imprudent as to meddle with a matter which only
Title:  concerned himself.  Since that time, monsieur, nobody entered his
Title:  chamber but his servant."
Title:  
Title:  "What!  Mousqueton is here, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, monsieur.  Five days after your departure, he came
Title:  back, and in a very bad condition, too.  It appears that he had
Title:  met with disagreeableness, likewise, on his journey.  Unfortunately,
Title:  he is more nimble than his master; so that for the sake of his
Title:  master, he puts us all under his feet, and as he thinks we might
Title:  refuse what he asked for, he takes all he wants without asking at
Title:  all."
Title:  
Title:  "The fact is," said d'Artagnan, "I have always observed a great
Title:  degree of intelligence and devotedness in Mousqueton."
Title:  
Title:  "That is possible, monsieur; but suppose I should happen to be
Title:  brought in contact, even four times a year, with such
Title:  intelligence and devotedness--why, I should be a ruined man!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, for Porthos will pay you."
Title:  
Title:  "Hum!" said the host, in a doubtful tone.
Title:  
Title:  "The favorite of a great lady will not be allowed to be
Title:  inconvenienced for such a paltry sum as he owes you."
Title:  
Title:  "If I durst say what I believe on that head--"
Title:  
Title:  "What you believe?"
Title:  
Title:  "I ought rather to say, what I know."
Title:  
Title:  "What you know?"
Title:  
Title:  "And even what I am sure of."
Title:  
Title:  "And of what are you so sure?"
Title:  
Title:  "I would say that I know this great lady."
Title:  
Title:  "You?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; I."
Title:  
Title:  "And how do you know her?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, monsieur, if I could believe I might trust in your
Title:  discretion."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak!  By the word of a gentleman, you shall have no cause to
Title:  repent of your confidence."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur, you understand that uneasiness makes us do many
Title:  things."
Title:  
Title:  "What have you done?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, nothing which was not right in the character of a creditor."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Porthos gave us a note for his duchess, ordering us to
Title:  put it in the post.  This was before his servant came.  As he
Title:  could not leave his chamber, it was necessary to charge us with
Title:  this commission."
Title:  
Title:  "And then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Instead of putting the letter in the post, which is never safe,
Title:  I took advantage of the journey of one of my lads to Paris, and
Title:  ordered him to convey the letter to this duchess himself.  This
Title:  was fulfilling the intentions of Monsieur Porthos, who had
Title:  desired us to be so careful of this letter, was it not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nearly so."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur, do you know who this great lady is?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; I have heard Porthos speak of her, that's all."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know who this pretended duchess is?
Title:  
Title:  "I repeat to you, I don't know her."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, she is the old wife of a procurator* of the Chatelet,
Title:  monsieur, named Madame Coquenard, who, although she is at least
Title:  fifty, still gives herself jealous airs.  It struck me as very
Title:  odd that a princess should live in the Rue aux Ours."
Title:  
Title:  *Attorney
Title:  
Title:  "But how do you know all this?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because she flew into a great passion on receiving the letter,
Title:  saying that Monsieur Porthos was a weathercock, and that she was
Title:  sure it was for some woman he had received this wound."
Title:  
Title:  "Has he been wounded, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, good Lord!  What have I said?"
Title:  
Title:  "You said that Porthos had received a sword cut."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but he has forbidden me so strictly to say so."
Title:  
Title:  "And why so."
Title:  
Title:  "Zounds, monsieur!  Because he had boasted that he would
Title:  perforate the stranger with whom you left him in dispute; whereas
Title:  the stranger, on the contrary, in spite of all his rodomontades
Title:  quickly threw him on his back.  As Monsieur Porthos is a very
Title:  boastful man, he insists that nobody shall know he has received
Title:  this wound except the duchess, whom he endeavored to interest by
Title:  an account of his adventure."
Title:  
Title:  "It is a wound that confines him to his bed?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, and a master stroke, too, I assure you.  Your friend's soul
Title:  must stick tight to his body."
Title:  
Title:  "Were you there, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, I followed them from curiosity, so that I saw the
Title:  combat without the combatants seeing me."
Title:  
Title:  "And what took place?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh!  The affair was not long, I assure you.  They placed
Title:  themselves on guard; the stranger made a feint and a lunge, and
Title:  that so rapidly that when Monsieur Porthos came to the PARADE, he
Title:  had already three inches of steel in his breast.  He immediately
Title:  fell backward.  The stranger placed the point of his sword at his
Title:  throat; and Monsieur Porthos, finding himself at the mercy of his
Title:  adversary, acknowledged himself conquered.  Upon which the
Title:  stranger asked his name, and learning that it was Porthos, and
Title:  not d'Artagnan, he assisted him to rise, brought him back to the
Title:  hotel, mounted his horse, and disappeared."
Title:  
Title:  "So it was with Monsieur d'Artagnan this stranger meant to
Title:  quarrel?"
Title:  
Title:  "It appears so."
Title:  
Title:  "And do you know what has become of him?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, I never saw him until that moment, and have not seen him
Title:  since."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well; I know all that I wish to know.  Porthos's chamber
Title:  is, you say, on the first story, Number One?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, the handsomest in the inn--a chamber that I could
Title:  have let ten times over."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!  Be satisfied," said d'Artagnan, laughing, "Porthos will
Title:  pay you with the money of the Duchess Coquenard."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, monsieur, procurator's wife or duchess, if she will but
Title:  loosen her pursestrings, it will be all the same; but she
Title:  positively answered that she was tired of the exigencies and
Title:  infidelities of Monsieur Porthos, and that she would not send him
Title:  a denier."
Title:  
Title:  "And did you convey this answer to your guest?"
Title:  
Title:  "We took good care not to do that; he would have found in what
Title:  fashion we had executed his commission."
Title:  
Title:  "So that he still expects his money?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, Lord, yes, monsieur!  Yesterday he wrote again; but it was
Title:  his servant who this time put the letter in the post."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you say the procurator's wife is old and ugly?"
Title:  
Title:  "Fifty at least, monsieur, and not at all handsome, according to
Title:  Pathaud's account."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case, you may be quite at ease; she will soon be
Title:  softened.  Besides, Porthos cannot owe you much."
Title:  
Title:  "How, not much!  Twenty good pistoles, already, without reckoning
Title:  the doctor.  He denies himself nothing; it may easily be seen he
Title:  has been accustomed to live well."
Title:  
Title:  "Never mind; if his mistress abandons him, he will find friends,
Title:  I will answer for it.  So, my dear host, be not uneasy, and
Title:  continue to take all the care of him that his situation
Title:  requires."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur has promised me not to open his mouth about the
Title:  procurator's wife, and not to say a word of the wound?"
Title:  
Title:  "That's agreed; you have my word."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, he would kill me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Don't be afraid; he is not so much of a devil as he appears."
Title:  
Title:  Saying these words, d'Artagnan went upstairs, leaving his host a
Title:  little better satisfied with respect to two things in which he
Title:  appeared to be very much interested--his debt and his life.
Title:  
Title:  At the top of the stairs, upon the most conspicuous door of the
Title:  corridor, was traced in black ink a gigantic number "1."
Title:  d'Artagnan knocked, and upon the bidding to come in which came
Title:  from inside, he entered the chamber.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos was in bed, and was playing a game at LANSQUENET with
Title:  Mousqueton, to keep his hand in; while a spit loaded with
Title:  partridges was turning before the fire, and on each side of a
Title:  large chimneypiece, over two chafing dishes, were boiling two
Title:  stewpans, from which exhaled a double odor of rabbit and fish
Title:  stews, rejoicing to the smell.  In addition to this he perceived
Title:  that the top of a wardrobe and the marble of a commode were
Title:  covered with empty bottles.
Title:  
Title:  At the sight of his friend, Porthos uttered a loud cry of joy;
Title:  and Mousqueton, rising respectfully, yielded his place to him,
Title:  and went to give an eye to the two stewpans, of which he appeared
Title:  to have the particular inspection.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, PARDIEU!  Is that you?" said Porthos to d'Artagnan.  "You
Title:  are right welcome.  Excuse my not coming to meet you; but," added
Title:  he, looking at d'Artagnan with a certain degree of uneasiness,
Title:  "you know what has happened to me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "Has the host told you nothing, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "I asked after you, and came up as soon as I could."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos seemed to breathe more freely.
Title:  
Title:  "And what has happened to you, my dear Porthos?" continued
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, on making a thrust at my adversary, whom I had already hit
Title:  three times, and whom I meant to finish with the fourth, I put my
Title:  foot on a stone, slipped, and strained my knee."
Title:  
Title:  "Truly?"
Title:  
Title:  "Honor!  Luckily for the rascal, for I should have left him dead
Title:  on the spot, I assure you."
Title:  
Title:  "And what has became of him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I don't know; he had enough, and set off without waiting for
Title:  the rest.  But you, my dear d'Artagnan, what has happened to
Title:  you?"
Title:  
Title:  "So that this strain of the knee," continued d'Artagnan, "my dear
Title:  Porthos, keeps you in bed?"
Title:  
Title:  "My God, that's all.  I shall be about again in a few days."
Title:  
Title:  "Why did you not have yourself conveyed to Paris?  You must be
Title:  cruelly bored here."
Title:  
Title:  "That was my intention; but, my dear friend, I have one thing to
Title:  confess to you."
Title:  
Title:  "What's that?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is that as I was cruelly bored, as you say, and as I had the
Title:  seventy-five pistoles in my pocket which you had distributed to
Title:  me, in order to amuse myself I invited a gentleman who was
Title:  traveling this way to walk up, and proposed a cast of dice.  He
Title:  accepted my challenge, and, my faith, my seventy-five pistoles
Title:  passed from my pocket to his, without reckoning my horse, which
Title:  he won into the bargain.  But you, my dear d'Artagnan?"
Title:  
Title:  "What can you expect, my dear Porthos; a man is not privileged in
Title:  all ways," said d'Artagnan.  "You know the proverb 'Unlucky at
Title:  play, lucky in love.'  You are too fortunate in your love for
Title:  play not to take its revenge.  What consequence can the reverses
Title:  of fortune be to you?  Have you not, happy rogue that you are--
Title:  have you not your duchess, who cannot fail to come to your aid?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, you see, my dear d'Artagnan, with what ill luck I play,"
Title:  replied Porthos, with the most careless air in the world.  "I
Title:  wrote to her to send me fifty louis or so, of which I stood
Title:  absolutely in need on account of my accident."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, she must be at her country seat, for she has not answered
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "Truly?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; so I yesterday addressed another epistle to her, still more
Title:  pressing than the first.  But you are here, my dear fellow, let
Title:  us speak of you.  I confess I began to be very uneasy on your
Title:  account."
Title:  
Title:  "But your host behaves very well toward you, as it appears, my
Title:  dear Porthos," said d'Artagnan, directing the sick man's
Title:  attention to the full stewpans and the empty bottles.
Title:  
Title:  "So, so," replied Porthos.  "Only three or four days ago the
Title:  impertinent jackanapes gave me his bill, and I was forced to turn
Title:  both him and his bill out of the door; so that I am here
Title:  something in the fashion of a conqueror, holding my position, as
Title:  it were, my conquest.  So you see, being in constant fear of
Title:  being forced from that position, I am armed to the teeth."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," said d'Artagnan, laughing, "it appears to me that from
Title:  time to time you must make SORTIES."  And he again pointed to the
Title:  bottles and the stewpans.
Title:  
Title:  "Not I, unfortunately!" said Porthos.  "This miserable strain
Title:  confines me to my bed; but Mousqueton forages, and brings in
Title:  provisions.  Friend Mousqueton, you see that we have a
Title:  reinforcement, and we must have an increase of supplies."
Title:  
Title:  "Mousqueton," said d'Artagnan, "you must render me a service."
Title:  
Title:  "What, monsieur?"
Title:  
Title:  "You must give your recipe to Planchet.  I may be besieged in my
Title:  turn, and I shall not be sorry for him to be able to let me enjoy
Title:  the same advantages with which you gratify your master."
Title:  
Title:  "Lord, monsieur!  There is nothing more easy," said Mousqueton,
Title:  with a modest air.  "One only needs to be sharp, that's all.  I
Title:  was brought up in the country, and my father in his leisure time
Title:  was something of a poacher."
Title:  
Title:  "And what did he do the rest of his time?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, he carried on a trade which I have always thought
Title:  satisfactory."
Title:  
Title:  "Which?"
Title:  
Title:  "As it was a time of war between the Catholics and the Huguenots,
Title:  and as he saw the Catholics exterminate the Huguenots and the
Title:  Huguenots exterminate the Catholics--all in the name of
Title:  religion--he adopted a mixed belief which permitted him to be
Title:  sometimes Catholic, sometimes a Huguenot.  Now, he was accustomed
Title:  to walk with his fowling piece on his shoulder, behind the hedges
Title:  which border the roads, and when he saw a Catholic coming alone,
Title:  the Protestant religion immediately prevailed in his mind.  He
Title:  lowered his gun in the direction of the traveler; then, when he
Title:  was within ten paces of him, he commenced a conversation which
Title:  almost always ended by the traveler's abandoning his purse to
Title:  save his life.  It goes without saying that when he saw a
Title:  Huguenot coming, he felt himself filled with such ardent Catholic
Title:  zeal that he could not understand how, a quarter of an hour
Title:  before, he had been able to have any doubts upon the superiority
Title:  of our holy religion.  For my part, monsieur, I am Catholic--my
Title:  father, faithful to his principles, having made my elder brother
Title:  a Huguenot."
Title:  
Title:  "And what was the end of this worthy man?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, of the most unfortunate kind, monsieur.  One day he was
Title:  surprised in a lonely road between a Huguenot and a Catholic,
Title:  with both of whom he had before had business, and who both knew
Title:  him again; so they united against him and hanged him on a tree.
Title:  Then they came and boasted of their fine exploit in the cabaret
Title:  of the next village, where my brother and I were drinking."
Title:  
Title:  "And what did you do?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "We let them tell their story out," replied Mousqueton.  "Then,
Title:  as in leaving the cabaret they took different directions, my
Title:  brother went and hid himself on the road of the Catholic, and I
Title:  on that of the Huguenot.  Two hours after, all was over; we had
Title:  done the business of both, admiring the foresight of our poor
Title:  father, who had taken the precaution to bring each of us up in a
Title:  different religion."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I must allow, as you say, your father was a very
Title:  intelligent fellow.  And you say in his leisure moments the
Title:  worthy man was a poacher?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, and it was he who taught me to lay a snare and
Title:  ground a line.  The consequence is that when I saw our laborers,
Title:  which did not at all suit two such delicate stomachs as ours, I
Title:  had recourse to a little of my old trade.  While walking near the
Title:  wood of Monsieur le Prince, I laid a few snare in the runs; and
Title:  while reclining on the banks of his Highness's pieces of water, I
Title:  slipped a few lines into his fish ponds.  So that now, thanks be
Title:  to God, we do not want, as Monsieur can testify, for partridges,
Title:  rabbits, carp or eels--all light, wholesome food, suitable for
Title:  the sick."
Title:  
Title:  "But the wine," said d'Artagnan, "who furnishes the wine?  Your
Title:  host?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, yes and no."
Title:  
Title:  "How yes and no?"
Title:  
Title:  "He furnishes it, it is true, but he does not know that he has
Title:  that honor."
Title:  
Title:  "Explain yourself, Mousqueton; your conversation is full of
Title:  instructive things."
Title:  
Title:  "That is it, monsieur.  It has so chanced that I met with a
Title:  Spaniard in my peregrinations who had seen many countries, and
Title:  among them the New World."
Title:  
Title:  "What connection can the New World have with the bottles which
Title:  are on the commode and the wardrobe?"
Title:  
Title:  "Patience, monsieur, everything will come in its turn."
Title:  
Title:  "This Spaniard had in his service a lackey who had accompanied
Title:  him in his voyage to Mexico.  This lackey was my compatriot; and
Title:  we became the more intimate from there being many resemblances of
Title:  character between us.  We loved sporting of all kinds better than
Title:  anything; so that he related to me how in the plains of the
Title:  Pampas the natives hunt the tiger and the wild bull with simple
Title:  running nooses which they throw to a distance of twenty or thirty
Title:  paces the end of a cord with such nicety; but in face of the
Title:  proof I was obliged to acknowledge the truth of the recital.  My
Title:  friend placed a bottle at the distance of thirty paces, and at
Title:  each cast he caught the neck of the bottle in his running noose.
Title:  I practiced this exercise, and as nature has endowed me with some
Title:  faculties, at this day I can throw the lasso with any man in the
Title:  world.  Well, do you understand, monsieur?  Our host has a well-
Title:  furnished cellar the key of which never leaves him; only this
Title:  cellar has a ventilating hole.  Now through this ventilating
Title:  hole I throw my lasso, and as I now know in which part of the
Title:  cellar is the best wine, that's my point for sport.  You see,
Title:  monsieur, what the New World has to do with the bottles which are
Title:  on the commode and the wardrobe.  Now, will you taste our wine,
Title:  and without prejudice say what you think of it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Thank you, my friend, thank you; unfortunately, I have just
Title:  breakfasted."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos, "arrange the table, Mousqueton, and while
Title:  we breakfast, d'Artagnan will relate to us what has happened to
Title:  him during the ten days since he left us."
Title:  
Title:  "Willingly," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  While Porthos and Mousqueton were breakfasting, with the
Title:  appetites of convalescents and with that brotherly cordiality
Title:  which unites men in misfortune, d'Artagnan related how Aramis,
Title:  being wounded, was obliged to stop at Crevecoeur, how he had left
Title:  Athos fighting at Amiens with four men who accused him of being a
Title:  coiner, and how he, d'Artagnan, had been forced to run the Comtes
Title:  de Wardes through the body in order to reach England.
Title:  
Title:  But there the confidence of d'Artagnan stopped.  He only added
Title:  that on his return from Great Britain he had brought back four
Title:  magnificent horses--one for himself, and one for each of his
Title:  companions; then he informed Porthos that the one intended for
