Title:  him was already installed in the stable of the tavern.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment Planchet entered, to inform his master that the
Title:  horses were sufficiently refreshed and that it would be possible
Title:  to sleep at Clermont.
Title:  
Title:  As d'Artagnan was tolerably reassured with regard to Porthos, and
Title:  as he was anxious to obtain news of his two other friends, he
Title:  held out his hand to the wounded man, and told him he was about
Title:  to resume his route in order to continue his researches.  For the
Title:  rest, as he reckoned upon returning by the same route in seven or
Title:  eight days, if Porthos were still at the Great St. Martin, he
Title:  would call for him on his way.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos replied that in all probability his sprain would not
Title:  permit him to depart yet awhile.  Besides, it was necessary he
Title:  should stay at Chantilly to wait for the answer from his duchess.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan wished that answer might be prompt and favorable; and
Title:  having again recommended Porthos to the care of Mousqueton, and
Title:  paid his bill to the host, he resumed his route with Planchet,
Title:  already relieved of one of his led horses.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  26  ARAMIS AND HIS THESIS
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had said nothing to Porthos of his wound or of his
Title:  procurator's wife.  Our Bearnais was a prudent lad, however young
Title:  he might be.  Consequently he had appeared to believe all that
Title:  the vainglorious Musketeer had told him, convinced that no
Title:  friendship will hold out against a surprised secret.  Besides, we
Title:  feel always a sort of mental superiority over those whose lives
Title:  we know better than they suppose.  In his projects of intrigue
Title:  for the future, and determined as he was to make his three
Title:  friends the instruments of his fortune, d'Artagnan was not sorry
Title:  at getting into his grasp beforehand the invisible strings by
Title:  which he reckoned upon moving them.
Title:  
Title:  And yet, as he journeyed along, a profound sadness weighed upon
Title:  his heart.  He thought of that young and pretty Mme. Bonacieux
Title:  who was to have paid him the price of his devotedness; but let us
Title:  hasten to say that this sadness possessed the young man less from
Title:  the regret of the happiness he had missed, than from the fear he
Title:  entertained that some serious misfortune had befallen the poor
Title:  woman.  For himself, he had no doubt she was a victim of the
Title:  cardinal's vengeance; and, and as was well known, the vengeance
Title:  of his Eminence was terrible.  How he had found grace in the eyes
Title:  of the minister, he did not know; but without doubt M. de Cavois
Title:  would have revealed this to him if the captain of the Guards had
Title:  found him at home.
Title:  
Title:  Nothing makes time pass more quickly or more shortens a journey
Title:  than a thought which absorbs in itself all the faculties of the
Title:  organization of him who thinks.  External existence then
Title:  resembles a sleep of which this thought is the dream.  By its
Title:  influence, time has no longer measure, space has no longer
Title:  distance.  We depart from one place, and arrive at another, that
Title:  is all.  Of the interval passed, nothing remains in the memory
Title:  but a vague mist in which a thousand confused images of trees,
Title:  mountains, and landscapes are lost.  It was as a prey to this
Title:  hallucination that d'Artagnan traveled, at whatever pace his
Title:  horse pleased, the six or eight leagues that separated Chantilly
Title:  from Crevecoeur, without his being able to remember on his
Title:  arrival in the village any of the things he had passed or met
Title:  with on the road.
Title:  
Title:  There only his memory returned to him.  He shook his head,
Title:  perceived the cabaret at which he had left Aramis, and putting
Title:  his horse to the trot, he shortly pulled up at the door.
Title:  
Title:  This time it was not a host but a hostess who received him.
Title:  d'Artagnan was a physiognomist.  His eye took in at a glance the
Title:  plump, cheerful countenance of the mistress of the place, and he
Title:  at once perceived there was no occasion for dissembling with her,
Title:  or of fearing anything from one blessed with such a joyous
Title:  physiognomy.
Title:  
Title:  "My good dame," asked d'Artagnan, "can you tell me what has
Title:  become of one of my friends, whom we were obliged to leave here
Title:  about a dozen days ago?"
Title:  
Title:  "A handsome young man, three- or four-and-twenty years old, mild,
Title:  amiable, and well made?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is he--wounded in the shoulder."
Title:  
Title:  "Just so.  Well, monsieur, he is still here."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, PARDIEU!  My dear dame," said d'Artagnan, springing from his
Title:  horse, and throwing the bridle to Planchet, "you restore me to
Title:  life; where is this dear Aramis?  Let me embrace him, I am in a
Title:  hurry to see him again."
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon, monsieur, but I doubt whether he can see you at this
Title:  moment."
Title:  
Title:  "Why so?  Has he a lady with him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Jesus!  What do you mean by that?  Poor lad!  No, monsieur, he
Title:  has not a lady with him."
Title:  
Title:  "With whom is he, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "With the curate of Montdidier and the superior of the Jesuits of
Title:  Amiens."
Title:  
Title:  "Good heavens!" cried d'Artagnan, "is the poor fellow worse,
Title:  then?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, quite the contrary; but after his illness grace
Title:  touched him, and he determined to take orders."
Title:  
Title:  "That's it!" said d'Artagnan, "I had forgotten that he was only a
Title:  Musketeer for a time."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur still insists upon seeing him?"
Title:  
Title:  "More than ever."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur has only to take the right-hand staircase in the
Title:  courtyard, and knock at Number Five on the second floor."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan walked quickly in the direction indicated, and found
Title:  one of those exterior staircases that are still to be seen in the
Title:  yards of our old-fashioned taverns.  But there was no getting at
Title:  the place of sojourn of the future abbe; the defiles of the
Title:  chamber of Aramis were as well guarded as the gardens of Armida.
Title:  Bazin was stationed in the corridor, and barred his passage with
Title:  the more intrepidity that, after many years of trial, Bazin found
Title:  himself near a result of which he had ever been ambitious.
Title:  
Title:  In fact, the dream of poor Bazin had always been to serve a
Title:  churchman; and he awaited with impatience the moment, always in
Title:  the future, when Aramis would throw aside the uniform and assume
Title:  the cassock.  The daily-renewed promise of the young man that the
Title:  moment would not long be delayed, had alone kept him in the
Title:  service of a Musketeer--a service in which, he said, his soul was
Title:  in constant jeopardy.
Title:  
Title:  Bazin was then at the height of joy.  In all probability, this
Title:  time his master would not retract.  The union of physical pain
Title:  with moral uneasiness had produced the effect so long desired.
Title:  Aramis, suffering at once in body and mind, had at length fixed
Title:  his eyes and his thoughts upon religion, and he had considered as
Title:  a warning from heaven the double accident which had happened to
Title:  him; that is to say, the sudden disappearance of his mistress and
Title:  the wound in his shoulder.
Title:  
Title:  It may be easily understood that in the present disposition of
Title:  his master nothing could be more disagreeable to Bazin than the
Title:  arrival of d'Artagnan, which might cast his master back again
Title:  into that vortex of mundane affairs which had so long carried him
Title:  away.  He resolved, then, to defend the door bravely; and as,
Title:  betrayed by the mistress of the inn, he could not say that Aramis
Title:  was absent, he endeavored to prove to the newcomer that it would
Title:  be the height of indiscretion to disturb his master in his pious
Title:  conference, which had commenced with the morning and would not,
Title:  as Bazin said, terminate before night.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan took very little heed of the eloquent discourse of
Title:  M. Bazin; and as he had no desire to support a polemic discussion
Title:  with his friend's valet, he simply moved him out of the way with
Title:  one hand, and with the other turned the handle of the door of
Title:  Number Five.  The door opened, and d'Artagnan went into the
Title:  chamber.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, in a black gown, his head enveloped in a sort of round
Title:  flat cap, not much unlike a CALOTTE, was seated before an oblong
Title:  table, covered with rolls of paper and enormous volumes in folio.
Title:  At his right hand was placed the superior of the Jesuits, and on
Title:  his left the curate of Montdidier.  The curtains were half drawn,
Title:  and only admitted the mysterious light calculated for beatific
Title:  reveries.  All the mundane objects that generally strike the eye
Title:  on entering the room of a young man, particularly when that young
Title:  man is a Musketeer, had disappeared as if by enchantment; and for
Title:  fear, no doubt, that the sight of them might bring his master
Title:  back to ideas of this world, Bazin had laid his hands upon sword,
Title:  pistols, plumed hat, and embroideries and laces of all kinds and
Title:  sorts.  In their stead d'Artagnan thought he perceived in an
Title:  obscure corner a discipline cord suspended from a nail in the
Title:  wall.
Title:  
Title:  At the noise made by d'Artagnan in entering, Aramis lifted up his
Title:  head, and beheld his friend; but to the great astonishment of the
Title:  young man, the sight of him did not produce much effect upon the
Title:  Musketeer, so completely was his mind detached from the things of
Title:  this world.
Title:  
Title:  "Good day, dear d'Artagnan," said Aramis; "believe me, I am glad
Title:  to see you."
Title:  
Title:  "So am I delighted to see you," said d'Artagnan, "although I am
Title:  not yet sure that it is Aramis I am speaking to."
Title:  
Title:  "To himself, my friend, to himself!  But what makes you doubt
Title:  it?"
Title:  
Title:  "I was afraid I had made a mistake in the chamber, and that I had
Title:  found my way into the apartment of some churchman.  Then another
Title:  error seized me on seeing you in company with these gentlemen--I
Title:  was afraid you were dangerously ill."
Title:  
Title:  The two men in black, who guessed d'Artagnan's meaning, darted at
Title:  him a glance which might have been thought threatening; but
Title:  d'Artagnan took no heed of it.
Title:  
Title:  "I disturb you, perhaps, my dear Aramis," continued d'Artagnan,
Title:  "for by what I see, I am led to believe that you are confessing
Title:  to these gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis colored imperceptibly.  "You disturb me?  Oh, quite the
Title:  contrary, dear friend, I swear; and as a proof of what I say,
Title:  permit me to declare I am rejoiced to see you safe and sound."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, he'll come round," thought d'Artagnan; "that's not bad!"
Title:  
Title:  "This gentleman, who is my friend, has just escaped from a
Title:  serious danger," continued Aramis, with unction, pointing to
Title:  d'Artagnan with his hand, and addressing the two ecclesiastics.
Title:  
Title:  "Praise God, monsieur," replied they, bowing together.
Title:  
Title:  "I have not failed to do so, your Reverences," replied the young
Title:  man, returning their salutation.
Title:  
Title:  "You arrive in good time, dear d'Artagnan," said Aramis, "and by
Title:  taking part in our discussion may assist us with your
Title:  intelligence.  Monsieur the Principal of Amiens, Monsieur the
Title:  Curate of Montdidier, and I are arguing certain theological
Title:  questions in which we have been much interested; I shall be
Title:  delighted to have your opinion."
Title:  
Title:  "The opinion of a swordsman can have very little weight," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan, who began to be uneasy at the turn things were
Title:  taking, "and you had better be satisfied, believe me, with the
Title:  knowledge of these gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  The two men in black bowed in their turn.
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary," replied Aramis, "your opinion will be very
Title:  valuable.  The question is this:  Monsieur the Principal thinks
Title:  that my thesis ought to be dogmatic and didactic."
Title:  
Title:  "Your thesis!  Are you then making a thesis?"
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt," replied the Jesuit.  "In the examination which
Title:  precedes ordination, a thesis is always a requisite."
Title:  
Title:  "Ordination!" cried d'Artagnan, who could not believe what the
Title:  hostess and Bazin had successively told him; and he gazed, half
Title:  stupefied, upon the three persons before him.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," continued Aramis, taking the same graceful position in his
Title:  easy chair that he would have assumed in bed, and complacently
Title:  examining his hand, which was as white and plump as that of a
Title:  woman, and which he held in the air to cause the blood to
Title:  descend, "now, as you have heard, d'Artagnan, Monsieur the
Title:  Principal is desirous that my thesis should be dogmatic, while I,
Title:  for my part, would rather it should be ideal.  This is the reason
Title:  why Monsieur the Principal has proposed to me the following
Title:  subject, which has not yet been treated upon, and in which I
Title:  perceive there is matter for magnificent elaboration-'UTRAQUE
Title:  MANUS IN BENEDICENDO CLERICIS INFERIORIBUS NECESSARIA EST.'"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, whose erudition we are well acquainted with, evinced
Title:  no more interest on hearing this quotation than he had at that of
Title:  M. de Treville in allusion to the gifts he pretended that
Title:  d'Artagnan had received from the Duke of Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  "Which means," resumed Aramis, that he might perfectly
Title:  understand, "'The two hands are indispensable for priests of the
Title:  inferior orders, when they bestow the benediction.'"
Title:  
Title:  "An admirable subject!" cried the Jesuit.
Title:  
Title:  "Admirable and dogmatic!" repeated the curate, who, about as
Title:  strong as d'Artagnan with respect to Latin, carefully watched the
Title:  Jesuit in order to keep step with him, and repeated his words
Title:  like an echo.
Title:  
Title:  As to d'Artagnan, he remained perfectly insensible to the
Title:  enthusiasm of the two men in black.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, admirable!  PRORSUS ADMIRABILE!" continued Aramis; "but
Title:  which requires a profound study of both the Scriptures and the
Title:  Fathers.  Now, I have confessed to these learned ecclesiastics,
Title:  and that in all humility, that the duties of mounting guard and
Title:  the service of the king have caused me to neglect study a little.
Title:  I should find myself, therefore, more at my ease, FACILUS NATANS,
Title:  in a subject of my own choice, which would be to these hard
Title:  theological questions what morals are to metaphysics in
Title:  philosophy."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan began to be tired, and so did the curate.
Title:  
Title:  "See what an exordium!" cried the Jesuit.
Title:  
Title:  "Exordium," repeated the curate, for the sake of saying
Title:  something.  "QUEMADMODUM INTER COELORUM IMMENSITATEM."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis cast a glance upon d'Artagnan to see what effect all this
Title:  produced, and found his friend gaping enough to split his jaws.
Title:  
Title:  "Let us speak French, my father," said he to the Jesuit;
Title:  "Monsieur d'Artagnan will enjoy our conversation better."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," replied d'Artagnan; "I am fatigued with reading, and all
Title:  this Latin confuses me."
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly," replied the Jesuit, a little put out, while the
Title:  curate, greatly delighted, turned upon d'Artagnan a look full of
Title:  gratitude.  "Well, let us see what is to be derived from this
Title:  gloss.  Moses, the servant of God-he was but a servant, please to
Title:  understand-Moses blessed with the hands; he held out both his
Title:  arms while the Hebrews beat their enemies, and then he blessed
Title:  them with his two hands.  Besides, what does the Gospel say?
Title:  IMPONITE MANUS, and not MANUM-place the HANDS, not the HAND."
Title:  
Title:  "Place the HANDS," repeated the curate, with a gesture.
Title:  
Title:  "St. Peter, on the contrary, of whom the Popes are the
Title:  successors," continued the Jesuit; "PORRIGE DIGITOS-present the
Title:  fingers.  Are you there, now?"
Title:  
Title:  "CERTES," replied Aramis, in a pleased tone, "but the thing is
Title:  subtle."
Title:  
Title:  "The FINGERS," resumed the Jesuit, "St. Peter blessed with the
Title:  FINGERS.  The Pope, therefore blesses with the fingers.  And with
Title:  how many fingers does he bless?  With THREE fingers, to be sure-
Title:  one for the Father, one for the Son, and one for the Holy Ghost."
Title:  
Title:  All crossed themselves.  D'Artagnan thought it was proper to
Title:  follow this example.
Title:  
Title:  "The Pope is the successor of St. Peter, and represents the three
Title:  divine powers; the rest-ORDINES INFERIORES-of the ecclesiastical
Title:  hierarchy bless in the name of the holy archangels and angels.
Title:  The most humble clerks such as our deacons and sacristans, bless
Title:  with holy water sprinklers, which resemble an infinite number of
Title:  blessing fingers.  There is the subject simplified.  ARGUMENTUM
Title:  OMNI DENUDATUM ORNAMENTO.  I could make of that subject two
Title:  volumes the size of this," continued the Jesuit; and in his
Title:  enthusiasm he struck a St. Chrysostom in folio, which made the
Title:  table bend beneath its weight.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan trembled.
Title:  
Title:  "CERTES," said Aramis, "I do justice to the beauties of this
Title:  thesis; but at the same time I perceive it would be overwhelming
Title:  for me.  I had chosen this text-tell me, dear d'Artagnan, if it
Title:  is not to your taste-'NON INUTILE EST DESIDERIUM IN OBLATIONE';
Title:  that is, 'A little regret is not unsuitable in an offering to the
Title:  Lord.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Stop there!" cried the Jesuit, "for that thesis touches closely
Title:  upon heresy.  There is a proposition almost like it in the
Title:  AUGUSTINUS of the heresiarch Jansenius, whose book will sooner or
Title:  later be burned by the hands of the executioner.  Take care, my
Title:  young friend.  You are inclining toward false doctrines, my young
Title:  friend; you will be lost."
Title:  
Title:  "You will be lost," said the curate, shaking his head
Title:  sorrowfully.
Title:  
Title:  "You approach that famous point of free will which is a mortal
Title:  rock.  You face the insinuations of the Pelagians and the semi-
Title:  Pelagians."
Title:  
Title:  "But, my Reverend-" replied Aramis, a little amazed by the shower
Title:  of arguments that poured upon his head.
Title:  
Title:  "How will you prove," continued the Jesuit, without allowing him
Title:  time to speak, "that we ought to regret the world when we offer
Title:  ourselves to God?  Listen to this dilemma: God is God, and the
Title:  world is the devil.  To regret the world is to regret the devil;
Title:  that is my conclusion."
Title:  
Title:  "And that is mine also," said the curate.
Title:  
Title:  "But, for heaven's sake-" resumed Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "DESIDERAS DIABOLUM, unhappy man!" cried the Jesuit.
Title:  
Title:  "He regrets the devil!  Ah, my young friend," added the curate,
Title:  groaning, "do not regret the devil, I implore you!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan felt himself bewildered.  It seemed to him as though
Title:  he were in a madhouse, and was becoming as mad as those he saw.
Title:  He was, however, forced to hold his tongue from not comprehending
Title:  half the language they employed.
Title:  
Title:  "But listen to me, then," resumed Aramis with politeness mingled
Title:  with a little impatience.  "I do not say I regret; no, I will
Title:  never pronounce that sentence, which would not be orthodox."
Title:  
Title:  The Jesuit raised his hands toward heaven, and the curate did the
Title:  same.
Title:  
Title:  "No; but pray grant me that it is acting with an ill grace to
Title:  offer to the Lord only that with which we are perfectly
Title:  disgusted!  Don't you think so, d'Artagnan?"
Title:  
Title:  "I think so, indeed," cried he.
Title:  
Title:  The Jesuit and the curate quite started from their chairs.
Title:  
Title:  "This is the point of departure; it is a syllogism.  The world is
Title:  not wanting in attractions.  I quit the world; then I make a
Title:  sacrifice.  Now, the Scripture says positively, 'Make a sacrifice
Title:  unto the Lord.'"
Title:  
Title:  "That is true," said his antagonists.
Title:  
Title:  "And then," said Aramis, pinching his ear to make it red, as he
Title:  rubbed his hands to make them white, "and then I made a certain
Title:  RONDEAU upon it last year, which I showed to Monsieur Voiture,
Title:  and that great man paid me a thousand compliments."
Title:  
Title:  "A RONDEAU!" said the Jesuit, disdainfully.
Title:  
Title:  "A RONDEAU!" said the curate, mechanically.
Title:  
Title:  "Repeat it!  Repeat it!" cried d'Artagnan; "it will make a little
Title:  change."
Title:  
Title:  "Not so, for it is religious," replied Aramis; "it is theology in
Title:  verse."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Here it is," said Aramis, with a little look of diffidence,
Title:  which, however, was not exempt from a shade of hypocrisy:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Vous qui pleurez un passe plein de charmes,
Title:  Et qui trainez des jours infortunes,
Title:  Tous vos malheurs se verront termines,
Title:  Quand a Dieu seul vous offrirez vos larmes,
Title:  Vous qui pleurez!"
Title:  
Title:  "You who weep for pleasures fled,
Title:  While dragging on a life of care,
Title:  All your woes will melt in air,
Title:  If to God your tears are shed,
Title:  You who weep!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  d'Artagnan and the curate appeared pleased.  The Jesuit persisted
Title:  in his opinion.  "Beware of a profane taste in your theological
Title:  style.  What says Augustine on this subject:  'SEVERUS SIT
Title:  CLERICORUM VERBO.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, let the sermon be clear," said the curate.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," hastily interrupted the Jesuit, on seeing that his acolyte
Title:  was going astray, "now your thesis would please the ladies; it
Title:  would have the success of one of Monsieur Patru's pleadings."
Title:  
Title:  "Please God!" cried Aramis, transported.
Title:  
Title:  "There it is," cried the Jesuit; "the world still speaks within
Title:  you in a loud voice, ALTISIMMA VOCE.  You follow the world, my
Title:  young friend, and I tremble lest grace prove not efficacious."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied, my reverend father, I can answer for myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Mundane presumption!"
Title:  
Title:  "I know myself, Father; my resolution is irrevocable."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you persist in continuing that thesis?"
Title:  
Title:  "I feel myself called upon to treat that, and no other.  I will
Title:  see about the continuation of it, and tomorrow I hope you will be
Title:  satisfied with the corrections I shall have made in consequence
Title:  of your advice."
Title:  
Title:  "Work slowly," said the curate; "we leave you in an excellent
Title:  tone of mind."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, the ground is all sown," said the Jesuit, "and we have not
Title:  to fear that one portion of the seed may have fallen upon stone,
Title:  another upon the highway, or that the birds of heaven have eaten
Title:  the rest, AVES COELI COMEDERUNT ILLAM."
Title:  
Title:  "Plague stifle you and your Latin!" said d'Artagnan, who began to
Title:  feel all his patience exhausted.
Title:  
Title:  "Farewell, my son," said the curate, "till tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  "Till tomorrow, rash youth," said the Jesuit.  "You promise to
Title:  become one of the lights of the Church.  Heaven grant that this
Title:  light prove not a devouring fire!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who for an hour past had been gnawing his nails with
Title:  impatience, was beginning to attack the quick.
Title:  
Title:  The two men in black rose, bowed to Aramis and d'Artagnan, and
Title:  advanced toward the door.  Bazin, who had been standing listening
Title:  to all this controversy with a pious jubilation, sprang toward
Title:  them, took the breviary of the curate and the missal of the
Title:  Jesuit, and walked respectfully before them to clear their way.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis conducted them to the foot of the stairs, and then
Title:  immediately came up again to d'Artagnan, whose senses were still
Title:  in a state of confusion.
Title:  
Title:  When left alone, the two friends at first kept an embarrassed
Title:  silence.  It however became necessary for one of them to break it
Title:  first, and as d'Artagnan appeared determined to leave that honor
Title:  to his companion, Aramis said, "you see that I am returned to my
Title:  fundamental ideas."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, efficacious grace has touched you, as that gentleman said
Title:  just now."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, these plans of retreat have been formed for a long time.
Title:  You have often heard me speak of them, have you not, my friend?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but I confess I always thought you jested."
Title:  
Title:  "With such things!  Oh, d'Artagnan!"
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  Why, people jest with death."
Title:  
Title:  "And people are wrong, d'Artagnan; for death is the door which
Title:  leads to perdition or to salvation."
Title:  
Title:  "Granted; but if you please, let us not theologize, Aramis.  You
Title:  must have had enough for today.  As for me, I have almost
Title:  forgotten the little Latin I have ever known.  Then I confess to
Title:  you that I have eaten nothing since ten o'clock this morning, and
Title:  I am devilish hungry."
Title:  
Title:  "We will dine directly, my friend; only you must please to
Title:  remember that this is Friday.  Now, on such a day I can neither
Title:  eat flesh nor see it eaten.  If you can be satisfied with my
Title:  dinner-it consists of cooked tetragones and fruits."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean by tetragones?" asked d'Artagnan, uneasily.
Title:  
Title:  "I mean spinach," replied Aramis; "but on your account I will add
Title:  some eggs, and that is a serious infraction of the rule-for eggs
Title:  are meat, since they engender chickens."
Title:  
Title:  "This feast is not very succulent; but never mind, I will put up
Title:  with it for the sake of remaining with you."
Title:  
Title:  "I am grateful to you for the sacrifice," said Aramis; "but if
Title:  your body be not greatly benefited by it, be assured your soul
Title:  will."
Title:  
Title:  "And so, Aramis, you are decidedly going into the Church?  What
Title:  will our two friends say?  What will Monsieur de Treville say?
Title:  They will treat you as a deserter, I warn you."
Title:  
Title:  "I do not enter the Church; I re-enter it.  I deserted the Church
Title:  for the world, for you know that I forced myself when I became a
Title:  Musketeer."
Title:  
Title:  "I?  I know nothing about it."
Title:  
Title:  "You don't know I quit the seminary?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not at all."
Title:  
Title:  "This is my story, then.  Besides, the Scriptures say, 'Confess
Title:  yourselves to one another,' and I confess to you, d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "And I give you absolution beforehand.  You see I am a good sort
Title:  of a man."
Title:  
Title:  "Do not jest about holy things, my friend."
Title:  
Title:  "Go on, then, I listen."
Title:  
Title:  "I had been at the seminary from nine years old; in three days I
Title:  should have been twenty.  I was about to become an abbe, and all
Title:  was arranged.  One evening I went, according to custom, to a
Title:  house which I frequented with much pleasure:  when one is young,
Title:  what can be expected?--one is weak.  An officer who saw me, with
Title:  a jealous eye, reading the LIVES OF THE SAINTS to the mistress of
Title:  the house, entered suddenly and without being announced.  That
Title:  evening I had translated an episode of Judith, and had just
Title:  communicated my verses to the lady, who gave me all sorts of
Title:  compliments, and leaning on my shoulder, was reading them a
Title:  second time with me.  Her pose, which I must admit was rather
Title:  free, wounded this officer.  He said nothing; but when I went out
Title:  he followed, and quickly came up with me.  'Monsieur the Abbe,'
Title:  said he, 'do you like blows with a cane?' 'I cannot say,
Title:  monsieur,' answered I; 'no one has ever dared to give me any.'
Title:  'Well, listen to me, then, Monsieur the Abbe!  If you venture
Title:  again into the house in which I have met you this evening, I will
Title:  dare it myself.'  I really think I must have been frightened.  I
Title:  became very pale; I felt my legs fail me; I sought for a reply,
Title:  but could find none-I was silent.  The officer waited for his
Title:  reply, and seeing it so long coming, he burst into a laugh,
Title:  turned upon his heel, and re-entered the house.  I returned to
Title:  the seminary.
Title:  
Title:  "I am a gentleman born, and my blood is warm, as you may have
Title:  remarked, my dear d'Artagnan.  The insult was terrible, and
Title:  although unknown to the rest of the world, I felt it live and
Title:  fester at the bottom of my heart.  I informed my superiors that I
Title:  did not feel myself sufficiently prepared for ordination, and at
Title:  my request the ceremony was postponed for a year.  I sought out
Title:  the best fencing master in Paris, I made an agreement with him to
Title:  take a lesson every day, and every day for a year I took that
Title:  lesson.  Then, on the anniversary of the day on which I had been
Title:  insulted, I hung my cassock on a peg, assumed the costume of a
Title:  cavalier, and went to a ball given by a lady friend of mine and
Title:  to which I knew my man was invited.  It was in the Rue des
Title:  France-Bourgeois, close to La Force.  As I expected, my officer
Title:  was there.  I went up to him as he was singing a love ditty and
Title:  looking tenderly at a lady, and interrupted him exactly in the
Title:  middle of the second couplet.  'Monsieur,' said I, 'does it still
Title:  displease you that I should frequent a certain house of La Rue
Title:  Payenne?  And would you still cane me if I took it into my head
Title:  to disobey you?  The officer looked at me with astonishment, and
Title:  then said, 'What is your business with me, monsieur?  I do not
Title:  know you.'  'I am,' said I, 'the little abbe who reads LIVES OF
Title:  THE SAINTS, and translates Judith into verse.'  'Ah, ah!  I
Title:  recollect now,' said the officer, in a jeering tone; 'well, what
Title:  do you want with me?'  'I want you to spare time to take a walk
Title:  with me.'  'Tomorrow morning, if you like, with the greatest
Title:  pleasure.'  'No, not tomorrow morning, if you please, but
Title:  immediately.'  'If you absolutely insist.'  'I do insist upon
Title:  it.'  'Come, then.  Ladies,' said the officer, 'do not disturb
Title:  yourselves; allow me time just to kill this gentleman, and I will
Title:  return and finish the last couplet.'
Title:  
Title:  "We went out.  I took him to the Rue Payenne, to exactly the same
Title:  spot where, a year before, at the very same hour, he had paid me
Title:  the compliment I have related to you.  It was a superb moonlight
Title:  night.  We immediately drew, and at the first pass I laid him
Title:  stark dead."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," continued Aramis, "as the ladies did not see the singer
Title:  come back, and as he was found in the Rue Payenne with a great
Title:  sword wound through his body, it was supposed that I had
Title:  accommodated him thus; and the matter created some scandal which
Title:  obliged me to renounce the cassock for a time.  Athos, whose
Title:  acquaintance I made about that period, and Porthos, who had in
Title:  addition to my lessons taught me some effective tricks of fence,
Title:  prevailed upon me to solicit the uniform of a Musketeer.  The
Title:  king entertained great regard for my father, who had fallen at
Title:  the siege of Arras, and the uniform was granted.  You may understand
Title:  that the moment has come for me to re-enter the bosom of the
Title:  Church."
Title:  
Title:  "And why today, rather than yesterday or tomorrow?  What has
Title:  happened to you today, to raise all these melancholy ideas?"
Title:  
Title:  "This wound, my dear d'Artagnan, has been a warning to me from
Title:  heaven."
Title:  
Title:  "This wound?  Bah, it is now nearly healed, and I am sure it is
Title:  not that which gives you the most pain."
Title:  
Title:  "What, then?" said Aramis, blushing.
Title:  
Title:  "You have one at heart, Aramis, one deeper and more painful--a
Title:  wound made by a woman."
Title:  
Title:  The eye of Aramis kindled in spite of himself.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said he, dissembling his emotion under a feigned
Title:  carelessness, "do not talk of such things, and suffer love pains?
Title:  VANITAS VANITATUM!  According to your idea, then, my brain is
Title:  turned.  And for whom-for some GRISETTE, some chambermaid with
Title:  whom I have trifled in some garrison?  Fie!"
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon, my dear Aramis, but I thought you carried your eyes
Title:  higher."
Title:  
Title:  "Higher?  And who am I, to nourish such ambition?  A poor
Title:  Musketeer, a beggar, an unknown-who hates slavery, and finds
Title:  himself ill-placed in the world."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis, Aramis!" cried d'Artagnan, looking at his friend with an
Title:  air of doubt.
Title:  
Title:  "Dust I am, and to dust I return.  Life is full of humiliations
Title:  and sorrows," continued he, becoming still more melancholy; "all
Title:  the ties which attach him to life break in the hand of man,
Title:  particularly the golden ties.  Oh, my dear d'Artagnan," resumed
Title:  Aramis, giving to his voice a slight tone of bitterness, "trust
Title:  me!  Conceal your wounds when you have any; silence is the last
Title:  joy of the unhappy.  Beware of giving anyone the clue to your
Title:  griefs; the curious suck our tears as flies suck the blood of a
Title:  wounded hart."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, my dear Aramis," said d'Artagnan, in his turn heaving a
Title:  profound sigh, "that is my story you are relating!"
Title:  
Title:  "How?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; a woman whom I love, whom I adore, has just been torn from
Title:  me by force.  I do not know where she is or whither they have
Title:  conducted her.  She is perhaps a prisoner; she is perhaps dead!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, but you have at least this consolation, that you can say to
Title:  yourself she has not quit you voluntarily, that if you learn no
Title:  news of her, it is because all communication with you is
Title:  interdicted; while I--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing," replied Aramis, "nothing."
Title:  
Title:  "So you renounce the world, then, forever; that is a settled
Title:  thing--a resolution registered!"
Title:  
Title:  "Forever!  You are my friend today; tomorrow you will be no more
Title:  to me than a shadow, or rather, even, you will no longer exist.
Title:  As for the world, it is a sepulcher and nothing else."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  All this is very sad which you tell me."
Title:  
Title:  "What will you?  My vocation commands me; it carries me away."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan smiled, but made no answer.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis continued, "And yet, while I do belong to the earth, I
Title:  wish to speak of you--of our friends."
Title:  
Title:  "And on my part," said d'Artagnan, "I wished to speak of you, but
Title:  I find you so completely detached from everything!  To love you
Title:  cry, 'Fie!  Friends are shadows!  The world is a sepulcher!'"
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, you will find it so yourself," said Aramis, with a sigh.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, let us say no more about it," said d'Artagnan; "and
Title:  let us burn this letter, which, no doubt, announces to you some
Title:  fresh infidelity of your GRISETTE or your chambermaid."
Title:  
Title:  "What letter?" cried Aramis, eagerly.
Title:  
Title:  "A letter which was sent to your abode in your absence, and which
Title:  was given to me for you."
Title:  
Title:  "But from whom is that letter?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, from some heartbroken waiting woman, some desponding
Title:  GRISETTE; from Madame de Chevreuse's chambermaid, perhaps, who
Title:  was obliged to return to Tours with her mistress, and who, in
Title:  order to appear smart and attractive, stole some perfumed paper,
Title:  and sealed her letter with a duchess's coronet."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hold!  I must have lost it,"  said the young man maliciously,
Title:  pretending to search for it.  "But fortunately the world is a
Title:  sepulcher; the men, and consequently the women, are but shadows,
Title:  and love is a sentiment to which you cry, 'Fie!  Fie!'"
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan, d'Artagnan," cried Aramis, "you are killing me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, here it is at last!" said d'Artagnan, as he drew the
Title:  letter from his pocket.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis made a bound, seized the letter, read it, or rather
Title:  devoured it, his countenance radiant.
Title:  
Title:  "This same waiting maid seems to have an agreeable style," said
Title:  the messenger, carelessly.
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, d'Artagnan, thanks!" cried Aramis, almost in a state of
Title:  delirium.  "She was forced to return to Tours; she is not
Title:  faithless; she still loves me!  Come, my friend, come, let me
Title:  embrace you.  Happiness almost stifles me!"
Title:  
Title:  The two friends began to dance around the venerable St.
Title:  Chrysostom, kicking about famously the sheets of the thesis,
Title:  which had fallen on the floor.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment Bazin entered with the spinach and the omelet.
Title:  
Title:  "Be off, you wretch!" cried Aramis, throwing his skullcap in his
Title:  face.  "Return whence you came; take back those horrible
Title:  vegetables, and that poor kickshaw!  Order a larded hare, a fat
Title:  capon, mutton leg dressed with garlic, and four bottles of old
Title:  Burgundy."
Title:  
Title:  Bazin, who looked at his master, without comprehending the cause
Title:  of this change, in a melancholy manner, allowed the omelet to
Title:  slip into the spinach, and the spinach onto the floor.
Title:  
Title:  "Now this is the moment to consecrate your existence to the King
Title:  of kings," said d'Artagnan, "if you persist in offering him a
Title:  civility.  NON INUTILE DESIDERIUM OBLATIONE."
Title:  
Title:  "Go to the devil with your Latin.  Let us drink, my dear
Title:  d'Artagnan, MORBLEU!  Let us drink while the wine is fresh!  Let
Title:  us drink heartily, and while we do so, tell me a little of what
Title:  is going on in the world yonder."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  27  THE WIFE OF ATHOS
Title:  
Title:  "We have now to search for Athos," said d'Artagnan to the
Title:  vivacious Aramis, when he had informed him of all that had passed
Title:  since their departure from the capital, and an excellent dinner
Title:  had made one of them forget his thesis and the other his fatigue.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you think, then, that any harm can have happened to him?"
Title:  asked Aramis.  "Athos is so cool, so brave, and handles his sword
Title:  so skillfully."
Title:  
Title:  "No doubt.  Nobody has a higher opinion of the courage and skill
Title:  of Athos than I have; but I like better to hear my sword clang
Title:  against lances than against staves.  I fear lest Athos should
Title:  have been beaten down by serving men.  Those fellows strike hard,
Title:  and don't leave off in a hurry.  This is why I wish to set out
Title:  again as soon as possible."
Title:  
Title:  "I will try to accompany you," said Aramis, "though I scarcely
Title:  feel in a condition to mount on horseback.  Yesterday I undertook
Title:  to employ that cord which you see hanging against the wall, but
Title:  pain prevented my continuing the pious exercise."
Title:  
Title:  "That's the first time I ever heard of anybody trying to cure
Title:  gunshot wounds with cat-o'-nine-tails; but you were ill, and
Title:  illness renders the head weak, therefore you may be excused."
Title:  
Title:  "When do you mean to set out?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow at daybreak.  Sleep as soundly as you can tonight, and
Title:  tomorrow, if you can, we will take our departure together."
Title:  
Title:  "Till tomorrow, then," said Aramis; "for iron-nerved as you are,
Title:  you must need repose."
Title:  
Title:  The next morning, when d'Artagnan entered Aramis's chamber, he
Title:  found him at the window.
Title:  
Title:  "What are you looking at?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!  I am admiring three magnificent horses which the
Title:  stable boys are leading about.  It would be a pleasure worthy of
Title:  a prince to travel upon such horses."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, my dear Aramis, you may enjoy that pleasure, for one of
Title:  those three horses is yours."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, bah!  Which?"
Title:  
Title:  "Whichever of the three you like, I have no preference."
Title:  
Title:  "And the rich caparison, is that mine, too?"
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt."
Title:  
Title:  "You laugh, d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "No, I have left off laughing, now that you speak French."
Title:  
Title:  "What, those rich holsters, that velvet housing, that saddle
Title:  studded with silver-are they all for me?"
Title:  
Title:  "For you and nobody else, as the horse which paws the ground is
Title:  mine, and the other horse, which is caracoling, belongs to
Title:  Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "PESTE!  They are three superb animals!"
Title:  
Title:  "I am glad they please you."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, it must have been the king who made you such a present."
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly it was not the cardinal; but don't trouble yourself
Title:  whence they come, think only that one of the three is your
Title:  property."
Title:  
Title:  "I choose that which the red-headed boy is leading."
Title:  
Title:  "It is yours!"
Title:  
Title:  "Good heaven!  That is enough to drive away all my pains; I could
Title:  mount him with thirty balls in my body.  On my soul, handsome
Title:  stirrups!  HOLA, Bazin, come here this minute."
Title:  
Title:  Bazin appeared on the threshold, dull and spiritless.
Title:  
Title:  "That last order is useless," interrupted d'Artagnan; "there are
Title:  loaded pistols in your holsters."
Title:  
Title:  Bazin sighed.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, Monsieur Bazin, make yourself easy," said d'Artagnan;
Title:  "people of all conditions gain the kingdom of heaven."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur was already such a good theologian," said Bazin, almost
Title:  weeping; "he might have become a bishop, and perhaps a cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but my poor Bazin, reflect a little.  Of what use is it to
Title:  be a churchman, pray?  You do not avoid going to war by that
Title:  means; you see, the cardinal is about to make the next campaign,
Title:  helm on head and partisan in hand.  And Monsieur de Nogaret de la
Title:  Valette, what do you say of him?  He is a cardinal likewise.  Ask
Title:  his lackey how often he has had to prepare lint of him."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!" sighed Bazin.  "I know it, monsieur; everything is turned
Title:  topsy-turvy in the world nowadays."
Title:  
Title:  While this dialogue was going on, the two young men and the poor
Title:  lackey descended.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold my stirrup, Bazin," cried Aramis; and Aramis sprang into
Title:  the saddle with his usual grace and agility, but after a few
Title:  vaults and curvets of the noble animal his rider felt his pains
Title:  come on so insupportably that he turned pale and became unsteady
Title:  in his seat.  D'Artagnan, who, foreseeing such an event, had kept
Title:  his eye on him, sprang toward him, caught him in his arms, and
Title:  assisted him to his chamber.
Title:  
Title:  "That's all right, my dear Aramis, take care of yourself," said
Title:  he; "I will go alone in search of Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "You are a man of brass," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "No, I have good luck, that is all.  But how do you mean to pass
Title:  your time till I come back?  No more theses, no more glosses upon
Title:  the fingers or upon benedictions, hey?"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis smiled.  "I will make verses," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I dare say; verses perfumed with the odor of the billet
Title:  from the attendant of Madame de Chevreuse.  Teach Bazin prosody;
Title:  that will console him.  As to the horse, ride him a little every
Title:  day, and that will accustom you to his maneuvers."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, make yourself easy on that head," replied Aramis.  "You will
Title:  find me ready to follow you."
Title:  
Title:  They took leave of each other, and in ten minutes, after having
Title:  commended his friend to the cares of the hostess and Bazin,
Title:  d'Artagnan was trotting along in the direction of Amiens.
Title:  
Title:  How was he going to find Athos?  Should he find him at all?  The
Title:  position in which he had left him was critical.  He probably had
Title:  succumbed.  This idea, while darkening his brow, drew several
Title:  sighs from him, and caused him to formulate to himself a few vows
Title:  of vengeance.  Of all his friends, Athos was the eldest, and the
Title:  least resembling him in appearance, in his tastes and sympathies.
Title:  
Title:  Yet he entertained a marked preference for this gentleman.  The
Title:  noble and distinguished air of Athos, those flashes of greatness
Title:  which from time to time broke out from the shade in which he
Title:  voluntarily kept himself, that unalterable equality of temper
Title:  which made him the most pleasant companion in the world, that
Title:  forced and cynical gaiety, that bravery which might have been
Title:  termed blind if it had not been the result of the rarest
Title:  coolness--such qualities attracted more than the esteem, more than
Title:  the friendship of d'Artagnan; they attracted his admiration.
Title:  
Title:  Indeed, when placed beside M. de Treville, the elegant and noble
Title:  courtier, Athos in his most cheerful days might advantageously
Title:  sustain a comparison.  He was of middle height; but his person
Title:  was so admirably shaped and so well proportioned that more than
Title:  once in his struggles with Porthos he had overcome the giant
Title:  whose physical strength was proverbial among the Musketeers.  His
Title:  head, with piercing eyes, a straight nose, a chin cut like that
Title:  of Brutus, had altogether an indefinable character of grandeur
Title:  and grace.  His hands, of which he took little care, were the
Title:  despair of Aramis, who cultivated his with almond paste and
Title:  perfumed oil.  The sound of his voice was at once penetrating and
Title:  melodious; and then, that which was inconceivable in Athos, who
Title:  was always retiring, was that delicate knowledge of the world and
Title:  of the usages of the most brilliant society--those manners of a
Title:  high degree which appeared, as if unconsciously to himself, in
Title:  his least actions.
Title:  
Title:  If a repast were on foot, Athos presided over it better than any
Title:  other, placing every guest exactly in the rank which his
Title:  ancestors had earned for him or that he had made for himself.  If
Title:  a question in heraldry were started, Athos knew all the noble
Title:  families of the kingdom, their genealogy, their alliances, their
Title:  coats of arms, and the origin of them.  Etiquette had no minutiae
Title:  unknown to him.  He knew what were the rights of the great land
Title:  owners.  He was profoundly versed in hunting and falconry, and
Title:  had one day when conversing on this great art astonished even
Title:  Louis XIII himself, who took a pride in being considered a past
Title:  master therein.
Title:  
Title:  Like all the great nobles of that period, Athos rode and fenced
Title:  to perfection.  But still further, his education had been so
Title:  little neglected, even with respect to scholastic studies, so
Title:  rare at this time among gentlemen, that he smiled at the scraps
Title:  of Latin which Aramis sported and which Porthos pretended to
Title:  understand.  Two or three times, even, to the great astonishment
Title:  of his friends, he had, when Aramis allowed some rudimental error
Title:  to escape him, replaced a verb in its right tense and a noun in
Title:  its case.  Besides, his probity was irreproachable, in an age in
Title:  which soldiers compromised so easily with their religion and
Title:  their consciences, lovers with the rigorous delicacy of our era,
Title:  and the poor with God's Seventh Commandment.  This Athos, then,
Title:  was a very extraordinary man.
Title:  
Title:  And yet this nature so distinguished, this creature so beautiful,
Title:  this essence so fine, was seen to turn insensibly toward material
Title:  life, as old men turn toward physical and moral imbecility.
Title:  Athos, in his hours of gloom--and these hours were frequent--was
Title:  extinguished as to the whole of the luminous portion of him, and
Title:  his brilliant side disappeared as into profound darkness.
Title:  
Title:  Then the demigod vanished; he remained scarcely a man.  His head
Title:  hanging down, his eye dull, his speech slow and painful, Athos
Title:  would look for hours together at his bottle, his glass, or at
Title:  Grimaud, who, accustomed to obey him by signs, read in the faint
Title:  glance of his master his least desire, and satisfied it
Title:  immediately.  If the four friends were assembled at one of these
Title:  moments, a word, thrown forth occasionally with a violent effort,
Title:  was the share Athos furnished to the conversation.  In exchange
Title:  for his silence Athos drank enough for four, and without
Title:  appearing to be otherwise affected by wine than by a more marked
Title:  constriction of the brow and by a deeper sadness.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, whose inquiring disposition we are acquainted with,
Title:  had not--whatever interest he had in satisfying his curiosity on
Title:  this subject--been able to assign any cause for these fits of for
Title:  the periods of their recurrence.  Athos never received any
Title:  letters; Athos never had concerns which all his friends did not
Title:  know.
Title:  
Title:  It could not be said that it was wine which produced this
Title:  sadness; for in truth he only drank to combat this sadness, which
Title:  wine however, as we have said, rendered still darker.  This
Title:  excess of bilious humor could not be attributed to play; for
Title:  unlike Porthos, who accompanied the variations of chance with
Title:  songs or oaths, Athos when he won remained as unmoved as when he
Title:  lost.  He had been known, in the circle of the Musketeers, to win
Title:  in one night three thousand pistoles; to lose them even to the
Title:  gold-embroidered belt for gala days, win all this again with the
Title:  addition of a hundred louis, without his beautiful eyebrow being
Title:  heightened or lowered half a line, without his hands losing their
Title:  pearly hue, without his conversation, which was cheerful that
Title:  evening, ceasing to be calm and agreeable.
Title:  
Title:  Neither was it, as with our neighbors, the English, an
Title:  atmospheric influence which darkened his countenance; for the
Title:  sadness generally became more intense toward the fine season of
Title:  the year.  June and July were the terrible months with Athos.
Title:  
Title:  For the present he had no anxiety.  He shrugged his shoulders
Title:  when people spoke of the future.  His secret, then, was in the
Title:  past, as had often been vaguely said to d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  This mysterious shade, spread over his whole person, rendered
Title:  still more interesting the man whose eyes or mouth, even in the
Title:  most complete intoxication, had never revealed anything, however
Title:  skillfully questions had been put to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," thought d'Artagnan, "poor Athos is perhaps at this moment
Title:  dead, and dead by my fault--for it was I who dragged him into this
Title:  affair, of which he did not know the origin, of which he is
Title:  ignorant of the result, and from which he can derive no
Title:  advantage."
Title:  
Title:  "Without reckoning, monsieur," added Planchet to his master's
Title:  audibly expressed reflections, "that we perhaps owe our lives to
Title:  him.  Do you remember how he cried, 'On, d'Artagnan, on, I am
Title:  taken'?  And when he had discharged his two pistols, what a
Title:  terrible noise he made with his sword!  One might have said that
Title:  twenty men, or rather twenty mad devils, were fighting."
Title:  
Title:  These words redoubled the eagerness of d'Artagnan, who urged his
Title:  horse, though he stood in need of no incitement, and they
Title:  proceeded at a rapid pace.  About eleven o'clock in the morning
Title:  they perceived Ameins, and at half past eleven they were at the
Title:  door of the cursed inn.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had often meditated against the perfidious host one of
Title:  those hearty vengeances which offer consolation while they are
Title:  hoped for.  He entered the hostelry with his hat pulled over his
Title:  eyes, his left hand on the pommel of the sword, and cracking his
Title:  whip with his right hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you remember me?" said he to the host, who advanced to greet
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  "I have not that honor, monseigneur," replied the latter, his
Title:  eyes dazzled by the brilliant style in which d'Artagnan traveled.
Title:  
Title:  "What, you don't know me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, two words will refresh your memory.  What have you done
Title:  with that gentleman against whom you had the audacity, about
Title:  twelve days ago, to make an accusation of passing false money?"
Title:  
Title:  The host became as pale as death; for d'Artagnan had assumed a
Title:  threatening attitude, and Planchet modeled himself after his
Title:  master.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monseigneur, do not mention it!" cried the host, in the most
Title:  pitiable voice imaginable.  "Ah, monseigneur, how dearly have I
Title:  paid for that fault, unhappy wretch as I am!"
Title:  
Title:  "That gentleman, I say, what has become of him?"
Title:  
Title:  "Deign to listen to me, monseigneur, and be merciful!  Sit down,
Title:  in mercy!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, mute with anger and anxiety, took a seat in the
Title:  threatening attitude of a judge.  Planchet glared fiercely over
Title:  the back of his armchair.
Title:  
Title:  "Here is the story, monseigneur," resumed the trembling host;
Title:  "for I now recollect you.  It was you who rode off at the moment
Title:  I had that unfortunate difference with the gentleman you speak
Title:  of."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, it was I; so you may plainly perceive that you have no
Title:  mercy to expect if you do not tell me the whole truth."
Title:  
Title:  "Condescend to listen to me, and you shall know all."
Title:  
Title:  "I listen."
Title:  
Title:  "I had been warned by the authorities that a celebrated coiner of
Title:  bad money would arrive at my inn, with several of his companions,
Title:  all disguised as Guards or Musketeers.  Monseigneur, I was
Title:  furnished with a description of your horses, your lackeys, your
Title:  countenances--nothing was omitted."
Title:  
Title:  "Go on, go on!" said d'Artagnan, who quickly understood whence
Title:  such an exact description had come.
Title:  
Title:  "I took then, in conformity with the orders of the authorities,
Title:  who sent me a reinforcement of six men, such measures as I
Title:  thought necessary to get possession of the persons of the
Title:  pretended coiners."
Title:  
Title:  "Again!" said d'Artagnan, whose ears chafed terribly under the
Title:  repetition of this word COINERs.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon me, monseigneur, for saying such things, but they form my
Title:  excuse.  The authorities had terrified me, and you know that an
Title:  innkeeper must keep on good terms with the authorities."
Title:  
Title:  "But once again, that gentleman--where is he?  What has become of
Title:  him?  Is he dead?  Is he living?"
Title:  
Title:  "Patience, monseigneur, we are coming to it.  There happened then
Title:  that which you know, and of which your precipitate departure,"
Title:  added the host, with an acuteness that did not escape d'Artagnan,
Title:  "appeared to authorize the issue.  That gentleman, your friend,
Title:  defended himself desperately.  His lackey, who, by an unforeseen
Title:  piece of ill luck, had quarreled with the officers, disguised as
Title:  stable lads--"
Title:  
Title:  "Miserable scoundrel!" cried d'Artagnan, "you were all in the
Title:  plot, then!  And I really don't know what prevents me from
Title:  exterminating you all."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, monseigneur, we were not in the plot, as you will soon
Title:  see.  Monsieur your friend (pardon for not calling him by the
Title:  honorable name which no doubt he bears, but we do not know that
Title:  name), Monsieur your friend, having disabled two men with his
Title:  pistols, retreated fighting with his sword, with which he disabled
Title:  one of my men, and stunned me with a blow of the flat side of
Title:  it."
Title:  
Title:  "You villain, will you finish?" cried d'Artagnan, "Athos--what has
Title:  become of Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "While fighting and retreating, as I have told Monseigneur, he
Title:  found the door of the cellar stairs behind him, and as the door
Title:  was open, he took out the key, and barricaded himself inside.  As
Title:  we were sure of finding him there, we left him alone."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said d'Artagnan, "you did not really wish to kill; you
Title:  only wished to imprison him."
Title:  
Title:  "Good God!  To imprison him, monseigneur?  Why, he imprisoned
Title:  himself, I swear to you he did.  In the first place he had made
Title:  rough work of it; one man was killed on the spot, and two others
Title:  were severely wounded.  The dead man and the two wounded were
Title:  carried off by their comrades, and I have heard nothing of either
Title:  of them since.  As for myself, as soon as I recovered my senses I
Title:  went to Monsieur the Governor, to whom I related all that had
Title:  passed, and asked, what I should do with my prisoner.  Monsieur
Title:  the Governor was all astonishment.  He told me he knew nothing
Title:  about the matter, that the orders I had received did not come
Title:  from him, and that if I had the audacity to mention his name as
Title:  being concerned in this disturbance he would have me hanged.  It
Title:  appears that I had made a mistake, monsieur, that I had arrested
Title:  the wrong person, and that he whom I ought to have arrested had
Title:  escaped."
Title:  
Title:  "But Athos!" cried d'Artagnan, whose impatience was increased by
Title:  the disregard of the authorities, "Athos, where is he?"
Title:  
Title:  "As I was anxious to repair the wrongs I had done the prisoner,"
Title:  resumed the innkeeper, "I took my way straight to the cellar in
Title:  order to set him at liberty.  Ah, monsieur, he was no longer a
Title:  man, he was a devil!  To my offer of liberty, he replied that it
Title:  was nothing but a snare, and that before he came out he intended
Title:  to impose his own conditions.  I told him very humbly--for I could
Title:  not conceal from myself the scrape I had got into by laying hands
Title:  on one of his Majesty's Musketeers--I told him I was quite ready
Title:  to submit to his conditions.
Title:  
Title:  "'In the first place,' said he, 'I wish my lackey placed with me,
Title:  fully armed.'  We hastened to obey this order; for you will
Title:  please to understand, monsieur, we were disposed to do everything
Title:  your friend could desire.  Monsieur Grimaud (he told us his name,
Title:  although he does not talk much)--Monsieur Grimaud, then, went down
Title:  to the cellar, wounded as he was; then his master, having
Title:  admitted him, barricaded the door afresh, and ordered us to
Title:  remain quietly in our own bar."
Title:  
Title:  "But where is Athos now?" cried d'Artagnan.  "Where is Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the cellar, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "What, you scoundrel!  Have you kept him in the cellar all this
Title:  time?"
Title:  
Title:  "Merciful heaven!  No, monsieur!  We keep him in the cellar!  You
Title:  do not know what he is about in the cellar.  Ah!  If you could
Title:  but persuade him to come out, monsieur, I should owe you the
Title:  gratitude of my whole life; I should adore you as my patron
Title:  saint!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then he is there?  I shall find him there?"
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt you will, monsieur; he persists in remaining
Title:  there.  We every day pass through the air hole some bread at the
Title:  end of a fork, and some meat when he asks for it; but alas!  It
Title:  is not of bread and meat of which he makes the greatest
Title:  consumption.  I once endeavored to go down with two of my
Title:  servants; but he flew into terrible rage.  I heard the noise he
Title:  made in loading his pistols, and his servant in loading his
Title:  musketoon.  Then, when we asked them what were their intentions,
Title:  the master replied that he had forty charges to fire, and that he
Title:  and his lackey would fire to the last one before he would allow a
Title:  single soul of us to set foot in the cellar.  Upon this I went
Title:  and complained to the governor, who replied that I only had what
Title:  I deserved, and that it would teach me to insult honorable
Title:  gentlemen who took up their abode in my house."
Title:  
Title:  "So that since that time--" replied d'Artagnan, totally unable to
Title:  refrain from laughing at the pitiable face of the host.
Title:  
Title:  "So from that time, monsieur," continued the latter, "we have led
Title:  the most miserable life imaginable; for you must know, monsieur,
Title:  that all our provisions are in the cellar.  There is our wine in
Title:  bottles, and our wine in casks; the beer, the oil, and the
Title:  spices, the bacon, and sausages.  And as we are prevented from
Title:  going down there, we are forced to refuse food and drink to the
Title:  travelers who come to the house; so that our hostelry is daily
Title:  going to ruin.  If your friend remains another week in my cellar
Title:  I shall be a ruined man."
Title:  
Title:  "And not more than justice, either, you ass!  Could you not
Title:  perceive by our appearance that we were people of quality, and
Title:  not coiners--say?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, you are right," said the host.  "But, hark, hark!
Title:  There he is!"
Title:  
Title:  "Somebody has disturbed him, without doubt," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "But he must be disturbed," cried the host; "Here are two English
Title:  gentlemen just arrived."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, the English like good wine, as you may know, monsieur;
Title:  these have asked for the best.  My wife has perhaps requested
Title:  permission of Monsieur Athos to go into the cellar to satisfy
Title:  these gentlemen; and he, as usual, has refused.  Ah, good heaven!
Title:  There is the hullabaloo louder than ever!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, in fact, heard a great noise on the side next the
Title:  cellar.  He rose, and preceded by the host wringing his hands,
Title:  and followed by Planchet with his musketoon ready for use, he
Title:  approached the scene of action.
Title:  
Title:  The two gentlemen were exasperated; they had had a long ride, and
Title:  were dying with hunger and thirst.
Title:  
Title:  "But this is tyranny!" cried one of them, in very good French,
Title:  though with a foreign accent, "that this madman will not allow
Title:  these good people access to their own wine!  Nonsense, let us
Title:  break open the door, and if he is too far gone in his madness,
Title:  well, we will kill him!"
Title:  
Title:  "Softly, gentlemen!" said d'Artagnan, drawing his pistols from
Title:  his belt, "you will kill nobody, if you please!"
Title:  
Title:  "Good, good!" cried the calm voice of Athos, from the other side
Title:  of the door, "let them just come in, these devourers of little
Title:  children, and we shall see!"
Title:  
Title:  Brave as they appeared to be, the two English gentlemen looked at
Title:  each other hesitatingly.  One might have thought there was in
Title:  that cellar one of those famished ogres--the gigantic heroes of
Title:  popular legends, into whose cavern nobody could force their way
Title:  with impunity.
Title:  
Title:  There was a moment of silence; but at length the two Englishmen
Title:  felt ashamed to draw back, and the angrier one descended the five
Title:  or six steps which led to the cellar, and gave a kick against the
Title:  door enough to split a wall.
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet," said d'Artagnan, cocking his pistols, "I will take
Title:  charge of the one at the top; you look to the one below.  Ah,
Title:  gentlemen, you want battle; and you shall have it."
Title:  
Title:  "Good God!" cried the hollow voice of Athos, "I can hear
Title:  d'Artagnan, I think."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," cried d'Artagnan, raising his voice in turn, "I am here,
Title:  my friend."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, good, then," replied Athos, "we will teach them, these door
Title:  breakers!"
Title:  
Title:  The gentlemen had drawn their swords, but they found themselves
Title:  taken between two fires.  They still hesitated an instant; but, as
Title:  before, pride prevailed, and a second kick split the door from
Title:  bottom to top.
Title:  
Title:  "Stand on one side, d'Artagnan, stand on one side," cried Athos.
Title:  "I am going to fire!"
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," exclaimed d'Artagnan, whom reflection never
Title:  abandoned, "gentlemen, think of what you are about.  Patience,
Title:  Athos!  You are running your heads into a very silly affair; you
Title:  will be riddled.  My lackey and I will have three shots at you,
Title:  and you will get as many from the cellar.  You will then have our
Title:  swords, with which, I can assure you, my friend and I can play
Title:  tolerably well.  Let me conduct your business and my own.  You
Title:  shall soon have something to drink; I give you my word."
Title:  
Title:  "If there is any left," grumbled the jeering voice of Athos.
Title:  
Title:  The host felt a cold sweat creep down his back.
Title:  
Title:  "How!  'If there is any left!'" murmured he.
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil!  There must be plenty left," replied d'Artagnan.
Title:  "Be satisfied of that; these two cannot have drunk all the
Title:  cellar.  Gentlemen, return your swords to their scabbards."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, provided you replace your pistols in your belt."
Title:  
Title:  "Willingly."
Title:  
Title:  And d'Artagnan set the example.  Then, turning toward Planchet,
Title:  he made him a sign to uncock his musketoon.
Title:  
Title:  The Englishmen, convinced of these peaceful proceedings, sheathed
Title:  their swords grumblingly.  The history of Athos's imprisonment
Title:  was then related to them; and as they were really gentlemen, they
Title:  pronounced the host in the wrong.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, "go up to your room again; and
Title:  in ten minutes, I will answer for it, you shall have all you
Title:  desire."
Title:  
Title:  The Englishmen bowed and went upstairs.
Title:  
Title:  "Now I am alone, my dear Athos," said d'Artagnan; "open the door,
Title:  I beg of you."
Title:  
Title:  "Instantly," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Then was heard a great noise of fagots being removed and of the
Title:  groaning of posts; these were the counterscarps and bastions of
Title:  Athos, which the besieged himself demolished.
Title:  
Title:  An instant after, the broken door was removed, and the pale face
Title:  of Athos appeared, who with a rapid glance took a survey of the
Title:  surroundings.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan threw himself on his neck and embraced him tenderly.
Title:  He then tried to draw him from his moist abode, but to his
Title:  surprise he perceived that Athos staggered.
Title:  
Title:  "You are wounded," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "I!  Not at all.  I am dead drunk, that's all, and never did a
Title:  man more strongly set about getting so.  By the Lord, my good
Title:  host!  I must at least have drunk for my part a hundred and fifty
Title:  bottles."
Title:  
Title:  "Mercy!" cried the host, "if the lackey has drunk only half as
Title:  much as the master, I am a ruined man."
Title:  
Title:  "Grimaud is a well-bred lackey.  He would never think of faring
Title:  in the same manner as his master; he only drank from the cask.
Title:  Hark!  I don't think he put the faucet in again.  Do you hear it?
Title:  It is running now."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan burst into a laugh which changed the shiver of the
Title:  host into a burning fever.
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime, Grimaud appeared in his turn behind his master,
Title:  with the musketoon on his shoulder, and his head shaking. Like
Title:  one of those drunken satyrs in the pictures of Rubens.  He was
Title:  moistened before and behind with a greasy liquid which the host
Title:  recognized as his best olive oil.
Title:  
Title:  The four crossed the public room and proceeded to take possession
Title:  of the best apartment in the house, which d'Artagnan occupied
Title:  with authority.
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime the host and his wife hurried down with lamps
Title:  into the cellar, which had so long been interdicted to them and
Title:  where a frightful spectacle awaited them.
Title:  
Title:  Beyond the fortifications through which Athos had made a breach
Title:  in order to get out, and which were composed of fagots, planks,
Title:  and empty casks, heaped up according to all the rules of the
Title:  strategic art, they found, swimming in puddles of oil and wine,
Title:  the bones and fragments of all the hams they had eaten; while a
Title:  heap of broken bottles filled the whole left-hand corner of the
Title:  cellar, and a tun, the cock of which was left running, was
Title:  yielding, by this means, the last drop of its blood.  "The image
Title:  of devastation and death," as the ancient poet says, "reigned as
Title:  over a field of battle."
Title:  
Title:  Of fifty large sausages, suspended from the joists, scarcely ten
Title:  remained.
Title:  
Title:  Then the lamentations of the host and hostess pierced the vault
Title:  of the cellar.  D'Artagnan himself was moved by them.  Athos did
Title:  not even turn his head.
Title:  
Title:  To grief succeeded rage.  The host armed himself with a spit, and
Title:  rushed into the chamber occupied by the two friends.
Title:  
Title:  "Some wine!" said Athos, on perceiving the host.
Title:  
Title:  "Some wine!" cried the stupefied host, "some wine?  Why you have
Title:  drunk more than a hundred pistoles' worth!  I am a ruined man,
Title:  lost, destroyed!"
Title:  
Title:  "Bah," said Athos, "we were always dry."
Title:  
Title:  "If you had been contented with drinking, well and good; but you
Title:  have broken all the bottles."
Title:  
Title:  "You pushed me upon a heap which rolled down.  That was your
Title:  fault."
Title:  
Title:  "All my oil is lost!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oil is a sovereign balm for wounds; and my poor Grimaud here was
Title:  obliged to dress those you had inflicted on him."
Title:  
Title:  "All my sausages are gnawed!"
Title:  
Title:  "There is an enormous quantity of rats in that cellar."
Title:  
Title:  "You shall pay me for all this," cried the exasperated host.
Title:  
Title:  "Triple ass!" said Athos, rising; but he sank down again
Title:  immediately.  He had tried his strength to the utmost.
Title:  d'Artagnan came to his relief with his whip in his hand.
Title:  
Title:  The host drew back and burst into tears.
Title:  
Title:  "This will teach you," said d'Artagnan, "to treat the guests God
Title:  sends you in a more courteous fashion."
Title:  
Title:  "God?  Say the devil!"
Title:  
Title:  "My dear friend," said d'Artagnan, "if you annoy us in this
Title:  manner we will all four go and shut ourselves up in your cellar,
Title:  and we will see if the mischief is as great as you say."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, gentlemen," said the host, "I have been wrong.  I confess
Title:  it, but pardon to every sin!  You are gentlemen, and I am a poor
Title:  innkeeper.  You will have pity on me."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, if you speak in that way," said Athos, "you will break my
Title:  heart, and the tears will flow from my eyes as the wine flowed
Title:  from the cask.  We are not such devils as we appear to be.  Come
Title:  hither, and let us talk."
Title:  
Title:  The host approached with hesitation.
Title:  
Title:  "Come hither, I say, and don't be afraid," continued Athos.  "At
Title:  the very moment when I was about to pay you, I had placed my
Title:  purse on the table."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "That purse contained sixty pistoles; where is it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Deposited with the justice; they said it was bad money."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well; get me my purse back and keep the sixty pistoles."
Title:  
Title:  "But Monseigneur knows very well that justice never lets go that
Title:  which it once lays hold of.  If it were bad money, there might be
Title:  some hopes; but unfortunately, those were all good pieces."
Title:  
Title:  "Manage the matter as well as you can, my good man; it does not
Title:  concern me, the more so as I have not a livre left."
Title:  
Title:  "Come," said d'Artagnan, "let us inquire further.  Athos's horse,
Title:  where is that?"
Title:  
Title:  "In the stable."
Title:  
Title:  "How much is it worth?"
Title:  
Title:  "Fifty pistoles at most."
Title:  
Title:  "It's worth eighty.  Take it, and there ends the matter."
Title:  
Title:  "What," cried Athos, "are you selling my horse--my Bajazet?  And
Title:  pray upon what shall I make my campaign; upon Grimaud?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have brought you another," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Another?"
Title:  
Title:  "And a magnificent one!" cried the host.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, since there is another finer and younger, why, you may
Title:  take the old one; and let us drink."
Title:  
Title:  "What?" asked the host, quite cheerful again.
Title:  
Title:  "Some of that at the bottom, near the laths.  There are twenty-
Title:  five bottles of it left; all the rest were broken by my fall.
Title:  Bring six of them."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, this man is a cask!" said the host, aside.  "If he only
Title:  remains here a fortnight, and pays for what he drinks, I shall
Title:  soon re-establish my business."
Title:  
Title:  "And don't forget," said d'Artagnan, "to bring up four bottles of
Title:  the same sort for the two English gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  "And now," said Athos, "while they bring the wine, tell me,
Title:  d'Artagnan, what has become of the others, come!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related how he had found Porthos in bed with a
Title:  strained knee, and Aramis at a table between two theologians.  As
Title:  he finished, the host entered with the wine ordered and a ham
Title:  which, fortunately for him, had been left out of the cellar.
Title:  
Title:  "That's well!" said Athos, filling his glass and that of his
Title:  friend; "here's to Porthos and Aramis!  But you, d'Artagnan, what
Title:  is the matter with you, and what has happened to you personally?
Title:  You have a sad air."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas," said d'Artagnan, "it is because I am the most
Title:  unfortunate."
Title:  
Title:  "Tell me."
Title:  
Title:  "Presently," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Presently!  And why presently?  Because you think I am drunk?
Title:  d'Artagnan, remember this!  My ideas are never so clear as when I
Title:  have had plenty of wine.  Speak, then, I am all ears."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related his adventure with Mme. Bonacieux.  Athos
Title:  listened to him without a frown; and when he had finished, said,
Title:  "Trifles, only trifles!"  That was his favorite word.
Title:  
Title:  "You always say TRIFLES, my dear Athos!" said d'Artagnan, "and
Title:  that come very ill from you, who have never loved."
Title:  
Title:  The drink-deadened eye of Athos flashed out, but only for a
Title:  moment; it became as dull and vacant as before.
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said he, quietly, "for my part I have never
Title:  loved."
Title:  
Title:  "Acknowledge, then, you stony heart," said d'Artagnan, "that you
Title:  are wrong to be so hard upon us tender hearts."
Title:  
Title:  "Tender hearts!   Pierced hearts!" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say that love is a lottery in which he who wins, wins death!
Title:  You are very fortunate to have lost, believe me, my dear
Title:  d'Artagnan.  And if I have any counsel to give, it is, always
Title:  lose!"
Title:  
Title:  "She seemed to love me so!"
Title:  
Title:  "She SEEMED, did she?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, she DID love me!"
Title:  
Title:  "You child, why, there is not a man who has not believed, as you
Title:  do, that his mistress loved him, and there lives not a man who
Title:  has not been deceived by his mistress."
Title:  
Title:  "Except you, Athos, who never had one."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said Athos, after a moment's silence, "that's
Title:  true!  I never had one!  Let us drink!"
Title:  
Title:  "But then, philosopher that you are," said d'Artagnan, "instruct
Title:  me, support me.  I stand in need of being taught and consoled."
Title:  
Title:  "Consoled for what?"
Title:  
Title:  "For my misfortune."
Title:  
Title:  "Your misfortune is laughable," said Athos, shrugging his
Title:  shoulders; "I should like to know what you would say if I were to
Title:  relate to you a real tale of love!"
Title:  
Title:  "Which has happened to you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Or one of my friends, what matters?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tell it, Athos, tell it."
Title:  
Title:  "Better if I drink."
Title:  
Title:  "Drink and relate, then."
Title:  
Title:  "Not a bad idea!" said Athos, emptying and refilling his glass.
Title:  "The two things agree marvelously well."
Title:  
Title:  "I am all attention," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  Athos collected himself, and in proportion as he did so,
Title:  d'Artagnan saw that he became pale.  He was at that period of
