Title:  intoxication in which vulgar drinkers fall on the floor and go to
Title:  sleep.  He kept himself upright and dreamed, without sleeping.
Title:  This somnambulism of drunkenness had something frightful in it.
Title:  
Title:  "You particularly wish it?" asked he.
Title:  
Title:  "I pray for it," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Be it then as you desire.  One of my friends--one of my friends,
Title:  please to observe, not myself," said Athos, interrupting himself
Title:  with a melancholy smile, "one of the counts of my province--that
Title:  is to say, of Berry--noble as a Dandolo or a Montmorency, at
Title:  twenty-five years of age fell in love with a girl of sixteen,
Title:  beautiful as fancy can paint.  Through the ingenuousness of her
Title:  age beamed an ardent mind, not of the woman, but of the poet.
Title:  She did not please; she intoxicated.  She lived in a small town
Title:  with her brother, who was a curate.  Both had recently come into
Title:  the country.  They came nobody knew whence; but when seeing her
Title:  so lovely and her brother so pious, nobody thought of asking
Title:  whence they came.  They were said, however, to be of good
Title:  extraction.  My friend, who was seigneur of the country, might
Title:  have seduced her, or taken her by force, at his will--for he was
Title:  master.  Who would have come to the assistance of two strangers,
Title:  two unknown persons?  Unfortunately he was an honorable man; he
Title:  married her.  The fool!  The ass!  The idiot!"
Title:  
Title:  "How so, if he love her?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Wait," said Athos.  "He took her to his chateau, and made her
Title:  the first lady in the province; and in justice it must be allowed
Title:  that she supported her rank becomingly."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, one day when she was hunting with her husband," continued
Title:  Athos, in a low voice, and speaking very quickly, "she fell from
Title:  her horse and fainted.  The count flew to her to help, and as she
Title:  appeared to be oppressed by her clothes, he ripped them open with
Title:  his ponaird, and in so doing laid bare her shoulder.
Title:  d'Artagnan," said Athos, with a maniacal burst of laughter,
Title:  "guess what she had on her shoulder."
Title:  
Title:  "How can I tell?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "A FLEUR-DE-LIS," said Athos.  "She was branded."
Title:  
Title:  Athos emptied at a single draught the glass he held in his hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Horror!" cried d'Artagnan.  "What do you tell me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Truth, my friend.  The angel was a demon; the poor young girl
Title:  had stolen the sacred vessels from a church."
Title:  
Title:  "And what did the count do?"
Title:  
Title:  "The count was of the highest nobility.  He had on his estates
Title:  the rights of high and low tribunals.  He tore the dress of the
Title:  countess to pieces; he tied her hands behind her, and hanged her
Title:  on a tree."
Title:  
Title:  "Heavens, Athos, a murder?" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "No less," said Athos, as pale as a corpse.  "But methinks I need
Title:  wine!" and he seized by the neck the last bottle that was left,
Title:  put it to his mouth, and emptied it at a single draught, as he
Title:  would have emptied an ordinary glass.
Title:  
Title:  Then he let his head sink upon his two hands, while d'Artagnan
Title:  stood before him, stupefied.
Title:  
Title:  "That has cured me of beautiful, poetical, and loving women,"
Title:  said Athos, after a considerable pause, raising his head, and
Title:  forgetting to continue the fiction of the count.  "God grant you
Title:  as much!  Let us drink."
Title:  
Title:  "Then she is dead?" stammered d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "PARBLEU!" said Athos.  "But hold out your glass.  Some ham, my
Title:  boy, or we can't drink."
Title:  
Title:  "And her brother?" added d'Artagnan, timidly.
Title:  
Title:  "Her brother?" replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, the priest."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I inquired after him for the purpose of hanging him
Title:  likewise; but he was beforehand with me, he had quit the curacy
Title:  the night before."
Title:  
Title:  "Was it ever known who this miserable fellow was?"
Title:  
Title:  "He was doubtless the first lover and accomplice of the fair
Title:  lady.  A worthy man, who had pretended to be a curate for the
Title:  purpose of getting his mistress married, and securing her a
Title:  position.  He has been hanged and quartered, I hope."
Title:  
Title:  "My God, my God!" cried d'Artagnan, quite stunned by the relation
Title:  of this horrible adventure.
Title:  
Title:  "Taste some of this ham, d'Artagnan; it is exquisite," said
Title:  Athos, cutting a slice, which he placed on the young man's plate.
Title:  
Title:  "What a pity it is there were only four like this in the cellar.
Title:  I could have drunk fifty bottles more."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan could no longer endure this conversation, which had
Title:  made him bewildered.  Allowing his head to sink upon his two
Title:  hands, he pretended to sleep.
Title:  
Title:  "These young fellows can none of them drink," said Athos, looking
Title:  at him with pity, "and yet this is one of the best!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  28  THE RETURN
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was astounded by the terrible confidence of Athos; yet
Title:  many things appeared very obscure to him in this half revelation.
Title:  In the first place it had been made by a man quite drunk to one
Title:  who was half drunk; and yet, in spite of the incertainty which
Title:  the vapor of three or four bottles of Burgundy carries with it to
Title:  the brain, d'Artagnan, when awaking on the following morning, had
Title:  all the words of Athos as present to his memory as if they then
Title:  fell from his mouth--they had been so impressed upon his mind.
Title:  All this doubt only gave rise to a more lively desire of arriving
Title:  at a certainty, and he went into his friend's chamber with a
Title:  fixed determination of renewing the conversation of the preceding
Title:  evening; but he found Athos quite himself again--that is to say,
Title:  the most shrewd and impenetrable of men.  Besides which, the
Title:  Musketeer, after having exchanged a hearty shake of the hand with
Title:  him, broached the matter first.
Title:  
Title:  "I was pretty drunk yesterday, d'Artagnan," said he, "I can tell
Title:  that by my tongue, which was swollen and hot this morning, and by
Title:  my pulse, which was very tremulous.  I wager that I uttered a
Title:  thousand extravagances."
Title:  
Title:  While saying this he looked at his friend with an earnestness
Title:  that embarrassed him.
Title:  
Title:  "No," replied d'Artagnan, "if I recollect well what you said, it
Title:  was nothing out of the common way."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you surprise me.  I thought I had told you a most lamentable
Title:  story."  And he looked at the young man as if he would read the
Title:  bottom of his heart.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith," said d'Artagnan, "it appears that I was more drunk
Title:  than you, since I remember nothing of the kind."
Title:  
Title:  Athos did not trust this reply, and he resumed; "you cannot have
Title:  failed to remark, my dear friend, that everyone has his
Title:  particular kind of drunkenness, sad or gay.  My drunkenness is
Title:  always sad, and when I am thoroughly drunk my mania is to relate
Title:  all the lugubrious stories which my foolish nurse inculcated into
Title:  my brain.  That is my failing--a capital failing, I admit; but
Title:  with that exception, I am a good drinker."
Title:  
Title:  Athos spoke this in so natural a manner that d'Artagnan was
Title:  shaken in his conviction.
Title:  
Title:  "It is that, then," replied the young man, anxious to find out
Title:  the truth, "it is that, then, I remember as we remember a dream.
Title:  We were speaking of hanging."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you see how it is," said Athos, becoming still paler, but
Title:  yet attempting to laugh; "I was sure it was so--the hanging of
Title:  people is my nightmare."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," replied d'Artagnan.  "I remember now; yes, it was
Title:  about--stop a minute--yes, it was about a woman."
Title:  
Title:  "That's it," replied Athos, becoming almost livid; "that is my
Title:  grand story of the fair lady, and when I relate that, I must be
Title:  very drunk."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that was it," said d'Artagnan, "the story of a tall, fair
Title:  lady, with blue eyes."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, who was hanged."
Title:  
Title:  "By her husband, who was a nobleman of your acquaintance,"
Title:  continued d'Artagnan, looking intently at Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, you see how a man may compromise himself when he does not
Title:  know what he says," replied Athos, shrugging his shoulders as if
Title:  he thought himself an object of pity.  "I certainly never will
Title:  get drunk again, d'Artagnan; it is too bad a habit."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan remained silent; and then changing the conversation
Title:  all at once, Athos said:
Title:  
Title:  "By the by, I thank you for the horse you have brought me."
Title:  
Title:  "Is it to your mind?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but it is not a horse for hard work."
Title:  
Title:  "You are mistaken; I rode him nearly ten leagues in less than an
Title:  hour and a half, and he appeared no more distressed than if he
Title:  had only made the tour of the Place St. Sulpice."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you begin to awaken my regret."
Title:  
Title:  "Regret?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; I have parted with him."
Title:  
Title:  "How?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, here is the simple fact.  This morning I awoke at six
Title:  o'clock.  You were still fast asleep, and I did not know what to
Title:  do with myself; I was still stupid from our yesterday's debauch.
Title:  As I came into the public room, I saw one of our Englishman
Title:  bargaining with a dealer for a horse, his own having died
Title:  yesterday from bleeding.  I drew near, and found he was bidding a
Title:  hundred pistoles for a chestnut nag.  'PARDIEU,' said I, 'my good
Title:  gentleman, I have a horse to sell, too.' 'Ay, and a very fine
Title:  one!  I saw him yesterday; your friend's lackey was leading him.'
Title:  'Do you think he is worth a hundred pistoles?' 'Yes!  Will you
Title:  sell him to me for that sum?' 'No; but I will play for him.'
Title:  'What?' 'At dice.'  No sooner said than done, and I lost the
Title:  horse.  Ah, ah!  But please to observe I won back the equipage,"
Title:  cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan looked much disconcerted.
Title:  
Title:  "This vexes you?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I must confess it does," replied d'Artagnan.  "That horse
Title:  was to have identified us in the day of battle.  It was a pledge,
Title:  a remembrance.  Athos, you have done wrong."
Title:  
Title:  "But, my dear friend, put yourself in my place," replied the
Title:  Musketeer.  "I was hipped to death; and still further, upon my
Title:  honor, I don't like English horses.  If it is only to be
Title:  recognized, why the saddle will suffice for that; it is quite
Title:  remarkable enough.  As to the horse, we can easily find some
Title:  excuse for its disappearance.  Why the devil!  A horse is mortal;
Title:  suppose mine had had the glanders or the farcy?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan did not smile.
Title:  
Title:  "It vexes me greatly," continued Athos, "that you attach so much
Title:  importance to these animals, for I am not yet at the end of my
Title:  story."
Title:  
Title:  "What else have you done."
Title:  
Title:  "After having lost my own horse, nine against ten--see how near--
Title:  I formed an idea of staking yours."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but you stopped at the idea, I hope?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; for I put it in execution that very minute."
Title:  
Title:  "And the consequence?" said d'Artagnan, in great anxiety.
Title:  
Title:  "I threw, and I lost."
Title:  
Title:  "What, my horse?"
Title:  
Title:  "Your horse, seven against eight; a point short--you know the
Title:  proverb."
Title:  
Title:  "Athos, you are not in your right senses, I swear."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear lad, that was yesterday, when I was telling you silly
Title:  stories, it was proper to tell me that, and not this morning.  I
Title:  lost him then, with all his appointments and furniture."
Title:  
Title:  "Really, this is frightful."
Title:  
Title:  "Stop a minute; you don't know all yet.  I should make an
Title:  excellent gambler if I were not too hot-headed; but I was hot-
Title:  headed, just as if I had been drinking.  Well, I was not hot-
Title:  headed then--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but what else could you play for?  You had nothing left?"
Title:  
Title:  'Oh, yes, my friend; there was still that diamond left which
Title:  sparkles on your finger, and which I had observed yesterday."
Title:  
Title:  "This diamond!" said d'Artagnan, placing his hand eagerly on his
Title:  ring.
Title:  
Title:  "And as I am a connoisseur in such things, having had a few of my
Title:  own once, I estimated it at a thousand pistoles."
Title:  
Title:  "I hope," said d'Artagnan, half dead with fright, "you made no
Title:  mention of my diamond?"
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary, my dear friend, this diamond became our only
Title:  resource; with it I might regain our horses and their harnesses,
Title:  and even money to pay our expenses on the road."
Title:  
Title:  "Athos, you make me tremble!" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I mentioned your diamond then to my adversary, who had likewise
Title:  remarked it.  What the devil, my dear, do you think you can wear
Title:  a star from heaven on your finger, and nobody observe it?
Title:  Impossible!"
Title:  
Title:  "Go on, go on, my dear fellow!" said d'Artagnan; "for upon my
Title:  honor, you will kill me with your indifference."
Title:  
Title:  "We divided, then, this diamond into ten parts of a hundred
Title:  pistoles each."
Title:  
Title:  "You are laughing at me, and want to try me!" said d'Artagnan,
Title:  whom anger began to take by the hair, as Minerva takes Achilles,
Title:  in the ILLIAD.
Title:  
Title:  "No, I do not jest, MORDIEU!  I should like to have seen you in
Title:  my place!  I had been fifteen days without seeing a human face,
Title:  and had been left to brutalize myself in the company of bottles."
Title:  
Title:  "That was no reason for staking my diamond!" replied d'Artagnan,
Title:  closing his hand with a nervous spasm.
Title:  
Title:  "Hear the end.  Ten parts of a hundred pistoles each, in ten
Title:  throws, without revenge; in thirteen throws I had lost all--in
Title:  thirteen throws.  The number thirteen was always fatal to me; it
Title:  was on the thirteenth of July that--"
Title:  
Title:  "VENTREBLEU!" cried d'Artagnan, rising from the table, the story
Title:  of the present day making him forget that of the preceding one.
Title:  
Title:  "Patience!" said Athos; "I had a plan.  The Englishman was an
Title:  original; I had seen him conversing that morning with Grimaud,
Title:  and Grimaud had told me that he had made him proposals to enter
Title:  into his service.  I staked Grimaud, the silent Grimaud, divided
Title:  into ten portions."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what next?" said d'Artagnan, laughing in spite of himself.
Title:  
Title:  "Grimaud himself, understand; and with the ten parts of Grimaud,
Title:  which are not worth a ducatoon, I regained the diamond.  Tell me,
Title:  now, if persistence is not a virtue?"
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!  But this is droll," cried d'Artagnan, consoled, and
Title:  holding his sides with laughter.
Title:  
Title:  "You may guess, finding the luck turned, that I again staked the
Title:  diamond."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said d'Artagnan, becoming angry again.
Title:  
Title:  "I won back your harness, then your horse, then my harness, then
Title:  my horse, and then I lost again.  In brief, I regained your
Title:  harness and then mine.  That's where we are.  That was a superb
Title:  throw, so I left off there."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan breathed as if the whole hostelry had been removed
Title:  from his breast.
Title:  
Title:  "Then the diamond is safe?" said he, timidly.
Title:  
Title:  "Intact, my dear friend; besides the harness of your Bucephalus
Title:  and mine."
Title:  
Title:  "But what is the use of harnesses without horses?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have an idea about them."
Title:  
Title:  "Athos, you make me shudder."
Title:  
Title:  "Listen to me.  You have not played for a long time, d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "And I have no inclination to play."
Title:  
Title:  "Swear to nothing.  You have not played for a long time, I said;
Title:  you ought, then, to have a good hand."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well; the Englishman and his companion are still here.  I
Title:  remarked that he regretted the horse furniture very much.  You
Title:  appear to think much of your horse.  In your place I would stake
Title:  the furniture against the horse."
Title:  
Title:  "But he will not wish for only one harness."
Title:  
Title:  "Stake both, PARDIEU!  I am not selfish, as you are."
Title:  
Title:  "You would do so?" said d'Artagnan, undecided, so strongly did
Title:  the confidence of Athos begin to prevail, in spite of himself.
Title:  
Title:  "On my honor, in one single throw."
Title:  
Title:  "But having lost the horses, I am particularly anxious to
Title:  preserve the harnesses."
Title:  
Title:  "Stake your diamond, then."
Title:  
Title:  "This?  That's another matter.  Never, never!"
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said Athos.  "I would propose to you to stake
Title:  Planchet, but as that has already been done, the Englishman would
Title:  not, perhaps, be willing."
Title:  
Title:  "Decidedly, my dear Athos," said d'Artagnan, "I should like
Title:  better not to risk anything."
Title:  
Title:  "That's a pity," said Athos, coolly.  "The Englishman is
Title:  overflowing with pistoles.  Good Lord, try one throw!  One throw
Title:  is soon made!"
Title:  
Title:  "And if I lose?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will win."
Title:  
Title:  "But if I lose?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, you will surrender the harnesses."
Title:  
Title:  "Have with you for one throw!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  Athos went in quest of the Englishman, whom he found in the
Title:  stable, examining the harnesses with a greedy eye.  The
Title:  opportunity was good.  He proposed the conditions--the two
Title:  harnesses, either against one horse or a hundred pistoles.  The
Title:  Englishman calculated fast; the two harnesses were worth three
Title:  hundred pistoles.  He consented.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan threw the dice with a trembling hand, and turned up
Title:  the number three; his paleness terrified Athos, who, however,
Title:  consented himself with saying, "That's a sad throw, comrade; you
Title:  will have the horses fully equipped, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  The Englishman, quite triumphant, did not even give himself the
Title:  trouble to shake the dice.  He threw them on the table without
Title:  looking at them, so sure was he of victory; d'Artagnan turned
Title:  aside to conceal his ill humor.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold, hold, hold!" said Athos, wit his quiet tone; "that throw
Title:  of the dice is extraordinary.  I have not seen such a one four
Title:  times in my life.  Two aces!"
Title:  
Title:  The Englishman looked, and was seized with astonishment.
Title:  d'Artagnan looked, and was seized with pleasure.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," continued Athos, "four times only; once at the house of
Title:  Monsieur Crequy; another time at my own house in the country, in
Title:  my chateau at--when I had a chateau; a third time at Monsieur de
Title:  Treville's where it surprised us all; and the fourth time at a
Title:  cabaret, where it fell to my lot, and where I lost a hundred
Title:  louis and a supper on it."
Title:  
Title:  "Then Monsieur takes his horse back again," said the Englishman.
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Then there is no revenge?"
Title:  
Title:  "Our conditions said, 'No revenge,' you will please to
Title:  recollect."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true; the horse shall be restored to your lackey,
Title:  monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "A moment," said Athos; "with your permission, monsieur, I wish
Title:  to speak a word with my friend."
Title:  
Title:  "Say on."
Title:  
Title:  Athos drew d'Artagnan aside.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, Tempter, what more do you want with me?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  "You want me to throw again, do you not?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, I would wish you to reflect."
Title:  
Title:  "On what?"
Title:  
Title:  "You mean to take your horse?"
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt."
Title:  
Title:  "You are wrong, then.  I would take the hundred pistoles.  You
Title:  know you have staked the harnesses against the horse or a hundred
Title:  pistoles, at your choice."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, I repeat, you are wrong.  What is the use of one
Title:  horse for us two?  I could not ride behind.  We should look like
Title:  the two sons of Anmon, who had lost their brother.  You cannot
Title:  think of humiliating me by prancing along by my side on that
Title:  magnificent charger.  For my part, I should not hesitate a
Title:  moment; I should take the hundred pistoles.  We want money for
Title:  our return to Paris."
Title:  
Title:  "I am much attached to that horse, Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "And there again you are wrong.  A horse slips and injures a
Title:  joint; a horse stumbles and breaks his knees to the bone; a horse
Title:  eats out of a manger in which a glandered horse has eaten.  There
Title:  is a horse, while on the contrary, the hundred pistoles feed
Title:  their master."
Title:  
Title:  "But how shall we get back?"
Title:  
Title:  "Upon our lackey's horses, PARDIEU.  Anybody may see by our
Title:  bearing that we are people of condition."
Title:  
Title:  "Pretty figures we shall cut on ponies while Aramis and Porthos
Title:  caracole on their steeds."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis!  Porthos!" cried Athos, and laughed aloud.
Title:  
Title:  "What is it?" asked d'Artagnan, who did not at all comprehend the
Title:  hilarity of his friend.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, nothing!  Go on!"
Title:  
Title:  "Your advice, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "To take the hundred pistoles, d'Artagnan.  With the hundred
Title:  pistoles we can live well to the end of the month.  We have
Title:  undergone a great deal of fatigue, remember, and a little rest
Title:  will do no harm."
Title:  
Title:  "I rest?  Oh, no, Athos.  Once in Paris, I shall prosecute my
Title:  search for that unfortunate woman!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, you may be assured that your horse will not be half so
Title:  serviceable to you for that purpose as good golden louis.  Take
Title:  the hundred pistoles, my friend; take the hundred pistoles!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan only required one reason to be satisfied.  This last
Title:  reason appeared convincing.  Besides, he feared that by resisting
Title:  longer he should appear selfish in the eyes of Athos.  He
Title:  acquiesced, therefore, and chose the hundred pistoles, which the
Title:  Englishman paid down on the spot.
Title:  
Title:  They then determined to depart.  Peace with the landlord, in
Title:  addition to Athos's old horse, cost six pistoles.  D'Artagnan and
Title:  Athos took the nags of Planchet and Grimaud, and the two lackeys
Title:  started on foot, carrying the saddles on their heads.
Title:  
Title:  However ill our two friends were mounted, they were soon far in
Title:  advance of their servants, and arrived at Creveccoeur.  From a
Title:  distance they perceived Aramis, seated in a melancholy manner at
Title:  his window, looking out, like Sister Anne, at the dust in the
Title:  horizon.
Title:  
Title:  "HOLA, Aramis!  What the devil are you doing there?" cried the
Title:  two friends.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, is that you, d'Artagnan, and you, Athos?" said the young
Title:  man.  "I was reflecting upon the rapidity with which the
Title:  blessings of this world leave us.  My English horse, which has
Title:  just disappeared amid a cloud of dust, has furnished me with a
Title:  living image of the fragility of the things of the earth.  Life
Title:  itself may be resolved into three words:  ERAT, EST, FUIT."
Title:  
Title:  "Which means--" said d'Artagnan, who began to suspect the truth.
Title:  
Title:  "Which means that I have just been duped-sixty louis for a horse
Title:  which by the manner of his gait can do at least five leagues an
Title:  hour."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan and Athos laughed aloud.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear d'Artagnan," said Aramis, "don't be too angry with me, I
Title:  beg.  Necessity has no law; besides, I am the person punished, as
Title:  that rascally horsedealer has robbed me of fifty louis, at least.
Title:  Ah, you fellows are good managers!  You ride on our lackey's
Title:  horses, and have your own gallant steeds led along carefully by
Title:  hand, at short stages."
Title:  
Title:  At the same instant a market cart, which some minutes before had
Title:  appeared upon the Amiens road, pulled up at the inn, and Planchet
Title:  and Grimaud came out of it with the saddles on their heads.  The
Title:  cart was returning empty to Paris, and the two lackeys had
Title:  agreed, for their transport, to slake the wagoner's thirst along
Title:  the route.
Title:  
Title:  "What is this?" said Aramis, on seeing them arrive.  "Nothing but
Title:  saddles?"
Title:  
Title:  "Now do you understand?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "My friends, that's exactly like me!  I retained my harness by
Title:  instinct.  HOLA, Bazin! Bring my new saddle and carry it along
Title:  with those of these gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  "And what have you done with your ecclesiastics?" asked
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear fellow, I invited them to a dinner the next day,"
Title:  replied Aramis.  "They have some capital wine here--please to
Title:  observe that in passing.  I did my best to make them drunk.  Then
Title:  the curate forbade me to quit my uniform, and the Jesuit
Title:  entreated me to get him made a Musketeer."
Title:  
Title:  "Without a thesis?" cried d'Artagnan, "without a thesis?  I
Title:  demand the suppression of the thesis."
Title:  
Title:  "Since then," continued Aramis, "I have lived very agreeably.  I
Title:  have begun a poem in verses of one syllable.  That is rather
Title:  difficult, but the merit in all things consists in the
Title:  difficulty.  The matter is gallant.  I will read you the first
Title:  canto.  It has four hundred lines, and lasts a minute."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, my dear Aramis," said d'Artagnan, who detested verses
Title:  almost as much as he did Latin, "add to the merit of the
Title:  difficulty that of the brevity, and you are sure that your poem
Title:  will at least have two merits."
Title:  
Title:  "You will see," continued Aramis, "that it breathes
Title:  irreproachable passion.  And so, my friends, we return to Paris?
Title:  Bravo!  I am ready.  We are going to rejoin that good fellow,
Title:  Porthos.  So much the better.  You can't think how I have missed
Title:  him, the great simpleton.  To see him so self-satisfied
Title:  reconciles me with myself.  He would not sell his horse; not for
Title:  a kingdom!  I think I can see him now, mounted upon his superb
Title:  animal and seated in his handsome saddle.  I am sure he will look
Title:  like the Great Mogul!"
Title:  
Title:  They made a halt for an hour to refresh their horses.  Aramis
Title:  discharged his bill, placed Bazin in the cart with his comrades,
Title:  and they set forward to join Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  They found him up, less pale than when d'Artagnan left him after
Title:  his first visit, and seated at a table on which, though he was
Title:  alone, was spread enough for four persons.  This dinner consisted
Title:  of meats nicely dressed, choice wines, and superb fruit.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, PARDIEU!" said he, rising, "you come in the nick of time,
Title:  gentlemen.  I was just beginning the soup, and you will dine with
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, oh!" said d'Artagnan, "Mousqueton has not caught these
Title:  bottles with his lasso.  Besides, here is a piquant FRICANDEAU
Title:  and a fillet of beef."
Title:  
Title:  "I am recruiting myself," said Porthos, "I am recruiting myself.
Title:  Nothing weakens a man more than these devilish strains.  Did you
Title:  ever suffer from a strain, Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Never!  Though I remember, in our affair of the Rue Ferou, I
Title:  received a sword wound which at the end of fifteen or eighteen
Title:  days produced the same effect."
Title:  
Title:  "But this dinner was not intended for you alone, Porthos?" said
Title:  Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "No," said Porthos, "I expected some gentlemen of the
Title:  neighborhood, who have just sent me word they could not come.
Title:  You will take their places and I shall not lose by the exchange.
Title:  HOLA, Mousqueton, seats, and order double the bottles!"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know what we are eating here?" said Athos, at the end of
Title:  ten minutes.
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU!" replied d'Artagnan, "for my part, I am eating veal
Title:  garnished with shrimps and vegetables."
Title:  
Title:  "And I some lamb chops," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "And I a plain chicken," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "You are all mistaken, gentlemen," answered Athos, gravely; "you
Title:  are eating horse."
Title:  
Title:  "Eating what?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Horse!" said Aramis, with a grimace of disgust.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos alone made no reply.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, horse.  Are we not eating a horse, Porthos?  And perhaps
Title:  his saddle, therewith."
Title:  
Title:  "No, gentlemen, I have kept the harness," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith," said Aramis, "we are all alike.  One would think we
Title:  had tipped the wink."
Title:  
Title:  "What could I do?" said Porthos.  "This horse made my visitors
Title:  ashamed of theirs, and I don't like to humiliate people."
Title:  
Title:  "Then your duchess is still at the waters?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Still," replied Porthos.  "And, my faith, the governor of the
Title:  province--one of the gentlemen I expected today--seemed to have
Title:  such a wish for him, that I gave him to him."
Title:  
Title:  "Gave him?" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "My God, yes, GAVE, that is the word," said Porthos; "for the
Title:  animal was worth at least a hundred and fifty louis, and the
Title:  stingy fellow would only give me eighty."
Title:  
Title:  "Without the saddle?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, without the saddle."
Title:  
Title:  "You will observe, gentlemen," said Athos, "that Porthos has made
Title:  the best bargain of any of us."
Title:  
Title:  And then commenced a roar of laughter in which they all joined,
Title:  to the astonishment of poor Porthos; but when he was informed of
Title:  the cause of their hilarity, he shared it vociferously according
Title:  to his custom.
Title:  
Title:  "There is one comfort, we are all in cash," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, for my part," said Athos, "I found Aramis's Spanish wine
Title:  so good that I sent on a hamper of sixty bottles of it in the
Title:  wagon with the lackeys.  That has weakened my purse."
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said Aramis, "imagined that I had given almost my last
Title:  sou to the church of Montdidier and the Jesuits of Amiens, with
Title:  whom I had made engagements which I ought to have kept.  I have
Title:  ordered Masses for myself, and for you, gentlemen, which will be
Title:  said, gentlemen, for which I have not the least doubt you will be
Title:  marvelously benefited."
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said Porthos, "do you think my strain cost me nothing?--
Title:  without reckoning Mousqueton's wound, for which I had to have the
Title:  surgeon twice a day, and who charged me double on account of that
Title:  foolish Mousqueton having allowed himself a ball in a part which
Title:  people generally only show to an apothecary; so I advised him to
Title:  try never to get wounded there any more."
Title:  
Title:  "Ay, ay!" said Athos, exchanging a smile with d'Artagnan and
Title:  Aramis, "it is very clear you acted nobly with regard to the poor
Title:  lad; that is like a good master."
Title:  
Title:  "In short," said Porthos, "when all my expenses are paid, I shall
Title:  have, at most, thirty crowns left."
Title:  
Title:  "And I about ten pistoles," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then it appears that we are the Croesuses of the society.
Title:  How much have you left of your hundred pistoles, d'Artagnan?"
Title:  
Title:  "Of my hundred pistoles?  Why, in the first place I gave you
Title:  fifty."
Title:  
Title:  "You think so?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, that is true.  I recollect."
Title:  
Title:  "Then I paid the host six."
Title:  
Title:  "What a brute of a host!  Why did you give him six pistoles?"
Title:  
Title:  "You told me to give them to him."
Title:  
Title:  "It is true; I am too good-natured.  In brief, how much remains?"
Title:  
Title:  "Twenty-five pistoles," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said Athos, taking some small change from his pocket,
Title:  I--"
Title:  
Title:  "You?  Nothing!"
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!  So little that it is not worth reckoning with the
Title:  general stock."
Title:  
Title:  "Now, then, let us calculate how much we posses in all."
Title:  
Title:  "Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Thirty crowns."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ten pistoles."
Title:  
Title:  "And you, d'Artagnan?"
Title:  
Title:  "Twenty-five."
Title:  
Title:  "That makes in all?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Four hundred and seventy-five livres," said d'Artagnan, who
Title:  reckoned like Archimedes.
Title:  
Title:  "On our arrival in Paris, we shall still have four hundred,
Title:  besides the harnesses," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "But our troop horses?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, of the four horses of our lackeys we will make two for the
Title:  masters, for which we will draw lots.  With the four hundred
Title:  livres we will make the half of one for one of the unmounted, and
Title:  then we will give the turnings out of our pockets to d'Artagnan,
Title:  who has a steady hand, and will go and play in the first gaming
Title:  house we come to.  There!"
Title:  
Title:  "Let us dine, then," said Porthos; "it is getting cold."
Title:  
Title:  The friends, at ease with regard to the future, did honor to the
Title:  repast, the remains of which were abandoned to Mousqueton, Bazin,
Title:  Planchet, and Grimaud.
Title:  
Title:  On arriving in Paris, d'Artagnan found a letter from M. de
Title:  Treville, which informed him that, at his request, the king had
Title:  promised that he should enter the company of the Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  As this was the height of d'Artagnan's worldly ambition--apart,
Title:  be it well understood, from his desire of finding Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux--he ran, full of joy, to seek his comrades, whom he had
Title:  left only half an hour before, but whom he found very sad and
Title:  deeply preoccupied.  They were assembled in council at the
Title:  residence of Athos, which always indicated an event of some
Title:  gravity.  M. de Treville had intimated to them his Majesty's
Title:  fixed intention to open the campaign on the first of May, and
Title:  they must immediately prepare their outfits.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The four philosophers looked at one another in a state of
Title:  bewilderment.  M. de Treville never jested in matters relating to
Title:  discipline.
Title:  
Title:  "And what do you reckon your outfit will cost?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, we can scarcely say.  We have made our calculations with
Title:  Spartan economy, and we each require fifteen hundred livres."
Title:  
Title:  "Four times fifteen makes sixty--six thousand livres," said
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "It seems to me," said d'Artagnan, "with a thousand livres each--
Title:  I do not speak as a Spartan, but as a procurator--"
Title:  
Title:  This word PROCURATOR roused Porthos.  "Stop," said he, "I have an
Title:  idea."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, that's something, for I have not the shadow of one," said
Title:  Athos coolly; "but as to d'Artagnan, gentlemen, the idea of
Title:  belonging to OURS has driven him out of his senses.  A thousand
Title:  livres!  For my part, I declare I want two thousand."
Title:  
Title:  "Four times two makes eight," then said Aramis; "it is eight
Title:  thousand that we want to complete our outfits, toward which, it
Title:  is true, we have already the saddles."
Title:  
Title:  "Besides," said Athos, waiting till d'Artagnan, who went to thank
Title:  Monsieur de Treville, had shut the door, "besides, there is that
Title:  beautiful ring which beams from the finger of our friend.  What
Title:  the devil!  D'Artagnan is too good a comrade to leave his
Title:  brothers in embarrassment while he wears the ransom of a king on
Title:  his finger."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  29  HUNTING FOR THE EQUIPMENTS
Title:  
Title:  The most preoccupied of the four friends was certainly
Title:  d'Artagnan, although he, in his quality of Guardsman, would be
Title:  much more easily equipped than Messieurs the Musketeers, who were
Title:  all of high rank; but our Gascon cadet was, as may have been
Title:  observed, of a provident and almost avaricious character, and
Title:  with that (explain the contradiction) so vain as almost to rival
Title:  Porthos.  To this preoccupation of his vanity, d'Artagnan at this
Title:  moment joined an uneasiness much less selfish.  Notwithstanding
Title:  all his inquiries respecting Mme. Bonacieux, he could obtain no
Title:  intelligence of her.  M. de Treville had spoken of her to the
Title:  queen.  The queen was ignorant where the mercer's young wife was,
Title:  but had promised to have her sought for; but this promise was
Title:  very vague and did not at all reassure d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  Athos did not leave his chamber; he made up his mind not to take
Title:  a single step to equip himself.
Title:  
Title:  "We have still fifteen days before us," said he to his friends.
Title:  "well, if at the end of a fortnight I have found nothing, or
Title:  rather if nothing has come to find me, as I, too good a
Title:  Catholic to kill myself with a pistol bullet, I will seek a good
Title:  quarrel with four of his Eminence's Guards or with eight
Title:  Englishmen, and I will fight until one of them has killed me,
Title:  which, considering the number, cannot fail to happen.  It will
Title:  then be said of me that I died for the king; so that I shall have
Title:  performed my duty without the expense of an outfit."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos continued to walk about with his hands behind him,
Title:  tossing his head and repeating, "I shall follow up on my idea."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, anxious and negligently dressed, said nothing.
Title:  
Title:  It may be seen by these disastrous details that desolation
Title:  reigned in the community.
Title:  
Title:  The lackeys on their part, like the coursers of Hippolytus,
Title:  shared the sadness of their masters.  Mousqueton collected a
Title:  store of crusts; Bazin, who had always been inclined to devotion,
Title:  never quit the churches; Planchet watched the flight of flies;
Title:  and Grimaud, whom the general distress could not induce to break
Title:  the silence imposed by his master, heaved sighs enough to soften
Title:  the stones.
Title:  
Title:  The three friends--for, as we have said, Athos had sworn not to
Title:  stir a foot to equip himself--went out early in the morning, and
Title:  returned late at night.  They wandered about the streets, looking
Title:  at the pavement as if to see whether the passengers had not left a
Title:  purse behind them.  They might have been supposed to be following
Title:  tracks, so observant were they wherever they went.  When they met
Title:  they looked desolately at one another, as much as to say, "Have
Title:  you found anything?"
Title:  
Title:  However, as Porthos had first found an idea, and had thought of
Title:  it earnestly afterward, he was the first to act.  He was a man of
Title:  execution, this worthy Porthos.  D'Artagnan perceived him one day
Title:  walking toward the church of St. Leu, and followed him
Title:  instinctively.  He entered, after having twisted his mustache and
Title:  elongated his imperial, which always announced on his part the
Title:  most triumphant resolutions.  As d'Artagnan took some precautions
Title:  to conceal himself, Porthos believed he had not been seen.
Title:  d'Artagnan entered behind him.  Porthos went and leaned against
Title:  the side of a pillar.  D'Artagnan, still unperceived, supported
Title:  himself against the other side.
Title:  
Title:  There happened to be a sermon, which made the church very full of
Title:  people.  Porthos took advantage of this circumstance to ogle the
Title:  women.  Thanks to the cares of Mousqueton, the exterior was far
Title:  from announcing the distress of the interior.  His hat was a
Title:  little napless, his feather was a little faded, his gold lace was
Title:  a little tarnished, his laces were a trifle frayed; but in the
Title:  obscurity of the church these things were not seen, and Porthos
Title:  was still the handsome Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan observed, on the bench nearest to the pillar against
Title:  which Porthos leaned, a sort of ripe beauty, rather yellow and
Title:  rather dry, but erect and haughty under her black hood.  The eyes
Title:  of Porthos were furtively cast upon this lady, and then roved
Title:  about at large over the nave.
Title:  
Title:  On her side the lady, who from time to time blushed, darted with
Title:  the rapidity of lightning a glance toward the inconstant Porthos;
Title:  and then immediately the eyes of Porthos wandered anxiously.  It
Title:  was plain that this mode of proceeding piqued the lady in the
Title:  black hood, for she bit her lips till they bled, scratched the
Title:  end of her nose, and could not sit still in her seat.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, seeing this, retwisted his mustache, elongated his
Title:  imperial a second time, and began to make signals to a beautiful
Title:  lady who was near the choir, and who not only was a beautiful
Title:  lady, but still further, no doubt, a great lady--for she had
Title:  behind her a Negro boy who had brought the cushion on which she
Title:  knelt, and a female servant who held the emblazoned bag in which
Title:  was placed the book from which she read the Mass.
Title:  
Title:  The lady with the black hood followed through all their
Title:  wanderings the looks of Porthos, and perceived that they rested
Title:  upon the lady with the velvet cushion, the little Negro, and the
Title:  maid-servant.
Title:  
Title:  During this time Porthos played close.  It was almost
Title:  imperceptible motions of his eyes, fingers placed upon the lips,
Title:  little assassinating smiles, which really did assassinate the
Title:  disdained beauty.
Title:  
Title:  Then she cried, "Ahem!" under cover of the MEA CULPA, striking
Title:  her breast so vigorously that everybody, even the lady with the
Title:  red cushion, turned round toward her.  Porthos paid no attention.
Title:  Nevertheless, he understood it all, but was deaf.
Title:  
Title:  The lady with the red cushion produced a great effect--for she
Title:  was very handsome--upon the lady with he black hood, who saw in
Title:  her a rival really to be dreaded; a great effect upon Porthos,
Title:  who thought her much prettier than the lady with the black hood;
Title:  a great effect upon d'Artagnan, who recognized in her the lady of
Title:  Meung, of Calais, and of Dover, whom his persecutor, the man with
Title:  the scar, had saluted by the name of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, without losing sight of the lady of the red cushion,
Title:  continued to watch the proceedings of Porthos, which amused him
Title:  greatly.  He guessed that the lady of the black hood was the
Title:  procurator's wife of the Rue aux Ours, which was the more
Title:  probable from the church of St. Leu being not far from that
Title:  locality.
Title:  
Title:  He guessed, likewise, by induction, that Porthos was taking his
Title:  revenge for the defeat of Chantilly, when the procurator's wife
Title:  had proved so refractory with respect to her purse.
Title:  
Title:  Amid all this, d'Artagnan remarked also that not one countenance
Title:  responded to the gallantries of Porthos.  There were only
Title:  chimeras and illusions; but for real love, for true jealousy, is
Title:  there any reality except illusions and chimeras?
Title:  
Title:  The sermon over, the procurator's wife advanced toward the holy
Title:  font.  Porthos went before her, and instead of a finger, dipped
Title:  his whole hand in.  The procurator's wife smiled, thinking that
Title:  it was for her Porthos had put himself to this trouble; but she
Title:  was cruelly and promptly undeceived.  When she was only about
Title:  three steps from him, he turned his head round, fixing his eyes
Title:  steadfastly upon the lady with the red cushion, who had risen and
Title:  was approaching, followed by her black boy and her woman.
Title:  
Title:  When the lady of the red cushion came close to Porthos, Porthos
Title:  drew his dripping hand from the font.  The fair worshipper
Title:  touched the great hand of Porthos with her delicate fingers,
Title:  smiled, made the sign of the cross, and left the church.
Title:  
Title:  This was too much for the procurator's wife; she doubted not
Title:  there was an intrigue between this lady and Porthos.  If she had
Title:  been a great lady she would have fainted; but as she was only a
Title:  procurator's wife, she contented herself saying to the Musketeer
Title:  with concentrated fury, "Eh, Monsieur Porthos, you don't offer me
Title:  any holy water?"
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, at the sound of that voice, started like a man awakened
Title:  from a sleep of a hundred years.
Title:  
Title:  "Ma-madame!" cried he; "is that you?  How is your husband, our
Title:  dear Monsieur Coquenard?  Is he still as stingy as ever?  Where
Title:  can my eyes have been not to have seen you during the two hours
Title:  of the sermon?"
Title:  
Title:  "I was within two paces of you, monsieur," replied the
Title:  procurator's wife; "but you did not perceive me because you had
Title:  no eyes but for the pretty lady to whom you just now gave the
Title:  holy water."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos pretended to be confused.  "Ah," said he, "you have
Title:  remarked--"
Title:  
Title:  "I must have been blind not to have seen."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Porthos, "that is a duchess of my acquaintance whom I
Title:  have great trouble to meet on account of the jealousy of her
Title:  husband, and who sent me word that she should come today to this
Title:  poor church, buried in this vile quarter, solely for the sake of
Title:  seeing me."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Porthos," said the procurator's wife, "will you have
Title:  the kindness to offer me your arm for five minutes?  I have
Title:  something to say to you."
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly, madame," said Porthos, winking to himself, as a
Title:  gambler does who laughs at the dupe he is about to pluck.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment d'Artagnan passed in pursuit of Milady; he cast a
Title:  passing glance at Porthos, and beheld this triumphant look.
Title:  
Title:  "Eh, eh!" said he, reasoning to himself according to the
Title:  strangely easy morality of that gallant period, "there is one who
Title:  will be equipped in good time!"
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, yielding to the pressure of the arm of the procurator's
Title:  wife, as a bark yields to the rudder, arrived at the cloister St.
Title:  Magloire--a little-frequented passage, enclosed with a turnstile
Title:  at each end.  In the daytime nobody was seen there but mendicants
Title:  devouring their crusts, and children at play.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, Monsieur Porthos," cried the procurator's wife, when she was
Title:  assured that no one who was a stranger to the population of the
Title:  locality could either see or hear her, "ah, Monsieur Porthos, you
Title:  are a great conqueror, as it appears!"
Title:  
Title:  "I, madame?" said Porthos, drawing himself up proudly; "how so?"
Title:  
Title:  "The signs just now, and the holy water!  But that must be a
Title:  princess, at least--that lady with her Negro boy and her maid!"
Title:  
Title:  "My God!  Madame, you are deceived," said Porthos; "she is simply
Title:  a duchess."
Title:  
Title:  "And that running footman who waited at the door, and that
Title:  carriage with a coachman in grand livery who sat waiting on his
Title:  seat?"
Title:  
Title:  Porthos had seen neither the footman nor the carriage, but with
Title:  the eye of a jealous woman, Mme. Coquenard had seen everything.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos regretted that he had not at once made the lady of the
Title:  red cushion a princess.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you are quite the pet of the ladies, Monsieur Porthos!"
Title:  resumed the procurator's wife, with a sigh.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," responded Porthos, "you may imagine, with the physique
Title:  with which nature has endowed me, I am not in want of good luck."
Title:  
Title:  "Good Lord, how quickly men forget!" cried the procurator's wife,
Title:  raising her eyes toward heaven.
Title:  
Title:  "Less quickly than the women, it seems to me," replied Porthos;
Title:  "for I, madame, I may say I was your victim, when wounded, dying,
Title:  I was abandoned by the surgeons.  I, the offspring of a noble
Title:  family, who placed reliance upon your friendship--I was near
Title:  dying of my wounds at first, and of hunger afterward, in a
Title:  beggarly inn at Chantilly, without you ever deigning once to
Title:  reply to the burning letters I addressed to you."
Title:  
Title:  "But, Monsieur Porthos," murmured the procurator's wife, who
Title:  began to feel that, to judge by the conduct of the great ladies
Title:  of the time, she was wrong.
Title:  
Title:  "I, who had sacrificed for you the Baronne de--"
Title:  
Title:  "I know it well."
Title:  
Title:  "The Comtesse de--"
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Porthos, be generous!"
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, madame, and I will not finish."
Title:  
Title:  "But it was my husband who would not hear of lending."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame Coquenard," said Porthos, "remember the first letter you
Title:  wrote me, and which I preserve engraved in my memory."
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife uttered a groan.
Title:  
Title:  "Besides," said she, "the sum you required me to borrow was
Title:  rather large."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame Coquenard, I gave you the preference.  I had but to write
Title:  to the Duchesse--but I won't repeat her name, for I am incapable
Title:  of compromising a woman; but this I know, that I had but to write
Title:  to her and she would have sent me fifteen hundred."
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife shed a tear.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Porthos," said she, "I can assure you that you have
Title:  severely punished me; and if in the time to come you should find
Title:  yourself in a similar situation, you have but to apply to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Fie, madame, fie!" said Porthos, as if disgusted.  "Let us not
Title:  talk about money, if you please; it is humiliating."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you no longer love me!" said the procurator's wife, slowly
Title:  and sadly.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos maintained a majestic silence.
Title:  
Title:  "And that is the only reply you make?  Alas, I understand."
Title:  
Title:  "Think of the offense you have committed toward me, madame!  It
Title:  remains HERE!" said Porthos, placing his hand on his heart, and
Title:  pressing it strongly.
Title:  
Title:  "I will repair it, indeed I will, my dear Porthos."
Title:  
Title:  "Besides, what did I ask of you?" resumed Porthos, with a
Title:  movement of the shoulders full of good fellowship.  "A loan,
Title:  nothing more!  After all, I am not an unreasonable man.  I know
Title:  you are not rich, Madame Coquenard, and that your husband is
Title:  obliged to bleed his poor clients to squeeze a few paltry crowns
Title:  from them.  Oh!  If you were a duchess, a marchioness, or a
Title:  countess, it would be quite a different thing; it would be
Title:  unpardonable."
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife was piqued.
Title:  
Title:  "Please to know, Monsieur Porthos," said she, "that my strongbox,
Title:  the strongbox of a procurator's wife though it may be, is better
Title:  filled than those of your affected minxes."
Title:  
Title:  "The doubles the offense," said Porthos, disengaging his arm from
Title:  that of the procurator's wife; "for if you are rich, Madame
Title:  Coquenard, then there is no excuse for your refusal."
Title:  
Title:  "When I said rich," replied the procurator's wife, who saw that
Title:  she had gone too far, "you must not take the word literally.  I
Title:  am not precisely rich, though I am pretty well off."
Title:  
Title:  "Hold, madame," said Porthos, "let us say no more upon the
Title:  subject, I beg of you.  You have misunderstood me, all sympathy
Title:  is extinct between us."
Title:  
Title:  "Ingrate that you are!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!  I advise you to complain!" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Begone, then, to your beautiful duchess; I will detain you no
Title:  longer."
Title:  
Title:  "And she is not to be despised, in my opinion."
Title:  
Title:  "Now, Monsieur Porthos, once more, and this is the last!  Do you
Title:  love me still?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, madame," said Porthos, in the most melancholy tone he could
Title:  assume, "when we are about to enter upon a campaign--a campaign,
Title:  in which my presentiments tell me I shall be killed--"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, don't talk of such things!" cried the procurator's wife,
Title:  bursting into tears.
Title:  
Title:  "Something whispers me so," continued Porthos, becoming more and
Title:  more melancholy.
Title:  
Title:  "Rather say that you have a new love."
Title:  
Title:  "Not so; I speak frankly to you.  No object affects me; and I
Title:  even feel here, at the bottom of my heart, something which speaks
Title:  for you.  But in fifteen days, as you know, or as you do not
Title:  know, this fatal campaign is to open.  I shall be fearfully
Title:  preoccupied with my outfit.  Then I must make a journey to see my
Title:  family, in the lower part of Brittany, to obtain the sum
Title:  necessary for my departure."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos observed a last struggle between love and avarice.
Title:  
Title:  "And as," continued he, "the duchess whom you saw at the church
Title:  has estates near to those of my family, we mean to make the
Title:  journey together.  Journeys, you know, appear much shorter when
Title:  we travel two in company."
Title:  
Title:  "Have you no friends in Paris, then, Monsieur Porthos?" said the
Title:  procurator's wife.
Title:  
Title:  "I thought I had," said Porthos, resuming his melancholy air;
Title:  "but I have been taught my mistake."
Title:  
Title:  "You have some!" cried the procurator's wife, in a transport that
Title:  surprised even herself.  "Come to our house tomorrow.  You are
Title:  the son of my aunt, consequently my cousin; you come from Noyon,
Title:  in Picardy; you have several lawsuits and no attorney.  Can you
Title:  recollect all that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perfectly, madame."
Title:  
Title:  "Come at dinnertime."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well."
Title:  
Title:  "And be upon your guard before my husband, who is rather shrewd,
Title:  notwithstanding his seventy-six years."
Title:  
Title:  "Seventy-six years!  PESTE!  That's a fine age!" replied Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "A great age, you mean, Monsieur Porthos.  Yes, the poor man may
Title:  be expected to leave me a widow, any hour," continued she,
Title:  throwing a significant glance at Porthos.  "Fortunately, by our
Title:  marriage contract, the survivor takes everything."
Title:  
Title:  "All?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, all."
Title:  
Title:  "You are a woman of precaution, I see, my dear Madame Coquenard,"
Title:  said Porthos, squeezing the hand of the procurator's wife
Title:  tenderly.
Title:  
Title:  "We are then reconciled, dear Monsieur Porthos?" said she,
Title:  simpering.
Title:  
Title:  "For life," replied Porthos, in the same manner.
Title:  
Title:  "Till we meet again, then, dear traitor!"
Title:  
Title:  "Till we meet again, my forgetful charmer!"
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow, my angel!"
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow, flame of my life!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  30  D'ARTAGNAN AND THE ENGLISHMAN
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan followed Milady without being perceived by her.
Title:  He saw her get into her carriage, and heard her order the
Title:  coachman to drive to St. Germain.
Title:  
Title:  It was useless to try to keep pace on foot with a carriage
Title:  drawn by two powerful horses.  D'Artagnan therefore returned
Title:  to the Rue Ferou.
Title:  
Title:  In the Rue de Seine he met Planchet, who had stopped before
Title:  the house of a pastry cook, and was contemplating with
Title:  ecstasy a cake of the most appetizing appearance.
Title:  
Title:  He ordered him to go and saddle two horses in M. de
Title:  Treville's stables--one for himself, d'Artagnan, and one for
Title:  Planchet--and bring them to Athens's place.  Once for all,
Title:  Treville had placed his stable at d'Artagnan's service.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet proceeded toward the Rue du Colombier, and
Title:  d'Artagnan toward the Rue Ferou.  Athos was at home,
Title:  emptying sadly a bottle of the famous Spanish wine he had
Title:  brought back with him from his journey into Picardy.  He
Title:  made a sign for Grimaud to bring a glass for d'Artagnan, and
Title:  Grimaud obeyed as usual.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related to Athos all that had passed at the
Title:  church between Porthos and the procurator's wife, and how
Title:  their comrade was probably by that time in a fair way to be
Title:  equipped.
Title:  
Title:  "As for me," replied Athos to this recital, "I am quite at
Title:  my ease; it will not be women that will defray the expense
Title:  of my outfit."
Title:  
Title:  "Handsome, well-bred, noble lord as you are, my dear Athos,
Title:  neither princesses nor queens would be secure from your
Title:  amorous solicitations."
Title:  
Title:  "How young this d'Artagnan is!" said Athos, shrugging his
Title:  shoulders; and he made a sign to Grimaud to bring another
Title:  bottle.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment Planchet put his head modestly in at the
Title:  half-open door, and told his master that the horses were
Title:  ready.
Title:  
Title:  "What horses?" asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Two horses that Monsieur de Treville lends me at my
Title:  pleasure, and with which I am now going to take a ride to
Title:  St. Germain."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, and what are you going to do at St. Germain?" then
Title:  demanded Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan described the meeting which he had at the
Title:  church, and how he had found that lady who, with the
Title:  seigneur in the black cloak and with the scar near his
Title:  temple, filled his mind constantly.
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, you are in love with this lady as you were
Title:  with Madame Bonacieux," said Athos, shrugging his shoulders
Title:  contemptuously, as if he pitied human weakness.
Title:  
Title:  "I? not at all!" said d'Artagnan.  "I am only curious to
Title:  unravel the mystery to which she is attached.  I do not know
Title:  why, but I imagine that this woman, wholly unknown to me as
Title:  she is, and wholly unknown to her as I am, has an influence
Title:  over my life."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, perhaps you are right," said Athos.  "I do not know a
Title:  woman that is worth the trouble of being sought for when she
Title:  is once lost.  Madame Bonacieux is lost; so much the worse
Title:  for her if she is found."
Title:  
Title:  "No, Athos, no, you are mistaken," said d'Artagnan; "I love
Title:  my poor Constance more than ever, and if I knew the place in
Title:  which she is, were it at the end of the world, I would go to
Title:  free her from the hands of her enemies; but I am ignorant.
Title:  All my researches have been useless.  What is to be said?  I
Title:  must divert my attention!"
Title:  
Title:  "Amuse yourself with Milady, my dear d'Artagnan; I wish you
Title:  may with all my heart, if that will amuse you."
Title:  
Title:  "Hear me, Athos," said d'Artagnan.  "Instead of shutting
Title:  yourself up here as if you were under arrest, get on
Title:  horseback and come and take a ride with me to St. Germain."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear fellow," said Athos, "I ride horses when I have
Title:  any; when I have none, I go afoot."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said d'Artagnan, smiling at the misanthropy of
Title:  Athos, which from any other person would have offended him,
Title:  "I ride what I can get; I am not so proud as you.  So AU
Title:  REVOIR, dear Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "AU REVOIR," said the Musketeer, making a sign to Grimaud to
Title:  uncork the bottle he had just brought.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan and Planchet mounted, and took the road to St.
Title:  Germain.
Title:  
Title:  All along the road, what Athos had said respecting Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux recurred to the mind of the young man.  Although
Title:  d'Artagnan was not of a very sentimental character, the
Title:  mercer's pretty wife had made a real impression upon his
Title:  heart.  As he said, he was ready to go to the end of the
Title:  world to seek her; but the world, being round, has many
Title:  ends, so that he did not know which way to turn. Meantime,
Title:  he was going to try to find out Milady.  Milady had spoken
Title:  to the man in the black cloak; therefore she knew him. Now,
Title:  in the opinion of d'Artagnan, it was certainly the man in
Title:  the black cloak who had carried off Mme. Bonacieux the
Title:  second time, as he had carried her off the first.
Title:  d'Artagnan then only half-lied, which is lying but little,
Title:  when he said that by going in search of Milady he at the
Title:  same time went in search of Constance.
Title:  
Title:  Thinking of all this, and from time to time giving a touch
Title:  of the spur to his horse, d'Artagnan completed his short
Title:  journey, and arrived at St. Germain.  He had just passed by
Title:  the pavilion in which ten years later Louis XIV was born.
Title:  He rode up a very quiet street, looking to the right and the
Title:  left to see if he could catch any vestige of his beautiful
Title:  Englishwoman, when from the ground floor of a pretty house,
Title:  which, according to the fashion of the time, had no window
Title:  toward the street, he saw a face peep out with which he
Title:  thought he was acquainted.  This person walked along the
Title:  terrace, which was ornamented with flowers.  Planchet
Title:  recognized him first.
Title:  
Title:  "Eh, monsieur!" said he, addressing d'Artagnan, "don't you
Title:  remember that face which is blinking yonder?"
Title:  
Title:  "No," said d'Artagnan, "and yet I am certain it is not the
Title:  first time I have seen that visage."
Title:  
Title:  "PARBLEU, I believe it is not," said Planchet.  "Why, it is
Title:  poor Lubin, the lackey of the Comte de Wardes--he whom you
Title:  took such good care of a month ago at Calais, on the road to
Title:  the governor's country house!"
Title:  
Title:  "So it is!" said d'Artagnan; "I know him now.  Do you think
Title:  he would recollect you?"
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, monsieur, he was in such trouble that I doubt if
Title:  he can have retained a very clear recollection of me."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, go and talk with the boy," said d'Artagnan, "and make
Title:  out if you can from his conversation whether his master is
Title:  dead."
Title:  
Title:  Planchet dismounted and went straight up to Lubin, who did
Title:  not at all remember him, and the two lackeys began to chat
Title:  with the best understanding possible; while d'Artagnan
Title:  turned the two horses into a lane, went round the house, and
Title:  came back to watch the conference from behind a hedge of
Title:  filberts.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of an instant's observation he heard the noise of
Title:  a vehicle, and saw Milady's carriage stop opposite to him.
Title:  He could not be mistaken; Milady was in it.  D'Artagnan
Title:  leaned upon the neck of his horse, in order that he might
Title:  see without being seen.
Title:  
Title:  Milady put her charming blond head out at the window, and
Title:  gave her orders to her maid.
Title:  
Title:  The latter--a pretty girl of about twenty or twenty-two
Title:  years, active and lively, the true SOUBRETTE of a great
Title:  lady--jumped from the step upon which, according to the
Title:  custom of the time, she was seated, and took her way toward
Title:  the terrace upon which d'Artagnan had perceived Lubin.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan followed the soubrette with his eyes, and saw her
Title:  go toward the terrace; but it happened that someone in the
Title:  house called Lubin, so that Planchet remained alone, looking
Title:  in all directions for the road where d'Artagnan had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  The maid approached Planchet, whom she took for Lubin, and
Title:  holding out a little billet to him said, "For your master."
Title:  
Title:  "For my master?" replied Planchet, astonished.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, and important.  Take it quickly."
Title:  
Title:  Thereupon she ran toward the carriage, which had turned
Title:  round toward the way it came, jumped upon the step, and the
Title:  carriage drove off.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet turned and returned the billet.  Then, accustomed
Title:  to passive obedience, he jumped down from the terrace, ran
Title:  toward the lane, and at the end of twenty paces met
Title:  d'Artagnan, who, having seen all, was coming to him.
Title:  
Title:  "For you, monsieur," said Planchet, presenting the billet to
Title:  the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "For me?" said d'Artagnan; "are you sure of that?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARDIEU, monsieur, I can't be more sure.  The SOUBRETTE said,
Title:  'For your master.' I have no other master but you; so--
Title:  a pretty little lass, my faith, is that SOUBRETTE!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan opened the letter, and read these words:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "A person who takes more interest in you than she is willing
Title:  to confess wishes to know on what day it will suit you to
Title:  walk in the forest?  Tomorrow, at the Hotel Field of the
Title:  Cloth of Gold, a lackey in black and red will wait for your
Title:  reply."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Oh!" said d'Artagnan, "this is rather warm; it appears that
Title:  Milady and I are anxious about the health of the same
Title:  person. Well, Planchet, how is the good Monsieur de Wardes?
Title:  He is not dead, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monsieur, he is as well as a man can be with four sword
Title:  wounds in his body; for you, without question, inflicted
Title:  four upon the dear gentleman, and he is still very weak,
Title:  having lost almost all his blood.  As I said, monsieur,
Title:  Lubin did not know me, and told me our adventure from one
Title:  end to the other."
Title:  
Title:  "Well done, Planchet! you are the king of lackeys.  Now jump
Title:  onto your horse, and let us overtake the carriage."
Title:  
Title:  This did not take long.  At the end of five minutes they
Title:  perceived the carriage drawn up by the roadside; a cavalier,
Title:  richly dressed, was close to the door.
Title:  
Title:  The conversation between Milady and the cavalier was so
Title:  animated that d'Artagnan stopped on the other side of the
Title:  carriage without anyone but the pretty SOUBRETTE perceiving
Title:  his presence.
Title:  
Title:  The conversation took place in English--a language which
Title:  d'Artagnan could not understand; but by the accent the young
Title:  man plainly saw that the beautiful Englishwoman was in a
Title:  great rage.  She terminated it by an action which left no
Title:  doubt as to the nature of this conversation; this was a blow
Title:  with her fan, applied with such force that the little
Title:  feminine weapon flew into a thousand pieces.
Title:  
Title:  The cavalier laughed aloud, which appeared to exasperate
Title:  Milady still more.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan thought this was the moment to interfere.  He
Title:  approached the other door, and taking off his hat
Title:  respectfully, said, "Madame, will you permit me to offer you
Title:  my services?  It appears to me that this cavalier has made
Title:  you very angry.  Speak one word, madame, and I take upon
Title:  myself to punish him for his want of courtesy."
Title:  
Title:  At the first word Milady turned, looking at the young man
Title:  with astonishment; and when he had finished, she said in
Title:  very good French, "Monsieur, I should with great confidence
Title:  place myself under your protection if the person with whom I
Title:  quarrel were not my brother."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, excuse me, then," said d'Artagnan.  "You must be aware
Title:  that I was ignorant of that, madame."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that stupid fellow troubling himself about?" cried
Title:  the cavalier whom Milady had designated as her brother,
Title:  stooping down to the height of the coach window.  "Why does
Title:  not he go about his business?"
Title:  
Title:  "Stupid fellow yourself!" said d'Artagnan, stooping in his
Title:  turn on the neck of his horse, and answering on his side
Title:  through the carriage window.  "I do not go on because it
Title:  pleases me to stop here."
Title:  
Title:  The cavalier addressed some words in English to his sister.
Title:  
Title:  "I speak to you in French," said d'Artagnan; "be kind
Title:  enough, then, to reply to me in the same language.  You are
Title:  Madame's brother, I learn--be it so; but fortunately you are
Title:  not mine."
Title:  
Title:  It might be thought that Milady, timid as women are in
Title:  general, would have interposed in this commencement of
Title:  mutual provocations in order to prevent the quarrel from
Title:  going too far; but on the contrary, she threw herself back
Title:  in her carriage, and called out coolly to the coachman,
Title:  "Go on--home!"
Title:  
Title:  The pretty SOUBRETTE cast an anxious glance at d'Artagnan,
Title:  whose good looks seemed to have made an impression on her.
Title:  
Title:  The carriage went on, and left the two men facing each
Title:  other; no material obstacle separated them.
Title:  
Title:  The cavalier made a movement as if to follow the carriage;
Title:  but d'Artagnan, whose anger, already excited, was much
Title:  increased by recognizing in him the Englishman of Amiens who
Title:  had won his horse and had been very near winning his diamond
Title:  of Athos, caught at his bridle and stopped him.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monsieur," said he, "you appear to be more stupid
Title:  than I am, for you forget there is a little quarrel to
Title:  arrange between us two."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said the Englishman, "is it you, my master?  It seems
Title:  you must always be playing some game or other."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; and that reminds me that I have a revenge to take.  We
Title:  will see, my dear monsieur, if you can handle a sword as
Title:  skillfully as you can a dice box."
Title:  
Title:  "You see plainly that I have no sword," said the Englishman.
Title:  "Do you wish to play the braggart with an unarmed man?"
Title:  
Title:  "I hope you have a sword at home; but at all events, I have
Title:  two, and if you like, I will throw with you for one of
Title:  them."
Title:  
Title:  "Needless," said the Englishman; "I am well furnished with
Title:  such playthings."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well, my worthy gentleman," replied d'Artagnan, "pick
Title:  out the longest, and come and show it to me this evening."
Title:  
Title:  "Where, if you please?"
Title:  
Title:  "Behind the Luxembourg; that's a charming spot for such
Title:  amusements as the one I propose to you."
Title:  
Title:  "That will do; I will be there."
Title:  
Title:  "Your hour?"
Title:  
Title:  "Six o'clock."
Title:  
Title:  "A PROPOS, you have probably one or two friends?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have three, who would be honored by joining in the sport
Title:  with me."
Title:  
Title:  "Three?  Marvelous!  That falls out oddly! Three is just my
Title:  number!"
Title:  
Title:  "Now, then, who are you?" asked the Englishman.
Title:  
Title:  "I am Monsieur d'Artagnan, a Gascon gentleman, serving in
Title:  the king's Musketeers.  And you?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am Lord de Winter, Baron Sheffield."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, I am your servant, Monsieur Baron," said
Title:  d'Artagnan, "though you have names rather difficult to
Title:  recollect."  And touching his horse with the spur, he
Title:  cantered back to Paris.  As he was accustomed to do in all
Title:  cases of any consequence, d'Artagnan went straight to the
Title:  residence of Athos.
Title:  
Title:  He found Athos reclining upon a large sofa, where he was
Title:  waiting, as he said, for his outfit to come and find him.
Title:  He related to Athos all that had passed, except the letter
Title:  to M. de Wardes.
Title:  
Title:  Athos was delighted to find he was going to fight an
Title:  Englishman. We might say that was his dream.
Title:  
Title:  They immediately sent their lackeys for Porthos and Aramis,
Title:  and on their arrival made them acquainted with the
Title:  situation.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos drew his sword from the scabbard, and made passes at
Title:  the wall, springing back from time to time, and making
Title:  contortions like a dancer.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, who was constantly at work at his poem, shut himself
Title:  up in Athos's closet, and begged not to be disturbed before
Title:  the moment of drawing swords.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, by signs, desired Grimaud to bring another bottle of
Title:  wine.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan employed himself in arranging a little plan, of
Title:  which we shall hereafter see the execution, and which
Title:  promised him some agreeable adventure, as might be seen by
Title:  the smiles which from time to time passed over his
Title:  countenance, whose thoughtfulness they animated.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  31  ENGLISH AND FRENCH
Title:  
Title:  The hour having come, they went with their four lackeys to a
Title:  spot behind the Luxembourg given up to the feeding of goats.
Title:  Athos threw a piece of money to the goatkeeper to withdraw.
Title:  The lackeys were ordered to act as sentinels.
Title:  
Title:  A silent party soon drew near to the same enclosure,
Title:  entered, and joined the Musketeers.  Then, according to
Title:  foreign custom, the presentations took place.
Title:  
Title:  The Englishmen were all men of rank; consequently the odd
Title:  names of their adversaries were for them not only a matter
Title:  of surprise, but of annoyance.
Title:  
Title:  "But after all," said Lord de Winter, when the three friends
Title:  had been named, "we do not know who you are.  We cannot
Title:  fight with such names; they are names of shepherds."
Title:  
Title:  "Therefore your lordship may suppose they are only assumed
Title:  names," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Which only gives us a greater desire to know the real
Title:  ones," replied the Englishman.
Title:  
Title:  "You played very willingly with us without knowing our
Title:  names," said Athos, "by the same token that you won our
Title:  horses."
Title:  
Title:  "That is true, but we then only risked our pistoles; this
Title:  time we risk our blood.  One plays with anybody; but one
Title:  fights only with equals."
Title:  
Title:  "And that is but just," said Athos, and he took aside the
Title:  one of the four Englishmen with whom he was to fight, and
Title:  communicated his name in a low voice.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis did the same.
Title:  
Title:  "Does that satisfy you?" said Athos to his adversary.  "Do
Title:  you find me of sufficient rank to do me the honor of
Title:  crossing swords with me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," said the Englishman, bowing.
Title:  
Title:  "Well! now shall I tell you something?" added Athos, coolly.
Title:  
Title:  "What?" replied the Englishman.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, that is that you would have acted much more wisely if
Title:  you had not required me to make myself known."
Title:  
Title:  "Why so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because I am believed to be dead, and have reasons for
Title:  wishing nobody to know I am living; so that I shall be
Title:  obliged to kill you to prevent my secret from roaming over
Title:  the fields."
Title:  
Title:  The Englishman looked at Athos, believing that he jested,
Title:  but Athos did not jest the least in the world.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Athos, addressing at the same time his
Title:  companions and their adversaries, "are we ready?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes!" answered the Englishmen and the Frenchmen, as with
Title:  one voice.
Title:  
Title:  "On guard, then!" cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Immediately eight swords glittered in the rays of the
Title:  setting sun, and the combat began with an animosity very
Title:  natural between men twice enemies.
Title:  
Title:  Athos fenced with as much calmness and method as if he had
Title:  been practicing in a fencing school.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, abated, no doubt, of his too-great confidence by
Title:  his adventure of Chantilly, played with skill and prudence.
Title:  Aramis, who had the third canto of his poem to finish,
Title:  behaved like a man in haste.
Title:  
Title:  Athos killed his adversary first.  He hit him but once, but
Title:  as he had foretold, that hit was a mortal one; the sword
Title:  pierced his heart.
Title:  
Title:  Second, Porthos stretched his upon the grass with a wound
Title:  through his thigh, As the Englishman, without making any
Title:  further resistance, then surrendered his sword, Porthos took
Title:  him up in his arms and bore him to his carriage.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis pushed his so vigorously that after going back fifty
Title:  paces, the man ended by fairly taking to his heels, and
Title:  disappeared amid the hooting of the lackeys.
Title:  
Title:  As to d'Artagnan, he fought purely and simply on the
Title:  defensive; and when he saw his adversary pretty well
Title:  fatigued, with a vigorous side thrust sent his sword flying.
Title:  The baron, finding himself disarmed, took two or three steps
Title:  back, but in this movement his foot slipped and he fell
Title:  backward.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was over him at a bound, and said to the
Title:  Englishman, pointing his sword to his throat, "I could kill
