Title:  you, my Lord, you are completely in my hands; but I spare
Title:  your life for the sake of your sister."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was at the height of joy; he had realized the
Title:  plan he had imagined beforehand, whose picturing had
Title:  produced the smiles we noted upon his face.
Title:  
Title:  The Englishman, delighted at having to do with a gentleman
Title:  of such a kind disposition, pressed d'Artagnan in his arms,
Title:  and paid a thousand compliments to the three Musketeers, and
Title:  as Porthos's adversary was already installed in the
Title:  carriage, and as Aramis's had taken to his heels, they had
Title:  nothing to think about but the dead.
Title:  
Title:  As Porthos and Aramis were undressing him, in the hope of
Title:  finding his wound not mortal, a large purse dropped from his
Title:  clothes.  D'Artagnan picked it up and offered it to Lord de
Title:  Winter.
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil would you have me do with that?" said the
Title:  Englishman.
Title:  
Title:  "You can restore it to his family," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "His family will care much about such a trifle as that!  His
Title:  family will inherit fifteen thousand louis a year from him.
Title:  Keep the purse for your lackeys."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan put the purse into his pocket.
Title:  
Title:  "And now, my young friend, for you will permit me, I hope,
Title:  to give you that name," said Lord de Winter, "on this very
Title:  evening, if agreeable to you, I will present you to my
Title:  sister, Milady Clarik, for I am desirous that she should
Title:  take you into her good graces; and as she is not in bad odor
Title:  at court, she may perhaps on some future day speak a word
Title:  that will not prove useless to you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan blushed with pleasure, and bowed a sign of
Title:  assent.
Title:  
Title:  At this time Athos came up to d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean to do with that purse?" whispered he.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, I meant to pass it over to you, my dear Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "Me! why to me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, you killed him!  They are the spoils of victory."
Title:  
Title:  "I, the heir of an enemy!" said Athos; "for whom, then, do
Title:  you take me?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is the custom in war," said d'Artagnan, "why should it
Title:  not be the custom in a duel?"
Title:  
Title:  "Even on the field of battle, I have never done that."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos shrugged his shoulders; Aramis by a movement of his
Title:  lips endorsed Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said d'Artagnan, "let us give the money to the
Title:  lackeys, as Lord de Winter desired us to do."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Athos; "let us give the money to the lackeys--not
Title:  to our lackeys, but to the lackeys of the Englishmen."
Title:  
Title:  Athos took the purse, and threw it into the hand of the
Title:  coachman.  "For you and your comrades."
Title:  
Title:  This greatness of spirit in a man who was quite destitute
Title:  struck even Porthos; and this French generosity, repeated by
Title:  Lord de Winter and his friend, was highly applauded, except
Title:  by MM. Grimaud, Bazin, Mousqueton and Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter, on quitting d'Artagnan, gave him his
Title:  sister's address.  She lived in the Place Royale--then the
Title:  fashionable quarter--at Number 6, and he undertook to call
Title:  and take d'Artagnan with him in order to introduce him.
Title:  d'Artagnan appointed eight o'clock at Athos's residence.
Title:  
Title:  This introduction to Milady Clarik occupied the head of our
Title:  Gascon greatly.  He remembered in what a strange manner this
Title:  woman had hitherto been mixed up in his destiny.  According
Title:  to his conviction, she was some creature of the cardinal,
Title:  and yet he felt himself invincibly drawn toward her by one
Title:  of those sentiments for which we cannot account.  His only
Title:  fear was that Milady would recognize in him the man of Meung
Title:  and of Dover.  Then she knew that he was one of the friends
Title:  of M. de Treville, and consequently, that he belonged body
Title:  and soul to the king; which would make him lose a part of
Title:  his advantage, since when known to Milady as he knew her, he
Title:  played only an equal game with her.  As to the commencement
Title:  of an intrigue between her and M.  de Wardes, our
Title:  presumptuous hero gave but little heed to that, although the
Title:  marquis was young, handsome, rich, and high in the
Title:  cardinal's favor.  It is not for nothing we are but twenty years old,
Title:  above all if we were born at Tarbes.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan began by making his most splendid toilet, then
Title:  returned to Athos's, and according to custom, related
Title:  everything to him.  Athos listened to his projects, then
Title:  shook his head, and recommended prudence to him with a shade
Title:  of bitterness.
Title:  
Title:  "What!" said he, "you have just lost one woman, whom you
Title:  call good, charming, perfect; and here you are, running
Title:  headlong after another."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan felt the truth of this reproach.
Title:  
Title:  "I loved Madame Bonacieux with my heart, while I only love
Title:  Milady with my head," said he.  "In getting introduced to
Title:  her, my principal object is to ascertain what part she plays
Title:  at court."
Title:  
Title:  "The part she plays, PARDIEU!  It is not difficult to divine
Title:  that, after all you have told me.  She is some emissary of
Title:  the cardinal; a woman who will draw you into a snare in
Title:  which you will leave your head."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil! my dear Athos, you view things on the dark side,
Title:  methinks."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear fellow, I mistrust women.  Can it be otherwise?  I
Title:  bought my experience dearly--particularly fair women.  Milady
Title:  is fair, you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "She has the most beautiful light hair imaginable!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my poor d'Artagnan!" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen to me! I want to be enlightened on a subject; then,
Title:  when I shall have learned what I desire to know, I will
Title:  withdraw."
Title:  
Title:  "Be enlightened!" said Athos, phlegmatically.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter arrived at the appointed time; but Athos,
Title:  being warned of his coming, went into the other chamber.  He
Title:  therefore found d'Artagnan alone, and as it was nearly eight
Title:  o'clock he took the young man with him.
Title:  
Title:  An elegant carriage waited below, and as it was drawn by two
Title:  excellent horses, they were soon at the Place Royale.
Title:  
Title:  Milady Clarik received d'Artagnan ceremoniously.  Her hotel
Title:  was remarkably sumptuous, and while the most part of the
Title:  English had quit, or were about to quit, France on account
Title:  of the war, Milady had just been laying out much money upon
Title:  her residence; which proved that the general measure which
Title:  drove the English from France did not affect her.
Title:  
Title:  "You see," said Lord de Winter, presenting d'Artagnan to his
Title:  sister, "a young gentleman who has held my life in his
Title:  hands, and who has not abused his advantage, although we
Title:  have been twice enemies, although it was I who insulted him,
Title:  and although I am an Englishman.  Thank him, then, madame,
Title:  if you have any affection for me."
Title:  
Title:  Milady frowned slightly; a scarcely visible cloud passed
Title:  over her brow, and so peculiar a smile appeared upon her
Title:  lips that the young man, who saw and observed this triple
Title:  shade, almost shuddered at it.
Title:  
Title:  The brother did not perceive this; he had turned round to
Title:  play with Milady's favorite monkey, which had pulled him by
Title:  the doublet.
Title:  
Title:  "You are welcome, monsieur," said Milady, in a voice whose
Title:  singular sweetness contrasted with the symptoms of ill-humor
Title:  which d'Artagnan had just remarked; "you have today acquired
Title:  eternal rights to my gratitude."
Title:  
Title:  The Englishman then turned round and described the combat
Title:  without omitting a single detail.  Milady listened with the
Title:  greatest attention, and yet it was easily to be perceived,
Title:  whatever effort she made to conceal her impressions, that
Title:  this recital was not agreeable to her.  The blood rose to
Title:  her head, and her little foot worked with impatience beneath
Title:  her robe.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter perceived nothing of this.  When he had
Title:  finished, he went to a table upon which was a salver with
Title:  Spanish wine and glasses.  He filled two glasses, and by a
Title:  sign invited d'Artagnan to drink.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan knew it was considered disobliging by an
Title:  Englishman to refuse to pledge him.  He therefore drew near
Title:  to the table and took the second glass.  He did not,
Title:  however, lose sight of Milady, and in a mirror he perceived
Title:  the change that came over her face. Now that she believed
Title:  herself to be no longer observed, a sentiment resembling
Title:  ferocity animated her countenance.  She bit her handkerchief
Title:  with her beautiful teeth.
Title:  
Title:  That pretty little SOUBRETTE whom d'Artagnan had already
Title:  observed then came in.  She spoke some words to Lord de
Title:  Winter in English, who thereupon requested d'Artagnan's
Title:  permission to retire, excusing himself on account of the
Title:  urgency of the business that had called him away, and
Title:  charging his sister to obtain his pardon.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan exchanged a shake of the hand with Lord de
Title:  Winter, and then returned to Milady.  Her countenance, with
Title:  surprising mobility, had recovered its gracious expression;
Title:  but some little red spots on her handkerchief indicated that
Title:  she had bitten her lips till the blood came.  Those lips
Title:  were magnificent; they might be said to be of coral.
Title:  
Title:  The conversation took a cheerful turn.  Milady appeared to
Title:  have entirely recovered.  She told d'Artagnan that Lord de
Title:  Winter was her brother-in-law, and not her brother.  She had
Title:  married a younger brother of the family, who had left her a
Title:  widow with one child.  This child was the only heir to Lord
Title:  de Winter, if Lord de Winter did not marry.  All this showed
Title:  d'Artagnan that there was a veil which concealed something;
Title:  but he could not yet see under this veil.
Title:  
Title:  In addition to this, after a half hour's conversation
Title:  d'Artagnan was convinced that Milady was his compatriot; she
Title:  spoke French with an elegance and a purity that left no
Title:  doubt on that head.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was profuse in gallant speeches and protestations
Title:  of devotion.  To all the simple things which escaped our
Title:  Gascon, Milady replied with a smile of kindness.  The hour
Title:  came for him to retire.  D'Artagnan took leave of Milady,
Title:  and left the saloon the happiest of men.
Title:  
Title:  On the staircase he met the pretty SOUBRETTE, who brushed
Title:  gently against him as she passed, and then, blushing to the
Title:  eyes, asked his pardon for having touched him in a voice so
Title:  sweet that the pardon was granted instantly.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan came again on the morrow, and was still better
Title:  received than on the evening before.  Lord de Winter was not
Title:  at home; and it was Milady who this time did all the honors
Title:  of the evening.  She appeared to take a great interest in
Title:  him, asked him whence he came, who were his friends, and
Title:  whether he had not sometimes thought of attaching himself to
Title:  the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who, as we have said, was exceedingly prudent
Title:  for a young man of twenty, then remembered his suspicions
Title:  regarding Milady.  He launched into a eulogy of his
Title:  Eminence, and said that he should not have failed to enter
Title:  into the Guards of the cardinal instead of the king's Guards
Title:  if he had happened to know M. de Cavois instead of M. de
Title:  Treville.
Title:  
Title:  Milady changed the conversation without any appearance of
Title:  affectation, and asked d'Artagnan in the most careless
Title:  manner possible if he had ever been in England.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan replied that he had been sent thither by M. de
Title:  Treville to treat for a supply of horses, and that he had
Title:  brought back four as specimens.
Title:  
Title:  Milady in the course of the conversation twice or thrice bit
Title:  her lips; she had to deal with a Gascon who played close.
Title:  
Title:  At the same hour as on the preceding evening, d'Artagnan
Title:  retired. In the corridor he again met the pretty Kitty; that
Title:  was the name of the SOUBRETTE.  She looked at him with an
Title:  expression of kindness which it was impossible to mistake;
Title:  but d'Artagnan was so preoccupied by the mistress that he
Title:  noticed absolutely nothing but her.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan came again on the morrow and the day after that,
Title:  and each day Milady gave him a more gracious reception.
Title:  
Title:  Every evening, either in the antechamber, the corridor, or
Title:  on the stairs, he met the pretty SOUBRETTE.  But, as we have
Title:  said, d'Artagnan paid no attention to this persistence of
Title:  poor Kitty.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  32  A PROCURATOR'S DINNER
Title:  
Title:  However brilliant had been the part played by Porthos in the
Title:  duel, it had not made him forget the dinner of the
Title:  procurator's wife.
Title:  
Title:  On the morrow he received the last touches of Mousqueton's
Title:  brush for an hour, and took his way toward the Rue aux Ours
Title:  with the steps of a man who was doubly in favor with
Title:  fortune.
Title:  
Title:  His heart beat, but not like d'Artagnan's with a young and
Title:  impatient love.  No; a more material interest stirred his
Title:  blood.  He was about at last to pass that mysterious
Title:  threshold, to climb those unknown stairs by which, one by
Title:  one, the old crowns of M. Coquenard had ascended.  He was
Title:  about to see in reality a certain coffer of which he had
Title:  twenty times beheld the image in his dreams--a coffer long
Title:  and deep, locked, bolted, fastened in the wall; a coffer of
Title:  which he had so often heard, and which the hands--a little
Title:  wrinkled, it is true, but still not without elegance--of the
Title:  procurator's wife were about to open to his admiring looks.
Title:  
Title:  And then he--a wanderer on the earth, a man without fortune,
Title:  a man without family, a soldier accustomed to inns,
Title:  cabarets, taverns, and restaurants, a lover of wine forced
Title:  to depend upon chance treats--was about to partake of
Title:  family meals, to enjoy the pleasures of a comfortable
Title:  establishment, and to give himself up to those little
Title:  attentions which "the harder one is, the more they please,"
Title:  as old soldiers say.
Title:  
Title:  To come in the capacity of a cousin, and seat himself every
Title:  day at a good table; to smooth the yellow, wrinkled brow of
Title:  the old procurator; to pluck the clerks a little by teaching
Title:  them BASSETTE, PASSE-DIX, and LANSQUENET, in their utmost
Title:  nicety, and winning from them, by way of fee for the lesson
Title:  he would give them in an hour, their savings of a month--all
Title:  this was enormously delightful to Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  The Musketeer could not forget the evil reports which then
Title:  prevailed, and which indeed have survived them, of the
Title:  procurators of the period--meanness, stinginess, fasts; but
Title:  as, after all, excepting some few acts of economy which
Title:  Porthos had always found very unseasonable, the procurator's
Title:  wife had been tolerably liberal--that is, be it understood,
Title:  for a procurator's wife--he hoped to see a household of a
Title:  highly comfortable kind.
Title:  
Title:  And yet, at the very door the Musketeer began to entertain
Title:  some doubts.  The approach was not such as to prepossess
Title:  people--an ill-smelling, dark passage, a staircase half-
Title:  lighted by bars through which stole a glimmer from a
Title:  neighboring yard; on the first floor a low door studded with
Title:  enormous nails, like the principal gate of the Grand
Title:  Chatelet.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos knocked with his hand.  A tall, pale clerk, his face
Title:  shaded by a forest of virgin hair, opened the door, and
Title:  bowed with the air of a man forced at once to respect in
Title:  another lofty stature, which indicated strength, the
Title:  military dress, which indicated rank, and a ruddy
Title:  countenance, which indicated familiarity with good living.
Title:  
Title:  A shorter clerk came behind the first, a taller clerk behind
Title:  the second, a stripling of a dozen years rising behind the
Title:  third.  In all, three clerks and a half, which, for the
Title:  time, argued a very extensive clientage.
Title:  
Title:  Although the Musketeer was not expected before one o'clock,
Title:  the procurator's wife had been on the watch ever since
Title:  midday, reckoning that the heart, or perhaps the stomach, of
Title:  her lover would bring him before his time.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Coquenard therefore entered the office from the house
Title:  at the same moment her guest entered from the stairs, and
Title:  the appearance of the worthy lady relieved him from an
Title:  awkward embarrassment.  The clerks surveyed him with great
Title:  curiosity, and he, not knowing well what to say to this
Title:  ascending and descending scale, remained tongue-tied.
Title:  
Title:  "It is my cousin!" cried the procurator's wife.  "Come in,
Title:  come in, Monsieur Porthos!"
Title:  
Title:  The name of Porthos produced its effect upon the clerks, who
Title:  began to laugh; but Porthos turned sharply round, and every
Title:  countenance quickly recovered its gravity.
Title:  
Title:  They reached the office of the procurator after having
Title:  passed through the antechamber in which the clerks were, and
Title:  the study in which they ought to have been.  This last
Title:  apartment was a sort of dark room, littered with papers.  On
Title:  quitting the study they left the kitchen on the right, and
Title:  entered the reception room.
Title:  
Title:  All these rooms, which communicated with one another, did
Title:  not inspire Porthos favorably.  Words might be heard at a
Title:  distance through all these open doors.  Then, while passing,
Title:  he had cast a rapid, investigating glance into the kitchen;
Title:  and he was obliged to confess to himself, to the shame of
Title:  the procurator's wife and his own regret, that he did not
Title:  see that fire, that animation, that bustle, which when a
Title:  good repast is on foot prevails generally in that sanctuary
Title:  of good living.
Title:  
Title:  The procurator had without doubt been warned of his visit,
Title:  as he expressed no surprise at the sight of Porthos, who
Title:  advanced toward him with a sufficiently easy air, and
Title:  saluted him courteously.
Title:  
Title:  "We are cousins, it appears, Monsieur Porthos?" said the
Title:  procurator, rising, yet supporting his weight upon the arms
Title:  of his cane chair.
Title:  
Title:  The old man, wrapped in a large black doublet, in which the
Title:  whole of his slender body was concealed, was brisk and dry.
Title:  His little gray eyes shone like carbuncles, and appeared,
Title:  with his grinning mouth, to be the only part of his face in
Title:  which life survived.  Unfortunately the legs began to refuse
Title:  their service to this bony machine.  During the last five or
Title:  six months that this weakness had been felt, the worthy
Title:  procurator had nearly become the slave of his wife.
Title:  
Title:  The cousin was received with resignation, that was all.  M.
Title:  Coquenard, firm upon his legs, would have declined all
Title:  relationship with M. Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur, we are cousins," said Porthos, without being
Title:  disconcerted, as he had never reckoned upon being received
Title:  enthusiastically by the husband.
Title:  
Title:  "By the female side, I believe?" said the procurator,
Title:  maliciously.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos did not feel the ridicule of this, and took it for a
Title:  piece of simplicity, at which he laughed in his large
Title:  mustache.  Mme. Coquenard, who knew that a simple-minded
Title:  procurator was a very rare variety in the species, smiled a
Title:  little, and colored a great deal.
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard had, since the arrival of Porthos, frequently
Title:  cast his eyes with great uneasiness upon a large chest
Title:  placed in front of his oak desk.  Porthos comprehended that
Title:  this chest, although it did not correspond in shape with
Title:  that which he had seen in his dreams, must be the blessed
Title:  coffer, and he congratulated himself that the reality was
Title:  several feet higher than the dream.
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard did not carry his genealogical investigations
Title:  any further; but withdrawing his anxious look from the chest
Title:  and fixing it upon Porthos, he contented himself with saying,
Title:  "Monsieur our cousin will do us the favor of dining with us
Title:  once before his departure for the campaign, will he not,
Title:  Madame Coquenard?"
Title:  
Title:  This time Porthos received the blow right in his stomach,
Title:  and felt it.  It appeared likewise that Mme. Coquenard was
Title:  not less affected by it on her part, for she added, "My
Title:  cousin will not return if he finds that we do not treat him
Title:  kindly; but otherwise he has so little time to pass in Paris,
Title:  and consequently to spare to us, that we must entreat him to
Title:  give us every instant he can call his own previous to his
Title:  departure."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my legs, my poor legs! where are you?" murmured
Title:  Coquenard, and he tried to smile.
Title:  
Title:  This succor, which came to Porthos at the moment in which he
Title:  was attacked in his gastronomic hopes, inspired much
Title:  gratitude in the Musketeer toward the procurator's wife.
Title:  
Title:  The hour of dinner soon arrived.  They passed into the eating
Title:  room--a large dark room situated opposite the kitchen.
Title:  
Title:  The clerks, who, as it appeared, had smelled unusual perfumes
Title:  in the house, were of military punctuality, and held their
Title:  stools in hand quite ready to sit down.  Their jaws moved
Title:  preliminarily with fearful threatenings.
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!" thought Porthos, casting a glance at the three hungry
Title:  clerks--for the errand boy, as might be expected, was not
Title:  admitted to the honors of the magisterial table, "in my
Title:  cousin's place, I would not keep such gourmands!  They look
Title:  like shipwrecked sailors who have not eaten for six weeks."
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard entered, pushed along upon his armchair with
Title:  casters by Mme. Coquenard, whom Porthos assisted in rolling
Title:  her husband up to the table.  He had scarcely entered when
Title:  he began to agitate his nose and his jaws after the example
Title:  of his clerks.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, oh!" said he; "here is a soup which is rather
Title:  inviting."
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil can they smell so extraordinary in this
Title:  soup?" said Porthos, at the sight of a pale liquid, abundant
Title:  but entirely free from meat, on the surface of which a few
Title:  crusts swam about as rare as the islands of an archipelago.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Coquenard smiled, and upon a sign from her everyone
Title:  eagerly took his seat.
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard was served first, then Porthos.  Afterward Mme.
Title:  Coquenard filled her own plate, and distributed the crusts
Title:  without soup to the impatient clerks.  At this moment the
Title:  door of the dining room unclosed with a creak, and Porthos
Title:  perceived through the half-open flap the little clerk who,
Title:  not being allowed to take part in the feast, ate his dry
Title:  bread in the passage with the double odor of the dining room
Title:  and kitchen.
Title:  
Title:  After the soup the maid brought a boiled fowl--a piece of
Title:  magnificence which caused the eyes of the diners to dilate
Title:  in such a manner that they seemed ready to burst.
Title:  
Title:  "One may see that you love your family, Madame Coquenard,"
Title:  said the procurator, with a smile that was almost tragic.
Title:  "You are certainly treating your cousin very handsomely!"
Title:  
Title:  The poor fowl was thin, and covered with one of those thick,
Title:  bristly skins through which the teeth cannot penetrate with
Title:  all their efforts.  The fowl must have been sought for a
Title:  long time on the perch, to which it had retired to die of
Title:  old age.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" thought Porthos, "this is poor work.  I respect
Title:  old age, but I don't much like it boiled or roasted."
Title:  
Title:  And he looked round to see if anybody partook of his
Title:  opinion; but on the contrary, he saw nothing but eager eyes
Title:  which were devouring, in anticipation, that sublime fowl
Title:  which was the object of his contempt.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Coquenard drew the dish toward her, skillfully detached
Title:  the two great black feet, which she placed upon her
Title:  husband's plate, cut off the neck, which with the head she
Title:  put on one side for herself, raised the wing for Porthos,
Title:  and then returned the bird otherwise intact to the servant
Title:  who had brought it in, who disappeared with it before the
Title:  Musketeer had time to examine the variations which
Title:  disappointment produces upon faces, according to the
Title:  characters and temperaments of those who experience it.
Title:  
Title:  In the place of the fowl a dish of haricot beans made its
Title:  appearance--an enormous dish in which some bones of mutton
Title:  that at first sight one might have believed to have some
Title:  meat on them pretended to show themselves.
Title:  
Title:  But the clerks were not the dupes of this deceit, and their
Title:  lugubrious looks settled down into resigned countenances.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Coquenard distributed this dish to the young men with
Title:  the moderation of a good housewife.
Title:  
Title:  The time for wine came.  M. Coquenard poured from a very
Title:  small stone bottle the third of a glass for each of the
Title:  young men, served himself in about the same proportion, and
Title:  passed the bottle to Porthos and Mme. Coquenard.
Title:  
Title:  The young men filled up their third of a glass with water;
Title:  then, when they had drunk half the glass, they filled it up
Title:  again, and continued to do so.  This brought them, by the
Title:  end of the repast, to swallowing a drink which from the
Title:  color of the ruby had passed to that of a pale topaz.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos ate his wing of the fowl timidly, and shuddered when
Title:  he felt the knee of the procurator's wife under the table,
Title:  as it came in search of his.  He also drank half a glass of
Title:  this sparingly served wine, and found it to be nothing but
Title:  that horrible Montreuil--the terror of all expert palates.
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard saw him swallowing this wine undiluted, and
Title:  sighed deeply.
Title:  
Title:  "Will you eat any of these beans, Cousin Porthos?" said Mme.
Title:  Coquenard, in that tone which says, "Take my advice, don't
Title:  touch them."
Title:  
Title:  "Devil take me if I taste one of them!" murmured Porthos to
Title:  himself, and then said aloud, "Thank you, my cousin, I am no
Title:  longer hungry."
Title:  
Title:  There was silence.  Porthos could hardly keep his
Title:  countenance.
Title:  
Title:  The procurator repeated several times, "Ah, Madame
Title:  Coquenard!  Accept my compliments; your dinner has been a
Title:  real feast.  Lord, how I have eaten!"
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard had eaten his soup, the black feet of the fowl,
Title:  and the only mutton bone on which there was the least
Title:  appearance of meat.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos fancied they were mystifying him, and began to curl
Title:  his mustache and knit his eyebrows; but the knee of Mme.
Title:  Coquenard gently advised him to be patient.
Title:  
Title:  This silence and this interruption in serving, which were
Title:  unintelligible to Porthos, had, on the contrary, a terrible
Title:  meaning for the clerks.  Upon a look from the procurator,
Title:  accompanied by a smile from Mme. Coquenard, they arose
Title:  slowly from the table, folded their napkins more slowly
Title:  still, bowed, and retired.
Title:  
Title:  "Go, young men! go and promote digestion by working," said
Title:  the procurator, gravely.
Title:  
Title:  The clerks gone, Mme. Coquenard rose and took from a buffet
Title:  a piece of cheese, some preserved quinces, and a cake which
Title:  she had herself made of almonds and honey.
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard knit his eyebrows because there were too many
Title:  good things.  Porthos bit his lips because he saw not the
Title:  wherewithal to dine.  He looked to see if the dish of beans
Title:  was still there; the dish of beans had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  "A positive feast!" cried M. Coquenard, turning about in his
Title:  chair, "a real feast, EPULCE EPULORUM.  Lucullus dines with
Title:  Lucullus."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos looked at the bottle, which was near him, and hoped
Title:  that with wine, bread, and cheese, he might make a dinner;
Title:  but wine was wanting, the bottle was empty.  M. and Mme.
Title:  Coquenard did not seem to observe it.
Title:  
Title:  "This is fine!" said Porthos to himself; "I am prettily
Title:  caught!"
Title:  
Title:  He passed his tongue over a spoonful of preserves, and stuck
Title:  his teeth into the sticky pastry of Mme. Coquenard.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said he, "the sacrifice is consummated!  Ah! if I had
Title:  not the hope of peeping with Madame Coquenard into her
Title:  husband's chest!"
Title:  
Title:  M. Coquenard, after the luxuries of such a repast, which he
Title:  called an excess, felt the want of a siesta.  Porthos began
Title:  to hope that the thing would take place at the present
Title:  sitting, and in that same locality; but the procurator would
Title:  listen to nothing, he would be taken to his room, and was
Title:  not satisfied till he was close to his chest, upon the edge
Title:  of which, for still greater precaution, he placed his feet.
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife took Porthos into an adjoining room,
Title:  and they began to lay the basis of a reconciliation.
Title:  
Title:  "You can come and dine three times a week," said Mme.
Title:  Coquenard.
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, madame!" said Porthos, "but I don't like to abuse
Title:  your kindness; besides, I must think of my outfit!"
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said the procurator's wife, groaning, "that
Title:  unfortunate outfit!"
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, yes," said Porthos, "it is so."
Title:  
Title:  "But of what, then, does the equipment of your company
Title:  consist, Monsieur Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, of many things!" said Porthos.  "The Musketeers are, as
Title:  you know, picked soldiers, and they require many things
Title:  useless to the Guardsmen or the Swiss."
Title:  
Title:  "But yet, detail them to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, they may amount to--", said Porthos, who preferred
Title:  discussing the total to taking them one by one.
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife waited tremblingly.
Title:  
Title:  "To how much?" said she.  "I hope it does not exceed--" She
Title:  stopped; speech failed her.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no," said Porthos, "it does not exceed two thousand
Title:  five hundred livres!  I even think that with economy I could
Title:  manage it with two thousand livres."
Title:  
Title:  "Good God!" cried she, "two thousand livres! Why, that is a
Title:  fortune!"
Title:  
Title:  Porthos made a most significant grimace; Mme. Coquenard
Title:  understood it.
Title:  
Title:  "I wished to know the detail," said she, "because, having
Title:  many relatives in business, I was almost sure of obtaining
Title:  things at a hundred per cent less than you would pay
Title:  yourself."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Porthos, "that is what you meant to say!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, dear Monsieur Porthos.  Thus, for instance, don't you
Title:  in the first place want a horse?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, a horse."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then!  I can just suit you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!" said Porthos, brightening, "that's well as regards my
Title:  horse; but I must have the appointments complete, as they
Title:  include objects which a Musketeer alone can purchase, and
Title:  which will not amount, besides, to more than three hundred
Title:  livres."
Title:  
Title:  "Three hundred livres?  Then put down three hundred livres,"
Title:  said the procurator's wife, with a sigh.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos smiled.  It may be remembered that he had the saddle
Title:  which came from Buckingham.  These three hundred livres he
Title:  reckoned upon putting snugly into his pocket.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," continued he, "there is a horse for my lackey, and
Title:  my valise.  As to my arms, it is useless to trouble you
Title:  about them; I have them."
Title:  
Title:  "A horse for your lackey?" resumed the procurator's wife,
Title:  hesitatingly; "but that is doing things in lordly style, my
Title:  friend."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, madame!" said Porthos, haughtily; "do you take me for a
Title:  beggar?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; I only thought that a pretty mule makes sometimes as
Title:  good an appearance as a horse, and it seemed to me that by
Title:  getting a pretty mule for Mousqueton--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, agreed for a pretty mule," said Porthos; "you are
Title:  right, I have seen very great Spanish nobles whose whole
Title:  suite were mounted on mules.  But then you understand,
Title:  Madame Coquenard, a mule with feathers and bells."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied," said the procurator's wife.
Title:  
Title:  "There remains the valise," added Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, don't let that disturb you," cried Mme. Coquenard.  "My
Title:  husband has five or six valises; you shall choose the best.
Title:  There is one in particular which he prefers in his journeys,
Title:  large enough to hold all the world."
Title:  
Title:  "Your valise is then empty?" asked Porthos, with simplicity.
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly it is empty," replied the procurator's wife, in
Title:  real innocence.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, but the valise I want," cried Porthos, "is a well-
Title:  filled one, my dear."
Title:  
Title:  Madame uttered fresh sighs.  Moliere had not written his
Title:  scene in "L'Avare" then.  Mme. Coquenard was in the dilemma
Title:  of Harpagan.
Title:  
Title:  Finally, the rest of the equipment was successively debated
Title:  in the same manner; and the result of the sitting was that
Title:  the procurator's wife should give eight hundred livres in
Title:  money, and should furnish the horse and the mule which
Title:  should have the honor of carrying Porthos and Mousqueton to
Title:  glory.
Title:  
Title:  These conditions being agreed to, Porthos took leave of Mme.
Title:  Coquenard.  The latter wished to detain him by darting
Title:  certain tender glances; but Porthos urged the commands of
Title:  duty, and the procurator's wife was obliged to give place to
Title:  the king.
Title:  
Title:  The Musketeer returned home hungry and in bad humor.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  33  SOUBRETTE AND MISTRESS
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, as we have said, despite the cries of his
Title:  conscience and the wise counsels of Athos, d'Artagnan became
Title:  hourly more in love with Milady.  Thus he never failed to
Title:  pay his diurnal court to her; and the self-satisfied Gascon
Title:  was convinced that sooner or later she could not fail to
Title:  respond.
Title:  
Title:  One day, when he arrived with his head in the air, and as
Title:  light at heart as a man who awaits a shower of gold, he
Title:  found the SOUBRETTE under the gateway of the hotel; but this
Title:  time the pretty Kitty was not contented with touching him as
Title:  he passed, she took him gently by the hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Good!" thought d'Artagnan, "She is charged with some
Title:  message for me from her mistress; she is about to appoint
Title:  some rendezvous of which she had not courage to speak."  And
Title:  he looked down at the pretty girl with the most triumphant
Title:  air imaginable.
Title:  
Title:  "I wish to say three words to you, Monsieur Chevalier,"
Title:  stammered the SOUBRETTE.
Title:  
Title:  "Speak, my child, speak," said d'Artagnan; "I listen."
Title:  
Title:  "Here?  Impossible!  That which I have to say is too long,
Title:  and above all, too secret."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what is to be done?"
Title:  
Title:  "If Monsieur Chevalier would follow me?" said Kitty,
Title:  timidly.
Title:  
Title:  "Where you please, my dear child."
Title:  
Title:  "Come, then."
Title:  
Title:  And Kitty, who had not let go the hand of d'Artagnan, led
Title:  him up a little dark, winding staircase, and after ascending
Title:  about fifteen steps, opened a door.
Title:  
Title:  "Come in here, Monsieur Chevalier," said she; "here we shall
Title:  be alone, and can talk."
Title:  
Title:  "And whose room is this, my dear child?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is mine, Monsieur Chevalier; it communicates with my
Title:  mistress's by that door.  But you need not fear.  She will
Title:  not hear what we say; she never goes to bed before
Title:  midnight."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan cast a glance around him.  The little apartment
Title:  was charming for its taste and neatness; but in spite of
Title:  himself, his eyes were directed to that door which Kitty
Title:  said led to Milady's chamber.
Title:  
Title:  Kitty guessed what was passing in the mind of the young man,
Title:  and heaved a deep sigh.
Title:  
Title:  "You love my mistress, then, very dearly, Monsieur
Title:  Chevalier?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, more than I can say, Kitty! I am mad for her!"
Title:  
Title:  Kitty breathed a second sigh.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, monsieur," said she, "that is too bad."
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil do you see so bad in it?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Because, monsieur," replied Kitty, "my mistress loves you
Title:  not at all."
Title:  
Title:  "HEIN!" said d'Artagnan, "can she have charged you to tell
Title:  me so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no, monsieur; but out of the regard I have for you, I
Title:  have taken the resolution to tell you so."
Title:  
Title:  "Much obliged, my dear Kitty; but for the intention only--for
Title:  the information, you must agree, is not likely to be at all
Title:  agreeable."
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, you don't believe what I have told you; is
Title:  it not so?"
Title:  
Title:  "We have always some difficulty in believing such things, my
Title:  pretty dear, were it only from self-love."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you don't believe me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I confess that unless you deign to give me some proof of
Title:  what you advance--"
Title:  
Title:  "What do you think of this?"
Title:  
Title:  Kitty drew a little note from her bosom.
Title:  
Title:  "For me?" said d'Artagnan, seizing the letter.
Title:  
Title:  "No; for another."
Title:  
Title:  "For another?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "His name; his name!" cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Read the address."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur El Comte de Wardes."
Title:  
Title:  The remembrance of the scene at St. Germain presented itself
Title:  to the mind of the presumptuous Gascon.  As quick as
Title:  thought, he tore open the letter, in spite of the cry which
Title:  Kitty uttered on seeing what he was going to do, or rather,
Title:  what he was doing.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, good Lord, Monsieur Chevalier," said she, "what are you
Title:  doing?"
Title:  
Title:  "I?" said d'Artagnan; "nothing," and he read,
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "You have not answered my first note.  Are you indisposed,
Title:  or have you forgotten the glances you favored me with at the
Title:  ball of Mme. de Guise?  You have an opportunity now, Count;
Title:  do not allow it to escape."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  d'Artagnan became very pale; he was wounded in his SELF-
Title:  love: he thought that it was in his LOVE.
Title:  
Title:  "Poor dear Monsieur d'Artagnan," said Kitty, in a voice full
Title:  of compassion, and pressing anew the young man's hand.
Title:  
Title:  "You pity me, little one?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, and with all my heart; for I know what it is to be
Title:  in love."
Title:  
Title:  "You know what it is to be in love?" said d'Artagnan,
Title:  looking at her for the first time with much attention.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, instead of pitying me, you would do much better
Title:  to assist me in avenging myself on your mistress."
Title:  
Title:  "And what sort of revenge would you take?"
Title:  
Title:  "I would triumph over her, and supplant my rival."
Title:  
Title:  "I will never help you in that, Monsieur Chevalier," said
Title:  Kitty, warmly.
Title:  
Title:  "And why not?" demanded d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "For two reasons."
Title:  
Title:  "What ones?"
Title:  
Title:  "The first is that my mistress will never love you."
Title:  
Title:  "How do you know that?"
Title:  
Title:  "You have cut her to the heart."
Title:  
Title:  "I? In what can I have offended her--I who ever since I have
Title:  known her have lived at her feet like a slave?  Speak, I beg
Title:  you!"
Title:  
Title:  "I will never confess that but to the man--who should read to
Title:  the bottom of my soul!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan looked at Kitty for the second time.  The young
Title:  girl had freshness and beauty which many duchesses would
Title:  have purchased with their coronets.
Title:  
Title:  "Kitty," said he, "I will read to the bottom of your soul
Title:  when-ever you like; don't let that disturb you." And he gave
Title:  her a kiss at which the poor girl became as red as a cherry.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no," said Kitty, "it is not me you love!  It is my
Title:  mistress you love; you told me so just now."
Title:  
Title:  "And does that hinder you from letting me know the second
Title:  reason?"
Title:  
Title:  "The second reason, Monsieur the Chevalier," replied Kitty,
Title:  emboldened by the kiss in the first place, and still further
Title:  by the expression of the eyes of the young man, "is that in
Title:  love, everyone for herself!"
Title:  
Title:  Then only d'Artagnan remembered the languishing glances of
Title:  Kitty, her constantly meeting him in the antechamber, the
Title:  corridor, or on the stairs, those touches of the hand every
Title:  time she met him, and her deep sighs; but absorbed by his
Title:  desire to please the great lady, he had disdained the
Title:  soubrette.  He whose game is the eagle takes no heed of the
Title:  sparrow.
Title:  
Title:  But this time our Gascon saw at a glance all the advantage
Title:  to be derived from the love which Kitty had just confessed
Title:  so innocently, or so boldly: the interception of letters
Title:  addressed to the Comte de Wardes, news on the spot, entrance
Title:  at all hours into Kitty's chamber, which was contiguous to
Title:  her mistress's.  The perfidious deceiver was, as may plainly
Title:  be perceived, already sacrificing, in intention, the poor
Title:  girl in order to obtain Milady, willy-nilly.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said he to the young girl, "are you willing, my dear
Title:  Kitty, that I should give you a proof of that love which you
Title:  doubt?"
Title:  
Title:  "What love?" asked the young girl.
Title:  
Title:  "Of that which I am ready to feel toward you."
Title:  
Title:  "And what is that proof?"
Title:  
Title:  "Are you willing that I should this evening pass with you
Title:  the time I generally spend with your mistress?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes," said Kitty, clapping her hands, "very willing."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, come here, my dear," said d'Artagnan,
Title:  establishing himself in an easy chair; "come, and let me
Title:  tell you that you are the prettiest SOUBRETTE I ever saw!"
Title:  
Title:  And he did tell her so much, and so well, that the poor
Title:  girl, who asked nothing better than to believe him, did
Title:  believe him. Nevertheless, to d'Artagnan's great
Title:  astonishment, the pretty Kitty defended herself resolutely.
Title:  
Title:  Time passes quickly when it is passed in attacks and
Title:  defenses.  Midnight sounded, and almost at the same time the
Title:  bell was rung in Milady's chamber.
Title:  
Title:  "Good God," cried Kitty, "there is my mistress calling me!
Title:  Go; go directly!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan rose, took his hat, as if it had been his
Title:  intention to obey, then, opening quickly the door of a large
Title:  closet instead of that leading to the staircase, he buried
Title:  himself amid the robes and dressing gowns of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "What are you doing?" cried Kitty.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who had secured the key, shut himself up in the
Title:  closet without reply.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," cried Milady, in a sharp voice.  "Are you asleep,
Title:  that you don't answer when I ring?"
Title:  
Title:  And d'Artagnan heard the door of communication opened
Title:  violently.
Title:  
Title:  "Here am I, Milady, here am I!" cried Kitty, springing
Title:  forward to meet her mistress.
Title:  
Title:  Both went into the bedroom, and as the door of communication
Title:  remained open, d'Artagnan could hear Milady for some time
Title:  scolding her maid.  She was at length appeased, and the
Title:  conversation turned upon him while Kitty was assisting her
Title:  mistress.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Milady, "I have not seen our Gascon this
Title:  evening."
Title:  
Title:  "What, Milady! has he not come?" said Kitty.  "Can he be
Title:  inconstant before being happy?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no; he must have been prevented by Monsieur de Treville
Title:  or Monsieur Dessessart.  I understand my game, Kitty; I have
Title:  this one safe."
Title:  
Title:  "What will you do with him, madame?"
Title:  
Title:  "What will I do with him?  Be easy, Kitty, there is
Title:  something between that man and me that he is quite ignorant
Title:  of: he nearly made me lose my credit with his Eminence. Oh,
Title:  I will be revenged!"
Title:  
Title:  "I believed that Madame loved him."
Title:  
Title:  "I love him?  I detest him! An idiot, who held the life of
Title:  Lord de Winter in his hands and did not kill him, by which I
Title:  missed three hundred thousand livres' income."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said Kitty; "your son was the only heir of
Title:  his uncle, and until his majority you would have had the
Title:  enjoyment of his fortune."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan shuddered to the marrow at hearing this suave
Title:  creature reproach him, with that sharp voice which she took
Title:  such pains to conceal in conversation, for not having killed
Title:  a man whom he had seen load her with kindnesses.
Title:  
Title:  "For all this," continued Milady, "I should long ago have
Title:  revenged myself on him if, and I don't know why, the
Title:  cardinal had not requested me to conciliate him."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes; but Madame has not conciliated that little woman
Title:  he was so fond of."
Title:  
Title:  "What, the mercer's wife of the Rue des Fossoyeurs?  Has he
Title:  not already forgotten she ever existed?  Fine vengeance
Title:  that, on my faith!"
Title:  
Title:  A cold sweat broke from d'Artagnan's brow.  Why, this woman
Title:  was a monster! He resumed his listening, but unfortunately
Title:  the toilet was finished.
Title:  
Title:  "That will do," said Milady; "go into your own room, and
Title:  tomorrow endeavor again to get me an answer to the letter I
Title:  gave you."
Title:  
Title:  "For Monsieur de Wardes?" said Kitty.
Title:  
Title:  "To be sure; for Monsieur de Wardes."
Title:  
Title:  "Now, there is one," said Kitty, "who appears to me quite a
Title:  different sort of a man from that poor Monsieur d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "Go to bed, mademoiselle," said Milady; "I don't like
Title:  comments."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan heard the door close; then the noise of two bolts
Title:  by which Milady fastened herself in.  On her side, but as
Title:  softly as possible, Kitty turned the key of the lock, and
Title:  then d'Artagnan opened the closet door.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, good Lord!" said Kitty, in a low voice, "what is the
Title:  matter with you?  How pale you are!"
Title:  
Title:  "The abominable creature" murmured d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, silence, begone!" said Kitty.  "There is nothing
Title:  but a wainscot between my chamber and Milady's; every word
Title:  that is uttered in one can be heard in the other."
Title:  
Title:  "That's exactly the reason I won't go," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "What!" said Kitty, blushing.
Title:  
Title:  "Or, at least, I will go--later."
Title:  
Title:  He drew Kitty to him.  She had the less motive to resist,
Title:  resistance would make so much noise.  Therefore Kitty
Title:  surrendered.
Title:  
Title:  It was a movement of vengeance upon Milady.  D'Artagnan
Title:  believed it right to say that vengeance is the pleasure of
Title:  the gods.  With a little more heart, he might have been
Title:  contented with this new conquest; but the principal features
Title:  of his character were ambition and pride.  It must, however,
Title:  be confessed in his justification that the first use he made
Title:  of his influence over Kitty was to try and find out what had
Title:  become of Mme. Bonacieux; but the poor girl swore upon the
Title:  crucifix to d'Artagnan that she was entirely ignorant on
Title:  that head, her mistress never admitting her into half her
Title:  secrets--only she believed she could say she was not dead.
Title:  
Title:  As to the cause which was near making Milady lose her credit
Title:  with the cardinal, Kitty knew nothing about it; but this
Title:  time d'Artagnan was better informed than she was.  As he had
Title:  seen Milady on board a vessel at the moment he was leaving
Title:  England, he suspected that it was, almost without a doubt,
Title:  on account of the diamond studs.
Title:  
Title:  But what was clearest in all this was that the true hatred,
Title:  the profound hatred, the inveterate hatred of Milady, was
Title:  increased by his not having killed her brother-in-law.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan came the next day to Milady's, and finding her in
Title:  a very ill-humor, had no doubt that it was lack of an answer
Title:  from M. de Wardes that provoked her thus.  Kitty came in,
Title:  but Milady was very cross with her.  The poor girl ventured
Title:  a glance at d'Artagnan which said, "See how I suffer on your
Title:  account!"
Title:  
Title:  Toward the end of the evening, however, the beautiful
Title:  lioness became milder; she smilingly listened to the soft
Title:  speeches of d'Artagnan, and even gave him her hand to kiss.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan departed, scarcely knowing what to think, but as
Title:  he was a youth who did not easily lose his head, while
Title:  continuing to pay his court to Milady, he had framed a
Title:  little plan in his mind.
Title:  
Title:  He found Kitty at the gate, and, as on the preceding
Title:  evening, went up to her chamber.  Kitty had been accused of
Title:  negligence and severely scolded.  Milady could not at all
Title:  comprehend the silence of the Comte de Wardes, and she
Title:  ordered Kitty to come at nine o'clock in the morning to take
Title:  a third letter.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan made Kitty promise to bring him that letter on
Title:  the following morning.  The poor girl promised all her lover
Title:  desired; she was mad.
Title:  
Title:  Things passed as on the night before.  D'Artagnan concealed
Title:  himself in his closet; Milady called, undressed, sent away
Title:  Kitty, and shut the door.  As the night before, d'Artagnan
Title:  did not return home till five o'clock in the morning.
Title:  
Title:  At eleven o'clock Kitty came to him.  She held in her hand a
Title:  fresh billet from Milady.  This time the poor girl did not
Title:  even argue with d'Artagnan; she gave it to him at once. She
Title:  belonged body and soul to her handsome soldier.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan opened the letter and read as follows:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  This is the third time I have written to you to tell you
Title:  that I love you.  Beware that I do not write to you a fourth
Title:  time to tell you that I detest you.
Title:  
Title:  If you repent of the manner in which you have acted toward
Title:  me, the young girl who brings you this will tell you how a
Title:  man of spirit may obtain his pardon.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  d'Artagnan colored and grew pale several times in reading
Title:  this billet.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you love her still," said Kitty, who had not taken her
Title:  eyes off the young man's countenance for an instant.
Title:  
Title:  "No, Kitty, you are mistaken.  I do not love her, but I will
Title:  avenge myself for her contempt."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, I know what sort of vengeance!  You told me that!"
Title:  
Title:  "What matters it to you, Kitty?  You know it is you alone
Title:  whom I love."
Title:  
Title:  "How can I know that?"
Title:  
Title:  "By the scorn I will throw upon her."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took a pen and wrote:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Madame, Until the present moment I could not believe that it
Title:  was to me your first two letters were addressed, so unworthy
Title:  did I feel myself of such an honor; besides, I was so
Title:  seriously indisposed that I could not in any case have
Title:  replied to them.
Title:  
Title:  But now I am forced to believe in the excess of your
Title:  kindness, since not only your letter but your servant
Title:  assures me that I have the good fortune to be beloved by
Title:  you.
Title:  
Title:  She has no occasion to teach me the way in which a man of
Title:  spirit may obtain his pardon.  I will come and ask mine at
Title:  eleven o'clock this evening.
Title:  
Title:  To delay it a single day would be in my eyes now to commit a
Title:  fresh offense.
Title:  
Title:  From him whom you have rendered the happiest of men,
Title:  Comte de Wardes
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  This note was in the first place a forgery; it was likewise
Title:  an indelicacy.  It was even, according to our present
Title:  manners, something like an infamous action; but at that
Title:  period people did not manage affairs as they do today.
Title:  Besides, d'Artagnan from her own admission knew Milady
Title:  culpable of treachery in matters more important, and could
Title:  entertain no respect for her.  And yet, notwithstanding this
Title:  want of respect, he felt an uncontrollable passion for this
Title:  woman boiling in his veins--passion drunk with contempt; but
Title:  passion or thirst, as the reader pleases.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan's plan was very simple.  By Kitty's chamber he
Title:  could gain that of her mistress.  He would take advantage of
Title:  the first moment of surprise, shame, and terror, to triumph
Title:  over her.  He might fail, but something must be left to
Title:  chance.  In eight days the campaign would open, and he would
Title:  be compelled to leave Paris; d'Artagnan had no time for a
Title:  prolonged love siege.
Title:  
Title:  "There," said the young man, handing Kitty the letter
Title:  sealed; "give that to Milady.  It is the count's reply."
Title:  
Title:  Poor Kitty became as pale as death; she suspected what the
Title:  letter contained.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen, my dear girl," said d'Artagnan; "you cannot but
Title:  perceive that all this must end, some way or other.  Milady
Title:  may discover that you gave the first billet to my lackey
Title:  instead of to the count's; that it is I who have opened the
Title:  others which ought to have been opened by de Wardes.  Milady
Title:  will then turn you out of doors, and you know she is not the
Title:  woman to limit her vengeance."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!" said Kitty, "for whom have I exposed myself to all that?"
Title:  
Title:  "For me, I well know, my sweet girl," said d'Artagnan.  "But
Title:  I am grateful, I swear to you."
Title:  
Title:  "But what does this note contain?"
Title:  
Title:  "Milady will tell you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you do not love me!" cried Kitty, "and I am very
Title:  wretched."
Title:  
Title:  To this reproach there is always one response which deludes
Title:  women.  D'Artagnan replied in such a manner that Kitty
Title:  remained in her great delusion.  Although she cried freely
Title:  before deciding to transmit the letter to her mistress, she
Title:  did at last so decide, which was all d'Artagnan wished.
Title:  Finally he promised that he would leave her mistress's
Title:  presence at an early hour that evening, and that when he
Title:  left the mistress he would ascend with the maid. This
Title:  promise completed poor Kitty's consolation.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  34  IN WHICH THE EQUIPMENT OF ARAMIS AND PORTHOS IS TREATED
Title:  OF
Title:  
Title:  Since the four friends had been each in search of his
Title:  equipments, there had been no fixed meeting between them.
Title:  They dined apart from one another, wherever they might
Title:  happen to be, or rather where they could.  Duty likewise on
Title:  its part took a portion of that precious time which was
Title:  gliding away so rapidly--only they had agreed to meet once a
Title:  week, about one o'clock, at the residence of Athos, seeing
Title:  that he, in agreement with the vow he had formed, did not
Title:  pass over the threshold of his door.
Title:  
Title:  This day of reunion was the same day as that on which Kitty
Title:  came to find d'Artagnan.  Soon as Kitty left him, d'Artagnan
Title:  directed his steps toward the Rue Ferou.
Title:  
Title:  He found Athos and Aramis philosophizing.  Aramis had some
Title:  slight inclination to resume the cassock.  Athos, according
Title:  to his system, neither encouraged nor dissuaded him.  Athos
Title:  believed that everyone should be left to his own free will.
Title:  He never gave advice but when it was asked, and even then he
Title:  required to be asked twice.
Title:  
Title:  "People, in general," he said, "only ask advice not to
Title:  follow it; or if they do follow it, it is for the sake of
Title:  having someone to blame for having given it."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos arrived a minute after d'Artagnan.  The four friends
Title:  were reunited.
Title:  
Title:  The four countenances expressed four different feelings:
Title:  that of Porthos, tranquillity; that of d'Artagnan, hope;
Title:  that of Aramis, uneasiness; that of Athos, carelessness.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of a moment's conversation, in which Porthos
Title:  hinted that a lady of elevated rank had condescended to
Title:  relieve him from his embarrassment, Mousqueton entered.  He
Title:  came to request his master to return to his lodgings, where
Title:  his presence was urgent, as he piteously said.
Title:  
Title:  "Is it my equipment?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes and no," replied Mousqueton.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but can't you speak?"
Title:  
Title:  "Come, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos rose, saluted his friends, and followed Mousqueton.
Title:  An instant after, Bazin made his appearance at the door.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you want with me, my friend?" said Aramis, with
Title:  that mildness of language which was observable in him every
Title:  time that his ideas were directed toward the Church.
Title:  
Title:  "A man wishes to see Monsieur at home," replied Bazin.
Title:  
Title:  "A man!  What man?"
Title:  
Title:  "A mendicant."
Title:  
Title:  "Give him alms, Bazin, and bid him pray for a poor sinner."
Title:  
Title:  "This mendicant insists upon speaking to you, and pretends
Title:  that you will be very glad to see him."
Title:  
Title:  "Has he sent no particular message for me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes.  If Monsieur Aramis hesitates to come," he said, "tell
Title:  him I am from Tours."
Title:  
Title:  "From Tours!" cried Aramis.  "A thousand pardons, gentlemen;
Title:  but no doubt this man brings me the news I expected." And
Title:  rising also, he went off at a quick pace.  There remained
Title:  Athos and d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I believe these fellows have managed their business.  What
Title:  do you think, d'Artagnan?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I know that Porthos was in a fair way," replied d'Artagnan;
Title:  "and as to Aramis to tell you the truth, I have never been
Title:  seriously uneasy on his account.  But you, my dear Athos--
Title:  you, who so generously distributed the Englishman's
Title:  pistoles, which were our legitimate property--what do you
Title:  mean to do?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am satisfied with having killed that fellow, my boy,
Title:  seeing that it is blessed bread to kill an Englishman; but
Title:  if I had pocketed his pistoles, they would have weighed me
Title:  down like a remorse.
Title:  
Title:  "Go to, my dear Athos; you have truly inconceivable ideas."
Title:  
Title:  "Let it pass. What do you think of Monsieur de Treville
Title:  telling me, when he did me the honor to call upon me
Title:  yesterday, that you associated with the suspected English,
Title:  whom the cardinal protects?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, I visit an Englishwoman--the one I named."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, ay! the fair woman on whose account I gave you advice,
Title:  which naturally you took care not to adopt."
Title:  
Title:  "I gave you my reasons."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; you look there for your outfit, I think you said."
Title:  
Title:  "Not at all.  I have acquired certain knowledge that that
Title:  woman was concerned in the abduction of Madame Bonacieux."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I understand now: to find one woman, you court
Title:  another.  It is the longest road, but certainly the most
Title:  amusing."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was on the point of telling Athos all; but one
Title:  consideration restrained him.  Athos was a gentleman,
Title:  punctilious in points of honor; and there were in the plan
Title:  which our lover had devised for Milady, he was sure, certain
Title:  things that would not obtain the assent of this Puritan.  He
Title:  was therefore silent; and as Athos was the least inquisitive
Title:  of any man on earth, d'Artagnan's confidence stopped there.
Title:  We will therefore leave the two friends, who had nothing
Title:  important to say to each other, and follow Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  Upon being informed that the person who wanted to speak to
Title:  him came from Tours, we have seen with what rapidity the
Title:  young man followed, or rather went before, Bazin; he ran
Title:  without stopping from the Rue Ferou to the Rue de Vaugirard.
Title:  On entering he found a man of short stature and intelligent
Title:  eyes, but covered with rags.
Title:  
Title:  "You have asked for me?" said the Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "I wish to speak with Monsieur Aramis.  Is that your name,
Title:  monsieur?"
Title:  
Title:  "My very own.  You have brought me something?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, if you show me a certain embroidered handkerchief."
Title:  
Title:  "Here it is," said Aramis, taking a small key from his
Title:  breast and opening a little ebony box inlaid with mother of
Title:  pearl, "here it is.  Look."
Title:  
Title:  "That is right," replied the mendicant; "dismiss your lackey."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, Bazin, curious to know what the mendicant could
Title:  want with his master, kept pace with him as well as he
Title:  could, and arrived almost at the same time he did; but his
Title:  quickness was not of much use to him.  At the hint from the
Title:  mendicant his master made him a sign to retire, and he was
Title:  obliged to obey.
Title:  
Title:  Bazin gone, the mendicant cast a rapid glance around him in
Title:  order to be sure that nobody could either see or hear him,
Title:  and opening his ragged vest, badly held together by a
Title:  leather strap, he began to rip the upper part of his
Title:  doublet, from which he drew a letter.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis uttered a cry of joy at the sight of the seal, kissed
Title:  the superscription with an almost religious respect, and
Title:  opened the epistle, which contained what follows:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "My Friend, it is the will of fate that we should be still
Title:  for some time separated; but the delightful days of youth
Title:  are not lost beyond return.  Perform your duty in camp; I
Title:  will do mine elsewhere.  Accept that which the bearer brings
Title:  you; make the campaign like a handsome true gentleman, and
Title:  think of me, who kisses tenderly your black eyes.
Title:  
Title:  "Adieu; or rather, AU REVOIR."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The mendicant continued to rip his garments; and drew from
Title:  amid his rags a hundred and fifty Spanish double pistoles,
Title:  which he laid down on the table; then he opened the door,
Title:  bowed, and went out before the young man, stupefied by his
Title:  letter, had ventured to address a word to him.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis then reperused the letter, and perceived a
Title:  postscript:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  P.S. You may behave politely to the bearer, who is a count
Title:  and a grandee of Spain!
Title:  
Title:  "Golden dreams!" cried Aramis.  "Oh, beautiful life! Yes, we
Title:  are young; yes, we shall yet have happy days! My love, my
Title:  blood, my life! all, all, all, are thine, my adored
Title:  mistress!"
Title:  
Title:  And he kissed the letter with passion, without even
Title:  vouchsafing a look at the gold which sparkled on the table.
Title:  
Title:  Bazin scratched at the door, and as Aramis had no longer any
Title:  reason to exclude him, he bade him come in.
Title:  
Title:  Bazin was stupefied at the sight of the gold, and forgot
Title:  that he came to announce d'Artagnan, who, curious to know
Title:  who the mendicant could be, came to Aramis on leaving Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Now, as d'Artagnan used no ceremony with Aramis, seeing that
Title:  Bazin forgot to announce him, he announced himself.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil! my dear Aramis," said d'Artagnan, "if these are
Title:  the prunes that are sent to you from Tours, I beg you will
Title:  make my compliments to the gardener who gathers them."
Title:  
Title:  "You are mistaken, friend d'Artagnan," said Aramis, always
Title:  on his guard; "this is from my publisher, who has just sent
Title:  me the price of that poem in one-syllable verse which I
Title:  began yonder."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, indeed," said d'Artagnan.  "Well, your publisher is
Title:  very generous, my dear Aramis, that's all I can say."
Title:  
Title:  "How, monsieur?" cried Bazin, "a poem sell so dear as that!
Title:  It is incredible! Oh, monsieur, you can write as much as you
Title:  like; you may become equal to Monsieur de Voiture and
Title:  Monsieur de Benserade.  I like that.  A poet is as good as
Title:  an abbe.  Ah! Monsieur Aramis, become a poet, I beg of you."
Title:  
Title:  "Bazin, my friend," said Aramis, "I believe you meddle with
Title:  my conversation."
Title:  
Title:  Bazin perceived he was wrong; he bowed and went out.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!" said d'Artagnan with a smile, "you sell your
Title:  productions at their weight in gold.  You are very
Title:  fortunate, my friend; but take care or you will lose that
Title:  letter which is peeping from your doublet, and which also
Title:  comes, no doubt, from your publisher."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis blushed to the eyes, crammed in the letter, and
Title:  re-buttoned his doublet.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear d'Artagnan," said he, "if you please, we will join
Title:  our friends; as I am rich, we will today begin to dine
Title:  together again, expecting that you will be rich in your
Title:  turn."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith!" said d'Artagnan, with great pleasure.  "It is
Title:  long since we have had a good dinner; and I, for my part,
Title:  have a somewhat hazardous expedition for this evening, and
Title:  shall not be sorry, I confess, to fortify myself with a few
Title:  glasses of good old Burgundy."
Title:  
Title:  "Agreed, as to the old Burgundy; I have no objection to
Title:  that," said Aramis, from whom the letter and the gold had
Title:  removed, as by magic, his ideas of conversion.
Title:  
Title:  And having put three or four double pistoles into his pocket
Title:  to answer the needs of the moment, he placed the others in
Title:  the ebony box, inlaid with mother of pearl, in which was the
Title:  famous handkerchief which served him as a talisman.
Title:  
Title:  The two friends repaired to Athos's, and he, faithful to his
Title:  vow of not going out, took upon him to order dinner to be
Title:  brought to them.  As he was perfectly acquainted with the
Title:  details of gastronomy, d'Artagnan and Aramis made no
Title:  objection to abandoning this important care to him.
Title:  
Title:  They went to find Porthos, and at the corner of the Rue Bac
Title:  met Mousqueton, who, with a most pitiable air, was driving
Title:  before him a mule and a horse.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise, which was not quite
Title:  free from joy.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my yellow horse," cried he.  "Aramis, look at that
Title:  horse!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, the frightful brute!" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my dear," replied d'Artagnan, "upon that very horse I
Title:  came to Paris."
Title:  
Title:  "What, does Monsieur know this horse?" said Mousqueton.
Title:  
Title:  "It is of an original color," said Aramis; "I never saw one
Title:  with such a hide in my life."
Title:  
Title:  "I can well believe it," replied d'Artagnan, "and that was
Title:  why I got three crowns for him.  It must have been for his
Title:  hide, for, CERTES, the carcass is not worth eighteen livres.
Title:  But how did this horse come into your bands, Mousqueton?"
Title:  
Title:  "Pray," said the lackey, "say nothing about it, monsieur; it
Title:  is a frightful trick of the husband of our duchess!"
Title:  
Title:  "How is that, Mousqueton?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, we are looked upon with a rather favorable eye by a
Title:  lady of quality, the Duchesse de--but, your pardon; my master
Title:  has commanded me to be discreet.  She had forced us to
Title:  accept a little souvenir, a magnificent Spanish GENET and an
Title:  Andalusian mule, which were beautiful to look upon.  The
Title:  husband heard of the affair; on their way he confiscated the
Title:  two magnificent beasts which were being sent to us, and
Title:  substituted these horrible animals."
Title:  
Title:  "Which you are taking back to him?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly!" replied Mousqueton. "You may well believe that we
Title:  will not accept such steeds as these in exchange for those
Title:  which had been promised to us."
Title:  
Title:  "No, PARDIEU; though I should like to have seen Porthos on
Title:  my yellow horse.  That would give me an idea of how I looked
Title:  when I arrived in Paris.  But don't let us hinder you,
Title:  Mousqueton; go and perform your master's orders.  Is he at
Title:  home?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," said Mousqueton, "but in a very ill humor.
Title:  Get up!"
Title:  
Title:  He continued his way toward the Quai des Grands Augustins,
Title:  while the two friends went to ring at the bell of the
Title:  unfortunate Porthos.  He, having seen them crossing the
Title:  yard, took care not to answer, and they rang in vain.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile Mousqueton continued on his way, and crossing the
Title:  Pont Neuf, still driving the two sorry animals before him,
Title:  he reached the Rue aux Ours.  Arrived there, he fastened,
Title:  according to the orders of his master, both horse and mule
Title:  to the knocker of the procurator's door; then, without
Title:  taking any thought for their future, he returned to Porthos,
Title:  and told him that his commission was completed.
Title:  
Title:  In a short time the two unfortunate beasts, who had not
Title:  eaten anything since the morning, made such a noise in
Title:  raising and letting fall the knocker that the procurator
Title:  ordered his errand boy to go and inquire in the neighborhood
Title:  to whom this horse and mule belonged.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Coquenard recognized her present, and could not at
Title:  first comprehend this restitution; but the visit of Porthos
Title:  soon enlightened her.  The anger which fired the eyes of the
Title:  Musketeer, in spite of his efforts to suppress it, terrified
Title:  his sensitive inamorata.  In fact, Mousqueton had not
Title:  concealed from his master that he had met d'Artagnan and
Title:  Aramis, and that d'Artagnan in the yellow horse had
Title:  recognized the Bearnese pony upon which he had come to
Title:  Paris, and which he had sold for three crowns.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos went away after having appointed a meeting with the
Title:  procurator's wife in the cloister of St. Magloire.  The
Title:  procurator, seeing he was going, invited him to dinner--an
Title:  invitation which the Musketeer refused with a majestic air.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Coquenard repaired trembling to the cloister of St.
Title:  Magloire, for she guessed the reproaches that awaited her
Title:  there; but she was fascinated by the lofty airs of Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  All that which a man wounded in his self-love could let fall
Title:  in the shape of imprecations and reproaches upon the head of
Title:  a woman Porthos let fall upon the bowed head of the
Title:  procurator's wife.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas," said she, "I did all for the best! One of our
Title:  clients is a horsedealer; he owes money to the office, and
Title:  is backward in his pay.  I took the mule and the horse for
Title:  what he owed us; he assured me that they were two noble
Title:  steeds."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, madame," said Porthos, "if he owed you more than five
Title:  crowns, your horsedealer is a thief."
Title:  
Title:  "There is no harm in trying to buy things cheap, Monsieur
Title:  Porthos," said the procurator's wife, seeking to excuse
Title:  herself.
Title:  
Title:  "No, madame; but they who so assiduously try to buy things
Title:  cheap ought to permit others to seek more generous friends."
Title:  And Porthos, turning on his heel, made a step to retire.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Porthos!  Monsieur Porthos!" cried the
Title:  procurator's wife.  "I have been wrong; I see it.  I ought
Title:  not to have driven a bargain when it was to equip a cavalier
Title:  like you."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, without reply, retreated a second step.  The
Title:  procurator's wife fancied she saw him in a brilliant cloud,
Title:  all surrounded by duchesses and marchionesses, who cast bags
Title:  of money at his feet.
Title:  
Title:  "Stop, in the name of heaven, Monsieur Porthos!" cried she.
Title:  "Stop, and let us talk."
Title:  
Title:  "Talking with you brings me misfortune," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "But, tell me, what do you ask?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing; for that amounts to the same thing as if I asked
Title:  you for something."
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife hung upon the arm of Porthos, and in
Title:  the violence of her grief she cried out, "Monsieur Porthos,
Title:  I am ignorant of all such matters!  How should I know what a
Title:  horse is?  How should I know what horse furniture is?"
Title:  
Title:  "You should have left it to me, then, madame, who know what
Title:  they are; but you wished to be frugal, and consequently to
Title:  lend at usury."
Title:  
Title:  "It was wrong, Monsieur Porthos; but I will repair that
Title:  wrong, upon my word of honor."
Title:  
Title:  "How so?" asked the Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen.  This evening M. Coquenard is going to the house of
Title:  the Due de Chaulnes, who has sent for him.  It is for a
Title:  consultation, which will last three hours at least.  Come!
Title:  We shall be alone, and can make up our accounts."
Title:  
Title:  "In good time.  Now you talk, my dear."
Title:  
Title:  "You pardon me?"
Title:  
Title:  "We shall see," said Porthos, majestically; and the two
Title:  separated saying, "Till this evening."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" thought Porthos, as he walked away, "it appears
Title:  I am getting nearer to Monsieur Coquenard's strongbox at
Title:  last."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  35  A GASCON A MATCH FOR CUPID
Title:  
Title:  The evening so impatiently waited for by Porthos and by
Title:  d'Artagnan at last arrived.
Title:  
Title:  As was his custom, d'Artagnan presented himself at Milady's
Title:  at about nine o'clock.  He found her in a charming humor.
Title:  Never had he been so well received.  Our Gascon knew, by the
Title:  first glance of his eye, that his billet had been delivered,
Title:  and that this billet had had its effect.
Title:  
Title:  Kitty entered to bring some sherbet.  Her mistress put on a
Title:  charming face, and smiled on her graciously; but alas! the
Title:  poor girl was so sad that she did not even notice Milady's
Title:  condescension.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan looked at the two women, one after the other, and
Title:  was forced to acknowledge that in his opinion Dame Nature
Title:  had made a mistake in their formation.  To the great lady
Title:  she had given a heart vile and venal; to the SOUBRETTE she
Title:  had given the heart of a duchess.
Title:  
Title:  At ten o'clock Milady began to appear restless.  D'Artagnan
Title:  knew what she wanted.  She looked at the clock, rose,
Title:  reseated herself, smiled at d'Artagnan with an air which
Title:  said, "You are very amiable, no doubt, but you would be
Title:  charming if you would only depart."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan rose and took his hat; Milady gave him her hand
Title:  to kiss.  The young man felt her press his hand, and
Title:  comprehended that this was a sentiment, not of coquetry, but
Title:  of gratitude because of his departure.
Title:  
Title:  "She loves him devilishly," he murmured.  Then he went out.
Title:  
Title:  This time Kitty was nowhere waiting for him; neither in the
Title:  antechamber, nor in the corridor, nor beneath the great
Title:  door.  It was necessary that d'Artagnan should find alone
Title:  the staircase and the little chamber.  She heard him enter,
Title:  but she did not raise her head.  The young man went to her
Title:  and took her hands; then she sobbed aloud.
Title:  
Title:  As d'Artagnan had presumed, on receiving his letter, Milady
Title:  in a delirium of joy had told her servant everything; and by
Title:  way of recompense for the manner in which she had this time
