Title:  executed the commission, she had given Kitty a purse.
Title:  
Title:  Returning to her own room, Kitty had thrown the purse into a
Title:  corner, where it lay open, disgorging three or four gold
Title:  pieces on the carpet.  The poor girl, under the caresses of
Title:  d'Artagnan, lifted her head.  D'Artagnan himself was
Title:  frightened by the change in her countenance.  She joined her
Title:  hands with a suppliant air, but without venturing to speak a
Title:  word.  As little sensitive as was the heart of d'Artagnan,
Title:  he was touched by this mute sorrow; but he held too
Title:  tenaciously to his projects, above all to this one, to
Title:  change the program which he had laid out in advance.  He did
Title:  not therefore allow her any hope that he would flinch; only
Title:  he represented his action as one of simple vengeance.
Title:  
Title:  For the rest this vengeance was very easy; for Milady,
Title:  doubtless to conceal her blushes from her lover, had ordered
Title:  Kitty to extinguish all the lights in the apartment, and
Title:  even in the little chamber itself.  Before daybreak M. de
Title:  Wardes must take his departure, still in obscurity.
Title:  
Title:  Presently they heard Milady retire to her room.  D'Artagnan
Title:  slipped into the wardrobe.  Hardly was he concealed when the
Title:  little bell sounded.  Kitty went to her mistress, and did
Title:  not leave the door open; but the partition was so thin that
Title:  one could hear nearly all that passed between the two women.
Title:  
Title:  Milady seemed overcome with joy, and made Kitty repeat the
Title:  smallest details of the pretended interview of the soubrette
Title:  with de Wardes when he received the letter; how he had
Title:  responded; what was the expression of his face; if he seemed
Title:  very amorous.  And to all these questions poor Kitty, forced
Title:  to put on a pleasant face, responded in a stifled voice
Title:  whose dolorous accent her mistress did not however remark,
Title:  solely because happiness is egotistical.
Title:  
Title:  Finally, as the hour for her interview with the count
Title:  approached, Milady had everything about her darkened, and
Title:  ordered Kitty to return to her own chamber, and introduce de
Title:  Wardes whenever he presented himself.
Title:  
Title:  Kitty's detention was not long.  Hardly had d'Artagnan seen,
Title:  through a crevice in his closet, that the whole apartment
Title:  was in obscurity, than he slipped out of his concealment, at
Title:  the very moment when Kitty reclosed the door of communication.
Title:  
Title:  "What is that noise?" demanded Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "It is I," said d'Artagnan in a subdued voice, "I, the Comte
Title:  de Wardes."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God!" murmured Kitty, "he has not even
Title:  waited for the hour he himself named!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Milady, in a trembling voice, "why do you not
Title:  enter?  Count, Count," added she, "you know that I wait for
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  At this appeal d'Artagnan drew Kitty quietly away, and
Title:  slipped into the chamber.
Title:  
Title:  If rage or sorrow ever torture the heart, it is when a lover
Title:  receives under a name which is not his own protestations of
Title:  love addressed to his happy rival.  D'Artagnan was in a
Title:  dolorous situation which he had not foreseen. Jealousy
Title:  gnawed his heart; and he suffered almost as much as poor
Title:  Kitty, who at that very moment was crying in the next
Title:  chamber.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, Count," said Milady, in her softest voice, and
Title:  pressing his hand in her own, "I am happy in the love which
Title:  your looks and your words have expressed to me every time we
Title:  have met.  I also--I love you.  Oh, tomorrow, tomorrow, I
Title:  must have some pledge from you which will prove that you
Title:  think of me; and that you may not forget me, take this!" and
Title:  she slipped a ring from her finger onto d'Artagnan's.
Title:  d'Artagnan remembered having seen this ring on the finger of
Title:  Milady; it was a magnificent sapphire, encircled with
Title:  brilliants.
Title:  
Title:  The first movement of d'Artagnan was to return it, but
Title:  Milady added, "No, no! Keep that ring for love of me.
Title:  Besides, in accepting it," she added, in a voice full of
Title:  emotion, "you render me a much greater service than you
Title:  imagine."
Title:  
Title:  "This woman is full of mysteries," murmured d'Artagnan to
Title:  himself.  At that instant he felt himself ready to reveal
Title:  all.  He even opened his mouth to tell Milady who he was,
Title:  and with what a revengeful purpose he had come; but she
Title:  added, "Poor angel, whom that monster of a Gascon barely
Title:  failed to kill."
Title:  
Title:  The monster was himself.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh," continued Milady, "do your wounds still make you
Title:  suffer?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, much," said d'Artagnan, who did not well know how to
Title:  answer.
Title:  
Title:  "Be tranquil," murmured Milady; "I will avenge you--and
Title:  cruelly!"
Title:  
Title:  "PESTE!" said d'Artagnan to himself, "the moment for
Title:  confidences has not yet come."
Title:  
Title:  It took some time for d'Artagnan to resume this little
Title:  dialogue; but then all the ideas of vengeance which he had
Title:  brought with him had completely vanished.  This woman
Title:  exercised over him an unaccountable power; he hated and
Title:  adored her at the same time.  He would not have believed
Title:  that two sentiments so opposite could dwell in the same
Title:  heart, and by their union constitute a passion so strange,
Title:  and as it were, diabolical.
Title:  
Title:  Presently it sounded one o'clock.  It was necessary to
Title:  separate.  D'Artagnan at the moment of quitting Milady felt
Title:  only the liveliest regret at the parting; and as they
Title:  addressed each other in a reciprocally passionate adieu,
Title:  another interview was arranged for the following week.
Title:  
Title:  Poor Kitty hoped to speak a few words to d'Artagnan when he
Title:  passed through her chamber; but Milady herself reconducted
Title:  him through the darkness, and only quit him at the
Title:  staircase.
Title:  
Title:  The next morning d'Artagnan ran to find Athos.  He was
Title:  engaged in an adventure so singular that he wished for
Title:  counsel.  He therefore told him all.
Title:  
Title:  "Your Milady," said he, "appears to be an infamous creature,
Title:  but not the less you have done wrong to deceive her.  In one
Title:  fashion or another you have a terrible enemy on your hands."
Title:  
Title:  While thus speaking Athos regarded with attention the
Title:  sapphire set with diamonds which had taken, on d'Artagnan's
Title:  finger, the place of the queen's ring, carefully kept in a
Title:  casket.
Title:  
Title:  "You notice my ring?" said the Gascon, proud to display so
Title:  rich a gift in the eyes of his friends.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Athos, "it reminds me of a family jewel."
Title:  
Title:  "It is beautiful, is it not?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Athos, "magnificent.  I did not think two
Title:  sapphires of such a fine water existed.  Have you traded it
Title:  for your diamond?"
Title:  
Title:  "No.  It is a gift from my beautiful Englishwoman, or rather
Title:  Frenchwoman--for I am convinced she was born in France,
Title:  though I have not questioned her."
Title:  
Title:  "That ring comes from Milady?" cried Athos, with a voice in
Title:  which it was easy to detect strong emotion.
Title:  
Title:  "Her very self; she gave it me last night.  Here it is,"
Title:  replied d'Artagnan, taking it from his finger.
Title:  
Title:  Athos examined it and became very pale.  He tried it on his
Title:  left hand; it fit his finger as if made for it.
Title:  
Title:  A shade of anger and vengeance passed across the usually
Title:  calm brow of this gentleman.
Title:  
Title:  "It is impossible it can be she," said be.  "How could this
Title:  ring come into the hands of Milady Clarik?  And yet it is
Title:  difficult to suppose such a resemblance should exist between
Title:  two jewels."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know this ring?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I thought I did," replied Athos; "but no doubt I was
Title:  mistaken."  And he returned d'Artagnan the ring without,
Title:  however, ceasing to look at it.
Title:  
Title:  "Pray, d'Artagnan," said Athos, after a minute, "either take
Title:  off that ring or turn the mounting inside; it recalls such
Title:  cruel recollections that I shall have no head to converse
Title:  with you.  Don't ask me for counsel; don't tell me you are
Title:  perplexed what to do.  But stop! let me look at that
Title:  sapphire again; the one I mentioned to you had one of its
Title:  faces scratched by accident."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took off the ring, giving it again to Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Athos started.  "Look," said he, "is it not strange?" and he
Title:  pointed out to d'Artagnan the scratch he had remembered.
Title:  
Title:  "But from whom did this ring come to you, Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "From my mother, who inherited it from her mother.  As I
Title:  told you, it is an old family jewel."
Title:  
Title:  "And you--sold it?" asked d'Artagnan, hesitatingly.
Title:  
Title:  "No," replied Athos, with a singular smile.  "I gave it away
Title:  in a night of love, as it has been given to you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan became pensive in his turn; it appeared as if
Title:  there were abysses in Milady's soul whose depths were dark
Title:  and unknown.  He took back the ring, but put it in his
Title:  pocket and not on his finger.
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan," said Athos, taking his hand, "you know I love
Title:  you; if I had a son I could not love him better.  Take my
Title:  advice, renounce this woman.  I do not know her, but a sort
Title:  of intuition tells me she is a lost creature, and that there
Title:  is something fatal about her."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right," said d'Artagnan; "I will have done with
Title:  her.  I own that this woman terrifies me."
Title:  
Title:  "Shall you have the courage?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I shall," replied d'Artagnan, "and instantly."
Title:  
Title:  "In truth, my young friend, you will act rightly," said the
Title:  gentleman, pressing the Gascon's hand with an affection
Title:  almost paternal; "and God grant that this woman, who has
Title:  scarcely entered into your life, may not leave a terrible
Title:  trace in it!" And Athos bowed to d'Artagnan like a man who
Title:  wishes it understood that he would not be sorry to be left
Title:  alone with his thoughts.
Title:  
Title:  On reaching home d'Artagnan found Kitty waiting for him.  A
Title:  month of fever could not have changed her more than this one
Title:  night of sleeplessness and sorrow.
Title:  
Title:  She was sent by her mistress to the false de Wardes.  Her
Title:  mistress was mad with love, intoxicated with joy.  She
Title:  wished to know when her lover would meet her a second night;
Title:  and poor Kitty, pale and trembling, awaited d'Artagnan's
Title:  reply.  The counsels of his friend, joined to the cries of
Title:  his own heart, made him determine, now his pride was saved
Title:  and his vengeance satisfied, not to see Milady again.  As a
Title:  reply, he wrote the following letter:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Do not depend upon me, madame, for the next meeting.  Since
Title:  my convalescence I have so many affairs of this kind on my
Title:  hands that I am forced to regulate them a little.  When your
Title:  turn comes, I shall have the honor to inform you of it.  I
Title:  kiss your hands.
Title:  
Title:  Comte de Wardes
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Not a word about the sapphire.  Was the Gascon determined to
Title:  keep it as a weapon against Milady, or else, let us be
Title:  frank, did he not reserve the sapphire as a last resource
Title:  for his outfit?  It would be wrong to judge the actions of
Title:  one period from the point of view of another.  That which
Title:  would now be considered as disgraceful to a gentleman was at
Title:  that time quite a simple and natural affair, and the younger
Title:  sons of the best families were frequently supported by their
Title:  mistresses.  D'Artagnan gave the open letter to Kitty, who
Title:  at first was unable to comprehend it, but who became almost
Title:  wild with joy on reading it a second time.  She could
Title:  scarcely believe in her happiness; and d'Artagnan was forced
Title:  to renew with the living voice the assurances which he had
Title:  written.  And whatever might be--considering the violent
Title:  character of Milady--the danger which the poor girl incurred
Title:  in giving this billet to her mistress, she ran back to the
Title:  Place Royale as fast as her legs could carry her.
Title:  
Title:  The heart of the best woman is pitiless toward the sorrows
Title:  of a rival.
Title:  
Title:  Milady opened the letter with eagerness equal to Kitty's in
Title:  bringing it; but at the first words she read she became
Title:  livid.  She crushed the paper in her hand, and turning with
Title:  flashing eyes upon Kitty, she cried, "What is this letter?"
Title:  
Title:  "The answer to Madame's," replied Kitty, all in a tremble.
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible!" cried Milady.  "It is impossible a gentleman
Title:  could have written such a letter to a woman." Then all at
Title:  once, starting, she cried, "My God! can he have--" and she
Title:  stopped. She ground her teeth; she was of the color of
Title:  ashes.  She tried to go toward the window for air, but she
Title:  could only stretch forth her arms; her legs failed her, and
Title:  she sank into an armchair.  Kitty, fearing she was ill,
Title:  hastened toward her and was beginning to open her dress; but
Title:  Milady started up, pushing her away.  "What do you want with
Title:  me?" said she, "and why do you place your hand on me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I thought that Madame was ill, and I wished to bring her
Title:  help," responded the maid, frightened at the terrible
Title:  expression which had come over her mistress's face.
Title:  
Title:  "I faint?  I? I? Do you take me for half a woman?  When I am
Title:  insulted I do not faint; I avenge myself!"
Title:  
Title:  And she made a sign for Kitty to leave the room.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  36  DREAM OF VENGEANCE
Title:  
Title:  That evening Milady gave orders that when M. d'Artagnan came
Title:  as usual, he should be immediately admitted; but he did not
Title:  come.
Title:  
Title:  The next day Kitty went to see the young man again, and
Title:  related to him all that had passed on the preceding evening.
Title:  d'Artagnan smiled; this jealous anger of Milady was his
Title:  revenge.
Title:  
Title:  That evening Milady was still more impatient than on the
Title:  preceding evening.  She renewed the order relative to the
Title:  Gascon; but as before she expected him in vain.
Title:  
Title:  The next morning, when Kitty presented herself at
Title:  d'Artagnan's, she was no longer joyous and alert as on the
Title:  two preceding days; but on the contrary sad as death.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan asked the poor girl what was the matter with her;
Title:  but she, as her only reply, drew a letter from her pocket
Title:  and gave it to him.
Title:  
Title:  This letter was in Milady's handwriting; only this time it
Title:  was addressed to M. d'Artagnan, and not to M. de Wardes.
Title:  
Title:  He opened it and read as follows:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Dear M. d'Artagnan, It is wrong thus to neglect your
Title:  friends, particularly at the moment you are about to leave
Title:  them for so long a time.  My brother-in-law and myself
Title:  expected you yesterday and the day before, but in vain.
Title:  Will it be the same this evening?
Title:  
Title:  Your very grateful,
Title:  Milady Clarik
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "That's all very simple," said d'Artagnan; "I expected this
Title:  letter. My credit rises by the fall of that of the Comte de
Title:  Wardes."
Title:  
Title:  "And will you go?" asked Kitty.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen to me, my dear girl," said the Gascon, who sought
Title:  for an excuse in his own eyes for breaking the promise he
Title:  had made Athos; "you must understand it would be impolitic
Title:  not to accept such a positive invitation.  Milady, not
Title:  seeing me come again, would not be able to understand what
Title:  could cause the interruption of my visits, and might suspect
Title:  something; who could say how far the vengeance of such a
Title:  woman would go?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!" said Kitty, "you know how to represent things
Title:  in such a way that you are always in the right.  You are
Title:  going now to pay your court to her again, and if this time
Title:  you succeed in pleasing her in your own name and with your
Title:  own face, it will be much worse than before."
Title:  
Title:  Instinct made poor Kitty guess a part of what was to happen.
Title:  d'Artagnan reassured her as well as he could, and promised
Title:  to remain insensible to the seductions of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  He desired Kitty to tell her mistress that he could not be
Title:  more grateful for her kindnesses than he was, and that he
Title:  would be obedient to her orders.  He did not dare to write
Title:  for fear of not being able--to such experienced eyes as those
Title:  of Milady--to disguise his writing sufficiently.
Title:  
Title:  As nine o'clock sounded, d'Artagnan was at the Place Royale.
Title:  It was evident that the servants who waited in the
Title:  antechamber were warned, for as soon as d'Artagnan appeared,
Title:  before even he had asked if Milady were visible, one of them
Title:  ran to announce him.
Title:  
Title:  "Show him in," said Milady, in a quick tone, but so piercing
Title:  that d'Artagnan heard her in the antechamber.
Title:  
Title:  He was introduced.
Title:  
Title:  "I am at home to nobody," said Milady; "observe, to nobody."
Title:  The servant went out.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan cast an inquiring glance at Milady.  She was
Title:  pale, and looked fatigued, either from tears or want of
Title:  sleep.  The number of lights had been intentionally
Title:  diminished, but the young woman could not conceal the traces
Title:  of the fever which had devoured her for two days.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan approached her with his usual gallantry.  She
Title:  then made an extraordinary effort to receive him, but never
Title:  did a more distressed countenance give the lie to a more
Title:  amiable smile.
Title:  
Title:  To the questions which d'Artagnan put concerning her health,
Title:  she replied, "Bad, very bad."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," replied he, "my visit is ill-timed; you, no doubt,
Title:  stand in need of repose, and I will withdraw."
Title:  
Title:  "No. no!" said Milady.  "On the contrary, stay, Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan; your agreeable company will divert me."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, oh!" thought d'Artagnan.  "She has never been so kind
Title:  before.  On guard!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady assumed the most agreeable air possible, and
Title:  conversed with more than her usual brilliancy.  At the same
Title:  time the fever, which for an instant abandoned her, returned
Title:  to give luster to her eyes, color to her cheeks, and
Title:  vermillion to her lips.  D'Artagnan was again in the
Title:  presence of the Circe who had before surrounded him with her
Title:  enchantments.  His love, which he believed to be extinct but
Title:  which was only asleep, awoke again in his heart.  Milady
Title:  smiled, and d'Artagnan felt that he could damn himself for
Title:  that smile.  There was a moment at which he felt something
Title:  like remorse.
Title:  
Title:  By degrees, Milady became more communicative.  She asked
Title:  d'Artagnan if he had a mistress.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!" said d'Artagnan, with the most sentimental air he
Title:  could assume, "can you be cruel enough to put such a
Title:  question to me--to me, who, from the moment I saw you, have
Title:  only breathed and sighed through you and for you?"
Title:  
Title:  Milady smiled with a strange smile.
Title:  
Title:  "Then you love me?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Have I any need to tell you so?  Have you not perceived
Title:  it?"
Title:  
Title:  "It may be; but you know the more hearts are worth the
Title:  capture, the more difficult they are to be won."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, difficulties do not affright me," said d'Artagnan.  "I
Title:  shrink before nothing but impossibilities."
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing is impossible," replied Milady, "to true love."
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, madame?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing," replied Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" thought d'Artagnan.  "The note is changed.  Is
Title:  she going to fall in love with me, by chance, this fair
Title:  inconstant; and will she be disposed to give me myself
Title:  another sapphire like that which she gave me for de Wardes?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan rapidly drew his seat nearer to Milady's.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, now," she said, "let us see what you would do to
Title:  prove this love of which you speak."
Title:  
Title:  "All that could be required of me.  Order; I am ready."
Title:  
Title:  "For everything?"
Title:  
Title:  "For everything," cried d'Artagnan, who knew beforehand that
Title:  he had not much to risk in engaging himself thus.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, now let us talk a little seriously," said Milady, in
Title:  her turn drawing her armchair nearer to d'Artagnan's chair.
Title:  
Title:  "I am all attention, madame," said he.
Title:  
Title:  Milady remained thoughtful and undecided for a moment; then,
Title:  as if appearing to have formed a resolution, she said, "I
Title:  have an enemy."
Title:  
Title:  "You, madame!" said d'Artagnan, affecting surprise; "is
Title:  that possible, my God?--good and beautiful as you are!"
Title:  
Title:  "A mortal enemy."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  "An enemy who has insulted me so cruelly that between him
Title:  and me it is war to the death.  May I reckon on you as an
Title:  auxiliary?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan at once perceived the ground which the vindictive
Title:  creature wished to reach.
Title:  
Title:  "You may, madame," said he, with emphasis.  "My arm and my
Title:  life belong to you, like my love."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said Milady, "since you are as generous as you are
Title:  loving--"
Title:  
Title:  She stopped.
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" demanded d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," replied Milady, after a moment of silence, "from the
Title:  present time, cease to talk of impossibilities."
Title:  
Title:  "Do not overwhelm me with happiness," cried d'Artagnan,
Title:  throwing himself on his knees, and covering with kisses the
Title:  hands abandoned to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Avenge me of that infamous de Wardes," said Milady, between
Title:  her teeth, "and I shall soon know how to get rid of you--you
Title:  double idiot, you animated sword blade!"
Title:  
Title:  "Fall voluntarily into my arms, hypocritical and dangerous
Title:  woman," said d'Artagnan, likewise to himself, "after having
Title:  abused me with such effrontery, and afterward I will laugh
Title:  at you with him whom you wish me to kill."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan lifted up his head.
Title:  
Title:  "I am ready," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "You have understood me, then, dear Monsieur d'Artagnan,"
Title:  said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "I could interpret one of your looks."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you would employ for me your arm which has already
Title:  acquired so much renown?"
Title:  
Title:  "Instantly!"
Title:  
Title:  "But on my part," said Milady, "how should I repay such a
Title:  service?  I know these lovers.  They are men who do nothing
Title:  for nothing."
Title:  
Title:  "You know the only reply that I desire," said d'Artagnan,
Title:  "the only one worthy of you and of me!"
Title:  
Title:  And he drew nearer to her.
Title:  
Title:  She scarcely resisted.
Title:  
Title:  "Interested man!" cried she, smiling.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," cried d'Artagnan, really carried away by the passion
Title:  this woman had the power to kindle in his heart, "ah, that
Title:  is because my happiness appears so impossible to me; and I
Title:  have such fear that it should fly away from me like a dream
Title:  that I pant to make a reality of it."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, merit this pretended happiness, then!"
Title:  
Title:  "I am at your orders," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Quite certain?" said Milady, with a last doubt.
Title:  
Title:  "Only name to me the base man that has brought tears into
Title:  your beautiful eyes!"
Title:  
Title:  "Who told you that I had been weeping?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "It appeared to me--"
Title:  
Title:  "Such women as I never weep," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "So much the better! Come, tell me his name!"
Title:  
Title:  "Remember that his name is all my secret."
Title:  
Title:  "Yet I must know his name."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, you must; see what confidence I have in you!"
Title:  
Title:  "You overwhelm me with joy.  What is his name?"
Title:  
Title:  "You know him."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "It is surely not one of my friends?" replied d'Artagnan,
Title:  affecting hesitation in order to make her believe him
Title:  ignorant.
Title:  
Title:  "If it were one of your friends you would hesitate, then?"
Title:  cried Milady; and a threatening glance darted from her eyes.
Title:  
Title:  "Not if it were my own brother!" cried d'Artagnan, as if
Title:  carried away by his enthusiasm.
Title:  
Title:  Our Gascon promised this without risk, for he knew all that
Title:  was meant.
Title:  
Title:  "I love your devotedness," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, do you love nothing else in me?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I love you also, YOU!" said she, taking his hand.
Title:  
Title:  The warm pressure made d'Artagnan tremble, as if by the
Title:  touch that fever which consumed Milady attacked himself.
Title:  
Title:  "You love me, you!" cried he.  "Oh, if that were so, I should
Title:  lose my reason!"
Title:  
Title:  And he folded her in his arms.  She made no effort to remove
Title:  her lips from his kisses; only she did not respond to them.
Title:  Her lips were cold; it appeared to d'Artagnan that he had
Title:  embraced a statue.
Title:  
Title:  He was not the less intoxicated with joy, electrified by
Title:  love.  He almost believed in the tenderness of Milady; he
Title:  almost believed in the crime of de Wardes.  If de Wardes had
Title:  at that moment been under his hand, he would have killed
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  Milady seized the occasion.
Title:  
Title:  "His name is--" said she, in her turn.
Title:  
Title:  "De Wardes; I know it," cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And how do you know it?" asked Milady, seizing both his
Title:  hands, and endeavoring to read with her eyes to the bottom
Title:  of his heart.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan felt he had allowed himself to be carried away,
Title:  and that he had committed an error.
Title:  
Title:  "Tell me, tell me, tell me, I say," repeated Milady, "how do
Title:  you know it?"
Title:  
Title:  "How do I know it?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "I know it because yesterday Monsieur de Wardes, in a saloon
Title:  where I was, showed a ring which he said he had received
Title:  from you."
Title:  
Title:  "Wretch!" cried Milady.
Title:  
Title:  The epithet, as may be easily understood, resounded to the
Title:  very bottom of d'Artagnan's heart.
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" continued she.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I will avenge you of this wretch," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan, giving himself the airs of Don Japhet of
Title:  Armenia.
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, my brave friend!" cried Milady; "and when shall I
Title:  be avenged?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tomorrow--immediately--when you please!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady was about to cry out, "Immediately," but she
Title:  reflected that such precipitation would not be very gracious
Title:  toward d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, she had a thousand precautions to take, a thousand
Title:  counsels to give to her defender, in order that he might
Title:  avoid explanations with the count before witnesses.  All
Title:  this was answered by an expression of d'Artagnan's.
Title:  "Tomorrow," said he, "you will be avenged, or I shall be
Title:  dead."
Title:  
Title:  "No," said she, "you will avenge me; but you will not be
Title:  dead.  He is a coward."
Title:  
Title:  "With women, perhaps; but not with men.  I know something of
Title:  him."
Title:  
Title:  "But it seems you had not much reason to complain of your
Title:  fortune in your contest with him."
Title:  
Title:  "Fortune is a courtesan; favorable yesterday, she may turn
Title:  her back tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  "Which means that you now hesitate?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, I do not hesitate; God forbid!  But would it be just to
Title:  allow me to go to a possible death without having given me
Title:  at least something more than hope?"
Title:  
Title:  Milady answered by a glance which said, "Is that all?--speak,
Title:  then." And then accompanying the glance with explanatory
Title:  words, "That is but too just," said she, tenderly.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you are an angel!" exclaimed the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Then all is agreed?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Except that which I ask of you, dear love."
Title:  
Title:  "But when I assure you that you may rely on my tenderness?"
Title:  
Title:  "I cannot wait till tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!  I hear my brother.  It will be useless for him to
Title:  find you here."
Title:  
Title:  She rang the bell and Kitty appeared.
Title:  
Title:  "Go out this way," said she, opening a small private door,
Title:  "and come back at eleven o'clock; we will then terminate
Title:  this conversation.  Kitty will conduct you to my chamber."
Title:  
Title:  The poor girl almost fainted at hearing these words.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, mademoiselle, what are you thinking about, standing
Title:  there like a statue?  Do as I bid you: show the chevalier
Title:  out; and this evening at eleven o'clock--you have heard what
Title:  I said."
Title:  
Title:  "It appears that these appointments are all made for eleven
Title:  o'clock," thought d'Artagnan; "that's a settled custom."
Title:  
Title:  Milady held out her hand to him, which he kissed tenderly.
Title:  
Title:  "But," said he, as he retired as quickly as possible from
Title:  the reproaches of Kitty, "I must not play the fool.  This
Title:  woman is certainly a great liar.  I must take care."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  37  MILADY'S SECRET
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan left the hotel instead of going up at once to
Title:  Kitty's chamber, as she endeavored to persuade him to do--and
Title:  that for two reasons: the first, because by this means he
Title:  should escape reproaches, recriminations, and prayers; the
Title:  second, because he was not sorry to have an opportunity of
Title:  reading his own thoughts and endeavoring, if possible, to
Title:  fathom those of this woman.
Title:  
Title:  What was most clear in the matter was that d'Artagnan loved
Title:  Milady like a madman, and that she did not love him at all.
Title:  In an instant d'Artagnan perceived that the best way in
Title:  which he could act would be to go home and write Milady a
Title:  long letter, in which he would confess to her that he and de
Title:  Wardes were, up to the present moment absolutely the same,
Title:  and that consequently he could not undertake, without
Title:  committing suicide, to kill the Comte de Wardes.  But he
Title:  also was spurred on by a ferocious desire of vengeance.  He
Title:  wished to subdue this woman in his own name; and as this
Title:  vengeance appeared to him to have a certain sweetness in it,
Title:  he could not make up his mind to renounce it.
Title:  
Title:  He walked six or seven times round the Place Royale, turning
Title:  at every ten steps to look at the light in Milady's
Title:  apartment, which was to be seen through the blinds.  It was
Title:  evident that this time the young woman was not in such haste
Title:  to retire to her apartment as she had been the first.
Title:  
Title:  At length the light disappeared.  With this light was
Title:  extinguished the last irresolution in the heart of
Title:  d'Artagnan.  He recalled to his mind the details of the
Title:  first night, and with a beating heart and a brain on fire he
Title:  re-entered the hotel and flew toward Kitty's chamber.
Title:  
Title:  The poor girl, pale as death and trembling in all her limbs,
Title:  wished to delay her lover; but Milady, with her ear on the
Title:  watch, had heard the noise d'Artagnan had made, and opening
Title:  the door, said, "Come in."
Title:  
Title:  All this was of such incredible immodesty, of such monstrous
Title:  effrontery, that d'Artagnan could scarcely believe what he
Title:  saw or what he heard.  He imagined himself to be drawn into
Title:  one of those fantastic intrigues one meets in dreams.  He,
Title:  however, darted not the less quickly toward Milady, yielding
Title:  to that magnetic attraction which the loadstone exercises
Title:  over iron.
Title:  
Title:  As the door closed after them Kitty rushed toward it.
Title:  Jealousy, fury, offended pride, all the passions in short
Title:  that dispute the heart of an outraged woman in love, urged
Title:  her to make a revelation; but she reflected that she would
Title:  be totally lost if she confessed having assisted in such a
Title:  machination, and above all, that d'Artagnan would also be
Title:  lost to her forever.  This last thought of love counseled
Title:  her to make this last sacrifice.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, on his part, had gained the summit of all his
Title:  wishes.  It was no longer a rival who was beloved; it was
Title:  himself who was apparently beloved.  A secret voice
Title:  whispered to him, at the bottom of his heart, that he was
Title:  but an instrument of vengeance, that he was only caressed
Title:  till he had given death; but pride, but self-love, but
Title:  madness silenced this voice and stifled its murmurs.  And
Title:  then our Gascon, with that large quantity of conceit which
Title:  we know he possessed, compared himself with de Wardes, and
Title:  asked himself why, after all, he should not be beloved for
Title:  himself?
Title:  
Title:  He was absorbed entirely by the sensations of the moment.
Title:  Milady was no longer for him that woman of fatal intentions
Title:  who had for a moment terrified him; she was an ardent,
Title:  passionate mistress, abandoning herself to love which she
Title:  also seemed to feel.  Two hours thus glided away.  When the
Title:  transports of the two lovers were calmer, Milady, who had
Title:  not the same motives for forgetfulness that d'Artagnan had,
Title:  was the first to return to reality, and asked the young man
Title:  if the means which were on the morrow to bring on the
Title:  encounter between him and de Wardes were already arranged in
Title:  his mind.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan, whose ideas had taken quite another course,
Title:  forgot himself like a fool, and answered gallantly that it
Title:  was too late to think about duels and sword thrusts.
Title:  
Title:  This coldness toward the only interests that occupied her
Title:  mind terrified Milady, whose questions became more pressing.
Title:  
Title:  Then d'Artagnan, who had never seriously thought of this
Title:  impossible duel, endeavored to turn the conversation; but he
Title:  could not succeed.  Milady kept him within the limits she
Title:  had traced beforehand with her irresistible spirit and her
Title:  iron will.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan fancied himself very cunning when advising Milady
Title:  to renounce, by pardoning de Wardes, the furious projects
Title:  she had formed.
Title:  
Title:  But at the first word the young woman started, and exclaimed
Title:  in a sharp, bantering tone, which sounded strangely in the
Title:  darkness, "Are you afraid, dear Monsieur d'Artagnan?"
Title:  
Title:  "You cannot think so, dear love!" replied d'Artagnan; "but
Title:  now, suppose this poor Comte de Wardes were less guilty than
Title:  you think him?"
Title:  
Title:  "At all events," said Milady, seriously, "he has deceived
Title:  me, and from the moment he deceived me, he merited death."
Title:  
Title:  "He shall die, then, since you condemn him!" said
Title:  d'Artagnan, in so firm a tone that it appeared to Milady an
Title:  undoubted proof of devotion.  This reassured her.
Title:  
Title:  We cannot say how long the night seemed to Milady, but
Title:  d'Artagnan believed it to be hardly two hours before the
Title:  daylight peeped through the window blinds, and invaded the
Title:  chamber with its paleness.  Seeing d'Artagnan about to leave
Title:  her, Milady recalled his promise to avenge her on the Comte
Title:  de Wardes.
Title:  
Title:  "I am quite ready," said d'Artagnan; "but in the first place
Title:  I should like to be certain of one thing."
Title:  
Title:  "And what is that?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "That is, whether you really love me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have given you proof of that, it seems to me."
Title:  
Title:  "And I am yours, body and soul!"
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, my brave lover; but as you are satisfied of my
Title:  love, you must, in your turn, satisfy me of yours.  Is it
Title:  not so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly; but if you love me as much as you say," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan, "do you not entertain a little fear on my
Title:  account?"
Title:  
Title:  "What have I to fear?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, that I may be dangerously wounded--killed even."
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible!" cried Milady, "you are such a valiant man, and
Title:  such an expert swordsman."
Title:  
Title:  "You would not, then, prefer a method," resumed d'Artagnan,
Title:  "which would equally avenge you while rendering the combat
Title:  useless?"
Title:  
Title:  Milady looked at her lover in silence.  The pale light of
Title:  the first rays of day gave to her clear eyes a strangely
Title:  frightful expression.
Title:  
Title:  "Really," said she, "I believe you now begin to hesitate."
Title:  
Title:  "No, I do not hesitate; but I really pity this poor Comte de
Title:  Wardes, since you have ceased to love him.  I think that a
Title:  man must be so severely punished by the loss of your love
Title:  that he stands in need of no other chastisement."
Title:  
Title:  "Who told you that I loved him?" asked Milady, sharply.
Title:  
Title:  "At least, I am now at liberty to believe, without too much
Title:  fatuity, that you love another," said the young man, in a
Title:  caressing tone, "and I repeat that I am really interested
Title:  for the count."
Title:  
Title:  "You?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I."
Title:  
Title:  "And why YOU?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because I alone know--"
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "That he is far from being, or rather having been, so guilty
Title:  toward you as he appears."
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!" said Milady, in an anxious tone; "explain
Title:  yourself, for I really cannot tell what you mean."
Title:  
Title:  And she looked at d'Artagnan, who embraced her tenderly,
Title:  with eyes which seemed to burn themselves away.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; I am a man of honor," said d'Artagnan, determined to
Title:  come to an end, "and since your love is mine, and I am
Title:  satisfied I possess it--for I do possess it, do I not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Entirely; go on."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I feel as if transformed--a confession weighs on my
Title:  mind."
Title:  
Title:  "A confession!"
Title:  
Title:  "If I had the least doubt of your love I would not make it,
Title:  but you love me, my beautiful mistress, do you not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt."
Title:  
Title:  "Then if through excess of love I have rendered myself
Title:  culpable toward you, you will pardon me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan tried with his sweetest smile to touch his lips
Title:  to Milady's, but she evaded him.
Title:  
Title:  "This confession," said she, growing paler, "what is this
Title:  confession?"
Title:  
Title:  "You gave de Wardes a meeting on Thursday last in this very
Title:  room, did you not?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, no! It is not true," said Milady, in a tone of voice so
Title:  firm, and with a countenance so unchanged, that if
Title:  d'Artagnan had not been in such perfect possession of the
Title:  fact, he would have doubted.
Title:  
Title:  "Do not lie, my angel," said d'Artagnan, smiling; "that
Title:  would be useless."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean?  Speak! you kill me."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied; you are not guilty toward me, and I have
Title:  already pardoned you."
Title:  
Title:  "What next? what next?"
Title:  
Title:  "De Wardes cannot boast of anything."
Title:  
Title:  "How is that?  You told me yourself that that ring--"
Title:  
Title:  "That ring I have! The Comte de Wardes of Thursday and the
Title:  d'Artagnan of today are the same person."
Title:  
Title:  The imprudent young man expected a surprise, mixed with
Title:  shame--a slight storm which would resolve itself into tears;
Title:  but he was strangely deceived, and his error was not of long
Title:  duration.
Title:  
Title:  Pale and trembling, Milady repulsed d'Artagnan's attempted
Title:  embrace by a violent blow on the chest, as she sprang out of
Title:  bed.
Title:  
Title:  It was almost broad daylight.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan detained her by her night dress of fine India
Title:  linen, to implore her pardon; but she, with a strong
Title:  movement, tried to escape.  Then the cambric was torn from
Title:  her beautiful shoulders; and on one of those lovely
Title:  shoulders, round and white, d'Artagnan recognized, with
Title:  inexpressible astonishment, the FLEUR-DE-LIS--that indelible
Title:  mark which the hand of the infamous executioner had
Title:  imprinted.
Title:  
Title:  "Great God!" cried d'Artagnan, loosing his hold of her
Title:  dress, and remaining mute, motionless, and frozen.
Title:  
Title:  But Milady felt herself denounced even by his terror.  He
Title:  had doubtless seen all.  The young man now knew her secret,
Title:  her terrible secret--the secret she concealed even from her
Title:  maid with such care, the secret of which all the world was
Title:  ignorant, except himself.
Title:  
Title:  She turned upon him, no longer like a furious woman, but
Title:  like a wounded panther.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, wretch!" cried she, "you have basely betrayed me, and
Title:  still more, you have my secret!  You shall die."
Title:  
Title:  And she flew to a little inlaid casket which stood upon the
Title:  dressing table, opened it with a feverish and trembling
Title:  band, drew from it a small poniard, with a golden haft and a
Title:  sharp thin blade, and then threw herself with a bound upon
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  Although the young man was brave, as we know, he was
Title:  terrified at that wild countenance, those terribly dilated
Title:  pupils, those pale cheeks, and those bleeding lips.  He
Title:  recoiled to the other side of the room as he would have done
Title:  from a serpent which was crawling toward him, and his sword
Title:  coming in contact with his nervous hand, he drew it almost
Title:  unconsciously from the scabbard.  But without taking any
Title:  heed of the sword, Milady endeavored to get near enough to
Title:  him to stab him, and did not stop till she felt the sharp
Title:  point at her throat.
Title:  
Title:  She then tried to seize the sword with her hands; but
Title:  d'Artagnan kept it free from her grasp, and presenting the
Title:  point, sometimes at her eyes, sometimes at her breast,
Title:  compelled her to glide behind the bedstead, while he aimed
Title:  at making his retreat by the door which led to Kitty's
Title:  apartment.
Title:  
Title:  Milady during this time continued to strike at him with
Title:  horrible fury, screaming in a formidable way.
Title:  
Title:  As all this, however, bore some resemblance to a duel,
Title:  d'Artagnan began to recover himself little by little.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, beautiful lady, very well," said he; "but, PARDIEU,
Title:  if you don't calm yourself, I will design a second
Title:  FLEUR-DE-LIS upon one of those pretty cheeks!"
Title:  
Title:  "Scoundrel, infamous scoundrel!" howled Milady.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan, still keeping on the defensive, drew near to
Title:  Kitty's door.  At the noise they made, she in overturning
Title:  the furniture in her efforts to get at him, he in screening
Title:  himself behind the furniture to keep out of her reach, Kitty
Title:  opened the door.  D'Artagnan, who had unceasingly maneuvered
Title:  to gain this point, was not at more than three paces from
Title:  it.  With one spring he flew from the chamber of Milady into
Title:  that of the maid, and quick as lightning, he slammed to the
Title:  door, and placed all his weight against it, while Kitty
Title:  pushed the bolts.
Title:  
Title:  Then Milady attempted to tear down the doorcase, with a
Title:  strength apparently above that of a woman; but finding she
Title:  could not accomplish this, she in her fury stabbed at the
Title:  door with her poniard, the point of which repeatedly
Title:  glittered through the wood. Every blow was accompanied with
Title:  terrible imprecations.
Title:  
Title:  "Quick, Kitty, quick!" said d'Artagnan, in a low voice, as
Title:  soon as the bolts were fast, "let me get out of the hotel;
Title:  for if we leave her time to turn round, she will have me
Title:  killed by the servants."
Title:  
Title:  "But you can't go out so," said Kitty; "you are naked."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said d'Artagnan, then first thinking of the
Title:  costume he found himself in, "that's true.  But dress me as
Title:  well as you are able, only make haste; think, my dear girl,
Title:  it's life and death!"
Title:  
Title:  Kitty was but too well aware of that.  In a turn of the hand
Title:  she muffled him up in a flowered robe, a large hood, and a
Title:  cloak.  She gave him some slippers, in which he placed his
Title:  naked feet, and then conducted him down the stairs.  It was
Title:  time.  Milady had already rung her bell, and roused the
Title:  whole hotel.  The porter was drawing the cord at the moment
Title:  Milady cried from her window, "Don't open!"
Title:  
Title:  The young man fled while she was still threatening him with
Title:  an impotent gesture.  The moment she lost sight of him,
Title:  Milady tumbled fainting into her chamber.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  38  HOW, WITHOUT INCOMMODING HIMSELF, ATHOS PROCURES HIS EQUIPMENT
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was so completely bewildered that without taking
Title:  any heed of what might become of Kitty he ran at full speed
Title:  across half Paris, and did not stop till he came to Athos's
Title:  door.  The confusion of his mind, the terror which spurred
Title:  him on, the cries of some of the patrol who started in
Title:  pursuit of him, and the hooting of the people who,
Title:  notwithstanding the early hour, were going to their work,
Title:  only made him precipitate his course.
Title:  
Title:  He crossed the court, ran up the two flights to Athos's
Title:  apartment, and knocked at the door enough to break it down.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud came, rubbing his half-open eyes, to answer this
Title:  noisy summons, and d'Artagnan sprang with such violence into
Title:  the room as nearly to overturn the astonished lackey.
Title:  
Title:  In spite of his habitual silence, the poor lad this time
Title:  found his speech.
Title:  
Title:  "Holloa, there!" cried he; "what do you want, you strumpet?
Title:  What's your business here, you hussy?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan threw off his hood, and disengaged his hands from
Title:  the folds of the cloak.  At sight of the mustaches and the
Title:  naked sword, the poor devil perceived he had to deal with a
Title:  man.  He then concluded it must be an assassin.
Title:  
Title:  "Help! murder! help!" cried he.
Title:  
Title:  "Hold your tongue, you stupid fellow!" said the young man; "I am
Title:  d'Artagnan; don't you know me?  Where is your master?"
Title:  
Title:  "You, Monsieur d'Artagnan!" cried Grimaud, "impossible."
Title:  
Title:  "Grimaud," said Athos, coming out of his apartment in a
Title:  dressing gown, "Grimaud, I thought I heard you permitting
Title:  yourself to speak?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur, it is--"
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!"
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud contented himself with pointing d'Artagnan out to
Title:  his master with his finger.
Title:  
Title:  Athos recognized his comrade, and phlegmatic as he was, he
Title:  burst into a laugh which was quite excused by the strange
Title:  masquerade before his eyes--petticoats falling over his
Title:  shoes, sleeves tucked up, and mustaches stiff with
Title:  agitation.
Title:  
Title:  "Don't laugh, my friend!" cried d'Artagnan; "for heaven's
Title:  sake, don't laugh, for upon my soul, it's no laughing
Title:  matter!"
Title:  
Title:  And he pronounced these words with such a solemn air and
Title:  with such a real appearance of terror, that Athos eagerly
Title:  seized his hand, crying, "Are you wounded, my friend?  How
Title:  pale you are!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, but I have just met with a terrible adventure!  Are you
Title:  alone, Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "PARBLEU! whom do you expect to find with me at this hour?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, well!" and d'Artagnan rushed into Athos's chamber.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, speak!" said the latter, closing the door and bolting
Title:  it, that they might not be disturbed.  "Is the king dead?
Title:  Have you killed the cardinal?  You are quite upset!  Come,
Title:  come, tell me; I am dying with curiosity and uneasiness!"
Title:  
Title:  "Athos," said d'Artagnan, getting rid of his female
Title:  garments, and appearing in his shirt, "prepare yourself to
Title:  hear an incredible, an unheard-of story."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but put on this dressing gown first," said the
Title:  Musketeer to his friend.

Title:  
Title:  As the Gascon had foreseen, they easily obtained three
Title:  hundred pistoles on the ring.  Still further, the Jew told
Title:  them that if they would sell it to him, as it would make a
Title:  magnificent pendant for earrings, he would give five hundred

Title:  
Title:  Athos and d'Artagnan, with the activity of two soldiers and
Title:  the knowledge of two connoisseurs, hardly required three
Title:  hours to purchase the entire equipment of the Musketeer.
Title:  Besides, Athos was very easy, and a noble to his fingers'

Title:  without thinking to ask for any abatement.  D'Artagnan would
Title:  have remonstrated at this; but Athos put his hand upon his
Title:  shoulder, with a smile, and d'Artagnan understood that it

Title:  Andalusian horse, black as jet, nostrils of fire, legs clean
Title:  and elegant, rising six years.  He examined him, and found
Title:  him sound and without blemish.  They asked a thousand livres
Title:  for him.
Title:  
Title:  He might perhaps have been bought for less; but while
Title:  d'Artagnan was discussing the price with the dealer, Athos
Title:  was counting out the money on the table.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud had a stout, short Picard cob, which cost three
Title:  hundred livres.
Title:  
Title:  But when the saddle and arms for Grimaud were purchased,
Title:  Athos had not a sou left of his hundred and fifty pistoles.

Title:  "What!  will you--"
Title:  
Title:  "This ring would certainly only recall very bitter

Title:  "Reflect, Athos!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ready money is needful for the present time, and we must

Title:  A half hour afterward, d'Artagnan returned with the two

Title:  
Title:  It was thus Athos found at home resources which he did not
Title:  expect.

Title:  
Title:  39  A VISION
Title:  
Title:  At four o'clock the four friends were all assembled with
Title:  Athos.  Their anxiety about their outfits had all
Title:  disappeared, and each countenance only preserved the
Title:  expression of its own secret disquiet--for behind all present
Title:  happiness is concealed a fear for the future.
Title:  
Title:  Suddenly Planchet entered, bringing two letters for
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  The one was a little billet, genteelly folded, with a pretty
Title:  seal in green wax on which was impressed a dove bearing a
Title:  green branch.
Title:  
Title:  The other was a large square epistle, resplendent with the
Title:  terrible arms of his Eminence the cardinal duke.
Title:  
Title:  At the sight of the little letter the heart of d'Artagnan
Title:  bounded, for he believed he recognized the handwriting, and
Title:  although he had seen that writing but once, the memory of it
Title:  remained at the bottom of his heart.
Title:  
Title:  He therefore seized the little epistle, and opened it
Title:  eagerly.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Be," said the letter, "on Thursday next, at from six to
Title:  seven o'clock in the evening, on the road to Chaillot, and
Title:  look carefully into the carriages that pass; but if you have
Title:  any consideration for your own life or that of those who
Title:  love you, do not speak a single word, do not make a movement
Title:  which may lead anyone to believe you have recognized her who
Title:  exposes herself to everything for the sake of seeing you but
Title:  for an instant."
Title:  
Title:  No signature.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "That's a snare," said Athos; "don't go, d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," replied d'Artagnan, "I think I recognize the
Title:  writing."
Title:  
Title:  "It may be counterfeit," said Athos.  "Between six and seven
Title:  o'clock the road of Chaillot is quite deserted; you might as
Title:  well go and ride in the forest of Bondy."
Title:  
Title:  "But suppose we all go," said d'Artagnan; "what the devil!
Title:  They won't devour us all four, four lackeys, horses, arms,
Title:  and all!"
Title:  
Title:  "And besides, it will be a chance for displaying our new
Title:  equipments," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "But if it is a woman who writes," said Aramis, "and that
Title:  woman desires not to be seen, remember, you compromise her,
Title:  d'Artagnan; which is not the part of a gentleman."
Title:  
Title:  "We will remain in the background," said Porthos, "and he
Title:  will advance alone."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but a pistol shot is easily fired from a carriage
Title:  which goes at a gallop."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!" said d'Artagnan, "they will miss me; if they fire we
Title:  will ride after the carriage, and exterminate those who may
Title:  be in it.  They must be enemies."
Title:  
Title:  "He is right," said Porthos; "battle.  Besides, we must try
Title:  our own arms."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah, let us enjoy that pleasure," said Aramis, with his
Title:  mild and careless manner.
Title:  
Title:  "As you please," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, "it is half past four, and we
Title:  have scarcely time to be on the road of Chaillot by six."
Title:  
Title:  "Besides, if we go out too late, nobody will see us," said
Title:  Porthos, "and that will be a pity.  Let us get ready,
Title:  gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  "But this second letter," said Athos, "you forget that; it
Title:  appears to me, however, that the seal denotes that it
Title:  deserves to be opened.  For my part, I declare, d'Artagnan,
Title:  I think it of much more consequence than the little piece of
Title:  waste paper you have so cunningly slipped into your bosom."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan blushed.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said he, "let us see, gentlemen, what are his
Title:  Eminence's commands," and d'Artagnan unsealed the letter and
Title:  read,
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "M. d'Artagnan, of the king's Guards, company Dessessart, is
Title:  expected at the Palais-Cardinal this evening, at eight
Title:  o'clock.
Title:  
Title:  "La Houdiniere, CAPTAIN OF THE GUARDS"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said Athos; "here's a rendezvous much more
Title:  serious than the other."
Title:  
Title:  "I will go to the second after attending the first," said
Title:  d'Artagnan.  "One is for seven o'clock, and the other for
Title:  eight; there will be time for both."
Title:  
Title:  "Hum!  I would not go at all," said Aramis.  "A gallant
Title:  knight cannot decline a rendezvous with a lady; but a
Title:  prudent gentleman may excuse himself from not waiting on his
Title:  Eminence, particularly when he has reason to believe he is
Title:  not invited to make his compliments."
Title:  
Title:  "I am of Aramis's opinion," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," replied d'Artagnan, "I have already received by
Title:  Monsieur de Cavois a similar invitation from his Eminence.
Title:  I neglected it, and on the morrow a serious misfortune
Title:  happened to me--Constance disappeared.  Whatever may ensue, I
Title:  will go."
Title:  
Title:  "If you are determined," said Athos, "do so."
Title:  
Title:  "But the Bastille?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Bah! you will get me out if they put me there," said

Title:  
Title:  "To be sure we will," replied Aramis and Porthos, with

Title:

Title:  Monsieur de Treville must think us dead."
Title:  
Title:  "To a certainty, Athos," said Aramis, "you were meant to be

Title:  
Title:  "Admirable!" replied the young men in chorus.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos, "I will run to the hotel, and engage

Title:  o'clock; the rendezvous, the Place du Palais-Cardinal.
Title:  Meantime, you see that the lackeys saddle the horses."
Title:  
Title:  "I have no horse," said d'Artagnan; "but that is of no
Title:  consequence, I can take one of Monsieur de Treville's."
Title:  
Title:  "That is not worth while," said Aramis, "you can have one of
Title:  mine."
Title:  
Title:  "One of yours! how many have you, then?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Three," replied Aramis, smiling.
Title:  
Title:  "Certes," cried Athos, "you are the best-mounted poet of
Title:  France or Navarre."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, my dear Aramis, you don't want three horses?  I
Title:  cannot comprehend what induced you to buy three!"
Title:  
Title:  "Therefore I only purchased two," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "The third, then, fell from the clouds, I suppose?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, the third was brought to me this very morning by a
Title:  groom out of livery, who would not tell me in whose service
Title:  he was, and who said he had received orders from his
Title:  master."
Title:  
Title:  "Or his mistress," interrupted d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "That makes no difference," said Aramis, coloring; "and who
Title:  affirmed, as I said, that he had received orders from his
Title:  master or mistress to place the horse in my stable, without
Title:  informing me whence it came."
Title:  
Title:  "It is only to poets that such things happen," said Athos,
Title:  gravely.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, in that case, we can manage famously," said
Title:  d'Artagnan; "which of the two horses will you ride--that
Title:  which you bought or the one that was given to you?"
Title:  
Title:  "That which was given to me, assuredly.  You cannot for a
Title:  moment imagine, d'Artagnan, that I would commit such an
Title:  offense toward--"
Title:  
Title:  "The unknown giver," interrupted d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Or the mysterious benefactress," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "The one you bought will then become useless to you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nearly so."
Title:  
Title:  "And you selected it yourself?"
Title:  
Title:  "With the greatest care.  The safety of the horseman, you
Title:  know, depends almost always upon the goodness of his horse."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, transfer it to me at the price it cost you?"
Title:  
Title:  "I was going to make you the offer, my dear d'Artagnan,
Title:  giving you all the time necessary for repaying me such a
Title:  trifle."
Title:  
Title:  "How much did it cost you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Eight hundred livres."
Title:  
Title:  "Here are forty double pistoles, my dear friend," said
Title:  d'Artagnan, taking the sum from his pocket; "I know that is
Title:  the coin in which you were paid for your poems."
Title:  
Title:  "You are rich, then?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Rich?  Richest, my dear fellow!"
Title:  
Title:  And d'Artagnan chinked the remainder of his pistoles in his
Title:  pocket.
Title:  
Title:  "Send your saddle, then, to the hotel of the Musketeers, and
Title:  your horse can be brought back with ours."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well; but it is already five o'clock, so make haste."
Title:  
Title:  A quarter of an hour afterward Porthos appeared at the end
Title:  of the Rue Ferou on a very handsome genet.  Mousqueton
Title:  followed him upon an Auvergne horse, small but very
Title:  handsome.  Porthos was resplendent with joy and pride.
Title:  
Title:  At the same time, Aramis made his appearance at the other
Title:  end of the street upon a superb English charger.  Bazin
Title:  followed him upon a roan, holding by the halter a vigorous
Title:  Mecklenburg horse; this was d'Artagnan mount.
Title:  
Title:  The two Musketeers met at the gate.  Athos and d'Artagnan
Title:  watched their approach from the window.
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" cried Aramis, "you have a magnificent horse
Title:  there, Porthos."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," replied Porthos, "it is the one that ought to have
Title:  been sent to me at first.  A bad joke of the husband's
Title:  substituted the other; but the husband has been punished
Title:  since, and I have obtained full satisfaction."
Title:  
Title:  Planchet and Grimaud appeared in their turn, leading their
Title:  masters' steeds.  D'Artagnan and Athos put themselves into
Title:  saddle with their companions, and all four set forward;
Title:  Athos upon a horse he owed to a woman, Aramis on a horse he
Title:  owed to his mistress, Porthos on a horse he owed to his
Title:  procurator's wife, and d'Artagnan on a horse he owed to his
Title:  good fortune--the best mistress possible.
Title:  
Title:  The lackeys followed.
Title:  
Title:  As Porthos had foreseen, the cavalcade produced a good
Title:  effect; and if Mme.  Coquenard had met Porthos and seen what
Title:  a superb appearance he made upon his handsome Spanish genet,
Title:  she would not have regretted the bleeding she had inflicted
Title:  upon the strongbox of her husband.
Title:  
Title:  Near the Louvre the four friends met with M. de Treville,
Title:  who was returning from St. Germain; he stopped them to offer
Title:  his compliments upon their appointments, which in an instant
Title:  drew round them a hundred gapers.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan profited by the circumstance to speak to M. de
Title:  Treville of the letter with the great red seal and the
Title:  cardinal's arms.  It is well understood that he did not
Title:  breathe a word about the other.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville approved of the resolution he had adopted,
Title:  and assured him that if on the morrow he did not appear, he
Title:  himself would undertake to find him, let him be where he
Title:  might.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment the clock of La Samaritaine struck six; the
Title:  four friends pleaded an engagement, and took leave of M. de
Title:  Treville.
Title:  
Title:  A short gallop brought them to the road of Chaillot; the day
Title:  began to decline, carriages were passing and repassing.
Title:  d'Artagnan, keeping at some distance from his friends,
Title:  darted a scrutinizing glance into every carriage that
Title:  appeared, but saw no face with which he was acquainted.
Title:  
Title:  At length, after waiting a quarter of an hour and just as
Title:  twilight was beginning to thicken, a carriage appeared,
Title:  coming at a quick pace on the road of Sevres.  A
Title:  presentiment instantly told d'Artagnan that this carriage
Title:  contained the person who had appointed the rendezvous; the
Title:  young man was himself astonished to find his heart beat so
Title:  violently.  Almost instantly a female head was put out at
Title:  the window, with two fingers placed upon her mouth, either
Title:  to enjoin silence or to send him a kiss.  D'Artagnan uttered
Title:  a slight cry of joy; this woman, or rather this apparition--
Title:  for the carriage passed with the rapidity of a vision--was
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  By an involuntary movement and in spite of the injunction
Title:  given, d'Artagnan put his horse into a gallop, and in a few
Title:  strides overtook the carriage; but the window was
Title:  hermetically closed, the vision had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan then remembered the injunction: "If you value
Title:  your own life or that of those who love you, remain
Title:  motionless, and as if you had seen nothing."
Title:  
Title:  He stopped, therefore, trembling not for himself but for the
Title:  poor woman who had evidently exposed herself to great danger
Title:  by appointing this rendezvous.
Title:  
Title:  The carriage pursued its way, still going at a great pace,
Title:  till it dashed into Paris, and disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan remained fixed to the spot, astounded and not
Title:  knowing what to think.  If it was Mme.  Bonacieux and if she
Title:  was returning to Paris, why this fugitive rendezvous, why
Title:  this simple exchange of a glance, why this lost kiss?  If,
Title:  on the other side, it was not she--which was still quite
Title:  possible--for the little light that remained rendered a
Title:  mistake easy--might it not be the commencement of some plot
Title:  against him through the allurement of this woman, for whom
Title:  his love was known?
Title:  
Title:  His three companions joined him.  All had plainly seen a
Title:  woman's head appear at the window, but none of them, except
Title:  Athos, knew Mme.  Bonacieux.  The opinion of Athos was that
Title:  it was indeed she; but less preoccupied by that pretty face
Title:  than d'Artagnan, he had fancied he saw a second head, a
Title:  man's head, inside the carriage.
Title:  
Title:  "If that be the case," said d'Artagnan, "they are doubtless
Title:  transporting her from one prison to another.  But what can
Title:  they intend to do with the poor creature, and how shall I
Title:  ever meet her again?"
Title:  
Title:  "Friend," said Athos, gravely, "remember that it is the dead
Title:  alone with whom we are not likely to meet again on this
Title:  earth.  You know something of that, as well as I do, I
Title:  think.  Now, if your mistress is not dead, if it is she we
Title:  have just seen, you will meet with her again some day or
Title:  other.  And perhaps, my God!" added he, with that
Title:  misanthropic tone which was peculiar to him, "perhaps sooner
Title:  than you wish."
Title:  
Title:  Half past seven had sounded.  The carriage had been twenty
Title:  minutes behind the time appointed.  D'Artagnan's friends
Title:  reminded him that he had a visit to pay, but at the same
Title:  time bade him observe that there was yet time to retract.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan was at the same time impetuous and curious.
Title:  He had made up his mind that he would go to the Palais-
Title:  Cardinal, and that he would learn what his Eminence had to
Title:  say to him.  Nothing could turn him from his purpose.
Title:  
Title:  They reached the Rue St. Honore, and in the Place du Palais-
Title:  Cardinal they found the twelve invited Musketeers, walking
Title:  about in expectation of their comrades.  There only they
Title:  explained to them the matter in hand.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was well known among the honorable corps of the
Title:  king's Musketeers, in which it was known he would one day
Title:  take his place; he was considered beforehand as a comrade.
Title:  It resulted from these antecedents that everyone entered
Title:  heartily into the purpose for which they met; besides, it
Title:  would not be unlikely that they would have an opportunity of
Title:  playing either the cardinal or his people an ill turn, and
Title:  for such expeditions these worthy gentlemen were always
Title:  ready.
Title:  
Title:  Athos divided them into three groups, assumed the command of
Title:  one, gave the second to Aramis, and the third to Porthos;
Title:  and then each group went and took their watch near an
Title:  entrance.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, on his part, entered boldly at the principal
Title:  gate.
Title:  
Title:  Although he felt himself ably supported, the young man was
Title:  not without a little uneasiness as he ascended the great
Title:  staircase, step by step.  His conduct toward Milady bore a
Title:  strong resemblance to treachery, and he was very suspicious
Title:  of the political relations which existed between that woman
Title:  and the cardinal.  Still further, de Wardes, whom he had
Title:  treated so ill, was one of the tools of his Eminence; and
Title:  d'Artagnan knew that while his Eminence was terrible to his
Title:  enemies, he was strongly attached to his friends.
Title:  
Title:  "If de Wardes has related all our affair to the cardinal,
Title:  which is not to be doubted, and if he has recognized me, as
Title:  is probable, I may consider myself almost as a condemned
Title:  man," said d'Artagnan, shaking his head.  "But why has he
Title:  waited till now?  That's all plain enough.  Milady has laid
Title:  her complaints against me with that hypocritical grief which
Title:  renders her so interesting, and this last offense has made
Title:  the cup overflow."
Title:  
Title:  "Fortunately," added he, "my good friends are down yonder,
Title:  and they will not allow me to be carried away without a
Title:  struggle.  Nevertheless, Monsieur de Treville's company of
Title:  Musketeers alone cannot maintain a war against the cardinal,
Title:  who disposes of the forces of all France, and before whom
Title:  the queen is without power and the king without will.
Title:  d'Artagnan, my friend, you are brave, you are prudent, you
Title:  have excellent qualities; but the women will ruin you!"
Title:  
Title:  He came to this melancholy conclusion as he entered the
Title:  antechamber.  He placed his letter in the hands of the usher
Title:  on duty, who led him into the waiting room and passed on
Title:  into the interior of the palace.
Title:  
Title:  In this waiting room were five or six of the cardinals
Title:  Guards, who recognized d'Artagnan, and knowing that it was
Title:  he who had wounded Jussac, they looked upon him with a smile
Title:  of singular meaning.
Title:  
Title:  This smile appeared to d'Artagnan to be of bad augury.
Title:  Only, as our Gascon was not easily intimidated--or rather,
Title:  thanks to a great pride natural to the men of his country,
Title:  he did not allow one easily to see what was passing in his
Title:  mind when that which was passing at all resembled fear--he
Title:  placed himself haughtily in front of Messieurs the Guards,
Title:  and waited with his hand on his hip, in an attitude by no
Title:  means deficient in majesty.
Title:  
Title:  The usher returned and made a sign to d'Artagnan to follow
Title:  him.  It appeared to the young man that the Guards, on
Title:  seeing him depart, chuckled among themselves.
Title:  
Title:  He traversed a corridor, crossed a grand saloon, entered a
Title:  library, and found himself in the presence of a man seated
Title:  at a desk and writing.
Title:  
Title:  The usher introduced him, and retired without speaking a
Title:  word.  D'Artagnan remained standing and examined this man.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan at first believed that he had to do with some
Title:  judge examining his papers; but he perceived that the man at
Title:  the desk wrote, or rather corrected, lines of unequal
Title:  length, scanning the words on his fingers.  He saw then that
Title:  he was with a poet.  At the end of an instant the poet
Title:  closed his manuscript, upon the cover of which was written
Title:  "Mirame, a Tragedy in Five Acts," and raised his head.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan recognized the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  40  A TERRIBLE VISION
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal leaned his elbow on his manuscript, his cheek
Title:  upon his hand, and looked intently at the young man for a
Title:  moment.  No one had a more searching eye than the Cardinal
Title:  de Richelieu, and d'Artagnan felt this glance run through
Title:  his veins like a fever.
Title:  
Title:  He however kept a good countenance, holding his hat in his
Title:  hand and awaiting the good pleasure of his Eminence, without
Title:  too much assurance, but also without too much humility.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said the cardinal, "are you a d'Artagnan from
Title:  Bearn?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur," replied the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "There are several branches of the d'Artagnans at Tarbes and
Title:  in its environs," said the cardinal; "to which do you
Title:  belong?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am the son of him who served in the Religious Wars under
Title:  the great King Henry, the father of his gracious Majesty."
Title:  
Title:  "That is well.  It is you who set out seven or eight months
Title:  ago from your country to seek your fortune in the capital?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "You came through Meung, where something befell you.  I
Title:  don't very well know what, but still something."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," said d'Artagnan, "this was what happened to
Title:  me--"
Title:  
Title:  "Never mind, never mind!" resumed the cardinal, with a smile
Title:  which indicated that he knew the story as well as he who
Title:  wished to relate it.  "You were recommended to Monsieur de
Title:  Treville, were you not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur; but in that unfortunate affair at
Title:  Meung--"
Title:  
Title:  "The letter was lost," replied his Eminence; "yes, I know
Title:  that.  But Monsieur de Treville is a skilled physiognomist,
Title:  who knows men at first sight; and he placed you in the
Title:  company of his brother-in-law, Monsieur Dessessart, leaving
Title:  you to hope that one day or other you should enter the
Title:  Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur is correctly informed," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Since that time many things have happened to you.  You were
Title:  walking one day behind the Chartreux, when it would have
Title:  been better if you had been elsewhere.  Then you took with
Title:  your friends a journey to the waters of Forges; they stopped
Title:  on the road, but you continued yours.  That is all very
Title:  simple: you had business in England."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," said d'Artagnan, quite confused, "I went--"
Title:  
Title:  "Hunting at Windsor, or elsewhere--that concerns nobody.  I
Title:  know, because it is my office to know everything.  On your
Title:  return you were received by an august personage, and I
Title:  perceive with pleasure that you preserve the souvenir she
Title:  gave you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan placed his hand upon the queen's diamond, which
Title:  he wore, and quickly turned the stone inward; but it was too
Title:  late.
Title:  
Title:  "The day after that, you received a visit from Cavois,"
Title:  resumed the cardinal.  "He went to desire you to come to the
Title:  palace.  You have not returned that visit, and you were
Title:  wrong."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur, I feared I had incurred disgrace with your
Title:  Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  "How could that be, monsieur?  Could you incur my
Title:  displeasure by having followed the orders of your superiors
Title:  with more intelligence and courage than another would have
Title:  done?  It is the people who do not obey that I punish, and
Title:  not those who, like you, obey--but too well.  As a proof,
Title:  remember the date of the day on which I had you bidden to
Title:  come to me, and seek in your memory for what happened to you
Title:  that very night."
Title:  
Title:  That was the very evening when the abduction of Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux took place.  D'Artagnan trembled; and he likewise
Title:  recollected that during the past half hour the poor woman
Title:  had passed close to him, without doubt carried away by the
Title:  same power that had caused her disappearance.
Title:  
Title:  "In short," continued the cardinal, "as I have heard nothing
Title:  of you for some time past, I wished to know what you were
Title:  doing.  Besides, you owe me some thanks.  You must yourself
Title:  have remarked how much you have been considered in all the
Title:  circumstances."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan bowed with respect.
Title:  
Title:  "That," continued the cardinal, "arose not only from a
Title:  feeling of natural equity, but likewise from a plan I have
Title:  marked out with respect to you."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan became more and more astonished.
Title:  
Title:  "I wished to explain this plan to you on the day you
Title:  received my first invitation; but you did not come.
Title:  Fortunately, nothing is lost by this delay, and you are now
Title:  about to hear it.  Sit down there, before me, d'Artagnan;
Title:  you are gentleman enough not to listen standing."  And the
Title:  cardinal pointed with his finger to a chair for the young
Title:  man, who was so astonished at what was passing that he
Title:  awaited a second sign from his interlocutor before he
Title:  obeyed.
Title:  
Title:  "You are brave, Monsieur d'Artagnan," continued his
Title:  Eminence; "you are prudent, which is still better.  I like
Title:  men of head and heart.  Don't be afraid," said he, smiling.
Title:  "By men of heart I mean men of courage. But young as you
Title:  are, and scarcely entering into the world, you have powerful
Title:  enemies; if you do not take great heed, they will destroy
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, monseigneur!" replied the young man, "very easily, no
Title:  doubt, for they are strong and well supported, while I am
Title:  alone."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that's true; but alone as you are, you have done much
Title:  already, and will do still more, I don't doubt.  Yet you
Title:  have need, I believe, to be guided in the adventurous career
Title:  you have undertaken; for, if I mistake not, you came to
Title:  Paris with the ambitious idea of making your fortune."
Title:  
Title:  "I am at the age of extravagant hopes, monseigneur," said
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "There are no extravagant hopes but for fools, monsieur, and you
Title:  are a man of understanding.  Now, what would you say to an
Title:  ensign's commission in my Guards, and a company after the
Title:  campaign?"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "You accept it, do you not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," replied d'Artagnan, with an embarrassed air.
Title:  
Title:  "How?  You refuse?" cried the cardinal, with astonishment.
Title:  
Title:  "I am in his Majesty's Guards, monseigneur, and I have no
Title:  reason to be dissatisfied."
Title:  
Title:  "But it appears to me that my Guards--mine--are also his
