Title:  Majesty's Guards; and whoever serves in a French corps
Title:  serves the king."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur, your Eminence has ill understood my words."
Title:  
Title:  "You want a pretext, do you not?  I comprehend.  Well, you
Title:  have this excuse: advancement, the opening campaign, the
Title:  opportunity which I offer you--so much for the world.  As
Title:  regards yourself, the need of protection; for it is fit you
Title:  should know, Monsieur d'Artagnan, that I have received heavy
Title:  and serious complaints against you.  You do not consecrate
Title:  your days and nights wholly to the king's service."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan colored.
Title:  
Title:  "In fact," said the cardinal, placing his hand upon a bundle
Title:  of papers, "I have here a whole pile which concerns you.  I
Title:  know you to be a man of resolution; and your services, well
Title:  directed, instead of leading you to ill, might be very
Title:  advantageous to you.  Come; reflect, and decide."
Title:  
Title:  "Your goodness confounds me, monseigneur," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan, "and I am conscious of a greatness of soul in
Title:  your Eminence that makes me mean as an earthworm; but since
Title:  Monseigneur permits me to speak freely--"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan paused.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; speak."
Title:  
Title:  "Then, I will presume to say that all my friends are in the
Title:  king's Musketeers and Guards, and that by an inconceivable
Title:  fatality my enemies are in the service of your Eminence; I
Title:  should, therefore, be ill received here and ill regarded
Title:  there if I accepted what Monseigneur offers me."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you happen to entertain the haughty idea that I have not
Title:  yet made you an offer equal to your value?" asked the
Title:  cardinal, with a smile of disdain.
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur, your Eminence is a hundred times too kind to
Title:  me; and on the contrary, I think I have not proved myself
Title:  worthy of your goodness.  The siege of La Rochelle is about
Title:  to be resumed, monseigneur.  I shall serve under the eye of
Title:  your Eminence, and if I have the good fortune to conduct
Title:  myself at the siege in such a manner as merits your
Title:  attention, then I shall at least leave behind me some
Title:  brilliant action to justify the protection with which you
Title:  honor me.  Everything is best in its time, monseigneur.
Title:  Hereafter, perhaps, I shall have the right of giving myself;
Title:  at present I shall appear to sell myself."
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, you refuse to serve me, monsieur," said the
Title:  cardinal, with a tone of vexation, through which, however,
Title:  might be seen a sort of esteem; "remain free, then, and
Title:  guard your hatreds and your sympathies."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, well," said the cardinal, "I don't wish you any ill;
Title:  but you must be aware that it is quite trouble enough to
Title:  defend and recompense our friends.  We owe nothing to our
Title:  enemies; and let me give you a piece of advice; take care of
Title:  yourself, Monsieur d'Artagnan, for from the moment I
Title:  withdraw my hand from behind you, I would not give an obolus
Title:  for your life."
Title:  
Title:  "I will try to do so, monseigneur," replied the Gascon, with
Title:  a noble confidence.
Title:  
Title:  "Remember at a later period and at a certain moment, if any
Title:  mischance should happen to you," said Richelieu,
Title:  significantly, "that it was I who came to seek you, and that
Title:  I did all in my power to prevent this misfortune befalling
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "I shall entertain, whatever may happen," said d'Artagnan,
Title:  placing his hand upon his breast and bowing, "an eternal
Title:  gratitude toward your Eminence for that which you now do for
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, let it be, then, as you have said, Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan; we shall see each other again after the
Title:  campaign.  I will have my eye upon you, for I shall be
Title:  there," replied the cardinal, pointing with his finger to a
Title:  magnificent suit of armor he was to wear, "and on our
Title:  return, well--we will settle our account!"
Title:  
Title:  "Young man," said Richelieu, "if I shall be able to say to
Title:  you at another time what I have said to you today, I promise
Title:  you to do so."
Title:  
Title:  This last expression of Richelieu's conveyed a terrible
Title:  doubt; it alarmed d'Artagnan more than a menace would have
Title:  done, for it was a warning.  The cardinal, then, was seeking
Title:  to preserve him from some misfortune which threatened him.
Title:  He opened his mouth to reply, but with a haughty gesture the
Title:  cardinal dismissed him.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan went out, but at the door his heart almost failed
Title:  him, and he felt inclined to return.  Then the noble and
Title:  severe countenance of Athos crossed his mind; if he made the
Title:  compact with the cardinal which he required, Athos would no
Title:  more give him his hand--Athos would renounce him.
Title:  
Title:  It was this fear that restrained him, so powerful is the
Title:  influence of a truly great character on all that surrounds
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan descended by the staircase at which he had
Title:  entered, and found Athos and the four Musketeers waiting his
Title:  appearance, and beginning to grow uneasy.  With a word,
Title:  d'Artagnan reassured them; and Planchet ran to inform the
Title:  other sentinels that it was useless to keep guard longer, as
Title:  his master had come out safe from the Palais-Cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  Returned home with Athos, Aramis and Porthos inquired
Title:  eagerly the cause of the strange interview; but d'Artagnan
Title:  confined himself to telling them that M. de Richelieu had
Title:  sent for him to propose to him to enter into his guards with
Title:  the rank of ensign, and that he had refused.
Title:  
Title:  "And you were right," cried Aramis and Porthos, with one
Title:  voice.
Title:  
Title:  Athos fell into a profound reverie and answered nothing.
Title:  But when they were alone he said, "You have done that which
Title:  you ought to have done, d'Artagnan; but perhaps you have
Title:  been wrong."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan sighed deeply, for this voice responded to a
Title:  secret voice of his soul, which told him that great
Title:  misfortunes awaited him.
Title:  
Title:  The whole of the next day was spent in preparations for
Title:  departure.  D'Artagnan went to take leave of M. de Treville.
Title:  At that time it was believed that the separation of the
Title:  Musketeers and the Guards would be but momentary, the king
Title:  holding his Parliament that very day and proposing to set
Title:  out the day after.  M. de Treville contented himself with
Title:  asking d'Artagnan if he could do anything for him, but
Title:  d'Artagnan answered that he was supplied with all he wanted.
Title:  
Title:  That night brought together all those comrades of the Guards
Title:  of M. Dessessart and the company of Musketeers of M. de
Title:  Treville who had been accustomed to associate together.
Title:  They were parting to meet again when it pleased God, and if
Title:  it pleased God.  That night, then, was somewhat riotous, as
Title:  may be imagined.  In such cases extreme preoccupation is
Title:  only to be combated by extreme carelessness.
Title:  
Title:  At the first sound of the morning trumpet the friends
Title:  separated; the Musketeers hastening to the hotel of M. de
Title:  Treville, the Guards to that of M. Dessessart.  Each of the
Title:  captains then led his company to the Louvre, where the king
Title:  held his review.
Title:  
Title:  The king was dull and appeared ill, which detracted a little
Title:  from his usual lofty bearing.  In fact, the evening before,
Title:  a fever had seized him in the midst of the Parliament, while
Title:  he was holding his Bed of Justice.  He had, not the less,
Title:  decided upon setting out that same evening; and in spite of
Title:  the remonstrances that had been offered to him, he persisted
Title:  in having the review, hoping by setting it at defiance to
Title:  conquer the disease which began to lay hold upon him.
Title:  
Title:  The review over, the Guards set forward alone on their
Title:  march, the Musketeers waiting for the king, which allowed
Title:  Porthos time to go and take a turn in his superb equipment
Title:  in the Rue aux Ours.
Title:  
Title:  The procurator's wife saw him pass in his new uniform and on
Title:  his fine horse.  She loved Porthos too dearly to allow him
Title:  to part thus; she made him a sign to dismount and come to
Title:  her.  Porthos was magnificent; his spurs jingled, his
Title:  cuirass glittered, his sword knocked proudly against his
Title:  ample limbs.  This time the clerks evinced no inclination to
Title:  laugh, such a real ear clipper did Porthos appear.
Title:  
Title:  The Musketeer was introduced to M. Coquenard, whose little
Title:  gray eyes sparkled with anger at seeing his cousin all
Title:  blazing new.  Nevertheless, one thing afforded him inward
Title:  consolation; it was expected by everybody that the campaign
Title:  would be a severe one.  He whispered a hope to himself that
Title:  this beloved relative might be killed in the field.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos paid his compliments to M. Coquenard and bade him
Title:  farewell.  M. Coquenard wished him all sorts of
Title:  prosperities.  As to Mme. Coquenard, she could not restrain
Title:  her tears; but no evil impressions were taken from her grief
Title:  as she was known to be very much attached to her relatives,
Title:  about whom she was constantly having serious disputes with
Title:  her husband.
Title:  
Title:  But the real adieux were made in Mme. Coquenard's chamber;
Title:  they were heartrending.
Title:  
Title:  As long as the procurator's wife could follow him with her
Title:  eyes, she waved her handkerchief to him, leaning so far out
Title:  of the window as to lead people to believe she wished to
Title:  precipitate herself.  Porthos received all these attentions
Title:  like a man accustomed to such demonstrations, only on
Title:  turning the corner of the street he lifted his hat
Title:  gracefully, and waved it to her as a sign of adieu.
Title:  
Title:  On his part Aramis wrote a long letter.  To whom?  Nobody
Title:  knew.  Kitty, who was to set out that evening for Tours, was
Title:  waiting in the next chamber.
Title:  
Title:  Athos sipped the last bottle of his Spanish wine.
Title:  
Title:  In the meantime d'Artagnan was defiling with his company.
Title:  Arriving at the Faubourg St. Antoine, he turned round to
Title:  look gaily at the Bastille; but as it was the Bastille alone
Title:  he looked at, he did not observe Milady, who, mounted upon a
Title:  light chestnut horse, designated him with her finger to two
Title:  ill-looking men who came close up to the ranks to take
Title:  notice of him.  To a look of interrogation which they made,
Title:  Milady replied by a sign that it was he.  Then, certain that
Title:  there could be no mistake in the execution of her orders,
Title:  she started her horse and disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  The two men followed the company, and on leaving the
Title:  Faubourg St. Antoine, mounted two horses properly equipped,
Title:  which a servant without livery had waiting for them.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  41  THE SEIGE OF LA ROCHELLE
Title:  
Title:  The Siege of La Rochelle was one of the great political
Title:  events of the reign of Louis XIII, and one of the great
Title:  military enterprises of the cardinal.  It is, then,
Title:  interesting and even necessary that we should say a few
Title:  words about it, particularly as many details of this siege
Title:  are connected in too important a manner with the story we
Title:  have undertaken to relate to allow us to pass it over in
Title:  silence.
Title:  
Title:  The political plans of the cardinal when he undertook this
Title:  siege were extensive.  Let us unfold them first, and then
Title:  pass on to the private plans which perhaps had not less
Title:  influence upon his Eminence than the others.
Title:  
Title:  Of the important cities given up by Henry IV to the
Title:  Huguenots as places of safety, there only remained La
Title:  Rochelle.  It became necessary, therefore, to destroy this
Title:  last bulwark of Calvinism--a dangerous leaven with which the
Title:  ferments of civil revolt and foreign war were constantly
Title:  mingling.
Title:  
Title:  Spaniards, Englishmen, and Italian malcontents, adventurers
Title:  of all nations, and soldiers of fortune of every sect,
Title:  flocked at the first summons under the standard of the
Title:  Protestants, and organized themselves like a vast
Title:  association, whose branches diverged freely over all parts
Title:  of Europe.
Title:  
Title:  La Rochelle, which had derived a new importance from the
Title:  ruin of the other Calvinist cities, was, then, the focus of
Title:  dissensions and ambition.  Moreover, its port was the last
Title:  in the kingdom of France open to the English, and by closing
Title:  it against England, our eternal enemy, the cardinal
Title:  completed the work of Joan of Arc and the Duc de Guise.
Title:  
Title:  Thus Bassompierre, who was at once Protestant and Catholic--
Title:  Protestant by conviction and Catholic as commander of the
Title:  order of the Holy Ghost; Bassompierre, who was a German by
Title:  birth and a Frenchman at heart--in short, Bassompierre, who
Title:  had a distinguished command at the siege of La Rochelle,
Title:  said, in charging at the head of several other Protestant
Title:  nobles like himself, "You will see, gentlemen, that we shall
Title:  be fools enough to take La Rochelle."
Title:  
Title:  And Bassompierre was right.  The cannonade of the Isle of Re
Title:  presaged to him the dragonnades of the Cevennes; the taking
Title:  of La Rochelle was the preface to the revocation of the
Title:  Edict of Nantes.
Title:  
Title:  We have hinted that by the side of these views of the
Title:  leveling and simplifying minister, which belong to history,
Title:  the chronicler is forced to recognize the lesser motives of
Title:  the amorous man and jealous rival.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu, as everyone knows, had loved the queen.  Was this
Title:  love a simple political affair, or was it naturally one of
Title:  those profound passions which Anne of Austria inspired in
Title:  those who approached her?  That we are not able to say; but
Title:  at all events, we have seen, by the anterior developments of
Title:  this story, that Buckingham had the advantage over him, and
Title:  in two or three circumstances, particularly that of the
Title:  diamond studs, had, thanks to the devotedness of the three
Title:  Musketeers and the courage and conduct of d'Artagnan,
Title:  cruelly mystified him.
Title:  
Title:  It was, then, Richelieu's object, not only to get rid of an
Title:  enemy of France, but to avenge himself on a rival; but this
Title:  vengeance must be grand and striking and worthy in every way
Title:  of a man who held in his hand, as his weapon for combat, the
Title:  forces of a kingdom.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu knew that in combating England he combated
Title:  Buckingham; that in triumphing over England he triumphed
Title:  over Buckingham--in short, that in humiliating England in
Title:  the eyes of Europe he humiliated Buckingham in the eyes of
Title:  the queen.
Title:  
Title:  On his side Buckingham, in pretending to maintain the honor
Title:  of England, was moved by interests exactly like those of the
Title:  cardinal.  Buckingham also was pursuing a private vengeance.
Title:  Buckingham could not under any pretense be admitted into
Title:  France as an ambassador; he wished to enter it as a
Title:  conqueror.
Title:  
Title:  It resulted from this that the real stake in this game,
Title:  which two most powerful kingdoms played for the good
Title:  pleasure of two amorous men, was simply a kind look from
Title:  Anne of Austria.
Title:  
Title:  The first advantage had been gained by Buckingham.  Arriving
Title:  unexpectedly in sight of the Isle of Re with ninety vessels
Title:  and nearly twenty thousand men, he had surprised the Comte
Title:  de Toiras, who commanded for the king in the Isle, and he
Title:  had, after a bloody conflict, effected his landing.
Title:  
Title:  Allow us to observe in passing that in this fight perished
Title:  the Baron de Chantal; that the Baron de Chantal left a
Title:  little orphan girl eighteen months old, and that this little
Title:  girl was afterward Mme. de Sevigne.
Title:  
Title:  The Comte de Toiras retired into the citadel St. Martin with
Title:  his garrison, and threw a hundred men into a little fort
Title:  called the fort of La Pree.
Title:  
Title:  This event had hastened the resolutions of the cardinal; and
Title:  till the king and he could take the command of the siege of
Title:  La Rochelle, which was determined, he had sent Monsieur to
Title:  direct the first operations, and had ordered all the troops
Title:  he could dispose of to march toward the theater of war.  It
Title:  was of this detachment, sent as a vanguard, that our friend
Title:  d'Artagnan formed a part.
Title:  
Title:  The king, as we have said, was to follow as soon as his Bed
Title:  of Justice had been held; but on rising from his Bed of
Title:  Justice on the twenty-eighth of June, he felt himself
Title:  attacked by fever.  He was, notwithstanding, anxious to set
Title:  out; but his illness becoming more serious, he was forced to
Title:  stop at Villeroy.
Title:  
Title:  Now, whenever the king halted, the Musketeers halted.  It
Title:  followed that d'Artagnan, who was as yet purely and simply
Title:  in the Guards, found himself, for the time at least,
Title:  separated from his good friends--Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.
Title:  This separation, which was no more than an unpleasant
Title:  circumstance, would have certainly become a cause of serious
Title:  uneasiness if he had been able to guess by what unknown
Title:  dangers he was surrounded.
Title:  
Title:  He, however, arrived without accident in the camp
Title:  established before La Rochelle, of the tenth of the month of
Title:  September of the year 1627.
Title:  
Title:  Everything was in the same state.  The Duke of Buckingham
Title:  and his English, masters of the Isle of Re, continued to
Title:  besiege, but without success, the citadel St. Martin and the
Title:  fort of La Pree; and hostilities with La Rochelle had
Title:  commenced, two or three days before, about a fort which the
Title:  Duc d'Angouleme had caused to be constructed near the city.
Title:  
Title:  The Guards, under the command of M. Dessessart, took up
Title:  their quarters at the Minimes; but, as we know, d'Artagnan,
Title:  possessed with ambition to enter the Musketeers, had formed
Title:  but few friendships among his comrades, and he felt himself
Title:  isolated and given up to his own reflections.
Title:  
Title:  His reflections were not very cheerful.  From the time of
Title:  his arrival in Paris, he had been mixed up with public
Title:  affairs; but his own private affairs had made no great
Title:  progress, either in love or fortune.  As to love, the only
Title:  woman he could have loved was Mme. Bonacieux; and Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux had disappeared, without his being able to
Title:  discover what had become of her.  As to fortune, he had
Title:  made--he, humble as he was--an enemy of the cardinal; that
Title:  is to say, of a man before whom trembled the greatest men of
Title:  the kingdom, beginning with the king.
Title:  
Title:  That man had the power to crush him, and yet he had not done
Title:  so.  For a mind so perspicuous as that of d'Artagnan, this
Title:  indulgence was a light by which he caught a glimpse of a
Title:  better future.
Title:  
Title:  Then he had made himself another enemy, less to be feared,
Title:  he thought; but nevertheless, he instinctively felt, not to
Title:  be despised.  This enemy was Milady.
Title:  
Title:  In exchange for all this, he had acquired the protection and
Title:  good will of the queen; but the favor of the queen was at
Title:  the present time an additional cause of persecution, and her
Title:  protection, as it was known, protected badly--as witness
Title:  Chalais and Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  What he had clearly gained in all this was the diamond,
Title:  worth five or six thousand livres, which he wore on his
Title:  finger; and even this diamond--supposing that d'Artagnan, in
Title:  his projects of ambition, wished to keep it, to make it
Title:  someday a pledge for the gratitude of the queen--had not in
Title:  the meanwhile, since he could not part with it, more value
Title:  than the gravel he trod under his feet.
Title:  
Title:  We say the gravel he trod under his feet, for d'Artagnan
Title:  made these reflections while walking solitarily along a
Title:  pretty little road which led from the camp to the village of
Title:  Angoutin.  Now, these reflections had led him further than
Title:  he intended, and the day was beginning to decline when, by
Title:  the last ray of the setting sun, he thought he saw the
Title:  barrel of a musket glitter from behind a hedge.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had a quick eye and a prompt understanding.  He
Title:  comprehended that the musket had not come there of itself,
Title:  and that he who bore it had not concealed himself behind a
Title:  hedge with any friendly intentions.  He determined,
Title:  therefore, to direct his course as clear from it as he could
Title:  when, on the opposite side of the road, from behind a rock,
Title:  he perceived the extremity of another musket.
Title:  
Title:  This was evidently an ambuscade.
Title:  
Title:  The young man cast a glance at the first musket and saw,
Title:  with a certain degree of inquietude, that it was leveled in
Title:  his direction; but as soon as he perceived that the orifice
Title:  of the barrel was motionless, he threw himself upon the
Title:  ground.  At the same instant the gun was fired, and he heard
Title:  the whistling of a ball pass over his head.
Title:  
Title:  No time was to be lost.  D'Artagnan sprang up with a bound,
Title:  and at the same instant the ball from the other musket tore
Title:  up the gravel on the very spot on the road where he had
Title:  thrown himself with his face to the ground.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was not one of those foolhardy men who seek a
Title:  ridiculous death in order that it may be said of them that
Title:  they did not retreat a single step.  Besides, courage was
Title:  out of the question here; d'Artagnan had fallen into an
Title:  ambush.
Title:  
Title:  "If there is a third shot," said he to himself, "I am a lost
Title:  man."
Title:  
Title:  He immediately, therefore, took to his heels and ran toward
Title:  the camp, with the swiftness of the young men of his
Title:  country, so renowned for their agility; but whatever might
Title:  be his speed, the first who fired, having had time to
Title:  reload, fired a second shot, and this time so well aimed
Title:  that it struck his hat, and carried it ten paces from him.
Title:  
Title:  As he, however, had no other hat, he picked up this as he
Title:  ran, and arrived at his quarters very pale and quite out of
Title:  breath.  He sat down without saying a word to anybody, and
Title:  began to reflect.
Title:  
Title:  This event might have three causes:
Title:  
Title:  The first and the most natural was that it might be an
Title:  ambuscade of the Rochellais, who might not be sorry to kill
Title:  one of his Majesty's Guards, because it would be an enemy
Title:  the less, and this enemy might have a well-furnished purse
Title:  in his pocket.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took his hat, examined the hole made by the ball,
Title:  and shook his head.  The ball was not a musket ball--it was
Title:  an arquebus ball.  The accuracy of the aim had first given
Title:  him the idea that a special weapon had been employed.  This
Title:  could not, then, be a military ambuscade, as the ball was
Title:  not of the regular caliber.
Title:  
Title:  This might be a kind remembrance of Monsieur the Cardinal.
Title:  It may be observed that at the very moment when, thanks to
Title:  the ray of the sun, he perceived the gun barrel, he was
Title:  thinking with astonishment on the forbearance of his
Title:  Eminence with respect to him.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan again shook his head.  For people toward whom
Title:  he had but to put forth his hand, his Eminence had rarely
Title:  recourse to such means.
Title:  
Title:  It might be a vengeance of Milady; that was most probable.
Title:  
Title:  He tried in vain to remember the faces or dress of the
Title:  assassins; he had escaped so rapidly that he had not had
Title:  leisure to notice anything.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my poor friends!" murmured d'Artagnan; "where are you?
Title:  And that you should fail me!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan passed a very bad night.  Three or four times he
Title:  started up, imagining that a man was approaching his bed for
Title:  the purpose of stabbing him.  Nevertheless, day dawned
Title:  without darkness having brought any accident.
Title:  
Title:  But d'Artagnan well suspected that that which was deferred
Title:  was not relinquished.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan remained all day in his quarters, assigning as a
Title:  reason to himself that the weather was bad.
Title:  
Title:  At nine o'clock the next morning, the drums beat to arms.
Title:  The Duc d'Orleans visited the posts.  The guards were under
Title:  arms, and d'Artagnan took his place in the midst of his
Title:  comrades.
Title:  
Title:  Monsieur passed along the front of the line; then all the
Title:  superior officers approached him to pay their compliments,
Title:  M. Dessessart, captain of the Guards, as well as the others.
Title:  
Title:  At the expiration of a minute or two, it appeared to
Title:  d'Artagnan that M. Dessessart made him a sign to approach.
Title:  He waited for a fresh gesture on the part of his superior,
Title:  for fear he might be mistaken; but this gesture being
Title:  repeated, he left the ranks, and advanced to receive orders.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur is about to ask for some men of good will for a
Title:  dangerous mission, but one which will do honor to those who
Title:  shall accomplish it; and I made you a sign in order that you
Title:  might hold yourself in readiness."
Title:  
Title:  "Thanks, my captain!" replied d'Artagnan, who wished for
Title:  nothing better than an opportunity to distinguish himself
Title:  under the eye of the lieutenant general.
Title:  
Title:  In fact the Rochellais had made a sortie during the night,
Title:  and had retaken a bastion of which the royal army had gained
Title:  possession two days before.  The matter was to ascertain, by
Title:  reconnoitering, how the enemy guarded this bastion.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of a few minutes Monsieur raised his voice, and
Title:  said, "I want for this mission three or four volunteers, led
Title:  by a man who can be depended upon."
Title:  
Title:  "As to the man to be depended upon, I have him under my
Title:  hand, monsieur," said M. Dessessart, pointing to d'Artagnan;
Title:  "and as to the four or five volunteers, Monsieur has but to
Title:  make his intentions known, and the men will not be wanting."
Title:  
Title:  "Four men of good will who will risk being killed with me!"
Title:  said d'Artagnan, raising his sword.
Title:  
Title:  Two of his comrades of the Guards immediately sprang
Title:  forward, and two other soldiers having joined them, the
Title:  number was deemed sufficient.  D'Artagnan declined all
Title:  others, being unwilling to take the first chance from those
Title:  who had the priority.
Title:  
Title:  It was not known whether, after the taking of the bastion,
Title:  the Rochellais had evacuated it or left a garrison in it;
Title:  the object then was to examine the place near enough to
Title:  verify the reports.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan set out with his four companions, and followed
Title:  the trench; the two Guards marched abreast with him, and the
Title:  two soldiers followed behind.
Title:  
Title:  They arrived thus, screened by the lining of the trench,
Title:  till they came within a hundred paces of the bastion.
Title:  There, on turning round, d'Artagnan perceived that the two
Title:  soldiers had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  He thought that, beginning to be afraid, they had stayed
Title:  behind, and he continued to advance.
Title:  
Title:  At the turning of the counterscarp they found themselves
Title:  within about sixty paces of the bastion.  They saw no one,
Title:  and the bastion seemed abandoned.
Title:  
Title:  The three composing our forlorn hope were deliberating
Title:  whether they should proceed any further, when all at once a
Title:  circle of smoke enveloped the giant of stone, and a dozen
Title:  balls came whistling around d'Artagnan and his companions.
Title:  
Title:  They knew all they wished to know; the bastion was guarded.
Title:  A longer stay in this dangerous spot would have been useless
Title:  imprudence.  D'Artagnan and his two companions turned their
Title:  backs, and commenced a retreat which resembled a flight.
Title:  
Title:  On arriving at the angle of the trench which was to serve
Title:  them as a rampart, one of the Guardsmen fell.  A ball had
Title:  passed through his breast.  The other, who was safe and
Title:  sound, continued his way toward the camp.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was not willing to abandon his companion thus,
Title:  and stooped to raise him and assist him in regaining the
Title:  lines; but at this moment two shots were fired.  One ball
Title:  struck the head of the already-wounded guard, and the other
Title:  flattened itself against a rock, after having passed within
Title:  two inches of d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  The young man turned quickly round, for this attack could
Title:  not have come from the bastion, which was hidden by the
Title:  angle of the trench.  The idea of the two soldiers who had
Title:  abandoned him occurred to his mind, and with them he
Title:  remembered the assassins of two evenings before.  He
Title:  resolved this time to know with whom he had to deal, and
Title:  fell upon the body of his comrade as if he were dead.
Title:  
Title:  He quickly saw two heads appear above an abandoned work
Title:  within thirty paces of him; they were the heads of the two
Title:  soldiers.  D'Artagnan had not been deceived; these two men
Title:  had only followed for the purpose of assassinating him,
Title:  hoping that the young man's death would be placed to the
Title:  account of the enemy.
Title:  
Title:  As he might be only wounded and might denounce their crime,
Title:  they came up to him with the purpose of making sure.
Title:  Fortunately, deceived by d'Artagnan's trick, they neglected
Title:  to reload their guns.
Title:  
Title:  When they were within ten paces of him, d'Artagnan, who in
Title:  falling had taken care not to let go his sword, sprang up
Title:  close to them.
Title:  
Title:  The assassins comprehended that if they fled toward the camp
Title:  without having killed their man, they should be accused by
Title:  him; therefore their first idea was to join the enemy.  One
Title:  of them took his gun by the barrel, and used it as he would
Title:  a club.  He aimed a terrible blow at d'Artagnan, who avoided
Title:  it by springing to one side; but by this movement he left a
Title:  passage free to the bandit, who darted off toward the
Title:  bastion.  As the Rochellais who guarded the bastion were
Title:  ignorant of the intentions of the man they saw coming toward
Title:  them, they fired upon him, and he fell, struck by a ball
Title:  which broke his shoulder.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime d'Artagnan had thrown himself upon the other
Title:  soldier, attacking him with his sword.  The conflict was not
Title:  long; the wretch had nothing to defend himself with but his
Title:  discharged arquebus.  The sword of the Guardsman slipped
Title:  along the barrel of the now-useless weapon, and passed
Title:  through the thigh of the assassin, who fell.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan immediately placed the point of his sword at his
Title:  throat.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, do not kill me!" cried the bandit.  "Pardon, pardon, my
Title:  officer, and I will tell you all."
Title:  
Title:  "Is your secret of enough importance to me to spare your
Title:  life for it?" asked the young man, withholding his arm.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; if you think existence worth anything to a man of
Title:  twenty, as you are, and who may hope for everything, being
Title:  handsome and brave, as you are."
Title:  
Title:  "Wretch," cried d'Artagnan, "speak quickly!  Who employed
Title:  you to assassinate me?"
Title:  
Title:  "A woman whom I don't know, but who is called Milady."
Title:  
Title:  "But if you don't know this woman, how do you know her
Title:  name?"
Title:  
Title:  "My comrade knows her, and called her so.  It was with him
Title:  she agreed, and not with me; he even has in his pocket a
Title:  letter from that person, who attaches great importance to
Title:  you, as I have heard him say."
Title:  
Title:  "But how did you become concerned in this villainous
Title:  affair?"
Title:  
Title:  "He proposed to me to undertake it with him, and I agreed."
Title:  
Title:  "And how much did she give you for this fine enterprise?"
Title:  
Title:  "A hundred louis."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, come!" said the young man, laughing, "she thinks I am
Title:  worth something.  A hundred louis?  Well, that was a
Title:  temptation for two wretches like you.  I understand why you
Title:  accepted it, and I grant you my pardon; but upon one
Title:  condition."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that?" said the soldier, uneasy at perceiving that
Title:  all was not over.
Title:  
Title:  "That you will go and fetch me the letter your comrade has
Title:  in his pocket."
Title:  
Title:  "But," cried the bandit, "that is only another way of
Title:  killing me.  How can I go and fetch that letter under the
Title:  fire of the bastion?"
Title:  
Title:  "You must nevertheless make up your mind to go and get it,
Title:  or I swear you shall die by my hand."
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon, monsieur; pity!  In the name of that young lady you
Title:  love, and whom you perhaps believe dead but who is not!"
Title:  cried the bandit, throwing himself upon his knees and
Title:  leaning upon his hand--for he began to lose his strength
Title:  with his blood.
Title:  
Title:  "And how do you know there is a young woman whom I love, and
Title:  that I believed that woman dead?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "By that letter which my comrade has in his pocket."
Title:  
Title:  "You see, then," said d'Artagnan, "that I must have that
Title:  letter.  So no more delay, no more hesitation; or else
Title:  whatever may be my repugnance to soiling my sword a second
Title:  time with the blood of a wretch like you, I swear by my
Title:  faith as an honest man--" and at these words d'Artagnan made
Title:  so fierce a gesture that the wounded man sprang up.
Title:  
Title:  "Stop, stop!" cried he, regaining strength by force of
Title:  terror.  "I will go--I will go!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took the soldier's arquebus, made him go on
Title:  before him, and urged him toward his companion by pricking
Title:  him behind with his sword.
Title:  
Title:  It was a frightful thing to see this wretch, leaving a long
Title:  track of blood on the ground he passed over, pale with
Title:  approaching death, trying to drag himself along without
Title:  being seen to the body of his accomplice, which lay twenty
Title:  paces from him.
Title:  
Title:  Terror was so strongly painted on his face, covered with a
Title:  cold sweat, that d'Artagnan took pity on him, and casting
Title:  upon him a look of contempt, "Stop," said he, "I will show
Title:  you the difference between a man of courage and such a
Title:  coward as you.  Stay where you are; I will go myself."
Title:  
Title:  And with a light step, an eye on the watch, observing the
Title:  movements of the enemy and taking advantage of the accidents
Title:  of the ground, d'Artagnan succeeded in reaching the second
Title:  soldier.
Title:  
Title:  There were two means of gaining his object--to search him on
Title:  the spot, or to carry him away, making a buckler of his
Title:  body, and search him in the trench.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan preferred the second means, and lifted the
Title:  assassin onto his shoulders at the moment the enemy fired.
Title:  
Title:  A slight shock, the dull noise of three balls which
Title:  penetrated the flesh, a last cry, a convulsion of agony,
Title:  proved to d'Artagnan that the would-be assassin had saved
Title:  his life.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan regained the trench, and threw the corpse beside
Title:  the wounded man, who was as pale as death.
Title:  
Title:  Then he began to search.  A leather pocketbook, a purse, in
Title:  which was evidently a part of the sum which the bandit had
Title:  received, with a dice box and dice, completed the
Title:  possessions of the dead man.
Title:  
Title:  He left the box and dice where they fell, threw the purse to
Title:  the wounded man, and eagerly opened the pocketbook.
Title:  
Title:  Among some unimportant papers he found the following letter,
Title:  that which he had sought at the risk of his life:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Since you have lost sight of that woman and she is now in
Title:  safety in the convent, which you should never have allowed
Title:  her to reach, try, at least, not to miss the man.  If you
Title:  do, you know that my hand stretches far, and that you shall
Title:  pay very dearly for the hundred louis you have from me."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  No signature.  Nevertheless it was plain the letter came
Title:  from Milady.  He consequently kept it as a piece of
Title:  evidence, and being in safety behind the angle of the
Title:  trench, he began to interrogate the wounded man.  He
Title:  confessed that he had undertaken with his comrade--the same
Title:  who was killed--to carry off a young woman who was to leave
Title:  Paris by the Barriere de La Villette; but having stopped to
Title:  drink at a cabaret, they had missed the carriage by ten
Title:  minutes.
Title:  
Title:  "But what were you to do with that woman?" asked d'Artagnan,
Title:  with anguish.
Title:  
Title:  "We were to have conveyed her to a hotel in the Place
Title:  Royale," said the wounded man.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes!" murmured d'Artagnan; "that's the place--Milady's
Title:  own residence!"
Title:  
Title:  Then the young man tremblingly comprehended what a terrible
Title:  thirst for vengeance urged this woman on to destroy him, as
Title:  well as all who loved him, and how well she must be
Title:  acquainted with the affairs of the court, since she had
Title:  discovered all.  There could be no doubt she owed this
Title:  information to the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  But amid all this he perceived, with a feeling of real joy,
Title:  that the queen must have discovered the prison in which poor
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux was explaining her devotion, and that she had
Title:  freed her from that prison; and the letter he had received
Title:  from the young woman, and her passage along the road of
Title:  Chaillot like an apparition, were now explained.
Title:  
Title:  Then also, as Athos had predicted, it became possible to
Title:  find Mme. Bonacieux, and a convent was not impregnable.
Title:  
Title:  This idea completely restored clemency to his heart.  He
Title:  turned toward the wounded man, who had watched with intense
Title:  anxiety all the various expressions of his countenance, and
Title:  holding out his arm to him, said, "Come, I will not abandon
Title:  you thus.  Lean upon me, and let us return to the camp."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said the man, who could scarcely believe in such
Title:  magnanimity, "but is it not to have me hanged?"
Title:  
Title:  "You have my word," said he; "for the second time I give you
Title:  your life."
Title:  
Title:  The wounded man sank upon his knees, to again kiss the feet
Title:  of his preserver; but d'Artagnan, who had no longer a motive
Title:  for staying so near the enemy, abridged the testimonials of
Title:  his gratitude.
Title:  
Title:  The Guardsman who had returned at the first discharge
Title:  announced the death of his four companions.  They were
Title:  therefore much astonished and delighted in the regiment when
Title:  they saw the young man come back safe and sound.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan explained the sword wound of his companion by a
Title:  sortie which he improvised.  He described the death of the
Title:  other soldier, and the perils they had encountered.  This
Title:  recital was for him the occasion of veritable triumph.  The
Title:  whole army talked of this expedition for a day, and Monsieur
Title:  paid him his compliments upon it.  Besides this, as every
Title:  great action bears its recompense with it, the brave exploit
Title:  of d'Artagnan resulted in the restoration of the tranquility
Title:  he had lost.  In fact, d'Artagnan believed that he might be
Title:  tranquil, as one of his two enemies was killed and the other
Title:  devoted to his interests.
Title:  
Title:  This tranquillity proved one thing--that d'Artagnan did not
Title:  yet know Milady.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  42  THE ANJOU WINE
Title:  
Title:  After the most disheartening news of the king's health, a
Title:  report of his convalescence began to prevail in the camp;
Title:  and as he was very anxious to be in person at the siege, it
Title:  was said that as soon as he could mount a horse he would set
Title:  forward.
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, Monsieur, who knew that from one day to the other
Title:  he might expect to be removed from his command by the Duc
Title:  d'Angouleme, by Bassompierre, or by Schomberg, who were all
Title:  eager for his post, did but little, lost his days in
Title:  wavering, and did not dare to attempt any great enterprise
Title:  to drive the English from the Isle of Re, where they still
Title:  besieged the citadel St. Martin and the fort of La Pree, as
Title:  on their side the French were besieging La Rochelle.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, as we have said, had become more tranquil, as
Title:  always happens after a past danger, particularly when the
Title:  danger seems to have vanished.  He only felt one uneasiness,
Title:  and that was at not hearing any tidings from his friends.
Title:  
Title:  But one morning at the commencement of the month of November
Title:  everything was explained to him by this letter, dated from
Title:  Villeroy:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  M. d'Artagnan,
Title:  
Title:  MM. Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, after having
Title:  had an entertainment at my house and enjoying themselves
Title:  very much, created such a disturbance that the provost of
Title:  the castle, a rigid man, has ordered them to be confined for
Title:  some days; but I accomplish the order they have given me by
Title:  forwarding to you a dozen bottles of my Anjou wine, with
Title:  which they are much pleased.  They are desirous that you
Title:  should drink to their health in their favorite wine.  I have
Title:  done this, and am, monsieur, with great respect,
Title:  
Title:  Your very humble and obedient servant,
Title:  
Title:  Godeau, Purveyor of the Musketeers
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "That's all well!" cried d'Artagnan.  "They think of me in
Title:  their pleasures, as I thought of them in my troubles.  Well,
Title:  I will certainly drink to their health with all my heart,
Title:  but I will not drink alone."
Title:  
Title:  And d'Artagnan went among those Guardsmen with whom he had
Title:  formed greater intimacy than with the others, to invite them
Title:  to enjoy with him this present of delicious Anjou wine which
Title:  had been sent him from Villeroy.
Title:  
Title:  One of the two Guardsmen was engaged that evening, and
Title:  another the next, so the meeting was fixed for the day after
Title:  that.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, on his return, sent the twelve bottles of wine
Title:  to the refreshment room of the Guards, with strict orders
Title:  that great care should be taken of it; and then, on the day
Title:  appointed, as the dinner was fixed for midday d'Artagnan
Title:  sent Planchet at nine in the morning to assist in preparing
Title:  everything for the entertainment.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet, very proud of being raised to the dignity of
Title:  landlord, thought he would make all ready, like an
Title:  intelligent man; and with this view called in the assistance
Title:  of the lackey of one of his master's guests, named Fourreau,
Title:  and the false soldier who had tried to kill d'Artagnan and
Title:  who, belonging to no corps, had entered into the service of
Title:  d'Artagnan, or rather of Planchet, after d'Artagnan had
Title:  saved his life.
Title:  
Title:  The hour of the banquet being come, the two guards arrived,
Title:  took their places, and the dishes were arranged on the
Title:  table.  Planchet waited, towel on arm; Fourreau uncorked the
Title:  bottles; and Brisemont, which was the name of the
Title:  convalescent, poured the wine, which was a little shaken by
Title:  its journey, carefully into decanters.  Of this wine, the
Title:  first bottle being a little thick at the bottom, Brisemont
Title:  poured the lees into a glass, and d'Artagnan desired him to
Title:  drink it, for the poor devil had not yet recovered his
Title:  strength.
Title:  
Title:  The guests having eaten the soup, were about to lift the
Title:  first glass of wine to their lips, when all at once the
Title:  cannon sounded from Fort Louis and Fort Neuf.  The
Title:  Guardsmen, imagining this to be caused by some unexpected
Title:  attack, either of the besieged or the English, sprang to
Title:  their swords.  D'Artagnan, not less forward than they, did
Title:  likewise, and all ran out, in order to repair to their
Title:  posts.
Title:  
Title:  But scarcely were they out of the room before they were made
Title:  aware of the cause of this noise.  Cries of "Live the king!
Title:  Live the cardinal!" resounded on every side, and the drums
Title:  were beaten in all directions.
Title:  
Title:  In short, the king, impatient, as has been said, had come by
Title:  forced marches, and had that moment arrived with all his
Title:  household and a reinforcement of ten thousand troops.  His
Title:  Musketeers proceeded and followed him.  D'Artagnan, placed
Title:  in line with his company, saluted with an expressive gesture
Title:  his three friends, whose eyes soon discovered him, and M. de
Title:  Treville, who detected him at once.
Title:  
Title:  The ceremony of reception over, the four friends were soon
Title:  in one another's arms.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardieu!" cried d'Artagnan, "you could not have arrived in
Title:  better time; the dinner cannot have had time to get cold!
Title:  Can it, gentlemen?" added the young man, turning to the two
Title:  Guards, whom he introduced to his friends.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Porthos, "it appears we are feasting!"
Title:  
Title:  "I hope," said Aramis, "there are no women at your dinner."
Title:  
Title:  "Is there any drinkable wine in your tavern?" asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, pardieu! there is yours, my dear friend," replied
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Our wine!" said Athos, astonished.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that you sent me."
Title:  
Title:  "We sent you wine?"
Title:  
Title:  "You know very well--the wine from the hills of Anjou."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I know what brand you are talking about."
Title:  
Title:  "The wine you prefer."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, in the absence of champagne and chambertin, you must
Title:  content yourselves with that."
Title:  
Title:  "And so, connoisseurs in wine as we are, we have sent you
Title:  some Anjou wine?" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Not exactly, it is the wine that was sent by your order."
Title:  
Title:  "On our account?" said the three Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  "Did you send this wine, Aramis?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "No; and you, Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; and you, Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "No!"
Title:  
Title:  "If it was not you, it was your purveyor," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Our purveyor!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, your purveyor, Godeau--the purveyor of the
Title:  Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith! never mind where it comes from," said Porthos,
Title:  "let us taste it, and if it is good, let us drink it."
Title:  
Title:  "No," said Athos; "don't let us drink wine which comes from
Title:  an unknown source."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, Athos," said d'Artagnan.  "Did none of you
Title:  charge your purveyor, Godeau, to send me some wine?"
Title:  
Title:  "No!  And yet you say he has sent you some as from us?"
Title:  
Title:  "Here is his letter," said d'Artagnan, and he presented the
Title:  note to his comrades.
Title:  
Title:  "This is not his writing!" said Athos.  "I am acquainted
Title:  with it; before we left Villeroy I settled the accounts of
Title:  the regiment."
Title:  
Title:  "A false letter altogether," said Porthos, "we have not been
Title:  disciplined."
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan," said Aramis, in a reproachful tone, "how could
Title:  you believe that we had made a disturbance?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan grew pale, and a convulsive trembling shook all
Title:  his limbs.
Title:  
Title:  "Thou alarmest me!" said Athos, who never used thee and thou
Title:  but upon very particular occasions, "what has happened?"
Title:  
Title:  "Look you, my friends!" cried d'Artagnan, "a horrible
Title:  suspicion crosses my mind!  Can this be another vengeance of
Title:  that woman?"
Title:  
Title:  It was now Athos who turned pale.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan rushed toward the refreshment room, the three
Title:  Musketeers and the two Guards following him.
Title:  
Title:  The first object that met the eyes of d'Artagnan on entering
Title:  the room was Brisemont, stretched upon the ground and
Title:  rolling in horrible convulsions.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet and Fourreau, as pale as death, were trying to give
Title:  him succor; but it was plain that all assistance was
Title:  useless--all the features of the dying man were distorted
Title:  with agony.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!" cried he, on perceiving d'Artagnan, "ah! this is
Title:  frightful!  You pretend to pardon me, and you poison me!"
Title:  
Title:  "I!" cried d'Artagnan.  "I, wretch?  What do you say?"
Title:  
Title:  "I say that it was you who gave me the wine; I say that it
Title:  was you who desired me to drink it.  I say you wished to
Title:  avenge yourself on me, and I say that it is horrible!"
Title:  
Title:  "Do not think so, Brisemont," said d'Artagnan; "do not think
Title:  so.  I swear to you, I protest--"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, but God is above!  God will punish you!  My God, grant
Title:  that he may one day suffer what I suffer!"
Title:  
Title:  "Upon the Gospel," said d'Artagnan, throwing himself down by
Title:  the dying man, "I swear to you that the wine was poisoned
Title:  and that I was going to drink of it as you did."
Title:  
Title:  "I do not believe you," cried the soldier, and he expired
Title:  amid horrible tortures.
Title:  
Title:  "Frightful! frightful!" murmured Athos, while Porthos broke
Title:  the bottles and Aramis gave orders, a little too late, that
Title:  a confessor should be sent for.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my friends," said d'Artagnan, "you come once more to
Title:  save my life, not only mine but that of these gentlemen.
Title:  Gentlemen," continued he, addressing the Guardsmen, "I
Title:  request you will be silent with regard to this adventure.
Title:  Great personages may have had a hand in what you have seen,
Title:  and if talked about, the evil would only recoil upon us."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!" stammered Planchet, more dead than alive,
Title:  "ah, monsieur, what an escape I have had!"
Title:  
Title:  "How, sirrah! you were going to drink my wine?"
Title:  
Title:  "To the health of the king, monsieur; I was going to drink a
Title:  small glass of it if Fourreau had not told me I was called."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!" said Fourreau, whose teeth chattered with terror,
Title:  "I wanted to get him out of the way that I might drink myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, addressing the Guardsmen, "you
Title:  may easily comprehend that such a feast can only be very
Title:  dull after what has taken place; so accept my excuses, and
Title:  put off the party till another day, I beg of you."
Title:  
Title:  The two Guardsmen courteously accepted d'Artagnan's excuses,
Title:  and perceiving that the four friends desired to be alone,
Title:  retired.
Title:  
Title:  When the young Guardsman and the three Musketeers were
Title:  without witnesses, they looked at one another with an air
Title:  which plainly expressed that each of them perceived the
Title:  gravity of their situation.
Title:  
Title:  "In the first place," said Athos, "let us leave this
Title:  chamber; the dead are not agreeable company, particularly
Title:  when they have died a violent death."
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet," said d'Artagnan, "I commit the corpse of this
Title:  poor devil to your care.  Let him be interred in holy
Title:  ground.  He committed a crime, it is true; but he repented
Title:  of it."
Title:  
Title:  And the four friends quit the room, leaving to Planchet and
Title:  Fourreau the duty of paying mortuary honors to Brisemont.
Title:  
Title:  The host gave them another chamber, and served them with
Title:  fresh eggs and some water, which Athos went himself to draw
Title:  at the fountain.  In a few words, Porthos and Aramis were
Title:  posted as to the situation.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said d'Artagnan to Athos, "you see, my dear friend,
Title:  that this is war to the death."
Title:  
Title:  Athos shook his head.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," replied he, "I perceive that plainly; but do you
Title:  really believe it is she?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am sure of it."
Title:  
Title:  "Nevertheless, I confess I still doubt."
Title:  
Title:  "But the fleur-de-lis on her shoulder?"
Title:  
Title:  "She is some Englishwoman who has committed a crime in
Title:  France, and has been branded in consequence."
Title:  
Title:  "Athos, she is your wife, I tell you," repeated d'Artagnan;
Title:  "only reflect how much the two descriptions resemble each
Title:  other."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but I should think the other must be dead, I hanged
Title:  her so effectually."
Title:  
Title:  It was d'Artagnan who now shook his head in his turn.
Title:  
Title:  "But in either case, what is to be done?" said the young
Title:  man.
Title:  
Title:  "The fact is, one cannot remain thus, with a sword hanging
Title:  eternally over his head," said Athos.  "We must extricate
Title:  ourselves from this position."
Title:  
Title:  "But how?"
Title:  
Title:  "Listen!  You must try to see her, and have an explanation
Title:  with her.  Say to her: 'Peace or war!  My word as a
Title:  gentleman never to say anything of you, never to do anything
Title:  against you; on your side, a solemn oath to remain neutral
Title:  with respect to me.  If not, I will apply to the chancellor,
Title:  I will apply to the king, I will apply to the hangman, I
Title:  will move the courts against you, I will denounce you as
Title:  branded, I will bring you to trial; and if you are
Title:  acquitted, well, by the faith of a gentleman, I will kill
Title:  you at the corner of some wall, as I would a mad dog.'"
Title:  
Title:  "I like the means well enough," said d'Artagnan, "but where
Title:  and how to meet with her?"
Title:  
Title:  "Time, dear friend, time brings round opportunity;
Title:  opportunity is the martingale of man.  The more we have
Title:  ventured the more we gain, when we know how to wait."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but to wait surrounded by assassins and poisoners."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!" said Athos.  "God has preserved us hitherto, God will
Title:  preserve us still."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, we.  Besides, we are men; and everything considered,
Title:  it is our lot to risk our lives; but she," asked he, in an
Title:  undertone.
Title:  
Title:  "What she?" asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Constance."
Title:  
Title:  "Madame Bonacieux!  Ah, that's true!" said Athos.  "My poor
Title:  friend, I had forgotten you were in love."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but," said Aramis, "have you not learned by the
Title:  letter you found on the wretched corpse that she is in a
Title:  convent?  One may be very comfortable in a convent; and as
Title:  soon as the siege of La Rochelle is terminated, I promise
Title:  you on my part--"
Title:  
Title:  "Good," cried Athos, "good!  Yes, my dear Aramis, we all
Title:  know that your views have a religious tendency."
Title:  
Title:  "I am only temporarily a Musketeer," said Aramis, humbly.
Title:  
Title:  "It is some time since we heard from his mistress," said
Title:  Athos, in a low voice.  "But take no notice; we know all
Title:  about that."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos, "it appears to me that the means are
Title:  very simple."
Title:  
Title:  "What?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "You say she is in a convent?" replied Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well.  As soon as the siege is over, we'll carry her
Title:  off from that convent."
Title:  
Title:  "But we must first learn what convent she is in."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "But I think I have it," said Athos.  "Don't you say, dear
Title:  d'Artagnan, that it is the queen who has made choice of the
Title:  convent for her?"
Title:  
Title:  "I believe so, at least."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case Porthos will assist us."
Title:  
Title:  "And how so, if you please?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, by your marchioness, your duchess, your princess.  She
Title:  must have a long arm."
Title:  
Title:  "Hush!" said Porthos, placing a finger on his lips.  "I
Title:  believe her to be a cardinalist; she must know nothing of
Title:  the matter."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said Aramis, "I take upon myself to obtain
Title:  intelligence of her."
Title:  
Title:  "You, Aramis?" cried the three friends.  "You!  And how?"
Title:  
Title:  "By the queen's almoner, to whom I am very intimately
Title:  allied," said Aramis, coloring.
Title:  
Title:  And on this assurance, the four friends, who had finished
Title:  their modest repast, separated, with the promise of meeting
Title:  again that evening.  D'Artagnan returned to less important
Title:  affairs, and the three Musketeers repaired to the king's
Title:  quarters, where they had to prepare their lodging.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  43  THE SIGN OF THE RED DOVECOT
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile the king, who, with more reason than the cardinal,
Title:  showed his hatred for Buckingham, although scarcely arrived
Title:  was in such a haste to meet the enemy that he commanded
Title:  every disposition to be made to drive the English from the
Title:  Isle of Re, and afterward to press the siege of La Rochelle;
Title:  but notwithstanding his earnest wish, he was delayed by the
Title:  dissensions which broke out between MM. Bassompierre and
Title:  Schomberg, against the Duc d'Angouleme.
Title:  
Title:  MM. Bassompierre and Schomberg were marshals of France, and
Title:  claimed their right of commanding the army under the orders
Title:  of the king; but the cardinal, who feared that Bassompierre,
Title:  a Huguenot at heart, might press but feebly the English and
Title:  Rochellais, his brothers in religion, supported the Duc
Title:  d'Angouleme, whom the king, at his instigation, had named
Title:  lieutenant general.  The result was that to prevent MM.
Title:  Bassompierre and Schomberg from deserting the army, a
Title:  separate command had to be given to each.  Bassompierre took
Title:  up his quarters on the north of the city, between Leu and
Title:  Dompierre; the Duc d'Angouleme on the east, from Dompierre
Title:  to Perigny; and M. de Schomberg on the south, from Perigny
Title:  to Angoutin.
Title:  
Title:  The quarters of Monsieur were at Dompierre; the quarters of
Title:  the king were sometimes at Estree, sometimes at Jarrie; the
Title:  cardinal's quarters were upon the downs, at the bridge of La
Title:  Pierre, in a simple house without any entrenchment.  So that
Title:  Monsieur watched Bassompierre; the king, the Duc
Title:  d'Angouleme; and the cardinal, M. de Schomberg.
Title:  
Title:  As soon as this organization was established, they set about
Title:  driving the English from the Isle.
Title:  
Title:  The juncture was favorable.  The English, who require, above
Title:  everything, good living in order to be good soldiers, only
Title:  eating salt meat and bad biscuit, had many invalids in their
Title:  camp.  Still further, the sea, very rough at this period of
Title:  the year all along the sea coast, destroyed every day some
Title:  little vessel; and the shore, from the point of l'Aiguillon
Title:  to the trenches, was at every tide literally covered with
Title:  the wrecks of pinnacles, roberges, and feluccas.  The result
Title:  was that even if the king's troops remained quietly in their
Title:  camp, it was evident that some day or other, Buckingham, who
Title:  only continued in the Isle from obstinacy, would be obliged
Title:  to raise the siege.
Title:  
Title:  But as M. de Toiras gave information that everything was
Title:  preparing in the enemy's camp for a fresh assault, the king
Title:  judged that it would be best to put an end to the affair,
Title:  and gave the necessary orders for a decisive action.
Title:  
Title:  As it is not our intention to give a journal of the siege,
Title:  but on the contrary only to describe such of the events of
Title:  it as are connected with the story we are relating, we will
Title:  content ourselves with saying in two words that the
Title:  expedition succeeded, to the great astonishment of the king
Title:  and the great glory of the cardinal.  The English, repulsed
Title:  foot by foot, beaten in all encounters, and defeated in the
Title:  passage of the Isle of Loie, were obliged to re-embark,
Title:  leaving on the field of battle two thousand men, among whom
Title:  were five colonels, three lieutenant colonels, two hundred
Title:  and fifty captains, twenty gentlemen of rank, four pieces of
Title:  cannon, and sixty flags, which were taken to Paris by Claude
Title:  de St. Simon, and suspended with great pomp in the arches of
Title:  Notre Dame.
Title:  
Title:  Te Deums were chanted in camp, and afterward throughout
Title:  France.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal was left free to carry on the siege, without
Title:  having, at least at the present, anything to fear on the
Title:  part of the English.
Title:  
Title:  But it must be acknowledged, this response was but
Title:  momentary.  An envoy of the Duke of Buckingham, named
Title:  Montague, was taken, and proof was obtained of a league
Title:  between the German Empire, Spain, England, and Lorraine.
Title:  This league was directed against France.
Title:  
Title:  Still further, in Buckingham's lodging, which he had been
Title:  forced to abandon more precipitately than he expected,
Title:  papers were found which confirmed this alliance and which,
Title:  as the cardinal asserts in his memoirs, strongly compromised
Title:  Mme. de Chevreuse and consequently the queen.
Title:  
Title:  It was upon the cardinal that all the responsibility fell,
Title:  for one is not a despotic minister without responsibility.
Title:  All, therefore, of the vast resources of his genius were at
Title:  work night and day, engaged in listening to the least report
Title:  heard in any of the great kingdoms of Europe.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal was acquainted with the activity, and more
Title:  particularly the hatred, of Buckingham.  If the league which
Title:  threatened France triumphed, all his influence would be
Title:  lost.  Spanish policy and Austrian policy would have their
Title:  representatives in the cabinet of the Louvre, where they had
Title:  as yet but partisans; and he, Richelieu--the French
Title:  minister, the national minister--would be ruined.  The king,
Title:  even while obeying him like a child, hated him as a child
Title:  hates his master, and would abandon him to the personal
Title:  vengeance of Monsieur and the queen.  He would then be lost,
Title:  and France, perhaps, with him.  All this must be prepared
Title:  against.
Title:  
Title:  Courtiers, becoming every instant more numerous, succeeded
Title:  one another, day and night, in the little house of the
Title:  bridge of La Pierre, in which the cardinal had established
Title:  his residence.
Title:  
Title:  There were monks who wore the frock with such an ill grace
Title:  that it was easy to perceive they belonged to the church
Title:  militant; women a little inconvenienced by their costume as
Title:  pages and whose large trousers could not entirely conceal
Title:  their rounded forms; and peasants with blackened hands but
Title:  with fine limbs, savoring of the man of quality a league
Title:  off.
Title:  
Title:  There were also less agreeable visits--for two or three
Title:  times reports were spread that the cardinal had nearly been
Title:  assassinated.
Title:  
Title:  It is true that the enemies of the cardinal said that it was
Title:  he himself who set these bungling assassins to work, in
Title:  order to have, if wanted, the right of using reprisals; but
Title:  we must not believe everything ministers say, nor everything
Title:  their enemies say.
Title:  
Title:  These attempts did not prevent the cardinal, to whom his
Title:  most inveterate detractors have never denied personal
Title:  bravery, from making nocturnal excursions, sometimes to
Title:  communicate to the Duc d'Angouleme important orders,
Title:  sometimes to confer with the king, and sometimes to have an
Title:  interview with a messenger whom he did not wish to see at
Title:  home.
Title:  
Title:  On their part the Musketeers, who had not much to do with
Title:  the siege, were not under very strict orders and led a
Title:  joyous life.  The was the more easy for our three companions
Title:  in particular; for being friends of M. de Treville, they
Title:  obtained from him special permission to be absent after the
Title:  closing of the camp.
Title:  
Title:  Now, one evening when d'Artagnan, who was in the trenches,
Title:  was not able to accompany them, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis,
Title:  mounted on their battle steeds, enveloped in their war
Title:  cloaks, with their hands upon their pistol butts, were
Title:  returning from a drinking place called the Red Dovecot,
Title:  which Athos had discovered two days before upon the route to
Title:  Jarrie, following the road which led to the camp and quite
Title:  on their guard, as we have stated, for fear of an ambuscade,
Title:  when, about a quarter of a league from the village of
Title:  Boisnau, they fancied they heard the sound of horses
Title:  approaching them.  They immediately all three halted, closed
Title:  in, and waited, occupying the middle of the road.  In an
Title:  instant, and as the moon broke from behind a cloud, they saw
Title:  at a turning of the road two horsemen who, on perceiving
Title:  them, stopped in their turn, appearing to deliberate whether
Title:  they should continue their route or go back.  The hesitation
Title:  created some suspicion in the three friends, and Athos,
Title:  advancing a few paces in front of the others, cried in a
Title:  firm voice, "Who goes there?"
Title:  
Title:  "Who goes there, yourselves?" replied one of the horsemen.
Title:  
Title:  "That is not an answer," replied Athos.  "Who goes there?
Title:  Answer, or we charge."
Title:  
Title:  "Beware of what you are about, gentlemen!" said a clear
Title:  voice which seemed accustomed to command.
Title:  
Title:  "It is some superior officer making his night rounds," said
Title:  Athos.  "What do you wish, gentlemen?"
Title:  
Title:  "Who are you?" said the same voice, in the same commanding
Title:  tone. "Answer in your turn, or you may repent of your
Title:  disobedience."
Title:  
Title:  "King's Musketeers," said Athos, more and more convinced
Title:  that he who interrogated them had the right to do so.
Title:  
Title:  "What company?"
Title:  
Title:  "Company of Treville."
Title:  
Title:  "Advance, and give an account of what you are doing here at
Title:  this hour."
Title:  
Title:  The three companions advanced rather humbly--for all were
Title:  now convinced that they had to do with someone more powerful
Title:  than themselves--leaving Athos the post of speaker.
Title:  
Title:  One of the two riders, he who had spoken second, was ten
Title:  paces in front of his companion.  Athos made a sign to
Title:  Porthos and Aramis also to remain in the rear, and advanced
Title:  alone.
Title:  
Title:  "Your pardon, my officer," said Athos; "but we were ignorant
Title:  with whom we had to do, and you may see that we were good
Title:  guard."
Title:  
Title:  "Your name?" said the officer, who covered a part of his
Title:  face with his cloak.
Title:  
Title:  "But yourself, monsieur," said Athos, who began to be
Title:  annoyed by this inquisition, "give me, I beg you, the proof
Title:  that you have the right to question me."
Title:  
Title:  "Your name?" repeated the cavalier a second time, letting
Title:  his cloak fall, and leaving his face uncovered.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur the Cardinal!" cried the stupefied Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "Your name?" cried his Eminence, for the third time.
Title:  
Title:  "Athos," said the Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal made a sign to his attendant, who drew near.
Title:  "These three Musketeers shall follow us," said he, in an
Title:  undertone.  "I am not willing it should be known I have left
Title:  the camp; and if they follow us we shall be certain they
Title:  will tell nobody."
Title:  
Title:  "We are gentlemen, monseigneur," said Athos; "require our
Title:  parole, and give yourself no uneasiness.  Thank God, we can
Title:  keep a secret."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal fixed his piercing eyes on this courageous
Title:  speaker.
Title:  
Title:  "You have a quick ear, Monsieur Athos," said the cardinal;
Title:  "but now listen to this.  It is not from mistrust that I
Title:  request you to follow me, but for my security.  Your
Title:  companions are no doubt Messieurs Porthos and Aramis."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, your Eminence," said Athos, while the two Musketeers
Title:  who had remained behind advanced hat in hand.
Title:  
Title:  "I know you, gentlemen," said the cardinal, "I know you.  I
Title:  know you are not quite my friends, and I am sorry you are
Title:  not so; but I know you are brave and loyal gentlemen, and
Title:  that confidence may be placed in you.  Monsieur Athos, do
Title:  me, then, the honor to accompany me; you and your two
Title:  friends, and then I shall have an escort to excite envy in
Title:  his Majesty, if we should meet him."
Title:  
Title:  The three Musketeers bowed to the necks of their horses.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, upon my honor," said Athos, "your Eminence is right
Title:  in taking us with you; we have seen several ill-looking
Title:  faces on the road, and we have even had a quarrel at the Red
Title:  Dovecot with four of those faces."
Title:  
Title:  "A quarrel, and what for, gentlemen?" said the cardinal;
Title:  "you know I don't like quarrelers."
Title:  
Title:  "And that is the reason why I have the honor to inform your
Title:  Eminence of what has happened; for you might learn it from
Title:  others, and upon a false account believe us to be in fault."
Title:  
Title:  "What have been the results of your quarrel?" said the
Title:  cardinal, knitting his brow.
Title:  
Title:  "My friend, Aramis, here, has received a slight sword wound
Title:  in the arm, but not enough to prevent him, as your Eminence
Title:  may see, from mounting to the assault tomorrow, if your
Title:  Eminence orders an escalade."
Title:  
Title:  "But you are not the men to allow sword wounds to be
Title:  inflicted upon you thus," said the cardinal.  "Come, be
Title:  frank, gentlemen, you have settled accounts with somebody!
Title:  Confess; you know I have the right of giving absolution."
Title:  
Title:  "I, monseigneur?" said Athos.  "I did not even draw my
Title:  sword, but I took him who offended me round the body, and
Title:  threw him out of the window.  It appears that in falling,"
Title:  continued Athos, with some hesitation, "he broke his thigh."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said the cardinal; "and you, Monsieur Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "I, monseigneur, knowing that dueling is prohibited--I
Title:  seized a bench, and gave one of those brigands such a blow
Title:  that I believe his shoulder is broken."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well," said the cardinal; "and you, Monsieur Aramis?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur, being of a very mild disposition, and being,
Title:  likewise, of which Monseigneur perhaps is not aware, about
Title:  to enter into orders, I endeavored to appease my comrades,
Title:  when one of these wretches gave me a wound with a sword,
Title:  treacherously, across my left arm.  Then I admit my patience
Title:  failed me; I drew my sword in my turn, and as he came back
Title:  to the charge, I fancied I felt that in throwing himself
Title:  upon me, he let it pass through his body.  I only know for a
Title:  certainty that he fell; and it seemed to me that he was
Title:  borne away with his two companions."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil, gentlemen!" said the cardinal, "three men placed
Title:  hors de combat in a cabaret squabble!  You don't do your
Title:  work by halves.  And pray what was this quarrel about?"
Title:  
Title:  "These fellows were drunk," said Athos, "and knowing there
Title:  was a lady who had arrived at the cabaret this evening, they
Title:  wanted to force her door."
Title:  
Title:  "Force her door!" said the cardinal, "and for what purpose?"
Title:  
Title:  "To do her violence, without doubt," said Athos.  "I have
Title:  had the honor of informing your Eminence that these men were
Title:  drunk."
Title:  
Title:  "And was this lady young and handsome?" asked the cardinal,
Title:  with a certain degree of anxiety.
Title:  
Title:  "We did not see her, monseigneur," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "You did not see her?  Ah, very well," replied the cardinal,
Title:  quickly.  "You did well to defend the honor of a woman; and
Title:  as I am going to the Red Dovecot myself, I shall know if you
Title:  have told me the truth."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," said Athos, haughtily, "we are gentlemen, and
Title:  to save our heads we would not be guilty of a falsehood."
Title:  
Title:  "Therefore I do not doubt what you say, Monsieur Athos, I do
Title:  not doubt it for a single instant; but," added he, "to
Title:  change the conversation, was this lady alone?"
Title:  
Title:  "The lady had a cavalier shut up with her," said Athos, "but
Title:  as notwithstanding the noise, this cavalier did not show
Title:  himself, it is to be presumed that he is a coward."
Title:  
Title:  "'Judge not rashly', says the Gospel," replied the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  Athos bowed.
Title:  
Title:  "And now, gentlemen, that's well," continued the cardinal.
Title:  "I know what I wish to know; follow me."
Title:  
Title:  The three Musketeers passed behind his Eminence, who again
Title:  enveloped his face in his cloak, and put his horse in
Title:  motion, keeping from eight to ten paces in advance of his
Title:  four companions.
Title:  
Title:  They soon arrived at the silent, solitary inn.  No doubt the
Title:  host knew what illustrious visitor was expected, and had
Title:  consequently sent intruders out of the way.
Title:  
Title:  Ten paces from the door the cardinal made a sign to his
Title:  esquire and the three Musketeers to halt.  A saddled horse
Title:  was fastened to the window shutter.  The cardinal knocked
Title:  three times, and in a peculiar manner.
Title:  
Title:  A man, enveloped in a cloak, came out immediately, and
Title:  exchanged some rapid words with the cardinal; after which he
Title:  mounted his horse, and set off in the direction of Surgeres,
Title:  which was likewise the way to Paris.
Title:  
Title:  "Advance, gentlemen," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "You have told me the truth, my gentlemen," said he,
Title:  addressing the Musketeers, "and it will not be my fault if
Title:  our encounter this evening be not advantageous to you.  In
Title:  the meantime, follow me."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal alighted; the three Musketeers did likewise.
Title:  The cardinal threw the bridle of his horse to his esquire;
Title:  the three Musketeers fastened the horses to the shutters.
Title:  
Title:  The host stood at the door.  For him, the cardinal was only
Title:  an officer coming to visit a lady.
Title:  
Title:  "Have you any chamber on the ground floor where these
Title:  gentlemen can wait near a good fire?" said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  The host opened the door of a large room, in which an old
Title:  stove had just been replaced by a large and excellent
Title:  chimney.
Title:  
Title:  "I have this," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "That will do," replied the cardinal.  "Enter, gentlemen,
Title:  and be kind enough to wait for me; I shall not be more than
Title:  half an hour."
Title:  
Title:  And while the three Musketeers entered the ground floor
Title:  room, the cardinal, without asking further information,
Title:  ascended the staircase like a man who has no need of having
Title:  his road pointed out to him.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  44  THE UTILITY OF STOVEPIPES
Title:  
Title:  It was evident that without suspecting it, and actuated
Title:  solely by their chivalrous and adventurous character, our
Title:  three friends had just rendered a service to someone the
Title:  cardinal honored with his special protection.
Title:  
Title:  Now, who was that someone?  That was the question the three
Title:  Musketeers put to one another.  Then, seeing that none of
Title:  their replies could throw any light on the subject, Porthos
Title:  called the host and asked for dice.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis placed themselves at the table and began
Title:  to play.  Athos walked about in a contemplative mood.
Title:  
Title:  While thinking and walking, Athos passed and repassed before
Title:  the pipe of the stove, broken in halves, the other extremity
Title:  passing into the chamber above; and every time he passed and
Title:  repassed he heard a murmur of words, which at length fixed
Title:  his attention.  Athos went close to it, and distinguished
Title:  some words that appeared to merit so great an interest that
Title:  he made a sign to his friends to be silent, remaining
