Title:  himself bent with his ear directed to the opening of the
Title:  lower orifice.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen, Milady," said the cardinal, "the affair is
Title:  important.  Sit down, and let us talk it over."
Title:  
Title:  "Milady!" murmured Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I listen to your Eminence with greatest attention," replied
Title:  a female voice which made the Musketeer start.
Title:  
Title:  "A small vessel with an English crew, whose captain is on my
Title:  side, awaits you at the mouth of Charente, at fort of the
Title:  Point.  He will set sail tomorrow morning."
Title:  
Title:  "I must go thither tonight?"
Title:  
Title:  "Instantly!  That is to say, when you have received my
Title:  instructions.  Two men, whom you will find at the door on
Title:  going out, will serve you as escort.  You will allow me to
Title:  leave first; then, after half an hour, you can go away in
Title:  your turn."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur.  Now let us return to the mission with
Title:  which you wish to charge me; and as I desire to continue to
Title:  merit the confidence of your Eminence, deign to unfold it to
Title:  me in terms clear and precise, that I may not commit an
Title:  error."
Title:  
Title:  There was an instant of profound silence between the two
Title:  interlocutors.  It was evident that the cardinal was
Title:  weighing beforehand the terms in which he was about to
Title:  speak, and that Milady was collecting all her intellectual
Title:  faculties to comprehend the things he was about to say, and
Title:  to engrave them in her memory when they should be spoken.
Title:  
Title:  Athos took advantage of this moment to tell his two
Title:  companions to fasten the door inside, and to make them a
Title:  sign to come and listen with him.
Title:  
Title:  The two Musketeers, who loved their ease, brought a chair
Title:  for each of themselves and one for Athos.  All three then
Title:  sat down with their heads together and their ears on the
Title:  alert.
Title:  
Title:  "You will go to London," continued the cardinal.  "Arrived
Title:  in London, you will seek Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  "I must beg your Eminence to observe," said Milady, "that
Title:  since the affair of the diamond studs, about which the duke
Title:  always suspected me, his Grace distrusts me."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, this time," said the cardinal, "it is not necessary
Title:  to steal his confidence, but to present yourself frankly and
Title:  loyally as a negotiator."
Title:  
Title:  "Frankly and loyally," repeated Milady, with an unspeakable
Title:  expression of duplicity.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, frankly and loyally," replied the cardinal, in the
Title:  same tone.  "All this negotiation must be carried on
Title:  openly."
Title:  
Title:  "I will follow your Eminence's instructions to the letter.
Title:  I only wait till you give them."
Title:  
Title:  "You will go to Buckingham in my behalf, and you will tell
Title:  him I am acquainted with all the preparations he has made;
Title:  but that they give me no uneasiness, since at the first step
Title:  he takes I will ruin the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "Will he believe that your Eminence is in a position to
Title:  accomplish the threat thus made?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; for I have the proofs."
Title:  
Title:  "I must be able to present these proofs for his
Title:  appreciation."
Title:  
Title:  "Without doubt.  And you will tell him I will publish the
Title:  report of Bois-Robert and the Marquis de Beautru, upon the
Title:  interview which the duke had at the residence of Madame the
Title:  Constable with the queen on the evening Madame the Constable
Title:  gave a masquerade.  You will tell him, in order that he may
Title:  not doubt, that he came there in the costume of the Great
Title:  Mogul, which the Chevalier de Guise was to have worn, and
Title:  that he purchased this exchange for the sum of three
Title:  thousand pistoles."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monseigneur?"
Title:  
Title:  "All the details of his coming into and going out of the
Title:  palace--on the night when he introduced himself in the
Title:  character of an Italian fortune teller--you will tell him,
Title:  that he may not doubt the correctness of my information;
Title:  that he had under his cloak a large white robe dotted with
Title:  black tears, death's heads, and crossbones--for in case of a
Title:  surprise, he was to pass for the phantom of the White Lady
Title:  who, as all the world knows, appears at the Louvre every
Title:  time any great event is impending."
Title:  
Title:  "Is that all, monseigneur?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tell him also that I am acquainted with all the details of
Title:  the adventure at Amiens; that I will have a little romance
Title:  made of it, wittily turned, with a plan of the garden and
Title:  portraits of the principal actors in that nocturnal
Title:  romance."
Title:  
Title:  "I will tell him that."
Title:  
Title:  "Tell him further that I hold Montague in my power; that
Title:  Montague is in the Bastille; that no letters were found upon
Title:  him, it is true, but that torture may make him tell much of
Title:  what he knows, and even what he does not know."
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly."
Title:  
Title:  "Then add that his Grace has, in the precipitation with
Title:  which he quit the Isle of Re, forgotten and left behind him
Title:  in his lodging a certain letter from Madame de Chevreuse
Title:  which singularly compromises the queen, inasmuch as it
Title:  proves not only that her Majesty can love the enemies of the
Title:  king but that she can conspire with the enemies of France.
Title:  You recollect perfectly all I have told you, do you not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Your Eminence will judge: the ball of Madame the Constable;
Title:  the night at the Louvre; the evening at Amiens; the arrest
Title:  of Montague; the letter of Madame de Chevreuse."
Title:  
Title:  "That's it," said the cardinal, "that's it.  You have an
Title:  excellent memory, Milady."
Title:  
Title:  "But," resumed she to whom the cardinal addressed this
Title:  flattering compliment, "if, in spite of all these reasons,
Title:  the duke does not give way and continues to menace France?"
Title:  
Title:  "The duke is in love to madness, or rather to folly,"
Title:  replied Richelieu, with great bitterness.  "Like the ancient
Title:  paladins, he has only undertaken this war to obtain a look
Title:  from his lady love.  If he becomes certain that this war
Title:  will cost the honor, and perhaps the liberty, of the lady of
Title:  his thoughts, as he says, I will answer for it he will look
Title:  twice."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," said Milady, with a persistence that proved she
Title:  wished to see clearly to the end of the mission with which
Title:  she was about to be charged, "if he persists?"
Title:  
Title:  "If he persists?" said the cardinal.  "That is not
Title:  probable."
Title:  
Title:  "It is possible," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "If he persists--" His Eminence made a pause, and resumed:
Title:  "If he persists--well, then I shall hope for one of those
Title:  events which change the destinies of states."
Title:  
Title:  "If your Eminence would quote to me some one of these events
Title:  in history," said Milady, "perhaps I should partake of your
Title:  confidence as to the future."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, here, for example," said Richelieu: "when, in 1610,
Title:  for a cause similar to that which moves the duke, King Henry
Title:  IV, of glorious memory, was about, at the same time, to
Title:  invade Flanders and Italy, in order to attack Austria on
Title:  both sides.  Well, did there not happen an event which saved
Title:  Austria?  Why should not the king of France have the same
Title:  chance as the emperor?"
Title:  
Title:  "Your Eminence means, I presume, the knife stab in the Rue
Title:  de la Feronnerie?"
Title:  
Title:  "Precisely," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Does not your Eminence fear that the punishment inflicted
Title:  upon Ravaillac may deter anyone who might entertain the idea
Title:  of imitating him?"
Title:  
Title:  "There will be, in all times and in all countries,
Title:  particularly if religious divisions exist in those
Title:  countries, fanatics who ask nothing better than to become
Title:  martyrs.  Ay, and observe--it just occurs to me that the
Title:  Puritans are furious against Buckingham, and their preachers
Title:  designate him as the Antichrist."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," continued the cardinal, in an indifferent tone, "the
Title:  only thing to be sought for at this moment is some woman,
Title:  handsome, young, and clever, who has cause of quarrel with
Title:  the duke.  The duke has had many affairs of gallantry; and
Title:  if he has fostered his amours by promises of eternal
Title:  constancy, he must likewise have sown the seeds of hatred by
Title:  his eternal infidelities."
Title:  
Title:  "No doubt," said Milady, coolly, "such a woman may be
Title:  found."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, such a woman, who would place the knife of Jacques
Title:  Clement or of Ravaillac in the hands of a fanatic, would
Title:  save France."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but she would then be the accomplice of an
Title:  assassination."
Title:  
Title:  "Were the accomplices of Ravaillac or of Jacques Clement
Title:  ever known?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; for perhaps they were too high-placed for anyone to
Title:  dare look for them where they were.  The Palace of Justice
Title:  would not be burned down for everybody, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "You think, then, that the fire at the Palace of Justice was
Title:  not caused by chance?" asked Richelieu, in the tone with
Title:  which he would have put a question of no importance.
Title:  
Title:  "I, monseigneur?" replied Milady.  "I think nothing; I quote
Title:  a fact, that is all.  Only I say that if I were named Madame
Title:  de Montpensier, or the Queen Marie de Medicis, I should use
Title:  less precautions than I take, being simply called Milady
Title:  Clarik."
Title:  
Title:  "That is just," said Richelieu.  "What do you require,
Title:  then?"
Title:  
Title:  "I require an order which would ratify beforehand all that I
Title:  should think proper to do for the greatest good of France."
Title:  
Title:  "But in the first place, this woman I have described must be
Title:  found who is desirous of avenging herself upon the duke."
Title:  
Title:  "She is found," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Then the miserable fanatic must be found who will serve as
Title:  an instrument of God's justice."
Title:  
Title:  "He will be found."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said the cardinal, "then it will be time to claim
Title:  the order which you just now required."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Eminence is right," replied Milady; "and I have been
Title:  wrong in seeing in the mission with which you honor me
Title:  anything but that which it really is--that is, to announce
Title:  to his Grace, on the part of your Eminence, that you are
Title:  acquainted with the different disguises by means of which he
Title:  succeeded in approaching the queen during the fete given by
Title:  Madame the Constable; that you have proofs of the interview
Title:  granted at the Louvre by the queen to a certain Italian
Title:  astrologer who was no other than the Duke of Buckingham;
Title:  that you have ordered a little romance of a satirical nature
Title:  to be written upon the adventures of Amiens, with a plan of
Title:  the gardens in which those adventures took place, and
Title:  portraits of the actors who figured in them; that Montague
Title:  is in the Bastille, and that the torture may make him say
Title:  things he remembers, and even things he has forgotten; that
Title:  you possess a certain letter from Madame de Chevreuse, found
Title:  in his Grace's lodging, which singularly compromises not
Title:  only her who wrote it, but her in whose name it was written.
Title:  Then, if he persists, notwithstanding all this--as that is,
Title:  as I have said, the limit of my mission--I shall have
Title:  nothing to do but to pray God to work a miracle for the
Title:  salvation of France.  That is it, is it not, monseigneur,
Title:  and I shall have nothing else to do?"
Title:  
Title:  "That is it," replied the cardinal, dryly.
Title:  
Title:  "And now," said Milady, without appearing to remark the
Title:  change of the duke's tone toward her--"now that I have
Title:  received the instructions of your Eminence as concerns your
Title:  enemies, Monseigneur will permit me to say a few words to
Title:  him of mine?"
Title:  
Title:  "Have you enemies, then?" asked Richelieu.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur, enemies against whom you owe me all your
Title:  support, for I made them by serving your Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  "Who are they?" replied the duke.
Title:  
Title:  "In the first place, there is a little intrigante named
Title:  Bonacieux."
Title:  
Title:  "She is in the prison of Nantes."
Title:  
Title:  "That is to say, she was there," replied Milady; "but the
Title:  queen has obtained an order from the king by means of which
Title:  she has been conveyed to a convent."
Title:  
Title:  "To a convent?" said the duke.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, to a convent."
Title:  
Title:  "And to which?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know; the secret has been well kept."
Title:  
Title:  "But I will know!"
Title:  
Title:  "And your Eminence will tell me in what convent that woman
Title:  is?"
Title:  
Title:  "I can see nothing inconvenient in that," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, now I have an enemy much more to be dreaded by me
Title:  than this little Madame Bonacieux."
Title:  
Title:  "Who is that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Her lover."
Title:  
Title:  "What is his name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, your Eminence knows him well," cried Milady, carried
Title:  away by her anger.  "He is the evil genius of both of us.
Title:  It is he who in an encounter with your Eminence's Guards
Title:  decided the victory in favor of the king's Musketeers; it is
Title:  he who gave three desperate wounds to de Wardes, your
Title:  emissary, and who caused the affair of the diamond studs to
Title:  fail; it is he who, knowing it was I who had Madame
Title:  Bonacieux carried off, has sworn my death."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said the cardinal, "I know of whom you speak."
Title:  
Title:  "I mean that miserable d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "He is a bold fellow," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "And it is exactly because he is a bold fellow that he is
Title:  the more to be feared."
Title:  
Title:  "I must have," said the duke, "a proof of his connection
Title:  with Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  "A proof?" cried Milady; "I will have ten."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, it becomes the simplest thing in the world; get
Title:  me that proof, and I will send him to the Bastille."
Title:  
Title:  "So far good, monseigneur; but afterwards?"
Title:  
Title:  "When once in the Bastille, there is no afterward!" said the
Title:  cardinal, in a low voice.  "Ah, pardieu!" continued he, "if
Title:  it were as easy for me to get rid of my enemy as it is easy
Title:  to get rid of yours, and if it were against such people you
Title:  require impunity--"
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," replied Milady, "a fair exchange.  Life for
Title:  life, man for man; give me one, I will give you the other."
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know what you mean, nor do I even desire to know
Title:  what you mean," replied the cardinal; "but I wish to please
Title:  you, and see nothing out of the way in giving you what you
Title:  demand with respect to so infamous a creature--the more so
Title:  as you tell me this d'Artagnan is a libertine, a duelist,
Title:  and a traitor."
Title:  
Title:  "An infamous scoundrel, monseigneur, a scoundrel!"
Title:  
Title:  "Give me paper, a quill, and some ink, then," said the
Title:  cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Here they are, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  There was a moment of silence, which proved that the
Title:  cardinal was employed in seeking the terms in which he
Title:  should write the note, or else in writing it.  Athos, who
Title:  had not lost a word of the conversation, took his two
Title:  companions by the hand, and led them to the other end of the
Title:  room.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Porthos, "what do you want, and why do you not
Title:  let us listen to the end of the conversation?"
Title:  
Title:  "Hush!" said Athos, speaking in a low voice.  "We have heard
Title:  all it was necessary we should hear; besides, I don't
Title:  prevent you from listening, but I must be gone."
Title:  
Title:  "You must be gone!" said Porthos; "and if the cardinal asks
Title:  for you, what answer can we make?"
Title:  
Title:  "You will not wait till he asks; you will speak first, and
Title:  tell him that I am gone on the lookout, because certain
Title:  expressions of our host have given me reason to think the
Title:  road is not safe.  I will say two words about it to the
Title:  cardinal's esquire likewise.  The rest concerns myself;
Title:  don't be uneasy about that."
Title:  
Title:  "Be prudent, Athos," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Be easy on that head," replied Athos; "you know I am cool
Title:  enough."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis resumed their places by the stovepipe.
Title:  
Title:  As to Athos, he went out without any mystery, took his
Title:  horse, which was tied with those of his friends to the
Title:  fastenings of the shutters, in four words convinced the
Title:  attendant of the necessity of a vanguard for their return,
Title:  carefully examined the priming of his pistols, drew his
Title:  sword, and took, like a forlorn hope, the road to the camp.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  45  A CONJUGAL SCENE
Title:  
Title:  As Athos had foreseen, it was not long before the cardinal
Title:  came down.  He opened the door of the room in which the
Title:  Musketeers were, and found Porthos playing an earnest game
Title:  of dice with Aramis.  He cast a rapid glance around the
Title:  room, and perceived that one of his men was missing.
Title:  
Title:  "What has become of Monseigneur Athos?" asked he.
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," replied Porthos, "he has gone as a scout, on
Title:  account of some words of our host, which made him believe
Title:  the road was not safe."
Title:  
Title:  "And you, what have you done, Monsieur Porthos?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have won five pistoles of Aramis."
Title:  
Title:  "Well; now will you return with me?"
Title:  
Title:  "We are at your Eminence's orders."
Title:  
Title:  "To horse, then, gentlemen; for it is getting late."
Title:  
Title:  The attendant was at the door, holding the cardinal's horse
Title:  by the bridle.  At a short distance a group of two men and
Title:  three horses appeared in the shade.  These were the two men
Title:  who were to conduct Milady to the fort of the Point, and
Title:  superintend her embarkation.
Title:  
Title:  The attendant confirmed to the cardinal what the two
Title:  Musketeers had already said with respect to Athos.  The
Title:  cardinal made an approving gesture, and retraced his route
Title:  with the same precautions he had used incoming.
Title:  
Title:  Let us leave him to follow the road to the camp protected by
Title:  his esquire and the two Musketeers, and return to Athos.
Title:  
Title:  For a hundred paces he maintained the speed at which he
Title:  started; but when out of sight he turned his horse to the
Title:  right, made a circuit, and came back within twenty paces of
Title:  a high hedge to watch the passage of the little troop.
Title:  Having recognized the laced hats of his companions and the
Title:  golden fringe of the cardinal's cloak, he waited till the
Title:  horsemen had turned the angle of the road, and having lost
Title:  sight of them, he returned at a gallop to the inn, which was
Title:  opened to him without hesitation.
Title:  
Title:  The host recognized him.
Title:  
Title:  "My officer," said Athos, "has forgotten to give a piece of
Title:  very important information to the lady, and has sent me back
Title:  to repair his forgetfulness."
Title:  
Title:  "Go up," said the host; "she is still in her chamber."
Title:  
Title:  Athos availed himself of the permission, ascended the stairs
Title:  with his lightest step, gained the landing, and through the
Title:  open door perceived Milady putting on her hat.
Title:  
Title:  He entered the chamber and closed the door behind him.  At
Title:  the noise he made in pushing the bolt, Milady turned round.
Title:  
Title:  Athos was standing before the door, enveloped in his cloak,
Title:  with his hat pulled down over his eyes.  On seeing this
Title:  figure, mute and immovable as a statue, Milady was
Title:  frightened.
Title:  
Title:  "Who are you, and what do you want?" cried she.
Title:  
Title:  "Humph," murmured Athos, "it is certainly she!"
Title:  
Title:  And letting fall his cloak and raising his hat, he advanced
Title:  toward Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know me, madame?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  Milady made one step forward, and then drew back as if she
Title:  had seen a serpent.
Title:  
Title:  "So far, well," said Athos, "I perceive you know me."
Title:  
Title:  "The Comte de la Fere!" murmured Milady, becoming
Title:  exceedingly pale, and drawing back till the wall prevented
Title:  her from going any farther.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, Milady," replied Athos; "the Comte de la Fere in
Title:  person, who comes expressly from the other world to have the
Title:  pleasure of paying you a visit.  Sit down, madame, and let
Title:  us talk, as the cardinal said."
Title:  
Title:  Milady, under the influence of inexpressible terror, sat
Title:  down without uttering a word.
Title:  
Title:  "You certainly are a demon sent upon the earth!" said Athos.
Title:  "Your power is great, I know; but you also know that with
Title:  the help of God men have often conquered the most terrible
Title:  demons.  You have once before thrown yourself in my path.  I
Title:  thought I had crushed you, madame; but either I was deceived
Title:  or hell has resuscitated you!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady at these words, which recalled frightful
Title:  remembrances, hung down her head with a suppressed groan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, hell has resuscitated you," continued Athos.  "Hell
Title:  has made you rich, hell has given you another name, hell has
Title:  almost made you another face; but it has neither effaced the
Title:  stains from your soul nor the brand from your body."
Title:  
Title:  Milady arose as if moved by a powerful spring, and her eyes
Title:  flashed lightning.  Athos remained sitting.
Title:  
Title:  "You believed me to be dead, did you not, as I believed you
Title:  to be?  And the name of Athos as well concealed the Comte de
Title:  la Fere, as the name Milady Clarik concealed Anne de Breuil.
Title:  Was it not so you were called when your honored brother
Title:  married us?  Our position is truly a strange one," continued
Title:  Athos, laughing.  "We have only lived up to the present time
Title:  because we believed each other dead, and because a
Title:  remembrance is less oppressive than a living creature,
Title:  though a remembrance is sometimes devouring."
Title:  
Title:  "But," said Milady, in a hollow, faint voice, "what brings
Title:  you back to me, and what do you want with me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I wish to tell you that though remaining invisible to your
Title:  eyes, I have not lost sight of you."
Title:  
Title:  "You know what I have done?"
Title:  
Title:  "I can relate to you, day by day, your actions from your
Title:  entrance to the service of the cardinal to this evening."
Title:  
Title:  A smile of incredulity passed over the pale lips of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen!  It was you who cut off the two diamond studs from
Title:  the shoulder of the Duke of Buckingham; it was you had the
Title:  Madame Bonacieux carried off; it was you who, in love with
Title:  de Wardes and thinking to pass the night with him, opened
Title:  the door to Monsieur d'Artagnan; it was you who, believing
Title:  that de Wardes had deceived you, wished to have him killed
Title:  by his rival; it was you who, when this rival had discovered
Title:  your infamous secret, wished to have him killed in his turn
Title:  by two assassins, whom you sent in pursuit of him; it was
Title:  you who, finding the balls had missed their mark, sent
Title:  poisoned wine with a forged letter, to make your victim
Title:  believe that the wine came from his friends.  In short, it
Title:  was you who have but now in this chamber, seated in this
Title:  chair I now fill, made an engagement with Cardinal Richelieu
Title:  to cause the Duke of Buckingham to be assassinated, in
Title:  exchange for the promise he has made you to allow you to
Title:  assassinate d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  Milady was livid.
Title:  
Title:  "You must be Satan!" cried she.
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps," said Athos; "But at all events listen well to
Title:  this.  Assassinate the Duke of Buckingham, or cause him to
Title:  be assassinated--I care very little about that!  I don't
Title:  know him.  Besides, he is an Englishman.  But do not touch
Title:  with the tip of your finger a single hair of d'Artagnan, who
Title:  is a faithful friend whom I love and defend, or I swear to
Title:  you by the head of my father the crime which you shall have
Title:  endeavored to commit, or shall have committed, shall be the
Title:  last."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur d'Artagnan has cruelly insulted me," said Milady,
Title:  in a hollow tone; "Monsieur d'Artagnan shall die!"
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed!  Is it possible to insult you, madame?" said Athos,
Title:  laughing; "he has insulted you, and he shall die!"
Title:  
Title:  "He shall die!" replied Milady; "she first, and he
Title:  afterward."
Title:  
Title:  Athos was seized with a kind of vertigo.  The sight of this
Title:  creature, who had nothing of the woman about her, recalled
Title:  awful remembrances.  He thought how one day, in a less
Title:  dangerous situation than the one in which he was now placed,
Title:  he had already endeavored to sacrifice her to his honor.
Title:  His desire for blood returned, burning his brain and
Title:  pervading his frame like a raging fever; he arose in his
Title:  turn, reached his hand to his belt, drew forth a pistol, and
Title:  cocked it.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, pale as a corpse, endeavored to cry out; but her
Title:  swollen tongue could utter no more than a hoarse sound which
Title:  had nothing human in it and resembled the rattle of a wild
Title:  beast.  Motionless against the dark tapestry, with her hair
Title:  in disorder, she appeared like a horrid image of terror.
Title:  
Title:  Athos slowly raised his pistol, stretched out his arm so
Title:  that the weapon almost touched Milady's forehead, and then,
Title:  in a voice the more terrible from having the supreme
Title:  calmness of a fixed resolution, "Madame," said he, "you will
Title:  this instant deliver to me the paper the cardinal signed; or
Title:  upon my soul, I will blow your brains out."
Title:  
Title:  With another man, Milady might have preserved some doubt;
Title:  but she knew Athos.  Nevertheless, she remained motionless.
Title:  
Title:  "You have one second to decide," said he.
Title:  
Title:  Milady saw by the contraction of his countenance that the
Title:  trigger was about to be pulled; she reached her hand quickly
Title:  to her bosom, drew out a paper, and held it toward Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Take it," said she, "and be accursed!"
Title:  
Title:  Athos took the paper, returned the pistol to his belt,
Title:  approached the lamp to be assured that it was the paper,
Title:  unfolded it, and read:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Dec. 3, 1627
Title:  
Title:  It is by my order and for the good of the state that the
Title:  bearer of this has done what he has done.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "And now," said Athos, resuming his cloak and putting on his
Title:  hat, "now that I have drawn your teeth, viper, bite if you
Title:  can."
Title:  
Title:  And he left the chamber without once looking behind him.
Title:  
Title:  At the door he found the two men and the spare horse which
Title:  they held.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said he, "Monseigneur's order is, you know, to
Title:  conduct that woman, without losing time, to the fort of the
Title:  Point, and never to leave her till she is on board."
Title:  
Title:  As these words agreed wholly with the order they had
Title:  received, they bowed their heads in sign of assent.
Title:  
Title:  With regard to Athos, he leaped lightly into the saddle and
Title:  set out at full gallop; only instead of following the road,
Title:  he went across the fields, urging his horse to the utmost
Title:  and stopping occasionally to listen.
Title:  
Title:  In one of those halts he heard the steps of several horses
Title:  on the road.  He had no doubt it was the cardinal and his
Title:  escort.  He immediately made a new point in advance, rubbed
Title:  his horse down with some heath and leaves of trees, and
Title:  placed himself across the road, about two hundred paces from
Title:  the camp.
Title:  
Title:  "Who goes there?" cried he, as soon as he perceived the
Title:  horsemen.
Title:  
Title:  "That is our brave Musketeer, I think," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur," said Porthos, "it is he."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur Athos," said Richelieu, "receive my thanks for the
Title:  good guard you have kept.  Gentlemen, we are arrived; take
Title:  the gate on the left.  The watchword is, 'King and Re.'"
Title:  
Title:  Saying these words, the cardinal saluted the three friends
Title:  with an inclination of his head, and took the right hand,
Title:  followed by his attendant--for that night he himself slept
Title:  in the camp.
Title:  
Title:  "Well!" said Porthos and Aramis together, as soon as the
Title:  cardinal was out of hearing, "well, he signed the paper she
Title:  required!"
Title:  
Title:  "I know it," said Athos, coolly, "since here it is."
Title:  
Title:  And the three friends did not exchange another word till
Title:  they reached their quarters, except to give the watchword to
Title:  the sentinels.  Only they sent Mousqueton to tell Planchet
Title:  that his master was requested, the instant that he left the
Title:  trenches, to come to the quarters of the Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, as Athos had foreseen, on finding the two men that
Title:  awaited her, made no difficulty in following them.  She had
Title:  had for an instant an inclination to be reconducted to the
Title:  cardinal, and relate everything to him; but a revelation on
Title:  her part would bring about a revelation on the part of
Title:  Athos.  She might say that Athos had hanged her; but then
Title:  Athos would tell that she was branded.  She thought it was
Title:  best to preserve silence, to discreetly set off to
Title:  accomplish her difficult mission with her usual skill; and
Title:  then, all things being accomplished to the satisfaction of
Title:  the cardinal, to come to him and claim her vengeance.
Title:  
Title:  In consequence, after having traveled all night, at seven
Title:  o'clock she was at the fort of the Point; at eight o'clock
Title:  she had embarked; and at nine, the vessel, which with
Title:  letters of marque from the cardinal was supposed to be
Title:  sailing for Bayonne, raised anchor, and steered its course
Title:  toward England.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  46  THE BASTION SAINT-GERVAIS
Title:  
Title:  On arriving at the lodgings of his three friends, d'Artagnan
Title:  found them assembled in the same chamber.  Athos was
Title:  meditating; Porthos was twisting his mustache; Aramis was
Title:  saying his prayers in a charming little Book of Hours, bound
Title:  in blue velvet.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardieu, gentlemen," said he.  "I hope what you have to
Title:  tell me is worth the trouble, or else, I warn you, I will
Title:  not pardon you for making me come here instead of getting a
Title:  little rest after a night spent in taking and dismantling a
Title:  bastion.  Ah, why were you not there, gentlemen?  It was
Title:  warm work."
Title:  
Title:  "We were in a place where it was not very cold," replied
Title:  Porthos, giving his mustache a twist which was peculiar to
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  "Hush!" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, oh!" said d'Artagnan, comprehending the slight frown of
Title:  the Musketeer.  "It appears there is something fresh
Title:  aboard."
Title:  
Title:  "Aramis," said Athos, "you went to breakfast the day before
Title:  yesterday at the inn of the Parpaillot, I believe?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "How did you fare?"
Title:  
Title:  "For my part, I ate but little.  The day before yesterday
Title:  was a fish day, and they had nothing but meat."
Title:  
Title:  "What," said Athos, "no fish at a seaport?"
Title:  
Title:  "They say," said Aramis, resuming his pious reading, "that
Title:  the dyke which the cardinal is making drives them all out
Title:  into the open sea."
Title:  
Title:  "But that is not quite what I mean to ask you, Aramis,"
Title:  replied Athos.  "I want to know if you were left alone, and
Title:  nobody interrupted you."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, I think there were not many intruders.  Yes, Athos, I
Title:  know what you mean: we shall do very well at the
Title:  Parpaillot."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us go to the Parpaillot, then, for here the walls are
Title:  like sheets of paper."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who was accustomed to his friend's manner of
Title:  acting, and who perceived immediately, by a word, a gesture,
Title:  or a sign from him, that the circumstances were serious,
Title:  took Athos's arm, and went out without saying anything.
Title:  Porthos followed, chatting with Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  On their way they met Grimaud.  Athos made him a sign to
Title:  come with them.  Grimaud, according to custom, obeyed in
Title:  silence; the poor lad had nearly come to the pass of
Title:  forgetting how to speak.
Title:  
Title:  They arrived at the drinking room of the Parpaillot.  It was
Title:  seven o'clock in the morning, and daylight began to appear.
Title:  The three friends ordered breakfast, and went into a room in
Title:  which the host said they would not be disturbed.
Title:  
Title:  Unfortunately, the hour was badly chosen for a private
Title:  conference.  The morning drum had just been beaten; everyone
Title:  shook off the drowsiness of night, and to dispel the humid
Title:  morning air, came to take a drop at the inn.  Dragoons,
Title:  Swiss, Guardsmen, Musketeers, light-horsemen, succeeded one
Title:  another with a rapidity which might answer the purpose of
Title:  the host very well, but agreed badly with the views of the
Title:  four friends.  Thus they applied very curtly to the
Title:  salutations, healths, and jokes of their companions.
Title:  
Title:  "I see how it will be," said Athos: "we shall get into some
Title:  pretty quarrel or other, and we have no need of one just
Title:  now.  D'Artagnan, tell us what sort of a night you have had,
Title:  and we will describe ours afterward."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, yes," said a light-horseman, with a glass of brandy in
Title:  his hand, which he sipped slowly.  "I hear you gentlemen of
Title:  the Guards have been in the trenches tonight, and that you
Title:  did not get much the best of the Rochellais."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan looked at Athos to know if he ought to reply to
Title:  this intruder who thus mixed unasked in their conversation.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Athos, "don't you hear Monsieur de Busigny, who
Title:  does you the honor to ask you a question?  Relate what has
Title:  passed during the night, since these gentlemen desire to
Title:  know it."
Title:  
Title:  "Have you not taken a bastion?" said a Swiss, who was
Title:  drinking rum out of beer glass.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monsieur," said d'Artagnan, bowing, "we have had that
Title:  honor.  We even have, as you may have heard, introduced a
Title:  barrel of powder under one of the angles, which in blowing
Title:  up made a very pretty breach.  Without reckoning that as the
Title:  bastion was not built yesterday all the rest of the building
Title:  was badly shaken."
Title:  
Title:  "And what bastion is it?" asked a dragoon, with his saber
Title:  run through a goose which he was taking to be cooked.
Title:  
Title:  "The bastion St. Gervais," replied d'Artagnan, "from behind
Title:  which the Rochellais annoyed our workmen."
Title:  
Title:  "Was that affair hot?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, moderately so.  We lost five men, and the Rochellais
Title:  eight or ten."
Title:  
Title:  "Balzempleu!" said the Swiss, who, notwithstanding the
Title:  admirable collection of oaths possessed by the German
Title:  language, had acquired a habit of swearing in French.
Title:  
Title:  "But it is probable," said the light-horseman, "that they
Title:  will send pioneers this morning to repair the bastion."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that's probable," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Athos, "a wager!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, wooi, a vager!" cried the Swiss.
Title:  
Title:  "What is it?" said the light-horseman.
Title:  
Title:  "Stop a bit," said the dragoon, placing his saber like a
Title:  spit upon the two large iron dogs which held the firebrands
Title:  in the chimney, "stop a bit, I am in it.  You cursed host! a
Title:  dripping pan immediately, that I may not lose a drop of the
Title:  fat of this estimable bird."
Title:  
Title:  "You was right," said the Swiss; "goose grease is kood with
Title:  basdry."
Title:  
Title:  "There!" said the dragoon.  "Now for the wager!  We listen,
Title:  Monsieur Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, the wager!" said the light-horseman.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, Monsieur de Busigny, I will bet you," said Athos,
Title:  "that my three companions, Messieurs Porthos, Aramis, and
Title:  d'Artagnan, and myself, will go and breakfast in the bastion
Title:  St. Gervais, and we will remain there an hour, by the watch,
Title:  whatever the enemy may do to dislodge us."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis looked at each other; they began to
Title:  comprehend.
Title:  
Title:  "But," said d'Artagnan, in the ear of Athos, "you are going
Title:  to get us all killed without mercy."
Title:  
Title:  "We are much more likely to be killed," said Athos, "if we
Title:  do not go."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, gentlemen," said Porthos, turning round upon his
Title:  chair and twisting his mustache, "that's a fair bet, I
Title:  hope."
Title:  
Title:  "I take it," said M. de Busigny; "so let us fix the stake."
Title:  
Title:  "You are four gentlemen," said Athos, "and we are four; an
Title:  unlimited dinner for eight.  Will that do?"
Title:  
Title:  "Capitally," replied M. de Busigny.
Title:  
Title:  "Perfectly," said the dragoon.
Title:  
Title:  "That shoots me," said the Swiss.
Title:  
Title:  The fourth auditor, who during all this conversation had
Title:  played a mute part, made a sign of the head in proof that he
Title:  acquiesced in the proposition.
Title:  
Title:  "The breakfast for these gentlemen is ready," said the host.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, bring it," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  The host obeyed.  Athos called Grimaud, pointed to a large
Title:  basket which lay in a corner, and made a sign to him to wrap
Title:  the viands up in the napkins.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud understood that it was to be a breakfast on the
Title:  grass, took the basket, packed up the viands, added the
Title:  bottles, and then took the basket on his arm.
Title:  
Title:  "But where are you going to eat my breakfast?" asked the
Title:  host.
Title:  
Title:  "What matter, if you are paid for it?" said Athos, and he
Title:  threw two pistoles majestically on the table.
Title:  
Title:  "Shall I give you the change, my officer?" said the host.
Title:  
Title:  "No, only add two bottles of champagne, and the difference
Title:  will be for the napkins."
Title:  
Title:  The host had not quite so good a bargain as he at first
Title:  hoped for, but he made amends by slipping in two bottles of
Title:  Anjou wine instead of two bottles of champagne.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Busigny," said Athos, "will you be so kind as
Title:  to set your watch with mine, or permit me to regulate mine
Title:  by yours?"
Title:  
Title:  "Which you please, monsieur!" said the light-horseman,
Title:  drawing from his fob a very handsome watch, studded with
Title:  diamonds; "half past seven."
Title:  
Title:  "Thirty-five minutes after seven," said Athos, "by which you
Title:  perceive I am five minutes faster than you."
Title:  
Title:  And bowing to all the astonished persons present, the young
Title:  men took the road to the bastion St. Gervais, followed by
Title:  Grimaud, who carried the basket, ignorant of where he was
Title:  going but in the passive obedience which Athos had taught
Title:  him not even thinking of asking.
Title:  
Title:  As long as they were within the circle of the camp, the four
Title:  friends did not exchange one word; besides, they were
Title:  followed by the curious, who, hearing of the wager, were
Title:  anxious to know how they would come out of it.  But when
Title:  once they passed the line of circumvallation and found
Title:  themselves in the open plain, d'Artagnan, who was completely
Title:  ignorant of what was going forward, thought it was time to
Title:  demand an explanation.
Title:  
Title:  "And now, my dear Athos," said he, "do me the kindness to
Title:  tell me where we are going?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, you see plainly enough we are going to the bastion."
Title:  
Title:  "But what are we going to do there?"
Title:  
Title:  "You know well that we go to breakfast there."
Title:  
Title:  "But why did we not breakfast at the Parpaillot?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because we have very important matters to communicate to
Title:  one another, and it was impossible to talk five minutes in
Title:  that inn without being annoyed by all those importunate
Title:  fellows, who keep coming in, saluting you, and addressing
Title:  you.  Here at least," said Athos, pointing to the bastion,
Title:  "they will not come and disturb us."
Title:  
Title:  "It appears to me," said d'Artagnan, with that prudence
Title:  which allied itself in him so naturally with excessive
Title:  bravery, "that we could have found some retired place on the
Title:  downs or the seashore."
Title:  
Title:  "Where we should have been seen all four conferring
Title:  together, so that at the end of a quarter of an hour the
Title:  cardinal would have been informed by his spies that we were
Title:  holding a council."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Aramis, "Athos is right: ANIMADVERTUNTUR IN
Title:  DESERTIS."
Title:  
Title:  "A desert would not have been amiss," said Porthos; "but it
Title:  behooved us to find it."
Title:  
Title:  "There is no desert where a bird cannot pass over one's
Title:  head, where a fish cannot leap out of the water, where a
Title:  rabbit cannot come out of its burrow, and I believe that
Title:  bird, fish, and rabbit each becomes a spy of the cardinal.
Title:  Better, then, pursue our enterprise; from which, besides, we
Title:  cannot retreat without shame.  We have made a wager--a wager
Title:  which could not have been foreseen, and of which I defy
Title:  anyone to divine the true cause.  We are going, in order to
Title:  win it, to remain an hour in the bastion.  Either we shall
Title:  be attacked, or not.  If we are not, we shall have all the
Title:  time to talk, and nobody will hear us--for I guarantee the
Title:  walls of the bastion have no ears; if we are, we will talk
Title:  of our affairs just the same.  Moreover, in defending
Title:  ourselves, we shall cover ourselves with glory.  You see
Title:  that everything is to our advantage."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said d'Artagnan; "but we shall indubitably attract a
Title:  ball."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, my dear," replied Athos, "you know well that the
Title:  balls most to be dreaded are not from the enemy."
Title:  
Title:  "But for such an expedition we surely ought to have brought
Title:  our muskets."
Title:  
Title:  "You are stupid, friend Porthos.  Why should we load
Title:  ourselves with a useless burden?"
Title:  
Title:  "I don't find a good musket, twelve cartridges, and a powder
Title:  flask very useless in the face of an enemy."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," replied Athos, "have you not heard what d'Artagnan
Title:  said?"
Title:  
Title:  "What did he say?" demanded Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan said that in the attack of last night eight or
Title:  ten Frenchmen were killed, and as many Rochellais."
Title:  
Title:  "What then?"
Title:  
Title:  "The bodies were not plundered, were they?  It appears the
Title:  conquerors had something else to do."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, we shall find their muskets, their cartridges, and
Title:  their flasks; and instead of four musketoons and twelve
Title:  balls, we shall have fifteen guns and a hundred charges to
Title:  fire."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, Athos!" said Aramis, "truly you are a great man."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos nodded in sign of agreement.  D'Artagnan alone did
Title:  not seem convinced.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud no doubt shared the misgivings of the young man, for
Title:  seeing that they continued to advance toward the
Title:  bastion--something he had till then doubted--he pulled his
Title:  master by the skirt of his coat.
Title:  
Title:  "Where are we going?" asked he, by a gesture.
Title:  
Title:  Athos pointed to the bastion.
Title:  
Title:  "But," said Grimaud, in the same silent dialect, "we shall
Title:  leave our skins there."
Title:  
Title:  Athos raised his eyes and his finger toward heaven.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud put his basket on the ground and sat down with a
Title:  shake of the head.
Title:  
Title:  Athos took a pistol from his belt, looked to see if it was
Title:  properly primed, cocked it, and placed the muzzle close to
Title:  Grimaud's ear.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud was on his legs again as if by a spring.  Athos then
Title:  made him a sign to take up his basket and to walk on first.
Title:  Grimaud obeyed.  All that Grimaud gained by this momentary
Title:  pantomime was to pass from the rear guard to the vanguard.
Title:  
Title:  Arrived at the bastion, the four friends turned round.
Title:  
Title:  More than three hundred soldiers of all kinds were assembled
Title:  at the gate of the camp; and in a separate group might be
Title:  distinguished M. de Busigny, the dragoon, the Swiss, and the
Title:  fourth bettor.
Title:  
Title:  Athos took off his hat, placed it on the end of his sword,
Title:  and waved it in the air.
Title:  
Title:  All the spectators returned him his salute, accompanying
Title:  this courtesy with a loud hurrah which was audible to the
Title:  four; after which all four disappeared in the bastion,
Title:  whither Grimaud had preceded them.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  47  THE COUNCIL OF THE MUSKETEERS
Title:  
Title:  As Athos had foreseen, the bastion was only occupied by a
Title:  dozen corpses, French and Rochellais.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Athos, who had assumed the command of the
Title:  expedition, "while Grimaud spreads the table, let us begin
Title:  by collecting the guns and cartridges together.  We can talk
Title:  while performing that necessary task.  These gentlemen,"
Title:  added he, pointing to the bodies, "cannot hear us."
Title:  
Title:  "But we could throw them into the ditch," said Porthos,
Title:  "after having assured ourselves they have nothing in their
Title:  pockets."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Athos, "that's Grimaud's business."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," cried d'Artagnan, "pray let Grimaud search
Title:  them and throw them over the walls."
Title:  
Title:  "Heaven forfend!" said Athos; "they may serve us."
Title:  
Title:  "These bodies serve us?" said Porthos.  "You are mad, dear
Title:  friend."
Title:  
Title:  "Judge not rashly, say the gospel and the cardinal," replied
Title:  Athos. "How many guns, gentlemen?"
Title:  
Title:  "Twelve," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "How many shots?"
Title:  
Title:  "A hundred."
Title:  
Title:  "That's quite as many as we shall want.  Let us load the
Title:  guns."
Title:  
Title:  The four Musketeers went to work; and as they were loading
Title:  the last musket Grimaud announced that the breakfast was
Title:  ready.
Title:  
Title:  Athos replied, always by gestures, that that was well, and
Title:  indicated to Grimaud, by pointing to a turret that resembled
Title:  a pepper caster, that he was to stand as sentinel.  Only, to
Title:  alleviate the tediousness of the duty, Athos allowed him to
Title:  take a loaf, two cutlets, and a bottle of wine.
Title:  
Title:  "And now to table," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  The four friends seated themselves on the ground with their
Title:  legs crossed like Turks, or even tailors.
Title:  
Title:  "And now," said d'Artagnan, "as there is no longer any fear
Title:  of being overheard, I hope you are going to let me into your
Title:  secret."
Title:  
Title:  "I hope at the same time to procure you amusement and glory,
Title:  gentlemen," said Athos.  "I have induced you to take a
Title:  charming promenade; here is a delicious breakfast; and
Title:  yonder are five hundred persons, as you may see through the
Title:  loopholes, taking us for heroes or madmen--two classes of
Title:  imbeciles greatly resembling each other."
Title:  
Title:  "But the secret!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "The secret is," said Athos, "that I saw Milady last night."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was lifting a glass to his lips; but at the name
Title:  of Milady, his hand trembled so, that he was obliged to put
Title:  the glass on the ground again for fear of spilling the
Title:  contents."
Title:  
Title:  "You saw your wi--"
Title:  
Title:  "Hush!" interrupted Athos.  "You forget, my dear, you forget
Title:  that these gentlemen are not initiated into my family
Title:  affairs like yourself.  I have seen Milady."
Title:  
Title:  "Where?" demanded d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Within two leagues of this place, at the inn of the Red
Title:  Dovecot."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case I am lost," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Not so bad yet," replied Athos; "for by this time she must
Title:  have quit the shores of France."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan breathed again.
Title:  
Title:  "But after all," asked Porthos, "who is Milady?"
Title:  
Title:  "A charming woman!" said Athos, sipping a glass of sparkling
Title:  wine.  "Villainous host!" cried he, "he has given us Anjou
Title:  wine instead of champagne, and fancies we know no better!
Title:  Yes," continued he, "a charming woman, who entertained kind
Title:  views toward our friend d'Artagnan, who, on his part, has
Title:  given her some offense for which she tried to revenge
Title:  herself a month ago by having him killed by two musket
Title:  shots, a week ago by trying to poison him, and yesterday by
Title:  demanding his head of the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "What! by demanding my head of the cardinal?" cried
Title:  d'Artagnan, pale with terror.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that is true as the Gospel," said Porthos; "I heard
Title:  her with my own ears."
Title:  
Title:  "I also," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said d'Artagnan, letting his arm fall with
Title:  discouragement, "it is useless to struggle longer.  I may as
Title:  well blow my brains out, and all will be over."
Title:  
Title:  "That's the last folly to be committed," said Athos, "seeing
Title:  it is the only one for which there is no remedy."
Title:  
Title:  "But I can never escape," said d'Artagnan, "with such
Title:  enemies.  First, my stranger of Meung; then de Wardes, to
Title:  whom I have given three sword wounds; next Milady, whose
Title:  secret I have discovered; finally, the cardinal, whose
Title:  vengeance I have balked."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Athos, "that only makes four; and we are
Title:  four--one for one.  Pardieu! if we may believe the signs
Title:  Grimaud is making, we are about to have to do with a very
Title:  different number of people.  What is it, Grimaud?
Title:  Considering the gravity of the occasion, I permit you to
Title:  speak, my friend; but be laconic, I beg.  What do you see?"
Title:  
Title:  "A troop."
Title:  
Title:  "Of how many persons?"
Title:  
Title:  "Twenty men."
Title:  
Title:  "What sort of men?"
Title:  
Title:  "Sixteen pioneers, four soldiers."
Title:  
Title:  "How far distant?"
Title:  
Title:  "Five hundred paces."
Title:  
Title:  "Good!  We have just time to finish this fowl and to drink
Title:  one glass of wine to your health, d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "To your health!" repeated Porthos and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, to my health! although I am very much afraid
Title:  that your good wishes will not be of great service to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!" said Athos, "God is great, as say the followers of
Title:  Mohammed, and the future is in his hands."
Title:  
Title:  Then, swallowing the contents of his glass, which he put
Title:  down close to him, Athos arose carelessly, took the musket
Title:  next to him, and drew near to one of the loopholes.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos, Aramis and d'Artagnan followed his example.  As to
Title:  Grimaud, he received orders to place himself behind the four
Title:  friends in order to reload their weapons.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardieu!" said Athos, "it was hardly worth while to
Title:  distribute ourselves for twenty fellows armed with pickaxes,
Title:  mattocks, and shovels.  Grimaud had only to make them a sign
Title:  to go away, and I am convinced they would have left us in
Title:  peace."
Title:  
Title:  "I doubt that," replied d'Artagnan, "for they are advancing
Title:  very resolutely.  Besides, in addition to the pioneers,
Title:  there are four soldiers and a brigadier, armed with
Title:  muskets."
Title:  
Title:  "That's because they don't see us," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith," said Aramis, "I must confess I feel a great
Title:  repugnance to fire on these poor devils of civilians."
Title:  
Title:  "He is a bad priest," said Porthos, "who has pity for
Title:  heretics."
Title:  
Title:  "In truth," said Athos, "Aramis is right.  I will warn
Title:  them."
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil are you going to do?" cried d'Artagnan, "you
Title:  will be shot."
Title:  
Title:  But Athos heeded not his advice.  Mounting on the breach,
Title:  with his musket in one hand and his hat in the other, he
Title:  said, bowing courteously and addressing the soldiers and the
Title:  pioneers, who, astonished at this apparition, stopped fifty
Title:  paces from the bastion:  "Gentlemen, a few friends and
Title:  myself are about to breakfast in this bastion.  Now, you
Title:  know nothing is more disagreeable than being disturbed when
Title:  one is at breakfast.  We request you, then, if you really
Title:  have business here, to wait till we have finished or repast,
Title:  or to come again a short time hence, unless; unless, which
Title:  would be far better, you form the salutary resolution to
Title:  quit the side of the rebels, and come and drink with us to
Title:  the health of the King of France."
Title:  
Title:  "Take care, Athos!" cried d'Artagnan; "don't you see they
Title:  are aiming?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," said Athos; "but they are only civilians--very
Title:  bad marksmen, who will be sure not to hit me."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, at the same instant four shots were fired, and the
Title:  balls were flattened against the wall around Athos, but not
Title:  one touched him.
Title:  
Title:  Four shots replied to them almost instantaneously, but much
Title:  better aimed than those of the aggressors; three soldiers
Title:  fell dead, and one of the pioneers was wounded.
Title:  
Title:  "Grimaud," said Athos, still on the breach, "another
Title:  musket!"
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud immediately obeyed.  On their part, the three
Title:  friends had reloaded their arms; a second discharge followed
Title:  the first.  The brigadier and two pioneers fell dead; the
Title:  rest of the troop took to flight.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, gentlemen, a sortie!" cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  And the four friends rushed out of the fort, gained the
Title:  field of battle, picked up the four muskets of the privates
Title:  and the half-pike of the brigadier, and convinced that the
Title:  fugitives would not stop till they reached the city, turned
Title:  again toward the bastion, bearing with them the trophies of
Title:  their victory.
Title:  
Title:  "Reload the muskets, Grimaud," said Athos, "and we,
Title:  gentlemen, will go on with our breakfast, and resume our
Title:  conversation.  Where were we?"
Title:  
Title:  "I recollect you were saying," said d'Artagnan, "that after
Title:  having demanded my head of the cardinal, Milady had quit the
Title:  shores of France.  Whither goes she?" added he, strongly
Title:  interested in the route Milady followed.
Title:  
Title:  "She goes into England," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "With what view?"
Title:  
Title:  "With the view of assassinating, or causing to be
Title:  assassinated, the Duke of Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan uttered an exclamation of surprise and
Title:  indignation.
Title:  
Title:  "But this is infamous!" cried he.
Title:  
Title:  "As to that," said Athos, "I beg you to believe that I care
Title:  very little about it.  Now you have done, Grimaud, take our
Title:  brigadier's half-pike, tie a napkin to it, and plant it on
Title:  top of our bastion, that these rebels of Rochellais may see
Title:  that they have to deal with brave and loyal soldiers of the
Title:  king."
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud obeyed without replying.  An instant afterward, the
Title:  white flag was floating over the heads of the four friends.
Title:  A thunder of applause saluted its appearance; half the camp
Title:  was at the barrier.
Title:  
Title:  "How?" replied d'Artagnan, "you care little if she kills
Title:  Buckingham or causes him to be killed?  But the duke is our
Title:  friend."
Title:  
Title:  "The duke is English; the duke fights against us.  Let her
Title:  do what she likes with the duke; I care no more about him
Title:  than an empty bottle."  And Athos threw fifteen paces from
Title:  him an empty bottle from which he had poured the last drop
Title:  into his glass.
Title:  
Title:  "A moment," said d'Artagnan.  "I will not abandon Buckingham
Title:  thus.  He gave us some very fine horses."
Title:  
Title:  "And moreover, very handsome saddles," said Porthos, who at
Title:  the moment wore on his cloak the lace of his own.
Title:  
Title:  "Besides," said Aramis, "God desires the conversion and not
Title:  the death of a sinner."
Title:  
Title:  "Amen!" said Athos, "and we will return to that subject
Title:  later, if such be your pleasure; but what for the moment
Title:  engaged my attention most earnestly, and I am sure you will
Title:  understand me, d'Artagnan, was the getting from this woman a
Title:  kind of carte blanche which she had extorted from the
Title:  cardinal, and by means of which she could with impunity get
Title:  rid of you and perhaps of us."
Title:  
Title:  "But this creature must be a demon!" said Porthos, holding
Title:  out his plate to Aramis, who was cutting up a fowl.
Title:  
Title:  "And this carte blanche," said d'Artagnan, "this carte
Title:  blanche, does it remain in her hands?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, it passed into mine; I will not say without trouble,
Title:  for if I did I should tell a lie."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Athos, I shall no longer count the number of times
Title:  I am indebted to you for my life."
Title:  
Title:  "Then it was to go to her that you left us?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly."
Title:  
Title:  "And you have that letter of the cardinal?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Here it is," said Athos; and he took the invaluable paper
Title:  from the pocket of his uniform.  D'Artagnan unfolded it with
Title:  one hand, whose trembling he did not even attempt to
Title:  conceal, to read:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Dec. 3, 1627
Title:  
Title:  It is by my order and for the good of the state that the
Title:  bearer of this has done what he has done.
Title:  
Title:  "Richelieu"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "In fact," said Aramis, "it is an absolution according to rule."
Title:  
Title:  "That paper must be torn to pieces," said d'Artagnan, who
Title:  fancied he read in it his sentence of death.
Title:  
Title:  "On the contrary," said Athos, "it must be preserved
Title:  carefully.  I would not give up this paper if covered with
Title:  as many gold pieces."
Title:  
Title:  "And what will she do now?" asked the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Why," replied Athos, carelessly, "she is probably going to
Title:  write to the cardinal that a damned Musketeer, named Athos,
Title:  has taken her safe-conduct from her by force; she will
Title:  advise him in the same letter to get rid of his two friends,
Title:  Aramis and Porthos, at the same time.  The cardinal will
Title:  remember that these are the same men who have often crossed
Title:  his path; and then some fine morning he will arrest
Title:  d'Artagnan, and for fear he should feel lonely, he will send
Title:  us to keep him company in the Bastille."
Title:  
Title:  "Go to!  It appears to me you make dull jokes, my dear,"
Title:  said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "I do not jest," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know," said Porthos, "that to twist that damned
Title:  Milady's neck would be a smaller sin than to twist those of
Title:  these poor devils of Huguenots, who have committed no other
Title:  crime than singing in French the psalms we sing in Latin?"
Title:  
Title:  "What says the abbe?" asked Athos, quietly.
Title:  
Title:  "I say I am entirely of Porthos's opinion," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "And I, too," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Fortunately, she is far off," said Porthos, "for I confess
Title:  she would worry me if she were here."
Title:  
Title:  "She worries me in England as well as in France," said
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "She worries me everywhere," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "But when you held her in your power, why did you not drown
Title:  her, strangle her, hang her?" said Porthos.  "It is only the
Title:  dead who do not return."
Title:  
Title:  "You think so, Porthos?" replied the Musketeer, with a sad
Title:  smile which d'Artagnan alone understood.
Title:  
Title:  "I have an idea," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "What is it?" said the Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  "To arms!" cried Grimaud.
Title:  
Title:  The young men sprang up, and seized their muskets.
Title:  
Title:  This time a small troop advanced, consisting of from twenty
Title:  to twenty-five men; but they were not pioneers, they were
Title:  soldiers of the garrison.
Title:  
Title:  "Shall we return to the camp?" said Porthos.  "I don't think
Title:  the sides are equal."
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible, for three reasons," replied Athos.  "The first,
Title:  that we have not finished breakfast; the second, that we
Title:  still have some very important things to say; and the third,
Title:  that it yet wants ten minutes before the lapse of the hour."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," said Aramis, "we must form a plan of battle."
Title:  
Title:  "That's very simple," replied Athos.  "As soon as the enemy
Title:  are within musket shot, we must fire upon them.  If they
Title:  continue to advance, we must fire again.  We must fire as
Title:  long as we have loaded guns.  If those who remain of the
Title:  troop persist in coming to the assault, we will allow the
Title:  besiegers to get as far as the ditch, and then we will push
Title:  down upon their heads that strip of wall which keeps its
Title:  perpendicular by a miracle."
Title:  
Title:  "Bravo!" cried Porthos.  "Decidedly, Athos, you were born to
Title:  be a general, and the cardinal, who fancies himself a great
Title:  soldier, is nothing beside you."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Athos, "no divided attention, I beg; let
Title:  each one pick out his man."
Title:  
Title:  "I cover mine," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And I mine," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "And I mine," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Fire, then," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  The four muskets made but one report, but four men fell.
Title:  
Title:  The drum immediately beat, and the little troop advanced at
Title:  charging pace.
Title:  
Title:  Then the shots were repeated without regularity, but always
Title:  aimed with the same accuracy.  Nevertheless, as if they had
Title:  been aware of the numerical weakness of the friends, the
Title:  Rochellais continued to advance in quick time.
Title:  
Title:  With every three shots at least two men fell; but the march
Title:  of those who remained was not slackened.
Title:  
Title:  Arrived at the foot of the bastion, there were still more
Title:  than a dozen of the enemy.  A last discharge welcomed them,
Title:  but did not stop them; they jumped into the ditch, and
Title:  prepared to scale the breach.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, my friends," said Athos, "finish them at a blow.  To
Title:  the wall; to the wall!"
Title:  
Title:  And the four friends, seconded by Grimaud, pushed with the
Title:  barrels of their muskets an enormous sheet of the wall,
Title:  which bent as if pushed by the wind, and detaching itself
Title:  from its base, fell with a horrible crash into the ditch.
Title:  Then a fearful crash was heard; a cloud of dust mounted
Title:  toward the sky--and all was over!
Title:  
Title:  "Can we have destroyed them all, from the first to the
Title:  last?" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, it appears so!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "No," cried Porthos; "there go three or four, limping away."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, three or four of these unfortunate men, covered
Title:  with dirt and blood, fled along the hollow way, and at
Title:  length regained the city.  These were all who were left of
Title:  the little troop.
Title:  
Title:  Athos looked at his watch.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said he, "we have been here an hour, and our
Title:  wager is won; but we will be fair players.  Besides,
Title:  d'Artagnan has not told us his idea yet."
Title:  
Title:  And the Musketeer, with his usual coolness, reseated himself
Title:  before the remains of the breakfast.
Title:  
Title:  "My idea?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; you said you had an idea," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I remember," said d'Artagnan.  "Well, I will go to
Title:  England a second time; I will go and find Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  "You shall not do that, d'Artagnan," said Athos, coolly.
Title:  
Title:  "And why not?  Have I not been there once?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; but at that period we were not at war.  At that period
Title:  Buckingham was an ally, and not an enemy.  What you would
Title:  now do amounts to treason."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan perceived the force of this reasoning, and was
Title:  silent.
Title:  
Title:  "But," said Porthos, "I think I have an idea, in my turn."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence for Monsieur Porthos's idea!" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "I will ask leave of absence of Monsieur de Treville, on
Title:  some pretext or other which you must invent; I am not very
Title:  clever at pretexts.  Milady does not know me; I will get
Title:  access to her without her suspecting me, and when I catch my
Title:  beauty, I will strangle her."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," replied Athos, "I am not far from approving the idea
Title:  of Monsieur Porthos."
Title:  
Title:  "For shame!" said Aramis.  "Kill a woman?  No, listen to me;
Title:  I have the true idea."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us see your idea, Aramis," said Athos, who felt much
Title:  deference for the young Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "We must inform the queen."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, my faith, yes!" said Porthos and d'Artagnan, at the

Title:  
Title:  "Inform the queen!" said Athos; "and how?  Have we relations
Title:  with the court?  Could we send anyone to Paris without its
Title:  being known in the camp?  From here to Paris it is a hundred
Title:  and forty leagues; before our letter was at Angers we should
Title:  be in a dungeon."
Title:  
Title:  "As to remitting a letter with safety to her Majesty," said
Title:  Aramis, coloring, "I will take that upon myself.  I know a
Title:  clever person at Tours--"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis stopped on seeing Athos smile.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, do you not adopt this means, Athos?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I do not reject it altogether," said Athos; "but I wish to
Title:  remind Aramis that he cannot quit the camp, and that nobody
Title:  but one of ourselves is trustworthy; that two hours after
Title:  the messenger has set out, all the Capuchins, all the

Title:  arrested."
Title:  
Title:  "Without reckoning," objected Porthos, "that the queen would
Title:  save Monsieur de Buckingham, but would take no heed of us."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said d'Artagnan, "what Porthos says is full of
Title:  sense."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah! but what's going on in the city yonder?" said
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "They are beating the general alarm."
Title:  
Title:  The four friends listened, and the sound of the drum plainly
Title:  reached them.
Title:  
Title:  "You see, they are going to send a whole regiment against
Title:  us," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "You don't think of holding out against a whole regiment, do
Title:  you?" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Why not?" said Musketeer.  "I feel myself quite in a humor
Title:  for it; and I would hold out before an army if we had taken
Title:  the precaution to bring a dozen more bottles of wine."
Title:  
Title:  "Upon my word, the drum draws near," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Let it come," said Athos.  "It is a quarter of an hour's
Title:  journey from here to the city, consequently a quarter of an
Title:  hour's journey from the city to hither.  That is more than
Title:  time enough for us to devise a plan.  If we go from this
Title:  place we shall never find another so suitable.  Ah, stop! I
Title:  have it, gentlemen; the right idea has just occurred to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Tell us."
Title:  
Title:  "Allow me to give Grimaud some indispensable orders."
Title:  
Title:  Athos made a sign for his lackey to approach.
Title:  
Title:  "Grimaud," said Athos, pointing to the bodies which lay
Title:  under the wall of the bastion, "take those gentlemen, set
Title:  them up against the wall, put their hats upon their heads,

Title:  
Title:  "Oh, the great man!" cried d'Artagnan.  "I comprehend now."
Title:  
Title:  "You comprehend?" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "And do you comprehend, Grimaud?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative.
Title:  
Title:  "That's all that is necessary," said Athos; "now for my
Title:  idea."
Title:  
Title:  "I should like, however, to comprehend," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "That is useless."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes!  Athos's idea!" cried Aramis and d'Artagnan, at
Title:  the same time.
Title:  
Title:  "This Milady, this woman, this creature, this demon, has a
Title:  brother-in-law, as I think you told me, d'Artagnan?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I know him very well; and I also believe that he has
Title:  not a very warm affection for his sister-in-law."
Title:  
Title:  "There is no harm in that.  If he detested her, it would be
Title:  all the better," replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "In that case we are as well off as we wish."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet," said Porthos, "I would like to know what Grimaud
Title:  is about."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, Porthos!" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "What is her brother-in-law's name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Lord de Winter."
Title:  
Title:  "Where is he now?"
Title:  
Title:  "He returned to London at the first sound of war."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, there's just the man we want," said Athos.  "It is he

Title:  "Ah, my faith!" said Athos, "you require too much,

Title:  
Title:  "But I think it would be still better," said Aramis, "to

Title:  "Yes; but who is to carry the letter to Tours, and who to

Title:

Title:  "And I for Planchet," said d'Artagnan.

Title:  
Title:  "To be sure they may; and this very day we will write the
Title:  letters," said Aramis.  "Give the lackeys money, and they
Title:  will start."
Title:  
Title:  "We will give them money?" replied Athos.  "Have you any

Title:  
Title:  The four friends looked at one another, and a cloud came
Title:  over the brows which but lately had been so cheerful.
Title:  
Title:  "Look out!" cried d'Artagnan, "I see black points and red

Title:  
Title:  "My faith, yes," said Athos; "there they are.  See the

Title:  
Title:  Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative, and pointed to a
Title:  dozen bodies which he had set up in the most picturesque
Title:  attitudes.  Some carried arms, others seemed to be taking
Title:  aim, and the remainder appeared merely to be sword in hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Bravo!" said Athos; "that does honor to your imagination."
Title:  
Title:  "All very well," said Porthos, "but I should like to
Title:  understand."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us decamp first, and you will understand afterward."
Title:  
Title:  "A moment, gentlemen, a moment; give Grimaud time to clear
Title:  away the breakfast."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Aramis, "the black points and the red points
Title:  are visibly enlarging.  I am of d'Artagnan's opinion; we
Title:  have no time to lose in regaining our camp."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith," said Athos, "I have nothing to say against a
Title:  retreat.  We bet upon one hour, and we have stayed an hour
Title:  and a half.  Nothing can be said; let us be off, gentlemen,

Title:  
Title:  Grimaud was already ahead, with the basket and the dessert.
Title:  The four friends followed, ten paces behind him.
Title:  
Title:  "What the devil shall we do now, gentlemen?" cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Have you forgotten anything?" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "The white flag, morbleu!  We must not leave a flag in the
Title:  hands of the enemy, even if that flag be but a napkin."
Title:  
Title:  And Athos ran back to the bastion, mounted the platform, and
Title:  bore off the flag; but as the Rochellais had arrived within
Title:  musket range, they opened a terrible fire upon this man, who
Title:  appeared to expose himself for pleasure's sake.
Title:  
Title:  But Athos might be said to bear a charmed life.  The balls
Title:  passed and whistled all around him; not one struck him.
Title:  
Title:  Athos waved his flag, turning his back on the guards of the
Title:  city, and saluting those of the camp.  On both sides loud
Title:  cries arose--on the one side cries of anger, on the other
Title:  cries of enthusiasm.
Title:  
Title:  A second discharge followed the first, and three balls, by
Title:  passing through it, made the napkin really a flag.  Cries
Title:  were heard from the camp, "Come down! come down!"
Title:  
Title:  Athos came down; his friends, who anxiously awaited him, saw
Title:  him returned with joy.
Title:  
Title:  "Come along, Athos, come along!" cried d'Artagnan; "now we
Title:  have found everything except money, it would be stupid to be
Title:  killed."
Title:  
Title:  But Athos continued to march majestically, whatever remarks
Title:  his companions made; and they, finding their remarks
Title:  useless, regulated their pace by his.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud and his basket were far in advance, out of the range
Title:  of the balls.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of an instant they heard a furious fusillade.
Title:  
Title:  "What's that?" asked Porthos, "what are they firing at now?
Title:  I hear no balls whistle, and I see nobody!"
Title:  
Title:  "They are firing at the corpses," replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "But the dead cannot return their fire."
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly not!  They will then fancy it is an ambuscade,
Title:  they will deliberate; and by the time they have found out
Title:  the pleasantry, we shall be out of the range of their balls.
Title:  That renders it useless to get a pleurisy by too much
Title:  haste."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I comprehend now," said the astonished Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "That's lucky," said Athos, shrugging his shoulders.
Title:  
Title:  On their part, the French, on seeing the four friends return
Title:  at such a step, uttered cries of enthusiasm.
Title:  
Title:  At length a fresh discharge was heard, and this time the
Title:  balls came rattling among the stones around the four
Title:  friends, and whistling sharply in their ears.  The
Title:  Rochellais had at last taken possession of the bastion.
Title:  
Title:  "These Rochellais are bungling fellows," said Athos; "how
Title:  many have we killed of them--a dozen?"
Title:  
Title:  "Or fifteen."
Title:  
Title:  "How many did we crush under the wall?"
Title:  
Title:  "Eight or ten."
Title:  
Title:  "And in exchange for all that not even a scratch!  Ah, but
Title:  what is the matter with your hand, d'Artagnan?  It bleeds,
Title:  seemingly."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, it's nothing," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "A spent ball?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not even that."
Title:  
Title:  "What is it, then?"
Title:  
Title:  We have said that Athos loved d'Artagnan like a child, and
Title:  this somber and inflexible personage felt the anxiety of a
Title:  parent for the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Only grazed a little," replied d'Artagnan; "my fingers were
Title:  caught between two stones--that of the wall and that of my
Title:  ring--and the skin was broken."
Title:  
Title:  "That comes of wearing diamonds, my master," said Athos,
Title:  disdainfully.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, to be sure," cried Porthos, "there is a diamond.  Why
Title:  the devil, then, do we plague ourselves about money, when
Title:  there is a diamond?"
Title:  
Title:  "Stop a bit!" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Well thought of, Porthos; this time you have an idea."
Title:  
Title:  "Undoubtedly," said Porthos, drawing himself up at Athos's
Title:  compliment; "as there is a diamond, let us sell it."
Title:  
Title:  "But," said d'Artagnan, "it is the queen's diamond."
Title:  
Title:  "The stronger reason why it should be sold," replied Athos.
Title:  The queen saving Monsieur de Buckingham, her lover; nothing
Title:  more just.  The queen saving us, her friends; nothing more
Title:  moral.  Let us sell the diamond.  What says Monsieur the
Title:  Abbe?  I don't ask Porthos; his opinion has been given."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, I think," said Aramis, blushing as usual, "that his
Title:  ring not coming from a mistress, and consequently not being
Title:  a love token, d'Artagnan may sell it."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Aramis, you speak like theology personified.  Your
Title:  advice, then, is--"
Title:  
Title:  "To sell the diamond," replied Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," said d'Artagnan, gaily, "let us sell the
Title:  diamond, and say no more about it."
Title:  
Title:  The fusillade continued; but the four friends were out of
