Title:  reach, and the Rochellais only fired to appease their
Title:  consciences.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, it was time that idea came into Porthos's head.
Title:  Here we are at the camp; therefore, gentlemen, not a word
Title:  more of this affair.  We are observed; they are coming to
Title:  meet us.  We shall be carried in triumph."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, as we have said, the whole camp was in motion.
Title:  More than two thousand persons had assisted, as at a
Title:  spectacle, in this fortunate but wild undertaking of the
Title:  four friends--an undertaking of which they were far from
Title:  suspecting the real motive.  Nothing was heard but cries of
Title:  "Live the Musketeers!  Live the Guards!"  M. de Busigny was
Title:  the first to come and shake Athos by the hand, and
Title:  acknowledge that the wager was lost.  The dragoon and the
Title:  Swiss followed him, and all their comrades followed the
Title:  dragoon and the Swiss.  There was nothing but felicitations,
Title:  pressures of the hand, and embraces; there was no end to the
Title:  inextinguishable laughter at the Rochellais.  The tumult at
Title:  length became so great that the cardinal fancied there must
Title:  be some riot, and sent La Houdiniere, his captain of the
Title:  Guards, to inquire what was going on.
Title:  
Title:  The affair was described to the messenger with all the
Title:  effervescence of enthusiasm.
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" asked the cardinal, on seeing La Houdiniere return.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, monseigneur," replied the latter, "three Musketeers
Title:  and a Guardsman laid a wager with Monsieur de Busigny that
Title:  they would go and breakfast in the bastion St. Gervais; and
Title:  while breakfasting they held it for two hours against the
Title:  enemy, and have killed I don't know how many Rochellais."
Title:  
Title:  "Did you inquire the names of those three Musketeers?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "What are their names?"
Title:  
Title:  "Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis."
Title:  
Title:  "Still my three brave fellows!" murmured the cardinal.  "And
Title:  the Guardsman?"
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  "Still my young scapegrace.  Positively, these four men must
Title:  be on my side."
Title:  
Title:  The same evening the cardinal spoke to M. de Treville of the
Title:  exploit of the morning, which was the talk of the whole
Title:  camp.  M. de Treville, who had received the account of the
Title:  adventure from the mouths of the heroes of it, related it in
Title:  all its details to his Eminence, not forgetting the episode
Title:  of the napkin.
Title:  
Title:  "That's well, Monsieur de Treville," said the cardinal;
Title:  "pray let that napkin be sent to me.  I will have three
Title:  fleur-de-lis embroidered on it in gold, and will give it to
Title:  your company as a standard."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," said M. de Treville, "that will be unjust to
Title:  the Guardsmen.  Monsieur d'Artagnan is not with me; he
Title:  serves under Monsieur Dessessart."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, take him," said the cardinal; "when four men
Title:  are so much attached to one another, it is only fair that
Title:  they should serve in the same company."
Title:  
Title:  That same evening M. de Treville announced this good news to
Title:  the three Musketeers and d'Artagnan, inviting all four to
Title:  breakfast with him next morning.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was beside himself with joy.  We know that the
Title:  dream of his life had been to become a Musketeer.  The three
Title:  friends were likewise greatly delighted.
Title:  
Title:  "My faith," said d'Artagnan to Athos, "you had a triumphant
Title:  idea!  As you said, we have acquired glory, and were enabled
Title:  to carry on a conversation of the highest importance."
Title:  
Title:  "Which we can resume now without anybody suspecting us, for,
Title:  with the help of God, we shall henceforth pass for
Title:  cardinalists."
Title:  
Title:  That evening d'Artagnan went to present his respects to M.
Title:  Dessessart, and inform him of his promotion.
Title:  
Title:  M. Dessessart, who esteemed d'Artagnan, made him offers of
Title:  help, as this change would entail expenses for equipment.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan refused; but thinking the opportunity a good one, he
Title:  begged him to have the diamond he put into his hand valued,
Title:  as he wished to turn it into money.
Title:  
Title:  The next day, M. Dessessart's valet came to d'Artagnan's
Title:  lodging, and gave him a bag containing seven thousand
Title:  livres.
Title:  
Title:  This was the price of the queen's diamond.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  48  A FAMILY AFFAIR
Title:  
Title:  Athos had invented the phrase, family affair.  A family
Title:  affair was not subject to the investigation of the cardinal;
Title:  a family affair concerned nobody.  People might employ
Title:  themselves in a family affair before all the world.
Title:  Therefore Athos had invented the phrase, family affair.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis had discovered the idea, the lackeys.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos had discovered the means, the diamond.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan alone had discovered nothing--he, ordinarily the
Title:  most inventive of the four; but it must be also said that
Title:  the very name of Milady paralyzed him.
Title:  
Title:  Ah! no, we were mistaken; he had discovered a purchaser for
Title:  his diamond.
Title:  
Title:  The breakfast at M. de Treville's was as gay and cheerful as
Title:  possible.  D'Artagnan already wore his uniform--for being
Title:  nearly of the same size as Aramis, and as Aramis was so
Title:  liberally paid by the publisher who purchased his poem as to
Title:  allow him to buy everything double, he sold his friend a
Title:  complete outfit.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan would have been at the height of his wishes if he
Title:  had not constantly seen Milady like a dark cloud hovering in
Title:  the horizon.
Title:  
Title:  After breakfast, it was agreed that they should meet again
Title:  in the evening at Athos's lodging, and there finish their
Title:  plans.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan passed the day in exhibiting his Musketeer's
Title:  uniform in every street of the camp.
Title:  
Title:  In the evening, at the appointed hour, the four friends met.
Title:  There only remained three things to decide--what they
Title:  should write to Milady's brother; what they should write to
Title:  the clever person at Tours; and which should be the lackeys
Title:  to carry the letters.
Title:  
Title:  Everyone offered his own.  Athos talked of the discretion of
Title:  Grimaud, who never spoke a word but when his master unlocked
Title:  his mouth.  Porthos boasted of the strength of Mousqueton,
Title:  who was big enough to thrash four men of ordinary size.
Title:  Aramis, confiding in the address of Bazin, made a pompous
Title:  eulogium on his candidate.  Finally, d'Artagnan had entire
Title:  faith in the bravery of Planchet, and reminded them of the
Title:  manner in which he had conducted himself in the ticklish
Title:  affair of Boulogne.
Title:  
Title:  These four virtues disputed the prize for a length of time,
Title:  and gave birth to magnificent speeches which we do not
Title:  repeat here for fear they should be deemed too long.
Title:  
Title:  "Unfortunately," said Athos, "he whom we send must possess
Title:  in himself alone the four qualities united."
Title:  
Title:  "But where is such a lackey to be found?"
Title:  
Title:  "Not to be found!" cried Athos.  "I know it well, so take
Title:  Grimaud."
Title:  
Title:  "Take Mousqueton."
Title:  
Title:  "Take Bazin."
Title:  
Title:  "Take Planchet.  Planchet is brave and shrewd; they are two
Title:  qualities out of the four."
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Aramis, "the principal question is not to
Title:  know which of our four lackeys is the most discreet, the
Title:  most strong, the most clever, or the most brave; the
Title:  principal thing is to know which loves money the best."
Title:  
Title:  "What Aramis says is very sensible," replied Athos; "we must
Title:  speculate upon the faults of people, and not upon their
Title:  virtues.  Monsieur Abbe, you are a great moralist."
Title:  
Title:  "Doubtless," said Aramis, "for we not only require to be
Title:  well served in order to succeed, but moreover, not to fail;
Title:  for in case of failure, heads are in question, not for our
Title:  lackeys--"
Title:  
Title:  "Speak lower, Aramis," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "That's wise--not for the lackeys," resumed Aramis, "but for
Title:  the master--for the masters, we may say.  Are our lackeys
Title:  sufficiently devoted to us to risk their lives for us?  No."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith," said d'Artagnan.  "I would almost answer for
Title:  Planchet."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, my dear friend, add to his natural devotedness a good
Title:  sum of money, and then, instead of answering for him once,
Title:  answer for him twice."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, good God! you will be deceived just the same," said
Title:  Athos, who was an optimist when things were concerned, and a
Title:  pessimist when men were in question.  "They will promise
Title:  everything for the sake of the money, and on the road fear
Title:  will prevent them from acting.  Once taken, they will be
Title:  pressed; when pressed, they will confess everything.  What
Title:  the devil! we are not children.  To reach England"--Athos
Title:  lowered his voice--"all France, covered with spies and
Title:  creatures of the cardinal, must be crossed.  A passport for
Title:  embarkation must be obtained; and the party must be
Title:  acquainted with English in order to ask the way to London.
Title:  Really, I think the thing very difficult."
Title:  
Title:  "Not at all," cried d'Artagnan, who was anxious the matter
Title:  should be accomplished; "on the contrary, I think it very
Title:  easy.  It would be, no doubt, parbleu, if we write to Lord
Title:  de Winter about affairs of vast importance, of the horrors
Title:  of the cardinal--"
Title:  
Title:  "Speak lower!" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "--of intrigues and secrets of state," continued d'Artagnan,
Title:  complying with the recommendation.  "There can be no doubt
Title:  we would all be broken on the wheel; but for God's sake, do
Title:  not forget, as you yourself said, Athos, that we only write
Title:  to him concerning a family affair; that we only write to him
Title:  to entreat that as soon as Milady arrives in London he will
Title:  put it out of her power to injure us.  I will write to him,
Title:  then, nearly in these terms."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us see," said Athos, assuming in advance a critical
Title:  look.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur and dear friend--"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, yes!  Dear friend to an Englishman," interrupted Athos;
Title:  "well commenced!  Bravo, d'Artagnan!  Only with that word
Title:  you would be quartered instead of being broken on the
Title:  wheel."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, perhaps.  I will say, then, Monsieur, quite short."
Title:  
Title:  "You may even say, My Lord," replied Athos, who stickled for
Title:  propriety.
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, do you remember the little goat pasture of the
Title:  Luxembourg?"
Title:  
Title:  "Good, the Luxembourg!  One might believe this is an
Title:  allusion to the queen-mother!  That's ingenious," said
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, we will put simply, My Lord, do you remember a
Title:  certain little enclosure where your life was spared?"
Title:  
Title:  "My dear d'Artagnan, you will never make anything but a very
Title:  bad secretary.  Where your life was spared!  For shame!
Title:  that's unworthy.  A man of spirit is not to be reminded of
Title:  such services.  A benefit reproached is an offense
Title:  committed."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!" said d'Artagnan, "you are insupportable.  If
Title:  the letter must be written under your censure, my faith, I
Title:  renounce the task."
Title:  
Title:  "And you will do right.  Handle the musket and the sword, my
Title:  dear fellow.  You will come off splendidly at those two
Title:  exercises; but pass the pen over to Monsieur Abbe.  That's
Title:  his province."
Title:  
Title:  "Ay, ay!" said Porthos; "pass the pen to Aramis, who writes
Title:  theses in Latin."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, so be it," said d'Artagnan.  "Draw up this note for
Title:  us, Aramis; but by our Holy Father the Pope, cut it short,
Title:  for I shall prune you in my turn, I warn you."
Title:  
Title:  "I ask no better," said Aramis, with that ingenious air of
Title:  confidence which every poet has in himself; "but let me be
Title:  properly acquainted with the subject.  I have heard here and
Title:  there that this sister-in-law was a hussy.  I have obtained
Title:  proof of it by listening to her conversation with the
Title:  cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Lower! SACRE BLEU!" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "But," continued Aramis, "the details escape me."
Title:  
Title:  "And me also," said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan and Athos looked at each other for some time in
Title:  silence.  At length Athos, after serious reflection and
Title:  becoming more pale than usual, made a sign of assent to
Title:  d'Artagnan, who by it understood he was at liberty to speak.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, this is what you have to say," said d'Artagnan:  "My
Title:  Lord, your sister-in-law is an infamous woman, who wished to
Title:  have you killed that she might inherit your wealth; but she
Title:  could not marry your brother, being already married in
Title:  France, and having been--" d'Artagnan stopped, as if
Title:  seeking for the word, and looked at Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Repudiated by her husband," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Because she had been branded," continued d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!" cried Porthos.  "Impossible!  What do you say--that
Title:  she wanted to have her brother-in-law killed?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "She was married?" asked Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "And her husband found out that she had a fleur-de-lis on
Title:  her shoulder?" cried Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  These three yeses had been pronounced by Athos, each with a
Title:  sadder intonation.
Title:  
Title:  "And who has seen this fleur-de-lis?" inquired Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan and I.  Or rather, to observe the chronological
Title:  order, I and d'Artagnan," replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "And does the husband of this frightful creature still
Title:  live?"  said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "He still lives."
Title:  
Title:  "Are you quite sure of it?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am he."
Title:  
Title:  There was a moment of cold silence, during which everyone
Title:  was affected according to his nature.
Title:  
Title:  "This time," said Athos, first breaking the silence,
Title:  "d'Artagnan has given us an excellent program, and the
Title:  letter must be written at once."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!  You are right, Athos," said Aramis; "and it is
Title:  a rather difficult matter.  The chancellor himself would be
Title:  puzzled how to write such a letter, and yet the chancellor
Title:  draws up an official report very readily.  Never mind!  Be
Title:  silent, I will write."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis accordingly took the quill, reflected for a few
Title:  moments, wrote eight or ten lines in a charming little
Title:  female hand, and then with a voice soft and slow, as if each
Title:  word had been scrupulously weighed, he read the following:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, The person who writes these few lines had the
Title:  honor of crossing swords with you in the little enclosure of
Title:  the Rue d'Enfer.  As you have several times since declared
Title:  yourself the friend of that person, he thinks it his duty to
Title:  respond to that friendship by sending you important
Title:  information.  Twice you have nearly been the victim of a near relative,
Title:  whom you believe to be your heir because you
Title:  are ignorant that before she contracted a marriage in
Title:  England she was already married in France.  But the third
Title:  time, which is the present, you may succumb.  Your relative
Title:  left La Rochelle for England during the night.  Watch her
Title:  arrival, for she has great and terrible projects.  If you
Title:  require to know positively what she is capable of, read her
Title:  past history on her left shoulder."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Well, now that will do wonderfully well," said Athos.  "My
Title:  dear Aramis, you have the pen of a secretary of state.  Lord
Title:  de Winter will now be upon his guard if the letter should
Title:  reach him; and even if it should fall into the hands of the
Title:  cardinal, we shall not be compromised.  But as the lackey
Title:  who goes may make us believe he has been to London and may
Title:  stop at Chatellerault, let us give him only half the sum
Title:  promised him, with the letter, with an agreement that he
Title:  shall have the other half in exchange for the reply.  Have
Title:  you the diamond?" continued Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "I have what is still better.  I have the price"; and
Title:  d'Artagnan threw the bag upon the table.  At the sound of
Title:  the gold Aramis raised his eyes and Porthos started.  As to
Title:  Athos, he remained unmoved.
Title:  
Title:  "How much in that little bag?"
Title:  
Title:  "Seven thousand livres, in louis of twelve francs."
Title:  
Title:  "Seven thousand livres!" cried Porthos.  "That poor little
Title:  diamond was worth seven thousand livres?"
Title:  
Title:  "It appears so," said Athos, "since here they are.  I don't
Title:  suppose that our friend d'Artagnan has added any of his own
Title:  to the amount."
Title:  
Title:  "But, gentlemen, in all this," said d'Artagnan, "we do not
Title:  think of the queen.  Let us take some heed of the welfare of
Title:  her dear Buckingham.  That is the least we owe her."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true," said Athos; "but that concerns Aramis."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," replied the latter, blushing, "what must I say?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, that's simple enough!" replied Athos.  "Write a second
Title:  letter for that clever personage who lives at Tours."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis resumed his pen, reflected a little, and wrote the
Title:  following lines, which he immediately submitted to the
Title:  approbation of his friends.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear cousin."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Athos.  "This clever person is your relative,
Title:  then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Cousin-german."
Title:  
Title:  "Go on, to your cousin, then!"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis continued:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Cousin, His Eminence, the cardinal, whom God
Title:  preserve for the happiness of France and the confusion of
Title:  the enemies of the kingdom, is on the point of putting an
Title:  end to the hectic rebellion of La Rochelle.  It is probable
Title:  that the succor of the English fleet will never even arrive
Title:  in sight of the place.  I will even venture to say that I am
Title:  certain M. de Buckingham will be prevented from setting out
Title:  by some great event.  His Eminence is the most illustrious
Title:  politician of times past, of times present, and probably of
Title:  times to come.  He would extinguish the sun if the sun
Title:  incommoded him.  Give these happy tidings to your sister, my
Title:  dear cousin.  I have dreamed that the unlucky Englishman was
Title:  dead.  I cannot recollect whether it was by steel or by
Title:  poison; only of this I am sure, I have dreamed he was dead,
Title:  and you know my dreams never deceive me.  Be assured, then,
Title:  of seeing me soon return."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Capital!" cried Athos; "you are the king of poets, my dear
Title:  Aramis.  You speak like the Apocalypse, and you are as true
Title:  as the Gospel.  There is nothing now to do but to put the
Title:  address to this letter."
Title:  
Title:  "That is easily done," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  He folded the letter fancifully, and took up his pen and
Title:  wrote:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "To Mlle. Michon, seamstress, Tours."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The three friends looked at one another and laughed; they
Title:  were caught.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said Aramis, "you will please to understand,
Title:  gentlemen, that Bazin alone can carry this letter to Tours.
Title:  My cousin knows nobody but Bazin, and places confidence in
Title:  nobody but him; any other person would fail.  Besides, Bazin
Title:  is ambitious and learned; Bazin has read history, gentlemen,
Title:  he knows that Sixtus the Fifth became Pope after having kept
Title:  pigs.  Well, as he means to enter the Church at the same
Title:  time as myself, he does not despair of becoming Pope in his
Title:  turn, or at least a cardinal.  You can understand that a man
Title:  who has such views will never allow himself to be taken, or
Title:  if taken, will undergo martyrdom rather than speak."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well," said d'Artagnan, "I consent to Bazin with all
Title:  my heart, but grant me Planchet.  Milady had him one day
Title:  turned out of doors, with sundry blows of a good stick to
Title:  accelerate his motions.  Now, Planchet has an excellent
Title:  memory; and I will be bound that sooner than relinquish any
Title:  possible means of vengeance, he will allow himself to be
Title:  beaten to death.  If your arrangements at Tours are your
Title:  arrangements, Aramis, those of London are mine.  I request,
Title:  then, that Planchet may be chosen, more particularly as he
Title:  has already been to London with me, and knows how to speak
Title:  correctly:  London, sir, if you please, and my master, Lord
Title:  d'Artagnan.  With that you may be satisfied he can make his
Title:  way, both going and returning."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case," said Athos, "Planchet must receive seven
Title:  hundred livres for going, and seven hundred livres for
Title:  coming back; and Bazin, three hundred livres for going, and
Title:  three hundred livres for returning--that will reduce the sum
Title:  to five thousand livres.  We will each take a thousand
Title:  livres to be employed as seems good, and we will leave a
Title:  fund of a thousand livres under the guardianship of Monsieur
Title:  Abbe here, for extraordinary occasions or common wants.
Title:  Will that do?"
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Athos," said Aramis, "you speak like Nestor, who
Title:  was, as everyone knows, the wisest among the Greeks."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," said Athos, "it is agreed.  Planchet and Bazin
Title:  shall go.  Everything considered, I am not sorry to retain
Title:  Grimaud; he is accustomed to my ways, and I am particular.
Title:  Yesterday's affair must have shaken him a little; his voyage
Title:  would upset him quite."
Title:  
Title:  Planchet was sent for, and instructions were given him.  The
Title:  matter had been named to him by d'Artagnan, who in the first
Title:  place pointed out the money to him, then the glory, and then
Title:  the danger.
Title:  
Title:  "I will carry the letter in the lining of my coat," said
Title:  Planchet; "and if I am taken I will swallow it."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, but then you will not be able to fulfill your
Title:  commission," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "You will give me a copy this evening, which I shall know by
Title:  heart tomorrow."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan looked at his friends, as if to say, "Well, what
Title:  did I tell you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Now," continued he, addressing Planchet, "you have eight
Title:  days to get an interview with Lord de Winter; you have eight
Title:  days to return--in all sixteen days.  If, on the sixteenth
Title:  day after your departure, at eight o'clock in the evening
Title:  you are not here, no money--even if it be but five minutes
Title:  past eight."
Title:  
Title:  "Then, monsieur," said Planchet, "you must buy me a watch."
Title:  
Title:  "Take this," said Athos, with his usual careless generosity,
Title:  giving him his own, "and be a good lad.  Remember, if you
Title:  talk, if you babble, if you get drunk, you risk your
Title:  master's head, who has so much confidence in your fidelity,
Title:  and who answers for you.  But remember, also, that if by
Title:  your fault any evil happens to d'Artagnan, I will find you,
Title:  wherever you may be, for the purpose of ripping up your
Title:  belly."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, monsieur!" said Planchet, humiliated by the suspicion,
Title:  and moreover, terrified at the calm air of the Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said Porthos, rolling his large eyes, "remember, I
Title:  will skin you alive."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!"
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said Aramis, with his soft, melodius voice,
Title:  "remember that I will roast you at a slow fire, like a
Title:  savage."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!"
Title:  
Title:  Planchet began to weep.  We will not venture to say whether
Title:  it was from terror created by the threats or from tenderness
Title:  at seeing four friends so closely united.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took his hand.  "See, Planchet," said he, "these
Title:  gentlemen only say this out of affection for me, but at
Title:  bottom they all like you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur," said Planchet, "I will succeed or I will
Title:  consent to be cut in quarters; and if they do cut me in
Title:  quarters, be assured that not a morsel of me will speak."
Title:  
Title:  It was decided that Planchet should set out the next day, at
Title:  eight o'clock in the morning, in order, as he had said, that
Title:  he might during the night learn the letter by heart.  He
Title:  gained just twelve hours by this engagement; he was to be
Title:  back on the sixteenth day, by eight o'clock in the evening.
Title:  
Title:  In the morning, as he was mounting his horse, d'Artagnan,
Title:  who felt at the bottom of his heart a partiality for the
Title:  duke, took Planchet aside.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen," said he to him.  "When you have given the letter
Title:  to Lord de Winter and he has read it, you will further say
Title:  to him:  Watch over his Grace Lord Buckingham, for they wish
Title:  to assassinate him.  But this, Planchet, is so serious and
Title:  important that I have not informed my friends that I would
Title:  entrust this secret to you; and for a captain's commission I
Title:  would not write it."
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied, monsieur," said Planchet, "you shall see if
Title:  confidence can be placed in me."
Title:  
Title:  Mounted on an excellent horse, which he was to leave at the
Title:  end of twenty leagues in order to take the post, Planchet
Title:  set off at a gallop, his spirits a little depressed by the
Title:  triple promise made him by the Musketeers, but otherwise as
Title:  light-hearted as possible.
Title:  
Title:  Bazin set out the next day for Tours, and was allowed eight
Title:  days for performing his commission.
Title:  
Title:  The four friends, during the period of these two absences,
Title:  had, as may well be supposed, the eye on the watch, the nose
Title:  to the wind, and the ear on the hark.  Their days were
Title:  passed in endeavoring to catch all that was said, in
Title:  observing the proceeding of the cardinal, and in looking out
Title:  for all the couriers who arrived.  More than once an
Title:  involuntary trembling seized them when called upon for some
Title:  unexpected service.  They had, besides, to look constantly
Title:  to their own proper safety; Milady was a phantom which, when
Title:  it had once appeared to people, did not allow them to sleep
Title:  very quietly.
Title:  
Title:  On the morning of the eighth day, Bazin, fresh as ever, and
Title:  smiling, according to custom, entered the cabaret of the
Title:  Parpaillot as the four friends were sitting down to
Title:  breakfast, saying, as had been agreed upon: "Monsieur
Title:  Aramis, the answer from your cousin."
Title:  
Title:  The four friends exchanged a joyful glance; half of the work
Title:  was done.  It is true, however, that it was the shorter and
Title:  easier part.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, blushing in spite of himself, took the letter, which
Title:  was in a large, coarse hand and not particular for its
Title:  orthography.
Title:  
Title:  "Good God!" cried he, laughing, "I quite despair of my poor
Title:  Michon; she will never write like Monsieur de Voiture."
Title:  
Title:  "What does you mean by boor Michon?" said the Swiss, who was
Title:  chatting with the four friends when the letter came.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, pardieu, less than nothing," said Aramis; "a charming
Title:  little seamstress, whom I love dearly and from whose hand I
Title:  requested a few lines as a sort of keepsake."
Title:  
Title:  "The duvil!" said the Swiss, "if she is as great a lady as
Title:  her writing is large, you are a lucky fellow, gomrade!"
Title:  
Title:  Aramis read the letter, and passed it to Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "See what she writes to me, Athos," said he.
Title:  
Title:  Athos cast a glance over the epistle, and to disperse all
Title:  the suspicions that might have been created, read aloud:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "My cousin, My sister and I are skillful in interpreting
Title:  dreams, and even entertain great fear of them; but of yours
Title:  it may be said, I hope, every dream is an illusion.  Adieu!
Title:  Take care of yourself, and act so that we may from time to
Title:  time hear you spoken of.
Title:  
Title:  "Marie Michon"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "And what dream does she mean?" asked the dragoon, who had
Title:  approached during the reading.
Title:  
Title:  "Yez; what's the dream?" said the Swiss.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, pardieu!" said Aramis, "it was only this:  I had a
Title:  dream, and I related it to her."
Title:  
Title:  "Yez, yez," said the Swiss; "it's simple enough to dell a
Title:  dream, but I neffer dream."
Title:  
Title:  "You are very fortunate," said Athos, rising; "I wish I
Title:  could say as much!"
Title:  
Title:  "Neffer," replied the Swiss, enchanted that a man like Athos
Title:  could envy him anything.  "Neffer, neffer!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, seeing Athos rise, did likewise, took his arm,
Title:  and went out.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis remained behind to encounter the jokes of
Title:  the dragoon and the Swiss.
Title:  
Title:  As to Bazin, he went and lay down on a truss of straw; and
Title:  as he had more imagination than the Swiss, he dreamed that
Title:  Aramis, having become pope, adorned his head with a
Title:  cardinal's hat.
Title:  
Title:  But, as we have said, Bazin had not, by his fortunate
Title:  return, removed more than a part of the uneasiness which
Title:  weighed upon the four friends.  The days of expectation are
Title:  long, and d'Artagnan, in particular, would have wagered that
Title:  the days were forty-four hours.  He forgot the necessary
Title:  slowness of navigation; he exaggerated to himself the power
Title:  of Milady.  He credited this woman, who appeared to him the
Title:  equal of a demon, with agents as supernatural as herself; at
Title:  the least noise, he imagined himself about to be arrested,
Title:  and that Planchet was being brought back to be confronted
Title:  with himself and his friends.  Still further, his confidence
Title:  in the worthy Picard, at one time so great, diminished day
Title:  by day.  This anxiety became so great that it even extended
Title:  to Aramis and Porthos.  Athos alone remained unmoved, as if
Title:  no danger hovered over him, and as if he breathed his
Title:  customary atmosphere.
Title:  
Title:  On the sixteenth day, in particular, these signs were so
Title:  strong in d'Artagnan and his two friends that they could not
Title:  remain quiet in one place, and wandered about like ghosts on
Title:  the road by which Planchet was expected.
Title:  
Title:  "Really," said Athos to them, "you are not men but children,
Title:  to let a woman terrify you so!  And what does it amount to,
Title:  after all?  To be imprisoned.  Well, but we should be taken
Title:  out of prison; Madame Bonacieux was released.  To be
Title:  decapitated?  Why, every day in the trenches we go
Title:  cheerfully to expose ourselves to worse than that--for a
Title:  bullet may break a leg, and I am convinced a surgeon would
Title:  give us more pain in cutting off a thigh than an executioner
Title:  in cutting off a head.  Wait quietly, then; in two hours, in
Title:  four, in six hours at latest, Planchet will be here.  He
Title:  promised to be here, and I have very great faith in
Title:  Planchet, who appears to me to be a very good lad."
Title:  
Title:  "But if he does not come?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, if he does not come, it will be because he has been
Title:  delayed, that's all.  He may have fallen from his horse, he
Title:  may have cut a caper from the deck; he may have traveled so
Title:  fast against the wind as to have brought on a violent
Title:  catarrh.  Eh, gentlemen, let us reckon upon accidents!  Life
Title:  is a chaplet of little miseries which the philosopher counts
Title:  with a smile.  Be philosophers, as I am, gentlemen; sit down
Title:  at the table and let us drink.  Nothing makes the future
Title:  look so bright as surveying it through a glass of
Title:  chambertin."
Title:  
Title:  "That's all very well," replied d'Artagnan; "but I am tired
Title:  of fearing when I open a fresh bottle that the wine may come
Title:  from the cellar of Milady."
Title:  
Title:  "You are very fastidious," said Athos; "such a beautiful
Title:  woman!"
Title:  
Title:  "A woman of mark!" said Porthos, with his loud laugh.
Title:  
Title:  Athos started, passed his hand over his brow to remove the
Title:  drops of perspiration that burst forth, and rose in his turn
Title:  with a nervous movement he could not repress.
Title:  
Title:  The day, however, passed away; and the evening came on
Title:  slowly, but finally it came.  The bars were filled with
Title:  drinkers.  Athos, who had pocketed his share of the diamond,
Title:  seldom quit the Parpaillot.  He had found in M. de Busigny,
Title:  who, by the by, had given them a magnificent dinner, a
Title:  partner worthy of his company.  They were playing together,
Title:  as usual, when seven o'clock sounded; the patrol was heard
Title:  passing to double the posts.  At half past seven the retreat
Title:  was sounded.
Title:  
Title:  "We are lost," said d'Artagnan, in the ear of Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "You mean to say we have lost," said Athos, quietly, drawing
Title:  four pistoles from his pocket and throwing them upon the
Title:  table.  "Come, gentlemen," said he, "they are beating the
Title:  tattoo.  Let us to bed!"
Title:  
Title:  And Athos went out of the Parpaillot, followed by
Title:  d'Artagnan.  Aramis came behind, giving his arm to Porthos.
Title:  Aramis mumbled verses to himself, and Porthos from time to
Title:  time pulled a hair or two from his mustache, in sign of
Title:  despair.
Title:  
Title:  But all at once a shadow appeared in the darkness the
Title:  outline of which was familiar to d'Artagnan, and a well-
Title:  known voice said, "Monsieur, I have brought your cloak; it
Title:  is chilly this evening."
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet!" cried d'Artagnan, beside himself with joy.
Title:  
Title:  "Planchet!" repeated Aramis and Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, yes, Planchet, to be sure," said Athos, "what is
Title:  there so astonishing in that?  He promised to be back by
Title:  eight o'clock, and eight is striking.  Bravo, Planchet, you
Title:  are a lad of your word, and if ever you leave your master, I
Title:  will promise you a place in my service."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no, never," said Planchet, "I will never leave Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan."
Title:  
Title:  At the same time d'Artagnan felt that Planchet slipped a
Title:  note into his hand.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan felt a strong inclination to embrace Planchet as
Title:  he had embraced him on his departure; but he feared lest
Title:  this mark of affection, bestowed upon his lackey in the open
Title:  street, might appear extraordinary to passers-by, and he
Title:  restrained himself.
Title:  
Title:  "I have the note," said he to Athos and to his friends.
Title:  
Title:  "That's well," said Athos, "let us go home and read it."
Title:  
Title:  The note burned the hand of d'Artagnan.  He wished to hasten
Title:  their steps; but Athos took his arm and passed it under his
Title:  own, and the young man was forced to regulate his pace by
Title:  that of his friend.
Title:  
Title:  At length they reached the tent, lit a lamp, and while
Title:  Planchet stood at the entrance that the four friends might
Title:  not be surprised, d'Artagnan, with a trembling hand, broke
Title:  the seal and opened the so anxiously expected letter.
Title:  
Title:  It contained half a line, in a hand perfectly British, and
Title:  with a conciseness as perfectly Spartan:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Thank you; be easy.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  d'Artagnan translated this for the others.
Title:  
Title:  Athos took the letter from the hands of d'Artagnan,
Title:  approached the lamp, set fire to the paper, and did not let
Title:  go till it was reduced to a cinder.
Title:  
Title:  Then, calling Planchet, he said, "Now, my lad, you may claim
Title:  your seven hundred livres, but you did not run much risk
Title:  with such a note as that."
Title:  
Title:  "I am not to blame for having tried every means to compress
Title:  it," said Planchet.
Title:  
Title:  "Well!" cried d'Artagnan, "tell us all about it."
Title:  
Title:  "Dame, that's a long job, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right, Planchet," said Athos; "besides, the tattoo
Title:  has been sounded, and we should be observed if we kept a
Title:  light burning much longer than the others."
Title:  
Title:  "So be it," said d'Artagnan.  "Go to bed, Planchet, and
Title:  sleep soundly."
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, monsieur! that will be the first time I have done
Title:  so for sixteen days."
Title:  
Title:  "And me, too!" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And me, too!" said Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "And me, too!" said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, if you will have the truth, and me, too!" said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  49  FATALITY
Title:  
Title:  Meantime Milady, drunk with passion, roaring on the deck like a
Title:  lioness that has been embarked, had been tempted to throw herself
Title:  into the sea that she might regain the coast, for she could not
Title:  get rid of the thought that she had been insulted by d'Artagnan,
Title:  threatened by Athos, and that she had quit France without being
Title:  revenged on them.  This idea soon became so insupportable to her
Title:  that at the risk of whatever terrible consequences might result
Title:  to herself from it, she implored the captain to put her on shore;
Title:  but the captain, eager to escape from his false position--placed
Title:  between French and English cruisers, like the bat between the
Title:  mice and the birds--was in great haste to regain England, and
Title:  positively refused to obey what he took for a woman's caprice,
Title:  promising his passenger, who had been particularly recommended to
Title:  him by the cardinal, to land her, if the sea and the French
Title:  permitted him, at one of the ports of Brittany, either at Lorient
Title:  or Brest.  But the wind was contrary, the sea bad; they tacked
Title:  and kept offshore.  Nine days after leaving the Charente, pale
Title:  with fatigue and vexation, Milady saw only the blue coasts of
Title:  Finisterre appear.
Title:  
Title:  She calculated that to cross this corner of France and return to
Title:  the cardinal it would take her at least three days.  Add another
Title:  day for landing, and that would make four.  Add these four to the
Title:  nine others, that would be thirteen days lost--thirteen days,
Title:  during which so many important events might pass in London.  She
Title:  reflected likewise that the cardinal would be furious at her
Title:  return, and consequently would be more disposed to listen to the
Title:  complaints brought against her than to the accusations she
Title:  brought against others.
Title:  
Title:  She allowed the vessel to pass Lorient and Brest without
Title:  repeating her request to the captain, who, on his part, took care
Title:  not to remind her of it.  Milady therefore continued her voyage,
Title:  and on the very day that Planchet embarked at Portsmouth for
Title:  France, the messenger of his Eminence entered the port in
Title:  triumph.
Title:  
Title:  All the city was agitated by an extraordinary movement.  Four
Title:  large vessels, recently built, had just been launched.  At the
Title:  end of the jetty, his clothes richly laced with gold, glittering,
Title:  as was customary with him, with diamonds and precious stones, his
Title:  hat ornamented with a white feather which drooped upon his
Title:  shoulder, Buckingham was seen surrounded by a staff almost as
Title:  brilliant as himself.
Title:  
Title:  It was one of those rare and beautiful days in winter when
Title:  England remembers that there is a sun.  The star of day, pale but
Title:  nevertheless still splendid, was setting in the horizon,
Title:  glorifying at once the heavens and the sea with bands of fire,
Title:  and casting upon the towers and the old houses of the city a last
Title:  ray of gold which made the windows sparkle like the reflection of
Title:  a conflagration.  Breathing that sea breeze, so much more
Title:  invigorating and balsamic as the land is approached,
Title:  contemplating all the power of those preparations she was
Title:  commissioned to destroy, all the power of that army which she was
Title:  to combat alone--she, a woman with a few bags of gold--Milady
Title:  compared herself mentally to Judith, the terrible Jewess, when
Title:  she penetrated the camp of the Assyrians and beheld the enormous
Title:  mass of chariots, horses, men, and arms, which a gesture of her
Title:  hand was to dissipate like a cloud of smoke.
Title:  
Title:  They entered the roadstead; but as they drew near in order to
Title:  cast anchor, a little cutter, looking like a coastguard
Title:  formidably armed, approached the merchant vessel and dropped into
Title:  the sea a boat which directed its course to the ladder.  This
Title:  boat contained an officer, a mate, and eight rowers.  The officer
Title:  alone went on board, where he was received with all the deference
Title:  inspired by the uniform.
Title:  
Title:  The officer conversed a few instants with the captain, gave him
Title:  several papers, of which he was the bearer, to read, and upon the
Title:  order of the merchant captain the whole crew of the vessel, both
Title:  passengers and sailors, were called upon deck.
Title:  
Title:  When this species of summons was made the officer inquired aloud
Title:  the point of the brig's departure, its route, its landings; and
Title:  to all these questions the captain replied without difficulty and
Title:  without hesitation.  Then the officer began to pass in review all
Title:  the people, one after the other, and stopping when he came to
Title:  Milady, surveyed her very closely, but without addressing a
Title:  single word to her.
Title:  
Title:  He then returned to the captain, said a few words to him, and as
Title:  if from that moment the vessel was under his command, he ordered
Title:  a maneuver which the crew executed immediately.  Then the vessel
Title:  resumed its course, still escorted by the little cutter, which
Title:  sailed side by side with it, menacing it with the mouths of its
Title:  six cannon.  The boat followed in the wake of the ship, a speck
Title:  near the enormous mass.
Title:  
Title:  During the examination of Milady by the officer, as may well be
Title:  imagined, Milady on her part was not less scrutinizing in her
Title:  glances.  But however great was the power of this woman with eyes
Title:  of flame in reading the hearts of those whose secrets she wished
Title:  to divine, she met this time with a countenance of such
Title:  impassivity that no discovery followed her investigation.  The
Title:  officer who had stopped in front of her and studied her with so
Title:  much care might have been twenty-five or twenty-six years of age.
Title:  He was of pale complexion, with clear blue eyes, rather deeply
Title:  set; his mouth, fine and well cut, remained motionless in its
Title:  correct lines; his chin, strongly marked, denoted that strength
Title:  of will which in the ordinary Britannic type denotes mostly
Title:  nothing but obstinacy; a brow a little receding, as is proper for
Title:  poets, enthusiasts, and soldiers, was scarcely shaded by short
Title:  thin hair which, like the beard which covered the lower part of
Title:  his face, was of a beautiful deep chestnut color.
Title:  
Title:  When they entered the port, it was already night.  The fog
Title:  increased the darkness, and formed round the sternlights and
Title:  lanterns of the jetty a circle like that which surrounds the moon
Title:  when the weather threatens to become rainy.  The air they
Title:  breathed was heavy, damp, and cold.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, that woman so courageous and firm, shivered in spite of
Title:  herself.
Title:  
Title:  The officer desired to have Milady's packages pointed out to him,
Title:  and ordered them to be placed in the boat.  When this operation
Title:  was complete, he invited her to descend by offering her his hand.
Title:  
Title:  Milady looked at this man, and hesitated.  "Who are you, sir,"
Title:  asked she, "who has the kindness to trouble yourself so
Title:  particularly on my account?"
Title:  
Title:  "You may perceive, madame, by my uniform, that I am an officer in
Title:  the English navy," replied the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "But is it the custom for the officers in the English navy to
Title:  place themselves at the service of their female compatriots when
Title:  they land in a port of Great Britain, and carry their gallantry
Title:  so far as to conduct them ashore?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, madame, it is the custom, not from gallantry but prudence,
Title:  that in time of war foreigners should be conducted to particular
Title:  hotels, in order that they may remain under the eye of the
Title:  government until full information can be obtained about them."
Title:  
Title:  These words were pronounced with the most exact politeness and
Title:  the most perfect calmness.  Nevertheless, they had not the power
Title:  of convincing Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "But I am not a foreigner, sir," said she, with an accent as pure
Title:  as ever was heard between Portsmouth and Manchester; "my name is
Title:  Lady Clarik, and this measure--"
Title:  
Title:  "This measure is general, madame; and you will seek in vain to
Title:  evade it."
Title:  
Title:  "I will follow you, then, sir."
Title:  
Title:  Accepting the hand of the officer, she began the descent of the
Title:  ladder, at the foot of which the boat waited.  The officer
Title:  followed her.  A large cloak was spread at the stern; the officer
Title:  requested her to sit down upon this cloak, and placed himself
Title:  beside her.
Title:  
Title:  "Row!" said he to the sailors.
Title:  
Title:  The eight oars fell at once into the sea, making but a single
Title:  sound, giving but a single stroke, and the boat seemed to fly
Title:  over the surface of the water.
Title:  
Title:  In five minutes they gained the land.
Title:  
Title:  The officer leaped to the pier, and offered his hand to Milady.
Title:  A carriage was in waiting.
Title:  
Title:  "Is this carriage for us?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, madame," replied the officer.
Title:  
Title:  "The hotel, then, is far away?"
Title:  
Title:  "At the other end of the town."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well," said Milady; and she resolutely entered the
Title:  carriage.
Title:  
Title:  The officer saw that the baggage was fastened carefully behind
Title:  the carriage; and this operation ended, he took his place beside
Title:  Milady, and shut the door.
Title:  
Title:  Immediately, without any order being given or his place of
Title:  destination indicated, the coachman set off at a rapid pace, and
Title:  plunged into the streets of the city.
Title:  
Title:  So strange a reception naturally gave Milady ample matter for
Title:  reflection; so seeing that the young officer did not seem at all
Title:  disposed for conversation, she reclined in her corner of the
Title:  carriage, and one after the other passed in review all the
Title:  surmises which presented themselves to her mind.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of a quarter of an hour, however, surprised at the
Title:  length of the journey, she leaned forward toward the door to see
Title:  whither she was being conducted.  Houses were no longer to be
Title:  seen; trees appeared in the darkness like great black phantoms
Title:  chasing one another.  Milady shuddered.
Title:  
Title:  "But we are no longer in the city, sir," said she.
Title:  
Title:  The young officer preserved silence.
Title:  
Title:  "I beg you to understand, sir, I will go no farther unless you
Title:  tell me whither you are taking me."
Title:  
Title:  This threat brought no reply.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, this is too much," cried Milady.  "Help! help!"
Title:  
Title:  No voice replied to hers; the carriage continued to roll on with
Title:  rapidity; the officer seemed a statue.
Title:  
Title:  Milady looked at the officer with one of those terrible
Title:  expressions peculiar to her countenance, and which so rarely
Title:  failed of their effect; anger made her eyes flash in the
Title:  darkness.
Title:  
Title:  The young man remained immovable.
Title:  
Title:  Milady tried to open the door in order to throw herself out.
Title:  
Title:  "Take care, madame," said the young man, coolly, "you will kill
Title:  yourself in jumping."
Title:  
Title:  Milady reseated herself, foaming.  The officer leaned forward,
Title:  looked at her in his turn, and appeared surprised to see that
Title:  face, just before so beautiful, distorted with passion and almost
Title:  hideous.  The artful creature at once comprehended that she was
Title:  injuring herself by allowing him thus to read her soul; she
Title:  collected her features, and in a complaining voice said:  "In the
Title:  name of heaven, sir, tell me if it is to you, if it is to your
Title:  government, if it is to an enemy I am to attribute the violence
Title:  that is done me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No violence will be offered to you, madame, and what happens to
Title:  you is the result of a very simple measure which we are obliged
Title:  to adopt with all who land in England."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you don't know me, sir?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is the first time I have had the honor of seeing you."
Title:  
Title:  "And on your honor, you have no cause of hatred against me?"
Title:  
Title:  "None, I swear to you."
Title:  
Title:  There was so much serenity, coolness, mildness even, in the voice
Title:  of the young man, that Milady felt reassured.
Title:  
Title:  At length after a journey of nearly an hour, the carriage stopped
Title:  before an iron gate, which closed an avenue leading to a castle
Title:  severe in form, massive, and isolated.  Then, as the wheels
Title:  rolled over a fine gravel, Milady could hear a vast roaring,
Title:  which she at once recognized as the noise of the sea dashing
Title:  against some steep cliff.
Title:  
Title:  The carriage passed under two arched gateways, and at length
Title:  stopped in a court large, dark, and square.  Almost immediately
Title:  the door of the carriage was opened, the young man sprang lightly
Title:  out and presented his hand to Milady, who leaned upon it, and in
Title:  her turn alighted with tolerable calmness.
Title:  
Title:  "Still, then, I am a prisoner," said Milady, looking around her,
Title:  and bringing back her eyes with a most gracious smile to the
Title:  young officer; "but I feel assured it will not be for long,"
Title:  added she.  "My own conscience and your politeness, sir, are the
Title:  guarantees of that."
Title:  
Title:  However flattering this compliment, the officer made no reply;
Title:  but drawing from his belt a little silver whistle, such as
Title:  boatswains use in ships of war, he whistled three times, with
Title:  three different modulations.  Immediately several men appeared,
Title:  who unharnessed the smoking horses, and put the carriage into a
Title:  coach house.
Title:  
Title:  Then the officer, with the same calm politeness, invited his
Title:  prisoner to enter the house.  She, with a still-smiling
Title:  countenance, took his arm, and passed with him under a low arched
Title:  door, which by a vaulted passage, lighted only at the farther
Title:  end, led to a stone staircase around an angle of stone.  They
Title:  then came to a massive door, which after the introduction into
Title:  the lock of a key which the young man carried with him, turned
Title:  heavily upon its hinges, and disclosed the chamber destined for
Title:  Milady.
Title:  
Title:  With a single glance the prisoner took in the apartment in its
Title:  minutest details.  It was a chamber whose furniture was at once
Title:  appropriate for a prisoner or a free man; and yet bars at the
Title:  windows and outside bolts at the door decided the question in
Title:  favor of the prison.
Title:  
Title:  In an instant all the strength of mind of this creature, though
Title:  drawn from the most vigorous sources, abandoned her; she sank
Title:  into a large easy chair, with her arms crossed, her head lowered,
Title:  and expecting every instant to see a judge enter to interrogate
Title:  her.
Title:  
Title:  But no one entered except two or three marines, who brought her
Title:  trunks and packages, deposited them in a corner, and retired
Title:  without speaking.
Title:  
Title:  The officer superintended all these details with the same
Title:  calmness Milady had constantly seen in him, never pronouncing a
Title:  word himself, and making himself obeyed by a gesture of his hand
Title:  or a sound of his whistle.
Title:  
Title:  It might have been said that between this man and his inferiors
Title:  spoken language did not exist, or had become useless.
Title:  
Title:  At length Milady could hold out no longer; she broke the silence.
Title:  "In the name of heaven, sir," cried she, "what means all that is
Title:  passing?  Put an end to my doubts; I have courage enough for any
Title:  danger I can foresee, for every misfortune which I understand.
Title:  Where am I, and why am I here?  If I am free, why these bars and
Title:  these doors?  If I am a prisoner, what crime have I committed?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are here in the apartment destined for you, madame.  I
Title:  received orders to go and take charge of you on the sea, and to
Title:  conduct you to this castle.  This order I believe I have
Title:  accomplished with all the exactness of a soldier, but also with
Title:  the courtesy of a gentleman.  There terminates, at least to the
Title:  present moment, the duty I had to fulfill toward you; the rest
Title:  concerns another person."
Title:  
Title:  "And who is that other person?" asked Milady, warmly.  "Can you
Title:  not tell me his name?"
Title:  
Title:  At the moment a great jingling of spurs was heard on the stairs.
Title:  Some voices passed and faded away, and the sound of a single
Title:  footstep approached the door.
Title:  
Title:  "That person is here, madame," said the officer, leaving the
Title:  entrance open, and drawing himself up in an attitude of respect.
Title:  
Title:  At the same time the door opened; a man appeared on the
Title:  threshold.  He was without a hat, carried a sword, and flourished
Title:  a handkerchief in his hand.
Title:  
Title:  Milady thought she recognized this shadow in the gloom; she
Title:  supported herself with one hand upon the arm of the chair, and
Title:  advanced her head as if to meet a certainty.
Title:  
Title:  The stranger advanced slowly, and as he advanced, after entering
Title:  into the circle of light projected by the lamp, Milady
Title:  involuntarily drew back.
Title:  
Title:  Then when she had no longer any doubt, she cried, in a state of
Title:  stupor, "What, my brother, is it you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, fair lady!" replied Lord de Winter, making a bow, half
Title:  courteous, half ironical; "it is I, myself."
Title:  
Title:  "But this castle, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Is mine."
Title:  
Title:  "This chamber?"
Title:  
Title:  "Is yours."
Title:  
Title:  "I am, then, your prisoner?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nearly so."
Title:  
Title:  "But this is a frightful abuse of power!"
Title:  
Title:  "No high-sounding words!  Let us sit down and chat quietly, as
Title:  brother and sister ought to do."
Title:  
Title:  Then, turning toward the door, and seeing that the young officer
Title:  was waiting for his last orders, he said.  "All is well, I thank
Title:  you; now leave us alone, Mr. Felton."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  50  CHAT BETWEEN BROTHER AND SISTER
Title:  
Title:  During the time which Lord de Winter took to shut the door, close
Title:  a shutter, and draw a chair near to his sister-in-law's fauteuil,
Title:  Milady, anxiously thoughtful, plunged her glance into the depths
Title:  of possibility, and discovered all the plan, of which she could
Title:  not even obtain a glance as long as she was ignorant into whose
Title:  hands she had fallen.  She knew her brother-in-law to be a worthy
Title:  gentleman, a bold hunter, an intrepid player, enterprising with
Title:  women, but by no means remarkable for his skill in intrigues.
Title:  How had he discovered her arrival, and caused her to be seized?
Title:  Why did he detain her?
Title:  
Title:  Athos had dropped some words which proved that the conversation
Title:  she had with the cardinal had fallen into outside ears; but she
Title:  could not suppose that he had dug a countermine so promptly and
Title:  so boldly.  She rather feared that her preceding operations in
Title:  England might have been discovered.  Buckingham might have
Title:  guessed that it was she who had cut off the two studs, and avenge
Title:  himself for that little treachery; but Buckingham was incapable
Title:  of going to any excess against a woman, particularly if that
Title:  woman was supposed to have acted from a feeling of jealousy.
Title:  
Title:  This supposition appeared to her most reasonable.  It seemed to
Title:  her that they wanted to revenge the past, and not to anticipate
Title:  the future.  At all events, she congratulated herself upon having
Title:  fallen into the hands of her brother-in-law, with whom she
Title:  reckoned she could deal very easily, rather than into the hands
Title:  of an acknowledged and intelligent enemy.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, let us chat, brother," said she, with a kind of
Title:  cheerfulness, decided as she was to draw from the conversation,
Title:  in spite of all the dissimulation Lord de Winter could bring, the
Title:  revelations of which she stood in need to regulate her future
Title:  conduct.
Title:  
Title:  "You have, then, decided to come to England again," said Lord de
Title:  Winter, "in spite of the resolutions you so often expressed in
Title:  Paris never to set your feet on British ground?"
Title:  
Title:  Milady replied to this question by another question.  "To begin
Title:  with, tell me," said she, "how have you watched me so closely as
Title:  to be aware beforehand not only of my arrival, but even of the
Title:  day, the hour, and the port at which I should arrive?"
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter adopted the same tactics as Milady, thinking that
Title:  as his sister-in-law employed them they must be the best.
Title:  
Title:  "But tell me, my dear sister," replied he, "what makes you come
Title:  to England?"
Title:  
Title:  "I come to see you," replied Milady, without knowing how much she
Title:  aggravated by this reply the suspicions to which d'Artagnan's
Title:  letter had given birth in the mind of her brother-in-law, and
Title:  only desiring to gain the good will of her auditor by a
Title:  falsehood.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, to see me?" said de Winter, cunningly.
Title:  
Title:  "To be sure, to see you.  What is there astonishing in that?"
Title:  
Title:  "And you had no other object in coming to England but to see me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No."
Title:  
Title:  "So it was for me alone you have taken the trouble to cross the
Title:  Channel?"
Title:  
Title:  "For you alone."
Title:  
Title:  "The deuce!  What tenderness, my sister!"
Title:  
Title:  "But am I not your nearest relative?" demanded Milady, with a
Title:  tone of the most touching ingenuousness.
Title:  
Title:  "And my only heir, are you not?" said Lord de Winter in his turn,
Title:  fixing his eyes on those of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  Whatever command she had over herself, Milady could not help
Title:  starting; and as in pronouncing the last words Lord de Winter
Title:  placed his hand upon the arm of his sister, this start did not
Title:  escape him.
Title:  
Title:  In fact, the blow was direct and severe.  The first idea that
Title:  occurred to Milady's mind was that she had been betrayed by
Title:  Kitty, and that she had recounted to the baron the selfish
Title:  aversion toward himself of which she had imprudently allowed some
Title:  marks to escape before her servant.  She also recollected the
Title:  furious and imprudent attack she had made upon d'Artagnan when he
Title:  spared the life of her brother.
Title:  
Title:  "I do not understand, my Lord," said she, in order to gain time
Title:  and make her adversary speak out.  "What do you mean to say?  Is
Title:  there any secret meaning concealed beneath your words?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, no!" said Lord de Winter, with apparent good nature.
Title:  "You wish to see me, and you come to England.  I learn this
Title:  desire, or rather I suspect that you feel it; and in order to
Title:  spare you all the annoyances of a nocturnal arrival in a port and
Title:  all the fatigues of landing, I send one of my officers to meet
Title:  you, I place a carriage at his orders, and he brings you hither
Title:  to this castle, of which I am governor, whither I come every day,
Title:  and where, in order to satisfy our mutual desire of seeing each
Title:  other, I have prepared you a chamber.  What is there more
Title:  astonishing in all that I have said to you than in what you have
Title:  told me?"
Title:  
Title:  "No; what I think astonishing is that you should expect my
Title:  coming."
Title:  
Title:  "And yet that is the most simple thing in the world, my dear
Title:  sister.  Have you not observed that the captain of your little
Title:  vessel, on entering the roadstead, sent forward, in order to
Title:  obtain permission to enter the port, a little boat bearing his
Title:  logbook and the register of his voyagers?  I am commandant of the
Title:  port.  They brought me that book.  I recognized your name in it.
Title:  My heart told me what your mouth has just confirmed--that is to
Title:  say, with what view you have exposed yourself to the dangers of a
Title:  sea so perilous, or at least so troublesome at this moment--and I
Title:  sent my cutter to meet you.  You know the rest."
Title:  
Title:  Milady knew that Lord de Winter lied, and she was the more
Title:  alarmed.
Title:  
Title:  "My brother," continued she, "was not that my Lord Buckingham
Title:  whom I saw on the jetty this evening as we arrived?"
Title:  
Title:  "Himself.  Ah, I can understand how the sight of him struck you,"
Title:  replied Lord de Winter.  "You came from a country where he must
Title:  be very much talked of, and I know that his armaments against
Title:  France greatly engage the attention of your friend the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "My friend the cardinal!" cried Milady, seeing that on this point
Title:  as on the other Lord de Winter seemed well instructed.
Title:  
Title:  "Is he not your friend?" replied the baron, negligently.  "Ah,
Title:  pardon!  I thought so; but we will return to my Lord Duke
Title:  presently.  Let us not depart from the sentimental turn our
Title:  conversation had taken.  You came, you say, to see me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, I reply that you shall be served to the height of your
Title:  wishes, and that we shall see each other every day."
Title:  
Title:  "Am I, then, to remain here eternally?" demanded Milady, with a
Title:  certain terror.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you find yourself badly lodged, sister?  Demand anything you
Title:  want, and I will hasten to have you furnished with it."
Title:  
Title:  "But I have neither my women nor my servants."
Title:  
Title:  "You shall have all, madame.  Tell me on what footing your
Title:  household was established by your first husband, and although I
Title:  am only your brother-in-law, I will arrange one similar."
Title:  
Title:  "My first husband!" cried Milady, looking at Lord de Winter with
Title:  eyes almost starting from their sockets.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, your French husband.  I don't speak of my brother.  If you
Title:  have forgotten, as he is still living, I can write to him and he
Title:  will send me information on the subject."
Title:  
Title:  A cold sweat burst from the brow of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "You jest!" said she, in a hollow voice.
Title:  
Title:  "Do I look so?" asked the baron, rising and going a step
Title:  backward.
Title:  
Title:  "Or rather you insult me," continued she, pressing with her
Title:  stiffened hands the two arms of her easy chair, and raising
Title:  herself upon her wrists.
Title:  
Title:  "I insult you!" said Lord de Winter, with contempt.  "In truth,
Title:  madame, do you think that can be possible?"
Title:  
Title:  "Indeed, sir," said Milady, "you must be either drunk or mad.
Title:  Leave the room, and send me a woman."
Title:  
Title:  "Women are very indiscreet, my sister.  Cannot I serve you as a
Title:  waiting maid?  By that means all our secrets will remain in the
Title:  family."
Title:  
Title:  "Insolent!" cried Milady; and as if acted upon by a spring, she
Title:  bounded toward the baron, who awaited her attack with his arms
Title:  crossed, but nevertheless with one hand on the hilt of his sword.
Title:  
Title:  "Come!" said he. "I know you are accustomed to assassinate
Title:  people; but I warn you I shall defend myself, even against you."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right," said Milady.  "You have all the appearance of
Title:  being cowardly enough to lift your hand against a woman."
Title:  
Title:  "Perhaps so; and I have an excuse, for mine would not be the
Title:  first hand of a man that has been placed upon you, I imagine."
Title:  
Title:  And the baron pointed, with a slow and accusing gesture, to the
Title:  left shoulder of Milady, which he almost touched with his finger.
Title:  
Title:  Milady uttered a deep, inward shriek, and retreated to a corner
Title:  of the room like a panther which crouches for a spring.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, growl as much as you please," cried Lord de Winter, "but
Title:  don't try to bite, for I warn you that it would be to your
Title:  disadvantage.  There are here no procurators who regulate
Title:  successions beforehand.  There is no knight-errant to come and
Title:  seek a quarrel with me on account of the fair lady I detain a
Title:  prisoner; but I have judges quite ready who will quickly dispose
Title:  of a woman so shameless as to glide, a bigamist, into the bed of
Title:  Lord de Winter, my brother.  And these judges, I warn you, will
Title:  soon send you to an executioner who will make both your shoulders
Title:  alike."
Title:  
Title:  The eyes of Milady darted such flashes that although he was a man
Title:  and armed before an unarmed woman, he felt the chill of fear
Title:  glide through his whole frame.  However, he continued all the
Title:  same, but with increasing warmth:  "Yes, I can very well
Title:  understand that after having inherited the fortune of my brother
Title:  it would be very agreeable to you to be my heir likewise; but
Title:  know beforehand, if you kill me or cause me to be killed, my
Title:  precautions are taken.  Not a penny of what I possess will pass
Title:  into your hands.  Were you not already rich enough--you who
Title:  possess nearly a million?  And could you not stop your fatal
Title:  career, if you did not do evil for the infinite and supreme joy
Title:  of doing it?  Oh, be assured, if the memory of my brother were
Title:  not sacred to me, you should rot in a state dungeon or satisfy
Title:  the curiosity of sailors at Tyburn.  I will be silent, but you
Title:  must endure your captivity quietly.  In fifteen or twenty days I
Title:  shall set out for La Rochelle with the army; but on the eve of my
Title:  departure a vessel which I shall see depart will take you hence
Title:  and convey you to our colonies in the south.  And be assured that
Title:  you shall be accompanied by one who will blow your brains out at
Title:  the first attempt you make to return to England or the
Title:  Continent."
Title:  
Title:  Milady listened with an attention that dilated her inflamed eyes.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, at present," continued Lord de Winter, "you will remain in
Title:  this castle.  The walls are thick, the doors strong, and the bars
Title:  solid; besides, your window opens immediately over the sea.  The
Title:  men of my crew, who are devoted to me for life and death, mount
Title:  guard around this apartment, and watch all the passages that lead
Title:  to the courtyard.  Even if you gained the yard, there would still
Title:  be three iron gates for you to pass.  The order is positive.  A
Title:  step, a gesture, a word, on your part, denoting an effort to
Title:  escape, and you are to be fired upon.  If they kill you, English
Title:  justice will be under an obligation to me for having saved it
Title:  trouble.  Ah! I see your features regain their calmness, your
Title:  countenance recovers its assurance.  You are saying to yourself:
Title:  'Fifteen days, twenty days?  Bah!  I have an inventive mind;
Title:  before that is expired some idea will occur to me.  I have an
Title:  infernal spirit.  I shall meet with a victim.  Before fifteen
Title:  days are gone by I shall be away from here.'  Ah, try it!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady, finding her thoughts betrayed, dug her nails into her
Title:  flesh to subdue every emotion that might give to her face any
Title:  expression except agony.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter continued:  "The officer who commands here in my
Title:  absence you have already seen, and therefore know him.  He knows
Title:  how, as you must have observed, to obey an order--for you did
Title:  not, I am sure, come from Portsmouth hither without endeavoring
Title:  to make him speak.  What do you say of him?  Could a statue of
Title:  marble have been more impassive and more mute?  You have already
Title:  tried the power of your seductions upon many men, and
Title:  unfortunately you have always succeeded; but I give you leave to
Title:  try them upon this one.  PARDIEU! if you succeed with him, I
Title:  pronounce you the demon himself."
Title:  
Title:  He went toward the door and opened it hastily.
Title:  
Title:  "Call Mr. Felton," said he. "Wait a minute longer, and I will
Title:  introduce him to you."
Title:  
Title:  There followed between these two personages a strange silence,
Title:  during which the sound of a slow and regular step was heard
Title:  approaching.  Shortly a human form appeared in the shade of the
Title:  corridor, and the young lieutenant, with whom we are already
Title:  acquainted, stopped at the threshold to receive the orders of the
Title:  baron.
Title:  
Title:  "Come in, my dear John," said Lord de Winter, "come in, and shut
Title:  the door."
Title:  
Title:  The young officer entered.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said the baron, "look at this woman.  She is young; she is
Title:  beautiful; she possesses all earthly seductions.  Well, she is a
Title:  monster, who, at twenty-five years of age, has been guilty of as
Title:  many crimes as you could read of in a year in the archives of our
Title:  tribunals.  Her voice prejudices her hearers in her favor; her
Title:  beauty serves as a bait to her victims; her body even pays what
Title:  she promises--I must do her that justice.  She will try to seduce
Title:  you, perhaps she will try to kill you.  I have extricated you
Title:  from misery, Felton; I have caused you to be named lieutenant; I
Title:  once saved your life, you know on what occasion.  I am for you
Title:  not only a protector, but a friend; not only a benefactor, but a
Title:  father.  This woman has come back again into England for the
Title:  purpose of conspiring against my life.  I hold this serpent in my
Title:  hands.  Well, I call you, and say to you:  Friend Felton, John,
Title:  my child, guard me, and more particularly guard yourself, against
Title:  this woman.  Swear, by your hopes of salvation, to keep her
Title:  safely for the chastisement she has merited.  John Felton, I
Title:  trust your word!  John Felton, I put faith in your loyalty!"
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord," said the young officer, summoning to his mild
Title:  countenance all the hatred he could find in his heart, "my Lord,
Title:  I swear all shall be done as you desire."
Title:  
Title:  Milady received this look like a resigned victim; it was
Title:  impossible to imagine a more submissive or a more mild expression
Title:  than that which prevailed on her beautiful countenance.  Lord de
Title:  Winter himself could scarcely recognize the tigress who, a minute
Title:  before, prepared apparently for a fight.
Title:  
Title:  "She is not to leave this chamber, understand, John," continued
Title:  the baron.  "She is to correspond with nobody; she is to speak to
Title:  no one but you--if you will do her the honor to address a word to
Title:  her."
Title:  
Title:  "That is sufficient, my Lord!  I have sworn."
Title:  
Title:  "And now, madame, try to make your peace with God, for you are
Title:  judged by men!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady let her head sink, as if crushed by this sentence.  Lord
Title:  de Winter went out, making a sign to Felton, who followed him,
Title:  shutting the door after him.
Title:  
Title:  One instant after, the heavy step of a marine who served as
Title:  sentinel was heard in the corridor--his ax in his girdle and his
Title:  musket on his shoulder.
Title:  
Title:  Milady remained for some minutes in the same position, for she
Title:  thought they might perhaps be examining her through the keyhole;
Title:  she then slowly raised her head, which had resumed its formidable
Title:  expression of menace and defiance, ran to the door to listen,
Title:  looked out of her window, and returning to bury herself again in
Title:  her large armchair, she reflected.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  51  OFFICER
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, the cardinal looked anxiously for news from England;
Title:  but no news arrived that was not annoying and threatening.
Title:  
Title:  Although La Rochelle was invested, however certain success might
Title:  appear--thanks to the precautions taken, and above all to the
Title:  dyke, which prevented the entrance of any vessel into the
Title:  besieged city--the blockade might last a long time yet.  This was
Title:  a great affront to the king's army, and a great inconvenience to
Title:  the cardinal, who had no longer, it is true, to embroil Louis
Title:  XIII with Anne of Austria--for that affair was over--but he had
Title:  to adjust matters for M. de Bassompierre, who was embroiled with
Title:  the Duc d'Angouleme.
Title:  
Title:  As to Monsieur, who had begun the siege, he left to the cardinal
Title:  the task of finishing it.
Title:  
Title:  The city, notwithstanding the incredible perseverance of its
Title:  mayor, had attempted a sort of mutiny for a surrender; the mayor
Title:  had hanged the mutineers.  This execution quieted the ill-
Title:  disposed, who resolved to allow themselves to die of hunger--this
Title:  death always appearing to them more slow and less sure than
Title:  strangulation.
Title:  
Title:  On their side, from time to time, the besiegers took the
Title:  messengers which the Rochellais sent to Buckingham, or the spies
Title:  which Buckingham sent to the Rochellais.  In one case or the
Title:  other, the trial was soon over.  The cardinal pronounced the
Title:  single word, "Hanged!"  The king was invited to come and see the
Title:  hanging.  He came languidly, placing himself in a good situation
Title:  to see all the details.  This amused him sometimes a little, and
Title:  made him endure the siege with patience; but it did not prevent
Title:  his getting very tired, or from talking at every moment of
Title:  returning to Paris--so that if the messengers and the spies had
Title:  failed, his Eminence, notwithstanding all his inventiveness,
Title:  would have found himself much embarrassed.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless, time passed on, and the Rochellais did not
Title:  surrender.  The last spy that was taken was the bearer of a
Title:  letter.  This letter told Buckingham that the city was at an
Title:  extremity; but instead of adding, "If your succor does not arrive
Title:  within fifteen days, we will surrender," it added, quite simply,
Title:  "If your succor comes not within fifteen days, we shall all be
Title:  dead with hunger when it comes."
Title:  
Title:  The Rochellais, then, had no hope but in Buckingham.  Buckingham
Title:  was their Messiah.  It was evident that if they one day learned
Title:  positively that they must not count on Buckingham, their courage
Title:  would fail with their hope.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal looked, then, with great impatience for the news
Title:  from England which would announce to him that Buckingham would
Title:  not come.
Title:  
Title:  The question of carrying the city by assault, though often
Title:  debated in the council of the king, had been always rejected.  In
Title:  the first place, La Rochelle appeared impregnable.  Then the
Title:  cardinal, whatever he said, very well knew that the horror of
Title:  bloodshed in this encounter, in which Frenchman would combat
Title:  against Frenchman, was a retrograde movement of sixty years
Title:  impressed upon his policy; and the cardinal was at that period
Title:  what we now call a man of progress.  In fact, the sack of La
Title:  Rochelle, and the assassination of three of four thousand
Title:  Huguenots who allowed themselves to be killed, would resemble too
Title:  closely, in 1628, the massacre of St. Bartholomew in 1572; and
Title:  then, above all this, this extreme measure, which was not at all
Title:  repugnant to the king, good Catholic as he was, always fell
Title:  before this argument of the besieging generals--La Rochelle is
Title:  impregnable except to famine.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal could not drive from his mind the fear he
Title:  entertained of his terrible emissary--for he comprehended the
Title:  strange qualities of this woman, sometimes a serpent, sometimes a
