Title:  lion.  Had she betrayed him?  Was she dead?  He knew her well
Title:  enough in all cases to know that, whether acting for or against
Title:  him, as a friend or an enemy, she would not remain motionless
Title:  without great impediments; but whence did these impediments
Title:  arise?  That was what he could not know.
Title:  
Title:  And yet he reckoned, and with reason, on Milady.  He had divined
Title:  in the past of this woman terrible things which his red mantle
Title:  alone could cover; and he felt, from one cause or another, that
Title:  this woman was his own, as she could look to no other but himself
Title:  for a support superior to the danger which threatened her.
Title:  
Title:  He resolved, then, to carry on the war alone, and to look for no
Title:  success foreign to himself, but as we look for a fortunate
Title:  chance.  He continued to press the raising of the famous dyke
Title:  which was to starve La Rochelle.  Meanwhile, he cast his eyes
Title:  over that unfortunate city, which contained so much deep misery
Title:  and so many heroic virtues, and recalling the saying of Louis XI,
Title:  his political predecessor, as he himself was the predecessor of
Title:  Robespierre, he repeated this maxim of Tristan's gossip:  "Divide
Title:  in order to reign."
Title:  
Title:  Henry IV, when besieging Paris, had loaves and provisions thrown
Title:  over the walls.  The cardinal had little notes thrown over in
Title:  which he represented to the Rochellais how unjust, selfish, and
Title:  barbarous was the conduct of their leaders.  These leaders had
Title:  corn in abundance, and would not let them partake of it; they
Title:  adopted as a maxim--for they, too, had maxims--that it was of
Title:  very little consequence that women, children, and old men should
Title:  die, so long as the men who were to defend the walls remained
Title:  strong and healthy.  Up to that time, whether from devotedness or
Title:  from want of power to act against it, this maxim, without being
Title:  generally adopted, nevertheless passed from theory into practice;
Title:  but the notes did it injury.  The notes reminded the men that the
Title:  children, women, and old men whom they allowed to die were their
Title:  sons, their wives, and their fathers, and that it would be more
Title:  just for everyone to be reduced to the common misery, in order
Title:  that equal conditions should give birth to unanimous resolutions.
Title:  
Title:  These notes had all the effect that he who wrote them could
Title:  expect, in that they induced a great number of the inhabitants to
Title:  open private negotiations with the royal army.
Title:  
Title:  But at the moment when the cardinal saw his means already
Title:  bearing fruit, and applauded himself for having put it in action, an
Title:  inhabitant of La Rochelle who had contrived to pass the royal
Title:  lines--God knows how, such was the watchfulness of Bassompierre,
Title:  Schomberg, and the Duc d'Angouleme, themselves watched over by
Title:  the cardinal--an inhabitant of La Rochelle, we say, entered the
Title:  city, coming from Portsmouth, and saying that he had seen a
Title:  magnificent fleet ready to sail within eight days.  Still
Title:  further, Buckingham announced to the mayor that at length the
Title:  great league was about to declare itself against France, and that
Title:  the kingdom would be at once invaded by the English, Imperial,
Title:  and Spanish armies.  This letter was read publicly in all parts
Title:  of the city.  Copies were put up at the corners of the streets;
Title:  and even they who had begun to open negotiations interrupted
Title:  them, being resolved to await the succor so pompously announced.
Title:  
Title:  This unexpected circumstance brought back Richelieu's former
Title:  anxiety, and forced him in spite of himself once more to turn his
Title:  eyes to the other side of the sea.
Title:  
Title:  During this time, exempt from the anxiety of its only and true
Title:  chief, the royal army led a joyous life, neither provisions nor
Title:  money being wanting in the camp.  All the corps rivaled one
Title:  another in audacity and gaiety.  To take spies and hang them, to
Title:  make hazardous expeditions upon the dyke or the sea, to imagine
Title:  wild plans, and to execute them coolly--such were the pastimes
Title:  which made the army find these days short which were not only so
Title:  long to the Rochellais, a prey to famine and anxiety, but even to
Title:  the cardinal, who blockaded them so closely.
Title:  
Title:  Sometimes when the cardinal, always on horseback, like the lowest
Title:  GENDARME of the army, cast a pensive glance over those works, so
Title:  slowly keeping pace with his wishes, which the engineers, brought
Title:  from all the corners of France, were executing under his orders,
Title:  if he met a Musketeer of the company of Treville, he drew near
Title:  and looked at him in a peculiar manner, and not recognizing in
Title:  him one of our four companions, he turned his penetrating look
Title:  and profound thoughts in another direction.
Title:  
Title:  One day when oppressed with a mortal weariness of mind, without
Title:  hope in the negotiations with the city, without news from
Title:  England, the cardinal went out, without any other aim than to be
Title:  out of doors, and accompanied only by Cahusac and La Houdiniere,
Title:  strolled along the beach.  Mingling the immensity of his dreams
Title:  with the immensity of the ocean, he came, his horse going at a
Title:  foot's pace, to a hill from the top of which he perceived behind
Title:  a hedge, reclining on the sand and catching in its passage one of
Title:  those rays of the sun so rare at this period of the year, seven
Title:  men surrounded by empty bottles.  Four of these men were our
Title:  Musketeers, preparing to listen to a letter one of them had just
Title:  received.  This letter was so important that it made them forsake
Title:  their cards and their dice on the drumhead.
Title:  
Title:  The other three were occupied in opening an enormous flagon of
Title:  Collicure wine; these were the lackeys of these gentlemen.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal was, as we have said, in very low spirits; and
Title:  nothing when he was in that state of mind increased his
Title:  depression so much as gaiety in others.  Besides, he had another
Title:  strange fancy, which was always to believe that the causes of his
Title:  sadness created the gaiety of others.  Making a sign to La
Title:  Houdiniere and Cahusac to stop, he alighted from his horse, and
Title:  went toward these suspected merry companions, hoping, by means of
Title:  the sand which deadened the sound of his steps and of the hedge
Title:  which concealed his approach, to catch some words of this
Title:  conversation which appeared so interesting.  At ten paces from
Title:  the hedge he recognized the talkative Gascon; and as he had
Title:  already perceived that these men were Musketeers, he did not
Title:  doubt that the three others were those called the Inseparables;
Title:  that is to say, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  It may be supposed that his desire to hear the conversation was
Title:  augmented by this discovery.  His eyes took a strange expression,
Title:  and with the step of a tiger-cat he advanced toward the hedge;
Title:  but he had not been able to catch more than a few vague syllables
Title:  without any positive sense, when a sonorous and short cry made
Title:  him start, and attracted the attention of the Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  "Officer!" cried Grimaud.
Title:  
Title:  "You are speaking, you scoundrel!" said Athos, rising upon his
Title:  elbow, and transfixing Grimaud with his flaming look.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud therefore added nothing to his speech, but contented
Title:  himself with pointing his index finger in the direction of the
Title:  hedge, announcing by this gesture the cardinal and his escort.
Title:  
Title:  With a single bound the Musketeers were on their feet, and
Title:  saluted with respect.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal seemed furious.
Title:  
Title:  "It appears that Messieurs the Musketeers keep guard," said he.
Title:  "Are the English expected by land, or do the Musketeers consider
Title:  themselves superior officers?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," replied Athos, for amid the general fright he
Title:  alone had preserved the noble calmness and coolness that never
Title:  forsook him, "Monseigneur, the Musketeers, when they are not on
Title:  duty, or when their duty is over, drink and play at dice, and
Title:  they are certainly superior officers to their lackeys."
Title:  
Title:  "Lackeys?" grumbled the cardinal.  "Lackeys who have the order to
Title:  warn their masters when anyone passes are not lackeys, they are
Title:  sentinels."
Title:  
Title:  "Your Eminence may perceive that if we had not taken this
Title:  precaution, we should have been exposed to allowing you to pass
Title:  without presenting you our respects or offering you our thanks
Title:  for the favor you have done us in uniting us.  D'Artagnan,"
Title:  continued Athos, "you, who but lately were so anxious for such an
Title:  opportunity for expressing your gratitude to Monseigneur, here it
Title:  is; avail yourself of it."
Title:  
Title:  These words were pronounced with that imperturbable phlegm which
Title:  distinguished Athos in the hour of danger, and with that
Title:  excessive politeness which made of him at certain moments a king
Title:  more majestic than kings by birth.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan came forward and stammered out a few words of
Title:  gratitude which soon expired under the gloomy looks of the
Title:  cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "It does not signify, gentlemen," continued the cardinal, without
Title:  appearing to be in the least swerved from his first intention by
Title:  the diversion which Athos had started, "it does not signify,
Title:  gentlemen.  I do not like to have simple soldiers, because they
Title:  have the advantage of serving in a privileged corps, thus to play
Title:  the great lords; discipline is the same for them as for everybody
Title:  else."
Title:  
Title:  Athos allowed the cardinal to finish his sentence completely, and
Title:  bowed in sign of assent.  Then he resumed in his turn:
Title:  "Discipline, Monseigneur, has, I hope, in no way been forgotten
Title:  by us.  We are not on duty, and we believed that not being on
Title:  duty we were at liberty to dispose of our time as we pleased.  If
Title:  we are so fortunate as to have some particular duty to perform
Title:  for your Eminence, we are ready to obey you.  Your Eminence may
Title:  perceive," continued Athos, knitting his brow, for this sort of
Title:  investigation began to annoy him, "that we have not come out
Title:  without our arms."
Title:  
Title:  And he showed the cardinal, with his finger, the four muskets
Title:  piled near the drum, on which were the cards and dice.
Title:  
Title:  "Your Eminence may believe," added d'Artagnan, "that we would
Title:  have come to meet you, if we could have supposed it was
Title:  Monseigneur coming toward us with so few attendants."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal bit his mustache, and even his lips a little.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know what you look like, all together, as you are armed
Title:  and guarded by your lackeys?" said the cardinal.  "You look like
Title:  four conspirators."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, as to that, Monseigneur, it is true," said Athos; "we do
Title:  conspire, as your Eminence might have seen the other morning.
Title:  Only we conspire against the Rochellais."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you gentlemen of policy!" replied the cardinal, knitting his
Title:  brow in his turn, "the secret of many unknown things might
Title:  perhaps be found in your brains, if we could read them as you
Title:  read that letter which you concealed as soon as you saw me
Title:  coming."
Title:  
Title:  The color mounted to the face of Athos, and he made a step toward
Title:  his Eminence.
Title:  
Title:  "One might think you really suspected us, monseigneur, and we
Title:  were undergoing a real interrogatory.  If it be so, we trust your
Title:  Eminence will deign to explain yourself, and we should then at
Title:  least be acquainted with our real position."
Title:  
Title:  "And if it were an interrogatory!" replied the cardinal.  "Others
Title:  besides you have undergone such, Monsieur Athos, and have replied
Title:  thereto."
Title:  
Title:  "Thus I have told your Eminence that you had but to question us,
Title:  and we are ready to reply."
Title:  
Title:  "What was that letter you were about to read, Monsieur Aramis,
Title:  and which you so promptly concealed?"
Title:  
Title:  "A woman's letter, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, yes, I see," said the cardinal; "we must be discreet with
Title:  this sort of letters; but nevertheless, we may show them to a
Title:  confessor, and you know I have taken orders."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," said Athos, with a calmness the more terrible
Title:  because he risked his head in making this reply, "the letter is a
Title:  woman's letter, but it is neither signed Marion de Lorme, nor
Title:  Madame d'Aiguillon."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal became as pale as death; lightning darted from his
Title:  eyes.  He turned round as if to give an order to Cahusac and
Title:  Houdiniere.  Athos saw the movement; he made a step toward the
Title:  muskets, upon which the other three friends had fixed their eyes,
Title:  like men ill-disposed to allow themselves to be taken.  The
Title:  cardinalists were three; the Musketeers, lackeys included, were
Title:  seven.  He judged that the match would be so much the less equal,
Title:  if Athos and his companions were really plotting; and by one of
Title:  those rapid turns which he always had at command, all his anger
Title:  faded away into a smile.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, well!" said he, "you are brave young men, proud in
Title:  daylight, faithful in darkness.  We can find no fault with you
Title:  for watching over yourselves, when you watch so carefully over
Title:  others.  Gentlemen, I have not forgotten the night in which you
Title:  served me as an escort to the Red Dovecot.  If there were any
Title:  danger to be apprehended on the road I am going, I would request
Title:  you to accompany me; but as there is none, remain where you are,
Title:  finish your bottles, your game, and your letter.  Adieu,
Title:  gentlemen!"
Title:  
Title:  And remounting his horse, which Cahusac led to him, he saluted
Title:  them with his hand, and rode away.
Title:  
Title:  The four young men, standing and motionless, followed him with
Title:  their eyes without speaking a single word until he had
Title:  disappeared.  Then they looked at one another.
Title:  
Title:  The countenances of all gave evidence of terror, for
Title:  notwithstanding the friendly adieu of his Eminence, they plainly
Title:  perceived that the cardinal went away with rage in his heart.
Title:  
Title:  Athos alone smiled, with a self-possessed, disdainful smile.
Title:  
Title:  When the cardinal was out of hearing and sight, "That Grimaud
Title:  kept bad watch!" cried Porthos, who had a great inclination to
Title:  vent his ill-humor on somebody.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud was about to reply to excuse himself.  Athos lifted his
Title:  finger, and Grimaud was silent.
Title:  
Title:  "Would you have given up the letter, Aramis?" said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I," said Aramis, in his most flutelike tone, "I had made up my
Title:  mind.  If he had insisted upon the letter being given up to him,
Title:  I would have presented the letter to him with one hand, and with
Title:  the other I would have run my sword through his body."
Title:  
Title:  "I expected as much," said Athos; "and that was why I threw
Title:  myself between you and him.  Indeed, this man is very much to
Title:  blame for talking thus to other men; one would say he had never
Title:  had to do with any but women and children."
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Athos, I admire you, but nevertheless we were in the
Title:  wrong, after all."
Title:  
Title:  "How, in the wrong?" said Athos.  "Whose, then, is the air we
Title:  breathe?  Whose is the ocean upon which we look?  Whose is the
Title:  sand upon which we were reclining?  Whose is that letter of your
Title:  mistress?  Do these belong to the cardinal?  Upon my honor, this
Title:  man fancies the world belongs to him.  There you stood,
Title:  stammering, stupefied, annihilated.  One might have supposed the
Title:  Bastille appeared before you, and that the gigantic Medusa had
Title:  converted you into stone.  Is being in love conspiring?  You are
Title:  in love with a woman whom the cardinal has caused to be shut up,
Title:  and you wish to get her out of the hands of the cardinal.  That's
Title:  a match you are playing with his Eminence; this letter is your
Title:  game.  Why should you expose your game to your adversary?  That
Title:  is never done.  Let him find it out if he can!  We can find out
Title:  his!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, that's all very sensible, Athos," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "In that case, let there be no more question of what's past, and
Title:  let Aramis resume the letter from his cousin where the cardinal
Title:  interrupted him."
Title:  
Title:  Aramis drew the letter from his pocket; the three friends
Title:  surrounded him, and the three lackeys grouped themselves again
Title:  near the wine jar.
Title:  
Title:  "You had only read a line or two," said d'Artagnan; "read the
Title:  letter again from the commencement."
Title:  
Title:  "Willingly," said Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "My dear Cousin, I think I shall make up my mind to set out for
Title:  Bethune, where my sister has placed our little servant in the
Title:  convent of the Carmelites; this poor child is quite resigned, as
Title:  she knows she cannot live elsewhere without the salvation of her
Title:  soul being in danger.  Nevertheless, if the affairs of our family
Title:  are arranged, as we hope they will be, I believe she will run the
Title:  risk of being damned, and will return to those she regrets,
Title:  particularly as she knows they are always thinking of her.
Title:  Meanwhile, she is not very wretched; what she most desires is a
Title:  letter from her intended.  I know that such viands pass with
Title:  difficulty through convent gratings; but after all, as I have
Title:  given you proofs, my dear cousin, I am not unskilled in such
Title:  affairs, and I will take charge of the commission.  My sister
Title:  thanks you for your good and eternal remembrance.  She has
Title:  experienced much anxiety; but she is now at length a little
Title:  reassured, having sent her secretary away in order that nothing
Title:  may happen unexpectedly.
Title:  
Title:  "Adieu, my dear cousin.  Tell us news of yourself as often as you
Title:  can; that is to say, as often as you can with safety.  I embrace
Title:  you.
Title:  
Title:  "Marie Michon."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, what do I not owe you, Aramis?" said d'Artagnan.  "Dear
Title:  Constance!  I have at length, then, intelligence of you.  She
Title:  lives; she is in safety in a convent; she is at Bethune!  Where
Title:  is Bethune, Athos?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, upon the frontiers of Artois and of Flanders.  The siege
Title:  once over, we shall be able to make a tour in that direction."
Title:  
Title:  "And that will not be long, it is to be hoped," said Porthos;
Title:  "for they have this morning hanged a spy who confessed that the
Title:  Rochellais were reduced to the leather of their shoes.  Supposing
Title:  that after having eaten the leather they eat the soles, I cannot
Title:  see much that is left unless they eat one another."
Title:  
Title:  "Poor fools!" said Athos, emptying a glass of excellent Bordeaux
Title:  wine which, without having at that period the reputation it now
Title:  enjoys, merited it no less, "poor fools!  As if the Catholic
Title:  religion was not the most advantageous and the most agreeable of
Title:  all religions!  All the same," resumed he, after having clicked
Title:  his tongue against his palate, "they are brave fellows!  But what
Title:  the devil are you about, Aramis?" continued Athos.  "Why, you are
Title:  squeezing that letter into your pocket!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said d'Artagnan, "Athos is right, it must be burned.  And
Title:  yet if we burn it, who knows whether Monsieur Cardinal has not a
Title:  secret to interrogate ashes?"
Title:  
Title:  "He must have one," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "What will you do with the letter, then?" asked Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "Come here, Grimaud," said Athos.  Grimaud rose and obeyed.  "As
Title:  a punishment for having spoken without permission, my friend, you
Title:  will please to eat this piece of paper; then to recompense you
Title:  for the service you will have rendered us, you shall afterward
Title:  drink this glass of wine.  First, here is the letter.  Eat
Title:  heartily."
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud smiled; and with his eyes fixed upon the glass which
Title:  Athos held in his hand, he ground the paper well between his
Title:  teeth and then swallowed it.
Title:  
Title:  "Bravo, Monsieur Grimaud!" said Athos; "and now take this.
Title:  That's well.  We dispense with your saying grace."
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud silently swallowed the glass of Bordeaux wine; but his
Title:  eyes, raised toward heaven during this delicious occupation,
Title:  spoke a language which, though mute, was not the less expressive.
Title:  
Title:  "And now," said Athos, "unless Monsieur Cardinal should form the
Title:  ingenious idea of ripping up Grimaud, I think we may be pretty
Title:  much at our ease respecting the letter."
Title:  
Title:  Meantime, his Eminence continued his melancholy ride, murmuring
Title:  between his mustaches, "These four men must positively be mine."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  52  CAPTIVITY:  THE FIRST DAY
Title:  
Title:  Let us return to Milady, whom a glance thrown upon the coast of
Title:  France has made us lose sight of for an instant.
Title:  
Title:  We shall find her still in the despairing attitude in which we
Title:  left her, plunged in an abyss of dismal reflection--a dark hell
Title:  at the gate of which she has almost left hope behind, because for
Title:  the first time she doubts, for the first time she fears.
Title:  
Title:  On two occasions her fortune has failed her, on two occasions she
Title:  has found herself discovered and betrayed; and on these two
Title:  occasions it was to one fatal genius, sent doubtlessly by the
Title:  Lord to combat her, that she has succumbed.  D'Artagnan has
Title:  conquered her--her, that invincible power of evil.
Title:  
Title:  He has deceived her in her love, humbled her in her pride,
Title:  thwarted her in her ambition; and now he ruins her fortune,
Title:  deprives her of liberty, and even threatens her life.  Still
Title:  more, he has lifted the corner of her mask--that shield with
Title:  which she covered herself and which rendered her so strong.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan has turned aside from Buckingham, whom she hates as
Title:  she hates everyone she has loved, the tempest with which
Title:  Richelieu threatened him in the person of the queen.  D'Artagnan
Title:  had passed himself upon her as de Wardes, for whom she had
Title:  conceived one of those tigerlike fancies common to women of her
Title:  character.  D'Artagnan knows that terrible secret which she has
Title:  sworn no one shall know without dying.  In short, at the moment
Title:  in which she has just obtained from Richelieu a carte blanche by
Title:  the means of which she is about to take vengeance on her enemy,
Title:  this precious paper is torn from her hands, and it is d'Artagnan
Title:  who holds her prisoner and is about to send her to some filthy
Title:  Botany Bay, some infamous Tyburn of the Indian Ocean.
Title:  
Title:  All this she owes to d'Artagnan, without doubt.  From whom can
Title:  come so many disgraces heaped upon her head, if not from him?  He
Title:  alone could have transmitted to Lord de Winter all these
Title:  frightful secrets which he has discovered, one after another, by
Title:  a train of fatalities.  He knows her brother-in-law.  He must
Title:  have written to him.
Title:  
Title:  What hatred she distills!  Motionless, with her burning and fixed
Title:  glances, in her solitary apartment, how well the outbursts of
Title:  passion which at times escape from the depths of her chest with
Title:  her respiration, accompany the sound of the surf which rises,
Title:  growls, roars, and breaks itself like an eternal and powerless
Title:  despair against the rocks on which is built this dark and lofty
Title:  castle!  How many magnificent projects of vengeance she conceives
Title:  by the light of the flashes which her tempestuous passion casts
Title:  over her mind against Mme. Bonacieux, against Buckingham, but
Title:  above all against d'Artagnan--projects lost in the distance of
Title:  the future.
Title:  
Title:  Yes; but in order to avenge herself she must be free.  And to be
Title:  free, a prisoner has to pierce a wall, detach bars, cut through a
Title:  floor--all undertakings which a patient and strong man may
Title:  accomplish, but before which the feverish irritations of a woman
Title:  must give way.  Besides, to do all this, time is necessary--
Title:  months, years; and she has ten or twelve days, as Lord de Winter,
Title:  her fraternal and terrible jailer, has told her.
Title:  
Title:  And yet, if she were a man she would attempt all this, and
Title:  perhaps might succeed; why, then, did heaven make the mistake of
Title:  placing that manlike soul in that frail and delicate body?
Title:  
Title:  The first moments of her captivity were terrible; a few
Title:  convulsions of rage which she could not suppress paid her debt of
Title:  feminine weakness to nature.  But by degrees she overcame the
Title:  outbursts of her mad passion; and nervous tremblings which
Title:  agitated her frame disappeared, and she remained folded within
Title:  herself like a fatigued serpent in repose.
Title:  
Title:  "Go to, go to!  I must have been mad to allow myself to be
Title:  carried away so," says she, gazing into the glass, which reflects
Title:  back to her eyes the burning glance by which she appears to
Title:  interrogate herself.  "No violence; violence is the proof of
Title:  weakness.  In the first place, I have never succeeded by that
Title:  means.  Perhaps if I employed my strength against women I might
Title:  perchance find them weaker than myself, and consequently conquer
Title:  them; but it is with men that I struggle, and I am but a woman to
Title:  them.  Let me fight like a woman, then; my strength is in my
Title:  weakness."
Title:  
Title:  Then, as if to render an account to herself of the changes she
Title:  could place upon her countenance, so mobile and so expressive,
Title:  she made it take all expressions from that of passionate anger,
Title:  which convulsed her features, to that of the most sweet, most
Title:  affectionate, and most seducing smile.  Then her hair assumed
Title:  successively, under her skillful hands, all the undulations she
Title:  thought might assist the charms of her face.  At length she
Title:  murmured, satisfied with herself, "Come, nothing is lost; I am
Title:  still beautiful."
Title:  
Title:  It was then nearly eight o'clock in the evening.  Milady
Title:  perceived a bed; she calculated that the repose of a few hours
Title:  would not only refresh her head and her ideas, but still further,
Title:  her complexion.  A better idea, however, came into her mind
Title:  before going to bed.  She had heard something said about supper.
Title:  She had already been an hour in this apartment; they could not
Title:  long delay bringing her a repast.  The prisoner did not wish to
Title:  lose time; and she resolved to make that very evening some
Title:  attempts to ascertain the nature of the ground she had to work
Title:  upon, by studying the characters of the men to whose guardianship
Title:  she was committed.
Title:  
Title:  A light appeared under the door; this light announced the
Title:  reappearance of her jailers.  Milady, who had arisen, threw
Title:  herself quickly into the armchair, her head thrown back, her
Title:  beautiful hair unbound and disheveled, her bosom half bare
Title:  beneath her crumpled lace, one hand on her heart, and the other
Title:  hanging down.
Title:  
Title:  The bolts were drawn; the door groaned upon its hinges.  Steps
Title:  sounded in the chamber, and drew near.
Title:  
Title:  "Place that table there," said a voice which the prisoner
Title:  recognized as that of Felton.
Title:  
Title:  The order was executed.
Title:  
Title:  "You will bring lights, and relieve the sentinel," continued
Title:  Felton.
Title:  
Title:  And this double order which the young lieutenant gave to the same
Title:  individuals proved to Milady that her servants were the same men
Title:  as her guards; that is to say, soldiers.
Title:  
Title:  Felton's orders were, for the rest, executed with a silent
Title:  rapidity that gave a good idea of the way in which he maintained
Title:  discipline.
Title:  
Title:  At length Felton, who had not yet looked at Milady, turned toward
Title:  her.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said he, "she is asleep; that's well.  When she wakes
Title:  she can sup."  And he made some steps toward the door.
Title:  
Title:  "But, my lieutenant," said a soldier, less stoical than his
Title:  chief, and who had approached Milady, "this woman is not asleep."
Title:  
Title:  "What, not asleep!" said Felton; "what is she doing, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "She has fainted.  Her face is very pale, and I have listened in
Title:  vain; I do not hear her breathe."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right," said Felton, after having looked at Milady from
Title:  the spot on which he stood without moving a step toward her. "Go
Title:  and tell Lord de Winter that his prisoner has fainted--for this
Title:  event not having been foreseen, I don't know what to do."
Title:  
Title:  The soldier went out to obey the orders of his officer.  Felton
Title:  sat down upon an armchair which happened to be near the door, and
Title:  waited without speaking a word, without making a gesture.  Milady
Title:  possessed that great art, so much studied by women, of looking
Title:  through her long eyelashes without appearing to open the lids.
Title:  She perceived Felton, who sat with his back toward her.  She
Title:  continued to look at him for nearly ten minutes, and in these ten
Title:  minutes the immovable guardian never turned round once.
Title:  
Title:  She then thought that Lord de Winter would come, and by his
Title:  presence give fresh strength to her jailer.  Her first trial was
Title:  lost; she acted like a woman who reckons up her resources.  As a
Title:  result she raised her head, opened her eyes, and sighed deeply.
Title:  
Title:  At this sigh Felton turned round.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you are awake, madame," he said; "then I have nothing more
Title:  to do here.  If you want anything you can ring."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God! how I have suffered!" said Milady, in that
Title:  harmonious voice which, like that of the ancient enchantresses,
Title:  charmed all whom she wished to destroy.
Title:  
Title:  And she assumed, upon sitting up in the armchair, a still more
Title:  graceful and abandoned position than when she reclined.
Title:  
Title:  Felton arose.
Title:  
Title:  "You will be served, thus, madame, three times a day," said he.
Title:  "In the morning at nine o'clock, in the day at one o'clock, and
Title:  in the evening at eight.  If that does not suit you, you can
Title:  point out what other hours you prefer, and in this respect your
Title:  wishes will be complied with."
Title:  
Title:  "But am I to remain always alone in this vast and dismal
Title:  chamber?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "A woman of the neighbourhood has been sent for, who will be
Title:  tomorrow at the castle, and will return as often as you desire
Title:  her presence."
Title:  
Title:  "I thank you, sir," replied the prisoner, humbly.
Title:  
Title:  Felton made a slight bow, and directed his steps toward the door.
Title:  At the moment he was about to go out, Lord de Winter appeared in
Title:  the corridor, followed by the soldier who had been sent to inform
Title:  him of the swoon of Milady.  He held a vial of salts in his hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what is it--what is going on here?" said he, in a jeering
Title:  voice, on seeing the prisoner sitting up and Felton about to go
Title:  out.  "Is this corpse come to life already?  Felton, my lad, did
Title:  you not perceive that you were taken for a novice, and that the
Title:  first act was being performed of a comedy of which we shall
Title:  doubtless have the pleasure of following out all the
Title:  developments?"
Title:  
Title:  "I thought so, my lord," said Felton; "but as the prisoner is a
Title:  woman, after all, I wish to pay her the attention that every man
Title:  of gentle birth owes to a woman, if not on her account, at least
Title:  on my own."
Title:  
Title:  Milady shuddered through her whole system.  These words of
Title:  Felton's passed like ice through her veins.
Title:  
Title:  "So," replied de Winter, laughing, "that beautiful hair so
Title:  skillfully disheveled, that white skin, and that languishing
Title:  look, have not yet seduced you, you heart of stone?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, my Lord," replied the impassive young man; "your Lordship
Title:  may be assured that it requires more than the tricks and coquetry
Title:  of a woman to corrupt me."
Title:  
Title:  "In that case, my brave lieutenant, let us leave Milady to find
Title:  out something else, and go to supper; but be easy!  She has a
Title:  fruitful imagination, and the second act of the comedy will not
Title:  delay its steps after the first."
Title:  
Title:  And at these words Lord de Winter passed his arm through that of
Title:  Felton, and led him out, laughing.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I will be a match for you!" murmured Milady, between her
Title:  teeth; "be assured of that, you poor spoiled monk, you poor
Title:  converted soldier, who has cut his uniform out of a monk's
Title:  frock!"
Title:  
Title:  "By the way," resumed de Winter, stopping at the threshold of the
Title:  door, "you must not, Milady, let this check take away your
Title:  appetite.  Taste that fowl and those fish.  On my honor, they are
Title:  not poisoned.  I have a very good cook, and he is not to be my
Title:  heir; I have full and perfect confidence in him.  Do as I do.
Title:  Adieu, dear sister, till your next swoon!"
Title:  
Title:  This was all that Milady could endure.  Her hands clutched her
Title:  armchair; she ground her teeth inwardly; her eyes followed the
Title:  motion of the door as it closed behind Lord de Winter and Felton,
Title:  and the moment she was alone a fresh fit of despair seized her.
Title:  She cast her eyes upon the table, saw the glittering of a knife,
Title:  rushed toward it and clutched it; but her disappointment was
Title:  cruel.  The blade was round, and of flexible silver.
Title:  
Title:  A burst of laughter resounded from the other side of the ill-
Title:  closed door, and the door reopened.
Title:  
Title:  "Ha, ha!" cried Lord de Winter; "ha, ha!  Don't you see, my brave
Title:  Felton; don't you see what I told you?  That knife was for you,
Title:  my lad; she would have killed you.  Observe, this is one of her
Title:  peculiarities, to get rid thus, after one fashion or another, of
Title:  all the people who bother her.  If I had listened to you, the
Title:  knife would have been pointed and of steel.  Then no more of
Title:  Felton; she would have cut your throat, and after that everybody
Title:  else's.  See, John, see how well she knows how to handle a
Title:  knife."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, Milady still held the harmless weapon in her clenched
Title:  hand; but these last words, this supreme insult, relaxed her
Title:  hands, her strength, and even her will.  The knife fell to the
Title:  ground.
Title:  
Title:  "You were right, my Lord," said Felton, with a tone of profound
Title:  disgust which sounded to the very bottom of the heart of Milady,
Title:  "you were right, my Lord, and I was wrong."
Title:  
Title:  And both again left the room.
Title:  
Title:  But this time Milady lent a more attentive ear than the first,
Title:  and she heard their steps die away in the distance of the
Title:  corridor.
Title:  
Title:  "I am lost," murmured she; "I am lost!  I am in the power of men
Title:  upon whom I can have no more influence than upon statues of
Title:  bronze or granite; they know me by heart, and are steeled against
Title:  all my weapons.  It is, however, impossible that this should end
Title:  as they have decreed!"
Title:  
Title:  In fact, as this last reflection indicated--this instinctive
Title:  return to hope--sentiments of weakness or fear did not dwell long
Title:  in her ardent spirit.  Milady sat down to table, ate from several
Title:  dishes, drank a little Spanish wine, and felt all her resolution
Title:  return.
Title:  
Title:  Before she went to bed she had pondered, analyzed, turned on all
Title:  sides, examined on all points, the words, the steps, the
Title:  gestures, the signs, and even the silence of her interlocutors;
Title:  and of this profound, skillful, and anxious study the result was
Title:  that Felton, everything considered, appeared the more vulnerable
Title:  of her two persecutors.
Title:  
Title:  One expression above all recurred to the mind of the prisoner:
Title:  "If I had listened to you," Lord de Winter had said to Felton.
Title:  
Title:  Felton, then, had spoken in her favor, since Lord de Winter had
Title:  not been willing to listen to him.
Title:  
Title:  "Weak or strong," repeated Milady, "that man has, then, a spark
Title:  of pity in his soul; of that spark I will make a flame that shall
Title:  devour him.  As to the other, he knows me, he fears me, and knows
Title:  what he has to expect of me if ever I escape from his hands.  It
Title:  is useless, then, to attempt anything with him.  But Felton--
Title:  that's another thing.  He is a young, ingenuous, pure man who
Title:  seems virtuous; him there are means of destroying."
Title:  
Title:  And Milady went to bed and fell asleep with a smile upon her
Title:  lips.  Anyone who had seen her sleeping might have said she was a
Title:  young girl dreaming of the crown of flowers she was to wear on
Title:  her brow at the next festival.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  53  CAPTIVITY:  THE SECOND DAY
Title:  
Title:  Milady dreamed that she at length had d'Artagnan in her power,
Title:  that she was present at his execution; and it was the sight of
Title:  his odious blood, flowing beneath the ax of the headsman, which
Title:  spread that charming smile upon her lips.
Title:  
Title:  She slept as a prisoner sleeps, rocked by his first hope.
Title:  
Title:  In the morning, when they entered her chamber she was still in
Title:  bed.  Felton remained in the corridor.  He brought with him the
Title:  woman of whom he had spoken the evening before, and who had just
Title:  arrived; this woman entered, and approaching Milady's bed,
Title:  offered her services.
Title:  
Title:  Milady was habitually pale; her complexion might therefore
Title:  deceive a person who saw her for the first time.
Title:  
Title:  "I am in a fever," said she; "I have not slept a single instant
Title:  during all this long night.  I suffer horribly.  Are you likely
Title:  to be more humane to me than others were yesterday?  All I ask is
Title:  permission to remain abed."
Title:  
Title:  "Would you like to have a physician called?" said the woman.
Title:  
Title:  Felton listened to this dialogue without speaking a word.
Title:  
Title:  Milady reflected that the more people she had around her the more
Title:  she would have to work upon, and Lord de Winter would redouble
Title:  his watch.  Besides, the physician might declare the ailment
Title:  feigned; and Milady, after having lost the first trick, was not
Title:  willing to lose the second.
Title:  
Title:  "Go and fetch a physician?" said she.  "What could be the good of
Title:  that?  These gentlemen declared yesterday that my illness was a
Title:  comedy; it would be just the same today, no doubt--for since
Title:  yesterday evening they have had plenty of time to send for a
Title:  doctor."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said Felton, who became impatient, "say yourself, madame,
Title:  what treatment you wish followed."
Title:  
Title:  "Eh, how can I tell?  My God!  I know that I suffer, that's all.
Title:  Give me anything you like, it is of little consequence."
Title:  
Title:  "Go and fetch Lord de Winter," said Felton, tired of these
Title:  eternal complaints.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no, no!" cried Milady; "no, sir, do not call him, I conjure
Title:  you.  I am well, I want nothing; do not call him."
Title:  
Title:  She gave so much vehemence, such magnetic eloquence to this
Title:  exclamation, that Felton in spite of himself advanced some steps
Title:  into the room.
Title:  
Title:  "He has come!" thought Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Meanwhile, madame, if you really suffer," said Felton, "a
Title:  physician shall be sent for; and if you deceive us--well, it will
Title:  be the worse for you.  But at least we shall not have to reproach
Title:  ourselves with anything."
Title:  
Title:  Milady made no reply, but turning her beautiful head round upon
Title:  her pillow, she burst into tears, and uttered heartbreaking sobs.
Title:  
Title:  Felton surveyed her for an instant with his usual impassiveness;
Title:  then, seeing that the crisis threatened to be prolonged, he went
Title:  out.  The woman followed him, and Lord de Winter did not appear.
Title:  
Title:  "I fancy I begin to see my way," murmured Milady, with a savage
Title:  joy, burying herself under the clothes to conceal from anybody
Title:  who might be watching her this burst of inward satisfaction.
Title:  
Title:  Two hours passed away.
Title:  
Title:  "Now it is time that the malady should be over," said she; "let
Title:  me rise, and obtain some success this very day.  I have but ten
Title:  days, and this evening two of them will be gone."
Title:  
Title:  In the morning, when they entered Milady's chamber they had
Title:  brought her breakfast.  Now, she thought, they could not long
Title:  delay coming to clear the table, and that Felton would then
Title:  reappear.
Title:  
Title:  Milady was not deceived.  Felton reappeared, and without
Title:  observing whether Milady had or had not touched her repast, made
Title:  a sign that the table should be carried out of the room, it
Title:  having been brought in ready spread.
Title:  
Title:  Felton remained behind; he held a book in his hand.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, reclining in an armchair near the chimney, beautiful,
Title:  pale, and resigned, looked like a holy virgin awaiting martyrdom.
Title:  
Title:  Felton approached her, and said, "Lord de Winter, who is a
Title:  Catholic, like yourself, madame, thinking that the deprivation of
Title:  the rites and ceremonies of your church might be painful to you,
Title:  has consented that you should read every day the ordinary of your
Title:  Mass; and here is a book which contains the ritual."
Title:  
Title:  At the manner in which Felton laid the book upon the little table
Title:  near which Milady was sitting, at the tone in which he pronounced
Title:  the two words, YOUR MASS, at the disdainful smile with which he
Title:  accompanied them, Milady raised her head, and looked more
Title:  attentively at the officer.
Title:  
Title:  By that plain arrangement of the hair, by that costume of extreme
Title:  simplicity, by the brow polished like marble and as hard and
Title:  impenetrable, she recognized one of those gloomy Puritans she had
Title:  so often met, not only in the court of King James, but in that of
Title:  the King of France, where, in spite of the remembrance of the St.
Title:  Bartholomew, they sometimes came to seek refuge.
Title:  
Title:  She then had one of those sudden inspirations which only people
Title:  of genius receive in great crises, in supreme moments which are
Title:  to decide their fortunes or their lives.
Title:  
Title:  Those two words, YOUR MASS, and a simple glance cast upon
Title:  Felton, revealed to her all the importance of the reply she was
Title:  about to make; but with that rapidity of intelligence which was
Title:  peculiar to her, this reply, ready arranged, presented itself to
Title:  her lips:
Title:  
Title:  "I?" said she, with an accent of disdain in unison with that
Title:  which she had remarked in the voice of the young officer, "I,
Title:  sir?  MY MASS?  Lord de Winter, the corrupted Catholic, knows
Title:  very well that I am not of his religion, and this is a snare he
Title:  wishes to lay for me!"
Title:  
Title:  "And of what religion are you, then, madame?" asked Felton, with
Title:  an astonishment which in spite of the empire he held over himself
Title:  he could not entirely conceal.
Title:  
Title:  "I will tell it," cried Milady, with a feigned exultation, "on
Title:  the day when I shall have suffered sufficiently for my faith."
Title:  
Title:  The look of Felton revealed to Milady the full extent of the
Title:  space she had opened for herself by this single word.
Title:  
Title:  The young officer, however, remained mute and motionless; his
Title:  look alone had spoken.
Title:  
Title:  "I am in the hands of my enemies," continued she, with that tone
Title:  of enthusiasm which she knew was familiar to the Puritans.
Title:  "Well, let my God save me, or let me perish for my God!  That is
Title:  the reply I beg you to make to Lord de Winter.  And as to this
Title:  book," added she, pointing to the manual with her finger but
Title:  without touching it, as if she must be contaminated by it, "you
Title:  may carry it back and make use of it yourself, for doubtless you
Title:  are doubly the accomplice of Lord de Winter--the accomplice in
Title:  his persecutions, the accomplice in his heresies."
Title:  
Title:  Felton made no reply, took the book with the same appearance of
Title:  repugnance which he had before manifested, and retired pensively.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter came toward five o'clock in the evening.  Milady
Title:  had had time, during the whole day, to trace her plan of conduct.
Title:  She received him like a woman who had already recovered all her
Title:  advantages.
Title:  
Title:  "It appears," said the baron, seating himself in the armchair
Title:  opposite that occupied by Milady, and stretching out his legs
Title:  carelessly upon the hearth, "it appears we have made a little
Title:  apostasy!"
Title:  
Title:  "What do you mean, sir!"
Title:  
Title:  "I mean to say that since we last met you have changed your
Title:  religion.  You have not by chance married a Protestant for a
Title:  third husband, have you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Explain yourself, my Lord," replied the prisoner, with majesty;
Title:  "for though I hear your words, I declare I do not understand
Title:  them."
Title:  
Title:  "Then you have no religion at all; I like that best," replied
Title:  Lord de Winter, laughing.
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly that is most in accord with your own principles,"
Title:  replied Milady, frigidly.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I confess it is all the same to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you need not avow this religious indifference, my Lord; your
Title:  debaucheries and crimes would vouch for it."
Title:  
Title:  "What, you talk of debaucheries, Madame Messalina, Lady Macbeth!
Title:  Either I misunderstand you or you are very shameless!"
Title:  
Title:  "You only speak thus because you are overheard," coolly replied
Title:  Milady; "and you wish to interest your jailers and your hangmen
Title:  against me."
Title:  
Title:  "My jailers and my hangmen!  Heyday, madame! you are taking a
Title:  poetical tone, and the comedy of yesterday turns to a tragedy
Title:  this evening.  As to the rest, in eight days you will be where
Title:  you ought to be, and my task will be completed."
Title:  
Title:  "Infamous task! impious task!" cried Milady, with the exultation
Title:  of a victim who provokes his judge.
Title:  
Title:  "My word," said de Winter, rising, "I think the hussy is going
Title:  mad!  Come, come, calm yourself, Madame Puritan, or I'll remove
Title:  you to a dungeon.  It's my Spanish wine that has got into your
Title:  head, is it not?  But never mind; that sort of intoxication is
Title:  not dangerous, and will have no bad effects."
Title:  
Title:  And Lord de Winter retired swearing, which at that period was a
Title:  very knightly habit.
Title:  
Title:  Felton was indeed behind the door, and had not lost one word of
Title:  this scene.  Milady had guessed aright.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, go, go!" said she to her brother; "the effects ARE drawing
Title:  near, on the contrary; but you, weak fool, will not see them
Title:  until it is too late to shun them."
Title:  
Title:  Silence was re-established.  Two hours passed away.  Milady's
Title:  supper was brought in, and she was found deeply engaged in saying
Title:  her prayers aloud--prayers which she had learned of an old
Title:  servant of her second husband, a most austere Puritan.  She
Title:  appeared to be in ecstasy, and did not pay the least attention to
Title:  what was going on around her. Felton made a sign that she should
Title:  not be disturbed; and when all was arranged, he went out quietly
Title:  with the soldiers.
Title:  
Title:  Milady knew she might be watched, so she continued her prayers to
Title:  the end; and it appeared to her that the soldier who was on duty
Title:  at her door did not march with the same step, and seemed to
Title:  listen.  For the moment she wished nothing better.  She arose,
Title:  came to the table, ate but little, and drank only water.
Title:  
Title:  An hour after, her table was cleared; but Milady remarked that
Title:  this time Felton did not accompany the soldiers.  He feared,
Title:  then, to see her too often.
Title:  
Title:  She turned toward the wall to smile--for there was in this smile
Title:  such an expression of triumph that this smile alone would have
Title:  betrayed her.
Title:  
Title:  She allowed, therefore, half an hour to pass away; and as at that
Title:  moment all was silence in the old castle, as nothing was heard
Title:  but the eternal murmur of the waves--that immense breaking of the
Title:  ocean--with her pure, harmonious, and powerful voice, she began
Title:  the first couplet of the psalm then in great favor with the
Title:  Puritans:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Thou leavest thy servants, Lord,
Title:  To see if they be strong;
Title:  But soon thou dost afford
Title:  Thy hand to lead them on."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  These verses were not excellent--very far from it; but as it is
Title:  well known, the Puritans did not pique themselves upon their
Title:  poetry.
Title:  
Title:  While singing, Milady listened.  The soldier on guard at her door
Title:  stopped, as if he had been changed into stone.  Milady was then
Title:  able to judge of the effect she had produced.
Title:  
Title:  Then she continued her singing with inexpressible fervor and
Title:  feeling.  It appeared to her that the sounds spread to a distance
Title:  beneath the vaulted roofs, and carried with them a magic charm to
Title:  soften the hearts of her jailers.  It however likewise appeared
Title:  that the soldier on duty--a zealous Catholic, no doubt--shook off
Title:  the charm, for through the door he called:  "Hold your tongue,
Title:  madame!  Your song is as dismal as a 'De profundis'; and if
Title:  besides the pleasure of being in garrison here, we must hear such
Title:  things as these, no mortal can hold out."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" then exclaimed another stern voice which Milady
Title:  recognized as that of Felton.  "What are you meddling with,
Title:  stupid?  Did anybody order you to prevent that woman from
Title:  singing?  No.  You were told to guard her--to fire at her if she
Title:  attempted to fly.  Guard her!  If she flies, kill her; but don't
Title:  exceed your orders."
Title:  
Title:  An expression of unspeakable joy lightened the countenance of
Title:  Milady; but this expression was fleeting as the reflection of
Title:  lightning.  Without appearing to have heard the dialogue, of
Title:  which she had not lost a word, she began again, giving to her
Title:  voice all the charm, all the power, all the seduction the demon
Title:  had bestowed upon it:
Title:  
Title:    "For all my tears, my cares,
Title:      My exile, and my chains,
Title:    I have my youth, my prayers,
Title:      And God, who counts my pains."
Title:  
Title:  Her voice, of immense power and sublime expression, gave to the
Title:  rude, unpolished poetry of these psalms a magic and an effect
Title:  which the most exalted Puritans rarely found in the songs of
Title:  their brethren, and which they were forced to ornament with all
Title:  the resources of their imagination.  Felton believed he heard the
Title:  singing of the angel who consoled the three Hebrews in the
Title:  furnace.
Title:  
Title:  Milady continued:
Title:  
Title:  "One day our doors will ope,
Title:  With God come our desire;
Title:  And if betrays that hope,
Title:  To death we can aspire."
Title:  
Title:  This verse, into which the terrible enchantress threw her whole
Title:  soul, completed the trouble which had seized the heart of the
Title:  young officer.  He opened the door quickly; and Milady saw him
Title:  appear, pale as usual, but with his eye inflamed and almost wild.
Title:  
Title:  "Why do you sing thus, and with such a voice?" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Your pardon, sir," said Milady, with mildness.  "I forgot that
Title:  my songs are out of place in this castle.  I have perhaps
Title:  offended you in your creed; but it was without wishing to do so,
Title:  I swear.  Pardon me, then, a fault which is perhaps great, but
Title:  which certainly was involuntary."
Title:  
Title:  Milady was so beautiful at this moment, the religious ecstasy in
Title:  which she appeared to be plunged gave such an expression to her
Title:  countenance, that Felton was so dazzled that he fancied he beheld
Title:  the angel whom he had only just before heard.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," said he; "you disturb, you agitate the people who
Title:  live in the castle."
Title:  
Title:  The poor, senseless young man was not aware of the incoherence of
Title:  his words, while Milady was reading with her lynx's eyes the very
Title:  depths of his heart.
Title:  
Title:  "I will be silent, then," said Milady, casting down her eyes with
Title:  all the sweetness she could give to her voice, with all the
Title:  resignation she could impress upon her manner.
Title:  
Title:  "No, no, madame," said Felton, "only do not sing so loud,
Title:  particularly at night."
Title:  
Title:  And at these words Felton, feeling that he could not long
Title:  maintain his severity toward his prisoner, rushed out of the
Title:  room.
Title:  
Title:  "You have done right, Lieutenant," said the soldier.  "Such songs
Title:  disturb the mind; and yet we become accustomed to them, her voice
Title:  is so beautiful."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  54  CAPTIVITY:  THE THIRD DAY
Title:  
Title:  Felton had fallen; but there was still another step to be taken.
Title:  He must be retained, or rather he must be left quite alone; and
Title:  Milady but obscurely perceived the means which could lead to this
Title:  result.
Title:  
Title:  Still more must be done.  He must be made to speak, in order that
Title:  he might be spoken to--for Milady very well knew that her
Title:  greatest seduction was in her voice, which so skillfully ran over
Title:  the whole gamut of tones from human speech to language celestial.
Title:  
Title:  Yet in spite of all this seduction Milady might fail--for Felton
Title:  was forewarned, and that against the least chance.  From that
Title:  moment she watched all his actions, all his words, from the
Title:  simplest glance of his eyes to his gestures--even to a breath
Title:  that could be interpreted as a sigh.  In short, she studied
Title:  everything, as a skillful comedian does to whom a new part has
Title:  been assigned in a line to which he is not accustomed.
Title:  
Title:  Face to face with Lord de Winter her plan of conduct was more
Title:  easy.  She had laid that down the preceding evening.  To remain
Title:  silent and dignified in his presence; from time to time to
Title:  irritate him by affected disdain, by a contemptuous word; to
Title:  provoke him to threats and violence which would produce a
Title:  contrast with her own resignation--such was her plan.  Felton
Title:  would see all; perhaps he would say nothing, but he would see.
Title:  
Title:  In the morning, Felton came as usual; but Milady allowed him to
Title:  preside over all the preparations for breakfast without
Title:  addressing a word to him.  At the moment when he was about to
Title:  retire, she was cheered with a ray of hope, for she thought he
Title:  was about to speak; but his lips moved without any sound leaving
Title:  his mouth, and making a powerful effort to control himself, he
Title:  sent back to his heart the words that were about to escape from
Title:  his lips, and went out.  Toward midday, Lord de Winter entered.
Title:  
Title:  It was a tolerably fine winter's day, and a ray of that pale
Title:  English sun which lights but does not warm came through the bars
Title:  of her prison.
Title:  
Title:  Milady was looking out at the window, and pretended not to hear
Title:  the door as it opened.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!" said Lord de Winter, "after having played comedy, after
Title:  having played tragedy, we are now playing melancholy?"
Title:  
Title:  The prisoner made no reply.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," continued Lord de Winter, "I understand.  You would
Title:  like very well to be at liberty on that beach!  You would like
Title:  very well to be in a good ship dancing upon the waves of that
Title:  emerald-green sea; you would like very well, either on land or on
Title:  the ocean, to lay for me one of those nice little ambuscades you
Title:  are so skillful in planning.  Patience, patience!  In four days'
Title:  time the shore will be beneath your feet, the sea will be open to
Title:  you--more open than will perhaps be agreeable to you, for in four
Title:  days England will be relieved of you."
Title:  
Title:  Milady folded her hands, and raising her fine eyes toward heaven,
Title:  "Lord, Lord," said she, with an angelic meekness of gesture and
Title:  tone, "pardon this man, as I myself pardon him."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, pray, accursed woman!" cried the baron; "your prayer is so
Title:  much the more generous from your being, I swear to you, in the
Title:  power of a man who will never pardon you!" and he went out.
Title:  
Title:  At the moment he went out a piercing glance darted through the
Title:  opening of the nearly closed door, and she perceived Felton, who
Title:  drew quickly to one side to prevent being seen by her.
Title:  
Title:  Then she threw herself upon her knees, and began to pray.
Title:  
Title:  "My God, my God!" said she, "thou knowest in what holy cause I
Title:  suffer; give me, then, strength to suffer."
Title:  
Title:  The door opened gently; the beautiful supplicant pretended not to
Title:  hear the noise, and in a voice broken by tears, she continued:
Title:  
Title:  "God of vengeance!  God of goodness! wilt thou allow the
Title:  frightful projects of this man to be accomplished?"
Title:  
Title:  Then only she pretended to hear the sound of Felton's steps, and
Title:  rising quick as thought, she blushed, as if ashamed of being
Title:  surprised on her knees.
Title:  
Title:  "I do not like to disturb those who pray, madame," said Felton,
Title:  seriously; "do not disturb yourself on my account, I beseech
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  "How do you know I was praying, sir?" said Milady, in a voice
Title:  broken by sobs.  "You were deceived, sir; I was not praying."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you think, then, madame," replied Felton, in the same serious
Title:  voice, but with a milder tone, "do you think I assume the right
Title:  of preventing a creature from prostrating herself before her
Title:  Creator?  God forbid!  Besides, repentance becomes the guilty;
Title:  whatever crimes they may have committed, for me the guilty are
Title:  sacred at the feet of God!"
Title:  
Title:  "Guilty?  I?" said Milady, with a smile which might have disarmed
Title:  the angel of the last judgment.  "Guilty?  Oh, my God, thou
Title:  knowest whether I am guilty!  Say I am condemned, sir, if you
Title:  please; but you know that God, who loves martyrs, sometimes
Title:  permits the innocent to be condemned."
Title:  
Title:  "Were you condemned, were you innocent, were you a martyr,"
Title:  replied Felton, "the greater would be the necessity for prayer;
Title:  and I myself would aid you with my prayers."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you are a just man!" cried Milady, throwing herself at his
Title:  feet.  "I can hold out no longer, for I fear I shall be wanting
Title:  in strength at the moment when I shall be forced to undergo the
Title:  struggle, and confess my faith.  Listen, then, to the
Title:  supplication of a despairing woman.  You are abused, sir; but
Title:  that is not the question.  I only ask you one favor; and if you
Title:  grant it me, I will bless you in this world and in the next."
Title:  
Title:  "Speak to the master, madame," said Felton; "happily I am neither
Title:  charged with the power of pardoning nor punishing.  It is upon
Title:  one higher placed than I am that God has laid this
Title:  responsibility."
Title:  
Title:  "To you--no, to you alone!  Listen to me, rather than add to my
Title:  destruction, rather than add to my ignominy!"
Title:  
Title:  "If you have merited this shame, madame, if you have incurred
Title:  this ignominy, you must submit to it as an offering to God."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you say?  Oh, you do not understand me!  When I speak of
Title:  ignominy, you think I speak of some chastisement, of imprisonment
Title:  or death.  Would to heaven!  Of what consequence to me is
Title:  imprisonment or death?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is I who no longer understand you, madame," said Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Or, rather, who pretend not to understand me, sir!" replied the
Title:  prisoner, with a smile of incredulity.
Title:  
Title:  "No, madame, on the honor of a soldier, on the faith of a
Title:  Christian."
Title:  
Title:  "What, you are ignorant of Lord de Winter's designs upon me?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am."
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible; you are his confidant!"
Title:  
Title:  "I never lie, madame."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, he conceals them too little for you not to divine them."
Title:  
Title:  "I seek to divine nothing, madame; I wait till I am confided in,
Title:  and apart from that which Lord de Winter has said to me before
Title:  you, he has confided nothing to me."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, then," cried Milady, with an incredible tone of
Title:  truthfulness, "you are not his accomplice; you do not know that
Title:  he destines me to a disgrace which all the punishments of the
Title:  world cannot equal in horror?"
Title:  
Title:  "You are deceived, madame," said Felton, blushing; "Lord de
Title:  Winter is not capable of such a crime."
Title:  
Title:  "Good," said Milady to herself; "without thinking what it is, he
Title:  calls it a crime!"  Then aloud, "The friend of THAT WRETCH is
Title:  capable of everything."
Title:  
Title:  "Whom do you call 'that wretch'?" asked Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Are there, then, in England two men to whom such an epithet can
Title:  be applied?"
Title:  
Title:  "You mean George Villiers?" asked Felton, whose looks became
Title:  excited.
Title:  
Title:  "Whom Pagans and unbelieving Gentiles call Duke of Buckingham,"
Title:  replied Milady.  "I could not have thought that there was an
Title:  Englishman in all England who would have required so long an
Title:  explanation to make him understand of whom I was speaking."
Title:  
Title:  "The hand of the Lord is stretched over him," said Felton; "he
Title:  will not escape the chastisement he deserves."
Title:  
Title:  Felton only expressed, with regard to the duke, the feeling of
Title:  execration which all the English had declared toward him whom the
Title:  Catholics themselves called the extortioner, the pillager, the
Title:  debauchee, and whom the Puritans styled simply Satan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God!" cried Milady; "when I supplicate thee to
Title:  pour upon this man the chastisement which is his due, thou
Title:  knowest it is not my own vengeance I pursue, but the deliverance
Title:  of a whole nation that I implore!"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know him, then?" asked Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "At length he interrogates me!" said Milady to herself, at the
Title:  height of joy at having obtained so quickly such a great result.
Title:  "Oh, know him?  Yes, yes! to my misfortune, to my eternal
Title:  misfortune!" and Milady twisted her arms as if in a paroxysm of
Title:  grief.
Title:  
Title:  Felton no doubt felt within himself that his strength was
Title:  abandoning him, and he made several steps toward the door; but
Title:  the prisoner, whose eye never left him, sprang in pursuit of him
Title:  and stopped him.
Title:  
Title:  "Sir," cried she, "be kind, be clement, listen to my prayer!
Title:  That knife, which the fatal prudence of the baron deprived me of,
Title:  because he knows the use I would make of it!  Oh, hear me to the
Title:  end! that knife, give it to me for a minute only, for mercy's,
Title:  for pity's sake!  I will embrace your knees!  You shall shut the
Title:  door that you may be certain I contemplate no injury to you!  My
Title:  God! to you--the only just, good, and compassionate being I have
Title:  met with!  To you--my preserver, perhaps!  One minute that knife,
Title:  one minute, a single minute, and I will restore it to you through
Title:  the grating of the door.  Only one minute, Mr. Felton, and you
Title:  will have saved my honor!"
Title:  
Title:  "To kill yourself?" cried Felton, with terror, forgetting to
Title:  withdraw his hands from the hands of the prisoner, "to kill
Title:  yourself?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have told, sir," murmured Milady, lowering her voice, and
Title:  allowing herself to sink overpowered to the ground; "I have told
Title:  my secret!  He knows all!  My God, I am lost!"
Title:  
Title:  Felton remained standing, motionless and undecided.
Title:  
Title:  "He still doubts," thought Milady; "I have not been earnest
Title:  enough."
Title:  
Title:  Someone was heard in the corridor; Milady recognized the step of
Title:  Lord de Winter.
Title:  
Title:  Felton recognized it also, and made a step toward the door.
Title:  
Title:  Milady sprang toward him.  "Oh, not a word," said she in a
Title:  concentrated voice, "not a word of all that I have said to you to
Title:  this man, or I am lost, and it would be you--you--"
Title:  
Title:  Then as the steps drew near, she became silent for fear of being
Title:  heard, applying, with a gesture of infinite terror, her beautiful
Title:  hand to Felton's mouth.
Title:  
Title:  Felton gently repulsed Milady, and she sank into a chair.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter passed before the door without stopping, and they
Title:  heard the noise of his footsteps soon die away.
Title:  
Title:  Felton, as pale as death, remained some instants with his ear
Title:  bent and listening; then, when the sound was quite extinct, he
Title:  breathed like a man awaking from a dream, and rushed out of the
Title:  apartment.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah!" said Milady, listening in her turn to the noise of Felton's
Title:  steps, which withdrew in a direction opposite to those of Lord de
Title:  Winter; "at length you are mine!"
Title:  
Title:  Then her brow darkened.  "If he tells the baron," said she, "I am
Title:  lost--for the baron, who knows very well that I shall not kill
Title:  myself, will place me before him with a knife in my hand, and he
Title:  will discover that all this despair is but acted."
Title:  
Title:  She placed herself before the glass, and regarded herself
Title:  attentively; never had she appeared more beautiful.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes," said she, smiling, "but we won't tell him!"
Title:  
Title:  In the evening Lord de Winter accompanied the supper.
Title:  
Title:  "Sir," said Milady, "is your presence an indispensable accessory
Title:  of my captivity?  Could you not spare me the increase of torture
Title:  which your visits cause me?"
Title:  
Title:  "How, dear sister!" said Lord de Winter.  "Did not you
Title:  sentimentally inform me with that pretty mouth of yours, so cruel
Title:  to me today, that you came to England solely for the pleasure of
Title:  seeing me at your ease, an enjoyment of which you told me you so
Title:  sensibly felt the deprivation that you had risked everything for
Title:  it--seasickness, tempest, captivity?  Well, here I am; be
Title:  satisfied.  Besides, this time, my visit has a motive."
Title:  
Title:  Milady trembled; she thought Felton had told all.  Perhaps never
Title:  in her life had this woman, who had experienced so many opposite
Title:  and powerful emotions, felt her heart beat so violently.
Title:  
Title:  She was seated.  Lord de Winter took a chair, drew it toward her,
Title:  and sat down close beside her.  Then taking a paper out of his
Title:  pocket, he unfolded it slowly.
Title:  
Title:  "Here," said he, "I want to show you the kind of passport which I
Title:  have drawn up, and which will serve you henceforward as the rule
Title:  of order in the life I consent to leave you."
Title:  
Title:  Then turning his eyes from Milady to the paper, he read: "'Order
Title:  to conduct--'  The name is blank," interrupted Lord de Winter.
Title:  "If you have any preference you can point it out to me; and if it
Title:  be not within a thousand leagues of London, attention will be
Title:  paid to your wishes.  I will begin again, then:
Title:  
Title:  "'Order to conduct to--the person named Charlotte Backson,
Title:  branded by the justice of the kingdom of France, but liberated
Title:  after chastisement.  She is to dwell in this place without ever
Title:  going more than three leagues from it.  In case of any attempt to
Title:  escape, the penalty of death is to be applied.  She will receive
Title:  five shillings per day for lodging and food'".
Title:  
Title:  "That order does not concern me," replied Milady, coldly, "since
Title:  it bears another name than mine."
Title:  
Title:  "A name?  Have you a name, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "I bear that of your brother."
Title:  
Title:  "Ay, but you are mistaken.  My brother is only your second
Title:  husband; and your first is still living.  Tell me his name, and I
Title:  will put it in the place of the name of Charlotte Backson.  No?
Title:  You will not?  You are silent?  Well, then you must be registered
Title:  as Charlotte Backson."
Title:  
Title:  Milady remained silent; only this time it was no longer from
Title:  affectation, but from terror.  She believed the order ready for
Title:  execution.  She thought that Lord de Winter had hastened her
Title:  departure; she thought she was condemned to set off that very
Title:  evening.  Everything in her mind was lost for an instant; when
Title:  all at once she perceived that no signature was attached to the
Title:  order.  The joy she felt at this discovery was so great she could
Title:  not conceal it.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," said Lord de Winter, who perceived what was passing
Title:  in her mind; "yes, you look for the signature, and you say to
Title:  yourself:  'All is not lost, for that order is not signed.  It is
Title:  only shown to me to terrify me, that's all.'  You are mistaken.
Title:  Tomorrow this order will be sent to the Duke of Buckingham.  The
Title:  day after tomorrow it will return signed by his hand and marked
Title:  with his seal; and four-and-twenty hours afterward I will answer
Title:  for its being carried into execution.  Adieu, madame.  That is
Title:  all I had to say to you."
Title:  
Title:  "And I reply to you, sir, that this abuse of power, this exile
Title:  under a fictitious name, are infamous!"
Title:  
Title:  "Would you like better to be hanged in your true name, Milady?
Title:  You know that the English laws are inexorable on the abuse of
Title:  marriage.  Speak freely.  Although my name, or rather that of my
Title:  brother, would be mixed up with the affair, I will risk the
Title:  scandal of a public trial to make myself certain of getting rid
Title:  of you."
Title:  
Title:  Milady made no reply, but became as pale as a corpse.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I see you prefer peregrination.  That's well madame; and
Title:  there is an old proverb that says, 'Traveling trains youth.'  My
Title:  faith! you are not wrong after all, and life is sweet.  That's
Title:  the reason why I take such care you shall not deprive me of mine.
Title:  There only remains, then, the question of the five shillings to
Title:  be settled.  You think me rather parsimonious, don't you?  That's
Title:  because I don't care to leave you the means of corrupting your
Title:  jailers.  Besides, you will always have your charms left to
Title:  seduce them with.  Employ them, if your check with regard to
Title:  Felton has not disgusted you with attempts of that kind."
Title:  
Title:  "Felton has not told him," said Milady to herself.  "Nothing is
Title:  lost, then."
Title:  
Title:  "And now, madame, till I see you again!  Tomorrow I will come and
Title:  announce to you the departure of my messenger."
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter rose, saluted her ironically, and went out.
Title:  
Title:  Milady breathed again.  She had still four days before her.  Four
Title:  days would quite suffice to complete the seduction of Felton.
Title:  
Title:  A terrible idea, however, rushed into her mind.  She thought that
Title:  Lord de Winter would perhaps send Felton himself to get the order
Title:  signed by the Duke of Buckingham.  In that case Felton would
Title:  escape her--for in order to secure success, the magic of a
Title:  continuous seduction was necessary.  Nevertheless, as we have
Title:  said, one circumstance reassured her.  Felton had not spoken.
Title:  
Title:  As she would not appear to be agitated by the threats of Lord de
Title:  Winter, she placed herself at the table and ate.
Title:  
Title:  Then, as she had done the evening before, she fell on her knees
Title:  and repeated her prayers aloud.  As on the evening before, the
Title:  soldier stopped his march to listen to her.
Title:  
Title:  Soon after she heard lighter steps than those of the sentinel,
Title:  which came from the end of the corridor and stopped before her
Title:  door.
Title:  
Title:  "It is he," said she.  And she began the same religious chant
Title:  which had so strongly excited Felton the evening before.
Title:  
Title:  But although her voice--sweet, full, and sonorous--vibrated as
Title:  harmoniously and as affectingly as ever, the door remained shut.
Title:  It appeared however to Milady that in one of the furtive glances
Title:  she darted from time to time at the grating of the door she
Title:  thought she saw the ardent eyes of the young man through the
Title:  narrow opening.  But whether this was reality or vision, he had
Title:  this time sufficient self-command not to enter.
Title:  
Title:  However, a few instants after she had finished her religious
Title:  song, Milady thought she heard a profound sigh.  Then the same
Title:  steps she had heard approach slowly withdrew, as if with regret.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  55  CAPTIVITY:  THE FOURTH DAY
Title:  
Title:  The next day, when Felton entered Milady's apartment he found her
Title:  standing, mounted upon a chair, holding in her hands a cord made
Title:  by means of torn cambric handkerchiefs, twisted into a kind of
Title:  rope one with another, and tied at the ends.  At the noise Felton
Title:  made in entering, Milady leaped lightly to the ground, and tried
Title:  to conceal behind her the improvised cord she held in her hand.
Title:  
Title:  The young man was more pale than usual, and his eyes, reddened by
Title:  want of sleep, denoted that he had passed a feverish night.
Title:  Nevertheless, his brow was armed with a severity more austere
Title:  than ever.
Title:  
Title:  He advanced slowly toward Milady, who had seated herself, and
Title:  taking an end of the murderous rope which by neglect, or perhaps
Title:  by design, she allowed to be seen, "What is this, madame?" he
Title:  asked coldly.
Title:  
Title:  "That?  Nothing," said Milady, smiling with that painful
Title:  expression which she knew so well how to give to her smile.
Title:  "Ennui is the mortal enemy of prisoners; I had ennui, and I
Title:  amused myself with twisting that rope."
Title:  
Title:  Felton turned his eyes toward the part of the wall of the
Title:  apartment before which he had found Milady standing in the
Title:  armchair in which she was now seated, and over her head he
Title:  perceived a gilt-headed screw, fixed in the wall for the purpose
Title:  of hanging up clothes or weapons.
Title:  
Title:  He started, and the prisoner saw that start--for though her eyes
Title:  were cast down, nothing escaped her.
Title:  
Title:  "What were you doing on that armchair?" asked he.
Title:  
Title:  "Of what consequence?" replied Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "But," replied Felton, "I wish to know."
Title:  
Title:  "Do not question me," said the prisoner; "you know that we who
Title:  are true Christians are forbidden to lie."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," said Felton, "I will tell you what you were doing,
Title:  or rather what you meant to do; you were going to complete the
Title:  fatal project you cherish in your mind.  Remember, madame, if our
Title:  God forbids falsehood, he much more severely condemns suicide."
Title:  
Title:  "When God sees one of his creatures persecuted unjustly, placed
Title:  between suicide and dishonor, believe me, sir," replied Milady,
Title:  in a tone of deep conviction, "God pardons suicide, for then
Title:  suicide becomes martyrdom."
Title:  
Title:  "You say either too much or too little; speak, madame.  In the
Title:  name of heaven, explain yourself."
Title:  
Title:  "That I may relate my misfortunes for you to treat them as
Title:  fables; that I may tell you my projects for you to go and betray
Title:  them to my persecutor?  No, sir.  Besides, of what importance to
Title:  you is the life or death of a condemned wretch?  You are only
Title:  responsible for my body, is it not so?  And provided you produce
Title:  a carcass that may be recognized as mine, they will require no
Title:  more of you; nay, perhaps you will even have a double reward."
Title:
