Title:  "I, madame, I?" cried Felton.  "You suppose that I would ever
Title:  accept the price of your life?  Oh, you cannot believe what you
Title:  say!"
Title:  
Title:  "Let me act as I please, Felton, let me act as I please," said
Title:  Milady, elated.  "Every soldier must be ambitious, must he not?
Title:  You are a lieutenant?  Well, you will follow me to the grave with
Title:  the rank of captain."
Title:  
Title:  "What have I, then, done to you," said Felton, much agitated,
Title:  "that you should load me with such a responsibility before God
Title:  and before men?  In a few days you will be away from this place;
Title:  your life, madame, will then no longer be under my care, and,"
Title:  added he, with a sigh, "then you can do what you will with it."
Title:  
Title:  "So," cried Milady, as if she could not resist giving utterance
Title:  to a holy indignation, "you, a pious man, you who are called a
Title:  just man, you ask but one thing--and that is that you may not be
Title:  inculpated, annoyed, by my death!"
Title:  
Title:  "It is my duty to watch over your life, madame, and I will
Title:  watch."
Title:  
Title:  "But do you understand the mission you are fulfilling?  Cruel
Title:  enough, if I am guilty; but what name can you give it, what name
Title:  will the Lord give it, if I am innocent?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am a soldier, madame, and fulfill the orders I have received."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you believe, then, that at the day of the Last Judgment God
Title:  will separate blind executioners from iniquitous judges?  You are
Title:  not willing that I should kill my body, and you make yourself the
Title:  agent of him who would kill my soul."
Title:  
Title:  "But I repeat it again to you," replied Felton, in great emotion,
Title:  "no danger threatens you; I will answer for Lord de Winter as for
Title:  myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Dunce," cried Milady, "dunce! who dares to answer for another
Title:  man, when the wisest, when those most after God's own heart,
Title:  hesitate to answer for themselves, and who ranges himself on the
Title:  side of the strongest and the most fortunate, to crush the
Title:  weakest and the most unfortunate."
Title:  
Title:  "Impossible, madame, impossible," murmured Felton, who felt to
Title:  the bottom of his heart the justness of this argument.  "A
Title:  prisoner, you will not recover your liberty through me; living,
Title:  you will not lose your life through me."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," cried Milady, "but I shall lose that which is much dearer
Title:  to me than life, I shall lose my honor, Felton; and it is you,
Title:  you whom I make responsible, before God and before men, for my
Title:  shame and my infamy."
Title:  
Title:  This time Felton, immovable as he was, or appeared to be, could
Title:  not resist the secret influence which had already taken
Title:  possession of him.  To see this woman, so beautiful, fair as the
Title:  brightest vision, to see her by turns overcome with grief and
Title:  threatening; to resist at once the ascendancy of grief and
Title:  beauty--it was too much for a visionary; it was too much for a
Title:  brain weakened by the ardent dreams of an ecstatic faith; it was
Title:  too much for a heart furrowed by the love of heaven that burns,
Title:  by the hatred of men that devours.
Title:  
Title:  Milady saw the trouble.  She felt by intuition the flame of the
Title:  opposing passions which burned with the blood in the veins of the
Title:  young fanatic.  As a skillful general, seeing the enemy ready to
Title:  surrender, marches toward him with a cry of victory, she rose,
Title:  beautiful as an antique priestess, inspired like a Christian
Title:  virgin, her arms extended, her throat uncovered, her hair
Title:  disheveled, holding with one hand her robe modestly drawn over
Title:  her breast, her look illumined by that fire which had already
Title:  created such disorder in the veins of the young Puritan, and went
Title:  toward him, crying out with a vehement air, and in her melodious
Title:  voice, to which on this occasion she communicated a terrible
Title:  energy:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Let this victim to Baal be sent,
Title:  To the lions the martyr be thrown!
Title:  Thy God shall teach thee to repent!
Title:  From th' abyss he'll give ear to my moan."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Felton stood before this strange apparition like one petrified.
Title:  
Title:  "Who art thou?  Who art thou?" cried he, clasping his hands.
Title:  "Art thou a messenger from God; art thou a minister from hell;
Title:  art thou an angel or a demon; callest thou thyself Eloa or
Title:  Astarte?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you not know me, Felton?  I am neither an angel nor a demon;
Title:  I am a daughter of earth, I am a sister of thy faith, that is
Title:  all."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes!" said Felton, "I doubted, but now I believe."
Title:  
Title:  "You believe, and still you are an accomplice of that child of
Title:  Belial who is called Lord de Winter!  You believe, and yet you
Title:  leave me in the hands of mine enemies, of the enemy of England,
Title:  of the enemy of God!  You believe, and yet you deliver me up to
Title:  him who fills and defiles the world with his heresies and
Title:  debaucheries--to that infamous Sardanapalus whom the blind call
Title:  the Duke of Buckingham, and whom believers name Antichrist!"
Title:  
Title:  "I deliver you up to Buckingham?  I? what mean you by that?"
Title:  
Title:  "They have eyes," cried Milady, "but they see not; ears have
Title:  they, but they hear not."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes!" said Felton, passing his hands over his brow, covered
Title:  with sweat, as if to remove his last doubt.  "Yes, I recognize
Title:  the voice which speaks to me in my dreams; yes, I recognize the
Title:  features of the angel who appears to me every night, crying to my
Title:  soul, which cannot sleep: 'Strike, save England, save thyself--
Title:  for thou wilt die without having appeased God!' Speak, speak!"
Title:  cried Felton, "I can understand you now."
Title:  
Title:  A flash of terrible joy, but rapid as thought, gleamed from the
Title:  eyes of Milady.
Title:  
Title:  However fugitive this homicide flash, Felton saw it, and started
Title:  as if its light had revealed the abysses of this woman's heart.
Title:  He recalled, all at once, the warnings of Lord de Winter, the
Title:  seductions of Milady, her first attempts after her arrival.  He
Title:  drew back a step, and hung down his head, without, however,
Title:  ceasing to look at her, as if, fascinated by this strange
Title:  creature, he could not detach his eyes from her eyes.
Title:  
Title:  Milady was not a woman to misunderstand the meaning of this
Title:  hesitation.  Under her apparent emotions her icy coolness never
Title:  abandoned her.  Before Felton replied, and before she should be
Title:  forced to resume this conversation, so difficult to be sustained
Title:  in the same exalted tone, she let her hands fall; and as if the
Title:  weakness of the woman overpowered the enthusiasm of the inspired
Title:  fanatic, she said:  "But no, it is not for me to be the Judith to
Title:  deliver Bethulia from this Holofernes.  The sword of the eternal
Title:  is too heavy for my arm.  Allow me, then, to avoid dishonor by
Title:  death; let me take refuge in martyrdom.  I do not ask you for
Title:  liberty, as a guilty one would, nor for vengeance, as would a
Title:  pagan.  Let me die; that is all.  I supplicate you, I implore you
Title:  on my knees--let me die, and my last sigh shall be a blessing for
Title:  my preserver."
Title:  
Title:  Hearing that voice, so sweet and suppliant, seeing that look, so
Title:  timid and downcast, Felton reproached himself.  By degrees the
Title:  enchantress had clothed herself with that magic adornment which
Title:  she assumed and threw aside at will; that is to say, beauty,
Title:  meekness, and tears--and above all, the irresistible attraction
Title:  of mystical voluptuousness, the most devouring of all
Title:  voluptuousness.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!" said Felton, "I can do but one thing, which is to pity
Title:  you if you prove to me you are a victim!  But Lord de Winter
Title:  makes cruel accusations against you.  You are a Christian; you
Title:  are my sister in religion.  I feel myself drawn toward you--I,
Title:  who have never loved anyone but my benefactor--I who have met
Title:  with nothing but traitors and impious men.  But you, madame, so
Title:  beautiful in reality, you, so pure in appearance, must have
Title:  committed great iniquities for Lord de Winter to pursue you
Title:  thus."
Title:  
Title:  "They have eyes," repeated Milady, with an accent of
Title:  indescribable grief, "but they see not; ears have they, but they
Title:  hear not."
Title:  
Title:  "But," cried the young officer, "speak, then, speak!"
Title:  
Title:  "Confide my shame to you," cried Milady, with the blush of
Title:  modesty upon her countenance, "for often the crime of one becomes
Title:  the shame of another--confide my shame to you, a man, and I a
Title:  woman?  Oh," continued she, placing her hand modestly over her
Title:  beautiful eyes, "never! never!--I could not!"
Title:  
Title:  "To me, to a brother?" said Felton.
Title:  
Title:  Milady looked at him for some time with an expression which the
Title:  young man took for doubt, but which, however, was nothing but
Title:  observation, or rather the wish to fascinate.
Title:  
Title:  Felton, in his turn a suppliant, clasped his hands.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then," said Milady, "I confide in my brother; I will dare
Title:  to--"
Title:  
Title:  At this moment the steps of Lord de Winter were heard; but this
Title:  time the terrible brother-in-law of Milady did not content
Title:  himself, as on the preceding day, with passing before the door
Title:  and going away again.  He paused, exchanged two words with the
Title:  sentinel; then the door opened, and he appeared.
Title:  
Title:  During the exchange of these two words Felton drew back quickly,
Title:  and when Lord de Winter entered, he was several paces from the
Title:  prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  The baron entered slowly, sending a scrutinizing glance from
Title:  Milady to the young officer.
Title:  
Title:  "You have been here a very long time, John," said he.  "Has this
Title:  woman been relating her crimes to you?  In that case I can
Title:  comprehend the length of the conversation."
Title:  
Title:  Felton started; and Milady felt she was lost if she did not come
Title:  to the assistance of the disconcerted Puritan.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you fear your prisoner should escape!" said she. "Well, ask
Title:  your worthy jailer what favor I this instant solicited of him."
Title:  
Title:  "You demanded a favor?" said the baron, suspiciously.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, my Lord," replied the young man, confused.
Title:  
Title:  "And what favor, pray?" asked Lord de Winter.
Title:  
Title:  "A knife, which she would return to me through the grating of the
Title:  door a minute after she had received it," replied Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "There is someone, then, concealed here whose throat this amiable
Title:  lady is desirous of cutting," said de Winter, in an ironical,
Title:  contemptuous tone.
Title:  
Title:  "There is myself," replied Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "I have given you the choice between America and Tyburn," replied
Title:  Lord de Winter.  "Choose Tyburn, madame.  Believe me, the cord is
Title:  more certain than the knife."
Title:  
Title:  Felton grew pale, and made a step forward, remembering that at
Title:  the moment he entered Milady had a rope in her hand.
Title:  
Title:  "You are right," said she, "I have often thought of it."  Then
Title:  she added in a low voice, "And I will think of it again."
Title:  
Title:  Felton felt a shudder run to the marrow of his bones; probably
Title:  Lord de Winter perceived this emotion.
Title:  
Title:  "Mistrust yourself, John," said he.  "I have placed reliance upon
Title:  you, my friend.  Beware!  I have warned you!  But be of good
Title:  courage, my lad; in three days we shall be delivered from this
Title:  creature, and where I shall send her she can harm nobody."
Title:  
Title:  "You hear him!" cried Milady, with vehemence, so that the baron
Title:  might believe she was addressing heaven, and that Felton might
Title:  understand she was addressing him.
Title:  
Title:  Felton lowered his head and reflected.
Title:  
Title:  The baron took the young officer by the arm, and turned his head
Title:  over his shoulder, so as not to lose sight of Milady till he was
Title:  gone out.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said the prisoner, when the door was shut, "I am not so
Title:  far advanced as I believed.  De Winter has changed his usual
Title:  stupidity into a strange prudence.  It is the desire of
Title:  vengeance, and how desire molds a man!  As to Felton, he
Title:  hesitates.  Ah, he is not a man like that cursed d'Artagnan.  A
Title:  Puritan only adores virgins, and he adores them by clasping his
Title:  hands.  A Musketeer loves women, and he loves them by clasping
Title:  his arms round them."
Title:  
Title:  Milady waited, then, with much impatience, for she feared the day
Title:  would pass away without her seeing Felton again.  At last, in an
Title:  hour after the scene we have just described, she heard someone
Title:  speaking in a low voice at the door.  Presently the door opened,
Title:  and she perceived Felton.
Title:  
Title:  The young man advanced rapidly into the chamber, leaving the door
Title:  open behind him, and making a sign to Milady to be silent; his
Title:  face was much agitated.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you want with me?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen," replied Felton, in a low voice.  "I have just sent away
Title:  the sentinel that I might remain here without anybody knowing it,
Title:  in order to speak to you without being overheard.  The baron has
Title:  just related a frightful story to me."
Title:  
Title:  Milady assumed her smile of a resigned victim, and shook her
Title:  head.
Title:  
Title:  "Either you are a demon," continued Felton, "or the baron--my
Title:  benefactor, my father--is a monster.  I have known you four days;
Title:  I have loved him four years.  I therefore may hesitate between
Title:  you.  Be not alarmed at what I say; I want to be convinced.
Title:  Tonight, after twelve, I will come and see you, and you shall
Title:  convince me."
Title:  
Title:  "No, Felton, no, my brother," said she; "the sacrifice is too
Title:  great, and I feel what it must cost you.  No, I am lost; do not
Title:  be lost with me.  My death will be much more eloquent than my
Title:  life, and the silence of the corpse will convince you much better
Title:  than the words of the prisoner."
Title:  
Title:  "Be silent, madame," cried Felton, "and do not speak to me thus;
Title:  I came to entreat you to promise me upon your honor, to swear to
Title:  me by what you hold most sacred, that you will make no attempt
Title:  upon your life."
Title:  
Title:  "I will not promise," said Milady, "for no one has more respect
Title:  for a promise or an oath than I have; and if I make a promise I
Title:  must keep it."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Felton, "only promise till you have seen me again.
Title:  If, when you have seen me again, you still persist--well, then
Title:  you shall be free, and I myself will give you the weapon you
Title:  desire."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Milady, "for you I will wait."
Title:  
Title:  "Swear."
Title:  
Title:  "I swear it, by our God.  Are you satisfied?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Felton, "till tonight."
Title:  
Title:  And he darted out of the room, shut the door, and waited in the
Title:  corridor, the soldier's half-pike in his hand, and as if he had
Title:  mounted guard in his place.
Title:  
Title:  The soldier returned, and Felton gave him back his weapon.
Title:  
Title:  Then, through the grating to which she had drawn near, Milady saw
Title:  the young man make a sign with delirious fervor, and depart in an
Title:  apparent transport of joy.
Title:  
Title:  As for her, she returned to her place with a smile of savage
Title:  contempt upon her lips, and repeated, blaspheming, that terrible
Title:  name of God, by whom she had just sworn without ever having
Title:  learned to know Him.
Title:  
Title:  "My God," said she, "what a senseless fanatic!  My God, it is I--
Title:  I--and this fellow who will help me to avenge myself."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  56  CAPTIVITY:  THE FIFTH DAY
Title:  
Title:  Milady had however achieved a half-triumph, and success doubled
Title:  her forces.
Title:  
Title:  It was not difficult to conquer, as she had hitherto done, men
Title:  prompt to let themselves be seduced, and whom the gallant
Title:  education of a court led quickly into her net.  Milady was
Title:  handsome enough not to find much resistance on the part of the
Title:  flesh, and she was sufficiently skillful to prevail over all the
Title:  obstacles of the mind.
Title:  
Title:  But this time she had to contend with an unpolished nature,
Title:  concentrated and insensible by force of austerity.  Religion and
Title:  its observances had made Felton a man inaccessible to ordinary
Title:  seductions.  There fermented in that sublimated brain plans so
Title:  vast, projects so tumultuous, that there remained no room for any
Title:  capricious or material love--that sentiment which is fed by
Title:  leisure and grows with corruption.  Milady had, then, made a
Title:  breach by her false virtue in the opinion of a man horribly
Title:  prejudiced against her, and by her beauty in the heart of a man
Title:  hitherto chaste and pure.  In short, she had taken the
Title:  measure of motives hitherto unknown to herself, through this
Title:  experiment, made upon the most rebellious subject that nature and
Title:  religion could submit to her study.
Title:  
Title:  Many a time, nevertheless, during the evening she despaired of
Title:  fate and of herself.  She did not invoke God, we very well know,
Title:  but she had faith in the genius of evil--that immense sovereignty
Title:  which reigns in all the details of human life, and by which, as
Title:  in the Arabian fable, a single pomegranate seed is sufficient to
Title:  reconstruct a ruined world.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, being well prepared for the reception of Felton, was able
Title:  to erect her batteries for the next day.  She knew she had only
Title:  two days left; that when once the order was signed by Buckingham--
Title:  and Buckingham would sign it the more readily from its bearing a
Title:  false name, and he could not, therefore, recognize the woman in
Title:  question--once this order was signed, we say, the baron would
Title:  make her embark immediately, and she knew very well that women
Title:  condemned to exile employ arms much less powerful in their
Title:  seductions than the pretendedly virtuous woman whose beauty is
Title:  lighted by the sun of the world, whose style the voice of fashion
Title:  lauds, and whom a halo of aristocracy gilds with enchanting
Title:  splendors.  To be a woman condemned to a painful and disgraceful
Title:  punishment is no impediment to beauty, but it is an obstacle to
Title:  the recovery of power.  Like all persons of real genius, Milady
Title:  knew what suited her nature and her means.  Poverty was repugnant
Title:  to her; degradation took away two-thirds of her greatness.
Title:  Milady was only a queen while among queens.  The pleasure of
Title:  satisfied pride was necessary to her domination.  To command
Title:  inferior beings was rather a humiliation than a pleasure for her.
Title:  
Title:  She should certainly return from her exile--she did not doubt
Title:  that a single instant; but how long might this exile last?  For
Title:  an active, ambitious nature, like that of Milady, days not spent
Title:  in climbing are inauspicious days.  What word, then, can be found
Title:  to describe the days which they occupy in descending?  To lose a
Title:  year, two years, three years, is to talk of an eternity; to
Title:  return after the death or disgrace of the cardinal, perhaps; to
Title:  return when d'Artagnan and his friends, happy and triumphant,
Title:  should have received from the queen the reward they had well
Title:  acquired by the services they had rendered her--these were
Title:  devouring ideas that a woman like Milady could not endure.  For
Title:  the rest, the storm which raged within her doubled her strength,
Title:  and she would have burst the walls of her prison if her body had
Title:  been able to take for a single instant the proportions of her
Title:  mind.
Title:  
Title:  Then that which spurred her on additionally in the midst of all
Title:  this was the remembrance of the cardinal.  What must the
Title:  mistrustful, restless, suspicious cardinal think of her silence--
Title:  the cardinal, not merely her only support, her only prop, her
Title:  only protector at present, but still further, the principal
Title:  instrument of her future fortune and vengeance?  She knew him;
Title:  she knew that at her return from a fruitless journey it would be
Title:  in vain to tell him of her imprisonment, in vain to enlarge upon
Title:  the sufferings she had undergone.  The cardinal would reply, with
Title:  the sarcastic calmness of the skeptic, strong at once by power
Title:  and genius, "You should not have allowed yourself to be taken."
Title:  
Title:  Then Milady collected all her energies, murmuring in the depths
Title:  of her soul the name of Felton--the only beam of light that
Title:  penetrated to her in the hell into which she had fallen; and like
Title:  a serpent which folds and unfolds its rings to ascertain its
Title:  strength, she enveloped Felton beforehand in the thousand meshes
Title:  of her inventive imagination.
Title:  
Title:  Time, however, passed away; the hours, one after another, seemed
Title:  to awaken the clock as they passed, and every blow of the brass
Title:  hammer resounded upon the heart of the prisoner.  At nine
Title:  o'clock, Lord de Winter made his customary visit, examined the
Title:  window and the bars, sounded the floor and the walls, looked to
Title:  the chimney and the doors, without, during this long and minute
Title:  examination, he or Milady pronouncing a single word.
Title:  
Title:  Doubtless both of them understood that the situation had become
Title:  too serious to lose time in useless words and aimless wrath.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said the baron, on leaving her "you will not escape
Title:  tonight!"
Title:  
Title:  At ten o'clock Felton came and placed the sentinel.  Milady
Title:  recognized his step.  She was as well acquainted with it now as a
Title:  mistress is with that of the lover of her heart; and yet Milady
Title:  at the same time detested and despised this weak fanatic.
Title:  
Title:  That was not the appointed hour.  Felton did not enter.
Title:  
Title:  Two hours after, as midnight sounded, the sentinel was relieved.
Title:  This time it WAS the hour, and from this moment Milady waited
Title:  with impatience.  The new sentinel commenced his walk in the
Title:  corridor.  At the expiration of ten minutes Felton came.
Title:  
Title:  Milady was all attention.
Title:  
Title:  "Listen," said the young man to the sentinel.  "On no pretense
Title:  leave the door, for you know that last night my Lord punished a
Title:  soldier for having quit his post for an instant, although I,
Title:  during his absence, watched in his place."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I know it," said the soldier.
Title:  
Title:  "I recommend you therefore to keep the strictest watch.  For my
Title:  part I am going to pay a second visit to this woman, who I fear
Title:  entertains sinister intentions upon her own life, and I have
Title:  received orders to watch her."
Title:  
Title:  "Good!" murmured Milady; "the austere Puritan lies."
Title:  
Title:  As to the soldier, he only smiled.
Title:  
Title:  "Zounds, Lieutenant!" said he; "you are not unlucky in being
Title:  charged with such commissions, particularly if my Lord has
Title:  authorized you to look into her bed."
Title:  
Title:  Felton blushed.  Under any other circumstances he would have
Title:  reprimanded the soldier for indulging in such pleasantry, but his
Title:  conscience murmured too loud for his mouth to dare speak.
Title:  
Title:  "If I call, come," said he.  "If anyone comes, call me."
Title:  
Title:  "I will, Lieutenant," said the soldier.
Title:  
Title:  Felton entered Milady's apartment.  Milady arose.
Title:  
Title:  "You are here!" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "I promised to come," said Felton, "and I have come."
Title:  
Title:  "You promised me something else."
Title:  
Title:  "What, my God!" said the young man, who in spite of his self-
Title:  command felt his knees tremble and the sweat start from his brow.
Title:  
Title:  "You promised to bring a knife, and to leave it with me after our
Title:  interview."
Title:  
Title:  "Say no more of that, madame," said Felton.  "There is no
Title:  situation, however terrible it may be, which can authorize a
Title:  creature of God to inflict death upon himself.  I have reflected,
Title:  and I cannot, must not be guilty of such a sin."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you have reflected!" said the prisoner, sitting down in her
Title:  armchair, with a smile of disdain; "and I also have reflected."
Title:  
Title:  "Upon what?"
Title:  
Title:  "That I can have nothing to say to a man who does not keep his
Title:  word."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!" murmured Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "You may retire," said Milady.  "I will not talk."
Title:  
Title:  "Here is the knife," said Felton, drawing from his pocket the
Title:  weapon which he had brought, according to his promise, but which
Title:  he hesitated to give to his prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  "Let me see it," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "For what purpose?"
Title:  
Title:  "Upon my honor, I will instantly return it to you.  You shall
Title:  place it on that table, and you may remain between it and me."
Title:  
Title:  Felton offered the weapon to Milady, who examined the temper of
Title:  it attentively, and who tried the point on the tip of her finger.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said she, returning the knife to the young officer, "this
Title:  is fine and good steel.  You are a faithful friend, Felton."
Title:  
Title:  Felton took back the weapon, and laid it upon the table, as he
Title:  had agreed with the prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  Milady followed him with her eyes, and made a gesture of
Title:  satisfaction.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said she, "listen to me."
Title:  
Title:  The request was needless.  The young officer stood upright before
Title:  her, awaiting her words as if to devour them.
Title:  
Title:  "Felton," said Milady, with a solemnity full of melancholy,
Title:  "imagine that your sister, the daughter of your father, speaks to
Title:  you.  While yet young, unfortunately handsome, I was dragged into
Title:  a snare.  I resisted.  Ambushes and violences multiplied around
Title:  me, but I resisted.  The religion I serve, the God I adore, were
Title:  blasphemed because I called upon that religion and that God, but
Title:  still I resisted.  Then outrages were heaped upon me, and as my
Title:  soul was not subdued they wished to defile my body forever.
Title:  Finally--"
Title:  
Title:  Milady stopped, and a bitter smile passed over her lips.
Title:  
Title:  "Finally," said Felton, "finally, what did they do?"
Title:  
Title:  "At length, one evening my enemy resolved to paralyze the
Title:  resistance he could not conquer.  One evening he mixed a powerful
Title:  narcotic with my water.  Scarcely had I finished my repast, when
Title:  I felt myself sink by degrees into a strange torpor.  Although I
Title:  was without mistrust, a vague fear seized me, and I tried to
Title:  struggle against sleepiness.  I arose.  I wished to run to the
Title:  window and call for help, but my legs refused their office.  It
Title:  appeared as if the ceiling sank upon my head and crushed me with
Title:  its weight.  I stretched out my arms.  I tried to speak.  I could
Title:  only utter inarticulate sounds, and irresistible faintness came
Title:  over me.  I supported myself by a chair, feeling that I was about
Title:  to fall, but this support was soon insufficient on account of my
Title:  weak arms.  I fell upon one knee, then upon both.  I tried to
Title:  pray, but my tongue was frozen.  God doubtless neither heard nor
Title:  saw me, and I sank upon the floor a prey to a slumber which
Title:  resembled death.
Title:  
Title:  "Of all that passed in that sleep, or the time which glided away
Title:  while it lasted, I have no remembrance.  The only thing I
Title:  recollect is that I awoke in bed in a round chamber, the
Title:  furniture of which was sumptuous, and into which light only
Title:  penetrated by an opening in the ceiling.  No door gave entrance
Title:  to the room.  It might be called a magnificent prison.
Title:  
Title:  "It was a long time before I was able to make out what place I
Title:  was in, or to take account of the details I describe.  My mind
Title:  appeared to strive in vain to shake off the heavy darkness of the
Title:  sleep from which I could not rouse myself.  I had vague
Title:  perceptions of space traversed, of the rolling of a carriage, of
Title:  a horrible dream in which my strength had become exhausted; but
Title:  all this was so dark and so indistinct in my mind that these
Title:  events seemed to belong to another life than mine, and yet mixed
Title:  with mine in fantastic duality.
Title:  
Title:  "At times the state into which I had fallen appeared so strange
Title:  that I believed myself dreaming.  I arose trembling.  My clothes
Title:  were near me on a chair; I neither remembered having undressed
Title:  myself nor going to bed.  Then by degrees the reality broke upon
Title:  me, full of chaste terrors.  I was no longer in the house where I
Title:  had dwelt.  As well as I could judge by the light of the sun, the
Title:  day was already two-thirds gone.  It was the evening before when
Title:  I had fallen asleep; my sleep, then, must have lasted twenty-four
Title:  hours!  What had taken place during this long sleep?
Title:  
Title:  "I dressed myself as quickly as possible; my slow and stiff
Title:  motions all attested that the effects of the narcotic were not
Title:  yet entirely dissipated.  The chamber was evidently furnished for
Title:  the reception of a woman; and the most finished coquette could
Title:  not have formed a wish, but on casting her eyes about the
Title:  apartment, she would have found that wish accomplished.
Title:  
Title:  "Certainly I was not the first captive that had been shut up in
Title:  this splendid prison; but you may easily comprehend, Felton, that
Title:  the more superb the prison, the greater was my terror.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, it was a prison, for I tried in vain to get out of it.  I
Title:  sounded all the walls, in the hopes of discovering a door, but
Title:  everywhere the walls returned a full and flat sound.
Title:  
Title:  "I made the tour of the room at least twenty times, in search of
Title:  an outlet of some kind; but there was none.  I sank exhausted
Title:  with fatigue and terror into an armchair.
Title:  
Title:  "Meantime, night came on rapidly, and with night my terrors
Title:  increased.  I did not know but I had better remain where I was
Title:  seated.  It appeared that I was surrounded with unknown dangers
Title:  into which I was about to fall at every instant.  Although I had
Title:  eaten nothing since the evening before, my fears prevented my
Title:  feeling hunger.
Title:  
Title:  "No noise from without by which I could measure the time reached
Title:  me; I only supposed it must be seven or eight o'clock in the
Title:  evening, for it was in the month of October and it was quite
Title:  dark.
Title:  
Title:  "All at once the noise of a door, turning on its hinges, made me
Title:  start.  A globe of fire appeared above the glazed opening of the
Title:  ceiling, casting a strong light into my chamber; and I perceived
Title:  with terror that a man was standing within a few paces of me.
Title:  
Title:  "A table, with two covers, bearing a supper ready prepared,
Title:  stood, as if by magic, in the middle of the apartment.
Title:  
Title:  "That man was he who had pursued me during a whole year, who had
Title:  vowed my dishonor, and who, by the first words that issued from
Title:  his mouth, gave me to understand he had accomplished it the
Title:  preceding night."
Title:  
Title:  "Scoundrel!" murmured Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, scoundrel!" cried Milady, seeing the interest which the
Title:  young officer, whose soul seemed to hang on her lips, took in
Title:  this strange recital.  "Oh, yes, scoundrel!  He believed, having
Title:  triumphed over me in my sleep, that all was completed.  He came,
Title:  hoping that I would accept my shame, as my shame was consummated;
Title:  he came to offer his fortune in exchange for my love.
Title:  
Title:  "All that the heart of a woman could contain of haughty contempt
Title:  and disdainful words, I poured out upon this man.  Doubtless he
Title:  was accustomed to such reproaches, for he listened to me calm and
Title:  smiling, with his arms crossed over his breast.  Then, when he
Title:  thought I had said all, he advanced toward me; I sprang toward
Title:  the table, I seized a knife, I placed it to my breast.
Title:  
Title:  "Take one step more," said I, "and in addition to my dishonor,
Title:  you shall have my death to reproach yourself with."
Title:  
Title:  "There was, no doubt, in my look, my voice, my whole person, that
Title:  sincerity of gesture, of attitude, of accent, which carries
Title:  conviction to the most perverse minds, for he paused.
Title:  
Title:  "'Your death?' said he; 'oh, no, you are too charming a mistress
Title:  to allow me to consent to lose you thus, after I have had the
Title:  happiness to possess you only a single time.  Adieu, my charmer;
Title:  I will wait to pay you my next visit till you are in a better
Title:  humor.'
Title:  
Title:  "At these words he blew a whistle; the globe of fire which
Title:  lighted the room reascended and disappeared.  I found myself
Title:  again in complete darkness.  The same noise of a door opening and
Title:  shutting was repeated the instant afterward; the flaming globe
Title:  descended afresh, and I was completely alone.
Title:  
Title:  "This moment was frightful; if I had any doubts as to my
Title:  misfortune, these doubts had vanished in an overwhelming reality.
Title:  I was in the power of a man whom I not only detested, but
Title:  despised--of a man capable of anything, and who had already given
Title:  me a fatal proof of what he was able to do."
Title:  
Title:  "But who, then was this man?" asked Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "I passed the night on a chair, starting at the least noise, for
Title:  toward midnight the lamp went out, and I was again in darkness.
Title:  But the night passed away without any fresh attempt on the part
Title:  of my persecutor.  Day came; the table had disappeared, only I
Title:  had still the knife in my hand.
Title:  
Title:  "This knife was my only hope.
Title:  
Title:  "I was worn out with fatigue.  Sleeplessness inflamed my eyes; I
Title:  had not dared to sleep a single instant.  The light of day
Title:  reassured me; I went and threw myself on the bed, without parting
Title:  with the emancipating knife, which I concealed under my pillow.
Title:  
Title:  "When I awoke, a fresh meal was served.
Title:  
Title:  "This time, in spite of my terrors, in spite of my agony, I began
Title:  to feel a devouring hunger.  It was forty-eight hours since I had
Title:  taken any nourishment.  I ate some bread and some fruit; then,
Title:  remembering the narcotic mixed with the water I had drunk, I
Title:  would not touch that which was placed on the table, but filled my
Title:  glass at a marble fountain fixed in the wall over my dressing
Title:  table.
Title:  
Title:  "And yet, notwithstanding these precautions, I remained for some
Title:  time in a terrible agitation of mind.  But my fears were this
Title:  time ill-founded; I passed the day without experiencing anything
Title:  of the kind I dreaded.
Title:  
Title:  "I took the precaution to half empty the carafe, in order that my
Title:  suspicions might not be noticed.
Title:  
Title:  "The evening came on, and with it darkness; but however profound
Title:  was this darkness, my eyes began to accustom themselves to it.  I
Title:  saw, amid the shadows, the table sink through the floor; a
Title:  quarter of an hour later it reappeared, bearing my supper.  In an
Title:  instant, thanks to the lamp, my chamber was once more lighted.
Title:  
Title:  "I was determined to eat only such things as could not possibly
Title:  have anything soporific introduced into them.  Two eggs and some
Title:  fruit composed my repast; then I drew another glass of water from
Title:  my protecting fountain, and drank it.
Title:  
Title:  "At the first swallow, it appeared to me not to have the same
Title:  taste as in the morning.  Suspicion instantly seized me.  I
Title:  paused, but I had already drunk half a glass.
Title:  
Title:  "I threw the rest away with horror, and waited, with the dew of
Title:  fear upon my brow.
Title:  
Title:  "No doubt some invisible witness had seen me draw the water from
Title:  that fountain, and had taken advantage of my confidence in it,
Title:  the better to assure my ruin, so coolly resolved upon, so cruelly
Title:  pursued.
Title:  
Title:  "Half an hour had not passed when the same symptoms began to
Title:  appear; but as I had only drunk half a glass of the water, I
Title:  contended longer, and instead of falling entirely asleep, I sank
Title:  into a state of drowsiness which left me a perception of what was
Title:  passing around me, while depriving me of the strength either to
Title:  defend myself or to fly.
Title:  
Title:  "I dragged myself toward the bed, to seek the only defense I had
Title:  left--my saving knife; but I could not reach the bolster.  I sank
Title:  on my knees, my hands clasped round one of the bedposts; then I
Title:  felt that I was lost."
Title:  
Title:  Felton became frightfully pale, and a convulsive tremor crept
Title:  through his whole body.
Title:  
Title:  "And what was most frightful," continued Milady, her voice
Title:  altered, as if she still experienced the same agony as at that
Title:  awful minute, "was that at this time I retained a consciousness
Title:  of the danger that threatened me; was that my soul, if I may say
Title:  so, waked in my sleeping body; was that I saw, that I heard.  It
Title:  is true that all was like a dream, but it was not the less
Title:  frightful.
Title:  
Title:  "I saw the lamp ascend, and leave me in darkness; then I heard
Title:  the well-known creaking of the door although I had heard that
Title:  door open but twice.
Title:  
Title:  "I felt instinctively that someone approached me; it is said that
Title:  the doomed wretch in the deserts of America thus feels the
Title:  approach of the serpent.
Title:  
Title:  "I wished to make an effort; I attempted to cry out.  By an
Title:  incredible effort of will I even raised myself up, but only to
Title:  sink down again immediately, and to fall into the arms of my
Title:  persecutor."
Title:  
Title:  "Tell me who this man was!" cried the young officer.
Title:  
Title:  Milady saw at a single glance all the painful feelings she
Title:  inspired in Felton by dwelling on every detail of her recital;
Title:  but she would not spare him a single pang.  The more profoundly
Title:  she wounded his heart, the more certainly he would avenge her.
Title:  She continued, then, as if she had not heard his exclamation, or
Title:  as if she thought the moment was not yet come to reply to it.
Title:  
Title:  "Only this time it was no longer an inert body, without feeling,
Title:  that the villain had to deal with.  I have told you that without
Title:  being able to regain the complete exercise of my faculties, I
Title:  retained the sense of my danger.  I struggled, then, with all my
Title:  strength, and doubtless opposed, weak as I was, a long
Title:  resistance, for I heard him cry out, 'These miserable Puritans!
Title:  I knew very well that they tired out their executioners, but I
Title:  did not believe them so strong against their lovers!'
Title:  
Title:  "Alas! this desperate resistance could not last long.  I felt my
Title:  strength fail, and this time it was not my sleep that enabled the
Title:  coward to prevail, but my swoon."
Title:  
Title:  Felton listened without uttering any word or sound, except an
Title:  inward expression of agony.  The sweat streamed down his marble
Title:  forehead, and his hand, under his coat, tore his breast.
Title:  
Title:  "My first impulse, on coming to myself, was to feel under my
Title:  pillow for the knife I had not been able to reach; if it had not
Title:  been useful for defense, it might at least serve for expiation.
Title:  
Title:  "But on taking this knife, Felton, a terrible idea occurred to
Title:  me.  I have sworn to tell you all, and I will tell you all.  I
Title:  have promised you the truth; I will tell it, were it to destroy
Title:  me."
Title:  
Title:  "The idea came into your mind to avenge yourself on this man, did
Title:  it not?" cried Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Milady.  "The idea was not that of a Christian, I
Title:  knew; but without doubt, that eternal enemy of our souls, that
Title:  lion roaring constantly around us, breathed it into my mind.  In
Title:  short, what shall I say to you, Felton?" continued Milady, in the
Title:  tone of a woman accusing herself of a crime.  "This idea occurred
Title:  to me, and did not leave me; it is of this homicidal thought that
Title:  I now bear the punishment."
Title:  
Title:  "Continue, continue!" said Felton; "I am eager to see you attain
Title:  your vengeance!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I resolved that it should take place as soon as possible.  I
Title:  had no doubt he would return the following night.  During the day
Title:  I had nothing to fear.
Title:  
Title:  "When the hour of breakfast came, therefore, I did not hesitate
Title:  to eat and drink.  I had determined to make believe sup, but to
Title:  eat nothing.  I was forced, then, to combat the fast of the
Title:  evening with the nourishment of the morning.
Title:  
Title:  "Only I concealed a glass of water, which remained after my
Title:  breakfast, thirst having been the chief of my sufferings when I
Title:  remained forty-eight hours without eating or drinking.
Title:  
Title:  "The day passed away without having any other influence on me
Title:  than to strengthen the resolution I had formed; only I took care
Title:  that my face should not betray the thoughts of my heart, for I
Title:  had no doubt I was watched.  Several times, even, I felt a smile
Title:  on my lips.  Felton, I dare not tell you at what idea I smiled;
Title:  you would hold me in horror--"
Title:  
Title:  "Go on! go on!" said Felton; "you see plainly that I listen, and
Title:  that I am anxious to know the end."
Title:  
Title:  "Evening came; the ordinary events took place.  During the
Title:  darkness, as before, my supper was brought.  Then the lamp was
Title:  lighted, and I sat down to table.  I only ate some fruit.  I
Title:  pretended to pour out water from the jug, but I only drank that
Title:  which I had saved in my glass.  The substitution was made so
Title:  carefully that my spies, if I had any, could have no suspicion of
Title:  it.
Title:  
Title:  "After supper I exhibited the same marks of languor as on the
Title:  preceding evening; but this time, as I yielded to fatigue, or as
Title:  if I had become familiarized with danger, I dragged myself toward
Title:  my bed, let my robe fall, and lay down.
Title:  
Title:  "I found my knife where I had placed it, under my pillow, and
Title:  while feigning to sleep, my hand grasped the handle of it
Title:  convulsively.
Title:  
Title:  "Two hours passed away without anything fresh happening.  Oh, my
Title:  God! who could have said so the evening before?  I began to fear
Title:  that he would not come.
Title:  
Title:  "At length I saw the lamp rise softly, and disappear in the
Title:  depths of the ceiling; my chamber was filled with darkness and
Title:  obscurity, but I made a strong effort to penetrate this darkness
Title:  and obscurity.
Title:  
Title:  "Nearly ten minutes passed; I heard no other noise but the
Title:  beating of my own heart.  I implored heaven that he might come.
Title:  
Title:  "At length I heard the well-known noise of the door, which opened
Title:  and shut; I heard, notwithstanding the thickness of the carpet, a
Title:  step which made the floor creak; I saw, notwithstanding the
Title:  darkness, a shadow which approached my bed."
Title:  
Title:  "Haste! haste!" said Felton; "do you not see that each of your
Title:  words burns me like molten lead?"
Title:  
Title:  "Then," continued Milady, "then I collected all my strength; I
Title:  recalled to my mind that the moment of vengeance, or rather, of
Title:  justice, had struck.  I looked upon myself as another Judith; I
Title:  gathered myself up, my knife in my hand, and when I saw him near
Title:  me, stretching out his arms to find his victim, then, with the
Title:  last cry of agony and despair, I struck him in the middle of his
Title:  breast.
Title:  
Title:  "The miserable villain!  He had foreseen all.  His breast was
Title:  covered with a coat-of-mail; the knife was bent against it.
Title:  
Title:  "'Ah, ah!' cried he, seizing my arm, and wresting from me the
Title:  weapon that had so badly served me, 'you want to take my life, do
Title:  you, my pretty Puritan?  But that's more than dislike, that's
Title:  ingratitude!  Come, come, calm yourself, my sweet girl!  I
Title:  thought you had softened.  I am not one of those tyrants who
Title:  detain women by force.  You don't love me.  With my usual fatuity
Title:  I doubted it; now I am convinced.  Tomorrow you shall be free.'
Title:  
Title:  "I had but one wish; that was that he should kill me.
Title:  
Title:  "'Beware!' said I, 'for my liberty is your dishonor.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Explain yourself, my pretty sibyl!'
Title:  
Title:  "'Yes; for as soon as I leave this place I will tell everything.
Title:  I will proclaim the violence you have used toward me.  I will
Title:  describe my captivity.  I will denounce this place of infamy.
Title:  You are placed on high, my Lord, but tremble!  Above you there is
Title:  the king; above the king there is God!'
Title:  
Title:  "However perfect master he was over himself, my persecutor
Title:  allowed a movement of anger to escape him.  I could not see the
Title:  expression of his countenance, but I felt the arm tremble upon
Title:  which my hand was placed.
Title:  
Title:  "'Then you shall not leave this place,' said he.
Title:  
Title:  "'Very well,' cried I, 'then the place of my punishment will be
Title:  that of my tomb.  I will die here, and you will see if a phantom
Title:  that accuses is not more terrible than a living being that
Title:  threatens!'
Title:  
Title:  "'You shall have no weapon left in your power.'
Title:  
Title:  "'There is a weapon which despair has placed within the reach of
Title:  every creature who has the courage to use it.  I will allow
Title:  myself to die with hunger.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Come,' said the wretch, 'is not peace much better than such a
Title:  war as that?  I will restore you to liberty this moment; I will
Title:  proclaim you a piece of immaculate virtue; I will name you the
Title:  Lucretia of England.'
Title:  
Title:  "'And I will say that you are the Sextus.  I will denounce you
Title:  before men, as I have denounced you before God; and if it be
Title:  necessary that, like Lucretia, I should sign my accusation with
Title:  my blood, I will sign it.'
Title:  
Title:  "'Ah!' said my enemy, in a jeering tone, 'that's quite another
Title:  thing.  My faith! everything considered, you are very well off
Title:  here.  You shall want for nothing, and if you let yourself die of
Title:  hunger that will be your own fault.'
Title:  
Title:  "At these words he retired.  I heard the door open and shut, and
Title:  I remained overwhelmed, less, I confess it, by my grief than by
Title:  the mortification of not having avenged myself.
Title:  
Title:  "He kept his word.  All the day, all the next night passed away
Title:  without my seeing him again.  But I also kept my word with him,
Title:  and I neither ate nor drank.  I was, as I told him, resolved to
Title:  die of hunger.
Title:  
Title:  "I passed the day and the night in prayer, for I hoped that God
Title:  would pardon me my suicide.
Title:  
Title:  "The second night the door opened; I was lying on the floor, for
Title:  my strength began to abandon me.
Title:  
Title:  "At the noise I raised myself up on one hand.
Title:  
Title:  "'Well,' said a voice which vibrated in too terrible a manner in
Title:  my ear not to be recognized, 'well!  Are we softened a little?
Title:  Will we not pay for our liberty with a single promise of silence?
Title:  Come, I am a good sort of a prince,' added he, 'and although I
Title:  like not Puritans I do them justice; and it is the same with
Title:  Puritanesses, when they are pretty.  Come, take a little oath for
Title:  me on the cross; I won't ask anything more of you.'
Title:  
Title:  "'On the cross,' cried I, rising, for at that abhorred voice I
Title:  had recovered all my strength, 'on the cross I swear that no
Title:  promise, no menace, no force, no torture, shall close my mouth!
Title:  On the cross I swear to denounce you everywhere as a murderer, as
Title:  a thief of honor, as a base coward!  On the cross I swear, if I
Title:  ever leave this place, to call down vengeance upon you from the
Title:  whole human race!'
Title:  
Title:  "'Beware!' said the voice, in a threatening accent that I had
Title:  never yet heard.  'I have an extraordinary means which I will not
Title:  employ but in the last extremity to close your mouth, or at least
Title:  to prevent anyone from believing a word you may utter.'
Title:  
Title:  "I mustered all my strength to reply to him with a burst of
Title:  laughter.
Title:  
Title:  "He saw that it was a merciless war between us--a war to the
Title:  death.
Title:  
Title:  "'Listen!' said he. 'I give you the rest of tonight and all day
Title:  tomorrow.  Reflect:  promise to be silent, and riches,
Title:  consideration, even honor, shall surround you; threaten to speak,
Title:  and I will condemn you to infamy.'
Title:  
Title:  "'You?' cried I. 'You?'
Title:  
Title:  "'To interminable, ineffaceable infamy!'
Title:  
Title:  "'You?' repeated I.  Oh, I declare to you, Felton, I thought him
Title:  mad!
Title:  
Title:  "'Yes, yes, I!' replied he.
Title:  
Title:  "'Oh, leave me!' said I. 'Begone, if you do not desire to see me
Title:  dash my head against that wall before your eyes!'
Title:  
Title:  "'Very well, it is your own doing.  Till tomorrow evening, then!'
Title:  
Title:  "'Till tomorrow evening, then!' replied I, allowing myself to
Title:  fall, and biting the carpet with rage."
Title:  
Title:  Felton leaned for support upon a piece of furniture; and Milady
Title:  saw, with the joy of a demon, that his strength would fail him
Title:  perhaps before the end of her recital.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  57  MEANS FOR CLASSICAL TRAGEDY
Title:  
Title:  After a moment of silence employed by Milady in observing the
Title:  young man who listened to her, Milady continued her recital.
Title:  
Title:  "It was nearly three days since I had eaten or drunk anything.  I
Title:  suffered frightful torments.  At times there passed before me
Title:  clouds which pressed my brow, which veiled my eyes; this was
Title:  delirium.
Title:  
Title:  "When the evening came I was so weak that every time I fainted I
Title:  thanked God, for I thought I was about to die.
Title:  
Title:  "In the midst of one of these swoons I heard the door open.
Title:  Terror recalled me to myself.
Title:  
Title:  "He entered the apartment followed by a man in a mask.  He was
Title:  masked likewise; but I knew his step, I knew his voice, I knew
Title:  him by that imposing bearing which hell has bestowed upon his
Title:  person for the curse of humanity.
Title:  
Title:  "'Well,' said he to me, 'have you made your mind up to take the
Title:  oath I requested of you?'
Title:  
Title:  "'You have said Puritans have but one word.  Mine you have heard,
Title:  and that is to pursue you--on earth to the tribunal of men, in
Title:  heaven to the tribunal of God.'
Title:  
Title:  "'You persist, then?'
Title:  
Title:  "'I swear it before the God who hears me.  I will take the whole
Title:  world as a witness of your crime, and that until I have found an
Title:  avenger.'
Title:  
Title:  "'You are a prostitute,' said he, in a voice of thunder, 'and you
Title:  shall undergo the punishment of prostitutes!  Branded in the eyes
Title:  of the world you invoke, try to prove to that world that you are
Title:  neither guilty nor mad!'
Title:  
Title:  "Then, addressing the man who accompanied him, 'Executioner,'
Title:  said he, 'do your duty.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, his name, his name!" cried Felton.  "His name, tell it me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then in spite of my cries, in spite of my resistance--for I
Title:  began to comprehend that there was a question of something worse
Title:  than death--the executioner seized me, threw me on the floor,
Title:  fastened me with his bonds, and suffocated by sobs, almost
Title:  without sense, invoking God, who did not listen to me, I uttered
Title:  all at once a frightful cry of pain and shame.  A burning fire, a
Title:  red-hot iron, the iron of the executioner, was imprinted on my
Title:  shoulder."
Title:  
Title:  Felton uttered a groan.
Title:  
Title:  "Here," said Milady, rising with the majesty of a queen, "here,
Title:  Felton, behold the new martyrdom invented for a pure young girl,
Title:  the victim of the brutality of a villain.  Learn to know the
Title:  heart of men, and henceforth make yourself less easily the
Title:  instrument of their unjust vengeance."
Title:  
Title:  Milady, with a rapid gesture, opened her robe, tore the cambric
Title:  that covered her bosom, and red with feigned anger and simulated
Title:  shame, showed the young man the ineffaceable impression which
Title:  dishonored that beautiful shoulder.
Title:  
Title:  "But," cried Felton, "that is a FLEUR-DE-LIS which I see there."
Title:  
Title:  "And therein consisted the infamy," replied Milady.  "The brand
Title:  of England!--it would be necessary to prove what tribunal had
Title:  imposed it on me, and I could have made a public appeal to all
Title:  the tribunals of the kingdom; but the brand of France!--oh, by
Title:  that, by THAT I was branded indeed!"
Title:  
Title:  This was too much for Felton.
Title:  
Title:  Pale, motionless, overwhelmed by this frightful revelation,
Title:  dazzled by the superhuman beauty of this woman who unveiled
Title:  herself before him with an immodesty which appeared to him
Title:  sublime, he ended by falling on his knees before her as the early
Title:  Christians did before those pure and holy martyrs whom the
Title:  persecution of the emperors gave up in the circus to the
Title:  sanguinary sensuality of the populace.  The brand disappeared;
Title:  the beauty alone remained.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon!  Pardon!" cried Felton, "oh, pardon!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady read in his eyes LOVE! LOVE!
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon for what?" asked she.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon me for having joined with your persecutors."
Title:  
Title:  Milady held out her hand to him.
Title:  
Title:  "So beautiful! so young!" cried Felton, covering that hand with
Title:  his kisses.
Title:  
Title:  Milady let one of those looks fall upon him which make a slave of
Title:  a king.
Title:  
Title:  Felton was a Puritan; he abandoned the hand of this woman to kiss
Title:  her feet.
Title:  
Title:  He no longer loved her; he adored her.
Title:  
Title:  When this crisis was past, when Milady appeared to have resumed
Title:  her self-possession, which she had never lost; when Felton had
Title:  seen her recover with the veil of chastity those treasures of
Title:  love which were only concealed from him to make him desire them
Title:  the more ardently, he said, "Ah, now!  I have only one thing to
Title:  ask of you; that is, the name of your true executioner.  For to
Title:  me there is but one; the other was an instrument, that was all."
Title:  
Title:  "What, brother!" cried Milady, "must I name him again?  Have you
Title:  not yet divined who he is?"
Title:  
Title:  "What?" cried Felton, "he--again he--always he?  What--the truly
Title:  guilty?"
Title:  
Title:  "The truly guilty," said Milady, "is the ravager of England, the
Title:  persecutor of true believers, the base ravisher of the honor of
Title:  so many women--he who, to satisfy a caprice of his corrupt heart,
Title:  is about to make England shed so much blood, who protects the
Title:  Protestants today and will betray them tomorrow--"
Title:  
Title:  "Buckingham!  It is, then, Buckingham!" cried Felton, in a high
Title:  state of excitement.
Title:  
Title:  Milady concealed her face in her hands, as if she could not
Title:  endure the shame which this name recalled to her.
Title:  
Title:  "Buckingham, the executioner of this angelic creature!" cried
Title:  Felton.  "And thou hast not hurled thy thunder at him, my God!
Title:  And thou hast left him noble, honored, powerful, for the ruin of
Title:  us all!"
Title:  
Title:  "God abandons him who abandons himself," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "But he will draw upon his head the punishment reserved for the
Title:  damned!" said Felton, with increasing exultation.  "He wills that
Title:  human vengeance should precede celestial justice."
Title:  
Title:  "Men fear him and spare him."
Title:  
Title:  "I," said Felton, "I do not fear him, nor will I spare him."
Title:  
Title:  The soul of Milady was bathed in an infernal joy.
Title:  
Title:  "But how can Lord de Winter, my protector, my father," asked
Title:  Felton, "possibly be mixed up with all this?"
Title:  
Title:  "Listen, Felton," resumed Milady, "for by the side of base and
Title:  contemptible men there are often found great and generous
Title:  natures.  I had an affianced husband, a man whom I loved, and who
Title:  loved me--a heart like yours, Felton, a man like you.  I went to
Title:  him and told him all; he knew me, that man did, and did not doubt
Title:  an instant.  He was a nobleman, a man equal to Buckingham in
Title:  every respect.  He said nothing; he only girded on his sword,
Title:  wrapped himself in his cloak, and went straight to Buckingham
Title:  Palace.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes," said Felton; "I understand how he would act.  But
Title:  with such men it is not the sword that should be employed; it is
Title:  the poniard."
Title:  
Title:  "Buckingham had left England the day before, sent as ambassador
Title:  to Spain, to demand the hand of the Infanta for King Charles I,
Title:  who was then only Prince of Wales.  My affianced husband
Title:  returned.
Title:  
Title:  "'Hear me,' said he; 'this man has gone, and for the moment has
Title:  consequently escaped my vengeance; but let us be united, as we
Title:  were to have been, and then leave it to Lord de Winter to
Title:  maintain his own honor and that of his wife.'"
Title:  
Title:  "Lord de Winter!" cried Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Milady, "Lord de Winter; and now you can understand
Title:  it all, can you not?  Buckingham remained nearly a year absent.
Title:  A week before his return Lord de Winter died, leaving me his sole
Title:  heir.  Whence came the blow?  God who knows all, knows without
Title:  doubt; but as for me, I accuse nobody."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, what an abyss; what an abyss!" cried Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Lord de Winter died without revealing anything to his brother.
Title:  The terrible secret was to be concealed till it burst, like a
Title:  clap of thunder, over the head of the guilty.  Your protector had
Title:  seen with pain this marriage of his elder brother with a
Title:  portionless girl.  I was sensible that I could look for no
Title:  support from a man disappointed in his hopes of an inheritance.
Title:  I went to France, with a determination to remain there for the
Title:  rest of my life.  But all my fortune is in England.
Title:  Communication being closed by the war, I was in want of
Title:  everything.  I was then obliged to come back again.  Six days
Title:  ago, I landed at Portsmouth."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?" said Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Well; Buckingham heard by some means, no doubt, of my return.
Title:  He spoke of me to Lord de Winter, already prejudiced against me,
Title:  and told him that his sister-in-law was a prostitute, a branded
Title:  woman.  The noble and pure voice of my husband was no longer here
Title:  to defend me.  Lord de Winter believed all that was told him with
Title:  so much the more ease that it was his interest to believe it.  He
Title:  caused me to be arrested, had me conducted hither, and placed me
Title:  under your guard.  You know the rest.  The day after tomorrow he
Title:  banishes me, he transports me; the day after tomorrow he exiles
Title:  me among the infamous.  Oh, the train is well laid; the plot is
Title:  clever.  My honor will not survive it!  You see, then, Felton, I
Title:  can do nothing but die.  Felton, give me that knife!"
Title:  
Title:  And at these words, as if all her strength was exhausted, Milady
Title:  sank, weak and languishing, into the arms of the young officer,
Title:  who, intoxicated with love, anger, and voluptuous sensations
Title:  hitherto unknown, received her with transport, pressed her
Title:  against his heart, all trembling at the breath from that charming
Title:  mouth, bewildered by the contact with that palpitating bosom.
Title:  
Title:  "No, no," said he.  "No, you shall live honored and pure; you
Title:  shall live to triumph over your enemies."
Title:  
Title:  Milady put him from her slowly with her hand, while drawing him
Title:  nearer with her look; but Felton, in his turn, embraced her more
Title:  closely, imploring her like a divinity.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, death, death!" said she, lowering her voice and her eyelids,
Title:  "oh, death, rather than shame!  Felton, my brother, my friend, I
Title:  conjure you!"
Title:  
Title:  "No," cried Felton, "no; you shall live and you shall be
Title:  avenged."
Title:  
Title:  "Felton, I bring misfortune to all who surround me!  Felton,
Title:  abandon me!  Felton, let me die!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, we will live and die together!" cried he, pressing
Title:  his lips to those of the prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  Several strokes resounded on the door; this time Milady really
Title:  pushed him away from her.
Title:  
Title:  "Hark," said she, "we have been overheard!  Someone is coming!
Title:  All is over!  We are lost!"
Title:  
Title:  "No," said Felton; it is only the sentinel warning me that they
Title:  are about to change the guard."
Title:  
Title:  "Then run to the door, and open it yourself."
Title:  
Title:  Felton obeyed; this woman was now his whole thought, his whole
Title:  soul.
Title:  
Title:  He found himself face to face with a sergeant commanding a watch-
Title:  patrol.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, what is the matter?" asked the young lieutenant.
Title:  
Title:  "You told me to open the door if I heard anyone cry out," said
Title:  the soldier; "but you forgot to leave me the key.  I heard you
Title:  cry out, without understanding what you said.  I tried to open
Title:  the door, but it was locked inside; then I called the sergeant."
Title:  
Title:  "And here I am," said the sergeant.
Title:  
Title:  Felton, quite bewildered, almost mad, stood speechless.
Title:  
Title:  Milady plainly perceived that it was now her turn to take part in
Title:  the scene.  She ran to the table, and seizing the knife which
Title:  Felton had laid down, exclaimed, "And by what right will you
Title:  prevent me from dying?"
Title:  
Title:  "Great God!" exclaimed Felton, on seeing the knife glitter in her
Title:  hand.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment a burst of ironical laughter resounded through the
Title:  corridor.  The baron, attracted by the noise, in his chamber
Title:  gown, his sword under his arm, stood in the doorway.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said he, "here we are, at the last act of the tragedy.  You
Title:  see, Felton, the drama has gone through all the phases I named;
Title:  but be easy, no blood will flow."
Title:  
Title:  Milady perceived that all was lost unless she gave Felton an
Title:  immediate and terrible proof of her courage.
Title:  
Title:  "You are mistaken, my Lord, blood will flow; and may that blood
Title:  fall back on those who cause it to flow!"
Title:  
Title:  Felton uttered a cry, and rushed toward her.  He was too late;
Title:  Milady had stabbed herself.
Title:  
Title:  But the knife had fortunately, we ought to say skillfully, come
Title:  in contact with the steel busk, which at that period, like a
Title:  cuirass, defended the chests of women.  It had glided down it,
Title:  tearing the robe, and had penetrated slantingly between the flesh
Title:  and the ribs.  Milady's robe was not the less stained with blood
Title:  in a second.
Title:  
Title:  Milady fell down, and seemed to be in a swoon.
Title:  
Title:  Felton snatched away the knife.
Title:  
Title:  "See, my Lord," said he, in a deep, gloomy tone, "here is a woman
Title:  who was under my guard, and who has killed herself!"
Title:  
Title:  "Be at ease, Felton," said Lord de Winter.  "She is not dead;
Title:  demons do not die so easily.  Be tranquil, and go wait for me in
Title:  my chamber."
Title:  
Title:  "But, my Lord--"
Title:  
Title:  "Go, sir, I command you!"
Title:  
Title:  At this injunction from his superior, Felton obeyed; but in going
Title:  out, he put the knife into his bosom.
Title:  
Title:  As to Lord de Winter, he contented himself with calling the woman
Title:  who waited on Milady, and when she was come, he recommended the
Title:  prisoner, who was still fainting, to her care, and left them
Title:  alone.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, all things considered and notwithstanding his
Title:  suspicions, as the wound might be serious, he immediately sent
Title:  off a mounted man to find a physician.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  58  ESCAPE
Title:  
Title:  As Lord de Winter had thought, Milady's wound was not dangerous.
Title:  So soon as she was left alone with the woman whom the baron had
Title:  summoned to her assistance she opened her eyes.
Title:  
Title:  It was, however, necessary to affect weakness and pain--not a
Title:  very difficult task for so finished an actress as Milady.  Thus
Title:  the poor woman was completely the dupe of the prisoner, whom,
Title:  notwithstanding her hints, she persisted in watching all night.
Title:  
Title:  But the presence of this woman did not prevent Milady from
Title:  thinking.
Title:  
Title:  There was no longer a doubt that Felton was convinced; Felton was
Title:  hers.  If an angel appeared to that young man as an accuser of
Title:  Milady, he would take him, in the mental disposition in which he
Title:  now found himself, for a messenger sent by the devil.
Title:  
Title:  Milady smiled at this thought, for Felton was now her only hope--
Title:  her only means of safety.
Title:  
Title:  But Lord de Winter might suspect him; Felton himself might now be
Title:  watched!
Title:  
Title:  Toward four o'clock in the morning the doctor arrived; but since
Title:  the time Milady stabbed herself, however short, the wound had
Title:  closed.  The doctor could therefore measure neither the direction
Title:  nor the depth of it; he only satisfied himself by Milady's pulse
Title:  that the case was not serious.
Title:  
Title:  In the morning Milady, under the pretext that she had not slept
Title:  well in the night and wanted rest, sent away the woman who
Title:  attended her.
Title:  
Title:  She had one hope, which was that Felton would appear at the
Title:  breakfast hour; but Felton did not come.
Title:  
Title:  Were her fears realized?  Was Felton, suspected by the baron,
Title:  about to fail her at the decisive moment?  She had only one day
Title:  left.  Lord de Winter had announced her embarkation for the
Title:  twenty-third, and it was now the morning of the twenty-second.
Title:  
Title:  Nevertheless she still waited patiently till the hour for dinner.
Title:  
Title:  Although she had eaten nothing in the morning, the dinner was
Title:  brought in at its usual time.  Milady then perceived, with
Title:  terror, that the uniform of the soldiers who guarded her was
Title:  changed.
Title:  
Title:  Then she ventured to ask what had become of Felton.
Title:  
Title:  She was told that he had left the castle an hour before on
Title:  horseback.  She inquired if the baron was still at the castle.
Title:  The soldier replied that he was, and that he had given orders to
Title:  be informed if the prisoner wished to speak to him.
Title:  
Title:  Milady replied that she was too weak at present, and that her
Title:  only desire was to be left alone.
Title:  
Title:  The soldier went out, leaving the dinner served.
Title:  
Title:  Felton was sent away.  The marines were removed.  Felton was then
Title:  mistrusted.
Title:  
Title:  This was the last blow to the prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  Left alone, she arose.  The bed, which she had kept from prudence
Title:  and that they might believe her seriously wounded, burned her
Title:  like a bed of fire.  She cast a glance at the door; the baron had
Title:  had a plank nailed over the grating.  He no doubt feared that by
Title:  this opening she might still by some diabolical means corrupt her
Title:  guards.
Title:  
Title:  Milady smiled with joy.  She was free now to give way to her
Title:  transports without being observed.  She traversed her chamber
Title:  with the excitement of a furious maniac or of a tigress shut up
Title:  in an iron cage.  CERTES, if the knife had been left in her
Title:  power, she would now have thought, not of killing herself, but of
Title:  killing the baron.
Title:  
Title:  At six o'clock Lord de Winter came in.  He was armed at all
Title:  points.  This man, in whom Milady till that time had only seen a
Title:  very simple gentleman, had become an admirable jailer.  He
Title:  appeared to foresee all, to divine all, to anticipate all.
Title:  
Title:  A single look at Milady apprised him of all that was passing in
Title:  her mind.
Title:  
Title:  "Ay!" said he, "I see; but you shall not kill me today.  You
Title:  have no longer a weapon; and besides, I am on my guard.  You had
Title:  begun to pervert my poor Felton.  He was yielding to your
Title:  infernal influence; but I will save him.  He will never see you
Title:  again; all is over.  Get your clothes together.  Tomorrow you
Title:  will go.  I had fixed the embarkation for the twenty-fourth; but
Title:  I have reflected that the more promptly the affair takes place
Title:  the more sure it will be.  Tomorrow, by twelve o'clock, I shall
Title:  have the order for your exile, signed, BUCKINGHAM.  If you
Title:  speak a single word to anyone before going aboard ship, my
Title:  sergeant will blow your brains out.  He has orders to do so.  If
Title:  when on the ship you speak a single word to anyone before the
Title:  captain permits you, the captain will have you thrown into the
Title:  sea.  That is agreed upon.
Title:  
Title:  "AU REVOIR; then; that is all I have to say today.  Tomorrow I
Title:  will see you again, to take my leave."  With these words the
Title:  baron went out.  Milady had listened to all this menacing tirade
Title:  with a smile of disdain on her lips, but rage in her heart.
Title:  
Title:  Supper was served.  Milady felt that she stood in need of all her
Title:  strength.  She did not know what might take place during this
Title:  night which approached so menacingly--for large masses of cloud
Title:  rolled over the face of the sky, and distant lightning announced
Title:  a storm.
Title:  
Title:  The storm broke about ten o'clock.  Milady felt a consolation in
Title:  seeing nature partake of the disorder of her heart.  The thunder
Title:  growled in the air like the passion and anger in her thoughts.
Title:  It appeared to her that the blast as it swept along disheveled
Title:  her brow, as it bowed the branches of the trees and bore away
Title:  their leaves.  She howled as the hurricane howled; and her voice
Title:  was lost in the great voice of nature, which also seemed to groan
Title:  with despair.
Title:  
Title:  All at once she heard a tap at her window, and by the help of a
Title:  flash of lightning she saw the face of a man appear behind the
Title:  bars.
Title:  
Title:  She ran to the window and opened it.
Title:  
Title:  "Felton!" cried she.  "I am saved."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Felton; "but silence, silence!  I must have time to
Title:  file through these bars.  Only take care that I am not seen
Title:  through the wicket."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, it is a proof that the Lord is on our side, Felton," replied
Title:  Milady.  "They have closed up the grating with a board."
Title:  
Title:  "That is well; God has made them senseless," said Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "But what must I do?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing, nothing, only shut the window.  Go to bed, or at least
Title:  lie down in your clothes.  As soon as I have done I will knock on
Title:  one of the panes of glass.  But will you be able to follow me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes!"
Title:  
Title:  "Your wound?"
Title:  
Title:  "Gives me pain, but will not prevent my walking."
Title:  
Title:  "Be ready, then, at the first signal."
Title:  
Title:  Milady shut the window, extinguished the lamp, and went, as
Title:  Felton had desired her, to lie down on the bed.  Amid the moaning
Title:  of the storm she heard the grinding of the file upon the bars,
Title:  and by the light of every flash she perceived the shadow of
Title:  Felton through the panes.
Title:  
Title:  She passed an hour without breathing, panting, with a cold sweat
Title:  upon her brow, and her heart oppressed by frightful agony at
Title:  every movement she heard in the corridor.
Title:  
Title:  There are hours which last a year.
Title:  
Title:  At the expiration of an hour, Felton tapped again.
Title:  
Title:  Milady sprang out of bed and opened the window.  Two bars removed
Title:  formed an opening for a man to pass through.
Title:  
Title:  "Are you ready?" asked Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes.  Must I take anything with me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Money, if you have any."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes; fortunately they have left me all I had."
Title:  
Title:  "So much the better, for I have expended all mine in chartering a
Title:  vessel."
Title:  
Title:  "Here!" said Milady, placing a bag full of louis in Felton's
Title:  hands.
Title:  
Title:  Felton took the bag and threw it to the foot of the wall.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said he, "will you come?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am ready."
Title:  
Title:  Milady mounted upon a chair and passed the upper part of her body
Title:  through the window.  She saw the young officer suspended over the
Title:  abyss by a ladder of ropes.  For the first time an emotion of
Title:  terror reminded her that she was a woman.
Title:  
Title:  The dark space frightened her.
Title:  
Title:  "I expected this," said Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "It's nothing, it's nothing!" said Milady.  "I will descend with
Title:  my eyes shut."
Title:  
Title:  "Have you confidence in me?" said Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "You ask that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Put your two hands together.  Cross them; that's right!"
Title:  
Title:  Felton tied her two wrists together with his handkerchief, and
Title:  then with a cord over the handkerchief.
Title:  
Title:  "What are you doing?" asked Milady, with surprise.
Title:  
Title:  "Pass your arms around my neck, and fear nothing."
Title:  
Title:  "But I shall make you lose your balance, and we shall both be
Title:  dashed to pieces."
Title:  
Title:  "Don't be afraid.  I am a sailor."
Title:  
Title:  Not a second was to be lost.  Milady passed her two arms round
Title:  Felton's neck, and let herself slip out of the window.  Felton
Title:  began to descend the ladder slowly, step by step.  Despite the
Title:  weight of two bodies, the blast of the hurricane shook them in
Title:  the air.
Title:  
Title:  All at once Felton stopped.
Title:  
Title:  "What is the matter?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence," said Felton, "I hear footsteps."
Title:  
Title:  "We are discovered!"
Title:  
Title:  There was a silence of several seconds.
Title:  
Title:  "No," said Felton, "it is nothing."
Title:  
Title:  "But what, then, is the noise?"
Title:  
Title:  "That of the patrol going their rounds."
Title:  
Title:  "Where is their road?"
Title:  
Title:  "Just under us."
Title:  
Title:  "They will discover us!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, if it does not lighten."
Title:  
Title:  "But they will run against the bottom of the ladder."
Title:  
Title:  "Fortunately it is too short by six feet."
Title:  
Title:  "Here they are!  My God!"
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!"
Title:  
Title:  Both remained suspended, motionless and breathless, within twenty
Title:  paces of the ground, while the patrol passed beneath them
Title:  laughing and talking.  This was a terrible moment for the
Title:  fugitives.
Title:  
Title:  The patrol passed.  The noise of their retreating footsteps and
Title:  the murmur of their voices soon died away.
Title:  
Title:  "Now," said Felton, "we are safe."
Title:  
Title:  Milady breathed a deep sigh and fainted.
Title:  
Title:  Felton continued to descend.  Near the bottom of the ladder, when
Title:  he found no more support for his feet, he clung with his hands;
Title:  at length, arrived at the last step, he let himself hang by the
Title:  strength of his wrists, and touched the ground.  He stooped down,
Title:  picked up the bag of money, and placed it between his teeth.
Title:  Then he took Milady in his arms, and set off briskly in the
Title:  direction opposite to that which the patrol had taken.  He soon
Title:  left the pathway of the patrol, descended across the rocks, and
Title:  when arrived on the edge of the sea, whistled.
Title:  
Title:  A similar signal replied to him; and five minutes after, a boat
Title:  appeared, rowed by four men.
Title:  
Title:  The boat approached as near as it could to the shore; but there
Title:  was not depth enough of water for it to touch land.  Felton
Title:  walked into the sea up to his middle, being unwilling to trust
Title:  his precious burden to anybody.
Title:  
Title:  Fortunately the storm began to subside, but still the sea was
Title:  disturbed.  The little boat bounded over the waves like a nut-
Title:  shell.
