Title:  
Title:  "To the sloop," said Felton, "and row quickly."
Title:  
Title:  The four men bent to their oars, but the sea was too high to let
Title:  them get much hold of it.
Title:  
Title:  However, they left the castle behind; that was the principal
Title:  thing.  The night was extremely dark.  It was almost impossible
Title:  to see the shore from the boat; they would therefore be less
Title:  likely to see the boat from the shore.
Title:  
Title:  A black point floated on the sea.  That was the sloop.  While the
Title:  boat was advancing with all the speed its four rowers could give
Title:  it, Felton untied the cord and then the handkerchief which bound
Title:  Milady's hands together.  When her hands were loosed he took some
Title:  sea water and sprinkled it over her face.
Title:  
Title:  Milady breathed a sigh, and opened her eyes.
Title:  
Title:  "Where am I?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Saved!" replied the young officer.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, saved, saved!" cried she.  "Yes, there is the sky; here is
Title:  the sea!  The air I breathe is the air of liberty!  Ah, thanks,
Title:  Felton, thanks!"
Title:  
Title:  The young man pressed her to his heart.
Title:  
Title:  "But what is the matter with my hands!" asked Milady; "it seems
Title:  as if my wrists had been crushed in a vice."
Title:  
Title:  Milady held out her arms; her wrists were bruised.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!" said Felton, looking at those beautiful hands, and
Title:  shaking his head sorrowfully.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, it's nothing, nothing!" cried Milady.  "I remember now."
Title:  
Title:  Milady looked around her, as if in search of something.
Title:  
Title:  "It is there," said Felton, touching the bag of money with his
Title:  foot.
Title:  
Title:  They drew near to the sloop.  A sailor on watch hailed the boat;
Title:  the boat replied.
Title:  
Title:  "What vessel is that?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "The one I have hired for you."
Title:  
Title:  "Where will it take me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Where you please, after you have put me on shore at Portsmouth."
Title:  
Title:  "What are you going to do at Portsmouth?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Accomplish the orders of Lord de Winter," said Felton, with a
Title:  gloomy smile.
Title:  
Title:  "What orders?" asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "You do not understand?" asked Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "No; explain yourself, I beg."
Title:  
Title:  "As he mistrusted me, he determined to guard you himself, and
Title:  sent me in his place to get Buckingham to sign the order for your
Title:  transportation."
Title:  
Title:  "But if he mistrusted you, how could he confide such an order to
Title:  you?"
Title:  
Title:  "How could I know what I was the bearer of?"
Title:  
Title:  "That's true!  And you are going to Portsmouth?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have no time to lose.  Tomorrow is the twenty-third, and
Title:  Buckingham sets sail tomorrow with his fleet."
Title:  
Title:  "He sets sail tomorrow!  Where for?"
Title:  
Title:  "For La Rochelle."
Title:  
Title:  "He need not sail!" cried Milady, forgetting her usual presence
Title:  of mind.
Title:  
Title:  "Be satisfied," replied Felton; "he will not sail."
Title:  
Title:  Milady started with joy.  She could read to the depths of the
Title:  heart of this young man; the death of Buckingham was written
Title:  there at full length.
Title:  
Title:  "Felton," cried she, "you are as great as Judas Maccabeus!  If
Title:  you die, I will die with you; that is all I can say to you."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!" cried Felton; "we are here."
Title:  
Title:  In fact, they touched the sloop.
Title:  
Title:  Felton mounted the ladder first, and gave his hand to Milady,
Title:  while the sailors supported her, for the sea was still much
Title:  agitated.
Title:  
Title:  An instant after they were on the deck.
Title:  
Title:  "Captain," said Felton, "this is person of whom I spoke to you,
Title:  and whom you must convey safe and sound to France."
Title:  
Title:  "For a thousand pistoles," said the captain.
Title:  
Title:  "I have paid you five hundred of them."
Title:  
Title:  "That's correct," said the captain.
Title:  
Title:  "And here are the other five hundred," replied Milady, placing
Title:  her hand upon the bag of gold.
Title:  
Title:  "No," said the captain, "I make but one bargain; and I have
Title:  agreed with this young man that the other five hundred shall not
Title:  be due to me till we arrive at Boulogne."
Title:  
Title:  "And shall we arrive there?"
Title:  
Title:  "Safe and sound, as true as my name's Jack Butler."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Milady, "if you keep your word, instead of five
Title:  hundred, I will give you a thousand pistoles."
Title:  
Title:  "Hurrah for you, then, my beautiful lady," cried the captain;
Title:  "and may God often send me such passengers as your Ladyship!"
Title:  
Title:  "Meanwhile," said Felton, "convey me to the little bay of--; you
Title:  know it was agreed you should put in there."
Title:  
Title:  The captain replied by ordering the necessary maneuvers, and
Title:  toward seven o'clock in the morning the little vessel cast anchor
Title:  in the bay that had been named.
Title:  
Title:  During this passage, Felton related everything to Milady--how,
Title:  instead of going to London, he had chartered the little vessel;
Title:  how he had returned; how he had scaled the wall by fastening
Title:  cramps in the interstices of the stones, as he ascended, to give
Title:  him foothold; and how, when he had reached the bars, he fastened
Title:  his ladder.  Milady knew the rest.
Title:  
Title:  On her side, Milady tried to encourage Felton in his project; but
Title:  at the first words which issued from her mouth, she plainly saw
Title:  that the young fanatic stood more in need of being moderated than
Title:  urged.
Title:  
Title:  It was agreed that Milady should wait for Felton till ten
Title:  o'clock; if he did not return by ten o'clock she was to sail.
Title:  
Title:  In that case, and supposing he was at liberty, he was to rejoin
Title:  her in France, at the convent of the Carmelites at Bethune.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  59  WHAT TOOK PLACE AT PORTSMOUTH AUGUST 23, 1628
Title:  
Title:  Felton took leave of Milady as a brother about to go for a mere walk
Title:  takes leave of his sister, kissing her hand.
Title:  
Title:  His whole body appeared in its ordinary state of calmness, only an
Title:  unusual fire beamed from his eyes, like the effects of a fever; his brow
Title:  was more pale than it generally was; his teeth were clenched, and his
Title:  speech had a short dry accent which indicated that something dark was at
Title:  work within him.
Title:  
Title:  As long as he remained in the boat which conveyed him to land, he kept
Title:  his face toward Milady, who, standing on the deck, followed him with her
Title:  eyes.  Both were free from the fear of pursuit; nobody ever came into
Title:  Milady's apartment before nine o'clock, and it would require three hours
Title:  to go from the castle to London.
Title:  
Title:  Felton jumped onshore, climbed the little ascent which led to the top of
Title:  the cliff, saluted Milady a last time, and took his course toward the
Title:  city.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of a hundred paces, the ground began to decline, and he could
Title:  only see the mast of the sloop.
Title:  
Title:  He immediately ran in the direction of Portsmouth, which he saw at
Title:  nearly half a league before him, standing out in the haze of the
Title:  morning, with its houses and towers.
Title:  
Title:  Beyond Portsmouth the sea was covered with vessels whose masts, like a
Title:  forest of poplars despoiled by the winter, bent with each breath of the
Title:  wind.
Title:  
Title:  Felton, in his rapid walk, reviewed in his mind all the accusations
Title:  against the favorite of James I and Charles I, furnished by two years of
Title:  premature meditation and a long sojourn among the Puritans.
Title:  
Title:  When he compared the public crimes of this minister--startling crimes,
Title:  European crimes, if so we may say--with the private and unknown crimes
Title:  with which Milady had charged him, Felton found that the more culpable
Title:  of the two men which formed the character of Buckingham was the one of
Title:  whom the public knew not the life.  This was because his love, so
Title:  strange, so new, and so ardent, made him view the infamous and imaginary
Title:  accusations of Milady de Winter as, through a magnifying glass, one
Title:  views as frightful monsters atoms in reality imperceptible by the side
Title:  of an ant.
Title:  
Title:  The rapidity of his walk heated his blood still more; the idea that he
Title:  left behind him, exposed to a frightful vengeance, the woman he loved,
Title:  or rather whom he adored as a saint, the emotion he had experienced,
Title:  present fatigue--all together exalted his mind above human feeling.
Title:  
Title:  He entered Portsmouth about eight o'clock in the morning.  The whole
Title:  population was on foot; drums were beating in the streets and in the
Title:  port; the troops about to embark were marching toward the sea.
Title:  
Title:  Felton arrived at the palace of the Admiralty, covered with dust, and
Title:  streaming with perspiration.  His countenance, usually so pale, was
Title:  purple with heat and passion.  The sentinel wanted to repulse him; but
Title:  Felton called to the officer of the post, and drawing from his pocket
Title:  the letter of which he was the bearer, he said, "A pressing message from
Title:  Lord de Winter."
Title:  
Title:  At the name of Lord de Winter, who was known to be one of his Grace's
Title:  most intimate friends, the officer of the post gave orders to let Felton
Title:  pass, who, besides, wore the uniform of a naval officer.
Title:  
Title:  Felton darted into the palace.
Title:  
Title:  At the moment he entered the vestibule, another man was entering
Title:  likewise, dusty, out of breath, leaving at the gate a post horse, which,
Title:  on reaching the palace, tumbled on his foreknees.
Title:  
Title:  Felton and he addressed Patrick, the duke's confidential lackey, at the
Title:  same moment.  Felton named Lord de Winter; the unknown would not name
Title:  anybody, and pretended that it was to the duke alone he would make
Title:  himself known.  Each was anxious to gain admission before the other.
Title:  
Title:  Patrick, who knew Lord de Winter was in affairs of the service, and in
Title:  relations of friendship with the duke, gave the preference to the one
Title:  who came in his name.  The other was forced to wait, and it was easily
Title:  to be seen how he cursed the delay.
Title:  
Title:  The valet led Felton through a large hall in which waited the deputies
Title:  from La Rochelle, headed by the Prince de Soubise, and introduced him
Title:  into a closet where Buckingham, just out of the bath, was finishing his
Title:  toilet, upon which, as at all times, he bestowed extraordinary
Title:  attention.
Title:  
Title:  "Lieutenant Felton, from Lord de Winter," said Patrick.
Title:  
Title:  "From Lord de Winter!" repeated Buckingham; "let him come in."
Title:  
Title:  Felton entered.  At that moment Buckingham was throwing upon a couch a
Title:  rich toilet robe, worked with gold, in order to put on a blue velvet
Title:  doublet embroidered with pearls.
Title:  
Title:  "Why didn't the baron come himself?" demanded Buckingham.  "I expected
Title:  him this morning."
Title:  
Title:  "He desired me to tell your Grace," replied Felton, "that he very much
Title:  regretted not having that honor, but that he was prevented by the guard
Title:  he is obliged to keep at the castle."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I know that," said Buckingham; "he has a prisoner."
Title:  
Title:  "It is of that prisoner that I wish to speak to your Grace," replied
Title:  Felton.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, then, speak!"
Title:  
Title:  "That which I have to say of her can only be heard by yourself, my
Title:  Lord!"
Title:  
Title:  "Leave us, Patrick," said Buckingham; "but remain within sound of the
Title:  bell.  I shall call you presently."
Title:  
Title:  Patrick went out.
Title:  
Title:  "We are alone, sir," said Buckingham; "speak!"
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord," said Felton, "the Baron de Winter wrote to you the other day
Title:  to request you to sign an order of embarkation relative to a young woman
Title:  named Charlotte Backson."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sir; and I answered him, to bring or send me that order and I
Title:  would sign it."
Title:  
Title:  "Here it is, my Lord."
Title:  
Title:  "Give it to me," said the duke.
Title:  
Title:  And taking it from Felton, he cast a rapid glance over the paper, and
Title:  perceiving that it was the one that had been mentioned to him, he placed
Title:  it on the table, took a pen, and prepared to sign it.
Title:  
Title:  "Pardon, my Lord," said Felton, stopping the duke; "but does your Grace
Title:  know that the name of Charlotte Backson is not the true name of this
Title:  young woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, sir, I know it," replied the duke, dipping the quill in the ink.
Title:  
Title:  "Then your Grace knows her real name?" asked Felton, in a sharp tone.
Title:  
Title:  "I know it"; and the duke put the quill to the paper.  Felton grew pale.
Title:  
Title:  "And knowing that real name, my Lord," replied Felton, "will you sign it
Title:  all the same?"
Title:  
Title:  "Doubtless," said Buckingham, "and rather twice than once."
Title:  
Title:  "I cannot believe," continued Felton, in a voice that became more sharp
Title:  and rough, "that your Grace knows that it is to Milady de Winter this
Title:  relates."
Title:  
Title:  "I know it perfectly, although I am astonished that you know it."
Title:  
Title:  "And will your Grace sign that order without remorse?"
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham looked at the young man haughtily.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know, sir, that you are asking me very strange questions, and
Title:  that I am very foolish to answer them?"
Title:  
Title:  "Reply to them, my Lord," said Felton; "the circumstances are more
Title:  serious than you perhaps believe."
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham reflected that the young man, coming from Lord de Winter,
Title:  undoubtedly spoke in his name, and softened.
Title:  
Title:  "Without remorse," said he.  "The baron knows, as well as myself, that
Title:  Milady de Winter is a very guilty woman, and it is treating her very
Title:  favorably to commute her punishment to transportation."
Title:  The duke put his pen to the paper.
Title:  
Title:  "You will not sign that order, my Lord!" said Felton, making a step
Title:  toward the duke.
Title:  
Title:  "I will not sign this order!  And why not?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because you will look into yourself, and you will do justice to the
Title:  lady."
Title:  
Title:  "I should do her justice by sending her to Tyburn," said Buckingham.
Title:  "This lady is infamous."
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, Milady de Winter is an angel; you know that she is, and I
Title:  demand her liberty of you."
Title:  
Title:  "Bah!  Are you mad, to talk to me thus?" said Buckingham.
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, excuse me!  I speak as I can; I restrain myself.  But, my
Title:  Lord, think of what you're about to do, and beware of going too far!"
Title:  
Title:  "What do you say?  God pardon me!" cried Buckingham, "I really think he
Title:  threatens me!"
Title:  
Title:  "No, my Lord, I still plead.  And I say to you:  one drop of water
Title:  suffices to make the full vase overflow; one slight fault may draw down
Title:  punishment upon the head spared, despite many crimes."
Title:  
Title:  "Mr. Felton," said Buckingham, "you will withdraw, and place yourself at
Title:  once under arrest."
Title:  
Title:  "You will hear me to the end, my Lord.  You have seduced this young
Title:  girl; you have outraged, defiled her.  Repair your crimes toward her;
Title:  let her go free, and I will exact nothing else from you."
Title:  
Title:  "You will exact!" said Buckingham, looking at Felton with astonishment,
Title:  and dwelling upon each syllable of the three words as he pronounced
Title:  them.
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord," continued Felton, becoming more excited as he spoke, "my
Title:  Lord, beware!  All England is tired of your iniquities; my Lord, you
Title:  have abused the royal power, which you have almost usurped; my Lord, you
Title:  are held in horror by God and men.  God will punish you hereafter, but I
Title:  will punish you here!"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, this is too much!" cried Buckingham, making a step toward the door.
Title:  
Title:  Felton barred his passage.
Title:  
Title:  "I ask it humbly of you, my Lord," said he; "sign the order for the
Title:  liberation of Milady de Winter.  Remember that she is a woman whom you
Title:  have dishonored."
Title:  
Title:  "Withdraw, sir," said Buckingham, "or I will call my attendant, and have
Title:  you placed in irons."
Title:  
Title:  "You shall not call," said Felton, throwing himself between the duke and
Title:  the bell placed on a stand encrusted with silver.  "Beware, my Lord, you
Title:  are in the hands of God!"
Title:  
Title:  "In the hands of the devil, you mean!" cried Buckingham, raising his
Title:  voice so as to attract the notice of his people, without absolutely
Title:  shouting.
Title:  
Title:  "Sign, my Lord; sign the liberation of Milady de Winter," said Felton,
Title:  holding out a paper to the duke.
Title:  
Title:  "By force? You are joking!  Holloa, Patrick!"
Title:  
Title:  "Sign, my Lord!"
Title:  
Title:  "Never."
Title:  
Title:  "Never?"
Title:  
Title:  "Help!" shouted the duke; and at the same time he sprang toward his
Title:  sword.
Title:  
Title:  But Felton did not give him time to draw it.  He held the knife with
Title:  which Milady had stabbed herself, open in his bosom; at one bound he was
Title:  upon the duke.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment Patrick entered the room, crying, "A letter from France,
Title:  my Lord."
Title:  
Title:  "From France!" cried Buckingham, forgetting everything in thinking from
Title:  whom that letter came.
Title:  
Title:  Felton took advantage of this moment, and plunged the knife into his
Title:  side up to the handle.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, traitor," cried Buckingham, "you have killed me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Murder!" screamed Patrick.
Title:  
Title:  Felton cast his eyes round for means of escape, and seeing the door
Title:  free, he rushed into the next chamber, in which, as we have said, the
Title:  deputies from La Rochelle were waiting, crossed it as quickly as
Title:  possible, and rushed toward the staircase; but upon the first step he
Title:  met Lord de Winter, who, seeing him pale, confused, livid, and stained
Title:  with blood both on his hands and face, seized him by the throat, crying,
Title:  "I knew it!  I guessed it!  But too late by a minute, unfortunate,
Title:  unfortunate that I am!"
Title:  
Title:  Felton made no resistance.  Lord de Winter placed him in the hands of
Title:  the guards, who led him, while awaiting further orders, to a little
Title:  terrace commanding the sea; and then the baron hastened to the duke's
Title:  chamber.
Title:  
Title:  At the cry uttered by the duke and the scream of Patrick, the man whom
Title:  Felton had met in the antechamber rushed into the chamber.
Title:  
Title:  He found the duke reclining upon a sofa, with his hand pressed upon the
Title:  wound.
Title:  
Title:  "Laporte," said the duke, in a dying voice, "Laporte, do you come from
Title:  her?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur," replied the faithful cloak bearer of Anne of
Title:  Austria, "but too late, perhaps."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, Laporte, you may be overheard.  Patrick, let no one enter.
Title:  Oh, I cannot tell what she says to me!  My God, I am dying!"
Title:  
Title:  And the duke swooned.
Title:  
Title:  Meanwhile, Lord de Winter, the deputies, the leaders of the expedition,
Title:  the officers of Buckingham's household, had all made their way into the
Title:  chamber.  Cries of despair resounded on all sides.  The news, which
Title:  filled the palace with tears and groans, soon became known, and spread
Title:  itself throughout the city.
Title:  
Title:  The report of a cannon announced that something new and unexpected had
Title:  taken place.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter tore his hair.
Title:  
Title:  "Too late by a minute!" cried he, "too late by a minute!  Oh, my God, my
Title:  God!  what a misfortune!"
Title:  
Title:  He had been informed at seven o'clock in the morning that a rope ladder
Title:  floated from one of the windows of the castle; he had hastened to
Title:  Milady's chamber, had found it empty, the window open, and the bars
Title:  filed, had remembered the verbal caution d'Artagnan had transmitted to
Title:  him by his messenger, had trembled for the duke, and running to the
Title:  stable without taking time to have a horse saddled, had jumped upon the
Title:  first he found, had galloped off like the wind, had alighted below in
Title:  the courtyard, had ascended the stairs precipitately, and on the top
Title:  step, as we have said, had encountered Felton.
Title:  
Title:  The duke, however, was not dead.  He recovered a little, reopened his
Title:  eyes, and hope revived in all hearts.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said he, "leave me alone with Patrick and Laporte--ah, is
Title:  that you, de Winter?  You sent me a strange madman this morning!  See
Title:  the state in which he has put me."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my Lord!" cried the baron, "I shall never console myself."
Title:  
Title:  "And you would be quite wrong, my dear de Winter," said Buckingham,
Title:  holding out his hand to him.  "I do not know the man who deserves being
Title:  regretted during the whole life of another man; but leave us, I pray
Title:  you."
Title:  
Title:  The baron went out sobbing.
Title:  
Title:  There only remained in the closet of the wounded duke Laporte and
Title:  Patrick.  A physician was sought for, but none was yet found.
Title:  
Title:  "You will live, my Lord, you will live!" repeated the faithful servant
Title:  of Anne of Austria, on his knees before the duke's sofa.
Title:  
Title:  "What has she written to me?" said Buckingham, feebly, streaming with
Title:  blood, and suppressing his agony to speak of her he loved, "what has she
Title:  written to me?  Read me her letter."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my Lord!" said Laporte.
Title:  
Title:  "Obey, Laporte, do you not see I have no time to lose?"
Title:  
Title:  Laporte broke the seal, and placed the paper before the eyes of the
Title:  duke; but Buckingham in vain tried to make out the writing.
Title:  
Title:  "Read!" said he, "read!  I cannot see.  Read, then!  For soon, perhaps,
Title:  I shall not hear, and I shall die without knowing what she has written
Title:  to me."
Title:  
Title:  Laporte made no further objection, and read:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord, By that which, since I have known you, have suffered by you
Title:  and for you, I conjure you, if you have any care for my repose, to
Title:  countermand those great armaments which you are preparing against
Title:  France, to put an end to a war of which it is publicly said religion is
Title:  the ostensible cause, and of which, it is generally whispered, your love
Title:  for me is the concealed cause.  This war may not only bring great
Title:  catastrophes upon England and France, but misfortune upon you, my Lord,
Title:  for which I should never console myself.
Title:  
Title:  "Be careful of your life, which is menaced, and which will be dear to me
Title:  from the moment I am not obliged to see an enemy in you.
Title:  
Title:  "Your affectionate
Title:  
Title:  "ANNE"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham collected all his remaining strength to listen to the reading
Title:  of the letter; then, when it was ended, as if he had met with a bitter
Title:  disappointment, he asked, "Have you nothing else to say to me by the
Title:  living voice, Laporte?"
Title:  
Title:  "The queen charged me to tell you to watch over yourself, for she had
Title:  advice that your assassination would be attempted."
Title:  
Title:  "And is that all--is that all?" replied Buckingham, impatiently.
Title:  
Title:  "She likewise charged me to tell you that she still loved you."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said Buckingham, "God be praised!  My death, then, will not be to
Title:  her as the death of a stranger!"
Title:  
Title:  Laporte burst into tears.
Title:  
Title:  "Patrick," said the due, "bring me the casket in which the diamond studs
Title:  were kept."
Title:  
Title:  Patrick brought the object desired, which Laporte recognized as having
Title:  belonged to the queen.
Title:  
Title:  "Now the scent bag of white satin, on which her cipher is embroidered in
Title:  pearls."
Title:  
Title:  Patrick again obeyed.
Title:  
Title:  "Here, Laporte," said Buckingham, "these are the only tokens I ever
Title:  received from her--this silver casket and these two letters.  You will
Title:  restore them to her Majesty; and as a last memorial"--he looked round
Title:  for some valuable object--"you will add--"
Title:  
Title:  He still sought; but his eyes, darkened by death, encountered only the
Title:  knife which had fallen from the hand of Felton, still smoking with the
Title:  blood spread over its blade.
Title:  
Title:  "And you will add to them this knife," said the duke, pressing the hand
Title:  of Laporte.  He had just strength enough to place the scent bag at the
Title:  bottom of the silver casket, and to let the knife fall into it, making a
Title:  sign to Laporte that he was no longer able to speak; than, in a last
Title:  convulsion, which this time he had not the power to combat, he slipped
Title:  from the sofa to the floor.
Title:  
Title:  Patrick uttered a loud cry.
Title:  
Title:  Buckingham tried to smile a last time; but death checked his thought,
Title:  which remained engraved on his brow like a last kiss of love.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment the duke's surgeon arrived, quite terrified; he was
Title:  already on board the admiral's ship, where they had been obliged to seek
Title:  him.
Title:  
Title:  He approached the duke, took his hand, held it for an instant in his
Title:  own, and letting it fall, "All is useless," said he, "he is dead."
Title:  
Title:  "Dead, dead!" cried Patrick.
Title:  
Title:  At this cry all the crowd re-entered the apartment, and throughout the
Title:  palace and town there was nothing but consternation and tumult.
Title:  
Title:  As soon as Lord de Winter saw Buckingham was dead, he ran to Felton,
Title:  whom the soldiers still guarded on the terrace of the palace.
Title:  
Title:  "Wretch!" said he to the young man, who since the death of Buckingham
Title:  had regained that coolness and self-possession which never after
Title:  abandoned him, "wretch!  what have you done?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have avenged myself!" said he.
Title:  
Title:  "Avenged yourself," said the baron.  "Rather say that you have served as
Title:  an instrument to that accursed woman; but I swear to you that this crime
Title:  shall be her last."
Title:  
Title:  "I don't know what you mean," replied Felton, quietly, "and I am
Title:  ignorant of whom you are speaking, my Lord.  I killed the Duke of
Title:  Buckingham because he twice refused you yourself to appoint me captain;
Title:  I have punished him for his injustice, that is all."
Title:  
Title:  De Winter, stupefied, looked on while the soldiers bound Felton, and
Title:  could not tell what to think of such insensibility.
Title:  
Title:  One thing alone, however, threw a shade over the pallid brow of Felton.
Title:  At every noise he heard, the simple Puritan fancied he recognized the
Title:  step and voice of Milady coming to throw herself into his arms, to
Title:  accuse herself, and die with him.
Title:  
Title:  All at once he started.  His eyes became fixed upon a point of the sea,
Title:  commanded by the terrace where he was.  With the eagle glance of a
Title:  sailor he had recognized there, where another would have seen only a
Title:  gull hovering over the waves, the sail of a sloop which was directed
Title:  toward the cost of France.
Title:  
Title:  He grew deadly pale, placed his hand upon his heart, which was breaking,
Title:  and at once perceived all the treachery.
Title:  
Title:  "One last favor, my Lord!" said he to the baron.
Title:  
Title:  "What?" asked his Lordship.
Title:  
Title:  "What o'clock is it?"
Title:  
Title:  The baron drew out his watch.  "It wants ten minutes to nine," said he.
Title:  
Title:  Milady had hastened her departure by an hour and a half.  As soon as she
Title:  heard the cannon which announced the fatal event, she had ordered the
Title:  anchor to be weighed.  The vessel was making way under a blue sky, at
Title:  great distance from the coast.
Title:  
Title:  "God has so willed it!" said he, with the resignation of a fanatic; but
Title:  without, however, being able to take his eyes from that ship, on board
Title:  of which he doubtless fancied he could distinguish the white outline of
Title:  her to whom he had sacrificed his life.
Title:  
Title:  De Winter followed his look, observed his feelings, and guessed all.
Title:  
Title:  "Be punished ALONE, for the first, miserable man!" said Lord de Winter
Title:  to Felton, who was being dragged away with his eyes turned toward the
Title:  sea; "but I swear to you by the memory of my brother whom I have loved
Title:  so much that your accomplice is not saved."
Title:  
Title:  Felton lowered his head without pronouncing a syllable.
Title:  
Title:  As to Lord de Winter, he descended the stairs rapidly, and went straight
Title:  to the port.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  60  IN FRANCE
Title:  
Title:  The first fear of the King of England, Charles I, on learning of the
Title:  death of the duke, was that such terrible news might discourage the
Title:  Rochellais; he tried, says Richelieu in his Memoirs, to conceal it from
Title:  them as long as possible, closing all the ports of his kingdom, and
Title:  carefully keeping watch that no vessel should sail until the army which
Title:  Buckingham was getting together had gone, taking upon himself, in
Title:  default of Buckingham, to superintend the departure.
Title:  
Title:  He carried the strictness of this order so far as to detain in England
Title:  the ambassadors of Denmark, who had taken their leave, and the regular
Title:  ambassador of Holland, who was to take back to the port of Flushing the
Title:  Indian merchantmen of which Charles I had made restitution to the United
Title:  Provinces.
Title:  
Title:  But as he did not think of giving this order till five hours after the
Title:  event--that is to say, till two o'clock in the afternoon--two vessels
Title:  had already left the port, the one bearing, as we know, Milady, who,
Title:  already anticipating the event, was further confirmed in that belief by
Title:  seeing the black flag flying at the masthead of the admiral's ship.
Title:  
Title:  As to the second vessel, we will tell hereafter whom it carried, and how
Title:  it set sail.
Title:  
Title:  During this time nothing new occurred in the camp at La Rochelle; only
Title:  the king, who was bored, as always, but perhaps a little more so in camp
Title:  than elsewhere, resolved to go incognito and spend the festival of St.
Title:  Louis at St. Germain, and asked the cardinal to order him an escort of
Title:  only twenty Musketeers.  The cardinal, who sometimes became weary of the
Title:  king, granted this leave of absence with great pleasure to his royal
Title:  lieutenant, who promised to return about the fifteenth of September.
Title:  
Title:  M. de Treville, being informed of this by his Eminence, packed his
Title:  portmanteau; and as without knowing the cause he knew the great desire
Title:  and even imperative need which his friends had of returning to Paris, it
Title:  goes without saying that he fixed upon them to form part of the escort.
Title:  
Title:  The four young men heard the news a quarter of an hour after M. de
Title:  Treville, for they were the first to whom he communicated it.  It was
Title:  then that d'Artagnan appreciated the favor the cardinal had conferred
Title:  upon him in making him at last enter the Musketeers--for without that
Title:  circumstance he would have been forced to remain in the camp while his
Title:  companions left it.
Title:  
Title:  It goes without saying that this impatience to return toward Paris had
Title:  for a cause the danger which Mme. Bonacieux would run of meeting at the
Title:  convent of Bethune with Milady, her mortal enemy.  Aramis therefore had
Title:  written immediately to Marie Michon, the seamstress at Tours who had
Title:  such fine acquaintances, to obtain from the queen authority for Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux to leave the convent, and to retire either into Lorraine or
Title:  Belgium.  They had not long to wait for an answer.  Eight or ten days
Title:  afterward Aramis received the following letter:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  My Dear Cousin, Here is the authorization from my sister to withdraw
Title:  our little servant from the convent of Bethune, the air of which you
Title:  think is bad for her.  My sister sends you this authorization with great
Title:  pleasure, for she is very partial to the little girl, to whom she
Title:  intends to be more serviceable hereafter.
Title:  
Title:  I salute you,
Title:  
Title:  MARIE MICHON
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  To this letter was added an order, conceived in these terms:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  At the Louvre, August 10, 1628
Title:  The superior of the convent of Bethune will place in the hands of the
Title:  person who shall present this note to her the novice who entered the
Title:  convent upon my recommendation and under my patronage.
Title:  
Title:  ANNE
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  It may be easily imagined how the relationship between Aramis and a
Title:  seamstress who called the queen her sister amused the young men; but
Title:  Aramis, after having blushed two or three times up to the whites of his
Title:  eyes at the gross pleasantry of Porthos, begged his friends not to
Title:  revert to the subject again, declaring that if a single word more was
Title:  said to him about it, he would never again implore his cousins to
Title:  interfere in such affairs.
Title:  
Title:  There was no further question, therefore, about Marie Michon among the
Title:  four Musketeers, who besides had what they wanted:  that was, the order
Title:  to withdraw Mme. Bonacieux from the convent of the Carmelites of
Title:  Bethune.  It was true that this order would not be of great use to them
Title:  while they were in camp at La Rochelle; that is to say, at the other end
Title:  of France.  Therefore d'Artagnan was going to ask leave of absence of M.
Title:  de Treville, confiding to him candidly the importance of his departure,
Title:  when the news was transmitted to him as well as to his three friends
Title:  that the king was about to set out for Paris with an escort of twenty
Title:  Musketeers, and that they formed part of the escort.
Title:  
Title:  Their joy was great.  The lackeys were sent on before with the baggage,
Title:  and they set out on the morning of the sixteenth.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal accompanied his Majesty from Surgeres to Mauzes; and there
Title:  the king and his minister took leave of each other with great
Title:  demonstrations of friendship.
Title:  
Title:  The king, however, who sought distraction, while traveling as fast as
Title:  possible--for he was anxious to be in Paris by the twenty-third--stopped
Title:  from time to time to fly the magpie, a pastime for which the taste had
Title:  been formerly inspired in him by de Luynes, and for which he had always
Title:  preserved a great predilection.  Out of the twenty Musketeers sixteen,
Title:  when this took place, rejoiced greatly at this relaxation; but the other
Title:  four cursed it heartily.  D'Artagnan, in particular, had a perpetual
Title:  buzzing in his ears, which Porthos explained thus:  "A very great lady
Title:  has told me that this means that somebody is talking of you somewhere."
Title:  
Title:  At length the escort passed through Paris on the twenty-third, in the
Title:  night.  The king thanked M. de Treville, and permitted him to distribute
Title:  furloughs for four days, on condition that the favored parties should
Title:  not appear in any public place, under penalty of the Bastille.
Title:  
Title:  The first four furloughs granted, as may be imagined, were to our four
Title:  friends.  Still further, Athos obtained of M. de Treville six days
Title:  instead of four, and introduced into these six days two more nights--for
Title:  they set out on the twenty-fourth at five o'clock in the evening, and as
Title:  a further kindness M. de Treville post-dated the leave to the morning of
Title:  the twenty-fifth.
Title:  
Title:  "Good Lord!" said d'Artagnan, who, as we have often said, never stumbled
Title:  at anything.  "It appears to me that we are making a great trouble of a
Title:  very simple thing.  In two days, and by using up two or three horses
Title:  (that's nothing; I have plenty of money), I am at Bethune.  I present my
Title:  letter from the queen to the superior, and I bring back the dear
Title:  treasure I go to seek--not into Lorraine, not into Belgium, but to
Title:  Paris, where she will be much better concealed, particularly while the
Title:  cardinal is at La Rochelle.  Well, once returned from the country, half
Title:  by the protection of her cousin, half through what we have personally
Title:  done for her, we shall obtain from the queen what we desire.  Remain,
Title:  then, where you are, and do not exhaust yourselves with useless fatigue.
Title:  Myself and Planchet are all that such a simple expedition requires."
Title:  
Title:  To this Athos replied quietly:  "We also have money left--for I have not
Title:  yet drunk all my share of the diamond, and Porthos and Aramis have not
Title:  eaten all theirs.  We can therefore use up four horses as well as one.
Title:  But consider, d'Artagnan," added he, in a tone so solemn that it made
Title:  the young man shudder, "consider that Bethune is a city where the
Title:  cardinal has given rendezvous to a woman who, wherever she goes, brings
Title:  misery with her.  If you had only to deal with four men, d'Artagnan, I
Title:  would allow you to go alone.  You have to do with that woman!  We four
Title:  will go; and I hope to God that with our four lackeys we may be in
Title:  sufficient number."
Title:  
Title:  "You terrify me, Athos!"  cried d'Artagnan.  "My God!  what do you
Title:  fear?"
Title:  
Title:  "Everything!" replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan examined the countenances of his companions, which, like that
Title:  of Athos, wore an impression of deep anxiety; and they continued their
Title:  route as fast as their horses could carry them, but without adding
Title:  another word.
Title:  
Title:  On the evening of the twenty-fifth, as they were entering Arras, and as
Title:  d'Artagnan was dismounting at the inn of the Golden Harrow to drink a
Title:  glass of wine, a horseman came out of the post yard, where he had just
Title:  had a relay, started off at a gallop, and with a fresh horse took the
Title:  road to Paris.  At the moment he passed through the gateway into the
Title:  street, the wind blew open the cloak in which he was wrapped, although
Title:  it was in the month of August, and lifted his hat, which the traveler
Title:  seized with his hand the moment it had left his head, pulling it eagerly
Title:  over his eyes.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, who had his eyes fixed upon this man, became very pale, and
Title:  let his glass fall.
Title:  
Title:  "What is the matter, monsieur?"  said Planchet.  "Oh, come, gentlemen,
Title:  my master is ill!"
Title:  
Title:  The three friends hastened toward d'Artagnan, who, instead of being ill,
Title:  ran toward his horse.  They stopped him at the door.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, where the devil are you going now?"  cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "It is he!"  cried d'Artagnan, pale with anger, and with the sweat on his
Title:  brow, "it is he!  let me overtake him!"
Title:  
Title:  "He?  What he?"  asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "He, that man!"
Title:  
Title:  "What man?"
Title:  
Title:  "That cursed man, my evil genius, whom I have always met with when
Title:  threatened by some misfortune, he who accompanied that horrible woman
Title:  when I met her for the first time, he whom I was seeking when I offended
Title:  our Athos, he whom I saw on the very morning Madame Bonacieux was
Title:  abducted.  I have seen him; that is he!  I recognized him when the wind
Title:  blew upon his cloak."
Title:  
Title:  "The devil!"  said Athos, musingly.
Title:  
Title:  "To saddle, gentlemen!  to saddle!  Let us pursue him, and we shall
Title:  overtake him!"
Title:  
Title:  "My dear friend," said Aramis, "remember that he goes in an opposite
Title:  direction from that in which we are going, that he has a fresh horse, and
Title:  ours are fatigued, so that we shall disable our own horses without even
Title:  a chance of overtaking him.  Let the man go, d'Artagnan; let us save the
Title:  woman."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur, monsieur!"  cried a hostler, running out and looking after
Title:  the stranger, "monsieur, here is a paper which dropped out of your hat!
Title:  Eh, monsieur, eh!"
Title:  
Title:  "Friend," said d'Artagnan, "a half-pistole for that paper!"
Title:  
Title:  "My faith, monsieur, with great pleasure!  Here it is!"
Title:  
Title:  The hostler, enchanted with the good day's work he had done, returned to
Title:  the yard.  D'Artagnan unfolded the paper.
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"  eagerly demanded all his three friends.
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing but one word!"  said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Aramis, "but that one word is the name of some town or
Title:  village."
Title:  
Title:  "Armentieres,"  read Porthos; "Armentieres?  I don't know such a
Title:  place."
Title:  
Title:  "And that name of a town or village is written in her hand!" cried
Title:  Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Come on, come on!"  said d'Artagnan; "let us keep that paper carefully,
Title:  perhaps I have not thrown away my half-pistole.  To horse, my friends,
Title:  to horse!"
Title:  
Title:  And the four friends flew at a gallop along the road to Bethune.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  61  THE CARMELITE CONVENT AT BETHUNE
Title:  
Title:  Great criminals bear about them a kind of predestination which makes them
Title:  surmount all obstacles, which makes them escape all dangers, up to the
Title:  moment which a wearied Providence has marked as the rock of their
Title:  impious fortunes.
Title:  
Title:  It was thus with Milady.  She escaped the cruisers of both nations, and
Title:  arrived at Boulogne without accident.
Title:  
Title:  When landing at Portsmouth, Milady was an Englishwoman whom the
Title:  persecutions of the French drove from La Rochelle; when landing at
Title:  Boulogne, after a two days' passage, she passed for a Frenchwoman whom
Title:  the English persecuted at Portsmouth out of their hatred for France.
Title:  
Title:  Milady had, likewise, the best of passports--her beauty, her noble
Title:  appearance, and the liberality with which she distributed her pistoles.
Title:  Freed from the usual formalities by the affable smile and gallant
Title:  manners of an old governor of the port, who kissed her hand, she only
Title:  remained long enough at Boulogne to put into the post a letter,
Title:  conceived in the following terms:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "To his Eminence Monseigneur the Cardinal Richelieu, in his camp before
Title:  La Rochelle.
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur, Let your Eminence be reassured.  His Grace the Duke of
Title:  Buckingham WILL NOT SET OUT for France.
Title:  
Title:  "MILADY DE ----
Title:  
Title:  "BOULOGNE, evening of the twenty-fifth.
Title:  
Title:  "P.S.--According to the desire of your Eminence, I report to the convent
Title:  of the Carmelites at Bethune, where I will await your orders."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  Accordingly, that same evening Milady commenced her journey.  Night
Title:  overtook her; she stopped, and slept at an inn.  At five o'clock the
Title:  next morning she again proceeded, and in three hours after entered
Title:  Bethune.  She inquired for the convent of the Carmelites, and went
Title:  thither immediately.
Title:  
Title:  The superior met her; Milady showed her the cardinal's order.  The
Title:  abbess assigned her a chamber, and had breakfast served.
Title:  
Title:  All the past was effaced from the eyes of this woman; and her looks,
Title:  fixed on the future, beheld nothing but the high fortunes reserved for
Title:  her by the cardinal, whom she had so successfully served without his
Title:  name being in any way mixed up with the sanguinary affair.  The ever-new
Title:  passions which consumed her gave to her life the appearance of those
Title:  clouds which float in the heavens, reflecting sometimes azure, sometimes
Title:  fire, sometimes the opaque blackness of the tempest, and which leave no
Title:  traces upon the earth behind them but devastation and death.
Title:  
Title:  After breakfast, the abbess came to pay her a visit.  There is very
Title:  little amusement in the cloister, and the good superior was eager to
Title:  make the acquaintance of her new boarder.
Title:  
Title:  Milady wished to please the abbess.  This was a very easy matter for a
Title:  woman so really superior as she was.  She tried to be agreeable, and she
Title:  was charming, winning the good superior by her varied conversation and
Title:  by the graces of her whole personality.
Title:  
Title:  The abbess, who was the daughter of a noble house, took particular
Title:  delight in stories of the court, which so seldom travel to the
Title:  extremities of the kingdom, and which, above all, have so much
Title:  difficulty in penetrating the walls of convents, at whose threshold the
Title:  noise of the world dies away.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, on the contrary, was quite conversant with all aristocratic
Title:  intrigues, amid which she had constantly lived for five or six years.
Title:  She made it her business, therefore, to amuse the good abbess with the
Title:  worldly practices of the court of France, mixed with the eccentric
Title:  pursuits of the king; she made for her the scandalous chronicle of the
Title:  lords and ladies of the court, whom the abbess knew perfectly by name,
Title:  touched lightly on the amours of the queen and the Duke of Buckingham,
Title:  talking a great deal to induce her auditor to talk a little.
Title:  
Title:  But the abbess contented herself with listening and smiling without
Title:  replying a word.  Milady, however, saw that this sort of narrative
Title:  amused her very much, and kept at it; only she now let her conversation
Title:  drift toward the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  But she was greatly embarrassed.  She did not know whether the abbess
Title:  was a royalist or a cardinalist; she therefore confined herself to a
Title:  prudent middle course.  But the abbess, on her part, maintained a
Title:  reserve still more prudent, contenting herself with making a profound
Title:  inclination of the head every time the fair traveler pronounced the name
Title:  of his Eminence.
Title:  
Title:  Milady began to think she should soon grow weary of a convent life; she
Title:  resolved, then, to risk something in order that she might know how to
Title:  act afterward.  Desirous of seeing how far the discretion of the good
Title:  abbess would go, she began to tell a story, obscure at first, but very
Title:  circumstantial afterward, about the cardinal, relating the amours of the
Title:  minister with Mme. d'Aiguillon, Marion de Lorme, and several other gay
Title:  women.
Title:  
Title:  The abbess listened more attentively, grew animated by degrees, and
Title:  smiled.
Title:  
Title:  "Good," thought Milady; "she takes a pleasure in my conversation.  If
Title:  she is a cardinalist, she has no fanaticism, at least."
Title:  
Title:  She then went on to describe the persecutions exercised by the cardinal
Title:  upon his enemies.  The abbess only crossed herself, without approving or
Title:  disapproving.
Title:  
Title:  This confirmed Milady in her opinion that the abbess was rather royalist
Title:  than cardinalist.  Milady therefore continued, coloring her narrations
Title:  more and more.
Title:  
Title:  "I am very ignorant of these matters," said the abbess, at length; "but
Title:  however distant from the court we may be, however remote from the
Title:  interests of the world we may be placed, we have very sad examples of
Title:  what you have related.  And one of our boarders has suffered much from
Title:  the vengeance and persecution of the cardinal!"
Title:  
Title:  "One of your boarders?" said Milady; "oh, my God!  Poor woman!  I pity
Title:  her, then."
Title:  
Title:  "And you have reason, for she is much to be pitied.  Imprisonment,
Title:  menaces, ill treatment-she has suffered everything.  But after all,"
Title:  resumed the abbess, "Monsieur Cardinal has perhaps plausible motives for
Title:  acting thus; and though she has the look of an angel, we must not always
Title:  judge people by the appearance."
Title:  
Title:  "Good!" said Milady to herself; "who knows!  I am about, perhaps, to
Title:  discover something here; I am in the vein."
Title:  
Title:  She tried to give her countenance an appearance of perfect candor.
Title:  
Title:  "Alas," said Milady, "I know it is so.  It is said that we must not
Title:  trust to the face; but in what, then, shall we place confidence, if not
Title:  in the most beautiful work of the Lord?  As for me, I shall be deceived
Title:  all my life perhaps, but I shall always have faith in a person whose
Title:  countenance inspires me with sympathy."
Title:  
Title:  "You would, then, be tempted to believe," said the abbess, "that this
Title:  young person is innocent?"
Title:  
Title:  "The cardinal pursues not only crimes," said she:  "there are certain
Title:  virtues which he pursues more severely than certain offenses."
Title:  
Title:  "Permit me, madame, to express my surprise," said the abbess.
Title:  
Title:  "At what?" said Milady, with the utmost ingenuousness.
Title:  
Title:  "At the language you use."
Title:  
Title:  "What do you find so astonishing in that language?" said Milady,
Title:  smiling.
Title:  
Title:  "You are the friend of the cardinal, for he sends you hither, and yet--"
Title:  
Title:  "And yet I speak ill of him," replied Milady, finishing the thought of
Title:  the superior.
Title:  
Title:  "At least you don't speak well of him."
Title:  
Title:  "That is because I am not his friend," said she, sighing, "but his
Title:  victim!"
Title:  
Title:  "But this letter in which he recommends you to me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Is an order for me to confine myself to a sort of prison, from which he
Title:  will release me by one of his satellites."
Title:  
Title:  "But why have you not fled?"
Title:  
Title:  "Whither should I go?  Do you believe there is a spot on the earth which
Title:  the cardinal cannot reach if he takes the trouble to stretch forth his
Title:  hand?  If I were a man, that would barely be possible; but what can a
Title:  woman do?  This young boarder of yours, has she tried to fly?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, that is true; but she--that is another thing; I believe she is
Title:  detained in France by some love affair."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said Milady, with a sigh, "if she loves she is not altogether
Title:  wretched."
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said the abbess, looking at Milady with increasing interest, "I
Title:  behold another poor victim?"
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, yes," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  The abbess looked at her for an instant with uneasiness, as if a fresh
Title:  thought suggested itself to her mind.
Title:  
Title:  "You are not an enemy of our holy faith?" said she, hesitatingly.
Title:  
Title:  "Who--I?"  cried Milady; "I a Protestant?  Oh, no!  I call to witness
Title:  the God who hears us, that on the contrary I am a fervent Catholic!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then, madame," said the abbess, smiling, "be reassured; the house in
Title:  which you are shall not be a very hard prison, and we will do all in our
Title:  power to make you cherish your captivity.  You will find here, moreover,
Title:  the young woman of whom I spoke, who is persecuted, no doubt, in
Title:  consequence of some court intrigue.  She is amiable and well-behaved."
Title:  
Title:  "What is her name?"
Title:  
Title:  "She was sent to me by someone of high rank, under the name of Kitty.  I
Title:  have not tried to discover her other name."
Title:  
Title:  "Kitty!"  cried Milady.  "What?  Are you sure?"
Title:  
Title:  "That she is called so?  Yes, madame.  Do you know her?"
Title:  
Title:  Milady smiled to herself at the idea which had occurred to her that this
Title:  might be her old chambermaid.  There was connected with the remembrance
Title:  of this girl a remembrance of anger; and a desire of vengeance
Title:  disordered the features of Milady, which, however, immediately recovered
Title:  the calm and benevolent expression which this woman of a hundred faces
Title:  had for a moment allowed them to lose.
Title:  
Title:  "And when can I see this young lady, for whom I already feel so great a
Title:  sympathy?"  asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, this evening," said the abbess; "today even.  But you have been
Title:  traveling these four days, as you told me yourself.  This morning you
Title:  rose at five o'clock; you must stand in need of repose.  Go to bed and
Title:  sleep; at dinnertime we will rouse you."
Title:  
Title:  Although Milady would very willingly have gone without sleep, sustained
Title:  as she was by all the excitements which a new adventure awakened in her
Title:  heart, ever thirsting for intrigues, she nevertheless accepted the offer
Title:  of the superior.  During the last fifteen days she had experienced so
Title:  many and such various emotions that if her frame of iron was still
Title:  capable of supporting fatigue, her mind required repose.
Title:  
Title:  She therefore took leave of the abbess, and went to bed, softly rocked
Title:  by the ideas of vengeance which the name of Kitty had naturally brought
Title:  to her thoughts.  She remembered that almost unlimited promise which the
Title:  cardinal had given her if she succeeded in her enterprise.  She had
Title:  succeeded; d'Artagnan was then in her power!
Title:  
Title:  One thing alone frightened her; that was the remembrance of her husband,
Title:  the Comte de la Fere, whom she had believed dead, or at least
Title:  expatriated, and whom she found again in Athos-the best friend of
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  But alas, if he was the friend of d'Artagnan, he must have lent him his
Title:  assistance in all the proceedings by whose aid the queen had defeated
Title:  the project of his Eminence; if he was the friend of d'Artagnan, he was
Title:  the enemy of the cardinal; and she doubtless would succeed in involving
Title:  him in the vengeance by which she hoped to destroy the young Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  All these hopes were so many sweet thoughts for Milady; so, rocked by
Title:  them, she soon fell asleep.
Title:  
Title:  She was awakened by a soft voice which sounded at the foot of her bed.
Title:  She opened her eyes, and saw the abbess, accompanied by a young woman
Title:  with light hair and delicate complexion, who fixed upon her a look full
Title:  of benevolent curiosity.
Title:  
Title:  The face of the young woman was entirely unknown to her.  Each examined
Title:  the other with great attention, while exchanging the customary
Title:  compliments; both were very handsome, but of quite different styles of
Title:  beauty.  Milady, however, smiled in observing that she excelled the
Title:  young woman by far in her high air and aristocratic bearing.  It is true
Title:  that the habit of a novice, which the young woman wore, was not very
Title:  advantageous in a contest of this kind.
Title:  
Title:  The abbess introduced them to each other.  When this formality was
Title:  ended, as her duties called her to chapel, she left the two young women
Title:  alone.
Title:  
Title:  The novice, seeing Milady in bed, was about to follow the example of
Title:  the superior; but Milady stopped her.
Title:  
Title:  "How, madame," said she, "I have scarcely seen you, and you already
Title:  wish to deprive me of your company, upon which I had counted a little, I
Title:  must confess, for the time I have to pass here?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, madame," replied the novice, "only I thought I had chosen my time
Title:  ill; you were asleep, you are fatigued."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Milady, "what can those who sleep wish for--a happy
Title:  awakening?  This awakening you have given me; allow me, then, to enjoy
Title:  it at my ease," and taking her hand, she drew her toward the armchair by

Title:  
Title:  The novice sat down.
Title:  
Title:  "How unfortunate I am!" said she; "I have been here six months without

Title:  afford me delightful company; yet I expect, in all probability, to quit

Title:  
Title:  "How, you are going soon?"  asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "At least I hope so," said the novice, with an expression of joy which
Title:  she made no effort to disguise.
Title:  
Title:  "I think I learned you had suffered persecutions from the cardinal,"
Title:  continued Milady; "that would have been another motive for sympathy
Title:  between us."
Title:  
Title:  "What I have heard, then, from our good mother is true; you have
Title:  likewise been a victim of that wicked priest."
Title:  
Title:  "Hush!"  said Milady; "let us not, even here, speak thus of him.  All my
Title:  misfortunes arise from my having said nearly what you have said before a
Title:  woman whom I thought my friend, and who betrayed me.  Are you also the
Title:  victim of a treachery?"
Title:  
Title:  "No," said the novice, "but of my devotion--of a devotion to a woman I
Title:  loved, for whom I would have laid down my life, for whom I would give it

Title:  
Title:  "And who has abandoned you--is that it?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have been sufficiently unjust to believe so; but during the last two
Title:  or three days I have obtained proof to the contrary, for which I thank

Title:  But you, madame, you appear to be free," continued the novice; "and if
Title:  you were inclined to fly it only rests with yourself to do so."
Title:  
Title:  "Whither would you have me go, without friends, without money, in a part

Title:  
Title:  "Oh," cried the novice, "as to friends, you would have them wherever you
Title:  want, you appear so good and are so beautiful!"
Title:  
Title:  "That does not prevent," replied Milady, softening her smile so as to

Title:  
Title:  "Hear me," said the novice; "we must trust in heaven.  There always

Title:  am, that you have met with me, for if I leave this place, well-I have

Title:  
Title:  "Oh, when I said I was alone," said Milady, hoping to make the novice

Title:  places; but these friends themselves tremble before the cardinal.  The

Title:  proof that her Majesty, notwithstanding her excellent heart, has more
Title:  than once been obliged to abandon to the anger of his Eminence persons
Title:  who had served her."
Title:  
Title:  "Trust me, madame; the queen may appear to have abandoned those persons,
Title:  but we must not put faith in appearances.  The more they are persecuted,
Title:  the more she thinks of them; and often, when they least expect it, they
Title:  have proof of a kind remembrance."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas!"  said Milady, "I believe so; the queen is so good!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you know her, then, that lovely and noble queen, that you speak of

Title:  
Title:  "That is to say," replied Milady, driven into her entrenchment, "that I
Title:  have not the honor of knowing her personally; but I know a great number
Title:  of her most intimate friends.  I am acquainted with Monsieur de Putange;

Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur de Treville!"  exclaimed the novice, "do you know Monsieur de

Title:  
Title:  "Yes, perfectly well--intimately even."
Title:  
Title:  "The captain of the king's Musketeers?"
Title:  
Title:  "The captain of the king's Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  "Why, then, only see!"  cried the novice; "we shall soon be well
Title:  acquainted, almost friends.  If you know Monsieur de Treville, you must

Title:  
Title:  "Often!"  said Milady, who, having entered this track, and perceiving

Title:  "Name a few of those whom you know, and you will see if they are my

Title:  
Title:  "Well!"  said Milady, embarrassed, "I know Monsieur de Louvigny,

Title:  The novice let her speak, then seeing that she paused, she said, "Don't

Title:  
Title:  Milady became as pale as the sheets in which she was lying, and mistress

Title:  
Title:  "What is the matter?  Good God!"  asked the poor woman, "have I said

Title:  
Title:  "No; but the name struck me, because I also have known that gentleman,

Title:  "Oh, yes, very well; not only him, but some of his friends, Messieurs

Title:  "Indeed!  you know them likewise?  I know them," cried Milady, who began

Title:  
Title:  "Well, if you know them, you know that they are good and free

Title:  "That is to say," stammered Milady, "I am not really very intimate with

Title:  
Title:  Then remarking the strange expression of Milady's countenance, she said,

Title:  "Why," replied Milady, embarrassed, "why, by the title of friend."

Title:  "You deceive me, madame," said the novice; "you have been his mistress!"
Title:  
Title:  "It is you who have been his mistress, madame!"  cried Milady, in her
Title:  turn.
Title:  
Title:  "I?"  said the novice.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, you!  I know you now.  You are Madame Bonacieux!"
Title:  
Title:  The young woman drew back, filled with surprise and terror.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, do not deny it!  Answer!" continued Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, yes, madame," said the novice, "Are we rivals?"
Title:  
Title:  The countenance of Milady was illumined by so savage a joy that under
Title:  any other circumstances Mme. Bonacieux would have fled in terror; but
Title:  she was absorbed by jealousy.
Title:  
Title:  "Speak, madame!"  resumed Mme. Bonacieux, with an energy of which she

Title:  mistress?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, no!"  cried Milady, with an accent that admitted no doubt of her
Title:  truth.  "Never, never!"
Title:

Title:  so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you not understand?" said Milady, who had already overcome her
Title:  agitation and recovered all her presence of mind.
Title:  
Title:  "How can I understand?  I know nothing."
Title:  
Title:  "Can you not understand that Monsieur d'Artagnan, being my friend, might
Title:  take me into his confidence?"
Title:  
Title:  "Truly?"

Title:  
Title:  And Milady stretched out her arms to Mme. Bonacieux, who, convinced by

Title:  she had believed her rival but a sincere and devoted friend.

Title:  Milady.  "Pardon me, I love him so much!"
Title:  
Title:  These two women held each other for an instant in a close embrace.
Title:  Certainly, if Milady's strength had been equal to her hatred, Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux would never have left that embrace alive.  But not being able
Title:  to stifle her, she smiled upon her.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, you beautiful, good little creature!"  said Milady.  "How delighted

Title:  words, she absolutely devoured her by her looks.  "Oh, yes it is you

Title:  
Title:  The poor young woman could not possibly suspect what frightful cruelty
Title:  was behind the rampart of that pure brow, behind those brilliant eyes in
Title:  which she read nothing but interest and compassion.
Title:  
Title:  "Then you know what I have suffered," said Mme. Bonacieux, "since he
Title:  has told you what he has suffered; but to suffer for him is happiness."
Title:  
Title:  Milady replied mechanically, "Yes, that is happiness."  She was thinking
Title:  of something else.
Title:  
Title:  "And then," continued Mme. Bonacieux, "my punishment is drawing to a

Title:  the past will no longer exist."
Title:  
Title:  "This evening?"  asked Milady, roused from her reverie by these words.

Title:  
Title:  "I expect himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Himself?  D'Artagnan here?"
Title:  
Title:  "Himself!"
Title:  
Title:  "But that's impossible!  He is at the siege of La Rochelle with the

Title:  "Ah, you fancy so!  But is there anything impossible for my d'Artagnan,

Title:  "Oh, I cannot believe you!"
Title:  
Title:  "Well, read, then!" said the unhappy young woman, in the excess of her

Title:

Title:

Title:  departure, and never despair of us.
Title:

Title:  "No, I only suspect he has warned the queen against some fresh
Title:  machinations of the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, that's it, no doubt!" said Milady, returning the letter to Mme.
