Title:  
Title:  "You talk very comfortably,--a hundred and eighty leagues!"
Title:  
Title:  "What's that?"
Title:  
Title:  "One can do it!  Afterward?"
Title:  
Title:  "Afterward?  Why, in passing through Lilliers you will send me your
Title:  chaise, with an order to your servant to place himself at my disposal."
Title:  
Title:  "Well."
Title:  
Title:  "You have, no doubt, some order from the cardinal about you?"
Title:  
Title:  "I have my FULL POWER."
Title:  
Title:  "Show it to the abbess, and tell her that someone will come and fetch
Title:  me, either today or tomorrow, and that I am to follow the person who
Title:  presents himself in your name."
Title:  
Title:  "Very well."
Title:  
Title:  "Don't forget to treat me harshly in speaking of me to the abbess."
Title:  
Title:  "To what purpose?"
Title:  
Title:  "I am a victim of the cardinal.  It is necessary to inspire confidence
Title:  in that poor little Madame Bonacieux."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true.  Now, will you make me a report of all that has happened?"
Title:  
Title:  "Why, I have related the events to you.  You have a good memory; repeat
Title:  what I have told you.  A paper may be lost."
Title:  
Title:  "You are right; only let me know where to find you that I may not run
Title:  needlessly about the neighborhood."
Title:  
Title:  "That's correct; wait!"
Title:  
Title:  "Do you want a map?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I know this country marvelously!"
Title:  
Title:  "You?  When were you here?"
Title:  
Title:  "I was brought up here."
Title:  
Title:  "Truly?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is worth something, you see, to have been brought up somewhere."
Title:  
Title:  "You will wait for me, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Let me reflect a little!  Ay, that will do--at Armentieres."
Title:  
Title:  "Where is that Armentieres?"
Title:  
Title:  "A little town on the Lys; I shall only have to cross the river, and I
Title:  shall be in a foreign country."
Title:  
Title:  "Capital!  but it is understood you will only cross the river in case of
Title:  danger."
Title:  
Title:  "That is well understood."
Title:  
Title:  "And in that case, how shall I know where you are?"
Title:  
Title:  "You do not want your lackey?"
Title:  
Title:  "Is he a sure man?"
Title:  
Title:  "To the proof."
Title:  
Title:  "Give him to me. Nobody knows him.  I will leave him at the place I
Title:  quit, and he will conduct you to me."
Title:  
Title:  "And you say you will wait for me at Armentieres?"
Title:  
Title:  "At Armentieres."
Title:  
Title:  "Write that name on a bit of paper, lest I should forget it.  There is
Title:  nothing compromising in the name of a town.  Is it not so?"
Title:  
Title:  "Eh, who knows?  Never mind," said Milady, writing the name on half a
Title:  sheet of paper; "I will compromise myself."
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said Rochefort, taking the paper from Milady, folding it, and
Title:  placing it in the lining of his hat, "you may be easy.  I will do as
Title:  children do, for fear of losing the paper--repeat the name along the
Title:  route.  Now, is that all?"
Title:  
Title:  "I believe so."
Title:  
Title:  "Let us see:  Buckingham dead or grievously wounded; your conversation
Title:  with the cardinal overheard by the four Musketeers; Lord de Winter
Title:  warned of your arrival at Portsmouth; d'Artagnan and Athos to the
Title:  Bastille; Aramis the lover of Madame de Chevreuse; Porthos an ass;
Title:  Madame Bonacieux found again; to send you the chaise as soon as
Title:  possible; to place my lackey at your disposal; to make you out a victim
Title:  of the cardinal in order that the abbess may entertain no suspicion;
Title:  Armentieres, on the banks of the Lys. Is that all, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "In truth, my dear Chevalier, you are a miracle of memory.  A PROPOS,
Title:  add one thing--"
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "I saw some very pretty woods which almost touch the convent garden.
Title:  Say that I am permitted to walk in those woods.  Who knows?  Perhaps I
Title:  shall stand in need of a back door for retreat."
Title:  
Title:  "You think of everything."
Title:  
Title:  "And you forget one thing."
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "To ask me if I want money."
Title:  
Title:  "That's true.  How much do you want?"
Title:  
Title:  "All you have in gold."
Title:  
Title:  "I have five hundred pistoles, or thereabouts."
Title:  
Title:  "I have as much.  With a thousand pistoles one may face everything.
Title:  Empty your pockets."
Title:  
Title:  "There."
Title:  
Title:  "Right.  And you go--"
Title:  
Title:  "In an hour--time to eat a morsel, during which I shall send for a post
Title:  horse."
Title:  
Title:  "Capital!  Adieu, Chevalier."
Title:  
Title:  "Adieu, Countess."
Title:  
Title:  "Commend me to the cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "Commend me to Satan."
Title:  
Title:  Milady and Rochefort exchanged a smile and separated.  An hour afterward
Title:  Rochefort set out at a grand gallop; five hours after that he passed
Title:  through Arras.
Title:  
Title:  Our readers already know how he was recognized by d'Artagnan, and how
Title:  that recognition by inspiring fear in the four Musketeers had given
Title:  fresh activity to their journey.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  63  THE DROP OF WATER
Title:  
Title:  Rochefort had scarcely departed when Mme. Bonacieux re-entered.  She
Title:  found Milady with a smiling countenance.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said the young woman, "what you dreaded has happened.  This
Title:  evening, or tomorrow, the cardinal will send someone to take you away."
Title:  
Title:  "Who told you that, my dear?"  asked Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "I heard it from the mouth of the messenger himself."
Title:  
Title:  "Come and sit down close to me," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Here I am."
Title:  
Title:  "Wait till I assure myself that nobody hears us."
Title:  
Title:  "Why all these precautions?"
Title:  
Title:  "You shall know."
Title:  
Title:  Milady arose, went to the door, opened it, looked in the corridor, and
Title:  then returned and seated herself close to Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," said she, "he has well played his part."
Title:  
Title:  "Who has?"
Title:  
Title:  "He who just now presented himself to the abbess as a messenger from the
Title:  cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "It was, then, a part he was playing?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, my child."
Title:  
Title:  "That man, then, was not--"
Title:  
Title:  "That man," said Milady, lowering her voice, "is my brother."
Title:  
Title:  "Your brother!"  cried Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  "No one must know this secret, my dear, but yourself.  If you reveal it
Title:  to anyone in the world, I shall be lost, and perhaps yourself likewise."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!"
Title:  
Title:  "Listen.  This is what has happened:  My brother, who was coming to my
Title:  assistance to take me away by force if it were necessary, met with the
Title:  emissary of the cardinal, who was coming in search of me.  He followed
Title:  him.  At a solitary and retired part of the road he drew his sword, and
Title:  required the messenger to deliver up to him the papers of which he was
Title:  the bearer.  The messenger resisted; my brother killed him."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh!" said Mme. Bonacieux, shuddering.
Title:  
Title:  "Remember, that was the only means.  Then my brother determined to
Title:  substitute cunning for force.  He took the papers, and presented himself
Title:  here as the emissary of the cardinal, and in an hour or two a carriage
Title:  will come to take me away by the orders of his Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  "I understand.  It is your brother who sends this carriage."
Title:  
Title:  "Exactly; but that is not all.  That letter you have received, and
Title:  which you believe to be from Madame de Chevreuse--"
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is a forgery."
Title:  
Title:  "How can that be?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, a forgery; it is a snare to prevent your making any resistance
Title:  when they come to fetch you."
Title:  
Title:  "But it is d'Artagnan that will come."
Title:  
Title:  "Do not deceive yourself.  D'Artagnan and his friends are detained at the
Title:  siege of La Rochelle."
Title:  
Title:  "How do you know that?"
Title:  
Title:  "My brother met some emissaries of the cardinal in the uniform of
Title:  Musketeers.  You would have been summoned to the gate; you would have
Title:  believed yourself about to meet friends; you would have been abducted,
Title:  and conducted back to Paris."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!  My senses fail me amid such a chaos of iniquities. I feel,
Title:  if this continues," said Mme. Bonacieux, raising her hands to her
Title:  forehead, "I shall go mad!"
Title:  
Title:  "Stop--"
Title:  
Title:  "What?"
Title:  
Title:  "I hear a horse's steps; it is my brother setting off again.  I should
Title:  like to offer him a last salute.  Come!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady opened the window, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to join her.
Title:  The young woman complied.
Title:  
Title:  Rochefort passed at a gallop.
Title:  
Title:  "Adieu, brother!" cried Milady.
Title:  
Title:  The chevalier raised his head, saw the two young women, and without
Title:  stopping, waved his hand in a friendly way to Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "The good George!"  said she, closing the window with an expression of
Title:  countenance full of affection and melancholy.  And she resumed her seat,
Title:  as if plunged in reflections entirely personal.
Title:  
Title:  "Dear lady," said Mme. Bonacieux, "pardon me for interrupting you; but
Title:  what do you advise me to do?  Good heaven!  You have more experience
Title:  than I have.  Speak; I will listen."
Title:  
Title:  "In the first place," said Milady, "it is possible I may be deceived,
Title:  and that d'Artagnan and his friends may really come to your assistance."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, that would be too much!"  cried Mme. Bonacieux, "so much happiness
Title:  is not in store for me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Then you comprehend it would be only a question of time, a sort of
Title:  race, which should arrive first.  If your friends are the more speedy,
Title:  you are to be saved; if the satellites of the cardinal, you are lost."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, yes; lost beyond redemption!  What, then, to do?  What to do?"
Title:  
Title:  "There would be a very simple means, very natural--"
Title:  
Title:  "Tell me what!"
Title:  
Title:  "To wait, concealed in the neighborhood, and assure yourself who are the
Title:  men who come to ask for you."
Title:  
Title:  "But where can I wait?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, there is no difficulty in that.  I shall stop and conceal myself a
Title:  few leagues hence until my brother can rejoin me.  Well, I take you with
Title:  me; we conceal ourselves, and wait together."
Title:  
Title:  "But I shall not be allowed to go; I am almost a prisoner."
Title:  
Title:  "As they believe that I go in consequence of an order from the cardinal,
Title:  no one will believe you anxious to follow me."
Title:  
Title:  "Well?"
Title:  
Title:  "Well!  The carriage is at the door; you bid me adieu; you mount the
Title:  step to embrace me a last time; my brother's servant, who comes to fetch
Title:  me, is told how to proceed; he makes a sign to the postillion, and we
Title:  set off at a gallop."
Title:  
Title:  "But d'Artagnan!  D'Artagnan!  if he comes?"
Title:  
Title:  "Shall we not know it?"
Title:  
Title:  "How?"
Title:  
Title:  "Nothing easier.  We will send my brother's servant back to Bethune,
Title:  whom, as I told you, we can trust.  He shall assume a disguise, and
Title:  place himself in front of the convent.  If the emissaries of the
Title:  cardinal arrive, he will take no notice; if it is Monsieur d'Artagnan
Title:  and his friends, he will bring them to us."
Title:  
Title:  "He knows them, then?"
Title:  
Title:  "Doubtless.  Has he not seen Monsieur d'Artagnan at my house?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes, yes; you are right.  Thus all may go well--all may be for the
Title:  best; but we do not go far from this place?"
Title:  
Title:  "Seven or eight leagues at the most.  We will keep on the frontiers, for
Title:  instance; and at the first alarm we can leave France."
Title:  
Title:  "And what can we do there?"
Title:  
Title:  "Wait."
Title:  
Title:  "But if they come?"
Title:  
Title:  "My brother's carriage will be here first."
Title:  
Title:  "If I should happen to be any distance from you when the carriage comes
Title:  for you--at dinner or supper, for instance?"
Title:  
Title:  "Do one thing."
Title:  
Title:  "What is that?"
Title:  
Title:  "Tell your good superior that in order that we may be as much together
Title:  as possible, you ask her permission to share my repast."
Title:  
Title:  "Will she permit it?"
Title:  
Title:  "What inconvenience can it be?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, delightful!  In this way we shall not be separated for an instant."
Title:  
Title:  "Well, go down to her, then, to make your request.  I feel my head a
Title:  little confused; I will take a turn in the garden."
Title:  
Title:  "Go and where shall I find you?"
Title:  
Title:  "Here, in an hour."
Title:  
Title:  "Here, in an hour.  Oh, you are so kind, and I am so grateful!"
Title:  
Title:  "How can I avoid interesting myself for one who is so beautiful and so
Title:  amiable? Are you not the beloved of one of my best friends?"
Title:  
Title:  "Dear d'Artagnan!  Oh, how he will thank you!"
Title:  
Title:  "I hope so.  Now, then, all is agreed; let us go down."
Title:  
Title:  "You are going into the garden?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes."
Title:  
Title:  "Go along this corridor, down a little staircase, and you are in it."
Title:  
Title:  "Excellent; thank you!"
Title:  
Title:  And the two women parted, exchanging charming smiles.
Title:  
Title:  Milady had told the truth--her head was confused, for her ill-arranged
Title:  plans clashed one another like chaos.  She required to be alone that
Title:  she might put her thoughts a little into order.  She saw vaguely the
Title:  future; but she stood in need of a little silence and quiet to give all
Title:  her ideas, as yet confused, a distinct form and a regular plan.
Title:  
Title:  What was most pressing was to get Mme. Bonacieux away, and convey her to
Title:  a place of safety, and there, if matters required, make her a hostage.
Title:  Milady began to have doubts of the issue of this terrible duel, in which
Title:  her enemies showed as much perseverance as she did animosity.
Title:  
Title:  Besides, she felt as we feel when a storm is coming on--that this issue
Title:  was near, and could not fail to be terrible.
Title:  
Title:  The principal thing for her, then, was, as we have said, to keep Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux in her power.  Mme. Bonacieux was the very life of d'Artagnan.
Title:  This was more than his life, the life of the woman he loved; this was,
Title:  in case of ill fortune, a means of temporizing and obtaining good
Title:  conditions.
Title:  
Title:  Now, this point was settled; Mme. Bonacieux, without any suspicion,
Title:  accompanied her.  Once concealed with her at Armentieres, it would be
Title:  easy to make her believe that d'Artagnan had not come to Bethune.  In
Title:  fifteen days at most, Rochefort would be back; besides, during that
Title:  fifteen days she would have time to think how she could best avenge
Title:  herself on the four friends.  She would not be weary, thank God!  for
Title:  she should enjoy the sweetest pastime such events could accord a woman
Title:  of her character--perfecting a beautiful vengeance.
Title:  
Title:  Revolving all this in her mind, she cast her eyes around her, and
Title:  arranged the topography of the garden in her head.  Milady was like a
Title:  good general who contemplates at the same time victory and defeat, and
Title:  who is quite prepared, according to the chances of the battle, to march
Title:  forward or to beat a retreat.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of an hour she heard a soft voice calling her; it was Mme.
Title:  Bonacieux's.  The good abbess had naturally consented to her request;
Title:  and as a commencement, they were to sup together.
Title:  
Title:  On reaching the courtyard, they heard the noise of a carriage which
Title:  stopped at the gate.
Title:  
Title:  Milady listened.
Title:  
Title:  "Do you hear anything?"  said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, the rolling of a carriage."
Title:  
Title:  "It is the one my brother sends for us."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!"
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come!  courage!"
Title:  
Title:  The bell of the convent gate was sounded; Milady was not mistaken.
Title:  
Title:  "Go to your chamber," said she to Mme. Bonacieux; "you have perhaps some
Title:  jewels you would like to take."
Title:  
Title:  "I have his letters," said she.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, go and fetch them, and come to my apartment.  We will snatch some
Title:  supper; we shall perhaps travel part of the night, and must keep our
Title:  strength up."
Title:  
Title:  "Great God!"  said Mme. Bonacieux, placing her hand upon her bosom, "my
Title:  heart beats so I cannot walk."
Title:  
Title:  "Courage, courage!  remember that in a quarter of an hour you will be
Title:  safe; and think that what you are about to do is for HIS sake."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, everything for him.  You have restored my courage by a single
Title:  word; go, I will rejoin you."
Title:  
Title:  Milady ran up to her apartment quickly; she there found Rochefort's
Title:  lackey, and gave him his instructions.
Title:  
Title:  He was to wait at the gate; if by chance the Musketeers should appear,
Title:  the carriage was to set off as fast as possible, pass around the
Title:  convent, and go and wait for Milady at a little village which was
Title:  situated at the other side of the wood.  In this case Milady would cross
Title:  the garden and gain the village on foot.  As we have already said,
Title:  Milady was admirably acquainted with this part of France.
Title:  
Title:  If the Musketeers did not appear, things were to go on as had been
Title:  agreed; Mme. Bonacieux was to get into the carriage as if to bid her
Title:  adieu, and she was to take away Mme. Bonacieux.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux came in; and to remove all suspicion, if she had any,
Title:  Milady repeated to the lackey, before her, the latter part of her
Title:  instructions.
Title:  
Title:  Milady asked some questions about the carriage.  It was a chaise drawn
Title:  by three horses, driven by a postillion; Rochefort's lackey would
Title:  precede it, as courier.
Title:  
Title:  Milady was wrong in fearing that Mme. Bonacieux would have any
Title:  suspicion.  The poor young woman was too pure to suppose that any female
Title:  could be guilty of such perfidy; besides, the name of the Comtesse de
Title:  Winter, which she had heard the abbess pronounce, was wholly unknown to
Title:  her, and she was even ignorant that a woman had had so great and so
Title:  fatal a share in the misfortune of her life.
Title:  
Title:  "You see," said she, when the lackey had gone out, "everything is ready.
Title:  The abbess suspects nothing, and believes that I am taken by order of
Title:  the cardinal.  This man goes to give his last orders; take the least
Title:  thing, drink a finger of wine, and let us be gone."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said Mme. Bonacieux, mechanically, "yes, let us be gone."
Title:  
Title:  Milady made her a sign to sit down opposite, poured her a small glass of
Title:  Spanish wine, and helped her to the wing of a chicken.
Title:  
Title:  "See," said she, "if everything does not second us!  Here is night
Title:  coming on; by daybreak we shall have reached our retreat, and nobody can
Title:  guess where we are.  Come, courage!  take something."
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux ate a few mouthfuls mechanically, and just touched the
Title:  glass with her lips.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, come!"  said Milady, lifting hers to her mouth, "do as I do."
Title:  
Title:  But at the moment the glass touched her lips, her hand remained
Title:  suspended; she heard something on the road which sounded like the
Title:  rattling of a distant gallop.  Then it grew nearer, and it seemed to
Title:  her, almost at the same time, that she heard the neighing of horses.
Title:  
Title:  This noise acted upon her joy like the storm which awakens the sleeper
Title:  in the midst of a happy dream; she grew pale and ran to the window,
Title:  while Mme. Bonacieux, rising all in a tremble, supported herself upon
Title:  her chair to avoid falling.  Nothing was yet to be seen, only they heard
Title:  the galloping draw nearer.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!"  said Mme. Bonacieux, "what is that noise?"
Title:  
Title:  "That of either our friends or our enemies," said Milady, with her
Title:  terrible coolness.  "Stay where you are, I will tell you."
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux remained standing, mute, motionless, and pale as a
Title:  statue.
Title:  
Title:  The noise became louder; the horses could not be more than a hundred and
Title:  fifty paces distant.  If they were not yet to be seen, it was because
Title:  the road made an elbow.  The noise became so distinct that the horses
Title:  might be counted by the rattle of their hoofs.
Title:  
Title:  Milady gazed with all the power of her attention; it was just light
Title:  enough for her to see who was coming.
Title:  
Title:  All at once, at the turning of the road she saw the glitter of laced
Title:  hats and the waving of feathers; she counted two, then five, then eight
Title:  horsemen.  One of them preceded the rest by double the length of his
Title:  horse.
Title:  
Title:  Milady uttered a stifled groan.  In the first horseman she recognized
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God," cried Mme. Bonacieux, "what is it?"
Title:  
Title:  "It is the uniform of the cardinal's Guards.  Not an instant to be lost!
Title:  Fly, fly!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, let us fly!"  repeated Mme. Bonacieux, but without being able
Title:  to make a step, glued as she was to the spot by terror.
Title:  
Title:  They heard the horsemen pass under the windows.
Title:  
Title:  "Come, then, come, then!"  cried Milady, trying to drag the young woman
Title:  along by the arm. "Thanks to the garden, we yet can flee; I have the
Title:  key, but make haste!  in five minutes it will be too late!"
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux tried to walk, made two steps, and sank upon her knees.
Title:  Milady tried to raise and carry her, but could not do it.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment they heard the rolling of the carriage, which at the
Title:  approach of the Musketeers set off at a gallop.  Then three or four
Title:  shots were fired.
Title:  
Title:  "For the last time, will you come?"  cried Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God, my God!  you see my strength fails me; you see plainly I
Title:  cannot walk.  Flee alone!"
Title:  
Title:  "Flee alone, and leave you here?  No, no, never!"  cried Milady.
Title:  
Title:  All at once she paused, a livid flash darted from her eyes; she ran to
Title:  the table, emptied into Mme. Bonacieux's glass the contents of a ring
Title:  which she opened with singular quickness.  It was a grain of a reddish
Title:  color, which dissolved immediately.
Title:  
Title:  Then, taking the glass with a firm hand, she said, "Drink.  This wine
Title:  will give you strength, drink!"  And she put the glass to the lips of
Title:  the young woman, who drank mechanically.
Title:  
Title:  "This is not the way that I wished to avenge myself," said Milady,
Title:  replacing the glass upon the table, with an infernal smile, "but, my
Title:  faith!  we do what we can!"  And she rushed out of the room.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux saw her go without being able to follow her; she was like
Title:  people who dream they are pursued, and who in vain try to walk.
Title:  
Title:  A few moments passed; a great noise was heard at the gate.  Every
Title:  instant Mme. Bonacieux expected to see Milady, but she did not return.
Title:  Several times, with terror, no doubt, the cold sweat burst from her
Title:  burning brow.
Title:  
Title:  At length she heard the grating of the hinges of the opening gates; the
Title:  noise of boots and spurs resounded on the stairs.  There was a great
Title:  murmur of voices which continued to draw near, amid which she seemed to
Title:  hear her own name pronounced.
Title:  
Title:  All at once she uttered a loud cry of joy, and darted toward the door;
Title:  she had recognized the voice of d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan!  D'Artagnan!"  cried she, "is it you?  This way!  this
Title:  way!"
Title:  
Title:  "Constance?  Constance?"  replied the young man, "where are you? where
Title:  are you?  My God!"
Title:  
Title:  At the same moment the door of the cell yielded to a shock, rather than
Title:  opened; several men rushed into the chamber.  Mme. Bonacieux had sunk
Title:  into an armchair, without the power of moving.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan threw down a yet-smoking pistol which he held in his hand,
Title:  and fell on his knees before his mistress.  Athos replaced his in his
Title:  belt; Porthos and Aramis, who held their drawn swords in their hands,
Title:  returned them to their scabbards.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, d'Artagnan, my beloved d'Artagnan!  You have come, then, at last!
Title:  You have not deceived me!  It is indeed thee!"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes, Constance.  Reunited!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, it was in vain she told me you would not come!  I hoped in silence.
Title:  I was not willing to fly.  Oh, I have done well!  How happy I am!"
Title:  
Title:  At this word SHE, Athos, who had seated himself quietly, started up.
Title:  
Title:  "SHE!  What she?"  asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Why, my companion.  She who out of friendship for me wished to take me
Title:  from my persecutors.  She who, mistaking you for the cardinal's Guards,
Title:  has just fled away."
Title:  
Title:  "Your companion!"  cried d'Artagnan, becoming more pale than the white
Title:  veil of his mistress.  "Of what companion are you speaking, dear
Title:  Constance?"
Title:  
Title:  "Of her whose carriage was at the gate; of a woman who calls herself

Title:  
Title:  "Her name, her name!"  cried d'Artagnan.  "My God, can you not remember
Title:  her name?"
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, it was pronounced in my hearing once.  Stop--but--it is very
Title:  strange--oh, my God, my head swims!  I cannot see!"
Title:  
Title:  "Help, help, my friends!  her hands are icy cold," cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  "She is ill!  Great God, she is losing her senses!"
Title:  
Title:  While Porthos was calling for help with all the power of his strong
Title:  voice, Aramis ran to the table to get a glass of water; but he stopped

Title:  countenance of Athos, who, standing before the table, his hair rising
Title:  from his head, his eyes fixed in stupor, was looking at one of the

Title:  
Title:  "Oh!"  said Athos, "oh, no, it is impossible!  God would not permit such
Title:  a crime!"
Title:  
Title:  "Water, water!"  cried d'Artagnan.  "Water!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, poor woman, poor woman!"  murmured Athos, in a broken voice.
Title:  
Title:  Mme. Bonacieux opened her eyes under the kisses of d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "She revives!"  cried the young man.  "Oh, my God, my God, I thank
Title:  thee!"
Title:  
Title:  "Madame!"  said Athos, "madame, in the name of heaven, whose empty glass

Title:  
Title:  "Mine, monsieur," said the young woman, in a dying voice.
Title:  
Title:  "But who poured the wine for you that was in this glass?"
Title:  
Title:  "She."
Title:  
Title:  "But who is SHE?"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I remember!"  said Mme. Bonacieux, "the Comtesse de Winter."
Title:  
Title:  The four friends uttered one and the same cry, but that of Athos
Title:  dominated all the rest.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment the countenance of Mme. Bonacieux became livid; a fearful

Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan seized the hands of Athos with an anguish difficult to be

Title:  
Title:  "And what do you believe?'  His voice was stifled by sobs.
Title:  
Title:  "I believe everything," said Athos biting his lips till the blood sprang

Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan, d'Artagnan!"  cried Mme. Bonacieux, "where art thou?  Do

Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan released the hands of Athos which he still held clasped in
Title:  both his own, and hastened to her.  Her beautiful face was distorted

Title:  "In the name of heaven, run, call!  Aramis!  Porthos!  Call for help!"
Title:  
Title:  "Useless!"  said Athos, "useless!  For the poison which SHE pours there
Title:  is no antidote."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, yes!  Help, help!"  murmured Mme. Bonacieux; "help!"
Title:  
Title:  Then, collecting all her strength, she took the head of the young man
Title:  between her hands, looked at him for an instant as if her whole soul
Title:  passed into that look, and with a sobbing cry pressed her lips to his.

Title:  "Constance, Constance!"  cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  A sigh escaped from the mouth of Mme. Bonacieux, and dwelt for an

Title:  and so loving, which reascended to heaven.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan pressed nothing but a corpse in his arms.  The young man
Title:  uttered a cry, and fell by the side of his mistress as pale and as icy
