Title:  
Title:  Porthos wept; Aramis pointed toward heaven; Athos made the sign of the
Title:  cross.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment a man appeared in the doorway, almost as pale as those in
Title:  the chamber.  He looked around him and saw Mme. Bonacieux dead, and
Title:  d'Artagnan in a swoon.  He appeared just at that moment of stupor which
Title:  follows great catastrophes.
Title:  
Title:  "I was not deceived," said he; "here is Monsieur d'Artagnan; and you are
Title:  his friends, Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis."
Title:  
Title:  The persons whose names were thus pronounced looked at the stranger with
Title:  astonishment.  It seemed to all three that they knew him.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," resumed the newcomer, "you are, as I am, in search of a
Title:  woman who," added he, with a terrible smile, "must have passed this way,
Title:  for I see a corpse."
Title:  
Title:  The three friends remained mute--for although the voice as well as the
Title:  countenance reminded them of someone they had seen, they could not
Title:  remember under what circumstances.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," continued the stranger, "since you do not recognize a man
Title:  who probably owes his life to you twice, I must name myself.  I am Lord
Title:  de Winter, brother-in-law of THAT WOMAN."
Title:  
Title:  The three friends uttered a cry of surprise.
Title:  
Title:  Athos rose, and offering him his hand, "Be welcome, my Lord," said he,
Title:  "you are one of us."
Title:  
Title:  "I set out five hours after her from Portsmouth," said Lord de Winter.
Title:  "I arrived three hours after her at Boulogne.  I missed her by twenty
Title:  minutes at St. Omer.  Finally, at Lilliers I lost all trace of her.  I
Title:  was going about at random, inquiring of everybody, when I saw you
Title:  gallop past.  I recognized Monsieur d'Artagnan.  I called to you, but
Title:  you did not answer me; I wished to follow you, but my horse was too much
Title:  fatigued to go at the same pace with yours.  And yet it appears, in
Title:  spite of all your diligence, you have arrived too late."
Title:  
Title:  "You see!"  said Athos, pointing to Mme. Bonacieux dead, and to
Title:  d'Artagnan, whom Porthos and Aramis were trying to recall to life.
Title:  
Title:  "Are they both dead?"  asked Lord de Winter, sternly.
Title:  
Title:  "No," replied Athos, "fortunately Monsieur d'Artagnan has only fainted."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, indeed, so much the better!"  said Lord de Winter.
Title:  
Title:  At that moment d'Artagnan opened his eyes.  He tore himself from the
Title:  arms of Porthos and Aramis, and threw himself like a madman on the
Title:  corpse of his mistress.
Title:  
Title:  Athos rose, walked toward his friend with a slow and solemn step,
Title:  embraced him tenderly, and as he burst into violent sobs, he said to him
Title:  with his noble and persuasive voice, "Friend, be a man!  Women weep for
Title:  the dead; men avenge them!"
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, yes!"  cried d'Artagnan, "yes!  If it be to avenge her, I am ready
Title:  to follow you."
Title:  
Title:  Athos profited by this moment of strength which the hope of vengeance
Title:  restored to his unfortunate friend to make a sign to Porthos and Aramis
Title:  to go and fetch the superior.
Title:  
Title:  The two friends met her in the corridor, greatly troubled and much upset
Title:  by such strange events; she called some of the nuns, who against all
Title:  monastic custom found themselves in the presence of five men.
Title:  
Title:  "Madame," said Athos, passing his arm under that of d'Artagnan, "we
Title:  abandon to your pious care the body of that unfortunate woman.  She was
Title:  an angel on earth before being an angel in heaven.  Treat her as one of
Title:  your sisters.  We will return someday to pray over her grave."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan concealed his face in the bosom of Athos, and sobbed aloud.
Title:  
Title:  "Weep," said Athos, "weep, heart full of love, youth, and life!  Alas,
Title:  would I could weep like you!"
Title:  
Title:  And he drew away his friend, as affectionate as a father, as consoling
Title:  as a priest, noble as a man who has suffered much.
Title:  
Title:  All five, followed by their lackeys leading their horses, took their way
Title:  to the town of Bethune, whose outskirts they perceived, and stopped
Title:  before the first inn they came to.
Title:  
Title:  "But," said d'Artagnan, "shall we not pursue that woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "Later," said Athos.  "I have measures to take."
Title:  
Title:  "She will escape us," replied the young man; "she will escape us, and it
Title:  will be your fault, Athos."
Title:  
Title:  "I will be accountable for her," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan had so much confidence in the word of his friend that he
Title:  lowered his head, and entered the inn without reply.
Title:  
Title:  Porthos and Aramis regarded each other, not understanding this assurance
Title:  of Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter believed he spoke in this manner to soothe the grief of
Title:  d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, gentlemen," said Athos, when he had ascertained there were five
Title:  chambers free in the hotel, "let everyone retire to his own apartment.
Title:  d'Artagnan needs to be alone, to weep and to sleep.  I take charge of
Title:  everything; be easy."
Title:  
Title:  "It appears, however," said Lord de Winter, "if there are any measures
Title:  to take against the countess, it concerns me; she is my sister-in-law."
Title:  
Title:  "And me," said Athos, "--she is my wife!"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan smiled--for he understood that Athos was sure of his
Title:  vengeance when he revealed such a secret.  Porthos and Aramis looked at
Title:  each other, and grew pale.  Lord de Winter thought Athos was mad.
Title:  
Title:  "Now, retire to your chambers," said Athos, "and leave me to act.  You
Title:  must perceive that in my quality of a husband this concerns me.  Only,
Title:  d'Artagnan, if you have not lost it, give me the paper which fell from
Title:  that man's hat, upon which is written the name of the village of--"
Title:  
Title:  "Ah," said d'Artagnan, "I comprehend!  that name written in her hand."
Title:  
Title:  "You see, then," said Athos, "there is a god in heaven still!"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  64  THE MAN IN THE RED CLOAK
Title:  
Title:  The despair of Athos had given place to a concentrated grief which only
Title:  rendered more lucid the brilliant mental faculties of that extraordinary
Title:  man.
Title:  
Title:  Possessed by one single thought--that of the promise he had made, and of
Title:  the responsibility he had taken--he retired last to his chamber, begged
Title:  the host to procure him a map of the province, bent over it, examined
Title:  every line traced upon it, perceived that there were four different
Title:  roads from Bethune to Armentieres, and summoned the lackeys.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet, Grimaud, Bazin, and Mousqueton presented themselves, and
Title:  received clear, positive, and serious orders from Athos.
Title:  
Title:  They must set out the next morning at daybreak, and go to Armentieres--
Title:  each by a different route.  Planchet, the most intelligent of the four,
Title:  was to follow that by which the carriage had gone upon which the four
Title:  friends had fired, and which was accompanied, as may be remembered, by
Title:  Rochefort's servant.
Title:  
Title:  Athos set the lackeys to work first because, since these men had been in
Title:  the service of himself and his friends he had discovered in each of them
Title:  different and essential qualities.  Then, lackeys who ask questions
Title:  inspire less mistrust than masters, and meet with more sympathy among
Title:  those to whom they address themselves.  Besides, Milady knew the
Title:  masters, and did not know the lackeys; on the contrary, the lackeys knew
Title:  Milady perfectly.
Title:  
Title:  All four were to meet the next day at eleven o'clock.  If they had
Title:  discovered Milady's retreat, three were to remain on guard; the fourth
Title:  was to return to Bethune in order to inform Athos and serve as a guide
Title:  to the four friends.  These arrangements made, the lackeys retired.
Title:  
Title:  Athos then arose from his chair, girded on his sword, enveloped himself
Title:  in his cloak, and left the hotel.  It was nearly ten o'clock.  At ten
Title:  o'clock in the evening, it is well known, the streets in provincial
Title:  towns are very little frequented.  Athos nevertheless was visibly
Title:  anxious to find someone of whom he could ask a question.  At length he
Title:  met a belated passenger, went up to him, and spoke a few words to him.
Title:  The man he addressed recoiled with terror, and only answered the few
Title:  words of the Musketeer by pointing.  Athos offered the man half a
Title:  pistole to accompany him, but the man refused.
Title:  
Title:  Athos then plunged into the street the man had indicated with his
Title:  finger; but arriving at four crossroads, he stopped again, visibly
Title:  embarrassed.  Nevertheless, as the crossroads offered him a better
Title:  chance than any other place of meeting somebody, he stood still.  In a
Title:  few minutes a night watch passed.  Athos repeated to him the same
Title:  question he had asked the first person he met.  The night watch evinced
Title:  the same terror, refused, in his turn, to accompany Athos, and only
Title:  pointed with his hand to the road he was to take.
Title:  
Title:  Athos walked in the direction indicated, and reached the suburb situated
Title:  at the opposite extremity of the city from that by which he and his
Title:  friends had entered it.  There he again appeared uneasy and embarrassed,
Title:  and stopped for the third time.
Title:  
Title:  Fortunately, a mendicant passed, who, coming up to Athos to ask charity,
Title:  Athos offered him half a crown to accompany him where he was going.  The
Title:  mendicant hesitated at first, but at the sight of the piece of silver
Title:  which shone in the darkness he consented, and walked on before Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Arrived at the angle of a street, he pointed to a small house, isolated,
Title:  solitary, and dismal.  Athos went toward the house, while the mendicant,
Title:  who had received his reward, left as fast as his legs could carry him.
Title:  
Title:  Athos went round the house before he could distinguish the door, amid
Title:  the red color in which the house was painted.  No light appeared through
Title:  the chinks of the shutters; no noise gave reason to believe that it was
Title:  inhabited.  It was dark and silent as the tomb.
Title:  
Title:  Three times Athos knocked without receiving an answer.  At the third
Title:  knock, however, steps were heard inside.  The door at length was opened,
Title:  and a man appeared, of high stature, pale complexion, and black hair and
Title:  beard.
Title:  
Title:  Athos and he exchanged some words in a low voice, then the tall man made
Title:  a sign to the Musketeer that he might come in.  Athos immediately
Title:  profited by the permission, and the door was closed behind him.
Title:  
Title:  The man whom Athos had come so far to seek, and whom he had found with
Title:  so much trouble, introduced him into his laboratory, where he was
Title:  engaged in fastening together with iron wire the dry bones of a
Title:  skeleton.  All the frame was adjusted except the head, which lay on the
Title:  table.
Title:  
Title:  All the rest of the furniture indicated that the dweller in this house
Title:  occupied himself with the study of natural science.  There were large
Title:  bottles filled with serpents, ticketed according to their species; dried
Title:  lizards shone like emeralds set in great squares of black wood, and
Title:  bunches of wild odoriferous herbs, doubtless possessed of virtues
Title:  unknown to common men, were fastened to the ceiling and hung down in the
Title:  corners of the apartment.  There was no family, no servant; the tall man
Title:  alone inhabited this house.
Title:  
Title:  Athos cast a cold and indifferent glance upon the objects we have
Title:  described, and at the invitation of him whom he came to seek sat down
Title:  near him.
Title:  
Title:  Then he explained to him the cause of his visit, and the service he
Title:  required of him.  But scarcely had he expressed his request when the
Title:  unknown, who remained standing before the Musketeer, drew back with
Title:  signs of terror, and refused.  Then Athos took from his pocket a small
Title:  paper, on which two lines were written, accompanied by a signature and
Title:  a seal, and presented them to him who had made too prematurely these
Title:  signs of repugnance.  The tall man had scarcely read these lines, seen
Title:  the signature, and recognized the seal, when he bowed to denote that he
Title:  had no longer any objection to make, and that he was ready to obey.
Title:  
Title:  Athos required no more.  He arose, bowed, went out, returned by the same
Title:  way he came, re-entered the hotel, and went to his apartment.
Title:  
Title:  At daybreak d'Artagnan entered the chamber, and demanded what was to be
Title:  done.
Title:  
Title:  "To wait," replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Some minutes after, the superior of the convent sent to inform the
Title:  Musketeers that the burial would take place at midday.  As to the
Title:  poisoner, they had heard no tidings of her whatever, only that she must
Title:  have made her escape through the garden, on the sand of which her
Title:  footsteps could be traced, and the door of which had been found shut.
Title:  As to the key, it had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  At the hour appointed, Lord de Winter and the four friends repaired to
Title:  the convent; the bells tolled, the chapel was open, the grating of the
Title:  choir was closed.  In the middle of the choir the body of the victim,
Title:  clothed in her novitiate dress, was exposed.  On each side of the choir
Title:  and behind the gratings opening into the convent was assembled the whole
Title:  community of the Carmelites, who listened to the divine service, and
Title:  mingled their chant with the chant of the priests, without seeing the
Title:  profane, or being seen by them.
Title:  
Title:  At the door of the chapel d'Artagnan felt his courage fall anew,
Title:  and returned to look for Athos; but Athos had disappeared.
Title:  
Title:  Faithful to his mission of vengeance, Athos had requested to be
Title:  conducted to the garden; and there upon the sand following the light
Title:  steps of this woman, who left sharp tracks wherever she went, he
Title:  advanced toward the gate which led into the wood, and causing it to be
Title:  opened, he went out into the forest.
Title:  
Title:  Then all his suspicions were confirmed; the road by which the carriage
Title:  had disappeared encircled the forest.  Athos followed the road for some
Title:  time, his eyes fixed upon the ground; slight stains of blood, which came
Title:  from the wound inflicted upon the man who accompanied the carriage as a
Title:  courier, or from one of the horses, dotted the road.  At the end of
Title:  three-quarters of a league, within fifty paces of Festubert, a larger
Title:  bloodstain appeared; the ground was trampled by horses.  Between the
Title:  forest and this accursed spot, a little behind the trampled ground, was
Title:  the same track of small feet as in the garden; the carriage had stopped
Title:  here.  At this spot Milady had come out of the wood, and entered the
Title:  carriage.
Title:  
Title:  Satisfied with this discovery which confirmed all his suspicions, Athos
Title:  returned to the hotel, and found Planchet impatiently waiting for him.
Title:  
Title:  Everything was as Athos had foreseen.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet had followed the road; like Athos, he had discovered the stains
Title:  of blood; like Athos, he had noted the spot where the horses had halted.
Title:  But he had gone farther than Athos--for at the village of Festubert,
Title:  while drinking at an inn, he had learned without needing to ask a
Title:  question that the evening before, at half-past eight, a wounded man who
Title:  accompanied a lady traveling in a post-chaise had been obliged to stop,
Title:  unable to go further.  The accident was set down to the account of
Title:  robbers, who had stopped the chaise in the wood.  The man remained in
Title:  the village; the woman had had a relay of horses, and continued her
Title:  journey.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet went in search of the postillion who had driven her, and found
Title:  him.  He   had taken the lady as far as Fromelles; and from Fromelles
Title:  she had set out for Armentieres.  Planchet took the crossroad, and by
Title:  seven o'clock in the morning he was at Armentieres.
Title:  
Title:  There was but one tavern, the Post.  Planchet went and presented himself
Title:  as a lackey out of a place, who was in search of a situation.  He had
Title:  not chatted ten minutes with the people of the tavern before he learned
Title:  that a woman had come there alone about eleven o'clock the night before,
Title:  had engaged a chamber, had sent for the master of the hotel, and told
Title:  him she desired to remain some time in the neighborhood.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet had no need to learn more.  He hastened to the rendezvous,
Title:  found the lackeys at their posts, placed them as sentinels at all the
Title:  outlets of the hotel, and came to find Athos, who had just received this
Title:  information when his friends returned.
Title:  
Title:  All their countenances were melancholy and gloomy, even the mild
Title:  countenance of Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "What is to be done?" asked d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "To wait!" replied Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Each retired to his own apartment.
Title:  
Title:  At eight o'clock in the evening Athos ordered the horses to be saddled,
Title:  and Lord de Winter and his friends notified that they must prepare for
Title:  the expedition.
Title:  
Title:  In an instant all five were ready.  Each examined his arms, and put them
Title:  in order.  Athos came down last, and found d'Artagnan already on
Title:  horseback, and growing impatient.
Title:  
Title:  "Patience!"  cried Athos; "one of our party is still wanting."
Title:  
Title:  The four horsemen looked round them with astonishment, for they sought
Title:  vainly in their minds to know who this other person could be.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment Planchet brought out Athos's house; the Musketeer leaped
Title:  lightly into the saddle.
Title:  
Title:  "Wait for me," cried he, "I will soon be back," and he set off at a
Title:  gallop.
Title:  
Title:  In a quarter of an hour he returned, accompanied by a tall man, masked,
Title:  and wrapped in a large red cloak.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter and the three Musketeers looked at one another
Title:  inquiringly.  Neither could give the others any information, for all
Title:  were ignorant who this man could be; nevertheless, they felt convinced
Title:  that all was as it should be, as it was done by the order of Athos.
Title:  
Title:  At nine o'clock, guided by Planchet, the little cavalcade set out,
Title:  taking the route the carriage had taken.
Title:  
Title:  It was a melancholy sight--that of these six men, traveling in silence,
Title:  each plunged in his own thoughts, sad as despair, gloomy as
Title:  chastisement.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  65  TRIAL
Title:  
Title:  It was a stormy and dark night; vast clouds covered the heavens,
Title:  concealing the stars; the moon would not rise till midnight.
Title:  
Title:  Occasionally, by the light of a flash of lightning which gleamed along
Title:  the horizon, the road stretched itself before them, white and solitary;
Title:  the flash extinct, all remained in darkness.
Title:  
Title:  Every minute Athos was forced to restrain d'Artagnan, constantly in
Title:  advance of the little troop, and to beg him to keep in the line, which
Title:  in an instant he again departed from.  He had but one thought--to go
Title:  forward; and he went.
Title:  
Title:  They passed in silence through the little village of Festubert, where
Title:  the wounded servant was, and then skirted the wood of Richebourg.  At
Title:  Herlier, Planchet, who led the column, turned to the left.
Title:  
Title:  Several times Lord de Winter, Porthos, or Aramis, tried to talk with the
Title:  man in the red cloak; but to every interrogation which they put to him
Title:  he bowed, without response.  The travelers then comprehended that there
Title:  must be some reason why the unknown preserved such a silence, and ceased
Title:  to address themselves to him.
Title:  
Title:  The storm increased, the flashes succeeded one another more rapidly, the
Title:  thunder began to growl, and the wind, the precursor of a hurricane,
Title:  whistled in the plumes and the hair of the horsemen.
Title:  
Title:  The cavalcade trotted on more sharply.
Title:  
Title:  A little before they came to Fromelles the storm burst.  They spread
Title:  their cloaks.  There remained three leagues to travel, and they did it
Title:  amid torrents of rain.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took off his hat, and could not be persuaded to make use of
Title:  his cloak.  He found pleasure in feeling the water trickle over his
Title:  burning brow and over his body, agitated by feverish shudders.
Title:  
Title:  The moment the little troop passed Goskal and were approaching the Port,
Title:  a man sheltered beneath a tree detached himself from the trunk with
Title:  which he had been confounded in the darkness, and advanced into the
Title:  middle of the road, putting his finger on his lips.
Title:  
Title:  Athos recognized Grimaud.
Title:  
Title:  "What's the manner?" cried Athos.  "Has she left Armentieres?"
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud made a sign in the affirmative.  D'Artagnan groaned his teeth.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, d'Artagnan!"  said Athos.  I have charged myself with this
Title:  affair.  It is for me, then, to interrogate Grimaud."
Title:  
Title:  "Where is she?"  asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud extended his hands in the direction of the Lys.  "Far from
Title:  here?" asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud showed his master his forefinger bent.
Title:  
Title:  "Alone?"  asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud made the sign yes.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said Athos, "she is alone within half a league of us, in
Title:  the direction of the river."
Title:  
Title:  "That's well," said d'Artagnan. "Lead us, Grimaud."
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud took his course across the country, and acted as guide to the
Title:  cavalcade.
Title:  
Title:  At the end of five hundred paces, more or less, they came to a rivulet,
Title:  which they forded.
Title:  
Title:  By the aid of the lightning they perceived the village of Erquinheim.
Title:  
Title:  "Is she there, Grimaud?"  asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud shook his head negatively.
Title:  
Title:  "Silence, then!"  cried Athos.
Title:  
Title:  And the troop continued their route.
Title:  
Title:  Another flash illuminated all around them.  Grimaud extended his arm,
Title:  and by the bluish splendor of the fiery serpent they distinguished a
Title:  little isolated house on the banks of the river, within a hundred paces
Title:  of a ferry.
Title:  
Title:  One window was lighted.
Title:  
Title:  "Here we are!"  said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment a man who had been crouching in a ditch jumped up and
Title:  came towards them.  It was Mousqueton.  He pointed his finger to the
Title:  lighted window.
Title:  
Title:  "She is there," said he.
Title:  
Title:  "And Bazin?"  asked Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "While I watched the window, he guarded the door."
Title:  
Title:  "Good!"  said Athos.  "You are good and faithful servants."
Title:  
Title:  Athos sprang from his horse, gave the bridle to Grimaud, and advanced
Title:  toward the window, after having made a sign to the rest of the troop to
Title:  go toward the door.
Title:  
Title:  The little house was surrounded by a low, quickset hedge, two or three
Title:  feet high.  Athos sprang over the hedge and went up to the window, which
Title:  was without shutters, but had the half-curtains closely drawn.
Title:  
Title:  He mounted the skirting stone that his eyes might look over the curtain.
Title:  
Title:  By the light of a lamp he saw a woman, wrapped in a dark mantle, seated
Title:  upon a stool near a dying fire.  Her elbows were placed upon a mean
Title:  table, and she leaned her head upon her two hands, which were white as
Title:  ivory.
Title:  
Title:  He could not distinguish her countenance, but a sinister smile passed
Title:  over the lips of Athos.  He was not deceived; it was she whom he sought.
Title:  
Title:  At this moment a horse neighed.  Milady raised her head, saw close to
Title:  the panes the pale face of Athos, and screamed.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, perceiving that she knew him, pushed the window with his knee and
Title:  hand.  The window yielded.  The squares were broken to shivers; and
Title:  Athos, like the spectre of vengeance, leaped into the room.
Title:  
Title:  Milady rushed to the door and opened it.  More pale and menacing than
Title:  Athos, d'Artagnan stood on the threshold.
Title:  
Title:  Milady recoiled, uttering a cry.  D'Artagnan, believing she might have
Title:  means of flight and fearing she should escape, drew a pistol from his
Title:  belt; but Athos raised his hand.
Title:  
Title:  "Put back that weapon, d'Artagnan!"  said he; "this woman must be tried,
Title:  not assassinated.  Wait an instant, my friend, and you shall be
Title:  satisfied.  Come in, gentlemen."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan obeyed; for Athos had the solemn voice and the powerful
Title:  gesture of a judge sent by the Lord himself.  Behind d'Artagnan entered
Title:  Porthos, Aramis, Lord de Winter, and the man in the red cloak.
Title:  
Title:  The four lackeys guarded the door and the window.
Title:  
Title:  Milady had sunk into a chair, with her hands extended, as if to conjure
Title:  this terrible apparition.  Perceiving her brother-in-law, she uttered a
Title:  terrible cry.
Title:  
Title:  "What do you want?"  screamed Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "We want," said Athos, "Charlotte Backson, who first was called Comtesse
Title:  de la Fere, and afterwards Milady de Winter, Baroness of Sheffield."
Title:  
Title:  "That is I!  that is I!"  murmured Milady, in extreme terror; "what do
Title:  you want?"
Title:  
Title:  "We wish to judge you according to your crime," said Athos; "you shall
Title:  be free to defend yourself.  Justify yourself if you can.  M.
Title:  d'Artagnan, it is for you to accuse her first."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan advanced.
Title:  
Title:  "Before God and before men," said he, "I accuse this woman of having
Title:  poisoned Constance Bonacieux, who died yesterday evening."
Title:  
Title:  He turned towards Porthos and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "We bear witness to this," said the two Musketeers, with one voice.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan continued:  "Before God and before men, I accuse this woman
Title:  of having attempted to poison me, in wine which she sent me from
Title:  Villeroy, with a forged letter, as if that wine came from my friends.
Title:  God preserved me, but a man named Brisemont died in my place."
Title:  
Title:  "We bear witness to this," said Porthos and Aramis, in the
Title:  same manner as before.
Title:  
Title:  "Before God and before men, I accuse this woman of having urged me to
Title:  the murder of the Baron de Wardes; but as no one else can attest the
Title:  truth of this accusation, I attest it myself.  I have done."  And
Title:  d'Artagnan passed to the other side of the room with Porthos and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Your turn, my Lord," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  The baron came forward.
Title:  
Title:  "Before God and before men," said he, "I accuse this woman of having
Title:  caused the assassination of the Duke of Buckingham."
Title:  
Title:  "The Duke of Buckingham assassinated!"  cried all present, with one
Title:  voice.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said the baron, "assassinated.  On receiving the warning letter
Title:  you wrote to me, I had this woman arrested, and gave her in charge to a
Title:  loyal servant.  She corrupted this man; she placed the poniard in his
Title:  hand; she made him kill the duke.  And at this moment, perhaps, Felton
Title:  is paying with his head for the crime of this fury!"
Title:  
Title:  A shudder crept through the judges at the revelation of these unknown
Title:  crimes.
Title:  
Title:  "That is not all," resumed Lord de Winter.  "My brother, who made you
Title:  his heir, died in three hours of a strange disorder which left livid
Title:  traces all over the body.  My sister, how did your husband die?"
Title:  
Title:  "Horror!"  cried Porthos and Aramis.
Title:  
Title:  "Assassin of Buckingham, assassin of Felton, assassin of my brother, I
Title:  demand justice upon you, and I swear that if it be not granted to me, I
Title:  will execute it myself."
Title:  
Title:  And Lord de Winter ranged himself by the side of d'Artagnan, leaving the
Title:  place free for another accuser.
Title:  
Title:  Milady let her head sink between her two hands, and tried to recall her
Title:  ideas, whirling in a mortal vertigo.
Title:  
Title:  "My turn," said Athos, himself trembling as the lion trembles at the
Title:  sight of the serpent--"my turn.  I married that woman when she was a
Title:  young girl; I married her in opposition to the wishes of all my family;
Title:  I gave her my wealth, I gave her my name; and one day I discovered that
Title:  this woman was branded--this woman was marked with a FLEUR-DE-LIS on her
Title:  left shoulder."
Title:  
Title:  "Oh," said Milady, raising herself, "I defy you to find any tribunal
Title:  which pronounced that infamous sentence against me.  I defy you to find
Title:  him who executed it."
Title:  
Title:  "Silence!"  said a hollow voice.  "It is for me to reply to that!"  And
Title:  the man in the red cloak came forward in his turn.
Title:  
Title:  "What man is that?  What man is that?"  cried Milady, suffocated by
Title:  terror, her hair loosening itself, and rising above her livid
Title:  countenance as if alive.
Title:  
Title:  All eyes were turned towards this man--for to all except Athos he was
Title:  unknown.
Title:  
Title:  Even Athos looked at him with as much stupefaction as the others, for he
Title:  knew not how he could in any way find himself mixed up with the horrible
Title:  drama then unfolded.
Title:  
Title:  After approaching Milady with a slow and solemn step, so that the table
Title:  alone separated them, the unknown took off his mask.
Title:  
Title:  Milady for some time examined with increasing terror that pale face,
Title:  framed with black hair and whiskers, the only expression of which was
Title:  icy impassibility.  Then she suddenly cried, "Oh, no, no!"  rising and
Title:  retreating to the very wall.  "No, no!  it is an infernal apparition!
Title:  It is not he!  Help, help!"  screamed she, turning towards the wall, as
Title:  if she would tear an opening with her hands.
Title:  
Title:  "Who are you, then?"  cried all the witnesses of this scene.
Title:  
Title:  "Ask that woman," said the man in the red cloak, "for you may plainly
Title:  see she knows me!"
Title:  
Title:  "The executioner of Lille, the executioner of Lille!"  cried Milady, a
Title:  prey to insensate terror, and clinging with her hands to the wall to
Title:  avoid falling.
Title:  
Title:  Every one drew back, and the man in the red cloak remained standing
Title:  alone in the middle of the room.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, grace, grace, pardon!" cried the wretch, falling on her knees.
Title:  
Title:  The unknown waited for silence, and then resumed, "I told you well that
Title:  she would know me.  Yes, I am the executioner of Lille, and this is my
Title:  history."
Title:  
Title:  All eyes were fixed upon this man, whose words were listened to with
Title:  anxious attention.
Title:  
Title:  "That woman was once a young girl, as beautiful as she is today.  She
Title:  was a nun in the convent of the Benedictines of Templemar.  A young
Title:  priest, with a simple and trustful heart, performed the duties of the
Title:  church of that convent.  She undertook his seduction, and succeeded; she
Title:  would have seduced a saint.
Title:  
Title:  "Their vows were sacred and irrevocable.  Their connection could not
Title:  last long without ruining both.  She prevailed upon him to leave the
Title:  country; but to leave the country, to fly together, to reach another
Title:  part of France, where they might live at ease because unknown, money was
Title:  necessary.  Neither had any.  The priest stole the sacred vases, and
Title:  sold them; but as they were preparing to escape together, they were both
Title:  arrested.
Title:  
Title:  "Eight days later she had seduced the son of the jailer, and escaped.
Title:  The young priest was condemned to ten years of imprisonment, and to be
Title:  branded.  I was executioner of the city of Lille, as this woman has
Title:  said.  I was obliged to brand the guilty one; and he, gentlemen, was my
Title:  brother!
Title:  
Title:  "I then swore that this woman who had ruined him, who was more than his
Title:  accomplice, since she had urged him to the crime, should at least share
Title:  his punishment.  I suspected where she was concealed.  I followed her, I
Title:  caught her, I bound her; and I imprinted the same disgraceful mark upon
Title:  her that I had imprinted upon my poor brother.
Title:  
Title:  "The day after my return to Lille, my brother in his turn succeeded in
Title:  making his escape; I was accused of complicity, and was condemned to
Title:  remain in his place till he should be again a prisoner.  My poor brother
Title:  was ignorant of this sentence.  He rejoined this woman; they fled
Title:  together into Berry, and there he obtained a little curacy.  This woman
Title:  passed for his sister.
Title:  
Title:  "The Lord of the estate on which the chapel of the curacy was situated
Title:  saw this pretend sister, and became enamoured of her--amorous to such a
Title:  degree that he proposed to marry her.  Then she quitted him she had
Title:  ruined for him she was destined to ruin, and became the Comtesse de la
Title:  Fere--"
Title:  
Title:  All eyes were turned towards Athos, whose real name that was, and who
Title:  made a sign with his head that all was true which the executioner had
Title:  said.
Title:  
Title:  "Then," resumed he, "mad, desperate, determined to get rid of an
Title:  existence from which she had stolen everything, honor and happiness, my
Title:  poor brother returned to Lille, and learning the sentence which had
Title:  condemned me in his place, surrendered himself, and hanged himself that
Title:  same night from the iron bar of the loophole of his prison.
Title:  
Title:  "To do justice to them who had condemned me, they kept their word.  As
Title:  soon as the identity of my brother was proved, I was set at liberty.
Title:  
Title:  "That is the crime of which I accuse her; that is the cause for which
Title:  she was branded."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur d'Artagnan," said Athos, "what is the penalty you demand
Title:  against this woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "The punishment of death," replied d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "My Lord de Winter," continued Athos, "what is the penalty you demand
Title:  against this woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "The punishment of death," replied Lord de Winter.
Title:  
Title:  "Messieurs Porthos and Aramis," repeated Athos, "you who are her judges,
Title:  what is the sentence you pronounce upon this woman?"
Title:  
Title:  "The punishment of death," replied the Musketeers, in a hollow voice.
Title:  
Title:  Milady uttered a frightful shriek, and dragged herself along several
Title:  paces upon her knees toward her judges.
Title:  
Title:  Athos stretched out his hand toward her.
Title:  
Title:  "Charlotte Backson, Comtesse de la Fere, Milady de Winter," said he,
Title:  "your crimes have wearied men on earth and God in heaven.  If you know a
Title:  prayer, say it--for you are condemned, and you shall die."
Title:  
Title:  At these words, which left no hope, Milady raised herself in all her
Title:  pride, and wished to speak; but her strength failed her.  She felt that
Title:  a powerful and implacable hand seized her by the hair, and dragged her
Title:  away as irrevocably as fatality drags humanity.  She did not, therefore,
Title:  even attempt the least resistance, and went out of the cottage.
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter, d'Artagnan, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, went out close
Title:  behind her.  The lackeys followed their masters, and the chamber was
Title:  left solitary, with its broken window, its open door, and its smoky lamp
Title:  burning sadly on the table.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  66  EXECUTION
Title:  
Title:  It was near midnight; the moon, lessened by its decline, and reddened by
Title:  the last traces of the storm, arose behind the little town of
Title:  Armentieres, which showed against its pale light the dark outline of its
Title:  houses, and the skeleton of its high belfry.  In front of them the Lys
Title:  rolled its waters like a river of molten tin; while on the other side
Title:  was a black mass of trees, profiled on a stormy sky, invaded by large
Title:  coppery clouds which created a sort of twilight amid the night.  On the
Title:  left was an old abandoned mill, with its motionless wings, from the
Title:  ruins of which an owl threw out its shrill, periodical, and monotonous
Title:  cry.  On the right and on the left of the road, which the dismal
Title:  procession pursued, appeared a few low, stunted trees, which looked like
Title:  deformed dwarfs crouching down to watch men traveling at this sinister
Title:  hour.
Title:  
Title:  From time to time a broad sheet of lightning opened the horizon in its
Title:  whole width, darted like a serpent over the black mass of trees, and
Title:  like a terrible scimitar divided the heavens and the waters into two
Title:  parts.  Not a breath of wind now disturbed the heavy atmosphere.  A
Title:  deathlike silence oppressed all nature.  The soil was humid and
Title:  glittering with the rain which had recently fallen, and the refreshed
Title:  herbs sent forth their perfume with additional energy.
Title:  
Title:  Two lackeys dragged Milady, whom each held by one arm.  The executioner
Title:  walked behind them, and Lord de Winter, d'Artagnan, Porthos, and Aramis
Title:  walked behind the executioner.  Planchet and Bazin came last.
Title:  
Title:  The two lackeys conducted Milady to the bank of the river.  Her mouth
Title:  was mute; but her eyes spoke with their inexpressible eloquence,
Title:  supplicating by turns each of those on whom she looked.
Title:  
Title:  Being a few paces in advance she whispered to the lackeys, "A thousand
Title:  pistoles to each of you, if you will assist my escape; but if you
Title:  deliver me up to your masters, I have near at hand avengers who will
Title:  make you pay dearly for my death."
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud hesitated.  Mousqueton trembled in all his members.
Title:  
Title:  Athos, who heard Milady's voice, came sharply up.  Lord de Winter did
Title:  the same.
Title:  
Title:  "Change these lackeys," said he; "she has spoken to them.  They are no
Title:  longer sure."
Title:  
Title:  Planchet and Bazin were called, and took the places of Grimaud and
Title:  Mousqueton.
Title:  
Title:  On the bank of the river the executioner approached Milady, and bound
Title:  her hands and feet.
Title:  
Title:  Then she broke the silence to cry out, "You are cowards, miserable
Title:  assassins--ten men combined to murder one woman.  Beware!  If I am not
Title:  saved I shall be avenged."
Title:  
Title:  "You are not a woman," said Athos, coldly and sternly.  "You do not
Title:  belong to the human species; you are a demon escaped from hell, whither
Title:  we send you back again."
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, you virtuous men!"  said Milady; "please to remember that he who
Title:  shall touch a hair of my head is himself an assassin."
Title:  
Title:  "The executioner may kill, without being on that account an assassin,"
Title:  said the man in the red cloak, rapping upon his immense sword.  "This is
Title:  the last judge; that is all.  NACHRICHTER, as say our neighbors, the
Title:  Germans."
Title:  
Title:  And as he bound her while saying these words, Milady uttered two or
Title:  three savage cries, which produced a strange and melancholy effect in
Title:  flying away into the night, and losing themselves in the depths of the
Title:  woods.
Title:  
Title:  "If I am guilty, if I have committed the crimes you accuse me of,"
Title:  shrieked Milady, "take me before a tribunal.  You are not judges!  You
Title:  cannot condemn me!"
Title:  
Title:  "I offered you Tyburn," said Lord de Winter.  "Why did you not accept
Title:  it?"
Title:  
Title:  "Because I am not willing to die!"  cried Milady, struggling.  "Because
Title:  I am too young to die!"
Title:  
Title:  "The woman you poisoned at Bethune was still younger than you, madame,
Title:  and yet she is dead," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I will enter a cloister; I will become a nun," said Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "You were in a cloister," said the executioner, "and you left it to ruin
Title:  my brother."
Title:  
Title:  Milady uttered a cry of terror and sank upon her knees.  The executioner
Title:  took her up in his arms and was carrying her toward the boat.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, my God!"  cried she, "my God!  are you going to drown me?"
Title:  
Title:  These cries had something so heartrending in them that M. d'Artagnan,
Title:  who had been at first the most eager in pursuit of Milady, sat down on
Title:  the stump of a tree and hung his head, covering his ears with the palms
Title:  of his hands; and yet, notwithstanding, he could still hear her cry and
Title:  threaten.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan was the youngest of all these men.  His heart failed him.
Title:  
Title:  "Oh, I cannot behold this frightful spectacle!"  said he.  "I cannot
Title:  consent that this woman should die thus!"
Title:  
Title:  Milady heard these few words and caught at a shadow of hope.
Title:  
Title:  "d'Artagnan, d'Artagnan!"  cried she; "remember that I loved you!"
Title:  
Title:  The young man rose and took a step toward her.
Title:  
Title:  But Athos rose likewise, drew his sword, and placed himself in the way.
Title:  
Title:  "If you take one step farther, d'Artagnan," said he, "we shall cross
Title:  swords together."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan sank on his knees and prayed.
Title:  
Title:  "Come," continued Athos, "executioner, do your duty."
Title:  
Title:  "Willingly, monseigneur," said the executioner; "for as I am a good
Title:  Catholic, I firmly believe I am acting justly in performing my functions
Title:  on this woman."
Title:  
Title:  "That's well."
Title:  
Title:  Athos made a step toward Milady.
Title:  
Title:  "I pardon you," said he, "the ill you have done me.  I pardon you for my
Title:  blasted future, my lost honor, my defiled love, and my salvation forever
Title:  compromised by the despair into which you have cast me.  Die in peace!"
Title:  
Title:  Lord de Winter advanced in his turn.
Title:  
Title:  "I pardon you," said he, "for the poisoning of my brother, and the
Title:  assassination of his Grace, Lord Buckingham.  I pardon you for the death
Title:  of poor Felton; I pardon you for the attempts upon my own person.  Die
Title:  in peace!"
Title:  
Title:  "And I," said M. d'Artagnan.  "Pardon me, madame, for having by a trick
Title:  unworthy of a gentleman provoked your anger; and I, in exchange, pardon
Title:  you the murder of my poor love and your cruel vengeance against me.  I
Title:  pardon you, and I weep for you.  Die in peace!"
Title:  
Title:  "I am lost!"  murmured Milady in English.  "I must die!"
Title:  
Title:  Then she arose of herself, and cast around her one of those piercing
Title:  looks which seemed to dart from an eye of flame.
Title:  
Title:  She saw nothing; she listened, and she heard nothing.
Title:  
Title:  "Where am I to die?" said she.
Title:  
Title:  "On the other bank," replied the executioner.
Title:  
Title:  Then he placed her in the boat, and as he was going to set foot in it
Title:  himself, Athos handed him a sum of silver.
Title:  
Title:  "Here," said he, "is the price of the execution, that it may be plain we
Title:  act as judges."
Title:  
Title:  "That is correct," said the executioner; "and now in her turn, let this
Title:  woman see that I am not fulfilling my trade, but my debt."
Title:  
Title:  And he threw the money into the river.
Title:  
Title:  The boat moved off toward the left-hand shore of the Lys, bearing the
Title:  guilty woman and the executioner; all the others remained on the right-
Title:  hand bank, where they fell on their knees.
Title:  
Title:  The boat glided along the ferry rope under the shadow of a pale cloud
Title:  which hung over the water at that moment.
Title:  
Title:  The troop of friends saw it gain the opposite bank; the figures were
Title:  defined like black shadows on the red-tinted horizon.
Title:  
Title:  Milady, during the passage had contrived to untie the cord which
Title:  fastened her feet.  On coming near the bank, she jumped lightly on shore
Title:  and took to flight.  But the soil was moist; on reaching the top of the
Title:  bank, she slipped and fell upon her knees.
Title:  
Title:  She was struck, no doubt, with a superstitious idea; she conceived that
Title:  heaven denied its aid, and she remained in the attitude in which she had
Title:  fallen, her head drooping and her hands clasped.
Title:  
Title:  Then they saw from the other bank the executioner raise both his arms
Title:  slowly; a moonbeam fell upon the blade of the large sword.  The two
Title:  arms fell with a sudden force; they heard the hissing of the scimitar
Title:  and the cry of the victim, then a truncated mass sank beneath the blow.
Title:  
Title:  The executioner then took off his red cloak, spread it upon the ground,
Title:  laid the body in it, threw in the head, tied all up by the four corners,
Title:  lifted it on his back, and entered the boat again.
Title:  
Title:  In the middle of the stream he stopped the boat, and suspending his
Title:  burden over the water cried in a loud voice, "Let the justice of God be
Title:  done!"  and he let the corpse drop into the depths of the waters, which
Title:  closed over it.
Title:  
Title:  Three days afterward the four Musketeers were in Paris; they had not
Title:  exceeded their leave of absence, and that same evening they went to pay
Title:  their customary visit to M. de Treville.
Title:  
Title:  "Well, gentlemen," said the brave captain, "I hope you have been well
Title:  amused during your excursion."
Title:  
Title:  "Prodigiously," replied Athos in the name of himself and his comrades.
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  67 CONCLUSION
Title:  
Title:  On the sixth of the following month the king, in compliance with the
Title:  promise he had made the cardinal to return to La Rochelle, left his
Title:  capital still in amazement at the news which began to spread itself of
Title:  Buckingham's assassination.
Title:  
Title:  Although warned that the man she had loved so much was in great danger,
Title:  the queen, when his death was announced to her, would not believe the
Title:  fact, and even imprudently exclaimed, "it is false; he has just written
Title:  to me!"
Title:  
Title:  But the next day she was obliged to believe this fatal intelligence;
Title:  Laporte, detained in England, as everyone else had been, by the orders
Title:  of Charles I, arrived, and was the bearer of the duke's dying gift to
Title:  the queen.
Title:  
Title:  The joy of the king was lively.  He did not even give himself the
Title:  trouble to dissemble, and displayed it with affectation before the
Title:  queen.  Louis XIII, like every weak mind, was wanting in generosity.
Title:  
Title:  But the king soon again became dull and indisposed; his brow was not one
Title:  of those that long remain clear.  He felt that in returning to camp he
Title:  should re-enter slavery; nevertheless, he did return.
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal was for him the fascinating serpent, and himself the bird
Title:  which flies from branch to branch without power to escape.
Title:  
Title:  The return to La Rochelle, therefore, was profoundly dull.  Our four
Title:  friends, in particular, astonished their comrades; they traveled
Title:  together, side by side, with sad eyes and heads lowered.  Athos alone
Title:  from time to time raised his expansive brow; a flash kindled in his
Title:  eyes, and a bitter smile passed over his lips, then, like his comrades,
Title:  he sank again into reverie.
Title:  
Title:  As soon as the escort arrived in a city, when they had conducted the
Title:  king to his quarters the four friends either retired to their own or to
Title:  some secluded cabaret, where they neither drank nor played; they only
Title:  conversed in a low voice, looking around attentively to see that no one
Title:  overheard them.
Title:  
Title:  One day, when the king had halted to fly the magpie, and the four
Title:  friends, according to their custom, instead of following the sport had
Title:  stopped at a cabaret on the high road, a man coming from la Rochelle on
Title:  horseback pulled up at the door to drink a glass of wine, and darted a
Title:  searching glance into the room where the four Musketeers were sitting.
Title:  
Title:  "Holloa, Monsieur d'Artagnan!"  said he, "is not that you whom I see
Title:  yonder?"
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan raised his head and uttered a cry of joy.  It was the man he
Title:  called his phantom; it was his stranger of Meung, of the Rue des
Title:  Fossoyeurs and of Arras.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan drew his sword, and sprang toward the door.
Title:  
Title:  But this time, instead of avoiding him the stranger jumped from his
Title:  horse, and advanced to meet d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, monsieur!"  said the young man, "I meet you, then, at last!  This
Title:  time you shall not escape me!"
Title:  
Title:  "Neither is it my intention, monsieur, for this time I was seeking you;
Title:  in the name of the king, I arrest you."
Title:  
Title:  "How!  what do you say?"  cried d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "I say that you must surrender your sword to me, monsieur, and that
Title:  without resistance.  This concerns your head, I warn you."
Title:  
Title:  "Who are you, then?"  demanded d'Artagnan, lowering the point of his
Title:  sword, but without yet surrendering it.
Title:  
Title:  "I am the Chevalier de Rochefort," answered the other, "the equerry of
Title:  Monsieur le Cardinal Richelieu, and I have orders to conduct you to his
Title:  Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  "We are returning to his Eminence, monsieur the Chevalier," said Athos,
Title:  advancing; "and you will please to accept the word of Monsieur
Title:  d'Artagnan that he will go straight to La Rochelle."
Title:  
Title:  "I must place him in the hands of guards who will take him into camp."
Title:  
Title:  "We will be his guards, monsieur, upon our word as gentlemen; but
Title:  likewise, upon our word as gentlemen," added Athos, knitting his brow,
Title:  "Monsieur d'Artagnan shall not leave us."
Title:  
Title:  The Chevalier de Rochefort cast a glance backward, and saw that Porthos
Title:  and Aramis had placed themselves between him and the gate; he understood
Title:  that he was completely at the mercy of these four men.
Title:  
Title:  "Gentlemen," said he, "if Monsieur d'Artagnan will surrender his sword
Title:  to me and join his word to yours, I shall be satisfied with your promise
Title:  to convey Monsieur d'Artagnan to the quarters of Monseigneur the
Title:  Cardinal."
Title:  
Title:  "You have my word, monsieur, and here is my sword."
Title:  
Title:  "This suits me the better," said Rochefort, "as I wish to continue my
Title:  journey."
Title:  
Title:  "If it is for the purpose of rejoining Milady," said Athos, coolly, "it
Title:  is useless; you will not find her."
Title:  
Title:  "What has become of her, then?"  asked Rochefort, eagerly.
Title:  
Title:  "Return to camp and you shall know."
Title:  
Title:  Rochefort remained for a moment in thought; then, as they were only a
Title:  day's journey from Surgeres, whither the cardinal was to come to meet
Title:  the king, he resolved to follow the advice of Athos and go with them.
Title:  Besides, this return offered him the advantage of watching his prisoner.
Title:  
Title:  They resumed their route.
Title:  
Title:  On the morrow, at three o'clock in the afternoon, they arrived at
Title:  Surgeres.  The cardinal there awaited Louis XIII.  The minister and the
Title:  king exchanged numerous caresses, felicitating each other upon the
Title:  fortunate chance which had freed France from the inveterate enemy who
Title:  set all Europe against her.  After which, the cardinal, who had been
Title:  informed that d'Artagnan was arrested and who was anxious to see him,
Title:  took leave of the king, inviting him to come the next day to view the
Title:  work already done upon the dyke.
Title:  
Title:  On returning in the evening to his quarters at the bridge of La Pierre,
Title:  the cardinal found, standing before the house he occupied, d'Artagnan,
Title:  without his sword, and the three Musketeers armed.
Title:  
Title:  This time, as he was well attended, he looked at them sternly, and made
Title:  a sign with his eye and hand for d'Artagnan to follow him.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan obeyed.
Title:  
Title:  "We shall wait for you, d'Artagnan," said Athos, loud enough for the
Title:  cardinal to hear him.
Title:  
Title:  His Eminence bent his brow, stopped for an instant, and then kept on his
Title:  way without uttering a single word.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan entered after the cardinal, and behind d'Artagnan the door
Title:  was guarded.
Title:  
Title:  His Eminence entered the chamber which served him as a study, and made a
Title:  sign to Rochefort to bring in the young Musketeer.
Title:  
Title:  Rochefort obeyed and retired.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan remained alone in front of the cardinal; this was his second
Title:  interview with Richelieu, and he afterward confessed that he felt well
Title:  assured it would be his last.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu remained standing, leaning against the mantelpiece; a table
Title:  was between him and d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said the cardinal, "you have been arrested by my orders."
Title:  
Title:  "So they tell me, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "Do you know why?"
Title:  
Title:  "No, monseigneur, for the only thing for which I could be arrested is
Title:  still unknown to your Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu looked steadfastly at the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Holloa!"  said he, "what does that mean?"
Title:  
Title:  "If Monseigneur will have the goodness to tell me, in the first place,
Title:  what crimes are imputed to me, I will then tell him the deeds I have
Title:  really done."
Title:  
Title:  "Crimes are imputed to you which had brought down far loftier heads than
Title:  yours, monsieur," said the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "What, monseigneur?"  said d'Artagnan, with a calmness which astonished
Title:  the cardinal himself.
Title:  
Title:  "You are charged with having corresponded with the enemies of the
Title:  kingdom; you are charged with having surprised state secrets; you are
Title:  charged with having tried to thwart the plans of your general."
Title:  
Title:  "And who charges me with this, monseigneur?"  said d'Artagnan, who had
Title:  no doubt the accusation came from Milady, "a woman branded by the
Title:  justice of the country; a woman who has espoused one man in France and
Title:  another in England; a woman who poisoned her second husband and who
Title:  attempted both to poison and assassinate me!"
Title:  
Title:  "What do you say, monsieur?"  cried the cardinal, astonished; "and of
Title:  what woman are you speaking thus?"
Title:  
Title:  "Of Milady de Winter," replied d'Artagnan, "yes, of Milady de Winter, of
Title:  whose crimes your Eminence is doubtless ignorant, since you have honored
Title:  her with your confidence."
Title:  
Title:  "Monsieur," said the cardinal, "if Milady de Winter has committed the
Title:  crimes you lay to her charge, she shall be punished."
Title:  
Title:  "She has been punished, monseigneur."
Title:  
Title:  "And who has punished her?"
Title:  
Title:  "We."
Title:  
Title:  "She is in prison?"
Title:  
Title:  "She is dead."
Title:  
Title:  "Dead!" repeated the cardinal, who could not believe what he heard,
Title:  "dead!  Did you not say she was dead?"
Title:  
Title:  "Three times she attempted to kill me, and I pardoned her; but she
Title:  murdered the woman I loved.  Then my friends and I took her, tried her,
Title:  and condemned her."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan then related the poisoning of Mme. Bonacieux in the convent
Title:  of the Carmelites at Bethune, the trial in the isolated house, and the
Title:  execution on the banks of the Lys.
Title:  
Title:  A shudder crept through the body of the cardinal, who did not shudder
Title:  readily.
Title:  
Title:  But all at once, as if undergoing the influence of an unspoken thought,
Title:  the countenance of the cardinal, till then gloomy, cleared up by
Title:  degrees, and recovered perfect serenity.
Title:  
Title:  "So," said the cardinal, in a tone that contrasted strongly with the
Title:  severity of his words, "you have constituted yourselves judges, without
Title:  remembering that they who punish without license to punish are
Title:  assassins?"
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur, I swear to you that I never for an instant had the
Title:  intention of defending my head against you.  I willingly submit to any
Title:  punishment your Eminence may please to inflict upon me.  I do not hold
Title:  life dear enough to be afraid of death."
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, I know you are a man of a stout heart, monsieur," said the
Title:  cardinal, with a voice almost affectionate; "I can therefore tell you
Title:  beforehand you shall be tried, and even condemned."
Title:  
Title:  "Another might reply to your Eminence that he had his pardon in his
Title:  pocket.  I content myself with saying:  Command, monseigneur; I am
Title:  ready."
Title:  
Title:  "Your pardon?" said Richelieu, surprised.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes, monseigneur," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "And signed by whom--by the king?"  And the cardinal pronounced these
Title:  words with a singular expression of contempt.
Title:  
Title:  "No, by your Eminence."
Title:  
Title:  "By me?  You are insane, monsieur."
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur will doubtless recognize his own handwriting."
Title:  
Title:  And d'Artagnan presented to the cardinal the precious piece of paper
Title:  which Athos had forced from Milady, and which he had given to d'Artagnan
Title:  to serve him as a safeguard.
Title:  
Title:  His Eminence took the paper, and read in a slow voice, dwelling upon
Title:  every syllable:
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  "Dec. 3, 1627
Title:  
Title:  "It is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of this
Title:  has done what he has done.
Title:  
Title:  "RICHELIEU"
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal, after having read these two lines, sank into a profound
Title:  reverie; but he did not return the paper to d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "He is meditating by what sort of punishment he shall cause me to die,"
Title:  said the Gascon to himself.  "Well, my faith!  he shall see how a
Title:  gentleman can die."
Title:  
Title:  The young Musketeer was in excellent disposition to die heroically.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu still continued thinking, rolling and unrolling the paper in
Title:  his hands.
Title:  
Title:  At length he raised his head, fixed his eagle look upon that loyal,
Title:  open, and intelligent countenance, read upon that face, furrowed with
Title:  tears, all the sufferings its possessor had endured in the course of a
Title:  month, and reflected for the third or fourth time how much there was in
Title:  that youth of twenty-one years before him, and what resources his
Title:  activity, his courage, and his shrewdness might offer to a good master.
Title:  On the other side, the crimes, the power, and the infernal genius of
Title:  Milady had more than once terrified him.  He felt something like a
Title:  secret joy at being forever relieved of this dangerous accomplice.
Title:  
Title:  Richelieu slowly tore the paper which d'Artagnan had generously
Title:  relinquished.
Title:  
Title:  "I am lost!"  said d'Artagnan to himself.  And he bowed profoundly
Title:  before the cardinal, like a man who says, "Lord, Thy will be done!"
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal approached the table, and without sitting down, wrote a few
Title:  lines upon a parchment of which two-thirds were already filled, and
Title:  affixed his seal.
Title:  
Title:  "That is my condemnation," thought d'Artagnan; "he will spare me the
Title:  ENNUI of the Bastille, or the tediousness of a trial.  That's very kind
Title:  of him."
Title:  
Title:  "Here, monsieur," said the cardinal to the young man.  "I have taken
Title:  from you one CARTE BLANCHE to give you another.  The name is wanting in
Title:  this commission; you can write it yourself."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took the paper hesitatingly and cast his eyes over it; it was
Title:  a lieutenant's commission in the Musketeers.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan fell at the feet of the cardinal.
Title:  
Title:  "Monseigneur," said he, "my life is yours; henceforth dispose of it.
Title:  But this favor which you bestow upon me I do not merit.  I have three
Title:  friends who are more meritorious and more worthy--"
Title:  
Title:  "You are a brave youth, d'Artagnan," interrupted the cardinal, tapping
Title:  him familiarly on the shoulder, charmed at having vanquished this
Title:  rebellious nature.  "Do with this commission what you will; only
Title:  remember, though the name be blank, it is to you I give it."
Title:  
Title:  "I shall never forget it," replied d'Artagnan.  "Your Eminence may be
Title:  certain of that."
Title:  
Title:  The cardinal turned and said in a loud voice, "Rochefort!"  The
Title:  chevalier, who no doubt was near the door, entered immediately.
Title:  
Title:  "Rochefort," said the cardinal, "you see Monsieur d'Artagnan.  I receive
Title:  him among the number of my friends.  Greet each other, then; and be wise
Title:  if you wish to preserve your heads."
Title:  
Title:  Rochefort and d'Artagnan coolly greeted each other with their lips; but
Title:  the cardinal was there, observing them with his vigilant eye.
Title:  
Title:  They left the chamber at the same time.
Title:  
Title:  "We shall meet again, shall we not, monsieur?"
Title:  
Title:  "When you please," said d'Artagnan.
Title:  
Title:  "An opportunity will come," replied Rochefort.
Title:  
Title:  "Hey?"  said the cardinal, opening the door.
Title:  
Title:  The two men smiled at each other, shook hands, and saluted his Eminence.
Title:  
Title:  "We were beginning to grow impatient," said Athos.
Title:  
Title:  "Here I am, my friends," replied d'Artagnan; "not only free, but in
Title:  favor."
Title:  
Title:  "Tell us about it."
Title:  
Title:  "This evening; but for the moment, let us separate."
Title:  
Title:  Accordingly, that same evening d'Artagnan repaired to the quarters of
Title:  Athos, whom he found in a fair way to empty a bottle of Spanish wine--an
Title:  occupation which he religiously accomplished every night.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related what had taken place between the cardinal and
Title:  himself, and drawing the commission from his pocket, said, "Here, my
Title:  dear Athos, this naturally belongs to you."
Title:  
Title:  Athos smiled with one of his sweet and expressive smiles.
Title:  
Title:  "Friend," said he, "for Athos this is too much; for the Comte de la Fere
Title:  it is too little.  Keep the commission; it is yours.  Alas!  you have
Title:  purchased it dearly enough."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan left Athos's chamber and went to that of Porthos.  He found
Title:  him clothed in a magnificent dress covered with splendid embroidery,
Title:  admiring himself before a glass.
Title:  
Title:  "Ah, ah!  is that you, dear friend?"  exclaimed Porthos.  "How do you
Title:  think these garments fit me?"
Title:  
Title:  "Wonderfully," said d'Artagnan; but I come to offer you a dress which
Title:  will become you still better."
Title:  
Title:  "What?"  asked Porthos.
Title:  
Title:  "That of a lieutenant of Musketeers."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan related to Porthos the substance of his interview with the
Title:  cardinal, and said, taking the commission from his pocket, "Here, my
Title:  friend, write your name upon it and become my chief."
Title:  
Title:  Porthos cast his eyes over the commission and returned it to d'Artagnan,
Title:  to the great astonishment of the young man.
Title:  
Title:  "Yes," said he, "yes, that would flatter me very much; but I should not
Title:  have time enough to enjoy the distinction.  During our expedition to
Title:  Bethune the husband of my duchess died; so, my dear, the coffer of the
Title:  defunct holding out its arms to me, I shall marry the widow.  Look here!
Title:  I was trying on my wedding suit.  Keep the lieutenancy, my dear, keep
Title:  it."
Title:  
Title:  The young man then entered the apartment of Aramis.  He found him
Title:  kneeling before a PRIEDIEU with his head leaning on an open prayer book.
Title:  
Title:  He described to him his interview with the cardinal, and said, for the
Title:  third time drawing his commission from his pocket, "You, our friend, our
Title:  intelligence, our invisible protector, accept this commission.  You have
Title:  merited it more than any of us by your wisdom and your counsels, always
Title:  followed by such happy results."
Title:  
Title:  "Alas, dear friend!"  said Aramis, "our late adventures have disgusted
Title:  me with military life.  This time my determination is irrevocably taken.
Title:  After the siege I shall enter the house of the Lazarists.  Keep the
Title:  commission, d'Artagnan; the profession of arms suits you.  You will be a
Title:  brave and adventurous captain."
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan, his eye moist with gratitude though beaming with joy, went
Title:  back to Athos, whom he found still at table contemplating the charms of
Title:  his last glass of Malaga by the light of his lamp.
Title:  
Title:  "Well," said he, "they likewise have refused me."
Title:  
Title:  "That, dear friend, is because nobody is more worthy than yourself."
Title:  
Title:  He took a quill, wrote the name of d'Artagnan in the commission, and
Title:  returned it to him.
Title:  
Title:  "I shall then have no more friends," said the young man.  "Alas!
Title:  nothing but bitter recollections."
Title:  
Title:  And he let his head sink upon his hands, while two large tears rolled
Title:  down his cheeks.
Title:  
Title:  "You are young," replied Athos; "and your bitter recollections have time
Title:  to change themselves into sweet remembrances."
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  
Title:  EPILOGUE
Title:  
Title:  La Rochelle, deprived of the assistance of the English fleet and of the
Title:  diversion promised by Buckingham, surrendered after a siege of a year.
Title:  On the twenty-eighth of October, 1628, the capitulation was signed.
Title:  
Title:  The king made his entrance into Paris on the twenty-third of December of
Title:  the same year.  He was received in triumph, as if he came from
Title:  conquering an enemy and not Frenchmen.  He entered by the Faubourg St.
Title:  Jacques, under verdant arches.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan took possession of his command.  Porthos left the service,
Title:  and in the course of the following year married Mme. Coquenard; the
Title:  coffer so much coveted contained eight hundred thousand livres.
Title:  
Title:  Mousqueton had a magnificent livery, and enjoyed the satisfaction of
Title:  which he had been ambitious all his life--that of standing behind a
Title:  gilded carriage.
Title:  
Title:  Aramis, after a journey into Lorraine, disappeared all at once, and
Title:  ceased to write to his friends; they learned at a later period through
Title:  Mme. de Chevreuse, who told it to two or three of her intimates, that,
Title:  yielding to his vocation, he had retired into a convent--only into
Title:  which, nobody knew.
Title:  
Title:  Bazin became a lay brother.
Title:  
Title:  Athos remained a Musketeer under the command of d'Artagnan till the year
Title:  1633, at which period, after a journey he made to Touraine, he also quit
Title:  the service, under the pretext of having inherited a small property in
Title:  Roussillon.
Title:  
Title:  Grimaud followed Athos.
Title:  
Title:  D'Artagnan fought three times with Rochefort, and wounded him three
Title:  times.
Title:  
Title:  "I shall probably kill you the fourth," said he to him, holding out his
Title:  hand to assist him to rise.
Title:  
Title:  "It is much better both for you and for me to stop where we are,"
Title:  answered the wounded man.  "CORBLEU--I am more your friend than you
Title:  think--for after our very first encounter, I could by saying a word to
Title:  the cardinal have had your throat cut!"
Title:  
Title:  They this time embraced heartily, and without retaining any malice.
Title:  
Title:  Planchet obtained from Rochefort the rank of sergeant in the Piedmont
Title:  regiment.
Title:  
Title:  M. Bonacieux lived on very quietly, wholly ignorant of what had become
Title:  of his wife, and caring very little about it.  One day he had the
Title:  imprudence to recall himself to the memory of the cardinal.  The
Title:  cardinal had him informed that he would provide for him so that he
Title:  should never want for anything in future.  In fact, M. Bonacieux,
Title:  having left his house at seven o'clock in the evening to go to the
Title:  Louvre, never appeared again in the Rue des Fossoyeurs; the opinion
Title:  of those who seemed to be best informed was that he was fed and
Title:  lodged in some royal castle, at the expense of his generous Eminence.
Title:

Title:  We produce about two million dollars for each hour we work.  The
Title:  time it takes us, a rather conservative estimate, is fifty hours
Title:  to get any eBook selected, entered, proofread, edited, copyright
Title:  searched and analyzed, the copyright letters written, etc.   Our
Title:  projected audience is one hundred million readers.  If the value
Title:  per text is nominally estimated at one dollar then we produce $2
Title:  million dollars per hour in 2002 as we release over 100 new text
Title:  files per month:  1240 more eBooks in 2001 for a total of 4000+
Title:  We are already on our way to trying for 2000 more eBooks in 2002
Title:  If they reach just 1-2% of the world's population then the total
Title:  will reach over half a trillion eBooks given away by year's end.
Title:  
Title:  The Goal of Project Gutenberg is to Give Away 1 Trillion eBooks!
Title:  This is ten thousand titles each to one hundred million readers,
Title:  which is only about 4% of the present number of computer users.
Title:
